original: Namo tassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: namaḥ tassa bhagavataḥ arahataḥ sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Homage to that Blessed One, perfected one, fully awakened Buddha.

original: Vinayapiṭake
analyzed: vinaya piṭake
translated: In the Vinaya Piṭaka

original: Sāratthadīpanī-ṭīkā (paṭhamo bhāgo)
analyzed: sāratthadīpanī ṭīkā paṭhamaḥ bhāgaḥ
translated: The Commentary on the Essence of the Meaning (First Part)

original: Ganthārambhakathā
analyzed: gantha ārambha kathā
translated: Introduction to the Text

original: Mahākāruṇikaṃ buddhaṃ, dhammañca vimalaṃ varaṃ;
analyzed: mahā kāruṇikam buddham dhammañca vimalam varam
translated: The Buddha, who has great compassion, and the supreme, stainless Dhamma,

original: Vande ariyasaṅghañca, dakkhiṇeyyaṃ niraṅgaṇaṃ.
analyzed: vande ariya saṅghañca dakkhiṇeyyam niraṅgaṇam
translated: I pay homage to the noble Saṅgha, worthy of offerings, free from defilements.

original: Uḷārapuññatejena, katvā sattuvimaddanaṃ;🔽Pattarajjābhisekena, sāsanujjotanatthinā.
analyzed: uḷāra puñña tejena katvā sattu vimaddanam  patta rajja abhisekena sāsana ujjotanatthinā
translated: Having made the earth tremble with the splendor of his vast merit,🔽With the consecration of his royal lineage, for the sake of illuminating the Dispensation,

original: Nissāya sīhaḷindena, yaṃ parakkamabāhunā;
analyzed: nissāya sīhaḷindena yam parakkama bāhunā
translated: Relying on the Lion King, Parakkamabāhu,

original: Katvā nikāyasāmaggiṃ, sāsanaṃ suvisodhitaṃ.🔽Kassapaṃ taṃ mahātheraṃ, saṅghassa pariṇāyakaṃ;
analyzed: katvā nikāya sāmaggim sa āsanam su visodhitam  kassapam tam mahā theram saṅghassa pariṇāyakam
translated: Having brought about unity among the sects, he thoroughly purified the Dispensation.🔽That great elder Kassapa, the guide of the Saṅgha,

original: Dīpasmiṃ tambapaṇṇimhi, sāsanodayakārakaṃ.
analyzed: dīpasmim tamba paṇṇimhi sa āsana udaya kārakam
translated: The one who caused the rise of the Dispensation on the island of Sri Lanka,

original: Paṭipattiparādhīnaṃ, sadāraññanivāsinaṃ;
analyzed: paṭipatti para adhīnam sa dārañña nivāsinam
translated: Devoted to practice, always dwelling in the forest,

original: Pākaṭaṃ gagane canda-maṇḍalaṃ viya sāsane.
analyzed: gagane canda maṇḍalam sa āsane
translated: Like the clearly visible orb of the moon in the sky, in the Dispensation.

original: Saṅghassa pitaraṃ vande, vinaye suvisāradaṃ;
analyzed: saṅghassa pitaram vande vinaye su visāra dam
translated: I pay homage to the father of the Saṅgha, well-versed in the Vinaya,

original: Yaṃ nissāya vasantohaṃ, vuddhippattosmi sāsane.
analyzed: yam nissāya vasantaḥ aham vuddhippattaḥ asmi sāsane
translated: Relying on whom, dwelling here, I have attained growth in the Dispensation.

original: Anutheraṃ mahāpuññaṃ, sumedhaṃ sutivissutaṃ;
analyzed: anutheram mahā puññam sumedham suti vissutam
translated: The elder Mahāpuñña, well-known as Sumedha,

original: Avikhaṇḍitasīlādi-parisuddhaguṇodayaṃ.
analyzed: a vikhaṇḍita sīla ādi parisuddha guṇa udayam
translated: Whose virtue and so on are unbroken, and whose qualities are pure and arise.

original: Bahussutaṃ satimantaṃ, dantaṃ santaṃ samāhitaṃ;
analyzed: bahussutam satimantam dantam santam samāhitam
translated: Learned, mindful, restrained, peaceful, concentrated,

original: Namāmi sirasā dhīraṃ, garuṃ me gaṇavācakaṃ.
analyzed: namāmi sirasā dhīram garum me gaṇa vācakam
translated: I pay homage with my head to the wise one, my teacher, who is the expounder to the assembly.

original: Āgatāgamatakkesu, saddasatthanayaññusu;
analyzed: āgata āgama takkesu sadda sattha naya ñusu
translated: In the arguments based on the scriptures, in the systems of sound and grammar,

original: Yassantevāsibhikkhūsu, sāsanaṃ suppatiṭṭhitaṃ.🔽Vinayaṭṭhakathāyāhaṃ, līnasāratthadīpaniṃ;
analyzed: yassa antevāsi bhikkhūsu sāsanam su patiṭṭhitam  vinaya ṭṭha kathāyāḥ aham līna sārattha dīpanim
translated: In the monks who are his pupils, his Dispensation is well-established.🔽I will make a commentary on the Vinaya, which is a lamp for the hidden meaning,

original: Karissāmi suviññeyyaṃ, paripuṇṇamanākulaṃ.
analyzed: karissāmi su viññeyyam paripuṇṇam an ākulam
translated: Easy to understand, complete, and unconfused.

original: Porāṇehi kataṃ yaṃ tu, līnatthassa pakāsanaṃ;
analyzed: porāṇehi katam yam tu līna atthassa pakāsanam
translated: But what has been done by the ancients, the revealing of the hidden meaning,

original: Na taṃ sabbattha bhikkhūnaṃ, atthaṃ sādheti sabbaso.
analyzed: na tam sabbattha bhikkhūnam attham sādheti sabbaso
translated: Does not completely accomplish the purpose of all the monks everywhere.

original: Duviññeyyasabhāvāya, sīhaḷāya niruttiyā;🔽Gaṇṭhipadesvanekesu, likhitaṃ kiñci katthaci.🔽Māgadhikāya bhāsāya, ārabhitvāpi kenaci;
analyzed: du viññeyya sabhāvāya sīhaḷāya niruttiyā  gaṇṭhi padesu anekesu likhitam kiñci katthaci  māgadhikāya bhāsāya ārabhitvā api kenacid
translated: Because of the twofold nature of the Sinhalese language, which is difficult to understand,🔽In some places, some have written about the many knotty points.🔽And some have begun with the Magadha language,

original: Bhāsantarehi sammissaṃ, likhitaṃ kiñcideva ca.
analyzed: bhāsa antarehi sammissam likhitam kiñcid eva ca
translated: But have written just a little, mixed with other languages.

original: Asāraganthabhāropi, tattheva bahu dissati;
analyzed: asāra gantha bhāraḥ api tattha iva bahu dissati
translated: And there the burden of the worthless text is seen to be much,

original: Ākulañca kataṃ yattha, suviññeyyampi atthato.
analyzed: ākulam ca katam yattha su viññeyyam pi atthataḥ
translated: And what has been done is confused, even though the meaning is easy to understand.

original: Tato aparipuṇṇena, tādisenettha sabbaso;
analyzed: tatas a paripuṇṇena tādisena ittha sabbaso
translated: So here with all that is complete,🔽How will they understand the meaning,

original: Kathamatthaṃ vijānanti, nānādesanivāsino.
analyzed: katham attham vijānanti nānā desa nivāsinaḥ
translated: Those who live in various lands?🔽Then, leaving out the language,

original: Bhāsantaraṃ tato hitvā, sāramādāya sabbaso;
analyzed: bhāsa antaram tatas hitvā sāram ādāya sabbaso
translated: Taking the essence in its entirety,🔽I will make it free from confusion,

original: Anākulaṃ karissāmi, paripuṇṇavinicchayanti.
analyzed: an ākulam karissāmi
translated: Complete with the exposition.

original: Ganthārambhakathāvaṇṇanā
analyzed: gantha ārambha kathā vaṇṇanā
translated: The Explanation of the Beginning of the Text

original: Vinayasaṃvaṇṇanārambhe ratanattayaṃ namassitukāmo tassa visiṭṭhaguṇayogasandassanatthaṃ
analyzed: vinaya saṃvaṇṇana ārambhe ratanattayam namassitu kāmo tassa visiṭṭha guṇa yoga sandassana attham
translated: At the beginning of the commentary on the Vinaya, wishing to pay homage to the Three Jewels, in order to show their special qualities,

original: “yo kappakoṭīhipī”tiādimāha. Visiṭṭhaguṇayogena hi vandanārahabhāvo, vandanārahe
analyzed: yaḥ kappa koṭī hipi iti ādim āha visiṭṭha guṇa yogena hi vandanāraha bhāvaḥ vandanārahe
translated: he says “Yo kappakoṭīhipī” . For it is by possessing special qualities that one becomes worthy of homage, and homage paid to one who is worthy of homage

original: ca katā vandanā yathādhippetamatthaṃ sādheti. Ettha ca saṃvaṇṇanārambhe ratanattayapaṇāmakaraṇappayojanaṃ
analyzed: ca katā vandanā yathā adhippetam attham sādha iti ettha ca saṃvaṇṇanā ārambhe
translated: accomplishes the desired purpose. Herein, the teachers have explained in various ways the purpose of paying homage to the Three Jewels at the beginning of the commentary.

original: tattha tattha bahudhā papañcenti ācariyā. Tathā hi vaṇṇayanti –
analyzed: tattha tattha bahudhā papañcenti ācariyā tathā hi vaṇṇayanti
translated: For they comment as follows:

original: “Saṃvaṇṇanārambhe ratanattayavandanā saṃvaṇṇetabbassa dhammassa pabhavanissayavisuddhipaṭivedanatthaṃ,
analyzed: saṃvaṇṇanā ārambhe ratana taya vandanā saṃvaṇṇetabbassa dhammassa pabhava nissaya visuddhi paṭivedana attham
translated: “The homage to the Three Jewels at the beginning of the commentary is for the purpose of showing that the Dhamma, which is to be commented on, has as its support and basis the Triple Gem, which is purified by the supermundane path,

original: taṃ pana dhammasaṃvaṇṇanāsu viññūnaṃ bahumānuppādanatthaṃ, taṃ sammadeva tesaṃ uggahaṇadhāraṇādikkamaladdhabbāya🔽sammāpaṭipattiyā sabbahitasukhanipphādanatthaṃ. Atha vā maṅgalabhāvato, sabbakiriyāsu
analyzed: tam pana dhamma saṃvaṇṇanāsu viññūnam bahu māna uppādana attham tam sammat eva tesam uggahaṇa dhāraṇa ādi kama laddhabbāya  sammā paṭipattiyā sabba hita sukha nipphādana attham atha vā maṅgala bhāvataḥ sabba kiriyāsu
translated: But that is done in order to generate in the wise a sense of the value of the Dhamma, and in order to bring about the welfare of all beings by the attainment of the goal of the Dhamma through its proper study, retention, etc.

original: pubbakiccabhāvato, paṇḍitehi samācaritabhāvato, āyatiṃ paresaṃ diṭṭhānugatiāpajjanato
analyzed: pubba kicca bhāvataḥ paṇḍitehi samācarita bhāvataḥ āyatim paresam diṭṭha anugati āpajjanato
translated: Or else, it is done because the Three Jewels are auspicious, because they are the preliminary to all undertakings, because they are the practice of the wise, and because it leads others to follow one’s example.

original: ca saṃvaṇṇanāyaṃ ratanattayapaṇāmakiriyā”ti.🔽Mayaṃ pana idhādhippetameva payojanaṃ dassayissāma. Tasmā saṃvaṇṇanārambhe ratanattayapaṇāmakaraṇaṃ
analyzed: ca saṃvaṇṇanā ayam  mayam pana idha adhippetam eva payojanam dassayissāma tasmai saṃvaṇṇanā ārambhe
translated: “The homage to the Three Jewels at the beginning of the exposition is done for these reasons.”🔽But we shall point out here only the purpose intended by the author of the commentary. Therefore the homage to the Three Jewels at the beginning of the exposition should be understood as done

original: yathāpaṭiññātasaṃvaṇṇanāya anantarāyena parisamāpanatthanti veditabbaṃ. Idameva hi
analyzed: yathā paṭiññāta saṃvaṇṇanāya anantarāyena parisamāpana atthan ti veditabbam idam eva hi
translated: in order to ensure the completion of the exposition without interruption, in accordance with the promise. For this is the purpose

original: payojanaṃ ācariyena idhādhippetaṃ. Tathā hi vakkhati –
analyzed: payojanam ācariyena idha adhippetam tathā hi vakkhati
translated: intended by the author of the commentary. For he says:

original: “Iccevamaccantanamassaneyyaṃ,
analyzed: icca ivam accantana massaneyyam
translated: “Thus by paying homage to the Three Jewels,

original: Namassamāno ratanattayaṃ yaṃ;
analyzed: namassamānaḥ ratanattayam yam
translated: Which are worthy of such reverence,

original: Puññābhisandaṃ vipulaṃ alatthaṃ,
analyzed: puñña abhisandam vipulam alattham
translated: I have gained abundant merit;

original: Tassānubhāvena hatantarāyo”ti.
analyzed: tassa anubhāvena
translated: By its power may all obstacles cease.”

original: Ratanattayapaṇāmakaraṇena cettha yathāpaṭiññātasaṃvaṇṇanāya anantarāyena parisamāpanaṃ
analyzed: ca ittha yathā paṭiññāta saṃvaṇṇanāya anantarāyena parisamāpanam
translated: The purification of his understanding by the veneration of the Triple Gem is the next condition for the successful completion of the practice without hindrance, in accordance with the promise.

original: ratanattayapūjāya paññāpāṭavabhāvato, tāya paññāpāṭavañca rāgādimalavidhamanato. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: paññāpāṭava bhāvato tāya paññāpāṭavam ca rāga ādi mala vidhamanataḥ vuttam ha etam
translated: The veneration of the Triple Gem is the cause for the purification of understanding by the development of the faculty of wisdom. And the development of the faculty of wisdom is the cause for the removal of the defilements of lust, etc.

original: “Yasmiṃ, mahānāma, samaye ariyasāvako tathāgataṃ anussarati, nevassa tasmiṃ samaye
analyzed: yasmin mahānāma samaye ariya sāvakaḥ tathāgatam anussarati na iva assa tasmin samaye
translated: For this is said: “Mahānāma, when a noble disciple recollects the Tathāgata …🔽on that occasion his mind is not obsessed by lust,

original: rāgapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na dosapariyuṭṭhitaṃ cittaṃ hoti, na mohapariyuṭṭhitaṃ
analyzed: rāga pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti na dosa pariyuṭṭhitam cittam hoti na moha pariyuṭṭhitam
translated: hatred, or delusion;

original: cittaṃ hoti, ujugatamevassa tasmiṃ samaye cittaṃ hotī”tiādi.
analyzed: cittam hoti uju gatam eva assa tasmin samaye cittam hoti itiādi
translated: on that occasion his mind is simply straight. ”

original: Tasmā ratanattayapūjanena vikkhālitamalāya paññāya pāṭavasiddhi.
analyzed: tasmai vikkhālita malāya paññāya pāṭava siddhi
translated: Thus the veneration of the Triple Gem is the cause for the purification of understanding by the development of the faculty of wisdom.

original: Atha vā ratanattayapūjanassa paññāpadaṭṭhānasamādhihetuttā paññāpāṭavaṃ. Vuttañhi tassa samādhihetuttaṃ –
analyzed: atha vā ratanattaya pūjanassa paññā padaṭṭhāna samādhi hetu ttā paññā pāṭavam vuttam hi tassa samādhi hetu ttam
translated: Or alternatively, the veneration of the Triple Gem is the cause for the purification of understanding by the development of the faculty of wisdom because it is the cause for the concentration that is the basis for the faculty of wisdom. For this is said to be the cause for concentration:

original: “Evaṃ ujugatacitto kho, mahānāma, ariyasāvako labhati atthavedaṃ, labhati dhammavedaṃ,
analyzed: evam uju gata cittaḥ kho mahā nāma ariya sāvakaḥ labhati attha vedam labhati dhamma vedam
translated: “Mahānāma, when a noble disciple recollects the Tathāgata in this way, on that occasion his mind is not obsessed by lust, hatred, or delusion;

original: labhati dhammūpasaṃhitaṃ pāmojjaṃ, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati,
analyzed: labhati dhamma upasaṃhitam pāmojjam pamuditassa pīti jāyati pīti manassa kāyo passambhati
translated: He gains gladness connected with the Dhamma. When he is glad, rapture arises in him. When the mind is uplifted by rapture the body becomes tranquil.

original: passaddhakāyo sukhaṃ vediyati, sukhino cittaṃ samādhiyatī”ti.
analyzed: passaddha kāyaḥ sukham vediyati sukhinaḥ cittam samādhiyati iti
translated: When he is tranquil in body and mind, he feels bliss. And when he is blissful, the mind becomes concentrated. ”

original: Samādhissa ca paññāya padaṭṭhānabhāvo vuttoyeva “samāhito yathābhūtaṃ pajānātī”ti.
analyzed: samādhissa ca paññāya padaṭṭhāna bhāvo vuttaḥ yā iva samāhitaḥ yathābhūtam pajānāti iti
translated: And the footing for concentration and understanding has already been stated thus: “One who is concentrated knows and sees correctly” .

original: Tato evaṃ paṭubhūtāya paññāya paṭiññāmahattakataṃ khedamabhibhuyya anantarāyena saṃvaṇṇanaṃ
analyzed: tatas evam paṭu bhūtāya paññāya paṭiññā mahatta katam khedam abhibhuyya anantarāyena saṃvaṇṇanam
translated: So when understanding has become keen in this way, he will surmount the fatigue by the strength of his resolution and will complete the recitation without interruption.

original: samāpayissati. Tena vuttaṃ “anantarāyena parisamāpanattha”nti.
analyzed: samāpayissati tena vuttam anantarāyena parisamāpana atthan ti
translated: That is why it is said that the purpose of the recitation is “to complete it without interruption. ”

original: Atha vā ratanattayapūjāya āyuvaṇṇasukhabalavaḍḍhanato anantarāyena parisamāpanaṃ veditabbaṃ. Ratanattayapaṇāmena hi āyuvaṇṇasukhabalāni vaḍḍhanti. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: atha vā ratana taya pūjāya āyu vaṇṇa sukha bala vaḍḍhanataḥ anantarāyena parisamāpanam veditabbam ratana taya paṇāmena hi āyu vaṇṇa sukha balāni vaḍḍhanti vuttam ha etam
translated: Or alternatively, the completion without interruption should be understood as the increase of life, beauty, happiness, strength, and so on, through paying homage to the Three Jewels. For by paying homage to the Three Jewels life, beauty, happiness, and strength increase. For this is said:🔽“For one who is polite and humble,

original: “Abhivādanasīlissa, niccaṃ vuḍḍhāpacāyino;
analyzed: abhivādana sīlissa niccam vuḍḍha apacāyinaḥ
translated: Who always respects the elders,🔽Four things increase:

original: Cattāro dhammā vaḍḍhanti, āyu vaṇṇo sukhaṃ bala”nti. ;
analyzed: cattāro dhammā vaḍḍhanti āyu vaṇṇo sukham
translated: Life, beauty, happiness, and strength” .

original: Tato āyuvaṇṇasukhabalavuḍḍhiyā hoteva kāriyaniṭṭhānamiti vuttaṃ “anantarāyena parisamāpanattha”nti.
analyzed: tatas āyu vaṇṇa sukha bala vuḍḍhiyā hotā iva kāriya niṭṭhānam iti vuttam anantarāyena parisamāpana attham ti
translated: Then, since it is certain that there will be increase of life, beauty, happiness, and strength, it is said that the purpose is “to bring the undertaking to completion without interruption.”

original: Atha vā ratanattayagāravassa paṭibhānāparihānāvahattā. Aparihānāvahañhi tīsupi ratanesu gāravaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: atha vā ratana ttaya gāravassa paṭibhāna a parihāna āvaha tā a parihāna āvahan hi tīsu pi ratanesu gāravam vuttam ha etam
translated: Or alternatively, it is because of the non-abandonment of the inspiration that has respect for the Triple Gem. For the non-abandonment of the inspiration is the respect for the three gems. For this is said:

original: “Sattime, bhikkhave, aparihāniyā dhammā. Katame satta? Satthugāravatā dhammagāravatā saṅghagāravatā sikkhāgāravatā samādhigāravatā kalyāṇamittatā sovacassatā”ti.
analyzed: sattime bhikkhave aparihāniyāḥ dhammāḥ katame satta satthu gāravatā dhamma gāravatā saṅgha gāravatā sikkhā gāravatā samādhi gāravatā kalyāṇa mitta tā sovacassatā ati
translated: “Bhikkhus, there are these seven things that are not to be abandoned. What seven? Respect for the Teacher, respect for the Dhamma, respect for the Sangha, respect for the training, respect for concentration, having good friends, being easy to admonish. ”

original: Hoteva ca tato paṭibhānāparihānena yathāpaṭiññātaparisamāpanaṃ.
analyzed: hotā iva ca tatas paṭibhāna a parihānena yathā paṭiññāta parisamāpanam
translated: And it is certain that the undertaking will be brought to completion without the abandonment of the inspiration.

original: Atha vā pasādavatthūsu pūjāya puññātisayabhāvato. Vuttañhi tassa puññātisayattaṃ –
analyzed: atha vā pasāda vatthūsu pūjāya puñña atisaya bhāvataḥ vuttam hi tassa puñña atisaya ttam
translated: Or alternatively, it is because of the abundance of merit in the act of worship among the bases for the manifestation of confidence. For the abundance of merit in that act of worship is stated thus:🔽“When one who is worthy of worship is worshipped,

original: “Pūjārahe pūjayato, buddhe yadiva sāvake;🔽Papañcasamatikkante, tiṇṇasokapariddave.
analyzed: pūjā rahe pūjayataḥ buddhe yat iva sāvake  papañca sama tikkante tiṇṇa soka pariddave
translated: The Enlightened One and his disciples,🔽Who have overcome the tangle,

original: “Te tādise pūjayato, nibbute akutobhaye;
analyzed: te tādise pūjayataḥ nibbute akutobhaye
translated: And crossed over sorrow’s flood,🔽When one who is worthy of worship is worshipped,

original: Na sakkā puññaṃ saṅkhātuṃ, imettamapi kenacī”ti. ;
analyzed: na sakkā puññam saṅkhātum kenaci iti
translated: The merit cannot be reckoned by anyone. ”

original: Puññātisayo ca yathādhippetaparisamāpanupāyo. Yathāha –
analyzed: puñña atisayaḥ ca yathā adhippeta parisamāpan upāyaḥ yathā āha
translated: and the means of attaining the highest merit as intended. As it is said:

original: “Esa devamanussānaṃ, sabbakāmadado nidhi;
analyzed: esa deva manussānam sabba kāma dadaḥ nidhi
translated: “This is the treasure of gods and men,🔽the fulfiller of all wishes,

original: Yaṃ yadevābhipatthenti, sabbametena labbhatī”ti. ;
analyzed: yam yat eva abhipatthenti sabbam etena labbhati iti
translated: by which whatever is desired is obtained.”

original: Upāyesu ca paṭipannassa hoteva kāriyaniṭṭhānaṃ. Ratanattayapūjā hi niratisayapuññakkhettasaṃbuddhiyā🔽aparimeyyappabhavo puññātisayoti bahuvidhantarāyepi lokasannivāse antarāyanibandhanasakalasaṃkilesaviddhaṃsanāya
analyzed: upāyesu ca paṭipannassa hotā iva kāriya niṭṭhānam ratanattaya pūjā hi niratisaya puñña kkhetta saṃbuddhiyā  aparimeyya pabhavo puññātisayo ti bahuvidha antarāye pi loka sannivāse antarāya nibandhana sakala saṃkilesa viddhaṃsanāya
translated: And when one is engaged in the means, one’s purpose is accomplished. For the worship of the Triple Gem is the supreme field of merit for the production of immeasurable and unsurpassed merit.

original: pahoti, bhayādiupaddavañca nivāreti. Tasmā suvuttaṃ “saṃvaṇṇanārambhe ratanattayapaṇāmakaraṇaṃ
analyzed: bhaya ādi upaddavam ca nivāreti tasmā su vuttam saṃvaṇṇanā ārambhe
translated: It is able to destroy all defilements, which are the cause of obstacles in the world, even in the face of many obstacles. And it prevents the occurrence of danger and other misfortunes. Therefore it is rightly said that the homage to the Triple Gem at the beginning of the commentary is for the purpose of

original: yathāpaṭiññātasaṃvaṇṇanāya anantarāyena parisamāpanatthanti veditabba”nti.
analyzed: yathā paṭiññāta saṃvaṇṇanāya anantarāyena parisamāpana atthanti veditabbanti
translated: making known the commentary as promised without hindrance.

original: Evaṃ pana sappayojanaṃ ratanattayavandanaṃ kattukāmo paṭhamaṃ tāva bhagavato vandanaṃ
analyzed: evam pana sa payojanam rata nattaya vandanam kattu kāmo paṭhamam tāva bhagavataḥ vandanam
translated: One who wishes to pay homage to the Triple Gem in this way, which is meaningful, should first pay homage to the Blessed One.

original: kātuṃ tammūlakattā sesaratanānaṃ “yo kappa…pe… mahākāruṇikassa tassā”ti āha. Ettha
analyzed: kātum sesa ratanānam yaḥ mahā kāruṇikassa tassa iti āha ettha
translated: and the rest of the jewels are rooted in that, he said: ‘The one who, for an aeon … the Greatly Compassionate One, his’.

original: pana yassā desanāya saṃvaṇṇanaṃ kattukāmo, sā yasmā karuṇāppadhānā, na suttantadesanā
analyzed: pana yassā desanāya saṃvaṇṇanam kattu kāmo sā yasmā karuṇā ppadhānā na suttanta desanā
translated: Herein, the one whose teaching he wanted to extol is the Great Compassionate One, not the one who teaches the Suttas, who does so with compassion as his chief characteristic,

original: viya karuṇāpaññāppadhānā, nāpi abhidhammadesanā viya paññāppadhānā, tasmā karuṇāppadhānameva
analyzed: viya karuṇā paññā appadhānā nā api abhidhamma desanā viya paññā appadhānā tasmā karuṇā ppadhānam eva
translated: nor the one who teaches the Abhidhamma, who does so with understanding as his chief characteristic. So he extolled the Blessed One’s compassion as his chief characteristic.

original: bhagavato thomanaṃ āraddhaṃ. Esā hi ācariyassa pakati, yadidaṃ ārambhānurūpathomanā.🔽Teneva suttantadesanāya saṃvaṇṇanārambhe “karuṇāsītalahadayaṃ, paññāpajjotavihatamohatama”nti🔽karuṇāpaññāppadhānaṃ, abhidhammadesanāya saṃvaṇṇanārambhe “karuṇā viya sattesu, paññā
analyzed: bhagavato thomanam āraddham esā hi ācariyassa pakati yat idam ārambha anurūpa thomanā  tena iva suttanta desanāya saṃvaṇṇanā ārambhe karuṇā sīta lahadayam  karuṇā paññā appadhānam abhidhamma desanāya saṃvaṇṇanā ārambhe karuṇā viya sattesu paññā
translated: This is the teacher’s own nature, namely, that he extols what is appropriate to the beginning.🔽That is why, when he began to extol the teaching of the Suttas, he said: ‘Whose heart is cool with compassion, Whose darkness of delusion is dispelled by the light of understanding’ ,🔽and when he began to extol the teaching of the Abhidhamma, he said: ‘Whose understanding, like his compassion, For beings is so great’ .

original: yassa mahesino”ti paññāppadhānañca thomanaṃ āraddhaṃ. Karuṇāpaññāppadhānā hi suttantadesanā
analyzed: yassa mahesino ti paññā appadhānam ca thomanam āraddham karuṇā paññā appadhānā hi suttanta desanā
translated: For the teaching of the Suttas is characterized by compassion and understanding,

original: tesaṃ tesaṃ sattānaṃ āsayānusayādhimutticariyādibhedaparicchindanasamatthāya paññāya🔽sattesu ca mahākaruṇāya tattha sātisayappavattito. Suttantadesanāya hi mahākaruṇāsamāpattibahulo
analyzed: tesam tesam sattānam āsaya anusaya adhimutti cariyā ādi bheda paricchindana samatthāya paññāya  sattesu ca mahā karuṇāya tattha sa atisaya ppavattito suttanta desanāya hi mahā karuṇā samāpatti bahulaḥ
translated: and to the understanding that is able to discern the various dispositions, latent tendencies, inclinations, and practices of the various beings,

original: veneyyasantānesu tadajjhāsayānulomena gambhīramatthapadaṃ patiṭṭhāpesi. Abhidhammadesanā
analyzed: veneyya santānesu tad ajjhāsayā anulomena gambhīram attha padam patiṭṭhāpesi abhidhamma desanā
translated: and to the great compassion for beings, which is the reason for its occurrence in such abundance in the case of the Buddha. For the Buddha is rich in the attainment of great compassion, and he establishes the profound meaning in the minds of his disciples in accordance with their dispositions.

original: ca kevalaṃ paññāppadhānā paramatthadhammānaṃ yathāsabhāvapaṭivedhasamatthāya paññāya🔽tattha sātisayappavattito.🔽Vinayadesanā pana āsayādinirapekkhaṃ kevalaṃ karuṇāya pākatikasattenapi asotabbārahaṃ🔽suṇanto apucchitabbārahaṃ pucchanto avattabbārahañca vadanto bhagavā sikkhāpadaṃ
analyzed: ca kevalam paññā appadhānā paramattha dhammānam yathā sabhāva paṭivedha samatthāya paññāya  tattha sa atisaya ppavattitaḥ  vinaya desanā pana āsaya ādi nirapekkham kevalam karuṇāya pākatika sattena api a sotabba araham  suṇantaḥ a pucchitabba āraham pucchantaḥ a vattabba āraham ca vadantaḥ bhagavā sikkhāpadam
translated: The teaching of the Abhidhamma is based on understanding, which is able to penetrate the ultimate realities in accordance with their true nature,🔽and to the understanding that is the reason for its occurrence in such abundance in the case of the Buddha.🔽The teaching of the Vinaya is based on compassion, which is indifferent to dispositions, etc., and which makes the Buddha teach the training rules to the ordinary person, who is not worthy to hear them,

original: paññapesīti karuṇāppadhānā. Tathā hi ukkaṃsapariyantagatahirottappopi bhagavā lokiyasādhujanehipi
analyzed: paññapesi iti karuṇā appadhānā tathā hi bhagavā lokiya sādhu janehi pi
translated: to ask questions about them, and to speak about them. For the Blessed One, who is endowed with a sense of shame and fear of wrongdoing to the extent of the tip of a hair, has announced the training rules🔽out of compassion for the ordinary person, who is not worthy to hear them, etc., and who is included among the “good people of the world.”

original: pariharitabbāni “sikharaṇīsī”tiādīni vacanāni yathāparādhañca garahavacanāni vinayapiṭakadesanāya
analyzed: pariharitabbāni sikharaṇīsī iti ādīni vacanāni yathāparādham ca garaha vacanāni vinaya piṭaka desanāya
translated: The words “the rule about the topknot” and so on and the words of censure according to the offence are taught in the Vinaya Piṭaka.

original: mahākaruṇāsañcoditamānaso mahāparisamajjhe abhāsi, taṃtaṃsikkhāpadapaññattikāraṇāpekkhāya🔽verañjādīsu sārīrikañca khedamanubhosi. Tasmā kiñcāpi bhūmantarapaccayākārasamayantarakathānaṃ
analyzed: mahā karuṇā sañcodita mānasaḥ mahā parisamajjhe abhāsi taṃ taṃ sikkhāpada paññatti kāraṇa apekkhāya  verañja ādīsu sārīrikam ca khedam anubhosi tasmai kiñca api
translated: He spoke in the midst of a great assembly, his mind being urged on by great compassion, and he did so in order to see the reason for the laying down of each training rule.

original: viya vinayapaññattiyāpi samuṭṭhāpikā paññā anaññasādhāraṇatāya atisayakiccavatī,🔽karuṇāya kiccaṃ pana tatopi adhikanti karuṇāppadhānā vinayadesanā. Karuṇābyāpārādhikatāya
analyzed: viya vinaya paññattiyā api samuṭṭhāpikā paññā anañña sādhāraṇa tāya atisaya kiccavatī  karuṇāya kiccam pana tatas pi adhikanti karuṇā appadhānā vinaya desanā karuṇā byāpāra adhikatāya
translated: He experienced physical weariness in such places as Verañjā. Therefore, although the understanding that originates the laying down of the training rules is, like the teaching of the various kinds of conditions, of bases, of causal relationship, and of time,🔽unique to the Buddha and so is of great service,🔽nevertheless compassion is of greater service. So the teaching of the Vinaya is dominated by compassion.

original: hi desanāya karuṇāppadhānatā. Tasmā ārambhānurūpaṃ karuṇāppadhānameva ettha thomanaṃ katanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: hi desanāya karuṇā ppadhāna tā tasmai ārambha anurūpam karuṇā ppadhānam eva ettha thomanam katanti veditabbam
translated: For the teaching is dominated by compassion because it is pervaded by compassion. Therefore the eulogy should be understood to be made in accordance with the origin, namely, “Compassion is its root,”

original: Karuṇāggahaṇena ca aparimeyyappabhāvā sabbepi buddhaguṇā saṅgahitāti daṭṭhabbā taṃmūlakattā
analyzed: karuṇā ggahaṇena ca aparimeyya ppabhāvā sabbe pi buddha guṇā saṅgahitā iti daṭṭhabbā tad mūlaka ttā
translated: and by the mention of compassion all the special qualities of the Buddha are included, since they have compassion as their root.

original: sesabuddhaguṇānaṃ. Mahākaruṇāya vā chasu asādhāraṇañāṇesu aññatarattā taṃsahacaritasesāsādhāraṇañāṇānampi🔽gahaṇasabbhāvato sabbepi buddhaguṇā nayato dassitāva honti. Esoyeva hi niravasesato🔽buddhaguṇānaṃ dassanupāyo yadidaṃ nayaggāho. Aññathā ko nāma samattho bhagavato guṇe
analyzed: sesa buddha guṇānam mahākaruṇāya vā chasu asādhāraṇa ñāṇesu aññatara ttā tad sahacarita sesa asādhāraṇa ñāṇānam pi  gahaṇa sabbhāvato sabbe pi buddha guṇāḥ nayataḥ dassitā ava honti hi niravasesato  buddha guṇānam dassan upāyaḥ yat idam naya ggāhaḥ aññathā kaḥ nāma samatthaḥ bhagavataḥ guṇe
translated: and the rest of the Buddha’s special qualities. Or else, since the great compassion is included in the six kinds of direct knowledge not shared by disciples, the rest of the Buddha’s special qualities that are shared with disciples are also included by implication.

original: anupadaṃ niravasesato dassetuṃ. Tenevāha –
analyzed: anupadam niravasesataḥ dassetum tena iva āha
translated: So all the Buddha’s special qualities are shown by implication. For this is the only way of showing them without omission, namely, by the method of the six kinds of direct knowledge. Otherwise, who is able to show the Blessed One’s qualities without omission and in detail? That is why it is said:

original: “Buddhopi buddhassa bhaṇeyya vaṇṇaṃ,🔽Kappampi ce aññamabhāsamāno;
analyzed: buddhaḥ api buddhassa bhaṇeyya vaṇṇam  kappam pi ce aññam a bhāsamāno
translated: “Even if the Enlightened One should speak in praise of the Enlightened One,

original: Khīyetha kappo ciradīghamantare,
analyzed: khīyetha cira dīgham antare
translated: And if he were to speak for an eon,

original: Vaṇṇo na khīyetha tathāgatassā”ti. ;🔽Teneva ca āyasmatā sāriputtattherenapi buddhaguṇaparicchedanaṃ patianuyuttena “no
analyzed: vaṇṇaḥ na khīyetha tathāgatassa ati  tena iva ca āyasmatā sāriputta ttherena api buddha guṇa paricchedanam pati anuyuttena no
translated: The eon would end but the description of the Tathāgata’s qualities would not. ”

original: hetaṃ, bhante”ti paṭikkhipitvā “apica me, bhante, dhammanvayo vidito”ti vuttaṃ. Tasmā
analyzed: ha itam bhante ti paṭikkhipitvā apica me bhante dhamma anvayaḥ viditaḥ ti vuttam tasmā
translated: And that is why the venerable Sāriputta, who was skilled in discerning the Buddha’s special qualities, replied: “No, venerable sir,” and then said: “But, venerable sir, the method of the Dhamma is known to me. ”🔽So

original: “yo kappakoṭīhipī”tiādinā karuṇāmukhena saṅkhepato sakalasabbaññuguṇehi bhagavantaṃ🔽abhitthavīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Ayamettha samudāyattho.
analyzed: yaḥ kappa koṭī hi pīti ādinā karuṇā mukhena saṅkhepato sakala sabbaññu guṇehi bhagavantam  daṭṭhabbam ayam ettha samudāya tthaḥ
translated: “Who for koṭis of kappa” etc. is the praise in brief of the Blessed One by way of his compassion, with all the qualities of the omniscient one.🔽This is the meaning of the compound.

original: Ayaṃ pana avayavattho – yoti aniyamavacanaṃ. Tassa “nātho”ti iminā sambandho. “Kappakoṭīhipī”tiādinā🔽pana yāya karuṇāya so “mahākāruṇiko”ti vuccati, tassā vasena kappakoṭigaṇanāyapi
analyzed: ayam pana avayava tthaḥ yaḥ ti aniyama vacanam tassa iminā sambandhaḥ kappa koṭī hipi iti ādinā  pana yāya so mahā kāruṇiko ti vuccati tassā vasena
translated: But the meaning of the component parts is as follows: “Yo” is a word of no particular meaning. It is connected with “nātho” .🔽But by “for koṭis of kappa” etc.🔽he shows the Blessed One’s experience of suffering for an immeasurable time by way of the compassion for which he is called “the Greatly Compassionate One” ,

original: appameyyaṃ kālaṃ lokahitatthāya atidukkaraṃ karontassa bhagavato dukkhānubhavanaṃ
analyzed: appameyyam kālam loka hita atthāya ati dukkaram karontassa bhagavato dukkha anubhavanam
translated: in the effort to bring about the welfare of the world, which is extremely difficult to do.

original: dasseti. Karuṇāya baleneva hi so bhagavā hatthagatampi nibbānaṃ pahāya saṃsārapaṅke
analyzed: dasseti karuṇāya balena iva hi so bhagavā hattha gatam pi nibbānam pahāya saṃsāra paṅke
translated: For it is only by the power of compassion that the Blessed One, having abandoned even the state of nibbāna which is in his very hand,🔽in order to rescue the multitude of beings who are sunk in the mire of saṃsāra,

original: nimuggaṃ sattanikāyaṃ tato samuddharaṇatthaṃ cintetumpi asakkuṇeyyaṃ nayanajīvitaputtabhariyadānādikaṃ
analyzed: nimuggam satta nikāyam tatas samuddharaṇa attham cintetum pi a sakkuṇeyyam nayana jīvita putta bhariya dāna ādikam
translated: did what is extremely difficult to do, such as giving away his eyes, his life, his children, his wife, etc., which is beyond the power of thought to conceive.

original: atidukkaramakāsi. Kappakoṭīhipi appameyyaṃ kālanti kappakoṭigaṇanāyapi “ettakā kappakoṭiyo”ti
analyzed: ati dukkaram akāsi kappa koṭīhi pi appameyyam kālanti kappa koṭi gaṇanāya pi ettakā kappa koṭiyā ti
translated: “For koṭis of kappa” means “for such and such koṭis of kappa.”

original: pametuṃ asakkuṇeyyaṃ kālaṃ, kappakoṭigaṇanavasenapi paricchinditumasakkuṇeyyattā
analyzed: pametum a sakkuṇeyyam kālam kappa koṭi gaṇana vasena api paricchinditum a sakkuṇeyya tā
translated: which cannot be measured, which cannot be limited even by calculation in terms of millions of eons.

original: aparicchinnāni kappasatasahassādhikāni cattāri asaṅkhyeyyānīti vuttaṃ hoti. Kappakoṭivaseneva🔽hi so kālo appameyyo, asaṅkhyeyyavasena pana paricchinnoyeva. “Kappakoṭīhipī”ti apisaddo
analyzed: aparicchinnāni kappa sata sahassa adhikāni cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni iti vuttam hoti kappa koṭi vasena iva  hi so kālaḥ appameyyaḥ asaṅkhyeyya vasena pana paricchinnaḥ yā iva kappa koṭī hipī iti api saddaḥ
translated: It is said that the time was “incalculable” because it could not be measured by the reckoning of a hundred thousand eons, or even by the reckoning of a hundred thousand koṭis of eons.🔽For that time was incalculable by the reckoning of a hundred thousand koṭis of eons, but it was limited by the reckoning of a hundred thousand eons.

original: kappakoṭivasenapi tāva pametuṃ na sakkā, pageva vassagaṇanāyāti dasseti. “Appameyyaṃ
analyzed: kappa koṭi vasena api tāva pametum na sakkā pagā iva vassa gaṇanāya ati dasseti appameyyam
translated: The word “even” in the phrase “even by the reckoning of a hundred thousand koṭis of eons” shows that it could not be measured even by the reckoning of a hundred thousand koṭis of eons, much less by the reckoning of years.

original: kāla”nti accantasaṃyoge upayogavacanaṃ “māsamadhīte, divasaṃ caratī”tiādīsu viya.
analyzed: upayoga vacanam māsam adhīte divasam carati iti ādīsu
translated: The phrase “incalculable time” is a locative absolute; it is equivalent to saying “having practiced for incalculable time.”

original: Karonto atidukkarānīti pañcamahāpariccāgādīni atidukkarāni karonto. Evamatidukkarāni🔽karonto kiṃ vindīti ce? Khedaṃ gato, kāyikaṃ khedamupagato, parissamaṃ pattoti attho,
analyzed: karontaḥ ati dukkarāni iti pañca mahāpariccāga ādīni ati dukkarāni karontaḥ evam ati dukkarāni  karontaḥ kim ce khedam gataḥ kāyikam khedam upagataḥ parissamam patto ti attho
translated: “Practicing austerities” means practicing the five austerities, etc., which are very difficult to practice.🔽If it be asked, “What did he find by practicing such difficult practices?” the answer is, “He came to suffering,” i.e., he came to physical suffering; he experienced pain.

original: dukkhamanubhavīti vuttaṃ hoti. Dukkhañhi khijjati sahitumasakkuṇeyyanti “khedo”ti
analyzed: dukkham anubhavīti vuttam hoti dukkham hi khijjati sahitum a sakkuṇeyyanti khedaḥ ti
translated: For suffering is called “kheda” because it is that which cannot be borne.

original: vuccati. Lokahitāyāti “anamatagge saṃsāre vaṭṭadukkhena accantapīḷitaṃ sattalokaṃ
analyzed: vuccati loka hitāya ati anamatagge saṃsāre vaṭṭa dukkhena accanta pīḷitam satta lokam
translated: It is said. For the welfare of the world: the world of beings is oppressed by the suffering of the round of rebirths without limit or end in the beginningless round of rebirths.

original: tamhā dukkhato mocetvā nibbānasukhabhāgiyaṃ karissāmī”ti evaṃ sattalokassa hitakaraṇatthāyāti🔽attho. Assa ca “atidukkarāni karonto”ti iminā sambandho. Lokahitāya khedaṃ gatoti🔽yojanāyapi natthi doso. Mahāgaṇṭhipadepi hi “atidukkarāni karonto khedaṃ gato, kimatthanti
analyzed: tamhā dukkhataḥ mocetvā nibbāna sukha bhāgiyam karissāmi iti evam satta lokassa hita karaṇa tthāya ati  atthaḥ assa ca ati dukkarāni karonto ti iminā sambandhaḥ loka hitāya khedam gataḥ ti  natthi dosaḥ mahāgaṇṭhi pade pi hi ati dukkarāni karontaḥ khedam gataḥ kimattha nti
translated: The meaning is that he is intent on the welfare of the world since he thinks, “I shall deliver it from that suffering and lead it to the bliss of Nibbāna.”🔽And the meaning of the words “undertaking what is hard to do” is connected with this.🔽And there is no fault in construing the words thus: “He went to the trouble for the welfare of the world.”

original: ce? Lokahitāyā”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ce loka hitāya iti vuttam
translated: For in the Mahā-Niddesa too it is said: “He went to the trouble undertaking what is hard to do. What was his purpose? The welfare of the world” .

original: Yaṃ pana evaṃ yojanaṃ asambhāventena kenaci vuttaṃ “na hi bhagavā lokahitāya saṃsāradukkhamanubhavati.
analyzed: yam pana evam yojanam asambhāventena kenacid vuttam na hi bhagavā loka hitāya saṃsāra dukkham anubhavati
translated: But someone who does not accept this construing says this: “The Blessed One does not experience the suffering of the round of rebirths for the welfare of the world.

original: Na hi kassaci dukkhānubhavanaṃ lokassa upakāraṃ āvahatī”ti, taṃ tassa matimattaṃ.
analyzed: na hi kassaci dukkha anubhavanam lokassa upakāram āvahati iti tam tassa matimattam
translated: For the experience of suffering by anyone does not bring any benefit to the world.”🔽That is just his opinion.

original: Evaṃ yojanāyapi atidukkarāni karontassa bhagavato dukkhānubhavanaṃ lokahitakaraṇatthāyāti
analyzed: evam ati dukkarāni karontassa bhagavataḥ dukkha anubhavanam loka hita karaṇa tthāya ati
translated: And even if the Blessed One’s experience of suffering by undertaking what is hard to do is construed thus, it is still for the benefit of the world.

original: ayamattho viññāyati, na tu dukkhānubhavaneneva lokahitasiddhīti. Paṭhamaṃ vuttayojanāyapi
analyzed: ayam atthaḥ viññāyati na tu dukkha anubhavanena iva loka hita siddhi iti paṭhamam vutta yojanāya api
translated: This is the meaning understood, but not that the welfare of the world is accomplished by mere suffering.🔽For even in the first interpretation,

original: hi na dukkarakaraṇamattena lokahitasiddhi. Na hi dukkaraṃ karonto kañci sattaṃ maggaphalādīsu🔽patiṭṭhāpeti, atha kho tādisaṃ atidukkaraṃ katvā sabbaññubhāvaṃ sacchikatvā niyyānikadhammadesanāya
analyzed: hi na dukkara karaṇa mattena na hi dukkaram karontaḥ kañci sattam magga phala ādīsu  patiṭṭhāpeti atha kho tādisam ati dukkaram katvā sabbaññu bhāvam sacchikatvā niyyānika dhamma desanāya
translated: the welfare of the world is not accomplished by mere doing of what is difficult. For one who does what is difficult does not establish any being in the paths, fruits, etc.,

original: maggaphalādīsu satte patiṭṭhāpento lokassa hitaṃ sādheti.🔽Kāmañcettha sattasaṅkhārabhājanavasena tividho loko, hitakaraṇassa pana adhippetattā
analyzed: magga phala ādīsu satte patiṭṭhāpentaḥ lokassa hitam sādheti  kāmam ca ittha satta saṅkhāra bhājana vasena tividhaḥ lokaḥ hita karaṇassa pana adhippeta ttā

original: taṃvisayasseva sattalokassa vasena attho gahetabbo. So hi lokīyanti ettha puññapāpāni🔽taṃvipāko cāti “loko”ti vuccati. Katthaci pana “sanarāmaralokagaru”ntiādīsu samūhatthopi

original: Nāthoti lokapaṭisaraṇo, lokasāmī lokanāyakoti vuttaṃ hoti. Tathā hi sabbānatthapaahārapubbaṅgamāya🔽niravasesahitasukhavidhānatapparāya niratisayāya payogasampattiyā sadevamanussāya🔽pajāya accantupakāritāya aparimitanirupamappabhāvaguṇavisesasamaṅgitāya ca sabbasattuttamo
analyzed: nātho ti loka paṭisaraṇaḥ loka sāmī loka nāyako ti vuttam hoti tathā hi sabba anattha paahāra pubbaṅgamāya  niravasesa hita sukha vidhāna tapparāya niratisayāya payoga sampattiyā sa deva manussāya  pajāya accantupakāritāya aparimita nirupama ppabhāva guṇa visesa samaṅgi tāya ca sabba sattuttamaḥ
translated: “Lord” means the world’s refuge, the world’s ruler, the world’s guide. For thus, with the perfection of his activity, which is foremost in abandoning all that is not good,🔽which is devoted to providing the highest, unsurpassed, and complete happiness, and which is beyond measure, he is the most excellent of all beings,🔽because he is of incomparable, unsurpassed, and immeasurable virtue, and because he is of the highest benefit to the world with its gods.

original: bhagavā aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu aparimāṇānaṃ sattānaṃ ekapaṭisaraṇo patiṭṭhā. Atha
analyzed: bhagavā aparimāṇāsu lokadhātūsu aparimāṇānam sattānam eka paṭisaraṇaḥ patiṭṭhā atha
translated: “Lord” : the world’s refuge, the world’s ruler, the world’s leader, is what is meant. For the Blessed One is the world’s supreme lord in the sense of being the world’s refuge, since he is the foremost of all beings because he is endowed with the special qualities of immeasurable, unsurpassed greatness, and because he is the world’s supreme benefactor by his incomparable performance of the highest benefit for the whole world of living beings, including gods and men, with his incomparable skill in means, which is characterized by the accomplishment of immeasurable, unsurpassed, and incomparable happiness.

original: vā nāthatīti nātho, veneyyānaṃ hitasukhaṃ mettāyanavasena āsīsati patthetīti attho.
analyzed: vā nāthati iti nāthaḥ veneyyānam hita sukham mettāyana vasena āsīsati pattheti iti attho
translated: Or alternatively, “lord” is derived from the verb “nāthati” , which means “he desires, he seeks” in the sense of desiring and seeking the welfare and happiness of his disciples through loving kindness.

original: Atha vā nāthati veneyyagate kilese upatāpetīti attho, nāthatīti vā yācatīti attho.
analyzed: atha vā nāthati veneyya gate kilese upatāpeti iti attho nāthati iti vā yācati iti attho
translated: Or alternatively, “lord” is derived from the verb “nāthatī” , which means “he torments” in the sense of tormenting the defilements in the mental continuity of his disciples. Or “lord” is derived from the verb “nāthatī” , which means “he begs” in the sense of begging beings to practice the various kinds of good conduct.

original: Bhagavā hi “sādhu, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kālena kālaṃ attasampattiṃ paccavekkheyyā”tiādinā
analyzed: bhagavā hi sādhu bhikkhave bhikkhu kālena kālam atta sampattim paccavekkheyya iti ādinā
translated: For the Blessed One, after begging beings to practice the various kinds of good conduct by saying: “Monks, a monk should review his own virtue from time to time” , etc. ,

original: sattānaṃ taṃ taṃ hitapaṭipattiṃ yācitvāpi karuṇāya samussāhito te tattha niyojeti.
analyzed: sattānam tam tam hita paṭipattim yācitvā api karuṇāya samussāhitaḥ te tattha niyojā iti
translated: encourages them to do so by his compassion.

original: Paramena vā cittissariyena samannāgato sabbasatte īsati abhibhavatīti paramissaro
analyzed: paramena vā cittissariyena samannāgataḥ sabba satte īsati abhibhavati iti paramissaraḥ
translated: Or else, he is the supreme lord because he is endowed with the supreme mind-made body and he dominates all beings.

original: bhagavā “nātho”ti vuccati. Sabbopi cāyamattho saddasatthānusārato veditabbo.
analyzed: bhagavā nātho ti vuccati sabbaḥ api ca ayam attho sadda sattha anusārataḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: The Blessed One is called “the Master” . And all this meaning should be understood according to the method of explanation of the word “master” .

original: Mahākāruṇikassāti yo karuṇāya kampitahadayattā lokahitatthaṃ atidukkarakiriyāya anekappakāraṃ
analyzed: mahā kāruṇikassa ati yaḥ karuṇāya kampita hadaya ttā loka hita attham ati dukkara kiriyāya aneka ppakāram
translated: To the Greatly Compassionate One: he who, because his heart was moved by compassion, went through the most difficult practices for the sake of the welfare of the world,

original: tādisaṃ saṃsāradukkhamanubhavitvā āgato, tassa mahākāruṇikassāti attho. Tattha kiratīti🔽karuṇā, paradukkhaṃ vikkhipati apanetīti attho. Dukkhitesu vā kirīyati pasārīyatīti
analyzed: tādisam saṃsāra dukkham anubhavitvā āgataḥ tassa mahā kāruṇikassa ati atthaḥ tattha kirati iti  karuṇā para dukkham vikkhipati apaneti iti atthaḥ dukkhitesu vā kirīyati pasārīyati iti
translated: and who came to this state after experiencing such suffering in the round of rebirths, he is the greatly compassionate one. Herein, it is said that he “compassionates” ,🔽the meaning is that he scatters, removes, other’s suffering. Or alternatively, he is “compassionate” because he is extended, spread out, over those who suffer.

original: karuṇā. Atha vā kiṇātīti karuṇā, paradukkhe sati kāruṇikaṃ hiṃsati vibādheti, vināseti🔽vā parassa dukkhanti attho. Paradukkhe sati sādhūnaṃ kampanaṃ hadayakhedaṃ karotīti
analyzed: karuṇā atha vā kiṇāti iti karuṇā para dukkhe sati kāruṇikam hiṃsati vibādheti vināseti  vā parassa dukkhanti attho para dukkhe sati sādhūnam kampanam hadaya khedam karoti iti
translated: Or else, he “compassionates” , the meaning is that he harms, injures, destroys, the one who is compassionate when there is another’s suffering.🔽Or else, he “compassionates” , the meaning is that he causes a good man to tremble, to be distressed in his heart, when there is another’s suffering.

original: vā karuṇā. Atha vā kamiti sukhaṃ, taṃ rundhatīti karuṇā. Esā hi paradukkhāpanayanakāmatālakkhaṇā
analyzed: vā karuṇā atha vā kam iti sukham tam rundhati iti karuṇā esā hi para dukkha apanayana kāma tā lakkhaṇā
translated: Or else, he “compassionates” , the meaning is that he stops, prevents, happiness . For this has the characteristic of desiring to remove the suffering of others.

original: attasukhanirapekkhatāya kāruṇikānaṃ sukhaṃ rundhati vibādhetīti. Karuṇāya niyuttoti
analyzed: atta sukha nirapekkha tāya kāruṇikānam sukham rundhati vibādheti iti karuṇāya
translated: He is called “compassionate” because he is intent on compassion.

original: kāruṇiko yathā “dovāriko”ti. Yathā hi dvāraṭṭhānato aññattha vattamānopi dvārapaṭibaddhajīviko🔽puriso dvārānativattavuttitāya dvāre niyuttoti “dovāriko”ti vuccati, evaṃ bhagavā
analyzed: kāruṇikaḥ yathā dovāriko ti yathā hi dvāra ṭṭhānataḥ aññattha vattamānaḥ api dvāra paṭibaddha jīviko  purisaḥ dvāra anativatta vutti tāya dvāre niyuttaḥ ti dovārikaḥ iti vuccati evam bhagavā
translated: Just as a doorkeeper is called “doorkeeper” because he is intent on the door,

original: mettādivasena karuṇāvihārato aññattha vattamānopi karuṇānativattavuttitāya karuṇāya🔽niyuttoti “kāruṇiko”ti vuccati. Mahābhinīhārato paṭṭhāya hi yāva mahāparinibbānā
analyzed: mettā ādi vasena karuṇā vihārataḥ aññattha vattamānaḥ api karuṇā anativatta vutti tāya karuṇāya  niyuttaḥ ti kāruṇiko ti vuccati mahā abhinīhārato paṭṭhāya hi yāva mahā parinibbānā
translated: so the Blessed One is called “compassionate” because he is intent on the abiding in compassion through loving-kindness, etc.

original: lokahitatthameva lokanāthā tiṭṭhanti. Mahanto kāruṇikoti mahākāruṇiko. Satipi bhagavato🔽tadaññaguṇānampi vasena mahantabhāve kāruṇikasaddasannidhānena vuttattā karuṇāvasenettha
analyzed: loka hita attham eva lokanāthā tiṭṭhanti mahanto kāruṇiko ti mahā kāruṇiko bhagavato  tad añña guṇānam pi vasena mahanta bhāve kāruṇika sadda sannidhānena vutta ttā karuṇā vasena ittha
translated: For from the time of his great resolution until his great final passing away the Lord of the World stood intent on the welfare of the world.🔽He is “greatly compassionate” because he is possessed of great compassion.

original: mahantabhāvo veditabbo yathā “mahāveyyākaraṇo”ti. Evañca katvā “mahākāruṇikassā”ti
analyzed: mahanta bhāvaḥ veditabbaḥ yathā mahā veyyākaraṇaḥ ti evañca katvā mahā kāruṇikassa ati
translated: And although the Blessed One is great in other respects as well, still he is called “great” here in the sense of the greatness of compassion, as in the expression “great grammarian” .

original: iminā padena puggalādhiṭṭhānena satthu mahākaruṇā vuttā hoti.
analyzed: iminā padena puggala adhiṭṭhānena satthu mahā karuṇā vuttā hoti
translated: By this word the Blessed One’s great compassion is stated with reference to a person.

original: Atha vā karuṇā karuṇāyanaṃ sīlaṃ pakati etassāti kāruṇiko, pathavīphassādayo viya
analyzed: atha vā karuṇā karuṇāyanam sīlam pakati etassa ati kāruṇikaḥ pathavī phassa ādayaḥ viya
translated: Or alternatively, he is compassionate because compassion is his delight, his virtue, his nature, like the earth’s being solid, water’s being moist, and so on.

original: kakkhaḷaphusanādisabhāvā karuṇāyanasabhāvo sabhāvabhūtakaruṇoti attho. Sesaṃ purimasadisameva.
analyzed: kakkhaḷa phusana ādi sabhāvā karuṇāyana sabhāvo sabhāva bhūta karuṇaḥ ti attho sesam purima sadisam eva
translated: The meaning is that compassion is his nature, his essence, as his delight. The rest is as already stated.

original: Atha vā mahāvisayatāya mahānubhāvatāya mahābalatāya ca mahatī karuṇāti mahākaruṇā.
analyzed: atha vā mahā visaya tāya mahā anubhāva tāya mahā bala tāya ca mahatī karuṇā ati mahākaruṇā
translated: Or alternatively, compassion is great because it has a great objective, because it has great influence, and because it has great power, thus it is great compassion.

original: Bhagavato hi karuṇā niravasesesu sattesu pavattati, pavattamānā ca anaññasādhāraṇā
analyzed: bhagavataḥ hi karuṇā niravasesesu sattesu pavattati pavattamānā ca anañña sādhāraṇā
translated: For the Blessed One’s compassion occurs towards all beings without exception, and when it occurs it does so in a way that is not shared by disciples and others,

original: pavattati, diṭṭhadhammikādibhedañca mahantameva sattānaṃ hitasukhaṃ ekantato nipphādeti,🔽mahākaruṇāya niyuttoti mahākāruṇikoti sabbaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Atha vā mahatī
analyzed: pavattati diṭṭhadhammika ādi bhedañca mahantam eva sattānam hita sukham ekantataḥ nipphādeti  mahā karuṇāya niyuttaḥ ti mahā kāruṇiko ti sabbam vutta nayena iva veditabbam atha vā mahatī
translated: and it produces exclusively the great welfare and happiness of beings classed as visible, etc.,🔽and he is devoted to great compassion, thus he is the Great Compassionate One. All this can be understood in the way already stated. Or alternatively, he is the Great Compassionate One because he has great,

original: pasatthā karuṇā assa atthīti mahākāruṇiko. Pūjāvacano hettha mahantasaddo “mahāpuriso”tiādīsu
analyzed: pasatthā karuṇā assa atthi iti mahā kāruṇikaḥ pūjā vacanaḥ ha ittha mahanta saddaḥ mahā purisaḥ ti ādīsu
translated: praiseworthy compassion. The word “great” here is a term of respect, like such usages as “great man” .

original: viya. Pasatthā ca bhagavato karuṇā mahākaruṇāsamāpattivasenapi pavattito anaññasādhāraṇattāti.
analyzed: viya pasatthā ca bhagavato karuṇā mahākaruṇā samāpatti vasena api pavattitaḥ anañña sādhāraṇa ttā ti
translated: and so on. And the Blessed One’s compassion is renowned because it occurs by means of the attainment of great compassion, which is not shared by others.

original: Evaṃ karuṇāmukhena saṅkhepato sakalasabbaññuguṇehi bhagavantaṃ thometvā idāni saddhammaṃ
analyzed: evam karuṇā mukhena saṅkhepataḥ sakala sabbaññu guṇehi bhagavantam thometvā idāni saddhammam
translated: Having thus briefly extolled the Blessed One by means of compassion with all the special qualities of omniscience, he now said “Asambudha” in order to extol the True Idea.

original: thometuṃ “asambudha”ntiādimāha. Tattha asambudhanti pubbakālakiriyāniddeso, tassa🔽asambujjhanto appaṭivijjhantoti attho, yathāsabhāvaṃ appaṭivijjhanatoti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: thometum asambudhan ti ādim āha tattha asambudhan ti pubba kāla kiriyā niddeso tassa  asambujjhantaḥ appaṭivijjhantoti atthaḥ yathā sabhāvam appaṭivijjhanato ti vuttam hoti
translated: Herein, asambudha is the description of the past event. The meaning is “not awakened to,” “not penetrated,” “not penetrated to its individual essence,” is what is meant.

original: Hetuattho hettha antasaddo “paṭhanto nisīdatī”tiādīsu viya. Yanti pubbakālakiriyāya
analyzed: hetu atthaḥ ha ittha anta saddo paṭhantaḥ nisīdati iti ādīsu viya yanti pubba kāla kiriyāya
translated: The word antasa is a causal one here, like the words “paṭhanto nisīdati” .🔽Yanti is a description of the action, which is not specified as to time,

original: aniyamato kammaniddeso. Buddhanisevitanti tassa visesanaṃ. Tattha buddhasaddassa🔽tāva “bujjhitā saccānīti buddho, bodhetā pajāyāti buddho”tiādinā niddesanayena attho🔽veditabbo. Atha vā savāsanāya aññāṇaniddāya accantavigamato, buddhiyā vā vikasitabhāvato
analyzed: aniyamataḥ kamma niddesaḥ buddha nisevitan ti tassa visesanam tattha buddha saddassa 🔽tāva saccāni iti buddhaḥ pajāyā ti buddha uti ādinā niddesa nayena atthaḥ 🔽veditabbaḥ atha vā sa vāsanāya aññāṇa niddāya accanta vigamataḥ buddhiyā vā vikasita bhāvataḥ

original: Tattha nibbānaṃ gocarāsevanāvaseneva nisevitaṃ, maggo pana attanā bhāvito ca bhāvanāsevanāvasena
analyzed: tattha nibbānam gocara āsevanā vasena iva nisevitam maggo pana attanā bhāvito ca bhāvanā sevanā vasena
translated: but the path is resorted to by the means of the resort of keeping in being and by the means of the resort of keeping in being that has been made to arise by oneself.

original: sevito, parehi uppāditāni pana maggaphalāni cetopariyañāṇādinā yadā parijānāti, attanā🔽uppāditāni vā paccavekkhaṇañāṇena paricchindati, tadā gocarāsevanāvasenapi sevitāni🔽hontiyeva. Ettha ca pariyattidhammassapi pariyāyato dhammaggahaṇena gahaṇe sati sopi
analyzed: sevitaḥ parehi uppāditāni pana magga phalāni cetaḥ pariyañāṇa ādinā yadā parijānāti attanā  uppāditāni vā paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇena paricchindati tadā gocara asevanā vasena api sevitāni  ettha ca pariyatti dhammassa api pariyāyataḥ dhamma ggahaṇena gahaṇe sati saḥ api
translated: But when he has direct-knowledge of the paths and fruits that have been made to arise by others by means of the knowledge of penetration of minds, etc.,🔽or when he has delimitation of those that have been made to arise by himself by means of the knowledge of reviewing, then they are also resorted to by the means of the resort of keeping in being.

original: desanāsammasanañāṇagocaratāya gocarāsevanāya sevitoti sakkā gahetuṃ. “Abhidhammanayasamuddaṃ
analyzed: desanā sammasana ñāṇa gocara tāya gocara a sevanāya sevito ti sakkā gahetum abhidhamma naya samuddam
translated: And here, when there is the apprehending of the doctrine of the scriptures by the apprehending of the doctrine in the sense of the text, then that can be taken as resorted to by the means of the resort of keeping in being, since it is the province of the knowledge of the resolving of the apparent contradictions in the Teaching.

original: adhigacchati, tīṇi piṭakāni sammasī”ti ca aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttattā pariyattidhammassapi
analyzed: adhigacchati tīṇi piṭakāni sammasī ti ca aṭṭhakathā ayam vutta ttā pariyatti dhammassa api
translated: And since it is said in the Commentary, “He reaches the ocean of the method of the Abhidhamma, he resolves the three Piṭakas” , the method of resolving the apparent contradictions in the doctrine of the scriptures is available.

original: sacchikiriyāya sammasanapariyāyo labbhatīti yaṃ asambudhaṃ asambujjhanto asacchikarontoti
analyzed: sacchikiriyāya sammasana pariyāyaḥ labbhati iti yam a sambudham a sambujjhantaḥ a sacchikaronto iti
translated: So when it is said “without having penetrated, without having awakened, without having realized” ,

original: atthasambhavato sopi idha vutto evāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tampi ca appaṭivijjhanto bhavābhavaṃ
analyzed: attha sambhavataḥ saḥ api idha vuttaḥ evā ti daṭṭhabbam tam pi ca a paṭivijjhantaḥ bhava abhavam
translated: and since it is possible to take it in that way, it should be regarded as stated here too. But one who does not penetrate it goes from existence to existence.

original: gacchati, pariññātadhammavinayo pana tadatthapaṭipattiyā sammāpaṭipanno na cirasseva
analyzed: gacchati pariññāta dhamma vinayaḥ pana tad attha paṭipattiyā sammāpaṭipannaḥ na cirassa eva
translated: and since it is possible to take it in that way, it should be regarded as included here too. But one who does not penetrate it goes from existence to existence. But one who has fully understood the Dhamma and Discipline and is practising the way in accordance with its meaning will soon

original: dukkhassantaṃ karissati. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: dukkhassantam karissati vuttam ha etam
translated: make an end of suffering. For this is said:🔽“He who shall live diligent

original: “Yo imasmiṃ dhammavinaye, appamatto vihassati;
analyzed: yaḥ imasmin dhamma vinaye appamattaḥ vihassati
translated: In this Dhamma and Discipline,🔽Abandonning the round of births,

original: Pahāya jātisaṃsāraṃ, dukkhassantaṃ karissatī”ti. ;
analyzed: pahāya jāti saṃsāram dukkha ssantam karissati iti
translated: Will make an end of suffering” .

original: Ettha ca kiñcāpi maggaphalanibbānāni paccekabuddhabuddhasāvakehipi gocarāsevanādinā🔽sevitāni honti, tathāpi ukkaṭṭhaparicchedavasena “buddhanisevita”nti vuttaṃ. Kenaci
analyzed: ettha ca kiñcā api magga phala nibbānāni paccekabuddha buddha sāvakehi pi gocara asevana ādinā  sevitāni honti tathā api ukkaṭṭha pariccheda vasena buddha nisevitan ti vuttam kenacid
translated: And although the path, fruition, and Nibbāna are frequented by Paccekabuddhas and Buddhas’ disciples too by their frequenting the resort of emptiness, etc.,

original: pana buddhasaddassa sāmaññato buddhānubuddhapaccekabuddhānampi ettheva saṅgaho vutto.
analyzed: pana buddha saddassa sāmaññato buddha anubuddha paccekabuddhānam pi ettha iva saṅgahaḥ vutto
translated: nevertheless it is said that they are “frequented by Buddhas” in the sense of the highest degree. But by the word “Buddha” in the sense of “awakened to” , the Paccekabuddhas and Buddhas are included too.

original: Bhavābhavanti aparakālakiriyāya kammaniddeso, bhavato bhavanti attho. Atha vā bhavābhavanti
analyzed: bhava abhavanti apara kāla kiriyāya kamma niddesaḥ bhavataḥ bhavanti atthaḥ atha vā bhava abhavanti
translated: “From existence to existence” is a description of kamma that leads to rebirth in the future. The meaning is: from existence to existence. Or alternatively, “from existence to existence” is a description of the round of rebirths.

original: sugatiduggativasena hīnapaṇītavasena ca khuddakaṃ mahantañca bhavanti attho. Vuddhatthopi
analyzed: sugati duggati vasena hīna paṇīta vasena ca khuddakam mahantam ca bhavanti atthaḥ vuddha tthaḥ api
translated: and they are small and great according to the difference between a happy destiny and a miserable destiny, and according to the difference between what is inferior and what is excellent.🔽The letter a is also seen in such passages as “The states that are not-so-the-three-times” , where it has the meaning of greatness.

original: hi a-kāro dissati “asekkhā dhammā”tiādīsu viya. Tasmā abhavoti mahābhavo vuccati.🔽Atha vā bhavoti vuddhi, abhavoti hāni. Bhavoti vā sassatadiṭṭhi, abhavoti ucchedadiṭṭhi.
analyzed: hi akāraḥ dissati asekkhā dhammā ti ādīsu viya tasmai abhavo ti mahābhavaḥ vuccati  atha vā bhavoti vuddhi abhavoti hāni bhavoti vā sassata diṭṭhi abhavoti uccheda diṭṭhi
translated: So non-existence is called “great existence.”🔽Or alternatively, existence is growth, non-existence is diminution. Or existence is the eternalist view, non-existence is the annihilationist view.

original: Vuttappakāro bhavo ca abhavo ca bhavābhavo. Taṃ bhavābhavaṃ. Gacchatīti aparakālakiriyāniddeso.
analyzed: vutta ppakāraḥ bhavaḥ ca abhavaḥ ca bhava abhavaḥ tam bhava abhavam gacchati iti apara kāla kiriyā niddeso
translated: The kind of existence and non-existence described is existence-and-non-existence. He goes to that existence-and-non-existence: this is a designation for the occurrence of death at another time.

original: Jīvalokoti sattaloko. Jīvaggahaṇena hi saṅkhārabhājanalokaṃ nivatteti tassa bhavābhavagamanāsambhavato.
analyzed: jīvaloko ti satta lokaḥ jīva ggahaṇena hi saṅkhāra bhājana lokam nivatteti tassa bhava abhava gamana asambhavato
translated: The world of living beings is the world of living beings. For by the word “living being” he excludes the world of inanimate beings, since it is impossible for that to go to existence-and-non-existence.

original: Namo atthūti pāṭhaseso daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: namaḥ atthu iti pāṭha sesaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: The reading “namo atthū” should be taken as a variant reading.

original: Avijjādikilesajālaviddhaṃsinoti dhammavisesanaṃ. Tattha avindiyaṃ vindatīti avijjā.
analyzed: avijjā ādi kilesa jāla viddhaṃsino ti dhamma visesanam tattha avindiyam vindati iti avijjā
translated: The phrase “who cuts through the net of defilements beginning with ignorance” is a description of the Dhamma. Herein, it is not known , thus it is ignorance .

original: Pūretuṃ ayuttaṭṭhena kāyaduccaritādi avindiyaṃ nāma, aladdhabbanti attho. Tabbiparītato
analyzed: pūretum ayutta ṭṭhena kāya duccarita ādi avindiyam nāma a laddhabbanti attho tad biparītataḥ
translated: Bad conduct in body, etc., is not to be known in the sense of being unfit to be fulfilled; the meaning is that it is not to be obtained.

original: kāyasucaritādi vindiyaṃ nāma, taṃ vindiyaṃ na vindatīti vā avijjā, khandhānaṃ rāsaṭṭhaṃ,
analyzed: kāya su carita ādi vindiyam nāma tam vindiyam na vindati iti vai avijjā khandhānam rāsaṭṭham
translated: The good conduct of body, etc., is called the “aggregate” in the Vinaya; he does not find that aggregate in the Vinaya, or it does not find him, thus he is “ignorant” of the mass of aggregates.

original: āyatanānaṃ āyatanaṭṭhaṃ, dhātūnaṃ suññataṭṭhaṃ, indriyānaṃ adhipatiyaṭṭhaṃ, saccānaṃ
analyzed: āyatanānam āyatana ṭṭham dhātūnam suññata ṭṭham indriyānam adhipatiya ṭṭham saccānam
translated: The good conduct of body, etc., is what is called the “field.” It is ignorance because it does not find, does not discover, that field. It is ignorance because it makes unknown the sixfold base of the aggregates, the sixfold base of the sense bases, the sixfold base of the elements, the sixfold base of the faculties, the sixfold base of the truths,🔽the sixfold base of the dependent origination, the sixfold base of the aggregates, etc., in the three periods of time.

original: tathaṭṭhaṃ aviditaṃ karotīti vā avijjā, dukkhādīnaṃ pīḷanādivasena vuttaṃ catubbidhaṃ
analyzed: tathaṭṭham aviditam karoti iti vā avijjā dukkha ādīnam pīḷana ādi vasena vuttam catubbidham
translated: It is ignorance because it makes unknown the fourfold meaning stated as oppression, etc., of suffering, etc.

original: atthaṃ aviditaṃ karotītipi avijjā, antavirahite saṃsāre sabbayonigatibhavaviññāṇaṭṭhitisattāvāsesu
analyzed: attham a viditam karoti iti pi avijjā anta virahite saṃsāre sabba yoni gati bhava viññāṇa ṭṭhiti sattā vāsesu
translated: It is ignorance because it causes beings to run in the round of rebirths, which is without discoverable beginning, through all the kinds of generation, all the destinies, all the kinds of being, all the stations of consciousness, and all the realms of existence.

original: satte javāpetīti vā avijjā, paramatthato avijjamānesupi itthipurisādīsu javati, vijjamānesupi
analyzed: satte javā apeti iti vā avijjā paramatthataḥ a vijjamānesu pi itthi purisa ādīsu javati vijjamānesu pi
translated: It is ignorance because it runs towards women and men, etc., that do not exist in the ultimate sense, and does not run towards the aggregates, etc., that do exist in the ultimate sense.

original: khandhādīsu na javatīti vā avijjā. Sā ādi yesaṃ taṇhādīnaṃ te avijjādayo, teyeva
analyzed: khandha ādīsu na vā avijjā sā ādi yesam taṇhā ādīnam te avijjā ādayaḥ
translated: Those beginning with craving are called “ignorance and craving,” etc.,

original: kilissanti etehi sattāti kilesā, teyeva ca sattānaṃ bandhanaṭṭhena jālasadisāti jālaṃ,
analyzed: kilissanti etehi sattā ati kilesā teyā iva ca sattānam bandhana ṭṭhena jāla sadisā ati jālam
translated: because they are the beginning, middle, and end respectively of the round of rebirths. They are defilements because they defile the three planes of becoming. They are the “net” because they are like a net in the sense of binding beings.

original: taṃ viddhaṃseti sabbaso vināseti sīlenāti avijjādikilesajālaviddhaṃsī. Nanu cettha
analyzed: tam sabbasas vināseti sīlena ati avijja ādi kilesa jāla viddhaṃsī nanu ca ittha
translated: He destroys it all, he destroys it completely, with virtue, thus he is a destroyer of the net of craving.

original: sapariyattiko navalokuttaradhammo adhippeto, tattha ca maggoyeva kilese viddhaṃseti,
analyzed: sa pariyattikaḥ nava lokuttara dhammaḥ adhippeto tattha ca kilese
translated: But is not the nine supramundane states with their learning together intended here, and does not only the path destroy defilements,

original: netareti ce? Vuccate. Maggassapi nibbānamāgamma kilesaviddhaṃsanato nibbānampi kilese🔽viddhaṃseti nāma, maggassa kilesaviddhaṃsanakiccaṃ phalena nipphannanti phalampi
analyzed: na itarā iti ce vuccate maggassa api nibbānam āgamma kilesa viddhaṃsanataḥ nibbānam api kilese  viddhaṃsā iti nāma maggassa kilesa viddhaṃsana kiccam phalena nipphannanti phalam pi
translated: not the others? —It may be said in reply that since the path leads to Nibbāna, Nibbāna too is called “a destroyer of defilements.”🔽And since the path’s function of destroying defilements is accomplished by the fruition, the fruition too is called “a destroyer of defilements.”

original: “kilesaviddhaṃsī”ti vuccati. Pariyattidhammopi kilesaviddhaṃsanassa paccayattā “kilesaviddhaṃsī”ti
analyzed: kilesa viddhaṃsī iti vuccati pariyatti dhammaḥ api kilesa viddhaṃsanassa paccaya ttā kilesa viddhaṃsī iti
translated: And since the states of learning are a condition for the destruction of defilements, they too are rightly called “a destroyer of defilements.”

original: vattumarahatīti na koci doso.
analyzed: vattum arahati iti na koci dosaḥ
translated: So there is no fault here.

original: Dhammavarassa tassāti pubbe aniyamitassa niyamavacanaṃ. Tattha yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipajjamāne catūsu apāyesu apatamāne dhāretīti dhammo.
analyzed: dhamma varassa tassa ati pubbe aniyamitassa niyama vacanam tattha yathānusiṭṭham paṭipajjamāne catūsu apāyesu a patamāne dhāreti iti dhammaḥ
translated: Of that Dhamma’s best: this is a statement of limitation where no limitation was stated before. Herein, the Dhamma is what bears up , since it does not let down those who have entered upon the way in accordance with the Dhamma into the four states of loss ,🔽“Those who have gone to the Dhamma for refuge

original: “Ye keci dhammaṃ saraṇaṃ gatāse, na te gamissanti apāyabhūmiṃ;
analyzed: ye keci dhammam saraṇam gatāse na te gamissanti apāya bhūmim
translated: Will not go to the states of loss,

original: Pahāya mānusaṃ dehaṃ, devakāyaṃ paripūressantī”ti. –
analyzed: pahāya mānusam deham deva kāyam paripūressanti iti
translated: and having abandoned the human body, they will fill up the divine body.”🔽For it is said:🔽Or else, “Dhamma” is what bears the round of rebirths in its own nature by not letting the suffering of the round of rebirths be lost.

original: Hi vuttaṃ. Saṃsāradukkhe vā apatamāne katvā dhāretīti dhammo maggaphaluppattiyā sattakkhattuparamatādivasena
analyzed: hi vuttam saṃsāra dukkhe vā a patamāne katvā dhāreti iti dhammaḥ magga phala uppattiyā satta kkhattu parama tā ādi vasena
translated: For the round of rebirths is limited by the occurrence of the path and fruition,

original: saṃsārassa paricchinnattā. Apāyādinibbattakakilesaviddhaṃsanañcettha dhāraṇaṃ. Evañca🔽katvā ariyamaggo tassa tadatthasiddhihetutāya nibbānañcāti ubhayameva nippariyāyato
analyzed: saṃsārassa paricchinna ttā apāya ādi nibbattaka kilesa viddhaṃsanam ca ittha dhāraṇam evam ca  katvā ariya maggo tassa tad attha siddhi hetutāya nibbānam ca ati ubhayam eva nippariyāyato
translated: and the destruction of the defilements that cause rebirth in the states of loss, etc., is borne by it.🔽And in this way the noble path bears both nibbāna and the noble fruition,

original: dhāreti, ariyaphalaṃ pana taṃsamucchinnakilesapaṭippassambhanena tadanuguṇatāya,🔽pariyattidhammo tadadhigamahetutāyāti ubhayaṃ pariyāyato dhāretīti veditabbaṃ. Vuttappakāro
analyzed: dhārā iti ariya phalam pana tad anuguṇa tāya  pariyatti dhammo tad adhigama hetu tāya ati ubhayam pariyāyataḥ dhāreti iti veditabbam vutta ppakāraḥ
translated: for it is the cause for the accomplishment of the latter. The noble fruition bears both in a derived sense, for it is the subsiding of the defilements that have been cut off by the path and it is conformable to the latter.🔽The Dhamma of the texts bears both in a derived sense, for it is the cause for the attainment of the path and fruition.🔽The Dhamma of the texts is the best, the most excellent, the unsurpassed, in the sense of being higher than anything else.

original: dhammoyeva attano uttaritarābhāvena varo pavaro anuttaroti dhammavaro, tassa dhammavarassa
analyzed: dhammoya iva attano uttaritara abhāvena varo pavaro anuttaro ti dhamma varo tassa dhamma varassa
translated: The compound dhammavaranamatthu is to be resolved as “Homage to the Dhamma, which is the best.”

original: namo atthūti sambandho. Ettāvatā cettha amhehi sārattho pakāsito. Yaṃ panettha kenaci
analyzed: namaḥ atthu iti sambandhaḥ ettāvatā ca ittha amhehi sāra tthaḥ pakāsitaḥ yam pana ittha kenacid
translated: So far we have explained the meaning of the words of the stanza. But the question may be asked:

original: papañcitaṃ, amhehi ca idha na dassitaṃ, na taṃ sārato paccetabbaṃ. Ito paresupi evameva🔽daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tasmā ito paṭṭhāya ettakampi avatvā sāratthameva dassayissāma. Yattha🔽pana kenaci accantaviruddhaṃ likhitaṃ, tampi katthaci dassayissāma. Ettha ca “avijjādikilesajālaviddhaṃsino”ti

original: etena svākkhātatādīhi dhammaṃ thometi, “dhammavarassā”ti etena aññassa visiṭṭhassa
analyzed: etena svākkhāta ta ādīhi dhammam thometi dhamma varassa ati etena aññassa visiṭṭhassa

analyzed: abhāva dīpanataḥ paripuṇṇa tāya paṭhamena vā pahāna sampadam dhammassa dasseti dutiyena pabhāva sampadam  evam saṅkhepena iva sabba dhamma guṇehi saddhammam thometvā idāni ariya saṅgham thometum

original: “vimuttiñāṇa”nti vuttaṃ. Ādisaddapariyāyena pabhutisaddena vā vimuttiggahaṇaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Tattha vimuttīti phalaṃ. Vimuttiñāṇanti paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ. Pabhuti-saddena chaḷabhiññācatupaṭisambhidādayo

translated: He said “virtue and concentration” and so on, showing that it is proper to do so. Herein, virtue is what is called “virtue consisting in limited purification” and so on. translated: means he received; the meaning is, he reached.

original: Tassānubhāvenāti tassa yathāvuttassa puññappavāhassa ānubhāvena balena. Hatantarāyoti
analyzed: tassa anubhāvena ati tassa yathāvuttassa puñña ppavāhassa ānubhāvena balena hata antarāyaḥ ti
translated: By the power of that: by the power of the merit-stream described in the way already stated.

original: taṃtaṃsampattiyā vibandhanavasena sattasantānassa antare vemajjhe eti āgacchatīti🔽antarāyo, diṭṭhadhammikādianattho. Paṇāmapayojane vuttavidhinā hato viddhasto antarāyo🔽upaddavo assāti hatantarāyo. Assa “vaṇṇayissaṃ vinaya”nti iminā sambandho, hatantarāyo
analyzed: tad tad sampattiyāḥ vibandhana vasena satta santānassa antare vemajjhe eti āgacchati iti  antarāyaḥ diṭṭhadhammika ādi anatthaḥ paṇāma payojane vutta vidhinā hataḥ antarāyaḥ  upaddavaḥ assa ati hata antarāyaḥ assa vaṇṇayissam vinayanti iminā sambandhaḥ hata antarāyaḥ
translated: Obstruction is a hindrance that comes, that occurs, in the middle, in the midst, of the continuity of being of creatures by obstructing the attainment of this or that success.🔽It is misfortune in this life, etc.🔽The obstruction that is destroyed, that is pierced, by the method stated in the section dealing with the purpose of paying homage is a destroyed obstruction.🔽The word “destroyed” is connected with the word “will expound” in the words “I will expound the Discipline.”

original: hutvā vinayaṃ vaṇṇayissanti vuttaṃ hoti. Etena tassa puññappavāhassa attano pasādasampattiyā🔽ratanattayassa ca khettabhāvasampattiyā atthasaṃvaṇṇanāya upaghātakaupaddavānaṃ hanane samatthataṃ dīpeti.
analyzed: hutvā vinayam vaṇṇayissanti vuttam hoti etena tassa puñña ppavāhassa attano pasāda sampattiyā  rata nattayassa ca khetta bhāva sampattiyāḥ attha saṃvaṇṇanāya upaghātaka opaddavānam hanane samattha tam dīpeti
translated: What is meant is: having destroyed the obstruction, I will expound the Discipline.🔽By this he shows that he is able to destroy the misfortune that obstructs the explanation of the meaning by his own possession of confidence and by the possession of the Triple Gem’s worthiness as a field.

original: Evaṃ ratanattayassa nipaccakārakaraṇe payojanaṃ dassetvā idāni yassa vinayapiṭakassa
analyzed: evam rata nattayassa nipacca kāra karaṇe payojanam dassetvā idāni yassa vinaya piṭakassa
translated: Having thus shown the purpose of paying homage to the Triple Gem, he now says, “I will expound the Discipline,”

original: atthaṃ saṃvaṇṇetukāmo, tassa tāva bhagavato sāsanassa mūlapatiṭṭhānabhāvaṃ dassetvā
analyzed: attham saṃvaṇṇetu kāmo tassa tāva bhagavataḥ sāsanassa mūla patiṭṭhāna bhāvam dassetvā
translated: He who wishes to expound the meaning, having shown the state of being the foundation of the Blessed One’s dispensation,

original: tampi thomento āha “yasmiṃ ṭhite”tiādi. Aṭṭhitassa susaṇṭhitassa bhagavato sāsanaṃ
analyzed: tam pi thomentaḥ āha yasmin ṭhita itiādi aṭṭhitassa su saṇṭhitassa bhagavato sāsanam
translated: he said in praise of it thus “Yasmin ṭhite” , etc. The Blessed One’s dispensation, which is well-established,

original: yasmiṃ ṭhite patiṭṭhitaṃ hotīti yojetabbaṃ. Tattha yasminti yasmiṃ vinayapiṭake.
analyzed: yasmin ṭhite patiṭṭhitam hoti iti yojetabbam tattha yasmin ti yasmim vinaya piṭake
translated: should be construed thus: “Yasmin ṭhite patiṭṭhitaṃ hotī” . Herein, yasmin means in which Vinaya Piṭaka.

original: Ṭhiteti pāḷito ca atthato ca anūnaṃ hutvā lajjīpuggalesu pavattanaṭṭhena ṭhiteti
analyzed: ṭhitā iti ca atthataḥ ca anūnam hutvā lajjī puggalesu pavattana ṭṭhena ṭhitā iti
translated: Ṭhite means established in the sense of occurring in the case of the modest person without deficiency in the text and in the meaning.

original: attho. Sāsananti adhisīlaadhicittaadhipaññāsaṅkhātasikkhattayasaṅgahitaṃ sāsanaṃ.
analyzed: atthaḥ sāsananti adhi sīla adhicitta adhi paññā saṅkhāta sikkhattaya saṅgahitam sāsanam
translated: Sāsana means the dispensation consisting of the three trainings called higher virtue, higher thought and higher understanding.

original: Aṭṭhitassāti kāmasukhallikattakilamathānuyogasaṅkhāte antadvaye aṭṭhitassāti attho.
analyzed: aṭṭhitassa ti kāma su khalli katta kilamatha anuyoga saṅkhāte anta dvaye aṭṭhitassa ati attho
translated: Aṭṭhitassa means not standing in the two extremes called sensual happiness and indulgence in self-mortification.

original: “Appatiṭṭhaṃ khvāhaṃ, āvuso, anāyūhaṃ oghamatari”nti hi vuttaṃ. Ayañcattho tīsupi
analyzed: appatiṭṭham khvā aham āvuso anāyūham ogham atarin ti hi vuttam ayam ca atthaḥ tīsu pi
translated: “I, friends, have crossed the flood not standing either here or yonder” . This meaning is stated in the three Sinhalese Commentaries.

original: sīhaḷagaṇṭhipadesu vuttoyeva. Gaṇṭhipade pana “aṭṭhitassāti parinibbutassapi bhagavato”ti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sīhaḷa gaṇṭhi padesu vuttaḥ yeva gaṇṭhi pade pana aṭṭhitassa ati parinibbutassa api bhagavato ti vuttam
translated: But in the Commentarial Guide it is said: “Aṭṭhitassa means even of the Blessed One who has attained Nibbāna.”

original: Patiṭṭhitaṃ hotīti tesuyeva lajjīpuggalesu pavattanaṭṭhena patiṭṭhitaṃ hoti. Susaṇṭhitassāti
analyzed: patiṭṭhitam hoti iti tesu yeva lajjī puggalesu pavattana ṭṭhena patiṭṭhitam hoti su saṇṭhitassa ati
translated: Well-proportioned:

original: ettha tāva tīsupi gaṇṭhipadesu idaṃ vuttaṃ “dvattiṃsamahāpurisalakkhaṇaasītianubyañjanehi
analyzed: ettha tāva tīsu pi gaṇṭhi padesu idam vuttam dvattiṃsa mahāpurisa lakkhaṇa asīti anubyañjanehi
translated: Herein, in the three places where the Thread is fastened, this is said: “The meaning is that he is well-proportioned in the sense of being possessed of the thirty-two characteristics of a Great Man and the eighty minor characteristics.

original: samannāgamanavasena susaṇṭhānassāti attho. Anena assa rūpakāyasampattiṃ nidassetī”ti.
analyzed: samannāgamana vasena su saṇṭhānassa ati atthaḥ anena assa rūpa kāya sampattim nidasseti iti
translated: This shows his excellence of physical form” .

original: Gaṇṭhipade pana “yathāṭhāne patiṭṭhitehi lakkhaṇehi samannāgatattā rūpakāyena susaṇṭhito,
analyzed: gaṇṭhi pade pana yathāṭhāne patiṭṭhitehi lakkhaṇehi samannāgata ttā rūpakāyena su saṇṭhitaḥ
translated: But in the Thread-fastening place it is said that he is well-proportioned in physical form since he is possessed of characteristics that are well-placed in their proper locations,

original: kāyavaṅkādirahitattā tādilakkhaṇasamannāgatattā ca nāmakāyenapī”ti vuttaṃ. Kenaci
analyzed: kāya vaṅka ādi rahita ttā ta ādi lakkhaṇa samannāgata ttā ca nāmakāyena api iti vuttam kenaci
translated: and also in mental form since he is devoid of such bodily distortions as limping and so on and since he is possessed of the characteristics of a True Man.

original: pana “catubrahmavihāravasena sattesu suṭṭhu sammā ca ṭhitassāti atthavasena vā susaṇṭhitassa.
analyzed: pana catu brahmavihāra vasena sattesu suṭṭhu sammā ca ṭhitassa ati attha vasena vā su saṇṭhitassa
translated: But by someone else it is said that the meaning is that he is well-proportioned in the sense that he is well and truly established in beings by means of the four divine abodes.

original: Susaṇṭhitattā hesa kevalaṃ sattānaṃ dukkhaṃ apanetukāmo hitaṃ upasaṃharitukāmo sampattiyā
analyzed: su saṇṭhita ttā ha esa kevalam sattānam dukkham apanetu kāmaḥ hitam upasaṃharitu kāmaḥ sampattiyā
translated: Because he is well-proportioned, he is only desirous of removing beings’ suffering and of bestowing what is beneficial, and he is desirous of bestowing excellence,

original: ca pamudito apakkhapatito ca hutvā vinayaṃ deseti. Tasmā imasmiṃ vinayasaṃvaṇṇanādhikāre
analyzed: ca pamuditaḥ a pakkha patitaḥ ca hutvā vinayam deseti tasmai imasmin vinaya saṃvaṇṇanā adhikāre
