analyzed: dānam paṭiggaṇhanti dhātuyaḥ āyatanāni iti vutte pi mahājanaḥ na jānāti sammoham āpajjati  paṭisattu hoti kim idam khandhāḥ dhātuyaḥ āyatanāni paṭiggaṇhanti nāma ati puggalā
translated: When it is said that the aggregates receive the gift, the elements and the sense-spheres do not understand. The great multitude does not know, falls into confusion,

original: paṭiggaṇhanti sīlavanto kalyāṇadhammā”ti vutte pana jānāti, na sammohamāpajjati,
analyzed: paṭiggaṇhanti sīlavanto kalyāṇa dhammā ti vutte pana jānāti na sammoham āpajjati
translated: and is perplexed, thinking: “What is this? Do the aggregates, elements and sense-spheres receive the gift?” But when it is said that the virtuous and well-behaved persons receive the gift, then they know, do not fall into confusion,

original: na paṭisattu hoti. Tasmā bhagavā dakkhiṇāvisuddhidīpanatthaṃ puggalakathaṃ katheti.
analyzed: na paṭisattu hoti tasmai bhagavā dakkhiṇā visuddhi dīpana attham puggala katham katheti
translated: and are not perplexed. Therefore the Blessed One speaks of a person in order to illustrate the purification of the gift.

original: Lokasammutiñca buddhā bhagavanto na vijahanti, lokasamaññāya lokaniruttiyā lokābhilāpe
analyzed: loka sammutim ca buddhāḥ bhagavantaḥ na vijahanti loka samaññāya loka niruttiyā loka abhilāpe
translated: The Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, do not abandon the worldly usage. They teach the Dhamma remaining in the worldly language, the worldly expression, the worldly usage,

original: ṭhitāyeva dhammaṃ desenti. Tasmā bhagavā lokasammutiyā appahānatthampi puggalakathaṃ
analyzed: ṭhitāya iva dhammam desenti tasmai bhagavā loka sammutiyā a pahāna attham pi puggala katham
translated: and the worldly designation. Therefore the Blessed One speaks of a person in order not to abandon the worldly usage.

original: katheti, tasmā iminā ca adhippāyena bhagavato puggaladesanā, na paramatthadesanāti
analyzed: kathā iti tasmai iminā ca adhippāyena bhagavato puggala desanā na paramattha desanā ati
translated: Therefore the Blessed One’s teaching of persons is by this intention, not by ultimate meaning.

original: evaṃ adhippāyaṃ ajānantoti vuttaṃ hoti.🔽Duggahitaṃ gaṇhātīti “tathāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, yathā tadevidaṃ🔽viññāṇaṃ sandhāvati saṃsarati, anañña”ntiādinā duggahitaṃ katvā gaṇhāti, viparītaṃ🔽gaṇhātīti vuttaṃ hoti. Duggahitanti hi bhāvanapuṃsakaniddeso. Yaṃ sandhāyāti yaṃ🔽duggahitagāhaṃ sandhāya. Attanā duggahitena dhammenāti pāṭhaseso veditabbo. Atha
analyzed: evam adhippāyam a jānanto ti vuttam hoti  duggahitam gaṇhāti iti tathā aham bhagavatā dhammam desitam ājānāmi yathā tat eva idam  viññāṇam sandhāvati saṃsarati anañña nti ādinā duggahitam katvā gaṇhāti viparītam  gaṇhāti iti vuttam hoti duggahitanti hi bhāva napuṃsaka niddesaḥ yam sandhāya ati yam  duggahita gāham sandhāya attanā duggahitena dhammena ati pāṭha sesaḥ veditabbaḥ atha
translated: So it is said, “not knowing the intention.”

original: vā duggahaṇaṃ duggahitaṃ. Attanāti ca sāmiatthe karaṇavacanaṃ, tasmā attano duggahaṇena🔽viparītagāhenāti vuttaṃ hoti. Amhe ceva abbhācikkhatīti amhākañca abbhācikkhanaṃ🔽karoti. Attānañca khanatīti attano kusalamūlāni khananto attānaṃ khanati nāma.
analyzed: vā duggahaṇam duggahitam attanā ati ca sāmiatthe karaṇa vacanam tasmai duggahaṇena 🔽viparīta gāhena āti vuttam hoti amhe ca iva abbhācikkhati iti amhākam ca abbhācikkhanam 🔽karoti attānam ca khanati iti attanaḥ kusala mūlāni khanantaḥ attānam khanati nāma
translated: “He takes it amiss”: he takes it amiss, having taken it thus: “I understand the Dhamma taught by the Blessed One in this way, that it is this consciousness that runs and wanders through the round of rebirths, not anything else.” He takes it amiss, he takes it wrongly, is what is meant. For “amiss” is a noun formed from the adjective “amisa” . “With reference to which”: with reference to which taking amiss. “With his own wrong grasp of the Dhamma”: the reading should be understood as “attano duggahitaṃ dhamman” . Or alternatively, “wrong grasping” is “wrong grasp” . “With his own” is in the instrumental case in the sense of agency, thus “with his own wrong grasp” means “with his own wrong taking, his wrong grasping.” “He misrepresents us”: he misrepresents us by his misrepresentation. “He digs up the earth”: he digs up himself by digging up his own roots of profit.

original: Dhammacintanti dhammasabhāvavijānanaṃ. Atidhāvantoti ṭhātabbamariyādāyaṃ aṭṭhatvā
analyzed: dhamma cintanti dhamma sabhāva vijānanam atidhāvanto ti ṭhātabbam ariyādāyam a ṭhatvā
translated: He overshoots the mark: he goes too far, not stopping at the right limit.

original: “cittuppādamattena dānaṃ hoti, sayameva cittaṃ attano ārammaṇaṃ hoti, sabbaṃ cittaṃ🔽asabhāvadhammārammaṇa”nti evamādinā atidhāvanto atikkamitvā pavattamāno. Cattārīti
analyzed: citta uppāda mattena dānam hoti sayam eva cittam attanaḥ ārammaṇam hoti sabbam cittam  evamādinā atidhāvantaḥ atikkamitvā pavattamāno cattāri iti
translated: “Giving is done by the mere arising of consciousness; the mind itself is the object of the mind; all mental phenomena are the object of mental phenomena.”

original: buddhavisayaiddhivisayakammavipākalokavisayasaṅkhātāni cattāri. Vuttañhetaṃ –🔽“Cattārimāni, bhikkhave, acinteyyāni na cintetabbāni, yāni cintento ummādassa vighātassa🔽bhāgī assa. Katamāni cattāri? Buddhānaṃ bhikkhave buddhavisayo acinteyyo na cintetabbo,🔽yaṃ cintento ummādassa vighātassa bhāgī assa. Jhāyissa, bhikkhave, jhānavisayo acinteyyo
analyzed: buddha visaya eddhi visaya kamma vipāka loka visaya saṅkhātāni cattāri vuttam ha etam  cattāri imāni bhikkhave acinteyyāni na cintetabbāni yāni cintentaḥ ummādassa vighātassa  bhāgī assa katamāni cattāri buddhānam bhikkhave buddha visayaḥ a cinteyyaḥ na cintetabbaḥ  yam cintentaḥ ummādassa vighātassa bhāgī assa jhāyissa bhikkhave jhāna visayaḥ a cinteyyaḥ
translated: Four: the four are called the Buddha’s range, the range of supernormal power, the range of kamma-result, and the range of the world. For this is said:

original: na cintetabbo…pe… kammavipāko, bhikkhave, acinteyyo na cintetabbo…pe… lokacintā bhikkhave
analyzed: na cintetabba upe kamma vipākaḥ bhikkhave a cinteyyaḥ na cintetabba upe loka cintā bhikkhave
translated: “Bhikkhus, there are these four things that should not be reflected upon. Reflecting upon them would lead to harm and suffering. What four? The range of the Buddhas is not to be reflected upon. Reflecting upon it would lead to harm and suffering. The range of concentration is not to be reflected upon. Reflecting upon it would lead to harm and suffering. The result of kamma is not to be reflected upon. Reflecting upon it would lead to harm and suffering. Worldly speculation is not to be reflected upon. Reflecting upon it would lead to harm and suffering” .

original: acinteyyā na cintetabbā…pe… imāni, bhikkhave, cattāri acinteyyāni na cintetabbāni,
analyzed: acinteyyā na cintetabbā āpe imāni bhikkhave cattāri acinteyyāni na cintetabbāni
translated: They are not to be reflected upon. … These four things are not to be reflected upon.

original: yāni cintento ummādassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti.🔽Tattha “acinteyyānī”ti tesaṃ sabhāvanidassanaṃ. “Na cintetabbānī”ti tattha kattabbatānidassanaṃ.
analyzed: yāni cintentaḥ ummādassa vighātassa bhāgī assa ati  tattha acinteyyāni iti tesam sabhāva nidassanam na cintetabbāni iti tattha kattabba tā nidassanam
translated: One who reflects upon them is a prey to obsession and bewilderment.”🔽Herein, “They are not to be reflected upon” shows their individual essences. “They are not to be reflected upon” shows what is to be done about them.

original: Tattha acinteyyānīti cintetumasakkuṇeyyāni, cintetuṃ araharūpāni na hontīti attho.🔽Acinteyyattā eva na cintetabbāni, kāmaṃ acinteyyānipi cha asādhāraṇādīni anussarantassa
analyzed: tattha acinteyyāni iti cintetum asakkuṇeyyāni cintetum araharūpāni na honti iti attho  a cinteyya tā eva na cintetabbāni kāmam a cinteyyāni pi cha a sādhāraṇa ādīni anussarantassa
translated: Herein, “They are not to be reflected upon” : they are not to be reflected upon because they cannot be reflected upon. The meaning is that they are not such as can be reflected upon.

original: kusaluppattihetubhāvato tāni cintetabbāni, imāni pana evaṃ na hontīti aphalabhāvato
analyzed: kusala uppatti hetu bhāvataḥ tāni cintetabbāni imāni pana evam na honti iti aphala bhāvato
translated: Because they are not to be reflected upon, they are not to be reflected upon. Although the six beginning with the unshared are not to be reflected upon, they are to be reflected upon by one who recollects them as a cause for the arousing of what is wholesome.

original: na cintetabbānīti adhippāyo. Tenevāha “yāni cintento ummādassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti.
analyzed: na cintetabbāni iti adhippāyaḥ tena iva āha yāni cintentaḥ ummādassa vighātassa bhāgī assa ati
translated: But these are not so. Therefore the intention is that they are not to be reflected upon because they are fruitless. Hence it is said: “One who reflects upon them is a prey to obsession and bewilderment.”

original: Tesanti tesaṃ piṭakānaṃ.
analyzed: tesanti tesam piṭakānam
translated: “These” : of those three Piṭakas.

original: Etanti etaṃ buddhavacanaṃ. Tivaggasaṅgahānīti sīlakkhandhavaggamahāvaggapāthikavaggasaṅkhātehi
analyzed: etat ti etam buddha vacanam ti vagga saṅgahāni iti sīlakkhandha vagga mahā vagga pāthika vagga saṅkhātehi
translated: “This” : this word of the Buddha. “Are included in the three sections” : in the section on the aggregate of virtue, in the Great Section, and in the Pāṭika Section.

original: tīhi vaggehi saṅgaho etesanti tivaggasaṅgahāni. Catuttiṃseva suttantāti gāthāya evamatthayojanā
analyzed: tīhi vaggehi saṅgahaḥ etesan ti ti vagga saṅgahāni catuttiṃsā iva suttantā ati gāthāya evam attha yojanā
translated: They are called “compilations in three sections” because they are compilations in three sections.

original: veditabbā – yassa nikāyassa suttagaṇanāto catuttiṃseva ca suttantā vaggasaṅgahavasena
analyzed: veditabbā yassa nikāyassa sutta gaṇanātaḥ catuttiṃsā iva ca suttantāḥ vagga saṅgaha vasena
translated: The meaning of the verse “With thirty-four suttas in three sections” should be understood as follows:🔽In the case of the collection of suttas in this collection, there are thirty-four suttas in three sections,

original: tayo vaggā assa saṅgahassāti tivaggo saṅgaho. Esa paṭhamo nikāyo dīghanikāyoti anulomiko
analyzed: tayaḥ vaggāḥ assa saṅgahassa ati ti vaggo saṅgahaḥ esa paṭhamaḥ nikāyaḥ dīgha nikāyaḥ ti anulomiko
translated: that is to say, in three sections compiled in vaggas. This is the first collection.🔽It is called “the Collection of Long Discourses” in the forward order,

original: apaccanīko, atthānulomanato anvatthanāmoti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: apaccanīkaḥ attha anulomanataḥ anvattha nāmaḥ ti vuttam hoti
translated: in the reverse order, and in the order of the meaning.🔽It is called “the Collection of Long Discourses” in the forward order because it is in the forward order of the meaning. In the reverse order because it is in the reverse order of the meaning. In the order of the meaning because it is in the order of the meaning.🔽In the forward order because it is in the forward order of the text. In the reverse order because it is in the reverse order of the text. In the order of the text because it is in the order of the text.🔽“But why is it called the Collection of Long Discourses?”—to answer this, he said “Because it contains long suttas.”🔽“But why is it called the Collection of Middle-Length Discourses?”—to answer this, he said “Because it contains middle-length suttas.”🔽“But why is it called the Collection of Connected Discourses?”—to answer this, he said “Because it contains connected suttas.”

original: Atthānulomanato anulomiko, anulomikattaṃyeva vibhāvetuṃ “kasmā panā”tiādimāha. Ekanikāyampīti🔽ekasamūhampi. Evaṃ cittanti evaṃ vicittaṃ. Yathayidanti yathā ime. Poṇikā cikkhallikā
analyzed: attha anulomanataḥ anulomikaḥ vibhāvetum kasmā pana ati ādim āha eka nikāyam pi iti  evam evam evam vicittam yathā ime poṇikā cikkhallikā
translated: “But why is it called the Collection of Numerical Discourses?”—to answer this, he said “Because it contains suttas in which the number is the main thing.”🔽“But why is it called the Collection of the Long Sayings?”—to answer this, he said “Because it contains long sayings.”

original: ca khattiyā, tesaṃ nivāso poṇikanikāyo cikkhallikanikāyoti vuccati. Evamādīni cettha🔽sādhakāni sāsanato ca lokato cāti evamādīni udāharaṇāni ettha nikāyasaddassa samūhanivāsānaṃ
analyzed: ca khattiyā tesam nivāso poṇika nikāyo cikkhallika nikāyo ti vuccati evamādīni ca ittha 🔽sādhakāni sāsanato ca lokato ca ati evamādīni udāharaṇāni ettha nikāya saddassa samūha nivāsānam
translated: “But why is it called the Collection of the Middle-Length Sayings?”—to answer this, he said “Because it contains middle-length sayings.”🔽“But why is it called the Collection of the Connected Discourses?”—to answer this, he said “Because it contains connected discourses.”

original: vācakabhāve sāsanato ca vohārato ca sādhakāni pamāṇānīti attho. Ettha paṭhamamudāharaṇaṃ
analyzed: vācaka bhāve sāsanato ca vohārato ca sādhakāni pamāṇāni iti atthaḥ ettha paṭhamam udāharaṇam
translated: The meaning is that the authorities are effective in the sense of the teaching and in the sense of usage in the verbal expression. The first example here

original: sāsanato sādhakavacanaṃ, dutiyaṃ lokatoti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: sāsanataḥ sādhaka vacanam dutiyam lokataḥ ti veditabbam
translated: should be understood as a statement effective in the sense of the teaching, and the second in the sense of the world.

original: Pañcadasavaggasaṅgahānīti mūlapariyāyavaggādīhi pañcadasahi vaggehi saṅgaho etesanti
analyzed: pañcadasa vagga saṅgahāni iti mūla pariyāya vagga ādīhi pañcadasahi vaggehi saṅgahaḥ etesan ti
translated: They are included in fifteen sections: they are included in the fifteen sections beginning with the Mūlapariyāya Vagga.

original: pañcadasavaggasaṅgahāni. Diyaḍḍhasataṃ dve ca suttānīti aḍḍhena dutiyaṃ diyaḍḍhaṃ,
analyzed: pañcadasa vagga saṅgahāni diyaḍḍha satam dve ca suttāni iti aḍḍhena dutiyam diyaḍḍham
translated: Two hundred and fifty-two suttas: the second half of a hundred is two hundred and fifty.

original: ekaṃ sataṃ dve paññāsasuttāni cāti attho. Yatthāti yasmiṃ nikāye. Pañcadasavaggapariggahoti
analyzed: ekam satam dve paññāsa suttāni ca ati atthaḥ yattha ati yasmin nikāye pañcadasa vagga pariggahaḥ ti
translated: The meaning is that there are two hundred and fifty-two suttas. In which: in which collection.

original: pañcadasahi vaggehi pariggahito saṅgahitoti attho.🔽Suttantānaṃ sahassāni sattasuttasatāni cāti pāṭhe suttantānaṃ satta sahassāni satta
analyzed: pañcadasahi vaggehi pariggahitaḥ saṅgahitaḥ iti attho  suttantānam sahassāni satta sutta satāni ca ati pāṭhe suttantānam satta sahassāni satta
translated: The fifteen-section classification: the meaning is that it is classified, included, in the fifteen sections.

original: satāni cāti yojetabbaṃ. Katthaci pana “satta suttasahassāni satta suttasatāni cā”tipi
analyzed: satāni ca ati yojetabbam katthaci pana satta sutta sahassāni satta sutta satāni
translated: Seven thousand and seven hundred suttas: in the reading “suttanta-sahassāni sattasuttasatāni ca,” the seven thousand and seven hundred should be construed together. But in some places the reading is “satta suttasahassāni satta suttasatāni ca.”

original: pāṭho. Saṃyuttasaṅgahoti saṃyuttanikāyassa saṅgaho.
analyzed: pāṭho saṃyutta saṅgaho ti saṃyutta nikāyassa saṅgahaḥ
translated: The Saṃyutta Saṅgaha: the Saṃyutta Saṅgaha of the Saṃyutta Nikāya.

original: Pubbe nidassitāti suttantapiṭakaniddese nidassitā. Vuttameva pakārantarena saṅkhipitvā
analyzed: pubbe nidassitā ti suttanta piṭaka niddese nidassitā vuttam eva pakāra antarena saṅkhipitvā
translated: “Previously indicated” : indicated in the exposition of the Sutta Piṭaka.

original: dassetuṃ “ṭhapetvā cattāro nikāye avasesaṃ buddhavacana”nti vuttaṃ. Sakalaṃ vinayapiṭakantiādinā
analyzed: dassetum ṭhapetvā cattāraḥ nikāye avasesam buddha vacanan ti vuttam sakalam vinayapiṭakam ti ādinā
translated: In order to show the same thing again in brief by another method, he says, “Except for the four Nikāyas, the rest is the word of the Buddha.”🔽For what is indicated by the words “the entire Vinaya Piṭaka” is stated again in brief by another method.

original: niddiṭṭhameva hi iminā pakārantarena saṅkhipitvā vuttaṃ. Tenevāha “ṭhapetvā caturopete”tiādi.
analyzed: niddiṭṭham eva hi iminā pakāra antarena saṅkhipitvā vuttam tena iva āha ṭhapetvā catura upeta itiādi
translated: Therefore he says, “Except for the four collections” and so on.

original: Tadaññanti tehi catūhi nikāyehi aññaṃ avasesanti attho.
analyzed: tad aññam ti tehi catūhi nikāyehi aññam avasesam ti attho
translated: “Other than that” : the meaning is, “other than those four Nikāyas, the rest.”🔽For all this is the word of the Buddha.

original: Sabbameva 2 hidanti sabbameva idaṃ buddhavacanaṃ. Navappabhedanti ettha kathaṃ panetaṃ
analyzed: sabbam eva hidam ti sabbam eva idam buddha vacanam nava ppabhedam ti ettha katham pana etam
translated: As to the ninefold classification: how is it that this is the ninefold classification?

original: navappabhedaṃ hoti. Tathā hi navahi aṅgehi vavatthitehi aññamaññasaṅkararahitehi🔽bhavitabbaṃ, tathā ca sati asuttasabhāvāneva geyyaṅgādīni siyuṃ, atha suttasabhāvāneva
analyzed: nava ppabhedam hoti tathā hi navahi aṅgehi vavatthitehi aññamañña saṅkara rahitehi  bhavitabbam tathā ca sati a sutta sabhāvān eva geyyaṅga ādīni siyum atha sutta sabhāvān eva
translated: For it must be defined by means of the nine factors without confusion of one with another.🔽And if that is so, the factors of prose-exposition, verse, etc., would be devoid of the nature of sutta.🔽But if the factors of verse, etc., were to have the nature of sutta, then the sutta factor would not exist separately.

original: geyyaṅgādīni, evaṃ sati suttanti visuṃ suttaṅgameva na siyā, evaṃ sante aṭṭhaṅgaṃ
analyzed: geyyaṅga ādīni evam sati suttanti visum suttaṅgam eva na siyā evam sante aṭṭhaṅgam
translated: And if that were so, the ninefold classification would be reduced to an eightfold classification.

original: sāsananti āpajjati. Apica “sagāthakaṃ suttaṃ geyyaṃ, niggāthakaṃ suttaṃ veyyākaraṇa”nti
analyzed: sāsananti āpajjati apica sagāthakam suttam geyyam niggāthakam suttam veyyākaraṇam ti
translated: He falls into the offense. Moreover, it is said in the commentary: “A sutta with a verse is a geyya; a sutta without a verse is a veyyākaraṇa.”

original: aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ. Suttañca nāma sagāthakaṃ vā siyā niggāthakaṃ vāti aṅgadvayeneva
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā ayam vuttam suttam ca nāma sagāthakam vā siyā niggāthakam vā ati aṅga dvayena iva
translated: And it is said in the Paṭisambhidā: “A sutta with a verse is a geyya; a sutta without a verse is a veyyākaraṇa.”

original: tadubhayaṃ saṅgahitanti tadubhayavinimuttañca suttaṃ udānādivisesasaññārahitaṃ natthi,
analyzed: tat ubhayam saṅgahitanti tad ubhaya vinimuttam ca suttam udāna ādi visesa saññā rahitam natthi
translated: So both of these are included under the two terms. There is no sutta that is not included under one or the other of these two terms.

original: yaṃ suttaṅgaṃ siyā, athāpi kathañci visuṃ suttaṅgaṃ siyā, maṅgalasuttādīnaṃ suttaṅgasaṅgaho🔽vā na siyā gāthābhāvato dhammapadādīnaṃ viya, geyyaṅgasaṅgaho vā siyā sagāthakattā
analyzed: yam suttaṅgam siyā atha api kathañci visum suttaṅgam siyā maṅgala sutta ādīnam suttaṅga saṅgahaḥ  vā na siyā gāthā bhāvataḥ dhamma pada ādīnam viya geyyaṅga saṅgahaḥ vā siyā sagāthaka ttā
translated: But if it is asked whether the sutta-collection is included under the sutta-collection, or whether the auspicious sutta, etc., are included under the sutta-collection, or whether the sutta-collection is included under the geyya-collection because it has verses, like the Sagāthāvagga,

original: sagāthakavaggassa viya, tathā ubhatovibhaṅgādīsu sagāthakappadesānanti? Vuccate –
analyzed: sagāthaka vaggassa viya tathā ubhatas vibhaṅga ādīsu sagāthaka ppadesānam ti vuccate
translated: or whether the auspicious sutta, etc., are included under the geyya-collection because they have verses, like the Dhammapada, or whether the two Vibhaṅgas are included under the geyya-collection because they have passages with verses, then we reply as follows:

original: Suttanti sāmaññavidhi, visesavidhayo pare;🔽Sanimittā niruḷhattā, sahatāññena nāññato.
analyzed: pare  sa nimittā niruḍha ttā sahatā aññena na aññatas
translated: The sutta is the general rule, the others are particular rules.🔽Because of the presence of a sign, because of the established usage,🔽Because of the presence of another, and because of the absence of another.

original: Yathāvuttassa dosassa, natthi etthāvagāhaṇaṃ;
analyzed: yathā vuttassa dosassa natthi ettha avagāhaṇam
translated: There is no contradiction in the above statement,

original: Tasmā asaṅkaraṃyeva, navaṅgaṃ satthusāsanaṃ.
analyzed: tasmai navaṅgam satthu sāsanam
translated: Therefore the ninefold teaching of the Master is not confused.

original: Sabbassapi hi buddhavacanassa suttanti ayaṃ sāmaññavidhi. Tathā hi “ettakaṃ tassa🔽bhagavato suttāgataṃ suttapariyāpannaṃ, sāvatthiyā suttavibhaṅge, sakavāde pañca
analyzed: sabbassa api hi buddha vacanassa ayam sāmañña vidhi tathā hi ettakam tassa  bhagavato sutta āgatam sutta pariyāpannam sāvatthiyā sutta vibhaṅge saka vāde pañca
translated: For all the Buddha’s word has this in common, namely, the name “discourse.” For this is said: “So much of the Blessed One’s word is in verse, belongs to the verses, is in the Sutta Vibhaṅga at Sāvatthī, in the section on one’s own standpoint, in the Pañcaka Nipāta, in the Paṭhama Vagga, in the Paṭhama Pañcaka.

original: suttasatānī”tiādivacanato vinayābhidhammapariyattivisesesupi suttavohāro dissati.
analyzed: sutta satāni iti ādi vacanataḥ vinaya abhidhamma pariyatti visesesu pi sutta vohāraḥ dissati
translated: For all the Buddha’s word is called “discourse” in the sense of “thread” . For it is said: “So much of the Blessed One’s word is in verse, belongs to the verse collection, is in the Sutta Vibhaṅga at Sāvatthī, is in the Sakavagga, and is five hundred suttas long” . And the expression “discourse” is found in the Vinaya and Abhidhamma Piṭakas too.

original: Teneva ca āyasmā mahākaccāno nettiyaṃ āha – “navavidhasuttantapariyeṭṭhī”ti. Tattha
analyzed: tena iva ca āyasmā mahākaccānaḥ nettiyam āha navavidha suttanta pariyeṭṭhī iti tattha
translated: That is why the venerable Mahākaccāna said in the Netti: “The search for the ninefold scriptures is the search for the ninefold scriptures” .

original: hi suttādivasena navaṅgassa sāsanassa pariyeṭṭhi pariyesanā atthavicāraṇā “navavidhasuttantapariyeṭṭhī”ti
analyzed: hi sutta ādi vasena navaṅgassa sāsanassa pariyeṭṭhi pariyesanā attha vicāraṇā navavidha suttanta pariyeṭṭhī iti
translated: For the search, the seeking, the investigation of the meaning of the ninefold scriptures of the Dispensation classed as sutta, etc., is called “the search for the ninefold scriptures” .

original: vuttā. Tadekadesesu pana geyyādayo visesavidhayo tena tena nimittena patiṭṭhitā.🔽Tathā hi geyyassa sagāthakattaṃ tabbhāvanimittaṃ. Lokepi hi sasilokaṃ sagāthakaṃ
analyzed: vuttā tad eka desesu pana geyya ādayaḥ visesa vidhayaḥ tena tena nimittena patiṭṭhitā  tathā hi geyyassa sagāthaka ttam tad bhāva nimittam loke pi hi sa silokam sa gāthakam
translated: But the special kinds classed as geyya, etc., are established by their respective characteristics.

original: vā cuṇṇiyaganthaṃ “geyya”nti vadanti. Gāthāvirahe pana sati pucchaṃ katvā visajjanabhāvo
analyzed: vā cuṇṇiya gantham vadanti gāthā virahe pana sati puccham katvā visajjana bhāvaḥ
translated: For the characteristic of the geyya is that it has a mixture of prose and verse. For in the world too, when a book has a mixture of prose and verse, it is called “geyya” . But when there is no verse, the characteristic is that it is a question-and-answer exposition.

original: veyyākaraṇassa tabbhāvanimittaṃ. Pucchāvisajjanañhi “byākaraṇa”nti vuccati. Byākaraṇameva
analyzed: veyyākaraṇassa tad bhāva nimittam pucchā visajjanam hi byākaraṇanti vuccati byākaraṇam eva
translated: and the question is the sign for the answer. For the answer is called “the explanation” . The explanation is

original: veyyākaraṇaṃ. Evaṃ sante sagāthakādīnampi pucchaṃ katvā visajjanavasena pavattānaṃ
analyzed: veyyākaraṇam evam sante sa gāthaka ādīnam pi puccham katvā visajjana vasena pavattānam
translated: the same as the answer . But if that is so, then the answer to a question in verse, etc., which occurs by way of an answer after a question,

original: veyyākaraṇabhāvo āpajjatīti? Nāpajjati. Geyyādisaññānaṃ anokāsabhāvato saokāsato
analyzed: veyyākaraṇa bhāvaḥ āpajjati iti na āpajjati geyya ādi saññānam anokāsa bhāvataḥ sa okāsato
translated: would be an explanation? It is not so. Because the name “verse,” etc., is not applicable, and because the name “explanation” is applicable,

original: anokāsavidhi balavāti “gāthāvirahe satī”ti visesitattā ca. Tathā hi dhammapadādīsu🔽kevalaṃ gāthābandhesu sagāthakattepi somanassañāṇamayikagāthāyuttesu “vuttañheta”ntiādivacanasambandhesu
analyzed: anokāsa vidhi balavāti gāthā virahe sati iti visesita ttā ca tathā hi dhamma pada ādīsu  kevalam gāthā bandhesu sa gāthaka tte pi somanassa ñāṇa mayika gāthā yuttesu vuttam hetat ti ādi vacana sambandhesu
translated: and because the rule that the applicable is stronger than the inapplicable is valid, and because the words “if there is no verse” are specific. For thus,🔽in the Dhammapada, etc., in the Suttas which are only in verse, in the Sagathaka Suttas which are a combination of prose and verse, in the🔽Somanassūpavicārasutta, in the Gāthāsamganikasutta, in the Vuttanhattasutta, in the Abhidhamma Suttas, in the Abbhūtadhamma Suttas,

original: abbhutadhammapaṭisaṃyuttesu ca suttavisesesu yathākkamaṃ gāthāudānaitivuttakaabbhutadhammasaññā
analyzed: abbhuta dhamma paṭisaṃyuttesu ca sutta visesesu yathākkamam gāthā udāna etivuttaka abbhuta dhamma saññā
translated: the names “verse,” “summary,” “thus was it said,” “abnormal dhamma,” are respectively established. For here, although there is a combination of the

original: patiṭṭhitā. Ettha hi satipi saññantaranimittayoge anokāsasaññānaṃ balavabhāveneva
analyzed: patiṭṭhitāḥ ettha hi sati pi anokāsa saññānam balava bhāvena iva
translated: signs for other names, because of the strength of the applicable names,

original: gāthādisaññā patiṭṭhitā, tathā satipi gāthābandhabhāve bhagavato atītāsu jātīsu cariyānubhāvappakāsakesu
analyzed: gāthā ādi saññā patiṭṭhitā tathā sati api gāthābandha bhāve bhagavataḥ atītāsu jātīsu cariyā anubhāva ppakāsakesu
translated: The name “verses” is established because of the presence of verses, and so on.🔽And although the verses are present, the name “Jātaka” is established because of the manifestation of the influence of the past lives of the Exalted One.

original: jātakasaññā patiṭṭhitā, satipi pañhāvisajjanabhāve sagāthakatte ca kesuci suttantesu🔽vedassa labhāpanato vedallasaññā patiṭṭhitāti evaṃ tena tena sagāthakattādinā nimittena
analyzed: jātaka saññā patiṭṭhitā sati pi pañhā visajjana bhāve sagāthaka tte ca kesuci suttantesu  vedassa labhāpanataḥ vedalla saññā patiṭṭhitā ati evam tena tena sagāthaka ttā ādinā nimittena
translated: And although the answers to questions are present, and although there are verses in some suttas,🔽the name “vedalla” is established because of the obtaining of the “vedalla” .

original: tesu tesu suttavisesesu geyyādisaññā patiṭṭhitāti visesavidhayo suttaṅgato pare geyyādayo.
analyzed: tesu tesu sutta visesesu geyya ādi saññā patiṭṭhitā ati visesa vidhayaḥ suttaṅgataḥ pare geyya ādayo
translated: Thus the names “geya” and the rest are established in these and those particular suttas because of this and that particular reason, such as the presence of verses, and so on.

original: Yaṃ panettha geyyaṅgādinimittarahitaṃ, taṃ suttaṅgaṃ visesasaññāparihārena sāmaññasaññāya pavattanato.
analyzed: yam pana ittha geyyaṅga ādi nimitta rahitam tam suttaṅgam visesa saññā parihārena sāmañña saññāya pavattanato
translated: But that sutta which is devoid of the reason for the names “geya” and the rest is the sutta-ṅga. It is so called because it occurs by the name “sutta” in the sense of generality, avoiding the particular names.

original: Nanu ca evaṃ santepi sagāthakaṃ suttaṃ geyyaṃ, niggāthakaṃ suttaṃ veyyākaraṇanti
analyzed: nanu ca evam sante pi sagāthakam suttam geyyam niggāthakam suttam veyyākaraṇam ti
translated: But if that is so, then since the sutta with verses is “geya” and the sutta without verses is “veyyākaraṇa,”🔽how can there be a sutta-ṅga?

original: suttaṅgaṃ na sambhavatīti codanā tadavatthā evāti? Na tadavatthā. Sodhitattā. Sodhitañhi
analyzed: suttaṅgam na sambhavati iti codanā tad avatthā eva ati na tad avatthā sodhita tā sodhitañhi
translated: This objection is not valid, because the sutta-ṅga has already been established.

original: pubbe gāthāvirahe sati pucchāvisajjanabhāvo veyyākaraṇassa tabbhāvanimittanti. Yañca
analyzed: pubbe gāthā virahe sati pucchā visajjana bhāvaḥ veyyākaraṇassa tad bhāva nimittan ti yat ca
translated: and the question-and-answer method is the reason for the prose-exposition part.

original: vuttaṃ “gāthābhāvato maṅgalasuttādīnaṃ suttaṅgasaṅgaho na siyā”ti, taṃ na, niruḷhattāti.
analyzed: vuttam gāthā bhāvataḥ maṅgala sutta ādīnam suttaṅga saṅgahaḥ na siyā iti tam na niruḷha ttā ti
translated: And as for the objection that “the ‘thread’ part would not be included in the case of the Mangala Sutta, etc., because they have no verses,” that is not so, because they are established as suttas.

original: Niruḷho hi maṅgalasuttādīnaṃ suttabhāvo. Na hi tāni dhammapadabuddhavaṃsādayo viya
analyzed: niruḷhaḥ hi maṅgala sutta ādīnam sutta bhāvaḥ na hi tāni dhamma pada buddha vaṃsa ādayaḥ viya
translated: For the status of the Mangala Sutta, etc., as suttas is established. For they are not known as suttas by virtue of having verses, as in the case of the Dhammapada and the Buddhavamsa, etc.,

original: gāthābhāvena paññātāni, atha kho suttabhāveneva. Teneva hi aṭṭhakathāyaṃ suttanāmakanti
analyzed: gāthā bhāvena paññātāni atha kho sutta bhāvena iva tena iva hi aṭṭhakathā ayam sutta nāmakanti
translated: but rather by virtue of being suttas. That is why in the commentary the name “sutta” is given to them.

original: nāmaggahaṇaṃ kataṃ. Yaṃ pana vuttaṃ “sagāthakattā geyyaṅgasaṅgaho siyā”ti, tampi🔽natthi. Yasmā sahatāññena. Sahabhāvo hi nāma atthato aññena hoti, saha gāthāhīti🔽ca sagāthakaṃ. Na ca maṅgalasuttādīsu gāthāvinimutto koci suttappadeso atthi, yo
analyzed: nāma ggahaṇam katam yat pana vuttam sa gāthaka ttā geyyaṅga saṅgahaḥ siyā ti tat pi  na atthi yasmā sahatā aññena sahabhāvaḥ hi nāma atthataḥ aññena hoti saha gāthāhi iti  ca sa gāthakam na ca maṅgala sutta ādīsu gāthā vinimuttaḥ koci sutta ppadesaḥ atthi yaḥ
translated: But as for the objection that “the ‘prose-exposition’ part would be included because they have verses,” that is not so either.🔽Because they have verses together with something else. For the state of being together with something else is in fact something else, and “together with verses” is “having verses.” And there is no passage in the Mangala Sutta, etc., that is devoid of verses and could be called “together with verses.”

original: “saha gāthāhī”ti vucceyya. Nanu ca gāthāsamudāyo gāthāhi añño hoti, tathā ca tassa
analyzed: saha gāthāhi iti vucceyya nanu ca gāthā samudāyaḥ gāthāhi aññaḥ hoti tathā ca tassa
translated: But is not the collection of verses something else than the verses? And so too the collection of prose-exposition?

original: vasena saha gāthāhīti sagāthakanti sakkā vattunti? Taṃ na. Na hi avayavavinimutto🔽samudāyo nāma koci atthi. Yampi vuttaṃ “ubhatovibhaṅgādīsu sagāthakappadesānaṃ geyyaṅgasaṅgaho
analyzed: vasena saha gāthāhi iti sagāthakam ti sakkā vattunti tam na na hi avayava vinimuttaḥ  samudāyaḥ nāma koci atthi yam pi vuttam ubhatas vibhaṅga ādīsu sagāthaka ppadesānam geyyaṅga saṅgaho
translated: But that is not so. For there is no such thing as a collection apart from its components.🔽And as for the words “The inclusion of the sections with verse in the two Vibhaṅgas, etc., is the verse section” , that is not so in the sense of another name for it. For those verses are different, being included in the Jātaka, etc., and the two Vibhaṅgas, etc.,

original: siyā”ti, tampi na aññato. Aññāyeva hi tā gāthā jātakādipariyāpannattā. Atho na tāhi
analyzed: siyā ti tat pi na aññatas aññāya iva hi tāḥ gāthāḥ jātaka ādi pariyāpanna ttāḥ atho na tāhi
translated: do not have those verses as their verse section.

original: ubhatovibhaṅgādīnaṃ geyyaṅgabhāvoti evaṃ suttādīnaṃ aṅgānaṃ aññamaññasaṅkarābhāvo veditabbo.
analyzed: ubhatas vibhaṅga ādīnam geyyaṅga bhāvaḥ ti evam sutta ādīnam aṅgānam aññamañña saṅkara abhāvaḥ veditabbo
translated: So the absence of confusion between the different kinds of Thread, etc., should be understood in this way.🔽Now, in order to show the nine-factored Thread, etc., by dividing it up, he said “Herein, the two Vibhaṅgas, the Niddesa, the Khandhakas, the Parivāra” , etc.

original: Idāni suttādīni navaṅgāni vibhajitvā dassento āha “tattha ubhatovibhaṅganiddesakhandhakaparivārā”tiādi. Tattha niddeso nāma suttanipāte –
analyzed: idāni sutta ādīni navaṅgāni vibhajitvā dassentaḥ āha tattha ubhatas vibhaṅga niddesa khandhaka parivāra ati ādi tattha niddesaḥ nāma sutta nipāte
translated: Herein, the Niddesa is the Suttanipāta,🔽“When one who longs for sense desires

original: “Kāmaṃ kāmayamānassa, tassa cetaṃ samijjhati;
analyzed: kāmam kāmayamānassa tassa cetam samijjhati
translated: And strives to get them succeeds,🔽He is elated, thinking ‘I have gained’

original: Addhā pītimano hoti, laddhā macco yadicchatī”ti. –
analyzed: addhā pītimanaḥ hoti laddhā maccaḥ yat icchati iti
translated: Like a man who has won at a gamble. ”

original: Ādinā āgatassa aṭṭhakavaggassa,
analyzed: ādinā āgatassa aṭṭhaka vaggassa
translated: and the Aṭṭhakavagga that begins thus:

original: “Kenassu nivuto loko, (iccāyasmā ajito;)
analyzed: kenassu nivutaḥ lokaḥ iccā ayasmai ajitaḥ
translated: “What is the world enveloped in?

original: Kenassu nappakāsati;
analyzed: na ppakāsati
translated: What is it that does not shine?

original: Kissābhilepanaṃ brūsi,
analyzed: kissa abhilepanam brūsi
translated: What is it that they anoint with oil?

original: Kiṃsu tassa mahabbhaya”nti. –
analyzed: kiṃsu tassa mahabbhayanti
translated: What is it that they fear so much? ”

original: Ādinā āgatassa pārāyanavaggassa,
analyzed: ādinā āgatassa pārāyana vaggassa
translated: The Niddesa is the commentary on the Ādinā and Pārāyana vaggas🔽and on the Khaggavisāṇa sutta, which begins:

original: “Sabbesu bhūtesu nidhāya daṇḍaṃ,
analyzed: sabbesu bhūtesu nidhāya daṇḍam
translated: “Having laid aside the rod against all beings,

original: Aviheṭhayaṃ aññatarampi tesaṃ;
analyzed: aviheṭhayam aññataram pi tesam
translated: harmless among all that is,

original: Na puttamiccheyya kuto sahāyaṃ,
analyzed: na puttam iccheyya kutas sahāyam
translated: he should not wish for a son, much less a friend;

original: Eko care khaggavisāṇakappo”ti. –🔽Ādinā āgatassa khaggavisāṇasuttassa ca tadatthavibhāgavasena satthukappena āyasmatā
analyzed: ekaḥ care khagga visāṇa kappo ti  ādinā āgatassa khaggavisāṇa suttassa ca tad attha vibhāga vasena satthu kappena āyasmatā
translated: he should wander alone like the horn of the rhinoceros.”

original: dhammasenāpatisāriputtattherena kato niddeso mahāniddeso cūḷaniddesoti ca vuccati.
analyzed: dhammasenāpati sāriputta therena kataḥ niddesaḥ mahāniddeso cūḷaniddeso ti ca vuccati
translated: The Niddesa is called the Mahāniddesa and the Cūḷaniddesa according to whether it is the commentary on the Ādinā or the Khaggavisāṇa sutta.

original: Evamidha niddesassa suttaṅgasaṅgaho bhadantabuddhaghosācariyena dassitoti veditabbo.🔽Aññatthāpi ca dīghanikāyaṭṭhakathādīsu sabbattha ubhatovibhaṅganiddesakhandhakaparivārāti
analyzed: evam idha niddesassa suttaṅga saṅgahaḥ bhadanta buddhaghosācariyena dassito ti veditabbo  aññattha api ca dīgha nikāya ṭṭhakathā ādīsu sabbattha ubhatas vibhaṅga niddesa khandhaka parivārā ti
translated: It is to be understood that the inclusion of the Niddesa in the Sutta Piṭaka is shown here in this way by the Elder Buddhaghosa, the Bhadanta.🔽And elsewhere too, in the Dīgha Nikāya Commentary and so on, it is shown everywhere that the inclusion of the Niddesa is in the Sutta Piṭaka and in the Vibhaṅga, the Paṭisambhidā, and the Khuddaka.

original: niddesassa suttaṅgasaṅgaho eva dassito. Ācariyadhammapālattherenapi nettipakaraṇaṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: niddesassa suttaṅga saṅgahaḥ eva dassitaḥ ācariya dhammapāla ttherena api
translated: And the Elder Dhammapāla, the teacher, has also shown in the Nettipakarana Commentary

original: evametassa suttaṅgasaṅgahova kathito. Keci pana niddesassa gāthāveyyākaraṇaṅgesu
analyzed: evam etassa kathito keci pana niddesassa
translated: So it is called a “knot of the tangle of mental proliferation” in this way.🔽But some say that it is included in the two, the description and the verse-explanation,

original: dvīsu saṅgahaṃ vadanti. Vuttañhetaṃ niddesaaṭṭhakathāyaṃ upasenattherena –
analyzed: dvīsu saṅgaham vadanti vuttam ha etam niddesa aṭṭhakathāyam upasena therena
translated: For this is said in the Niddesa Commentary by the Elder Upasena:

original: “Tadetaṃ vinayapiṭakaṃ suttantapiṭakaṃ abhidhammapiṭakanti tīsu piṭakesu suttantapiṭakapariyāpannaṃ,
analyzed: tat etam vinaya piṭakam suttanta piṭakam abhidhamma piṭakam ti tīsu piṭakesu suttanta piṭaka pariyāpannam
translated: “This Vinaya Piṭaka is included in the three Piṭakas, namely, the Vinaya Piṭaka, the Suttanta Piṭaka, and the Abhidhamma Piṭaka.

original: dīghanikāyo majjhimanikāyo saṃyuttanikāyo aṅguttaranikāyo khuddakanikāyoti pañcasu🔽mahānikāyesu khuddakamahānikāye pariyāpannaṃ, suttaṃ geyyaṃ veyyākaraṇaṃ gāthā udānaṃ
analyzed: dīgha nikāyaḥ majjhima nikāyaḥ saṃyutta nikāyaḥ aṅguttara nikāyaḥ khuddaka nikāyaḥ iti pañcasu  mahā nikāyesu khuddaka mahā nikāye pariyāpannam suttam geyyam veyyākaraṇam gāthāḥ udānam
translated: It is included in the five great Piṭakas, namely, the Dīgha Nikāya, the Majjhima Nikāya, the Saṃyutta Nikāya, the Aṅguttara Nikāya, and the Khuddaka Nikāya.

original: itivuttakaṃ jātakaṃ abbhutadhammaṃ vedallanti navasu satthusāsanaṅgesu yathāsambhavaṃ
analyzed: itivuttakam jātakam abbhuta dhammam vedallanti navasu satthu sāsana aṅgesu yathāsambhavam
translated: It is included in the nine parts of the Master’s Dispensation, namely, sutta, geyya, veyyākaraṇa, gāthā, udāna, itivuttaka, jātaka, abbhutadhamma, and vedalla, as appropriate.

original: gāthāveyyākaraṇaṅgadvayasaṅgahita”nti.
translated: It is included in the two parts, the description and the verse-explanation.”

original: Ettha tāva katthaci pucchāvisajjanasabhāvato niddesekadesassa veyyākaraṇaṅgasaṅgaho
analyzed: ettha tāva katthaci pucchā visajjana sabhāvataḥ niddesa ikadesassa veyyākaraṇa aṅga saṅgaho
translated: Herein, firstly, in some places the description is included in the verse-explanation part because of the similarity of question and answer.

original: yujjatu nāma, gāthaṅgasaṅgaho pana kathaṃ yujjeyyāti idamettha vīmaṃsitabbaṃ. Dhammapadādīnaṃ
analyzed: yujjatu nāma gāthaṅga saṅgahaḥ pana katham yujjeyya iti idam ettha vīmaṃsitabbam dhamma pada ādīnam
translated: But how can the collection of verses be called a collection of verses? This is what should be examined here.🔽For the mere fact of being in verse is the reason for the collection of verses being called a collection of verses, just as the Dhammapada, etc., are.

original: viya hi kevalaṃ gāthābandhabhāvo gāthaṅgassa tabbhāvanimittaṃ. Dhammapadādīsu hi
analyzed: viya hi kevalam gāthābandha bhāvaḥ gāthaṅgassa tad bhāva nimittam dhamma pada ādīsu hi
translated: For the name “verses” is established in the Dhammapada, etc.,

original: kevalaṃ gāthābandhesu gāthāsamaññā patiṭṭhitā, niddese ca na koci kevalo gāthābandhappadeso
analyzed: kevalam gāthā bandhesu gāthā samaññā patiṭṭhitā niddese ca na koci kevalaḥ gāthābandha ppadeso
translated: only in what is in verse. And in the Niddesa no single word in verse is found.🔽For the mere exposition of the verses included in the Aṭṭhakavagga, etc.,

original: upalabbhati. Sammāsambuddhena bhāsitānaṃyeva hi aṭṭhakavaggādisaṅgahitānaṃ gāthānaṃ
analyzed: upalabbhati sammāsambuddhena bhāsitānam yeva hi aṭṭhaka vagga ādi saṅgahitānam gāthānam
translated: and spoken by the Fully Enlightened One was made by the General of the Dhamma .

original: niddesamattaṃ dhammasenāpatinā kataṃ. Atthavibhajanatthaṃ ānītāpi hi tā aṭṭhakavaggādisaṅgahitā
analyzed: niddesa mattam dhammasenāpatinā katam attha vibhajana attham ānītā api hi tāḥ aṭṭhaka vagga ādi saṅgahitā
translated: And although they are brought in for the sake of explaining the meaning, those verses included in the Aṭṭhakavagga, etc.,

original: niddisitabbā mūlagāthāyo suttanipātapariyāpannattā aññāyevāti na niddesasaṅkhyaṃ
analyzed: niddisitabbāḥ mūlagāthāyo sutta nipāta pariyāpanna ttā aññāya iva ati na niddesa saṅkhyam
translated: are not reckoned as exposition because they are included in the Suttanipāta and so are the original verses to be expounded.

original: gacchanti ubhatovibhaṅgādīsu āgatabhāvepi taṃ vohāraṃ alabhamānā jātakādigāthāpariyāpannā
analyzed: gacchanti ubhatas vibhaṅga ādīsu āgata bhāve pi tam vohāram a labhamānāḥ jātaka ādi gāthā pariyāpannā
translated: And although they occur in the two Vibhaṅgas, etc., they do not get the name “exposition” any more than do the verses included in the Jātaka, etc.

original: gāthāyo viya, tasmā kāraṇantaramettha gavesitabbaṃ, yuttataraṃ vā gahetabbaṃ.
analyzed: gāthāyaḥ viya tasmā kāraṇa antaram ettha gavesitabbam yuttataram vā gahetabbam
translated: So some other reason must be sought for their inclusion here, or else they can be taken as included because they are appropriate.

original: Nālakasuttatuvaṭṭakasuttānīti ettha nālakasuttaṃ nāma padumuttarassa bhagavato sāvakaṃ
analyzed: nālaka sutta tuvaṭṭaka suttāni iti ettha nālaka suttam nāma padumuttarassa bhagavataḥ sāvakam
translated: The Thread of the Nail and the Thread of the Tuvataka . Herein, the Thread of the Nail is the Thread called “The Nail” , which is the Thread of the Elder Nail, the nephew of the Seer Asita, who, after seeing a disciple of the Blessed One Padumuttara who was practising the Way to Worthiness, desired to know the meaning of it, and after fulfilling the Perfections for a hundred thousand cycles of time,

original: moneyyapaṭipadaṃ paṭipannaṃ disvā tadatthaṃ abhikaṅkhamānena tato pabhuti kappasatasahassaṃ
analyzed: moneyya paṭipadam paṭipannam disvā tad attham abhikaṅkhamānena tatas pabhuti kappa sata sahassam
translated: on the seventh day after the Blessed One had set the Wheel of the True Idea rolling, asked him about the Way to Worthiness with the two verses beginning, “ This is not known by me” ,

original: pāramiyo pūretvā āgatena asitassa isino bhāgineyyena nālakattherena dhammacakkappavattitadivasato
analyzed: pāramiyaḥ pūretvā āgatena asitassa isino bhāgineyyena nālakattherena dhamma cakka ppavattita divasato
translated: and the Blessed One answered him with the verse beginning, “ You will come to know the Way to Worthiness” , which is the Thread that illustrates the Way to Worthiness.🔽The Thread of the Tuvataka is the Thread called “The Tuvataka” , which is the Thread spoken by the Elder Tuvataka, who, after seeing a disciple of the Blessed One Padumuttara who was practising the Way to Worthiness, desired to know the meaning of it, and after fulfilling the Perfections for a hundred thousand cycles of time,

original: sattame divase “aññātameta”ntiādīhi dvīhi gāthāhi moneyyapaṭipadaṃ puṭṭhena bhagavatā
analyzed: sattame divase aññātam etat ti ādīhi dvīhi gāthāhi moneyya paṭipadam puṭṭhena bhagavatā
translated: on the seventh day after the Blessed One had set the Wheel of the True Idea rolling, asked him about the Way to Worthiness with the two verses beginning, “ This is not known by me” ,

analyzed: moneyyam te upaññissanti ādinā nālaka ttherassa bhāsitam moneyya paṭipadā paridīpakam
translated: and the Blessed One answered him with the verse beginning, “ You will come to know the Way to Worthiness” , which is the Thread that illustrates the Way to Worthiness.

original: suttaṃ. Tuvaṭṭakasuttaṃ pana mahāsamayasuttantadesanāya sannipatitesu devesu “kā🔽nu kho arahattappattiyā paṭipattī”ti uppannacittānaṃ ekaccānaṃ devatānaṃ tamatthaṃ
analyzed: suttam tuvaṭṭaka suttam pana mahā samaya suttanta desanāya sannipatitesu devesu kā  nu kho arahatta pattiyāḥ paṭipatti iti uppanna cittānam ekaccānam devatānam tam attham
translated: The Thread of the Tuvataka is the Thread called “The Tuvataka” , which is the Thread spoken by the Elder Tuvataka, who, after seeing a disciple of the Blessed One Padumuttara who was practising the Way to Worthiness, desired to know the meaning of it, and after fulfilling the Perfections for a hundred thousand cycles of time,🔽on the seventh day after the Blessed One had set the Wheel of the True Idea rolling, asked him about the Way to Worthiness with the two verses beginning, “ This is not known by me” ,

original: pakāsetuṃ “pucchāmi taṃ ādiccabandhū”tiādinā nimmitabuddhena attānaṃ pucchāpetvā
analyzed: pakāsetum pucchāmi tam ādiccabandhu uti ādinā nimmita buddhena attānam
translated: and the Blessed One answered him with the verse beginning, “ You will come to know the Way to Worthiness” , which is the Thread that illustrates the Way to Worthiness.🔽The Thread of the Tuvataka is the Thread called “The Tuvataka” , which is the Thread spoken by the Elder Tuvataka

original: “mūlaṃ papañcasaṅkhāyā”tiādinā bhāsitaṃ suttaṃ. Evamidhasuttanipāte āgatānaṃ maṅgalasuttādīnaṃ🔽suttaṅgasaṅgaho dassito, tattheva āgatānaṃ asuttanāmikānaṃ suddhikagāthānaṃ gāthaṅgasaṅgahañca
analyzed: mūlam pa pañca saṅkhāya ati ādinā bhāsitam suttam evam idha sutta nipāte āgatānam maṅgala sutta ādīnam  suttaṅga saṅgahaḥ dassitaḥ tattha eva āgatānam a sutta nāmikānam suddhika gāthānam gāthaṅga saṅgahañca
translated: The sutta beginning, “The root of the formation of determinations” .🔽Thus the inclusion of the sutta-collection in the Sutta-collection has been shown.🔽He will show the inclusion of the verse-collection in the Sutta-collection in the Sutta-collection commentary,

original: dassayissati, evaṃ sati suttanipātaṭṭhakathārambhe –
analyzed: dassayissati evam sati sutta nipāta ṭṭhakathā ārambhe
translated: beginning thus:🔽“Why is it called the Sutta-collection,

original: “Gāthāsatasamākiṇṇo, geyyabyākaraṇaṅkito;
analyzed: gāthā sata samākiṇṇaḥ
translated: Which is full of a hundred suttas,

original: Kasmā suttanipātoti, saṅkhamesa gatoti ce”ti. –
analyzed: kasmā sutta nipāto ti saṅkhamesa gato ti ca iti
translated: And marked with geyya and veyyākaraṇa? ”

original: Sakalassapi suttanipātassa geyyaveyyākaraṇaṅgasaṅgaho kasmā coditoti? Nāyaṃ virodho.
analyzed: sakalassa api sutta nipātassa geyya veyyākaraṇa aṅga saṅgaho kasmā coditaḥ iti na ayam virodho
translated: Why is the inclusion of the geyya and veyyākaraṇa collections in the whole Sutta-collection asked about? There is no contradiction here.

original: Kevalañhi tattha codakena sagāthakattaṃ katthaci pucchāvisajjanamattañca gahetvā
analyzed: kevalam hi tattha ca udakena sagāthaka ttam katthaci pucchā visajjana mattam ca gahetvā
translated: For the questioner has taken the inclusion as merely the inclusion of the verses and the inclusion of the questions and answers in some places,

analyzed: codanā mattam katan ti gahetabbam aññathā sutta nipāte niggāthakassa suttassa iva abhāvato

analyzed: veyyākaraṇa aṅga saṅgahaḥ na codetabbaḥ siyā iti sa gāthā vaggaḥ geyyan ti yojetabbam aṭṭhahi

original: pītisomanassaṃ. Laddhā laddhāti labhitvā labhitvā, punappunaṃ labhitvāti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: pīti somanassam laddhā laddhā ati labhitvā labhitvā punappunam labhitvā iti vuttam hoti

translated: Desiring to tell, he said, “How, by the mass of Dhamma? ” etc. Herein, by the mass of Dhamma means

original: dhammarāsivasena. Dvāsīti sahassāni buddhato gaṇhiṃ, dve sahassāni bhikkhuto gaṇhinti🔽sambandho. Tattha buddhato gaṇhinti sammāsambuddhato uggaṇhiṃ, dvesahassādhikāni🔽asīti dhammakkhandhasahassāni satthu santikā adhigaṇhinti attho. Dve sahassāni bhikkhutoti🔽dve dhammakkhandhasahassāni bhikkhuto uggaṇhiṃ, dhammasenāpatiādīnaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ santikā🔽adhigaṇhiṃ. Sāriputtattherādīhi bhāsitānaṃ sammādiṭṭhisuttantādīnaṃ vasena hi “dve🔽sahassāni bhikkhuto”ti vuttaṃ. Caturāsīti sahassānīti tadubhayaṃ samodhānetvā catusahassādhikāni
analyzed: dhammarāsi vasena dvāsīti sahassāni buddhataḥ dve sahassāni bhikkhutaḥ gaṇhinti  sambandhaḥ tattha buddhataḥ gaṇhinti sammāsambuddhataḥ uggaṇhim dvi sahassa adhikāni  asīti dhammakkhandha sahassāni satthu santikā adhigaṇhinti attho dve sahassāni bhikkhuto ti  dve dhammakkhandha sahassāni bhikkhutaḥ uggaṇhim dhammasenāpati ādīnam bhikkhūnam santikā  sāriputta thera ādīhi bhāsitānam sammādiṭṭhi suttanta ādīnam vasena hi dve  sahassāni bhikkhuto ti vuttam caturāsīti sahassāni iti tat ubhayam samodhānetvā catu sahassa adhikāni
translated: by the herd of Dhamma. I learned from the Enlightened One eighty-four thousand dhammas, and two thousand from bhikkhus.

original: asīti sahassāni. Ye me dhammā pavattinoti ye dhammā mama pavattino pavattamānā paguṇā
analyzed: asīti sahassāni ye me dhammā pavattinaḥ ti ye dhammā mama pavattinaḥ pavattamānā paguṇā
translated: This is the connexion. Herein, I learned from the Enlightened One means I learned from the Fully Enlightened One. The meaning is that I learned from the Master eighty-four thousand dhammas in excess of two thousand. Two thousand from bhikkhus means I learned two thousand dhammas from bhikkhus. I learned from bhikkhus such as the General of the Dhamma. For it is by way of such suttas as the Sammādiṭṭhi Sutta that “two thousand from bhikkhus” is said. Eighty-four thousand means adding those two together, eighty-four thousand in excess of four thousand. Those dhammas that occur to me means those dhammas that occur to me, that occur to me as familiar,

original: vācuggatā jivhagge parivattanti, te dhammā caturāsīti dhammakkhandhasahassānīti vuttaṃ🔽hoti. Keci pana “ye ime”ti padacchedaṃ katvā “ye ime dhammā buddhassa bhagavato bhikkhūnañca
analyzed: vācuggatāḥ jivhagge parivattanti te dhammā catur asīti dhammakkhandha sahassāni iti vuttam  hoti keci pana ye ime iti pada chedam katvā ye ime dhammā buddhassa bhagavataḥ bhikkhūnañca
translated: and they turn round in the tip of his tongue. These ideas are the eighty-four thousand doctrinal expressions, is what is said.

original: pavattino, tehi pavattitā, tesvāhaṃ dvāsīti sahassāni buddhato gaṇhiṃ, dve sahassāni
analyzed: pavattinaḥ tehi pavatti tā tesu aham dvāsīti sahassāni buddhataḥ dve sahassāni
translated: But some, taking the analysis of the words thus ‘ These ideas that occur in the Blessed One and in bhikkhus ‘, say that the connexion is as follows: ‘ I learned eighty-four thousand doctrinal expressions from the Enlightened One, and two thousand from bhikkhus,

original: bhikkhutoti evaṃ caturāsīti dhammakkhandhasahassānī”ti evamettha sambandhaṃ vadanti.🔽Ettha ca subhasuttaṃ gopakamoggallānasuttañca parinibbute bhagavati ānandattherena
analyzed: bhikkhutaḥ ti evam caturāsīti dhammakkhandha sahassāni iti evam ettha sambandham vadanti  ettha ca subha suttam gopakamoggallāna suttañca parinibbute bhagavati ānanda ttherena
translated: so that is how there are eighty-four thousand doctrinal expressions ‘.

original: vuttattā caturāsītidhammakkhandhasahassesu antogadhaṃ hoti, na hotīti? Tattha paṭisambhidāgaṇṭhipade
analyzed: vutta ttā caturāsīti dhammakkhandha sahassesu antogadham hoti na hoti iti tattha paṭisambhidā gaṇṭhi pade
translated: And here, since the Subha and Gopaka Moggallana Suttas were spoken by the Elder Ananda after the Blessed One’s final attainment of Nibbana, are they included among the eighty-four thousand doctrinal expressions or not?🔽Herein, in the first place, in the Paṭisambhidā it is said as follows: ‘ The doctrinal expressions spoken by the Blessed One himself are included only in what was learned from bhikkhus. He said this:

original: tāva idaṃ vuttaṃ “sayaṃ vuttadhammakkhandhānaṃ bhikkhuto gahiteyeva saṅgahetvā evamāhāti
analyzed: tāva idam vuttam sayam vutta dhammakkhandhānam bhikkhutaḥ gahitā iya iva saṅgahetvā evam āha ati
translated: This is said: “The bhikkhu has grasped the aggregates of the Dhamma spoken by himself, and having grasped them thus he says:

original: daṭṭhabba”nti. Bhagavatā pana dinnanaye ṭhatvā bhāsitattā sayaṃ vuttadhammakkhandhānampi
analyzed: daṭṭhabbanti bhagavatā pana dinna naye ṭhatvā bhāsita ttā sayam vutta dhamma kkhandhānam pi
translated: But since they were spoken by the disciples in accordance with the method given by the Blessed One, it is more appropriate to include them in the collection of the Dhamma spoken by the Buddha,

original: “buddhato gaṇhi”nti ettha saṅgahaṃ katvā vuttanti evamettha vattuṃ yuttataraṃ viya
analyzed: buddhataḥ gaṇhin ti ettha saṅgaham katvā vuttam iti evam ettha vattum yuttataram viya
translated: as is done in the expression “taken from the Buddha.”

original: dissati. Bhagavatāyeva hi dinnanaye ṭhatvā sāvakā dhammaṃ desenti. Teneva hi tatiyasaṅgītiyañca
analyzed: dissati bhagavatāya iva hi dinna naye ṭhatvā sāvakāḥ dhammaṃ desenti tena iva hi tatiya saṅgītiyam ca
translated: For the disciples teach the Dhamma in accordance with the method given by the Blessed One himself. It is for this reason that the Kathāvatthu,

original: moggaliputtatissattherena bhāsitampi kathāvatthuppakaraṇaṃ buddhabhāsitaṃ nāma jātaṃ,🔽tatoyeva ca attanā bhāsitampi subhasuttādi saṅgītiṃ āropentena āyasmatā ānandattherena
analyzed: moggaliputta tissa therena bhāsitam api kathā vatthu ppakaraṇam buddhabhāsitam nāma jātam  ca attanā bhāsitam pi subha sutta ādi saṅgītim āropentena āyasmatā ānandattherena
translated: though spoken by the Elder Moggaliputtatissa at the Third Council, is called “spoken by the Buddha.”

original: “evaṃ me suta”nti vuttaṃ.🔽Evaṃ paridīpitadhammakkhandhavasenāti gopakamoggallānena brāhmaṇena “tvaṃ bahussutoti
analyzed: evam me sutam ti vuttam  evam paridīpita dhamma kkhandha vasena ati gopakamoggallānena brāhmaṇena tvam bahu ssuta iti
translated: And the Elder Ānanda, when he himself spoke the Subhasutta, etc., included them in the recitation, saying “Thus have I heard.”🔽“In accordance with the collection of the Dhamma as thus revealed”: when the brahmin Gopaka Moggallāna asked, “You are well known as a man of great learning in the Dispensation of the Buddha.

original: buddhasāsane pākaṭo, kittakā dhammā te satthārā bhāsitā, tayā dhāritā”ti pucchite
analyzed: buddha sāsane pākaṭaḥ kittakāḥ dhammā te satthārā bhāsitā tayā dhāritā ati pucchite
translated: How many teachings has the Master spoken that you have learned?”

original: tassa paṭivacanaṃ dentena āyasmatā ānandattherena evaṃ “dvāsīti buddhato gaṇhi”ntiādinā
analyzed: tassa paṭivacanam dentena āyasmatā ānandattherena evam dvāsī iti buddhataḥ
translated: The answer to this was given by the Elder Ānanda thus: “He learned eighty-two from the Buddha” .🔽The method of teaching is shown by the aggregates of dhamma.

original: paridīpitadhammakkhandhānaṃ vasena. Ekānusandhikaṃ suttaṃ satipaṭṭhānādi. Satipaṭṭhānasuttañhi🔽“ekāyano ayaṃ, bhikkhave, maggo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā”tiādinā cattāro satipaṭṭhāne
analyzed: paridīpita dhamma kkhandhānam vasena eka anusandhikam suttam sati paṭṭhāna ādi sati paṭṭhāna suttam hi  eka ayanaḥ ayam bhikkhave maggo sattānam visuddhiyā ti ādinā cattāro sati paṭṭhāne
translated: The sutta with a single application is the Satipaṭṭhāna Sutta.🔽The Satipaṭṭhāna Sutta is called “with a single application” because it begins with the four satipaṭṭhānas thus: “Monks, this is the direct path for the purification of beings, for the surmounting of sorrow and lamentation, for the disappearance of pain and grief, for the attainment of the true way, for the realisation of Nibbāna—namely, the four satipaṭṭhānas” ,

original: ārabhitvā tesaṃyeva vibhāgadassanavasena pavattattā “ekānusandhika”nti vuccati. Anekānusandhikanti
analyzed: ārabhitvā tesam yeva vibhāga dassana vasena pavatta ttā eka anusandhikanti vuccati aneka anusandhikanti
translated: and it proceeds with the exposition of just those .🔽The sutta with multiple applications is the Parinibbāna Sutta.

original: nānānusandhikaṃ parinibbānasuttādi. Parinibbānasuttañhi nānāṭhānesu nānādhammadesanānaṃ
analyzed: nānā anusandhikam parinibbāna sutta ādi parinibbāna suttam hi nānā ṭhānesu nānā dhamma desanānam
translated: The Parinibbāna Sutta is called “with multiple applications” because it proceeds with the exposition of various teachings in various places.

original: vasena pavattattā “anekānusandhika”nti vuccati. Gāthābandhesu pañhapucchananti –
analyzed: vasena pavatta ttā aneka anusandhikanti vuccati gāthābandhesu pañha pucchananti
translated: In the case of the verses, the asking of the question is one aggregate of dhamma.🔽“How many should he cut off, how many abandon,

original: “Kati chinde kati jahe, kati cuttari bhāvaye;
analyzed: kati chinde kati jahe kati cuttari bhāvaye
translated: How many should he thoroughly develop,🔽How many should he surmount, that he may be called

analyzed: kati saṅga atigaḥ bhikkhu ogha tiṇṇaḥ ti vuccati iti
translated: A bhikkhu who has crossed the flood?”

original: Evamādinayappavattaṃ pañhapucchanaṃ eko dhammakkhandhoti attho.
translated: The meaning is: the asking of the question, which occurs in this way, is one aggregate of dhamma.

original: “Pañca chinde pañca jahe, pañca cuttari bhāvaye;
analyzed: pañca chinde pañca jahe pañca cuttari bhāvaye
translated: “Five things to be cut off, five to be given up, Five more to be worn away,

original: Pañca saṅgātigo bhikkhu, ‘oghatiṇṇo’ti vuccatī”ti. –
analyzed: pañca saṅga atigaḥ bhikkhu ogha tiṇṇaḥ ti vuccati iti
translated: The monk who has transcended the five strings Is said to have crossed the flood.”

original: Evamādinayappavattaṃ visajjananti veditabbaṃ. Tikadukabhājanaṃ nikkhepakaṇḍaaṭṭhakathākaṇḍavasena🔽veditabbaṃ. Tasmā “kusalā dhammā, akusalā dhammā, abyākatā dhammā, sukhāya vedanāya🔽sampayuttā dhammā, dukkhāya vedanāya sampayuttā dhammā, adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya
analyzed: evamādi naya ppavattam visajjanan ti veditabbam tika duka bhājanam nikkhepa kaṇḍa aṭṭhakathā kaṇḍa vasena  veditabbam tasmā kusalāḥ dhammāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ abyākatāḥ dhammāḥ sukhāya vedanāya  sampayuttāḥ dhammāḥ dukkhāya vedanāya sampayuttāḥ dhammāḥ adukkhamasukhāya vedanāya
translated: The exposition should be understood to occur in this way. The analysis into triads and dyads should be understood as the analysis of the exposition and the analysis of the section on expulsion.

original: sampayuttā dhammā”ti evamādīsu tikesu kusalattikassa vibhajanavasena yaṃ vuttaṃ nikkhepakaṇḍe –🔽“Katame dhammā kusalā? Tīṇi kusalamūlāni alobho adoso amoho, taṃsampayutto vedanākkhandho
analyzed: sampayuttāḥ dhammā ti evamādīsu tikesu kusala ttikassa vibhajana vasena yam vuttam nikkhepa kaṇḍe  katame dhammā kusalā tīṇi kusala mūlāni alobhaḥ adosaḥ amohaḥ tad sampayuttaḥ vedanā khandho
translated: Therefore, in the case of the triads such as “wholesome states,” “unwholesome states,” “indeterminate states,” “states associated with pleasant feeling,” “states associated with painful feeling,” “states associated with neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling,” etc., the analysis of the exposition is given in the section on expulsion in the way beginning:

original: saññākkhandho saṅkhārakkhandho viññāṇakkhandho, taṃsamuṭṭhānaṃ kāyakammaṃ vacīkammaṃ
analyzed: saññā kkhandho saṅkhāra kkhandho viññāṇa kkhandho tad samuṭṭhānam kāya kammam vacī kammam
translated: “What are wholesome states? The three wholesome roots, non-greed, non-hate, non-delusion; the aggregate of feeling … the aggregate of perception … the aggregate of volitional formations … the aggregate of consciousness associated with them; bodily and verbal kamma originated by them;

original: manokammaṃ. Ime dhammā kusalā.
analyzed: manaḥ kammam ime dhammā kusalā
translated: these are wholesome states.

original: “Katame dhammā akusalā? Tīṇi akusalamūlāni lobho doso moho, tadekaṭṭhā ca kilesā, taṃsampayutto vedanākkhandho…pe… manokammaṃ. Ime dhammā akusalā.
analyzed: katame dhammā akusalā tīṇi akusala mūlāni lobhaḥ dosaḥ mohaḥ tad ekaṭṭhā ca kilesā tad sampayuttaḥ manaḥ kammaṃ ime dhammā akusalā
translated: “What are unwholesome ideas? Three roots of unwholesomeness, greed, hate, delusion, and the defilements that are associated with them, and the feeling aggregate … and the mental volition that occurs therewith. These are unwholesome ideas.

original: “Katame dhammā abyākatā? Kusalākusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ vipākā kāmāvacarā rūpāvacarā arūpāvacarā🔽apariyāpannā vedanākkhandho …pe… viññāṇakkhandho, ye ca dhammā kiriyā neva kusalā
analyzed: katame dhammā abyākatā kusala akusalānam dhammānam vipākā kāmāvacarā rūpāvacarā arūpāvacarā  apariyāpannā vedanā kkhandho pe viññāṇa kkhandho ye ca dhammā kiriyā na iva kusalā
translated: “What are indeterminate ideas? Resultants of wholesome and unwholesome ideas in the Sensuous Universe, in the Fine Material Universe, and in the Supramundane,

original: nākusalā na ca kammavipākā sabbañca rūpaṃ asaṅkhatā ca dhātu. Ime dhammā abyākatā”ti –
analyzed: na akusalā na ca kamma vipākā sabbam ca rūpam asaṅkhatā ca dhātu ime dhammā abyākatā ati
translated: and the aggregates of feeling, perception, and consciousness that are neither wholesome nor unwholesome nor results of deeds done, and all materiality, and the Unformed Element. These are indeterminate ideas.”

original: Ayameko dhammakkhandho. Evaṃ sesattikānampi ekekassa tikassa vibhajanaṃ ekeko dhammakkhandhoti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ayam ekaḥ dhamma kkhandhaḥ evam sesa ttikānam pi ekekassa tikassa vibhajanam ekekaḥ dhamma kkhandho ti veditabbam
translated: This is one idea-group. So too, the analysis of each of the remaining triads should be understood as a separate idea-group.

original: Tathā “hetū dhammā”ti evamādikesu dukesu ekekassa dukassa vibhajanavasena yaṃ vuttaṃ –
analyzed: tathā hetū dhammā ti evamādikesu dukesu ekekassa dukassa vibhajana vasena yat vuttam
translated: Similarly, in the case of the dyads beginning with “Ideas that are causes” , the analysis of each dyad is given as follows:

original: “Katame dhammā hetū? Tayo kusalā hetū, tayo akusalā hetū, tayo abyākatā hetū”ti –
analyzed: katame dhammā hetū tayo kusalāḥ hetū tayo akusalāḥ hetū tayo abyākatāḥ hetū ti
translated: “What are ideas that are causes? Three wholesome causes, three unwholesome causes, three indeterminate causes.”

original: Ādi, tatthāpi ekekassa dukassa vibhajanaṃ ekeko dhammakkhandho. Puna aṭṭhakathākaṇḍe –
analyzed: ādi tattha api ekekassa dukassa vibhajanam ekekaḥ dhamma khandho puna aṭṭhakathā kaṇḍe
translated: and the analysis of each of these is a single chapter. Again, in the section on the commentaries:

original: “Katame dhammā kusalā? Catūsu bhūmīsu kusalaṃ. Ime dhammā kusalā. Katame dhammā akusalā?
analyzed: katame dhammā kusalā catūsu bhūmīsu kusalam ime dhammā kusalā katame dhammā akusalā
translated: “What are wholesome states? Wholesome consciousness in the four planes. These are wholesome states. What are unwholesome states?

original: Dvādasa akusalacittuppādā. Ime dhammā akusalā. Katame dhammā abyākatā? Catūsu bhūmīsu
analyzed: dvādasa akusala cittuppādāḥ ime dhammā akusalā katame dhammā abyākatā catūsu bhūmīsu
translated: Twelve types of unprofitable consciousness. These are unwholesome states. What are indeterminate states?

original: vipāko tīsu bhūmīsu kiriyābyākataṃ rūpañca nibbānañca. Ime dhammā abyākatā”ti –
analyzed: vipāko tīsu bhūmīsu kiriyā abyākatam rūpañca nibbānañca ime dhammā abyākatā ati
translated: Resultant in the four planes, and the indeterminate materiality in the three planes, and Nibbāna. These are indeterminate states” .

original: Evamādinā kusalattikādivibhajanavasena pavattesu tikabhājanesu ekekassa tikassa bhājanaṃ ekeko dhammakkhandho. Tathā –
analyzed: evamādinā kusala ttika ādi vibhajana vasena pavattesu tika bhājanesu ekekassa tikassa bhājanam ekekaḥ dhamma kkhandhaḥ tathā
translated: Thus in the case of the triads, which occur in the analysis of the wholesome triad, etc., the analysis of each triad is a single chapter. Likewise:

original: “Katame dhammā hetū? Tayo kusalā hetū, tayo akusalā hetū, tayo abyākatā hetū”ti –
analyzed: katame dhammā hetū tayo kusalāḥ hetū tayo akusalāḥ hetū tayo abyākatāḥ hetū ti
translated: “What are states that are roots? Three roots that are wholesome, three roots that are unwholesome, three roots that are indeterminate” .

original: Ādinayappavattesu dukabhājanesu ekamekaṃ dukabhājanaṃ ekeko dhammakkhandhoti evamettha tikadukabhājanavasena dhammakkhandhavibhāgo veditabbo.
analyzed: ādi naya ppavattesu duka bhājanesu ekam ekam duka bhājanam ekekaḥ dhamma kkhandho ti evam ettha tika duka bhājana vasena dhamma kkhandha vibhāgaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: Thus in the case of the dyads, which occur in the analysis beginning thus, the analysis of each dyad is a single chapter. This is how the analysis of the chapters should be understood here as to triads and dyads.

original: Ekamekañca cittavārabhājananti ettha pana –
analyzed: ekam ekam ca ettha pana
translated: And a single occurrence of consciousness is a single component of the Dhamma: here,

original: “Yasmiṃ samaye kāmāvacaraṃ kusalaṃ cittaṃ uppannaṃ hoti somanassasahagataṃ ñāṇasampayuttaṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ vā…pe… tasmiṃ samaye phasso hoti…pe… avikkhepo hotī”ti –🔽Evamādinayappavatte cittuppādakaṇḍe ekamekaṃ cittavārabhājanaṃ ekeko dhammakkhandhoti🔽gahetabbaṃ. Eko dhammakkhandhoti ettha “ekekatikadukabhājanaṃ ekamekaṃ cittavārabhājana”nti
analyzed: yasmin samaye kāmāvacaram kusalam cittam uppannam hoti somanassa sahagatam ñāṇa sampayuttam rūpa ārammaṇam vā ape tasmin samaye phassaḥ hoti pe avikkhepaḥ hoti iti  evamādi naya ppavatte cittuppāda kaṇḍe ekam ekam citta vāra bhājanam ekekaḥ dhammakkhandho ti  gahetabbam ekaḥ dhamma kkhandho ti ettha eka ekatika duka bhājanam ekam ekam citta vāra bhājanam ti
translated: “On an occasion when a profitable consciousness belonging to the sense sphere has arisen accompanied by joy and associated with knowledge, having a form object … a sound object … a tangible object as its object … on that occasion there is contact … there is non-distraction” .🔽So in the section on the kinds of consciousness given in the way beginning thus: “On an occasion when a profitable consciousness belonging to the sense sphere has arisen accompanied by joy and associated with knowledge” , each single occurrence of consciousness is a single component of the Dhamma.🔽And since it is said that “a single occurrence of consciousness is a single component of the Dhamma” ,

original: vuttattā ekeko dhammakkhandhoti attho veditabbo. “Ekeko”ti avuttepi hi ayamattho
analyzed: vutta ttā ekekaḥ dhamma kkhandho ti atthaḥ veditabbaḥ ekekaḥ ti a vutte pi hi ayam atthaḥ
translated: the meaning of “a single component of the Dhamma” should be understood as a single occurrence of consciousness.🔽For although the word “single” is not actually stated, the meaning is understood,🔽and so it is said that “a single component of the Dhamma is a single occurrence of consciousness.”

original: atthato viññāyamānova hotīti “eko dhammakkhandho”ti vuttaṃ. Atthi vatthūtiādīsu vatthu
analyzed: atthataḥ viññāyamānaḥ iva hoti iti ekaḥ dhamma kkhandho ti vuttam atthi vatthu utiādīsu vatthu
translated: As regards the words “a single basis” and so on, a basis is such as Sudinna’s head.

original: Ādikā gāthāyo. Sīlakkhandhavaggamūlapariyāyavaggādivasena saṅgaho vaggasaṅgaho. Uttarimanussadhammapeyyālanīlacakkapeyyālādivavatthāpanavasena
analyzed: ādikāḥ sīla kkhandha vagga mūla pariyāya vagga ādi vasena saṅgahaḥ vagga saṅgahaḥ uttari manussa dhamma peyyāla nīla cakka peyyāla ādi vavatthāpana vasena

The collection of the peyyālas by way of the Uttarimanussadhammapeyyāla, Nīlacakkapreyyāla, etc., which are the divisions,🔽is the peyyāla collection. The collection of the ekakanipātas, etc., in the Aṅguttaranikāya, etc.,

original: saṃyuttasaṅgaho. Majjhimanikāyādīsu mūlapaṇṇāsakādivasena paṇṇāsakasaṅgaho.
translated: is the saṃyutta collection. The collection of the mūlapaṇṇāsakas, etc., in the Majjhimanikāya, etc.,

original: Assa buddhavacanassa saṅgītipariyosāne sādhukāraṃ dadamānā viyāti sambandho. Saṅkampīti
analyzed: assa buddha vacanassa saṅgīti pariyosāne sādhukāram dadamānā viyāti sambandhaḥ saṅkampī iti
translated: is the paṇṇāsaka collection. At the end of the recitation of the Buddha’s word, they were as if giving a good report. This is the connection. It shook:

original: uddhaṃ uddhaṃ gacchantī suṭṭhu kampi. Sampakampīti uddhaṃ adho ca gacchantī sampakampi.
analyzed: uddham uddham gacchantī suṭṭhu kampi sampakampi iti uddham adhas ca gacchantī sampakampi
translated: it shook well, going up and up. It quivered: it quivered all around, going up and down.

analyzed: sampavedhi iti catūsu disāsu gacchantī suṭṭhu pavedhi accharam paharitum yuttāni acchariyāni
translated: It trembled: it trembled well, going in the four directions. Marvels are things worthy of being struck with wonder,

original: pupphavassacelukkhepādīni. Yā paṭhamamahāsaṅgīti dhammasaṅgāhakehi mahākassapādīhi
