translated: because he is unable to make others understand a meaning that he himself does not understand, and because of his fear of lying, etc.

original: vikkhepaṃ āpajjatīti. Tathā ca vuttaṃ “satteva ucchedadiṭṭhiyo, sesā sassatadiṭṭhiyo”ti.🔽Atha vā puññapāpānaṃ tabbipākānañca anavabodhena asaddahanena ca tabbisayāya pucchāya
analyzed: vikkhepam āpajjati iti tathā ca vuttam sattā iva uccheda diṭṭhiyo sesā sassata diṭṭhiyo ti  atha vā puñña pāpānam tad vipākānam ca anavabodhena asat dahanena ca tad visayāya pucchāya
translated: Thus it is said: “The annihilationist views are seven, the rest are eternalist views” .

original: vikkhepakaraṇaṃyeva sundaranti khantiṃ ruciṃ uppādetvā abhinivisantassa uppannā visuṃyeva🔽cesā ekā diṭṭhi sattabhaṅgadiṭṭhi viyāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tatoyeva ca vuttaṃ “pariyantarahitā
analyzed: vikkhepa karaṇam yeva sundaranti khantim rucim uppādetvā abhinivisantassa uppannā visum yeva  ca isā ekā diṭṭhi satta bhaṅga diṭṭhi viya ati daṭṭhabbam ca vuttam pariyanta rahitā
translated: Or else, because of his failure to understand merit and demerit and their results, and because of his lack of confidence in them, he generates a liking for and approval of the mere fact that he can evade the question by means of a roundabout answer.🔽Thus he arrives at a settled conclusion and generates a view that is separate from the other views.

original: diṭṭhigatikassa diṭṭhi ceva vācā cā”ti.🔽Adhiccasamuppannikāti ettha adhicca yadicchakaṃ yaṃ kiñci kāraṇaṃ vinā samuppanno
analyzed: diṭṭhi gatikassa diṭṭhi ca iva vācā ca ati  adhiccasamuppannikā ati ettha adhicca yadicchakam yam kiñci kāraṇam vinā samuppannaḥ
translated: This is how the view should be understood. And it is said accordingly: “The views of one who has views are either endless or they come to an end in a base” .🔽“The view that what is called the self is adventitious”: the self and the world arise adventitiously, without cause.

original: attā ca loko cāti dassanaṃ adhiccasamuppannaṃ. Attalokasaññitānañhi khandhānaṃ adhiccuppattiākārārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: attā ca loko ca ati dassanam adhicca samuppannam atta loka saññitānam hi khandhānam adhiccuppatti ākāra ārammaṇam
translated: This is the view that the self and the world arise adventitiously. The mode of perception of the aggregates called “self” and “world” is the object of the view that they arise adventitiously.

original: dassanaṃ tadākārasannissayavasena pavattito tadākārasahacaritatāya ca adhiccasamuppannanti
analyzed: dassanam tad ākāra sannissaya vasena pavattitaḥ tad ākāra sahacarita tāya ca adhicca samuppannanti
translated: and the seeing is called fortuitous since it occurs by the support of that and is associated with that.

original: vuccati yathā “mañcā ghosanti, kuntā pacarantī”ti ca. Taṃ etesamatthīti adhiccasamuppannikā.
analyzed: vuccati yathā mañcāḥ ghosanti kuntā pacaranti iti ca tam etesam atthi iti adhiccasamuppannikā
translated: It is called “accidental” because it occurs by depending on that as its object and because it is associated with that as its object, just as a cry of “The bed is crying, the chair is jumping” is said. They have that, thus they are “accidentalists.”

original: Saññīvādāti saññī vādo etesamatthīti saññīvādā “buddhaṃ assa atthīti buddho”ti yathā.
analyzed: saññīvādā ati saññī vādaḥ etesam atthi iti saññīvādā buddham assa atthi iti buddhaḥ ti yathā
translated: “Belief in perception”: they have the belief in perception, thus they are “belief in perceptionists.” As it is said: “He has a Buddha, thus he is a Buddha.”

original: Atha vā saññīti pavatto vādo saññīsahacaraṇanayena. Saññī vādo yesaṃ te saññīvādā.🔽“Rūpī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā, saññīti naṃ paññapenti, arūpī attā hoti, rūpī🔽ca arūpī ca attā hoti, neva rūpī nārūpī ca attā hoti. Antavā attā hoti, anantavā🔽attā hoti, antavā ca anantavā ca attā hoti, nevantavā nānantavā attā hoti. Ekattasaññī
analyzed: atha vā saññī iti pavattaḥ vādo saññī sahacaraṇa nayena saññī vādaḥ yesam te saññīvādāḥ  rūpī attā hoti arogo param maraṇā saññī iti nam paññapenti arūpī attā hoti rūpī  ca arūpī ca attā hoti na iva rūpī na arūpī ca attā hoti antavā attā hoti anantavā  attā hoti antavā ca anantavā ca attā hoti na iva antavā na anantavā attā hoti ekatta saññī
translated: Or alternatively, the belief that has occurred as “perception” is “belief in perception” in the sense of being associated with perception. They have that, thus they are “belief in perceptionists.”

original: attā hoti, nānattasaññī attā hoti. Parittasaññī attā hoti, appamāṇasaññī attā hoti.
analyzed: attā hoti nānatta saññī attā hoti paritta saññī attā hoti appamāṇa saññī attā hoti
translated: “The self is material after death, perceiving, they declare. The self is immaterial after death, the self is both material and immaterial after death, the self is neither material nor immaterial after death. The self is finite after death, the self is infinite after death, the self is both finite and infinite after death, the self is neither finite nor infinite after death. The self possesses perception after death, the self is without perception after death, the self possesses limited perception after death, the self possesses measureless perception after death.

original: Ekantasukhī attā hoti, ekantadukkhī attā hoti. Sukhadukkhī attā hoti, adukkhamasukhī
analyzed: ekanta sukhī attā hoti ekanta dukkhī attā hoti sukha dukkhī attā hoti adukkhamasukhī
translated: The self is absolutely happy, absolutely miserable, both happy and miserable, neither happy nor miserable;🔽after death the self is healthy and percipient, and so on.

original: attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā, saññīti naṃ paññapentī”ti evaṃ soḷasavidhena vibhattavādānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ.🔽Asaññīvādā nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā ca saññīvāde vuttanayeneva veditabbā. Kevalañhi “saññī
analyzed: attā hoti arogo param maraṇā saññī iti nam paññapenti iti evam soḷasavidhena adhivacanam  asaññī vādā nevasaññīnāsaññī vādā ca saññī vāde vutta nayena iva veditabbā kevalam hi saññī
translated: The terms “percipient” and so on are synonyms for the sixteen kinds of views stated in the following way:🔽The “percipient” view is stated from the standpoint of those who hold that the self is percipient.

original: attā”ti gaṇhantānaṃ vasena saññīvādā vuttā, “asaññī”ti ca “nevasaññīnāsaññī”ti ca
analyzed: attā iti gaṇhantānam vasena saññīvādāḥ vuttāḥ asaññī iti ca nevasaññīnāsaññī iti ca
translated: The “nonpercipient” and “neither percipient nor nonpercipient” views are stated from the standpoint of those who hold that the self is nonpercipient and neither percipient nor nonpercipient, respectively.

original: gaṇhantānaṃ vasena asaññīvādā ca nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā ca vuttāti veditabbā. Tattha🔽asaññīvādā “rūpī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā, asaññīti naṃ paññapenti, arūpī attā
analyzed: gaṇhantānam vasena asaññīvādā ca nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā ca vuttā iti veditabbā tattha  asaññī vādāḥ rūpī attā hoti arogo param maraṇā asaññī iti nam paññapenti arūpī attā
translated: Herein, the “nonpercipient” view is stated in the following way:🔽The self is material, healthy, and nonpercipient after death; the self is immaterial, both material and immaterial, and neither material nor immaterial; the self is finite, infinite,

original: hoti, rūpī ca arūpī ca attā hoti, neva rūpī nārūpī attā hoti. Antavā attā hoti, anantavā
analyzed: hoti rūpī ca arūpī ca attā hoti na iva rūpī na arūpī attā hoti antavā attā hoti anantavā
translated: both finite and infinite, and neither finite nor infinite; the self is possessed of form, formless, both possessed of form and formless, and neither possessed of form nor formless; the self is conscious, unconscious, both conscious and unconscious, and neither conscious nor unconscious.

original: attā hoti, antavā ca anantavā ca attā hoti, nevantavā nānantavā attā hoti arogo paraṃ🔽maraṇā, asaññīti naṃ paññapentī”ti evaṃ aṭṭhavidhena vibhattā. Nevasaññīnāsaññīvādāpi
analyzed: attā hoti antavā ca anantavā ca attā hoti na iva antavā na anantavā attā hoti arogaḥ param  maraṇā asaññī iti nam paññapenti iti evam aṭṭhavidhena vibhattā nevasaññī nāsaññī vādā api
translated: “The self is both finite and infinite,” “The self is neither finite nor infinite,” “The self is percipient of unity after death,” “The self is percipient of diversity after death,” “The self is percipient of the limited after death,” “The self is percipient of the immeasurable after death,” “The self is percipient of the finite after death,” “The self is percipient of the infinite after death,” “The self is percipient of the neither-finite-nor-infinite after death,” “The self is percipient of the neither-percipient-of-unity-nor-percipient-of-diversity after death,” “The self is percipient of the neither-percipient-of-the-limited-nor-percipient-of-the-immeasurable after death,” “The self is percipient of the neither-percipient-of-the-finite-nor-percipient-of-the-infinite after death,” “The self is percipient of the neither-percipient-of-the-neither-finite-nor-infinite-nor-percipient-of-the-not-so-after death,” “The self is percipient of the not-so after death,” “The self is not percipient after death,” “The self is happy after death,” “The self is miserable after death,” “The self is both happy and miserable after death,” “The self is neither happy nor miserable after death,” “The self exists after death,” “The self does not exist after death,” “The self both exists and does not exist after death,” “The self neither exists nor does not exist after death.”🔽The theories of the percipient of neither-perception-nor-non-perception are analyzed in eight ways.

original: evameva “rūpī attā hoti arogo paraṃ maraṇā, nevasaññīnāsaññīti naṃ paññapentī”tiādinā
analyzed: evam eva rūpī attā hoti arogo param maraṇā nevasaññī na asaññī iti nam paññapenti itiādinā
translated: and so on. The views about the self being finite and infinite, and the view that the self is both finite and infinite, and the view that the self is neither finite nor infinite, are also stated in the same way. The views about the self being percipient of unity, and the views about the self being percipient of diversity, and the views about the self being percipient of the limited, and the views about the self being percipient of the immeasurable, and the views about the self being percipient of the existent, and the views about the self being percipient of the non-existent, and the views about the self being percipient of the finite, and the views about the self being percipient of the infinite, are also stated in the same way. The views about the self being percipient of the existent and the non-existent, and the views about the self being percipient of the finite and the infinite, are also stated in the same way.

original: aṭṭhavidhena vibhattāti veditabbā.
analyzed: aṭṭhavidhena vibhattā iti veditabbā
translated: The annihilationists are those who hold the annihilationist view.🔽The annihilationist view is the view that the self is annihilated.

original: Ucchedavādāti “ayaṃ attā rūpī cātumahābhūtiko mātāpettikasambhavo kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati
analyzed: uccheda vādā ati ayam attā rūpī cātumahābhūtikaḥ mātāpettika sambhavaḥ kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati
translated: The annihilationist view is a view that is expressed in such passages as “This self, which is material, consisting of the four great elements and produced from mother and father, is annihilated at death,🔽it perishes and does not exist after death.”🔽The annihilationists are those who hold the annihilationist view, or those who have the annihilationist view.

original: vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā”ti evamādinā nayena pavattaṃ ucchedadassanaṃ ucchedo
analyzed: vinassati na hoti param evamādinā nayena pavattam uccheda dassanam ucchedo
translated: The view of annihilation is the annihilationist view.🔽The view of annihilation is a view that is expressed in such passages as “This self, which is material, consisting of the four great elements and produced from mother and father, is annihilated at death,🔽it perishes and does not exist after death.”🔽The annihilationists are those who hold the annihilationist view.

original: sahacaraṇanayena. Ucchedo vādo yesaṃ te ucchedavādā, ucchedavādo vā etesamatthīti
analyzed: sahacaraṇa nayena ucchedaḥ vādaḥ yesam te uccheda vādāḥ uccheda vādaḥ vā etesam atthi iti
translated: The annihilationist view is a view that is expressed in such passages as “This self, which is material, consisting of the four great elements and produced from mother and father, is annihilated at death,🔽it perishes and does not exist after death.”

original: ucchedavādā, ucchedaṃ vadantīti vā ucchedavādā.
analyzed: uccheda vādāḥ ucchedam vadanti iti vai uccheda vādā
translated: The annihilationists are those who hold the annihilationist view, or those who have the annihilationist view.🔽The view of annihilation is the annihilationist view.

original: Diṭṭhadhammanibbānavādāti ettha diṭṭhadhammo nāma dassanabhūtena ñāṇena upaladdhadhammo,
analyzed: diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vādā ti ettha diṭṭhadhammaḥ nāma dassana bhūtena ñāṇena upaladdha dhammaḥ
translated: The view of annihilation is a view that is expressed in such passages as “This self, which is material, consisting of the four great elements and produced from mother and father, is annihilated at death,🔽it perishes and does not exist after death.”

original: paccakkhadhammoti attho. Tattha tattha paṭiladdhattabhāvassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Diṭṭhadhamme
analyzed: paccakkhadhammo ti atthaḥ tattha tattha paṭiladdha tta bhāvassa etam adhivacanam diṭṭha dhamme

analyzed: nibbānam diṭṭhadhamma nibbānam imasmin yeva atta bhāve dukkha vūpasamanti attho tam  vadanti iti diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vādā te pana yatas kho bho ayam attā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi
translated: Nibbāna in the visible here and now is called “nibbāna in the visible here and now.” The meaning is: the stilling of suffering in this very individual existence.🔽They say that is nibbāna in the visible here and now.

analyzed: samappitaḥ samaṅgībhūtaḥ paricāreti ettāvatā kho bho ayam attā parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna ppatto  hoti iti evamādinā nayena diṭṭhe iva dhamme nibbānam paññapenti te hi man dhātu kāma guṇa sadise  mānusake kāma guṇe para nimmita vasavatti devarājassa kāma guṇa sadise dibbe ca kāma guṇe

original: upagatānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme nibbānappattiṃ vadanti.

In order to show them he says, “From here and there violent winds blow,” etc. “Violent winds”: strong winds capable of splitting trees and hurling down mountain peaks. “Lightning flashes”: the lightning splits, falls, is what is meant. “Weapons fall”: many kinds of weapons fall. “Take them away”: take them and remove them. “Terrible things”:

translated: But I am smeared with my own urine and excrement, and I cannot get up and wash myself by my own strength.🔽I cannot even say, ‘I am dirty, bathe me.’ I am so because I am not free from birth.

analyzed: a parimutta tāya edisaḥ jātaḥ na kho pana aham eva tumhe pi jātitaḥ a parimuttāḥ ava yathā iva
translated: But it is not only I; you too are not free from birth. As

original: hi mayhaṃ, evaṃ tumhākampi jāti āgamissati, iti tassā pure āgamanāva kalyāṇaṃ karothā”ti.
analyzed: hi mayham evam tumhākam pi jāti āgamissati iti tassā pure kalyāṇam karotha ati
translated: “Look, friends, I have come to you like this. So do good deeds before old age comes to you.”

original: Tenesa devadūto nāma jāto.
analyzed: tena isa deva dūtaḥ nāma jātaḥ
translated: So he became known as the god-messenger.

original: Jarājiṇṇasattopi atthato evaṃ vadati nāma “passatha bho ahampi tumhe viya taruṇo
analyzed: jarā jiṇṇa sattaḥ api atthatas evam vadati nāma passatha bho aham pi tumhe viya taruṇaḥ
translated: An old and decrepit creature also says as it were: “Look, friends, I was young like you.

original: ahosiṃ ūrubalabāhubalajavasampanno, tassa me tā balajavasampattiyo antarahitā, hatthapādā
analyzed: ahosim ūru bala bāhu bala java sampannaḥ tassa me tāḥ bala java sampattiyaḥ antarahitāḥ hattha pādā
translated: I had strong thighs and strong arms and speed. But my strength and speed have disappeared. My hands and feet

analyzed: hattha pāda kiccam ca na karonti jarāyamhi a parimutta tāya edisaḥ jātaḥ na kho pana aham eva
translated: do not do the work of hands and feet. I have become like this because I am not free from old age. But it is not only I

analyzed: tumhe pi jarāya a parimuttāḥ ava yathā iva hi mayham evam tumhākam pi jarā āgamissati
translated: who are not free from old age. As it is with me, so old age will come to you.

original: iti tassā pure āgamanāva kalyāṇaṃ karothā”ti. Tenesa devadūto nāma jāto.🔽Gilānasattopi atthato evaṃ vadati nāma “passatha bho ahampi tumhe viya nirogo ahosiṃ,
analyzed: iti tassā pure kalyāṇam karotha ati tena isa deva dūtaḥ nāma jātaḥ  gilāna sattaḥ api atthatas evam vadati nāma passatha bho aham pi tumhe viya nirogaḥ ahosiṃ
translated: So do good deeds before old age comes to you.” So he became known as the god-messenger.🔽A sick creature also says as it were: “Look, friends, I was healthy like you.

original: somhi etarahi byādhinā abhihato sake muttakarīse palipanno, uṭṭhātumpi na sakkomi,
analyzed: somhi etarahi byādhinā abhihato sake mutta karīse palipanno uṭṭhātum pi na sakkomi
translated: Now I am afflicted with a disease. I am covered with my own urine and excrement. I cannot get up.

original: vijjamānāpi me hatthapādā hatthapādakiccaṃ na karonti, byādhitomhi aparimuttatāya
analyzed: vijjamānā api me hattha pādāḥ hattha pāda kiccam na karonti byādhitaḥ asmi a parimutta tāya
translated: Though my hands and feet are there, they do not perform the functions of hands and feet. I am sick because I am not exempt from sickness.

original: ediso jāto, na kho panāhameva, tumhepi byādhito aparimuttāva. Yatheva hi mayhaṃ,
analyzed: edisaḥ jātaḥ na kho pana aham eva tumhe pi byādhitaḥ a parimuttā ava yathā iva hi mayham
translated: I have become like this. But I am not the only one. You too are not exempt from sickness. Just as it is for me,

analyzed: evam tumhākam pi byādhi āgamissati iti tassa pure kalyāṇam karotha ati
translated: so sickness will come to you. Do good before it comes.”

original: Tenesa devadūto nāma jāto.
analyzed: tena isa deva dūtaḥ nāma jātaḥ
translated: So he became known as a god’s messenger.

original: Kammakāraṇā kammakāraṇikā vā catuttho devadūtoti veditabbā. Tattha kammakāraṇapakkhe
analyzed: kamma kāraṇā kamma kāraṇikā vā catutthaḥ deva dūto ti veditabbā tattha kamma kāraṇa pakkhe
translated: The third messenger should be understood as the one who points out the reason for the action. The fourth messenger should be understood as the one who points out the action itself.

analyzed: dvattiṃsa tāva kamma kāraṇāḥ atthataḥ evam vadanti nāma mayam nibbattamānāḥ na rukkhe
translated: Herein, the thirty-two parts of the body that point out the reason for the action say this: “When we are reborn, we are not reborn in a tree,

analyzed: vā pāsāṇe vā nibbattāma tumha ādisānam sarīre nibbattāma iti amhākam pure nibbattitaḥ uva
translated: in a rock, or in a clod of earth, but we are reborn in a body like yours. So do good before we are reborn in you.”

original: kalyāṇaṃ karothā”ti. Tenetā devadūtā nāma jātā. Kammakāraṇikāpi atthato evaṃ vadanti
analyzed: kalyāṇam karotha ati tena itāḥ deva dūtāḥ nāma jātā kamma kāraṇikā api atthataḥ evam vadanti
translated: So they are called god’s messengers. The thirty-two parts of the body that point out the action itself say this:

analyzed: nāma mayam dvattiṃsa kamma kāraṇā karontā na rukkha ādīsu karoma tumha ādisesu sattesu yeva
translated: “When we are doing the action of the thirty-two parts of the body, we do not do it in a tree, etc., but we do it in beings like you.

analyzed: karomaḥ iti amhākam tumhesu pure kamma kāraṇa akāraṇataḥ uva kalyāṇam karotha ati tena ite api deva dūtāḥ nāma jātā
translated: “We are doing it. So do good to us in return for what we have done for you.” That is how they came to be called “divine messengers.”

original: Matakasattopi atthato evaṃ vadati nāma “passatha bho maṃ āmakasusāne chaḍḍitaṃ uddhumātakādibhāvaṃ
analyzed: matakasatto api atthataḥ evam vadati nāma passatha bho mam āmaka susāne chaḍḍitam uddhumātaka ādi bhāvam
translated: The dead body also speaks as it were, saying: “Look, friends, how I have been thrown on the charnel ground, how I have become bloated and so on,

original: pattaṃ, maraṇatomhi aparimuttatāya ediso jāto, na kho panāhameva, tumhepi maraṇato🔽aparimuttāva. Yatheva hi mayhaṃ, evaṃ tumhākampi maraṇaṃ āgamissati, iti tassa pure
analyzed: pattam maraṇataḥ mhi a parimutta tāya edisaḥ jātaḥ na kho pana aham eva tumhe pi maraṇataḥ  a parimuttā ava yathā iva hi mayham evam tumhākam pi maraṇam āgamissati iti tassa pure
translated: because I have not escaped death. But I am not the only one; you too have not escaped death.

original: āgamanāva kalyāṇaṃ karothā”ti. Tenesa devadūto nāma jāto. Tasmā daharakumārādayo
analyzed: kalyāṇam karotha ati tena isa deva dūtaḥ nāma jātaḥ tasmai dahara kumāra ādayaḥ

original: ettha “devadūtā”ti veditabbā.🔽Anamataggiyanti anamataggasaṃyuttaṃ. Dhammāmataṃ pāyesīti lokuttaradhammāmataṃ pānaṃ
analyzed: ettha deva dūtā ati veditabbā  anamataggiyanti anamatagga saṃyuttam dhamma amatam pāyesi iti lokuttara dhamma amatam pānam

original: paṭilābhakaraṇavasena pāyesīti attho. Samadhikānīti sahādhikāni. Sahattho hettha
analyzed: paṭilābha karaṇa vasena samadhikāni iti saha adhikāni ha ittha

analyzed: saṃsaddaḥ isi iti sīlakkhandha ādayaḥ dhammakkhandhe esi gavesi pariyesi iti isi iti vuccati  pañca raṭṭhāni iti pañcavidha cīna raṭṭhāni himavantam gantvā dhamma cakka ppavattanam

analyzed: pakāsentaḥ yakkha senam pasādayi iti yojetabbam  tena ca samayena ati tasmin samaye tesam gamanataḥ pubbabhāga kāle laddham bhavissati iti  vessavaṇa santikā laddham bhavissati vegasāti vegena samantataḥ ārakkham ṭhapesi iti

original: pabbataṃ. Diṭṭhasaccoti anāgāmimaggena paṭividdhasacco, anāgāmiphalaṃ pattoti vuttaṃ

original: Therena deviyā dhammaṃ, sutvā desitameva tu;
analyzed: therena deviyā dhammam sutvā desitam eva tu
translated: After hearing the Dhamma taught by the Elder to the queen,

translated: “At the foot of the Chāta mountain, three bamboo poles grew,

original: aruṇavaṇṇamattikaṃ. Harītakaṃ āmalakanti agadaharītakaṃ agadāmalakaṃ. Taṃ khippameva🔽sarīramalasodhanādikaraṇasamatthaṃ hoti.

analyzed: tam pana mukha sodhanana hāna pariyosāne mahatā parihārena upanenti tena te  aṅgarāgam nāma karonti ca yathāraham
translated: They presented them to the kings with great ceremony at the end of their bathing and mouth-washing.🔽And they made what is called “body paint” with them, and when they did so they prepared the body, which is called the “forehead, the top of the head, the chest, and the heart,” with two or three colours of ingredients of the antidote,

analyzed: sā pana guḷikā ahivicchikā ādīnam pi visam hanati tena api tam vuccati  aham buddham ca ati ādīsu sabba dhamme yāthāvataḥ abujjhi paṭibujjhi iti buddhaḥ iti saṅkhyam  gatam sammāsambuddham ca adhigata magge sacchikata nirodhe yathānusiṭṭham paṭipajjamāne
translated: But that pill also counteracted the poison of snakes, scorpions, and so on, and for that reason it was called “the antidote.”🔽In the passage beginning, “I have the Buddha and the Truth” , he has the “awakened” , which is the name for one who has awakened to, has fully awakened to, all things in their individual essences, the “fully enlightened Buddha,”

original: ca apāyesu apatamāne dhāretīti dhammoti saṅkhyaṃ gataṃ pariyattiyā saddhiṃ nava lokuttaradhammañca,
analyzed: ca apāyesu a patamāne dhāreti iti saṅkhyam gatam pariyattiyā saddhim nava lokuttara dhammaṃ ca
translated: and he has the “Truth” , which is the name for the nine supramundane states together with the learning sign, in which the path is reached and cessation verified, and which keeps those who practice in accordance with the advice from falling into states of loss,

original: diṭṭhisīlasāmaññena saṃhatattā saṅghoti saṅkhyaṃ gataṃ ariyasāvakasaṅghañca ahaṃ🔽saraṇaṃ gato parāyaṇanti upagato, bhajiṃ sevinti attho. Atha vā hiṃsati tappasādataggarukatāhi🔽vihatakilesena tapparāyaṇatākārappavattena cittuppādena saraṇagatānaṃ teneva saraṇagamanena🔽bhayaṃ santāsaṃ dukkhaṃ duggatiṃ parikilesaṃ hanati vināsetīti saraṇaṃ, ratanattayassetaṃ
analyzed: diṭṭhi sīla sāmaññena saṃhata ttā saṅghaḥ iti saṅkhyam gatam ariya sāvaka saṅgham ca aham  saraṇam gataḥ parāyaṇanti upagataḥ bhajim sevinti attho atha vā hiṃsati tad pasāda taggaruka tāhi  vihata kilesena tad parāyaṇa tā ākāra ppavattena cittuppādena saraṇa gatānam tena iva saraṇa gamanena  bhayam santāsam dukkham duggatim parikilesam hanati vināseti iti saraṇam ratanattayassa etam
translated: and the Community of Noble Disciples, which is reckoned a Community because of the unity of the view and virtue of its members,🔽I have gone for refuge, I have gone for shelter, I have gone for protection, I have gone for support, I have gone for refuge in the Triple Gem, is the meaning. Or alternatively, it harms, it destroys, fear, terror, suffering, unhappy destination, defilement, for those who have gone for refuge with the thought of going for refuge that is expressed by the mode of going for refuge with the intention that is free from defilement by the violence of faith, confidence, and respect, therefore it is a refuge. This is the etymological explanation of the word saraṇa .🔽🔽

original: adhivacanaṃ. Apica sammāsambuddho hite pavattanena ahitā ca nivattanena sattānaṃ🔽bhayaṃ hiṃsatīti saraṇanti vuccati. Dhammopi bhavakantārā uttāraṇena assāsadānena🔽ca sattānaṃ bhayaṃ hiṃsatīti saraṇanti vuccati. Saṅghopi appakānampi kārānaṃ vipulaphalapaṭilābhakaraṇena
analyzed: adhivacanam apica sammāsambuddhaḥ hite pavattanena ahitā ca nivattanena sattānam 🔽bhayam hiṃsati iti saraṇanti vuccati dhammaḥ api bhava kantārā uttāraṇena assāsa dānena 🔽ca sattānam bhayam hiṃsati iti saraṇanti vuccati saṅghaḥ api appakānam pi kārānam vipula phala paṭilābha karaṇena
translated: And the Community of the Noble Disciples, which is reckoned a Community because of the unity of the view and virtue of its members, I have gone to for refuge, for the supreme resort, I have resorted to, I have used, I have attended on, is the meaning. Or alternatively, it harms, it destroys, the fear, the anxiety, the suffering, the unhappy destination, and the defilement of those who have gone for refuge by means of the act of consciousness that has the form of the going for refuge, which is accompanied by faith, gladness, and respect, and which is the cause of the supreme resort. That is why it is called ‘refuge.’ This is a term for the Triple Gem. Furthermore, the Fully Enlightened One is called ‘refuge’ because he harms, he destroys, the fear of beings by setting them in what is beneficial and by keeping them from what is harmful. The True Idea is called ‘refuge’ because it harms, it destroys, the fear of beings by delivering them from the desert of existence and by giving them comfort. The Community is called ‘refuge’ because it harms, it destroys, the fear of beings by causing them to obtain a great fruit from a small action.

original: sattānaṃ bhayaṃ hiṃsatīti saraṇanti vuccati. Iminā atthena saraṇabhūtaṃ ratanattayaṃ
analyzed: sattānam bhayam hiṃsati iti saraṇanti vuccati iminā atthena saraṇa bhūtam
translated: for it is a refuge for beings from fear and harm.

original: teneva kāraṇena saraṇanti gato avagato, jāninti attho. Upāsakattaṃ desesinti ratanattayaṃ🔽upāsatīti upāsakoti evaṃ dassitaṃ upāsakabhāvaṃ mayi abhiniviṭṭhaṃ vācāya pakāsesinti
analyzed: tena iva kāraṇena gataḥ avagataḥ jāninti attho upāsaka ttam desesinti ratanattayam  upāsati iti upāsako ti evam dassitam upāsaka bhāvam mayi abhiniviṭṭham vācāya pakāsesin ti
translated: For this reason he has gone to, has understood, the refuge, which is the Three Jewels. The meaning is that he has known them.🔽He has made known to me, has revealed to me, the state of being a lay follower, which is shown thus: “One who possesses faith, after approaching, is a lay follower.”

original: attho, “upāsakohaṃ ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gato”ti evaṃ upāsakattaṃ paṭivedesinti
analyzed: attha upāsakaḥ uham ajjatagge pāṇupetam saraṇam gataḥ ti evam upāsaka ttam paṭivedesin ti
translated: The meaning is that he has revealed the state of being a lay follower thus: “From today for as long as I live I go for refuge to the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha.”

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Sakyaputtassa sāsaneti sakyassa suddhodanassa putto so bhagavā sakyaputto,🔽tassa sakyaputtassa sāsaneti attho. Saddhāti saddhāya, “sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā”tiādīsu
analyzed: vuttam hoti sakya puttassa sāsane iti sakyassa suddhodanassa putto so bhagavā sakya putto  tassa sakyaputtassa sāsane iti attho saddhā iti saddhāya sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā itiādīsu
