analyzed: ca khīṇa āsavā cetas upariya kovidā keci khīṇa āsavā ati visum yojetvā arahantaḥ ti iminā sukkha vipassakā vuttā ti vadanti
translated: But some say that the first two phrases refer to those who have attained the three knowledges and the supernormal powers, and the third to those who are cankers-destroyed and have the knowledge of the penetration of minds, and that the phrase “those who are cankers-destroyed” is used separately to refer to those who are dry-insight workers.🔽“The highest degree of understanding”: the highest degree of understanding’s keenness, is the meaning.

original: Paññāveyyattiyanti paññāpāṭavaṃ, paññāya tikkhavisadabhāvanti attho. Āsannanti āsanne
analyzed: paññā veyyattiyanti paññā pāṭavam paññāya tikkha visada bhāvanti attho āsannanti āsanne
translated: “Near”: close by.🔽“You are wise, great king,” he praises the king.

original: ṭhitaṃ. Sādhu mahārāja paṇḍitosīti rājānaṃ pasaṃsati. Puna vīmaṃsanto “atthi pana🔽te mahārājā”tiādimāha. Cūḷahatthipadopamasuttantaṃ kathesīti “ayaṃ rājā ‘ime samaṇā
analyzed: ṭhitam sādhu mahā rāja paṇḍitaḥ asi iti rājānam pasaṃsati puna vīmaṃsantaḥ atthi pana  te mahā rājā ati ādim āha cūḷahatthi pada upama suttantam kathesi iti ayam rājā ime samaṇāḥ
translated: Then, testing him further, he said: “But, great king,🔽have you ever heard what the state of a recluse is like?”

original: nāma īdisā, sīlādipaṭipatti ca tesaṃ īdisī’ti ca na jānāti, handa naṃ imāya cūḷahatthipadopamasuttantadesanāya
analyzed: nāma īdisā sīla ādi paṭipatti ca tesam īdisī iti ca na jānāti handa nam imāya cūḷahatthi pada upama suttanta desanāya
translated: “He thought: ‘This king does not know that recluses are like this and that their practice of virtue, etc., is like this. Well, I shall make him understand the state of a recluse and the practice of a recluse by teaching him the Cūḷahatthipadopama Sutta .’

original: samaṇabhāvūpagamanaṃ samaṇapaṭipattiñca viññāpessāmī”ti cintetvā paṭhamaṃ cūḷahatthipadopamasuttantaṃ
analyzed: samaṇa bhāva upagamanam samaṇa paṭipattiñca viññāpessāmi iti cintetvā paṭhamam cūḷahatthipadopama suttantam
translated: So he first taught the Cūḷahatthipadopama Sutta .

original: kathesi. Tattha hi –
analyzed: kathesi tattha hi
translated: For in that sutta it is said:

original: “Evameva kho, brāhmaṇa, idha tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno…pe…
analyzed: evam eva kho brāhmaṇaḥ idha tathāgataḥ loke uppajjati araham sammāsambuddhaḥ vijjā caraṇa sampanna upe
translated: “So too, brahmin, a Tathagata appears in the world, accomplished, fully enlightened…🔽he reveals this world—with its devas, Mara, and Brahma, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its devas and humans—having realized it through his own direct knowledge.

original: sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti, taṃ dhammaṃ
analyzed: sa attham sa byañjanam kevala paripuṇṇam parisuddham brahmacariyam pakāseti tam dhammaṃ
translated: He teaches the Dhamma that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with the right meaning and phrasing, and he reveals a holy life that is utterly perfect and pure.

original: suṇāti gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aññatarasmiṃ vā kule paccājāto, so taṃ dhammaṃ
analyzed: suṇāti gahapati vā gahapati putto vā aññatarasmim vā kule paccājātaḥ so tam dhammaṃ
translated: A householder hears that Dhamma or a householder’s son or one born in some other clan.🔽Having heard that Dhamma he acquires faith in the Tathagata.

original: sutvā tathāgate saddhaṃ paṭilabhati, so tena saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati
analyzed: sutvā tathāgate saddham paṭilabhati saḥ tena saddhā paṭilābhena samannāgataḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: Being thus possessed of faith, he considers thus:

original: ‘sambādho gharāvāso rajopatho, abbhokāso pabbajjā, nayidaṃ sukaraṃ agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā
analyzed: sambādhaḥ gharāvāsaḥ rajopathaḥ abbhokāsaḥ pabbajjā nayidam sukaram agāram ajjhāvasatā
translated: ‘Household life is crowded and dusty; life gone forth is wide open.

original: ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ ekantaparisuddhaṃ saṅkhalikhitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carituṃ, yannūnāhaṃ
analyzed: ekanta paripuṇṇam ekanta parisuddham saṅkha likhitam brahmacariyam caritum yat nūna aham
translated: It is not easy, while living in a home, to lead the holy life utterly perfect and pure as a polished shell.

original: kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyya’nti.
analyzed: kesa massuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasma anagāriyam pabbajeyyanti
translated: Suppose I shave off my hair and beard, put on the yellow robe, and go forth from the home life into homelessness.’

original: So aparena samayena appaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya mahantaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya🔽appaṃ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya mahantaṃ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya kesamassuṃ ohāretvā
analyzed: so aparena samayena appam vā bhogakkhandham pahāya mahantam vā bhogakkhandham pahāya  appam vā ñāti parivaṭṭam pahāya mahantam vā ñāti parivaṭṭam pahāya kesa massuṃ ohāretvā
translated: After a time, giving up a small amount of wealth or a large amount of wealth,🔽giving up a small circle of relatives or a large circle of relatives, he shaves off his hair and beard, puts on the ocher robes, and goes forth from the household life into homelessness.

original: kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati.
analyzed: kāsāyāni vatthāni a chādetvā agārasma anagāriyam pabbajati
translated: After a time, having given up much or little wealth, having given up much or little in the way of relatives, having shaved off his hair and beard, having put on ochre clothes, he goes forth from the home life into homelessness.

original: “So evaṃ pabbajito samāno bhikkhūnaṃ sikkhāsājīvasamāpanno pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā
analyzed: so evam pabbajitaḥ samānaḥ bhikkhūnam sikkhā sājīva samāpannaḥ pāṇātipātam pahāya pāṇātipātā
translated: “Having gone forth thus, he becomes endowed with the bhikkhus’ training and livelihood. He abstains from killing living beings, from taking what is not given,

original: paṭivirato hoti nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho, lajjī dayāpanno sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati.🔽“Adinnādānaṃ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti dinnādāyī dinnapāṭikaṅkhī, athenena sucibhūtena attanā viharatī”ti –
analyzed: paṭivirataḥ hoti nihita daṇḍaḥ nihita satthaḥ lajjī dayā āpanno sabba pāṇa bhūta hita anukampī viharati  a dinna ādānam pahāya a dinna ādānā paṭivirataḥ hoti dinna ādāyī dinna pāṭikaṅkhī atha enena sucibhūtena attanā viharati iti
translated: from misconduct in sensual pleasures, from false speech, and from wine, liquor, and intoxicants, which are the basis of negligence.🔽He abstains from eating at night, from accepting gold and silver. He abstains from bodily adornment and from the performance of ceremonies. He abstains from accepting women and girls, from accepting boys and girls, from accepting men and women slaves, from accepting goats and sheep, from accepting fowl and pigs, from accepting elephants, cattle, horses, and mares, from accepting fields and land. He abstains from going on errands and from buying and selling, from cheating with false weights and measures, from bribery and corruption, deception and insincerity, from wounding, killing, imprisoning, highway robbery, and taking food by force.”

original: Evamādinā sāsane saddhāpaṭilābhaṃ paṭiladdhasaddhehi ca pabbajjupagamanaṃ pabbajitehi ca paṭipajjitabbā sīlakkhandhādayo dhammā pakāsitā.
analyzed: evamādinā sāsane saddhā paṭilābham paṭiladdha saddhehi ca pabbajjupagamanam pabbajitehi ca paṭipajjitabbā sīla kkhandha ādayaḥ dhammā pakāsitā
translated: In this way the virtues of the training, etc., which should be undertaken by those who have acquired faith in the Dispensation and gone forth into homelessness, are expounded.

original: Rājā suttantaṃ suṇantoyeva aññāsīti “so bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhā paṭivirato hoti,
analyzed: rājā suttantam suṇantaḥ yā iva aññāsi iti so bīja gāma bhūta gāma samārambhā paṭivirataḥ hoti
translated: The king understood even as he listened to the sutta, “He abstains from injuring seeds and plants,

original: ekabhattiko hoti rattuparato virato vikālabhojanā”ti evaṃ tasmiṃ suttante āgatattā
analyzed: ekabhattikaḥ hoti ratta uparataḥ virataḥ evam tasmin suttante āgata ttā
translated: from eating at improper times, and from accepting gold and silver.”

original: taṃ suṇantoyeva aññāsi. Idheva vasissāmāti na tāva rattiyā upaṭṭhitattā anāgatavacanamakāsi.🔽Āgataphaloti anāgāmiphalaṃ sandhāyāha, sampattaanāgāmiphaloti attho. Tatoyeva ca
analyzed: tam suṇantaḥ yā iva aññāsi idha iva vasissāma ati na tāva rattiyāḥ upaṭṭhita ttā anāgata vacanam akāsi  āgata phalaḥ iti anāgāmi phalam sandhāya āha sampatta anāgāmi phalaḥ ti ca
translated: Since this was stated in the sutta, he understood even as he listened to it. He said, “We will stay right here,” not because the night had already set in, but because he was speaking of the future.

original: visesato aviparītaviditasatthusāsanattā viññātasāsano. Idāni pabbajissatīti gihiliṅgena
analyzed: visesataḥ aviparīta vidita satthu sāsana ttā viññāta sāsanaḥ idāni pabbajissati iti gihi liṅgena
translated: “One who has attained the fruit” : he says this with reference to the non-returner fruit; the meaning is, “one who has attained the non-returner fruit.” And he is “one who has learned the Master’s Dispensation” because he has learned the Master’s Dispensation without error.🔽“He will go forth now” : he says this because the king has already completed his duties as a householder.

original: ānītakiccassa niṭṭhitattā evamāha. Acirapakkantassa raññoti raññe acirapakkanteti
analyzed: ānīta kiccassa niṭṭhita ttā evam āha acira pakkantassa rañño ti raññe acira pakkanta iti
translated: “After the king had gone away for a short while” : the meaning is, “after the king had gone away.”

original: attho. Adhiṭṭhahitvāti antotambapaṇṇidīpe samāgatā suṇantūti adhiṭṭhahitvā.
analyzed: atthaḥ adhiṭṭhahitvā ti antotambapaṇṇidīpe samāgatā suṇantu iti adhiṭṭhahitvā
translated: “Having resolved” : having resolved, “May they come together and listen in the Rose-Apple Island.”🔽“By the method of covering the ground” : by the method of covering the ground.

original: Bhūmattharaṇasaṅkhepenāti bhūmattharaṇākārena. Uppātapāṭhakāti nimittapāṭhakā, nemittakāti
analyzed: bhūmattharaṇa saṅkhepena ati bhūmattharaṇa ākārena uppāta pāṭhakā ati nimitta pāṭhakā nemittakā ati
translated: “Astrologers” : fortune-tellers.

original: attho. Gahitā dāni imehi pathavīti āsanānaṃ pathaviyaṃ atthatattā evamāhaṃsu. Patiṭṭhahissatīti🔽cintentoti ettha tena kāraṇena sāsanapatiṭṭhānassa abhāvato avassaṃ patiṭṭhahantassa
analyzed: atthaḥ gahitā dāni imehi pathavī iti āsanānam pathaviyam evam āhaṃsu patiṭṭhahissati iti  cintento ti ettha tena kāraṇena sāsana patiṭṭhānassa abhāvataḥ avassam patiṭṭhahantassa
translated: “The meaning is: ‘Now that they have taken possession of the earth, the earth will be theirs.’ He said this because the seats were placed on the earth. ‘It will be established’🔽means: ‘It will be established without doubt.’ He thought thus because there was no establishment of the Dispensation for that reason.

original: sāsanassa pubbanimittamidanti evaṃ pubbanimittabhāvena sallakkhesīti veditabbaṃ.🔽Paṇītenāti uttamena. Sahatthāti sahatthena santappetvāti suṭṭhu tappetvā, paripuṇṇaṃ
analyzed: sāsanassa pubba nimittam idam ti evam pubba nimitta bhāvena sallakkhesi iti veditabbam  paṇītena ati uttamena sahatthā ati sahatthena santappetvā ati suṭṭhu tappetvā paripuṇṇam
translated: ‘He considered’ means: ‘He considered it as a sign of the future establishment of the Dispensation.’🔽‘With excellent food’ means: with the best food. ‘With his own hands’ means: with his own hands. ‘He served them well’ means: he served them well, he gave them enough food, he satisfied them.

original: suhitaṃ yāvadatthaṃ katvāti attho. Petavatthuṃ vimānavatthuṃ saccasaṃyuttañca kathesīti
analyzed: su hitam yāvadattham katvā ati attho peta vatthum vimāna vatthum sacca saṃyuttam ca kathesi iti
translated: ‘He related the Petavatthu, the Vimānavatthu, and the Saccasamyutta’

original: desanāvidhikusalo thero janassa saṃvegaṃ janetuṃ paṭhamaṃ petavatthuṃ kathetvā tadanantaraṃ🔽saṃvegajātaṃ janaṃ assāsetuṃ saggakathāvasena vimānavatthuñca kathetvā tadanantaraṃ
analyzed: desanā vidhi kusalaḥ theraḥ janassa saṃvegam janetum paṭhamam peta vatthum kathetvā tad anantaram  saṃvega jātam janam assāsetum sagga kathā vasena vimāna vatthuñca kathetvā tad anantaram
translated: means: the Elder, who was skilled in the method of teaching, first related the Petavatthu in order to arouse a sense of urgency in the people. After that,🔽in order to console the people who had become anxious, he related the Vimānavatthu in the form of a discourse on heaven. After that,

original: paṭiladdhassāsānaṃ “mā ettha assādaṃ karotha nibbānaṃ vinā na aññaṃ kiñci saṅkhāragataṃ
analyzed: paṭiladdhassa āsānam mā ettha assādam karotha nibbānam vinā na aññam kiñci saṅkhāra gatam
translated: he related the Saccasamyutta in order to show the people who had obtained consolation that there is no other happiness in the world than Nibbāna.🔽‘He related the Saccasamyutta’ means: he related the Saccasamyutta.

original: dhuvaṃ nāma atthi, tasmā paramassāsakaṃ nibbānamadhigantuṃ vāyamathā”ti saccapaṭivedhatthāya
analyzed: dhuvam nāma atthi tasmai parama ssāsakam nibbānam adhigantum sacca paṭivedha tthāya
translated: There is a permanent state, therefore strive to attain the supreme security of Nibbāna.”

original: ussāhaṃ janento ante saccasaṃyuttaṃ kathesīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ussāham janentaḥ ante sacca saṃyuttam kathesi iti veditabbam
translated: It should be understood that he spoke this discourse on the Truths in order to arouse their zeal for the penetration of the Truths.

original: Tesaṃ sutvāti tesaṃ santikā therānaṃ guṇakathaṃ sutvā. Rañño saṃviditaṃ katvāti rañño
analyzed: tesam sutvā iti tesam santikā therānam guṇa katham sutvā rañño saṃviditam katvā ati rañño
translated: Having heard from them: having heard the talk about the Elders’ virtues from them.

original: nivedanaṃ katvā, rājānaṃ paṭivedayitvāti attho. Alaṃ gacchāmāti purassa accāsannattā
analyzed: nivedanam katvā rājānam paṭivedayitvā ati atthaḥ alam gacchāma ati purassa accāsannattā
translated: Having informed the king: having made known to the king.🔽It is not proper: it is not suitable.

original: sāruppaṃ na hotīti paṭipakkhipanto āha. Meghavanaṃ nāma uyyānanti mahāmeghavanuyyānaṃ.
analyzed: sāruppam na hoti iti paṭipakkhipantaḥ āha meghavanam nāma uyyānam ti mahā meghavan uyyānam
translated: The Meghavana Garden: the Great Meghavana Garden.🔽On the day that the site for the garden was being selected, it is said, an untimely great rain cloud arose and,

original: Tassa kira uyyānassa bhūmiggahaṇadivase akālamahāmegho uṭṭhahitvā sabbataḷākapokkharaṇiyo🔽pūrento gimhābhihatarukkhalatādīnaṃ anuggaṇhantova pāvassi, tena kāraṇena taṃ mahāmeghavanaṃ
analyzed: tassa kira uyyānassa bhūmi ggahaṇa divase akāla mahā meghaḥ uṭṭhahitvā sabba taḷāka pokkharaṇiyo  pūrentaḥ gimha abhihata rukkha latā ādīnam anuggaṇhantaḥ iva pāvassi tena kāraṇena tam mahā meghavanam
translated: filling all the tanks and ponds,🔽disappeared after satisfying the trees, creepers, etc., which were afflicted by the hot season. For this reason the garden was called the Great Meghavana.

original: nāma uyyānaṃ jātaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ mahāvaṃse –
analyzed: nāma uyyānam jātam vuttam ha etam mahāvaṃse
translated: This is said in the Mahāvamsa:

original: “Uyyānaṭṭhānaggahaṇe, mahāmegho akālajo;
analyzed: uyyāna ṭṭhāna ggahaṇe mahāmeghaḥ akāla jaḥ
translated: “At the selection of the site for the garden, an untimely great rain cloud arose,

original: Pāvassi tena uyyānaṃ, mahāmeghavanaṃ ahū”ti.🔽Sukhasayitabhāvaṃ pucchitvāti “kacci, bhante, idha sukhaṃ sayittha, tumhākaṃ idha🔽nivāso sukha”nti evaṃ sukhasayitabhāvaṃ pucchitvā tato therena “sukhasayitamhi, mahārāja,
analyzed: tena uyyānam mahā megha vanam  sukha sayita bhāvam pucchitvā ati kacci bhante idha sukham tumhākam idha  nivāso evam sukhasayita bhāvam pucchitvā tatas therena mahā rāja
translated: And so the park became known as the Great Cloud Wood.🔽After asking about their comfort of rest, he asked: “Venerable Sirs, I hope you slept well here, I hope your stay here was comfortable?”

original: bhikkhūnaṃ phāsukamidaṃ uyyāna”nti vutte “evaṃ sati idaṃ no uyyānaṃ dassāmī”ti cintetvā
analyzed: bhikkhūnam phāsukam idam uyyānanti vutte evam sati idam naḥ uyyānam dassāmi iti cintetvā
translated: After the Elder replied: “Great King, the monks slept well, this park is comfortable for the monks,” he thought: “If that is so, I will give this park to them.”

original: “kappati, bhante, bhikkhusaṅghassa ārāmo”ti pucchi. Imaṃ suttanti veḷuvanārāmapaṭiggahaṇe🔽vuttamimaṃ suttaṃ. Udakanti dakkhiṇodakaṃ. Mahāmeghavanuyyānaṃ adāsīti “imaṃ mahāmeghavanuyyānaṃ
analyzed: kappati bhante bhikkhu saṅghassa ārāmaḥ ti pucchi imam veḷuvana ārāma paṭiggahaṇe  vuttam imam suttam udakam ti dakkhiṇa udakam mahā megha vana uyyānam adāsi iti imam mahā megha vana uyyānam
translated: He asked: “Venerable Sirs, is a park suitable for the Community of monks?” This sutta is the sutta spoken in the acceptance of the Veḷuvana.🔽Water means: water for the gift. He gave the Great Cloud Wood Park.

original: saṅghassa dammī”ti vatvā jeṭṭhamāsassa kāḷapakkhe dutiyadivase adāsi. Mahāvihārassa
analyzed: saṅghassa dammi iti vatvā jeṭṭha māsassa kāḷapakkhe dutiya divase adāsi mahāvihārassa
translated: After saying: “I give this Great Cloud Wood Park to the Community,” he gave it on the second day of the dark part of the month of Jeṭṭha.

original: dakkhiṇodakapāteneva saddhiṃ patiṭṭhitabhāvepi na tāva tattha vihārakammaṃ niṭṭhitanti
analyzed: dakkhiṇa udakapātena iva saddhim patiṭṭhita bhāve pi na tāva tattha vihāra kammam niṭṭhitan ti
translated: Although the establishment of the Great Monastery together with the water for the gift was completed, the work on the monastery was not yet finished there.

original: āha “idañca paṭhamaṃ vihāraṭṭhānaṃ bhavissatī”ti. Punadivasepīti kāḷapakkhassa dutiyadivaseyeva.
analyzed: āha idam ca paṭhamam vihāra ṭṭhānam bhavissati iti puna divase pi iti kāḷa pakkhassa dutiya divase yeva
translated: On the following day: on the very next day, the second day of the dark fortnight.

original: Aḍḍhanavamānaṃ pāṇasahassānanti aḍḍhena navamānaṃ pāṇasahassānaṃ, pañcasatādhikānaṃ
analyzed: aḍḍha navamānam pāṇa sahassānam ti aḍḍhena navamānam pāṇa sahassānam pañca sata adhikānam
translated: Nine thousand and five hundred: the meaning is, nine thousand and five hundred plus half.

original: aṭṭhasahassānanti attho. Jotipātubhāvaṭṭhānanti ñāṇālokassa pātubhāvaṭṭhānaṃ. Appamādasuttanti
analyzed: aṭṭha sahassānam ti attho joti pātubhāva ṭṭhānanti ñāṇa ālokassa pātubhāva ṭṭhānaṃ appamāda suttam ti
translated: The place of the manifestation of the light of knowledge: the place of the manifestation of the light of knowledge. The Discourse on Diligence:

original: aṅguttaranikāye mahāappamādasuttaṃ, rājovādasuttanti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāye mahāappamāda suttam rājovāda suttan ti vuttam hoti
translated: the Discourse on Great Diligence in the Anguttara Nikāya. The Discourse to the King:

original: Mahaccanti karaṇatthe paccattavacanaṃ, mahatā rājānubhāvenāti attho. Tumhe jānanatthanti
analyzed: karaṇa atthe paccatta vacanam mahatā rāja anubhāvena ati tumhe jānana ttham ti
translated: the meaning is, with great royal majesty. For the purpose of your knowing:

original: sambandho. Ariṭṭho nāma amaccoti rañño bhāgineyyo ariṭṭho nāma amacco. Pañcapaṇṇāsāyāti
analyzed: sambandhaḥ ariṭṭhaḥ nāma amacco ti raññaḥ bhāgineyyaḥ ariṭṭhaḥ nāma amacco pañcapaṇṇāsāya ati
translated: the connection. The minister named Ariṭṭha: the minister named Ariṭṭha, the king’s nephew. Fifty-five:

original: ettha “catupaṇṇāsāyā”ti vattabbaṃ. Evañhi sati upari vuccamānaṃ “dvāsaṭṭhi arahanto”ti
analyzed: ettha catu paṇṇāsāya iti vattabbam evam hi sati upari vuccamānam dvāsaṭṭhi arahantaḥ ti
translated: here “fifty-four” should be said. For only then does the statement made above, “sixty-two arahants,”

original: vacanaṃ sameti. Teneva ca sīhaḷabhāsāya likhite mahāvaṃse “catupaṇṇāsāya saddhi”nti
analyzed: vacanam sameti tena iva ca sīhaḷabhāsāya likhite mahā vaṃse catupaṇṇāsāya
translated: make sense. And in the Mahāvamsa written in the Sinhalese language it is said, “with fifty-four.”

original: vuttaṃ. Dasabhātikasamākulaṃ rājakulanti muṭasivassa puttehi abhayo devānaṃpiyatisso
analyzed: vuttam dasa bhātika samākulam rāja kulanti muṭasivassa puttehi abhayaḥ devānaṃpiya tisso
translated: The king’s court was crowded with ten brothers. The king’s court was crowded with ten brothers, namely, Abhaya, Devānampiya, Tissa,

original: mahānāgo uttiyo mattābhayo sūratissoti evamādīhi dasahi bhātikehi samākiṇṇaṃ rājakulaṃ.
analyzed: mahā nāgaḥ uttiyaḥ mattābhayaḥ sūratissaḥ ti evamādīhi dasahi bhātikehi samākiṇṇam rājakulam
translated: Mahānāga, Uttiya, Mattābhaya, Sūratissa, and so on.

original: Cetiyagirimhi vassaṃ vasiṃsūti āsāḷhīpuṇṇamadivase raññā dinnavihāreyeva paṭiggahetvā🔽pāṭipadadivase vassaṃ vasiṃsu. Pavāretvāti mahāpavāraṇāya pavāretvā. Kattikapuṇṇamāyanti🔽aparakattikapuṇṇamāyaṃ. Mahāmahindatthero hi purimikāyaṃ upagantvā vutthavasso mahāpavāraṇāya
analyzed: cetiya girimhi vassam vasiṃsu iti raññā dinna vihāreya iva paṭiggahetvā  pāṭipada divase vassam vasiṃsu pavāretvā ati mahāpavāraṇāya pavāretvā kattikapuṇṇam āyanti  apara kattikapuṇṇamāyam mahāmahinda theraḥ hi purimikāyam upagantvā vuttha vassaḥ mahā pavāraṇāya
translated: They spent the rains in Cetiya Mountain. On the full-moon day of Āsāḷhi, they accepted the monastery given by the king and🔽spent the rains there on the day of the Observance. After the Invitation ceremony, on the full-moon day of Kattika,🔽the Elder Mahinda went into residence in the first month, spent the rains, and after the Invitation ceremony in the month of Āsāḷhi,

original: pavāretvā tato ekamāsaṃ atikkamma cātumāsiniyaṃ puṇṇamadivase ariyagaṇaparivuto rājakulaṃ
analyzed: pavāretvā tatas eka māsam atikkamma cātumāsiniyam puṇṇama divase ariya gaṇa parivutaḥ rājakulam
translated: he went to the king’s court on the full-moon day of the month of Caitra, a month after the Invitation ceremony, surrounded by the noble community.

original: gantvā bhojanāvasāne “mahārāja, amhehi ciradiṭṭho sammāsambuddho”tiādivacanamabrvi.
analyzed: gantvā bhojana avasāne mahā rāja amhehi cira diṭṭhaḥ sammāsambuddhaḥ iti ādi vacanam abrvi
translated: At the end of the meal, he said, “Great king, we have not seen the Buddha for a long time.”

original: Evañca katvā vakkhati “puṇṇamāyaṃ mahāvīro, cātumāsiniyā idhā”ti. Yaṃ panettha kenaci🔽vuttaṃ “vutthavasso pavāretvāti cātumāsiniyā pavāraṇāyāti attho, paṭhamapavāraṇāya🔽vā pavāretvā ekamāsaṃ tattheva vasitvā kattikapuṇṇamiyaṃ avoca, aññathā ‘puṇṇamāyaṃ
analyzed: evam ca katvā vakkhati puṇṇamāyam mahāvīro cātumāsiniyā idha ati yam pana ittha kenacid  vuttam vutthavasso pavāretvā ti cātumāsiniyā pavāraṇāya ati attho paṭhama pavāraṇāya  vā pavāretvā eka māsam tattha iva vasitvā kattikapuṇṇamiyam avoca aññathā puṇṇamāyam
translated: and it is in this way that he says, “The Great Hero, having spent the four months here, on the full moon day of Kattika. ”🔽But here it is said by someone, “Having spent the four months here, having performed the Pavarana ceremony, is the meaning. Or else, having performed the Pavarana ceremony on the first Pavarana day, having spent one month there itself, on the full moon day of Kattika he spoke. Otherwise, because of the words ‘The Great Hero, on the full moon day’ it cannot be taken. ”

original: mahāvīro’ti vuttattā na sakkā gahetu”nti, tattha cātumāsiniyā pavāraṇāyāti ayamatthavikappo
analyzed: mahāvīraḥ iti vutta ttā na sakkā gahetunti tattha cātumāsiniyā pavāraṇāya ati ayam attha vikappaḥ
translated: Here, the explanation of the meaning, “Having spent the four months here, having performed the Pavarana ceremony,” is not correct.🔽For those who have entered upon the Rains in the first month do not perform the Pavarana ceremony in the fourth month.

original: na yujjati. Na hi purimikāya vassūpagatā cātumāsiniyaṃ pavārenti. Ciradiṭṭho sammāsambuddhoti
analyzed: na yujjati na hi purimikāya vassūpagatā cātumāsiniyam pavārenti cira diṭṭhaḥ sammāsambuddho ti
translated: “Long since we saw the Fully Enlightened One”🔽and because the relic of the Teacher is the Fully Enlightened One himself,

original: satthussa sarīrāvayavo ca sammāsambuddhoyevāti katvā avayave samudāyavohāravasena
analyzed: satthussa sarīra avayavo ca sammāsambuddhaḥ yeva ati katvā avayave samudāya vohāra vasena
translated: it should be regarded as said by way of the usage of the whole for the part,

original: evamāhāti daṭṭhabbaṃ yathā “samuddo diṭṭho”ti.
analyzed: evam āha ati daṭṭhabbam yathā samuddaḥ diṭṭhaḥ iti
translated: as in the case of “The ocean was seen.”🔽The Elder, having set aside the reason for going,🔽and wishing to show the purpose of staying here,

original: Therena vuttampi gamanakāraṇaṃ ṭhapetvā idha vāse payojanameva dassetvā gamanaṃ paṭisedhetukāmo
analyzed: therena vuttam api gamana kāraṇam ṭhapetvā idha vāse payojanam eva dassetvā gamanam paṭisedhetu kāmo
translated: and to prevent going,

original: āha “ahaṃ bhante tumhe”tiādi. Abhivādanādīsu ācariyaṃ disvā abhivādanakaraṇaṃ abhivādanaṃ
analyzed: āha aham bhante tumha itiādi abhivādana ādīsu ācariyam disvā abhivādana karaṇam abhivādanam
translated: In the case of paying homage, etc., the paying of homage is the act of paying homage on seeing the teacher.

original: nāma. Yasmiṃ vā disābhāge ācariyo vasati iriyāpathe kappento, tato abhimukhova vanditvā
analyzed: nāma yasmin vā disā bhāge ācariyaḥ vasati iriyāpathe kappentaḥ tatas abhimukhaḥ uva vanditvā
translated: Or else, in whatever direction the teacher is staying, walking about, and so on, one should go in that direction, and after paying homage,

original: gacchati, vanditvā tiṭṭhati, vanditvā nisīdati, vanditvā nipajjati, idaṃ abhivādanaṃ
analyzed: gacchati vanditvā tiṭṭhati vanditvā nisīdati vanditvā nipajjati idam abhivādanam
translated: one should go on; after paying homage, one should stand; after paying homage, one should sit down; after paying homage, one should lie down. This is called paying homage.

original: nāma. Ācariyaṃ pana dūratova disvā paccuṭṭhāya paccuggamanakaraṇaṃ paccuṭṭhānaṃ nāma.
analyzed: nāma ācariyam pana dūratas va disvā paccuṭṭhāya paccuggamana karaṇam paccuṭṭhānam nāma
translated: But when one sees the teacher from a distance, one should rise from one’s seat and go to meet him. This is called rising up.

original: Ācariyaṃ pana disvā añjaliṃ paggayha sīse ṭhapetvā ācariyaṃ namassati, yasmiṃ disābhāge
analyzed: ācariyam pana disvā añjalim paggayha sīse ṭhapetvā ācariyam namassati yasmin disā bhāge
translated: But when one sees the teacher, one should raise one’s joined palms and place one’s head at his feet. One should pay homage to the teacher in the direction in which he is staying.

original: so vasati, tadabhimukhopi tatheva namassati, gacchantopi ṭhitopi nisinnopi añjaliṃ
analyzed: saḥ vasati tad abhimukhaḥ api tathā iva namassati gacchantaḥ api ṭhitaḥ upi nisinnaḥ api añjalim
translated: One should pay homage in the same way while going, standing, or sitting, by raising one’s joined palms.

original: paggayha namassatiyevāti idaṃ añjalikammaṃ nāma. Anucchavikakammassa pana karaṇaṃ
analyzed: paggayha namassatiyā iva ati idam añjalikammam nāma anucchavika kammassa pana karaṇam
translated: This is called paying respect with joined palms. The doing of what is suitable is called service.

original: sāmīcikaraṇaṃ nāma. Cīvarādīsu hi cīvaraṃ dento na yaṃ vā taṃ vā deti, mahagghaṃ
analyzed: sāmīcikaraṇam nāma cīvara ādīsu hi cīvaram dentaḥ na yam vā tam vā deti mahaggham
translated: For when one is giving a robe, one should not give just any robe, but rather a costly one.

original: satamūlagghampi pañcasatamūlagghampi satasahassamūlagghampi detiyeva. Piṇḍapātādīsupi
analyzed: sata mūla ggham pañca sata mūla ggham sata sahassa mūla ggham detiyā iva piṇḍapāta ādīsu pi
translated: He gave a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand, and so on.

original: eseva nayo. Idaṃ sāmīcikaraṇaṃ nāma. Sarīradhātuyoti sarīrāvayavā. Aññātanti aññātaṃ,
analyzed: idam sāmīcikaraṇam nāma sarīra avayavāḥ aññātanti aññātam
translated: The same method applies to the almsfood, etc. This is called “making it acceptable.”🔽“The bodily relics”: the parts of the body. “We have not known”: we have not known, we have not heard of, we have not seen.

original: viditaṃ mayāti attho. Kuto lacchāmāti kuto labhissāma. Sumanena saddhiṃ mantehīti
analyzed: viditam mayā ati attho kutas lacchāma ati kutas labhissāma sumanena saddhim mantehi iti
translated: “Where can we get them?” means “Where can we find them?” “Consult with Sumana”

original: paṭhamameva sāmaṇerassa kathitattā vā “jānāti esa amhākamadhippāya”nti ñatvā vā evamāhāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: paṭhamam eva sāmaṇerassa kathita ttā vā jānāti esa amhākam adhippāyanti ñatvā vā evam āha ati daṭṭhabbam
translated: means “Consult with Sumana.” This should be understood as said because the novice monk told the king first or because the king knew that Sumana knew his intention.

original: Appossukko tvaṃ mahārājāti mahārāja tvaṃ dhātūnaṃ paṭilābhe mā ussukkaṃ karohi, mā
analyzed: appa ussukkaḥ tvam mahā rāja ati mahā rāja tvam dhātūnam paṭilābhe mā ussukkam karohi mā
translated: “You should not be anxious, great king” means “Great king, you should not be anxious about obtaining the bodily relics.

original: tvaṃ tattha vāvaṭo bhava, aññaṃ tayā kattabbaṃ karohīti adhippāyo. Idāni tadeva raññā
analyzed: tvam tattha vāvaṭaḥ bhava aññam tayā kattabbam karohi iti adhippāyaḥ idāni tat eva raññā
translated: You should not be concerned about that. You should do something else.” This is the meaning. Now, showing that very thing which the king should do, he said, “Having had the streets cleaned,” etc.

original: kattabbakiccaṃ dassento “vīthiyo sodhāpetvā”tiādimāha. Sabbatāḷāvacare upaṭṭhāpetvāti
analyzed: kattabba kiccam dassentaḥ vīthiyaḥ sodhāpetvā iti ādim āha sabba tāḷāvacare upaṭṭhāpetvā iti
translated: “Having had the whole city decorated” means having had the whole city decorated.

original: kaṃsatāḷāditāḷaṃ avacarati etthāti tāḷāvacaraṃ vuccati ātatavitatādi sabbaṃ tūriyabhaṇḍaṃ.
analyzed: kaṃsa tāḷa ādi tāḷam avacarati ettha ati tāḷa avacaram vuccati ātata vitata ādi sabbam tūriya bhaṇḍam
translated: The word tāḷāvacara is said to be derived from the fact that it is the place where they play the tāḷa and other drums. All musical instruments such as the āta, the vitas, etc., are included.

original: Teneva parinibbānasuttaṭṭhakathāyaṃ “sabbañca tāḷāvacaraṃ sannipātethāti ettha sabbañca
analyzed: tena iva parinibbāna sutta ṭṭhakathā ayam sabbañca tāḷāvacaram sannipātetha iti ettha sabbañca
translated: Thus in the Parinibbāna Sutta Commentary it is said: “All musical instruments” means all musical instruments such as the tāḷāvacara.

original: tāḷāvacaranti sabbaṃ tūriyabhaṇḍa”nti vuttaṃ. Ettha pana sahacaraṇanayena sabbatūriyabhaṇḍānaṃ🔽vādakāpi gahetuṃ vaṭṭantīti te sabbe upaṭṭhāpetvā sannipātetvāti vuttaṃ hoti. Lacchasīti
analyzed: tāḷa avacaranti sabbam tūriya bhaṇḍanti vuttam ettha pana sahacaraṇa nayena sabba tūriya bhaṇḍānam  vādakā api gahetum vaṭṭanti iti te sabbe upaṭṭhāpetvā sannipātetvā iti vuttam hoti lacchasi iti
translated: Here, by the method of sahacaraṇa, the players of all musical instruments are also included.

original: labhissasi. Therā cetiyagirimeva agamaṃsūti rājanivesanato nikkhamitvā puna cetiyagirimeva agamaṃsu.🔽Tāvadevāti taṃ khaṇaṃyeva. Pāṭaliputtadvāreti pāṭaliputtanagaradvāre. Kiṃ bhante
analyzed: labhissasi therā cetiyagirim eva agamaṃsu iti rāja nivesanataḥ nikkhamitvā puna cetiyagirim eva agamaṃsu  tāvat eva ati tam pāṭaliputta dvāra iti pāṭaliputta nagara dvāre kim bhante
translated: Therefore it is said: “having engaged all of them.” Lacchasī means you will get. The elders went to Cetiyagiri itself means that after leaving the royal residence they went to Cetiyagiri itself.

original: sumana āhiṇḍasīti sumana tvaṃ samaṇadhammaṃ akatvā kasmā vicarasīti pucchati. Cetiyagirimhiyeva
analyzed: sumanaḥ āhiṇḍasi iti sumana tvam samaṇa dhammam a katvā kasmai vicarasi iti pucchati
translated: Tāvadeva means at that very moment. Pāṭaliputtadvāra means the gate of the city of Pāṭaliputta. Kiṃ bhante sumana āhiṇḍasī means why are you wandering about without doing the duties of an ascetic? Cetiyagirimhiyeva means only at Cetiyagiri.

original: patiṭṭhāpetvāti pacchā tattha vihāratthāya ākaṅkhitabbabhāvato cetiyagirimhiyeva🔽patiṭṭhāpetvā. Vaḍḍhamānakacchāyāyāti pacchābhattanti attho. Pacchābhattameva hi🔽chāyā vaḍḍhati. Athassa etadahosīti dhātucaṅkoṭakaṃ disvā evaṃ cintesi. Chattaṃ apanamatūti
analyzed: patiṭṭhāpetvā ti pacchā tattha vihāra atthāya ākaṅkhitabba bhāvato  patiṭṭhāpetvā vaḍḍhamānaka chāyāya iti pacchābhattam ti attho pacchābhattam eva hi  chāyā vaḍḍhati atha assa etat ahosi iti dhātu caṅkoṭakam disvā evam cintesi chattam apanamatu uti
translated: and had it placed there: because he wanted to have a dwelling there in the future,🔽he had it placed there on Cetiya Mountain. In the shade of the growing tree: the meaning is ‘after the midday meal,’

original: idaṃ setacchattaṃ sayameva me sīsoparito dhātucaṅkoṭakābhimukhaṃ hutvā namatūti attho.
analyzed: idam seta chattam sayam eva me sīsa uparitas dhātu caṅkoṭaka abhimukham hutvā namatu iti
translated: for it is only after midday that the shade grows. Then this occurred to him: having seen the relic casket, he thought thus. Let the sunshade be lowered: the meaning is, let this white sunshade of mine be lowered by itself, and be over my head facing the relic casket.

original: Mayhaṃ matthake patiṭṭhātūti idaṃ dhātucaṅkoṭakaṃ therassa hatthato dhātuyā saha🔽āgantvā sirasmiṃ me patiṭṭhātūti attho. Pokkharavassaṃ nāma pokkharapattappamāṇaṃ🔽valāhakamajjhe uṭṭhahitvā kamena pharitvā temetukāmeyeva temayamānaṃ mahantaṃ hutvā
analyzed: mayham matthake patiṭṭhātu uti idam dhātu caṅkoṭakam therassa hatthataḥ dhātuyā saha  āgantvā sirasmim me patiṭṭhātu uti pokkhara vassam nāma pokkhara patta ppamāṇam  valāhaka majjhe uṭṭhahitvā kamena pharitvā temetu kāmeya iva temayamānam mahantam hutvā
translated: Let it stand on my head: the meaning is, let this relic casket, having come with the relic from the Elder’s hand,🔽stand on my head. Pokkharavassa: the size of a lotus leaf🔽arises in the middle of the cloud and gradually spreads out and, as if wishing to sprinkle, becomes great and rains down. Great hero: of great courage. Herein, the relics are called ‘the great hero’s portion’

original: vassati. Mahāvīroti mahāparakkamo. Mahāvīrāvayavattā cettha satthuvohārena dhātuyo
analyzed: vassati mahāvīraḥ iti mahā parakkamaḥ mahāvīra avayava ttā ca ittha satthu vohārena dhātuyo
translated: by the title of the Master.

original: eva niddiṭṭhā. Dhātusarīrenāgamanañhi sandhāya ayaṃ gāthā vuttā.
analyzed: eva niddiṭṭhā dhātu sarīrena āgamanam hi sandhāya ayam gāthā vuttā
translated: and so they are shown. For this verse was spoken with reference to his coming by means of the element of water.

original: Pacchimadisābhimukhova hutvā apasakkantoti piṭṭhito piṭṭhitoyeva pacchimadisābhimukho🔽hutvā osakkanto, gacchantoti attho. Kiñcāpi esa pacchimadisaṃ na oloketi, tathāpi
analyzed: pacchima disā abhimukhaḥ eva hutvā apasakkanto ti piṭṭhito piṭṭhitaḥ yeva pacchima disā abhimukhaḥ  hutvā osakkantaḥ gacchantaḥ iti attho kiñcā api esa pacchima disam na oloketi tathā api
translated: “Turning his back on the western direction”: going backwards, that is, turning his back on the western direction.🔽Though he did not look at the western direction,

original: pacchimadisaṃ sandhāya gacchatīti “pacchimadisābhimukho”ti vuttaṃ. Puratthimena dvārena
analyzed: pacchima disam sandhāya gacchati iti pacchima disa abhimukhaḥ ti vuttam puratthimena dvārena
translated: nevertheless he went with reference to it. That is why it is said that he “turned his back on the western direction.”

original: nagaraṃ pavisitvāti ettha piṭṭhito piṭṭhitoyeva āgantvā dvāre sampatte parivattetvā
analyzed: nagaram pavisitvā ti ettha āgantvā dvāre sampatte parivattetvā
translated: “Having entered the city by the eastern gate”: having come backwards, that is, turning round when he reached the gate,🔽he entered the city by the eastern gate, looking straight on. This should be understood.

original: ujukeneva nagaraṃ pāvisīti veditabbaṃ. Mahejavatthu nāmāti mahejanāmakena yakkhena🔽pariggahitaṃ ekaṃ devaṭṭhānanti veditabbaṃ. Paribhogacetiyaṭṭhānanti ettha paribhuttūpakaraṇāni
analyzed: ujukena iva nagaram pāvisi iti veditabbam mahejavatthu nāma ati maheja nāmakena yakkhena  pariggahitam ekam devaṭṭhānan ti veditabbam paribhoga cetiya ṭṭhānan ti ettha paribhuttu upakaraṇāni
translated: The “place named Maheja” should be understood as a shrine occupied by a spirit named Maheja.

original: nidahitvā kataṃ cetiyaṃ paribhogacetiyanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tividhañhi cetiyaṃ vadanti
analyzed: nidahitvā katam cetiyam paribhoga cetiyanti daṭṭhabbam tividham hi cetiyam vadanti
translated: As regards “the shrine where the requisites are used,” a shrine is to be understood as one made by depositing the requisites used by the Enlightened One. For they call a shrine of three kinds,

original: paribhogacetiyaṃ dhātucetiyaṃ dhammacetiyanti. Tattha paribhogacetiyaṃ vuttanayameva.🔽Dhātucetiyaṃ pana dhātuyo nidahitvā kataṃ. Paṭiccasamuppādādilikhitapotthakaṃ nidahitvā
analyzed: paribhoga cetiyam dhātu cetiyam dhamma cetiyanti tattha paribhoga cetiyam vutta nayam eva  dhātu cetiyam pana nidahitvā katam paṭiccasamuppāda ādi likhita potthakam nidahitvā
translated: Herein, the shrine of use is as already described.🔽The shrine of relics is one made after depositing relics.🔽But one made after depositing a book written with the dependent origination, etc.,🔽is called a shrine of the Dhamma.

original: kataṃ pana dhammacetiyaṃ nāma. Sārīrikaṃ paribhogikaṃ uddissakanti evampi tippabhedaṃ
analyzed: katam pana dhammacetiyam nāma sārīrikam paribhogikam evam pi ti pabhedam
translated: They also call a shrine of the Dhamma a shrine of the bodily relics, a shrine of use, and a shrine of dedication.

original: cetiyaṃ vadanti. Ayaṃ pana pabhedo paṭimārūpassapi uddissakacetiyeneva saṅgahitattā
analyzed: cetiyam vadanti ayam pana pabhedaḥ paṭimā rūpassa api uddissaka cetiyena iva saṅgahita ttā
translated: But this classification is more appropriate: since the image shrine is included in the shrine of dedication,

original: suṭṭhutaraṃ yujjati.
analyzed: suṭṭhutaram yujjati
translated: the classification is more appropriate.🔽But how did this place become a shrine of use for three Buddhas?

original: Kathaṃ pana idaṃ ṭhānaṃ tiṇṇaṃ buddhānaṃ paribhogacetiyaṭṭhānaṃ ahosīti āha “atīte🔽kirā”tiādi. Pajjarakenāti ettha pajjarako nāma rogo vuccati. So ca yakkhānubhāvena🔽samuppannoti veditabbo. Tadā kira puṇṇakāḷo nāma yakkho attano ānubhāvena manussānampi
analyzed: katham pana idam ṭhānam tiṇṇam buddhānam paribhoga cetiya ṭṭhānam ahosi iti āha atīte  kirāti ādi pajjarakena ati ettha pajjarakaḥ nāma rogaḥ vuccati saḥ ca yakkha anubhāvena  samuppannaḥ ti veditabbaḥ tadā kira puṇṇakāḷaḥ nāma yakkho attanaḥ ānubhāvena manussānam pi
translated: “In the past, it seems,” etc.🔽Herein, the word pajjaraka is a disease. And it should be understood that it arose through the power of a yakkha.

original: sarīre pajjarakaṃ nāma rogaṃ samuṭṭhāpesi. Vuttañhetaṃ mahāvaṃse –
analyzed: sarīre pajjarakam nāma rogam samuṭṭhāpesi vuttam ha etam mahāvaṃse
translated: For then, it seems, a yakkha called Puṇṇakaḷāka caused a disease called pajjaraka to arise in the bodies of men through his own power. This is said in the Mahāvaṃsa:

original: “Rakkhasehi janassettha, rogo pajjarako ahū”ti;
analyzed: rakkhasehi janassa ittha rogaḥ pajjarakaḥ ahū ti
translated: “Protect the people, Lord of Men, for the plague has broken out.”

original: Dīpavaṃsepi cetaṃ vuttaṃ –
analyzed: dīpa vaṃse pi ca itam vuttam
translated: And this is said in the Dīpavaṃsa, too:

original: “Rakkhasā ca bahū tattha, pajjarā ca samuṭṭhitā;
analyzed: rakkhasā ca bahū tattha pajjarā ca samuṭṭhitā
translated: “And there were many demons there, and the plague broke out;

original: Pajjarena bahū sattā, nassanti dīpamuttame”ti.
analyzed: pajjarena bahū sattāḥ nassanti dīpam uttama iti
translated: And many beings perished in the plague in the best of islands.”

original: Anayabyasananti ettha anayoti avaḍḍhi. Kāyikaṃ cetasikañca sukhaṃ byasati vikkhipati
analyzed: anaya byasanam ti ettha kāyikam cetasikam ca sukham byasati vikkhipati
translated: “Misery and disaster”: here “misery” is non-prosperity. It destroys, scatters, and wipes out bodily and mental pleasure,

original: vināsetīti byasananti dukkhaṃ vuccati. Kiñcāpi “buddhacakkhunā lokaṃ olokento”ti
analyzed: vināseti iti byasanam ti dukkham vuccati kiñcā api buddha cakkhunā lokam olokento ti
translated: and therefore it is called “disaster.” Although it is said, “looking over the world with his Buddha-eye,”

original: vuttaṃ, tathāpi “te satte anayabyasanamāpajjante disvā”ti vacanato paṭhamaṃ buddhacakkhunā
analyzed: vuttam tathā api te satte anaya byasanam āpajjante disvā iti vacanataḥ paṭhamam buddha cakkhunā
translated: nevertheless, because of the statement, “seeing those beings falling into misery and disaster,” it should be understood that first he looked over the world with his Buddha-eye

original: lokaṃ oloketvā pacchā sabbaññutaññāṇena lokaṃ olokento te satte anayabyasanamāpajjante🔽disvāti gahetabbaṃ. Na hi āsayānusayādibuddhacakkhussa te sattā anayabyasanaṃ āpajjantā
analyzed: lokaṃ oloketvā pacchā sabbaññuta ññāṇena lokaṃ olokento te satte anaya byasanam āpajjante  disvā iti gahetabbam na hi āsaya anusaya ādi buddha cakkhussa te sattāḥ anaya byasanam āpajjantā
translated: and afterwards, looking over the world with his knowledge of omniscience, he saw those beings falling into misery and disaster.

original: dissanti. Dubbuṭṭhikāti visamavassādivasena duṭṭhā asobhanā vuṭṭhiyeva dubbuṭṭhikā,
analyzed: dissanti dubbuṭṭhikā ati visama vassa ādi vasena duṭṭhā asobhanā vuṭṭhiyā iva dubbuṭṭhikā
translated: For those beings do not appear to the Buddha-eye that sees the dispositions, latent tendencies, etc., as falling into misery and disaster. “Bad weather”: bad, ugly weather due to irregular rains, etc., is bad weather.

original: sassuppattihetubhūtā kāyasukhuppattisappāyā sattupakārā sammā vuṭṭhi tattha na hotīti
analyzed: sassu patti hetu bhūtā kāya sukhu patti sappāyā sattu pakārā sammā vuṭṭhi tattha na hoti iti
translated: The meaning is that there is no right rainfall there, which is a condition for the growth of the crops and is helpful to beings by being favourable to the arising of bodily pleasure.🔽And it is said: “Famine, too, is in the land” .

original: adhippāyo. Tatoyeva ca “dubbhikkhaṃ dussassa”nti vuttaṃ. Bhikkhāya abhāvo, dullabhabhāvo
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ tatas yeva ca dubbhikkham dussassanti vuttam bhikkhāya abhāvaḥ dullabha bhāvo
translated: Famine is the absence of alms or the difficulty of getting them;🔽the meaning is that alms are not easily got there.

original: vā dubbhikkhaṃ, sulabhā tattha bhikkhā na hotīti vuttaṃ hoti. Sassānaṃ abhāvo, asampannatā
analyzed: vā dubbhikkham sulabhā tattha bhikkhā na hoti iti vuttam hoti sassānam abhāvaḥ asampanna tā
translated: The absence of crops or their failure is famine.🔽“The god” is a name for the cloud.

original: vā dussassaṃ. Devoti meghassetaṃ nāmaṃ. Sammādhāramanupavecchīti udakadhāraṃ sammā
analyzed: vā dussassam devaḥ iti meghassa etam nāmam sammā dhāram anupavecchi iti udaka dhāram sammā
translated: “Seeking to pour down rain” : he was about to release a downpour,

original: vimuñci, sammā anupavassīti vuttaṃ hoti.🔽Mahāvivādo hotīti tasmiṃ kira kāle jayantamahārājena ca tassa rañño kaniṭṭhabhātukena
analyzed: vimuñci sammā anupavassi iti vuttam hoti  mahā vivādaḥ hoti iti tasmin kira kāle jayanta mahā rājena ca tassa rañño kaniṭṭha bhātukena
translated: the meaning is.

original: samiddhakumāranāmakena uparājena ca saddhiṃ imasmiṃ dīpe mahāyuddhaṃ upaṭṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: samiddhakumāra nāmakena uparājena ca saddhim imasmin dīpe mahā yuddham upaṭṭhitam
translated: “There was a great war” : on that occasion, it seems, a great war was being waged in this island between King Jayasena and the king’s younger brother, the prince named Samiddha.

original: Tenetaṃ vuttaṃ “tena kho pana samayena maṇḍadīpe mahāvivādo hotī”ti. Hotīti kiriyā
analyzed: tena itam vuttam tena kho pana samayena maṇḍadīpe mahāvivādaḥ hoti iti hoti iti kiriyā
translated: That is why it is said: “At that time there was a great war in the land of Maṇḍa.”🔽“Was” : this is a verb.

original: kālamapekkhitvā vattamānapayogo, vivādassa pana atītakālikattaṃ “tena kho pana samayenā”ti🔽imināva viññāyati. Saddantarasannidhānena hettha atītakālāvagamo yathā “bhāsate vaḍḍhate
analyzed: kālam apekkhitvā vattamāna payogaḥ vivādassa pana atīta kālikattam tena kho pana samayena ati  iminā ava viññāyati sadda antara sannidhānena ha itthā atīta kāla avagamaḥ yathā bhāsate vaḍḍhate
translated: The present tense is used in consideration of the time of speaking. But the past tense of the dispute is known by the words “Then at that time” .

original: tadā”ti. Evaṃ sabbattha īdisesu ṭhānesu vattamānapayogo daṭṭhabbo. Kalahaviggahajātāti🔽ettha kalaho nāma matthakappatto kāyakalahopi vācākalahopi. Tattha hatthaparāmāsādivasena
analyzed: tadā ti evam sabbattha īdisesu ṭhānesu vattamāna payogaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ kalaha viggaha jātā ti  ettha kalahaḥ nāma matthaka ppatto kāya kalahaḥ pi vācā kalahaḥ pi tattha hattha parāmāsa ādi vasena
translated: The knowledge of the past time here is by the proximity of another statement, as in the words “He spoke, he grew, then at that time” . So in all such places the present tense should be understood. Quarrelling and brawling :

original: kāyena kātabbo kalaho kāyakalaho. Mammaghaṭṭanādivasena vācāya kātabbo kalaho vācākalaho.
analyzed: kāyena kātabbaḥ kalahaḥ kāya kalahaḥ mamma ghaṭṭana ādi vasena vācāya kātabbaḥ kalahaḥ vācā kalahaḥ
translated: herein, quarrelling is a dispute that has reached the point of blows, either by body or by speech. Herein, that which is to be done by body, by the laying on of hands, etc., is quarrelling by body. That which is to be done by speech, by the striking of the chest, etc., is quarrelling by speech.

original: Vipaccanīkagahaṇaṃ viggaho. Kalahassa pubbabhāge uppanno aññamaññaviruddhagāho. Atha🔽vā kalaho nāma vācākalaho. Aññamaññaṃ hatthaparāmāsādivasena virūpaṃ viruddhaṃ vā
analyzed: vipaccanīka gahaṇam viggahaḥ kalahassa pubba bhāge uppannaḥ aññamañña viruddha gāhaḥ atha  vā kalahaḥ nāma vācā kalahaḥ aññamaññam hattha parāmāsa ādi vasena virūpam viruddham vā
translated: Brawling is the taking up of opposite sides. It is the taking up of opposite sides against each other that arises in the preliminary stage of a quarrel.

original: gahaṇaṃ viggaho kāyakalaho. Yathāvutto kalaho ca viggaho ca jāto sañjāto etesanti
analyzed: gahaṇam viggaho kāya kalaho yathā vutto kalaho ca viggaho ca jāto sañjāto etesan ti
translated: Or alternatively, quarrelling is verbal quarrelling. The taking up of an opposite side against each other by the laying on of hands, etc., is brawling, quarrelling by body. Quarrelling and brawling that have arisen, come to be, among these is what is meant by “quarrelling and brawling arisen and come to be among them.”

original: kalahaviggahajātā, sañjātakalahaviggahāti attho.🔽Tāni sāsanantaradhānena nassantīti pariyattipaṭivedhapaṭipattisaṅkhātassa tividhassapi
analyzed: kalaha viggaha jātā sañjāta kalaha viggahā ti attho  tāni sāsana antara dhānena nassanti iti pariyatti paṭivedha paṭipatti saṅkhātassa tividhassa api
translated: Quarrelling and fighting: quarrelling and fighting have arisen, is the meaning.

original: sāsanassa antaradhānena dhātuparinibbāne sati tāni cetiyāni vinassanti. Tīṇi hi parinibbānāni🔽kilesaparinibbānaṃ khandhaparinibbānaṃ dhātuparinibbānanti, tāni pana amhākaṃ bhagavato
analyzed: sāsanassa antaradhānena dhātu parinibbāne sati tāni cetiyāni vinassanti tīṇi hi parinibbānāni  kilesa parinibbānam khandha parinibbānam dhātu parinibbānanti tāni pana amhākam bhagavataḥ
translated: They will disappear with the disappearance of the Dispensation: with the disappearance of the Dispensation, which is of three kinds as learning, understanding, and practice, they will disappear. For when the elements disappear, the monuments will disappear. There are three kinds of disappearance:

original: vasena evaṃ veditabbāni. Tassa hi kilesaparinibbānaṃ bodhipallaṅke ahosi, khandhaparinibbānaṃ🔽kusinārāyaṃ. Dhātuparinibbānaṃ anāgate bhavissati. Sāsanassa kira osakkanakāle imasmiṃ
analyzed: vasena evam veditabbāni tassa hi kilesa parinibbānam bodhi pallaṅke ahosi khandha parinibbānam  kusinārāyam dhātu parinibbānam anāgate bhavissati sāsanassa kira osakkana kāle imasmin
translated: the disappearance of defilements, the disappearance of aggregates, and the disappearance of elements. But these should be understood in our Blessed One’s case as follows. For his disappearance of defilements was at the foot of the Bodhi Tree, his disappearance of aggregates at Kusinārā,

original: tambapaṇṇidīpe dhātuyo sannipatitvā mahācetiyaṃ gamissanti, mahācetiyato nāgadīpe
analyzed: tambapaṇṇidīpe dhātuyaḥ sannipatitvā mahācetiyam gamissanti mahācetiyataḥ nāgadīpe
translated: and his disappearance of elements will be in the future. For when the Dispensation is abolished, the relics will assemble here in the Island of Tambapaṇṇi and go to the Great Relic Shrine. From the Great Relic Shrine they will go to the Rājavāha Relic Shrine in the Naga country,

original: rājāyatanacetiyaṃ, tato mahābodhipallaṅkaṃ gamissanti, nāgabhavanatopi devalokatopi
analyzed: rājāyatana cetiyam tatas mahā bodhipallaṅkam gamissanti nāga bhavanataḥ pi deva lokataḥ pi
translated: and from there to the Great Bodhi Tree. And from the Naga world and from the world of the gods they will come and assemble there.

original: brahmalokatopi dhātuyo mahābodhipallaṅkameva gamissanti, sāsapamattāpi dhātu na antarā
analyzed: brahmalokataḥ api dhātuyaḥ mahā bodhi pallaṅkam eva gamissanti sāsapa mattā api dhātu na antarā
translated: and the relics will go from the world of Brahmā to the great Bodhi throne, and not a single relic the size of a mustard seed will be left in between.

original: nassissati. Sabbā dhātuyo mahābodhipallaṅke rāsibhūtā suvaṇṇakkhandho viya ekagghanā
analyzed: sabbāḥ dhātuyaḥ mahā bodhi pallaṅke rāsi bhūtā suvaṇṇa kkhandhaḥ viya ekagghanā
translated: and from the Brahma-world the relics will go to the Great Bodhi Tree. Not even a relic the size of a mustard seed will be lost on the way. All the relics will be heaped up at the Great Bodhi Tree, and will be worth a lump of gold.

original: hutvā chabbaṇṇarasmiyo vissajjessanti, tā dasasahassilokadhātuṃ pharissanti. Tato
analyzed: hutvā chabbaṇṇa rasmiyaḥ vissajjessanti tāḥ dasa sahassi lokadhātum pharissanti tatas
translated: They will be burnt and will emit six-coloured rays, which will spread through the ten-thousand world system.

original: dasasahassacakkavāḷe devatā sannipatitvā “ajja satthā parinibbāti, ajja sāsanaṃ osakkati,
analyzed: dasa sahassa cakkavāḷe devatā sannipatitvā ajja satthā parinibbāti ajja sāsanam osakkati
translated: Then the deities of the ten-thousand world system will assemble and say: “Today the Teacher will attain final Nibbāna. Today the Dispensation will decline.

original: pacchimadassanaṃ dāni idaṃ amhāka”nti dasabalassa parinibbutadivasato mahantataraṃ
analyzed: pacchima dassanam dāni idam amhākam ti dasabalassa parinibbuta divasataḥ mahantataram
translated: This is our last sight of him.” They will feel greater compassion for the ten-powered one on the day of his final Nibbāna than they will on the day of his enlightenment.

original: kāruññaṃ karissanti, ṭhapetvā anāgāmikhīṇāsave avasesā sakabhāvena saṇṭhātuṃ na sakkhissanti.🔽Dhātūsu tejodhātu uṭṭhahitvā yāva brahmalokā uggacchissati, sāsapamattiyāpi dhātuyā
analyzed: kāruññam karissanti ṭhapetvā anāgāmi khīṇāsave avasesā saka bhāvena saṇṭhātum na sakkhissanti  dhātūsu tejaḥ dhātu uṭṭhahitvā yāva brahmalokāḥ uggacchissati dhātuyā
translated: Except for the non-returners and the perfected ones, no one will be able to remain in his own place.🔽The fire element will arise in the relics and will blaze up as far as the Brahma-world. Even if there were only a relic the size of a mustard seed, it would be like a single net.

original: sati ekajālāva bhavissati, dhātūsu pariyādānaṃ gatāsu paricchijjissati. Evaṃ mahantaṃ
analyzed: sati bhavissati dhātūsu pariyādānam gatāsu paricchijjissati evam mahantam
translated: When the relics have been consumed, the net will disappear.

original: ānubhāvaṃ dassetvā dhātūsu antarahitāsu sāsanaṃ antarahitaṃ nāma hoti.
analyzed: ānubhāvam dassetvā dhātūsu antarahitāsu sāsanam antarahitam nāma hoti
translated: When the relics have disappeared, the Dispensation has disappeared.

original: Divā bodhirukkhaṭṭhāne hatthisālāyaṃ tiṭṭhatīti divā vatthuvicinanāya okāsaṃ kurumāno
analyzed: divā bodhi rukkha ṭṭhāne hatthi sālāyam tiṭṭhati iti divā vatthu vicinanāya okāsam kurumānaḥ
translated: “By day it stands in the elephant stable at the Bodhi Tree”: by day it makes room for the search for the relics.

original: tato dhātuṃ gahetvā kumbhe ṭhapetvā sadhātukova hutvā tiṭṭhatīti vadanti. Vuttañhetaṃ mahāvaṃse –
analyzed: tatas dhātum gahetvā kumbhe ṭhapetvā sa dhātukaḥ va hutvā tiṭṭhati iti vadanti vuttam ha etam mahāvaṃse
translated: “Then it takes the relics and places them in the urn and stands there as the urn” is what they say. For this is said in the Mahāvamsa:

original: “Rattiṃ nāgonupariyāti, taṃ ṭhānaṃ so sadhātukaṃ;
analyzed: rattim nāgaḥ unupariyāti tam ṭhānam saḥ sa dhātukam
translated: “By night the nāga goes round, That place is then the urn;

original: Bodhiṭṭhānamhi sālāyaṃ, divā ṭhāti sadhātuko”ti.🔽Thūpapatiṭṭhānabhūmiṃ pariyāyatīti matthakato dhātuṃ tattha patiṭṭhāpetvā sadhātukaṃ🔽thūpapatiṭṭhānabhūmiṃ rattibhāge pariyāyati, samantato vicaratīti attho. Jaṅghappamāṇanti
analyzed: bodhiṭṭhānamhi divā ṭhāti sa dhātukā uti  thūpa patiṭṭhāna bhūmim pariyāyati iti matthakataḥ dhātum tattha patiṭṭhāpetvā sa dhātukam  thūpa patiṭṭhāna bhūmim ratti bhāge pariyāyati samantataḥ vicarati iti atthaḥ jaṅgha ppamāṇam ti
translated: By day the urn stands there, In the elephant stable at the Bodhi Tree.”🔽“It goes round the site of the Thūpa”: having placed the relic at the top there, it goes round the site of the Thūpa as the urn by night,

original: pupphaṭṭhānappamāṇaṃ. Thūpakucchito heṭṭhābhāgañhi thūpassa jaṅghāti vadanti. Dhātuoropanatthāyāti
analyzed: puppha ṭṭhāna ppamāṇam thūpa kucchitaḥ heṭṭhā bhāgam hi thūpassa jaṅghā iti vadanti dhātu oropana atthāya ati
translated: it moves about all round it, is the meaning. “The size of a thigh” is the size of the place for the flowers. For they call the lower part of the Thūpa from the top of the dome the “thigh” of the Thūpa. “For the purpose of depositing the relics” is the purpose of depositing the relics.

original: hatthikumbhato dhātukaraṇḍakassa oropanatthāya. Sakalanagarañca janapado cāti nagaravāsino🔽janapadavāsino ca abhedato nagarajanapadasaddehi vuttā “sabbo gāmo āgato, mañcā ukkuṭṭhiṃ
analyzed: hatthi kumbhataḥ dhātu karaṇḍakassa oropana tthāya sakala nagaram ca janapadaḥ ca ati nagara vāsinaḥ  janapada vāsinaḥ ca abhedataḥ nagara janapada saddehi vuttā sabbaḥ gāmaḥ āgataḥ mañcāḥ ukkuṭṭhim
translated: and from the elephant’s head to the relic casket. The whole city and the country are mentioned together without distinction. The inhabitants of the city🔽and the inhabitants of the country are referred to by the words “the whole city” and “the whole country” respectively, as in the passages “The whole village has come” and “The beds are making a noise by creaking.”

original: karontī”tiādīsu viya. Mahājanakāyeti mahājanasamūhe. Samūhapariyāyo hettha kāyasaddo.
analyzed: karonti itiādīsu mahājana kāya iti mahājana samūhe samūha pariyāyaḥ ha ittha kāya saddo
translated: The great multitude is the great crowd. The word “body” here is a collective term.

original: Ekekadhātuppadesato tejodakanikkhamanādivasena yamakayamakaṃ hutvā pavattaṃ pāṭihāriyaṃ
analyzed: ekeka dhātu padesataḥ teja udaka nikkhamana ādi vasena yamaka yamakam hutvā pavattam pāṭihāriyam
translated: The miracle that occurred in pairs, in the form of the appearance of fire and water, etc., by the manifestation of each relic,

original: yamakapāṭihāriyaṃ. Channaṃ vaṇṇānaṃ rasmiyo cāti sambandho kātabbo. Channaṃ vaṇṇānaṃ🔽udakadhārā cāti evampettha sambandhaṃ vadanti. Parinibbutepi bhagavati tassānubhāvena
analyzed: yamaka pāṭihāriyam channam vaṇṇānam rasmiyaḥ ca ati sambandhaḥ kātabbaḥ channam vaṇṇānam  udaka dhārā ca ati evam pa ittha sambandham vadanti parinibbute api bhagavati tassa anubhāvena
translated: is the “double miracle.” The connection is to be made thus: “The rays of the six colors.” They say that the connection here is thus: “The streams of water of the six colors.”

original: evarūpaṃ pāṭihāriyamahosiyevāti dassetuṃ “evaṃ acintiyā”tiādigāthamāha. Buddhadhammāti ettha buddhaguṇā.
analyzed: evarūpam dassetum evam acintiyā iti ādi gātham āha buddha dhammā ti ettha buddha guṇā
translated: Even after the passing away of the Blessed One, this kind of miracle occurred by his power. In order to show this, the stanza “Thus, by the inconceivable power of the Buddha” is stated. The word “Buddha-Dhamma” here refers to the qualities of the Buddha.

original: Dharamānakālepi tikkhattuṃ āgamāsīti bhagavā kira abhisambodhito navame māse phussapuṇṇamadivase
analyzed: dharamāna kāle pi tikkhattum āgamāsi iti bhagavā kira abhisambodhitaḥ navame māse phussa puṇṇama divase
translated: Even when he was measuring out the earth, he came three times. The Blessed One, it seems, after his enlightenment, in the ninth month, on the full-moon day of the month of Phagguna,

original: yakkhādhivāsaṃ laṅkādīpamupagantvā laṅkāmajjhe tiyojanāyate yojanavitthate mahānāgavanuyyāne
analyzed: yakkha adhivāsam laṅkā dīpam upagantvā laṅkā majjhe tiyojanāyate yojana vitthate mahā nāga van uyyāne
translated: went to the island of Laṅkā, which is inhabited by demons, and in the middle of Laṅkā, in the Mahānāga Garden, three leagues in extent and one league in breadth,

original: mahāyakkhasamāgame upariākāse ṭhatvā kappuṭṭhānasamaye samuṭṭhitavuṭṭhivātanibbisesavassavāyunā🔽ca lokantarikanirayandhakārasadisaghorandhakāranikāyena ca sītanarakanibbisesabahalasītena

translated: And the Fortunate One Kassapa, seeing the destruction of living creatures through the war between the supporting king and the opposing king, being urged on by compassion,

original: imaṃ dīpamāgantvā taṃ kalahaṃ vūpasametvā dhammaṃ desento caturāsīti pāṇasahassāni
analyzed: imam dīpam āgantvā tam kalaham vūpasametvā dhammam desento catur asīti pāṇa sahassāni
translated: having come to this Island, and having pacified that quarrel, teaching the Dhamma, and establishing eighty-four thousand people in the Three knowledges,

original: maggaphalaṃ pāpetvā mahābodhiṭṭhānaṃ gantvā tattha samāpattiṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya
analyzed: magga phalam pāpetvā mahā bodhiṭṭhānam gantvā tattha samāpattim samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya
translated: and having brought them to the state of Stream-Enterer, he went to the Great Bodhi Tree, and after entering into meditation there,

original: “mama nigrodhamahābodhito dakkhiṇamahāsākhamādāya sudhammā bhikkhunī idhāgacchatū”ti
analyzed: mama nigrodha mahābodhitaḥ dakkhiṇa mahā sākham ādāya sudhammā bhikkhunī idha āgacchatu uti
translated: he resolved: “May the nun Sudhammā come here, taking with her the great southern branch of my Nigrodha Great Bodhi Tree.”

original: adhiṭṭhāsi. Sā bhagavato cittaṃ viditvā taṅkhaṇaññeva bārāṇasīrājadhāniyā brahmadattarājānamādāya
analyzed: sā bhagavataḥ cittam viditvā taṅkhaṇaññā iva bārāṇasī rājadhāniyāḥ brahmadatta rājānam ādāya
translated: She, knowing the mind of the Lord, immediately went to the city of Bārāṇasī, and taking with her King Brahmadatta,

original: mahābodhimupagantvā dakkhiṇamahāsākhāya manosilālekhaṃ brahmadattena dāpetvā taṃ
analyzed: mahābodhim upagantvā dakkhiṇa mahā sākhāya manosilā lekham brahmadattena dāpetvā tam
translated: she approached the Great Bodhi Tree, and after having the southern branch engraved with the writing of the Manosilā gem by Brahmadatta,

original: sayaṃ chijjitvā kanakakaṭāhe ṭhitaṃ bodhisākhamādāya pañcasatabhikkhunīparivārā devagaṇaparivutā🔽iddhiyā ettha ānetvā munindena pasārite dakkhiṇakaratale sasuvaṇṇakaṭāhaṃ mahābodhiṃ
analyzed: sayam chijjitvā kanaka kaṭāhe ṭhitam bodhisākham ādāya pañca sata bhikkhunī parivārā deva gaṇa parivutā  iddhiyā ettha ānetvā munindena pasārite dakkhiṇa kara tale sa suvaṇṇa kaṭāham mahā bodhim
translated: she herself cut it off, and taking the branch of the Bodhi Tree which was placed in a golden basket, surrounded by a retinue of five hundred nuns, and by a multitude of gods,🔽she brought it here by her supernatural power, and placed the Great Bodhi Tree in a golden basket in the right hand of the Lord of Sages which was extended out. The Lord gave it to King Jayanta, and by him it was planted in the place called the “Great Sāla Grove” at that time,

original: ṭhapesi. Taṃ bhagavā jayantarañño datvā tena tasmiṃ samaye “mahāsālavana”nti saṅkhyaṃ
analyzed: ṭhapesi tam bhagavā jayantaraññaḥ da tvā tena tasmin samaye mahā sālavananti saṅkhyam
translated: and it was called the “Jayanta Great Bodhi Tree.”

original: gate mahāmeghavanuyyāne mahābodhiṃ patiṭṭhāpesi. Evaṃ imasmiṃ dīpe purimakānaṃ tiṇṇaṃ🔽sammāsambuddhānaṃ bodhiṃ patiṭṭhāpesi. Taṃ sandhāya evamāha “imasmiñca mahārāja dīpe
analyzed: gate mahāmeghavan uyyāne mahābodhim patiṭṭhāpesi evam imasmin dīpe purimakānam tiṇṇam  sammāsambuddhānam bodhim patiṭṭhāpesi tam sandhāya evam āha imasmin ca mahā rāja dīpe
translated: and he planted the Great Bodhi Tree in the Mahāmeghavana Garden. Thus he planted the Bodhi Trees of three former Supreme Buddhas in this Island. With reference to this he said:🔽“In this Island, O King,🔽

original: purimakānaṃ tiṇṇaṃ sammāsambuddhānaṃ bodhi patiṭṭhāsī”ti.🔽Sarasaraṃsijālavissajjanakenāti siniddhatāya rasavantaṃ ojavantaṃ abhinavaraṃsijālaṃ🔽vissajjentena. Atha vā ito cito ca saṃsaraṇato sarasaṃ sajīvaṃ jīvamānaṃ viya raṃsijālaṃ🔽vissajjentena. Atha vā sarasakāle dharamānakāle buddhena viya raṃsijālaṃ muñcantenāti🔽evamettha atthaṃ vaṇṇayanti. Ekadivaseneva agamāsīti sambandho. Pañcahi kaññāsatehīti
analyzed: purimakānam tiṇṇam sammāsambuddhānam bodhi patiṭṭhāsi iti  sa rasa raṃsi jāla vissajjanakena ati sinidh hatāya rasavantam ojavantam abhinava raṃsi jālam  atha vā itas citas ca saṃsaraṇataḥ sa rasam sa jīvam jīvamānam viya raṃsi jālam  vissajjentena atha vā sarasa kāle dharamāna kāle buddhena raṃsi jālam muñcantena ati  evam ettha attham vaṇṇayanti eka divasena iva agamāsi iti sambandho pañcahi kaññā satehi iti
translated: and he planted the Great Bodhi Tree in the Mahāmeghavana Monastery. Thus he planted the Bodhi Trees of three Buddhas in this Island. With reference to this he said: “In this Island, O great king, the Bodhi Trees of three Buddhas have been planted.”

original: attano paricārikehi pañcahi kaññāsatehi. Upassayaṃ kārāpetvāti bhikkhunupassayaṃ
analyzed: attanaḥ paricārikehi pañcahi kaññā satehi upassayam kārāpetvā ati bhikkhun upassayam
translated: With the one who had sent forth a net of rays that were sweet and shining: with the one who had sent forth a net of rays that were sweet, shining and fresh. Or, with the one who had sent forth a net of rays that were sweet, alive, and living as if moving here and there. Or, with the one who had sent forth a net of rays like the Buddha who had held it at the time of the sweet season. Thus they explain the meaning here. He came in one day: the connection is this. With five hundred maidens: with his own five hundred attendants. Having had a nunnery built: having had a nunnery built.

original: kārāpetvā. Appesīti lekhasāsanaṃ patiṭṭhāpesi. Evañca avocāti rājasandesaṃ appetvā
analyzed: kārāpetvā appesi iti lekha sāsanam patiṭṭhāpesi evañca avoca ati rāja sandesam appetvā
translated: and had it written. He sent a message: he had a written message sent.

original: therassa mukhasāsanaṃ viññāpento evaṃ avoca. Udikkhatīti apekkhati pattheti.
analyzed: therassa mukha sāsanam viññāpentaḥ evam avoca udikkhati iti apekkhati pattheti
translated: He said thus: he said thus, making known the Elder’s oral message after sending the king’s message. He looked up: he looked, he desired.

original: Chinnahatthaṃ viyāti chinnahatthavantaṃ viya. Chinnā hatthā etassāti chinnahatthoti
analyzed: chinna hattham viya iti chinna hatthavantam viya chinnāḥ hatthāḥ etassa ati chinna hatthaḥ iti
translated: Like one with a cut-off hand: like one having a cut-off hand. His hand is cut off, thus he is one with a cut-off hand.

original: aññapadatthasamāso daṭṭhabbo. Pabbajjāpurekkhārāti pabbajjābhimukhā, pabbajjāya sañjātābhilāsā🔽“kadā nu kho pabbajissāmī”ti tattha ussukkamāpannāti vuttaṃ hoti. Maṃ paṭimānetīti
analyzed: añña padattha samāsaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ pabbajjā purekkhārā ati pabbajja abhimukhā pabbajjāya sañjāta abhilāsā  kadā nu kho pabbajissāmi iti tattha ussukkam āpannā ati vuttam hoti mama paṭimāneti iti
translated: The compound is to be regarded as a bahubbīhi compound with an omitted term. He was intent on going forth: he was intent on going forth, he was desirous of going forth.

original: maṃ udikkhati. Satthena ghātaṃ na arahatīti asatthaghātārahaṃ. Himavalāhakagabbhanti
analyzed: mam udikkhati satthena ghātam na arahati iti a sattha ghāta araham hima valāhaka gabbhanti
translated: “When shall I go forth?” Thus he was intent on that. He looked up to me: he looked at me. He was not worthy to be killed by a weapon: he was not worthy to be killed by a weapon. In the womb of a cloud of snow:

original: himapuṇṇavalāhakagabbhaṃ. Pāṭihāriyavasena jātaṃ himameva “valāhakagabbha”ntipi vadanti.
analyzed: hima puṇṇa valāhaka gabbham pāṭihāriya vasena jātam himam eva valāhaka gabbham ti pi vadanti
translated: in the womb of a cloud full of snow. By way of a miracle, snow itself is called “the womb of a cloud.”

original: Doṇamattāti magadhanāḷiyā soḷasanāḷippamāṇā.
analyzed: magadha nāḷiyā soḷasa nāḷippamāṇā
translated: The size of a doṇa: sixteen nāḷis of Magadha rice.

original: Magganti sattayojanikaṃ maggaṃ. Paṭijaggāpetvāti sodhāpetvā, khāṇukaṇṭakādīni harāpetvā
analyzed: magganti satta yojanikam maggam paṭijaggāpetvā iti sodhāpetvā khāṇu kaṇṭaka ādīni harāpetvā
translated: The road: a road seven leagues long. Having it looked after: having it cleaned, having stumps, thorns, etc., removed,

original: tattha bahalavipulavālukaṃ okirāpetvāti vuttaṃ hoti. Kammāravaṇṇanti rañño pakatisuvaṇṇakāravaṇṇaṃ.
analyzed: tattha bahala vipula vālukam okirāpetvā iti vuttam hoti kammāra vaṇṇam ti rañño pakati suvaṇṇa kāra vaṇṇam
translated: having it sprinkled and swept, having it made even, having it made beautiful with various adornments. The colour of the royal goldsmith’s: the colour of the king’s ordinary gold.

original: Navahatthaparikkhepanti navahatthappamāṇo parikkhepo assāti navahatthaparikkhepaṃ,🔽parikkhepato navahatthappamāṇanti vuttaṃ hoti. “Pañcahatthubbedha”ntiādīsupi imināva
analyzed: nava hattha parikkhepanti nava hattha ppamāṇaḥ parikkhepaḥ assa ati nava hattha parikkhepam  parikkhepataḥ nava hattha ppamāṇanti vuttam hoti pañca hatthubbedha ntiādīsu pi iminā ava
translated: Nine-league extent: it has a nine-league extent.

original: nayena attho veditabbo. Tihatthavikkhambhanti tihatthappamāṇavitthāraṃ. Samussitadhajapaṭākanti🔽ussāpitanīlapītādivividhadhajapaṭākaṃ. Nānāratanavicittanti tattha tattha racitanānāratanehi
analyzed: nayena atthaḥ veditabbo ti hattha vikkhambhanti ti hattha ppamāṇa vitthāram samussita dhaja paṭākanti  ussāpita nīla pīta ādi vividha dhaja paṭākam tattha tattha racita nānā ratanehi
translated: The extent is nine leagues, is what is meant. The same method of explanation applies to the following terms, “five-league height,” etc. Three-league breadth: it has a three-league breadth.🔽With flags and banners hoisted: with various flags and banners hoisted, blue, yellow, etc.🔽Adorned with various gems: adorned with various gems set here and there.

original: suvicittaṃ. Anekālaṅkārapaṭimaṇḍitanti pasannajanapūjitehi hatthūpagādīhi nānālaṅkārehi
analyzed: su vicittam aneka alaṅkāra paṭimaṇḍitam ti pasanna jana pūjitehi hatthūpaga ādīhi nānā alaṅkārehi
translated: With many decorations: with many decorations, such as the hand-parasol, etc., which are worshipped by the people.

original: sajjitaṃ. Nānāvidhakusumasamākiṇṇanti upahāravasena upanītehi nānappakārehi vaṇṇagandhasampannehi
analyzed: sajjitam nānāvidha kusuma samākiṇṇanti upahāra vasena upanītehi nānappakārehi vaṇṇa gandha sampannehi
translated: “Adorned with various flowers”: strewn with various flowers of various colors and scents that have been brought as offerings.

original: jalathalapupphehi ākiṇṇaṃ. Anekatūriyasaṅghuṭṭhanti ātabhavitatādipañcaṅgikatūriyasaṅghositaṃ.🔽Avasesaṃ adassanaṃ agamāsīti ettha “handa, mahārāja, tayā gahetabbā ayaṃ sākhā, tassa
analyzed: jala thala pupphehi ākiṇṇam aneka tūriya saṅghuṭṭhanti ātabha vitata ādi pañcaṅgika tūriya saṅghositam  avasesam a dassanam agamāsi iti ettha handa mahā rāja tayā gahetabbā ayam sākhā tassa
translated: and strewn. With various flowers means strewn with various flowers of good colour and scent brought as offerings. With the sound of many musical instruments means with the sound of the five musical instruments such as the tabaphalaka, etc.

original: upanissayabhūto ayaṃ khandho, na mayaṃ tayā gahetabbā”ti vadantā viya avasesā sākhā
analyzed: upanissaya bhūtaḥ ayam khandho na mayam tayā gahetabbā ti vadantā viya avasesā sākhā
translated: The rest disappeared from sight. Here they say: “Now, great king, you should take this branch, this trunk is the supporting condition for that, we are not to be taken by you.” Thus speaking, the rest of the branches

original: satthu tejasā adassanamagamaṃsūti vadanti. Gavakkhajālasadisanti bhāvanapuṃsakaṃ,🔽jālakavāṭasadisaṃ katvāti attho. Celukkhepasatasahassāni pavattiṃsūti tesaṃ tesaṃ
analyzed: satthu tejasā vadanti bhāva napuṃsakam  jāla kavāṭa sadisam katvā ti attho celu khepa sata sahassāni tesam tesam
translated: and leaves disappeared from sight through the power of the Teacher. Like the net of Indra means like the net of the god Indra.

original: janānaṃ sīsopari bhamantānaṃ uttarāsaṅgacelānaṃ ukkhepasatasahassāni pavattiṃsūti
analyzed: janānam sīsa upari bhamantānam uttarāsaṅga celānam ukkhepa sata sahassāni pavattiṃsūti
translated: The meaning is: having made it like a net of lattice-work. Hundreds of thousands of robes were waved means the meaning is: hundreds of thousands of robes were waved over the heads of those people who were flying around.

original: attho. Mūlasatenāti dasasu lekhāsu ekekāya dasa dasa hutvā nikkhantamūlasatena. Dasa
analyzed: attho mūla satena ati dasasu lekhāsu ekekāya dasa dasa hutvā nikkhanta mūla satena dasa
translated: With a hundred roots means with a hundred roots which had come out in groups of ten from each of the ten lines.

original: mahāmūlāti paṭhamalekhāya nikkhantadasamahāmūlāni.
analyzed: paṭhama lekhāya nikkhanta dasa mahāmūlāni
translated: ‘Great roots’: the great roots of the first line.

original: Devadundubhiyo phaliṃsūti devadundubhiyo thaniṃsu. Devadundubhīti ca na ettha kāci
analyzed: deva dundubhiyaḥ deva dundubhiyaḥ deva dundubhī iti ca na ettha kāci
translated: ‘The devas’ drums beat’: the devas’ drums sounded. And here the word ‘devas’ drums’ does not refer to any kind of drum,

original: bherī adhippetā, atha kho uppātabhāvena ākāsagato nigghosasaddo. Devoti hi megho.🔽Tassa hi acchabhāvena ākāsavaṇṇassa devassābhāvena sukkhagajjitasaññite sadde niccharante
analyzed: bherī adhippetā atha kho uppāta bhāvena ākāsa gataḥ nigghosa saddaḥ devaḥ ti hi meghaḥ  tassa hi accha bhāvena ākāsa vaṇṇassa devassa abhāvena sukkha gajjita saññite sadde niccharante
translated: but rather to a sound that goes up into the sky by its own impetus. For ‘deva’ means ‘cloud’.🔽And when a sound occurs that is called ‘devas’ drums’ because it is like the sound of a dry lightning flash,

original: devadundubhīti samaññā, tasmā devadundubhiyo phaliṃsūti devo sukkhagajjitaṃ gajjīti
analyzed: deva dundubhī iti samaññā tasmai deva dundubhiyaḥ phaliṃsu uti devaḥ sukkha gajjitam gajjīti
translated: which is the colour of the sky and is very bright, it is said that ‘the devas’ drums beat’.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Pabbatānaṃ naccehīti pathavīkampena ito cito ca bhamantānaṃ pabbatānaṃ
analyzed: vuttam hoti pabbatānam naccehi iti pathavī kampena itas ca itas ca bhamantānam pabbatānam
translated: ‘The mountains danced’: the mountains moved hither and thither by the earthquake.

original: naccehi. Yakkhānaṃ hiṅkārehīti vimhayajātānaṃ yakkhānaṃ vimhayappakāsanavasena pavattehi
analyzed: naccehi yakkhānam hiṅkārehi iti vimhaya jātānam yakkhānam vimhaya ppakāsana vasena pavattehi
translated: ‘The spirits cried out’: the spirits cried out with cries that arose by way of their manifestation of wonder.

original: hiṅkārasaddehi. Yakkhā hi vimhayajātā “hiṃ hi”nti saddaṃ nicchārenti. Thutijappehīti
analyzed: hiṅkāra saddehi yakkhāḥ hi vimhaya jātāḥ him hinti saddam nicchārenti thuti jappehi iti
translated: For when spirits are amazed, they utter the sound ‘Hiṃ hi’. ‘The praises were sung’:

original: pasaṃsāvacanehi. Brahmānaṃ apphoṭanehīti pītisomanassajātānaṃ brahmānaṃ bāhāyaṃ paharaṇasaṅkhātehi
analyzed: pasaṃsā vacanehi brahmānam apphoṭanehi iti pīti somanassa jātānam brahmānam bāhāyam paharaṇa saṅkhātehi
translated: and with words of praise. With the clapping of the Brahmās: with the clapping called the striking of the arms of the Brahmās who were filled with joy and gladness.

original: apphoṭanehi. Pītisomanassajātā hi brahmāno vāmahatthaṃ samiñjitvā dakkhiṇena hatthena
analyzed: apphoṭanehi pīti somanassa jātāḥ hi brahmānaḥ vāma hattham samiñjitvā dakkhiṇena hatthena
translated: For the Brahmās who are filled with joy and gladness, having bent their left arm,

original: bāhāyaṃ pahāraṃ denti. Ekakolāhalanti ekato pavattakolāhalaṃ. Ekaninnādanti ekato
analyzed: bāhāyam pahāram denti eka kolāhalanti ekatas pavatta kolāhalam eka ninnādanti ekatas
translated: give a blow on their arm with their right hand. A single uproar: a single occurrence of uproar. A single shout: a single occurrence of shouting.

original: pavattanigghosaṃ. Phalato nikkhantā chabbaṇṇarasmiyo ujukaṃ uggantvā onamitvā cakkavāḷapabbatamukhavaṭṭiṃ
analyzed: pavatta nigghosam phalataḥ nikkhantā chabbaṇṇa rasmiyaḥ ujukam uggantvā onamitvā cakkavāḷa pabbata mukha vaṭṭim
translated: The rays of the six colours issuing from the fruit went straight up, bent down,

original: āhacca tiṭṭhantīti āha “sakalacakkavāḷaṃ ratanagopānasīvinaddhaṃ viya kurumānā”ti.🔽Taṅkhaṇato ca pana pabhutīti vuttanayena suvaṇṇakaṭāhe patiṭṭhitassa mahābodhissa
analyzed: tiṭṭhanti iti āha sakala cakkavāḷam ratana gopānasī vinaddham viya  tad khaṇato ca pana pabhuti iti vutta nayena suvaṇṇa kaṭāhe patiṭṭhitassa mahā bodhissa
translated: and stood touching the rim of the world-sphere mountain. Therefore it is said: “making the whole world like a jewelled gateway.”🔽And from that moment on: from the moment when the six-coloured rays of the Great Bodhi Tree

original: chabbaṇṇarasmīnaṃ vissajjitakālato pabhuti. Himavalāhakagabbhaṃ pavisitvā aṭṭhāsīti
analyzed: chabbaṇṇa rasmīnam vissajjita kālataḥ pabhuti himavalāhaka gabbham pavisitvā aṭṭhāsi iti
translated: which had been established in the golden casket were emitted, as described above. He stood in the womb of the Himalayas:

original: suvaṇṇakaṭāheneva saddhiṃ uggantvā himodakapuṇṇaṃ valāhakagabbhaṃ pavisitvā aṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: suvaṇṇa kaṭāhena iva saddhim uggantvā himodaka puṇṇam valāhaka gabbham pavisitvā aṭṭhāsi
translated: and it rose up with the golden casket and entered the womb of the cloud filled with cool water and stood there.

original: Paṭhamaṃ suvaṇṇakaṭāhe patiṭṭhitoyeva hi bodhi pacchā vuttappakāraacchariyapaṭimaṇḍito🔽hutvā himavalāhakagabbhaṃ pavisitvā aṭṭhāsi. Teneva vakkhati “paṭhamaṃ suvaṇṇakaṭāhe🔽patiṭṭhahi, tato himagabbhasattāhaṃ abhisekasattāhañca vītināmetvā”tiādi. Tatoyeva
analyzed: paṭhamam suvaṇṇa kaṭāhe patiṭṭhitaḥ yā iva hi bodhi pacchā vutta ppakāra acchariya paṭimaṇḍito  hutvā himavalāhaka gabbham pavisitvā aṭṭhāsi tena iva vakkhati paṭhamam suvaṇṇa kaṭāhe  patiṭṭhahi tatas himagabbha sattāham abhiseka sattāham ca
translated: For the Bodhi Tree stood first in the golden casket and afterwards in the womb of the cloud, which was adorned with the aforesaid wonders.🔽and having stood there it entered the womb of the cloud and stood there. Therefore it is said: “First it stood in the golden casket,

original: ca mahāvaṃsepi vuttaṃ –
analyzed: ca mahā vaṃse pi vuttam
translated: and afterwards it stood in the womb of the cloud for seven days, and for seven days it was sprinkled with water.” And in the Mahāvamsa it is said:

original: “Evaṃ satena mūlānaṃ, tatthesā gandhakaddame;
analyzed: evam satena mūlānam tattha isā gandha kaddame
translated: “Thus with its ten roots it stood there in the fragrant mire,

original: Patiṭṭhāsi mahābodhi, pasādentī mahājanaṃ.
analyzed: patiṭṭhā asi mahā bodhi pasādentī mahā janam
translated: the Great Bodhi Tree, delighting the great multitude.

original: “Tassā khandho dasahattho, pañca sākhā manoramā;
analyzed: tassā khandhaḥ dasa hatthaḥ pañca sākhā manoramā
translated: “Its trunk was ten cubits high, and it had five delightful branches,

original: Catuhatthā catuhatthā, dasaḍḍhaphalamaṇḍitā.
analyzed: catuhatthā catuhatthā dasaḍḍha phala maṇḍitā
translated: four cubits long, four cubits, and ten cubits, adorned with fruits.

original: “Sahassantu pasākhānaṃ, sākhānaṃ tāsamāsi ca;
analyzed: sahassantu pasākhānam sākhānam tāsam asi ca
translated: “And it had a thousand branches, and of those branches

original: Evaṃ āsi mahābodhi, manoharasirindharā.
analyzed: evam āsi mahā bodhi manohara sirindharā
