analyzed: kusalam cittam uppannam hoti tasmin yeva kāle puñje ca phassa ādayaḥ api honti iti ayaṃ hi tattha atthaḥ
translated: When a wholesome consciousness of the sense sphere arises in a given mass of dhammas, in that same mass of dhammas contact, etc., also exist. This is the meaning there.

original: Nanu cāyaṃ upādāya paññatto kālo samūho ca vohāramattako, so kathaṃ ādhāro tattha🔽vuttadhammānanti? Nāyaṃ doso. Yathā hi kālo sabhāvadhammaparicchinno sayaṃ paramatthato🔽avijjamānopi ādhārabhāvena paññatto taṅkhaṇappavattānaṃ tato pubbe parato ca abhāvato🔽“pubbaṇhe jāto sāyanhe gacchatī”tiādīsu, samūho ca avayavavinimutto avijjamānopi
analyzed: nanu ca ayam upādāya paññatto kālo samūho ca vohāra mattako so katham ādhāraḥ tattha  vutta dhammānan ti na ayam dosaḥ yathā hi kālaḥ sabhāva dhamma paricchinno sayam paramatthato  a vijjamānaḥ api ādhāra bhāvena paññatto tad khaṇa ppavattānam tatas pubbe paratas ca abhāvato  pubbaṇhe jātaḥ sāyanhe gacchati iti ādīsu samūhaḥ ca avayava vinimuttaḥ a vijjamānaḥ api
translated: But is not time and collection merely a designation based on something else? How can they be the basis for the dhammas stated there?🔽This is not a fault. For just as time, though itself non-existent in the ultimate sense, is delimited by the dhammas that exist in actuality, and is designated as a basis,🔽since there is no occurrence of dhammas before or after that time, as in the expressions “He who was born in the morning died in the evening,” and so on;

original: kappanāmattasiddho avayavānaṃ ādhārabhāvena paññapīyati “rukkhe sākhā, yavarāsimhi
analyzed: kappanā matta siddhaḥ avayavānam ādhāra bhāvena paññapīyati rukkhe sākhā yava rāsimhi
translated: and just as a collection, though non-existent apart from its components, is designated as a basis for the components, as in the expressions “in the tree there are branches, in the heap of grass there is fire,”

original: sambhūto”tiādīsu, evamidhāpīti daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Abhidhamme ādhāratthasambhavaṃ dassetvā idāni bhāvenabhāvalakkhaṇatthasambhavaṃ dassento
analyzed: sambhūtaḥ iti ādīsu evam idha api iti daṭṭhabbam  abhidhamme ādhāra attha sambhavam dassetvā idāni bhāvena bhāva lakkhaṇa ttha sambhavam dassento
translated: in the passage beginning, “The Blessed One is the one who has arisen” .

original: āha “khaṇasamavāyahetusaṅkhātassā”tiādi. Tattha khaṇo nāma aṭṭhakkhaṇavinimutto navamo🔽buddhuppādasaṅkhāto khaṇo, yāni vā panetāni “cattārimāni, bhikkhave, cakkāni yehi
analyzed: āha khaṇa samavāya hetu saṅkhātassa atiādi tattha khaṇaḥ nāma aṭṭhakkhaṇa vinimuttaḥ navamaḥ  buddhuppāda saṅkhātaḥ khaṇaḥ yāni vā pana itāni cattāri imāni bhikkhave cakkāni yehi
translated: Having shown the occurrence of the meaning of basis in the Abhidhamma, he now shows the occurrence of the meaning of characteristic of presence and absence in the words “of that” and so on. Herein, the moment is the ninth moment, which is not included in the eight moments,

original: samannāgatānaṃ devamanussānaṃ catucakkaṃ pavattatī”ti ettha patirūpadesavāso, sappurisūpanissayo,🔽attasammāpaṇidhi, pubbe ca katapuññatāti cattāri cakkāni vuttāni, tāni ekajjhaṃ katvā
analyzed: samannāgatānam deva manussānam catu cakkam pavattati iti ettha patirūpa desa vāso sappurisa upanissayo  pubbe ca kata puñña tā ti cattāri cakkāni vuttāni tāni ekajjham katvā
translated: or it is the moment called the arising of a Buddha. Or again, the four wheels that are stated in the passage beginning, “Bhikkhus, there are these four wheels. When these are present in a monk or a nun, it is not long before they realize the supreme security from bondage” ,🔽namely, living in a suitable locality, associating with people of virtue,

original: okāsaṭṭhena khaṇoti veditabbo. Tāni hi kusaluppattiyā okāsabhūtāni. Samavāyo nāma
analyzed: okāsa aṭṭhena khaṇo ti veditabbo tāni hi kusala uppattiyāḥ okāsa bhūtāni samavāyaḥ nāma
translated: right aspiration, and previously accumulated merit, are called the moment in the sense of opportunity,🔽for they are the opportunity for the arising of the profitable. The concurrence is the concurrence of the eye, visible data, light, and the appropriate activity of the mind, which is stated in the passage beginning, “Dependent on the eye and forms eye-consciousness arises” ,

original: “cakkhuñca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhuviññāṇa”nti evamādinā niddiṭṭhā cakkhuviññāṇādisaṅkhātasādhāraṇaphalanipphādakattena
analyzed: cakkhum ca paṭicca rūpe ca uppajjati cakkhu viññāṇan ti evamādinā niddiṭṭhā cakkhu viññāṇa ādi saṅkhāta sādhāraṇa phala nipphādaka ttena
translated: and so on. It is the concurrence of the eye, etc., in the producing of the eye-consciousness, etc., which are the shared fruits of the concurrence.

original: saṇṭhitā cakkhurūpādipaccayasāmaggī. Cakkhurūpādīnañhi cakkhuviññāṇādisādhāraṇaphalaṃ.🔽Hetūti janakahetu. Yathāvuttakhaṇasaṅkhaātassa samavāyasaṅkhātassa hetusaṅkhātassa
analyzed: saṇṭhitā cakkhu rūpa ādi paccaya sāmaggī cakkhu rūpa ādīnam hi cakkhu viññāṇa ādi sādhāraṇa phalam  hetu iti janaka hetu yathāvutta khaṇa saṅkhaātassa samavāya saṅkhātassa hetu saṅkhātassa
translated: The state of being present is the state of being complete of the conditions beginning with eye and visible-data. For the eye and visible data, etc., are the joint fruit of eye-consciousness, and so on.

original: ca samayassa bhāvena sattāya tesaṃ phassādidhammānaṃ bhāvo sattā lakkhīyati viññāyatīti
analyzed: ca samayassa bhāvena sattāya tesam phassa ādi dhammānam bhāvo sattā lakkhīyati viññāyati iti
translated: Cause is the cause that generates. The state of being present of the states of consciousness beginning with eye-consciousness is characterized by the presence of the cause called the “state” consisting in the presence of the conditions beginning with eye and visible data.

original: attho. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – yathā “gāvīsu duyhamānāsu gato, duddhāsu āgato”ti dohanakiriyāya
analyzed: attho idam vuttam hoti yathā gāvīsu duyhamānāsu gataḥ duddhāsu āgataḥ iti dohana kiriyāya
translated: The meaning is that it is known. This is what is said: just as the act of going is characterized by the act of milking in the passage, “When the cows were being milked he went” , so too here the meaning “present” is known when the words “at the time of that, at that time” are used,🔽because there is no absence of the presence of the meaning of the words in the absence of a connection with another act.

original: gamanakiriyā lakkhīyati, evamidhāpi “yasmiṃ samaye, tasmiṃ samaye”ti ca vutte “satī”ti🔽ayamattho viññāyamāno eva hoti aññakiriyāya sambandhābhāve padatthassa sattāvirahābhāvatoti
analyzed: gamana kiriyā lakkhīyati evam idha api yasmin samaye tasmin samaya iti ca vutte sati iti  ayam atthaḥ viññāyamānaḥ eva hoti añña kiriyāya sambandha abhāve padatthassa sattā viraha abhāvato ti
translated: This is what is said: just as the act of milking is characterized by the act of going in the passage, “When the cows were being milked he went” , so too here the meaning “present” is known when the words “at the time of that, at that time” are used,🔽because there is no absence of the presence of the meaning of the words in the absence of a connection with another act.

original: samayassa sattākiriyāya cittassa uppādakiriyā phassādibhavanakiriyā ca lakkhīyatīti.
analyzed: samayassa sattā kiriyāya cittassa uppāda kiriyā phassa ādi bhavana kiriyā ca lakkhīyati iti
translated: The state of being present of the states of consciousness beginning with eye-consciousness is characterized by the act of the state of being present of the cause, and by the act of arising of the mind, and by the act of occurrence of the states beginning with contact.

original: Ayañhi tattha attho yasmiṃ yathāvutte khaṇe paccayasamavāye hetumhi ca sati kāmāvacaraṃ
analyzed: ayam hi tattha atthaḥ yasmin yathā vutte khaṇe paccaya samavāye hetumhi ca sati kāmāvacaram
translated: For this is the meaning here: when, at the moment stated thus, there is concurrence of conditions and a cause, then a profitable consciousness belonging to the sense sphere

original: kusalaṃ cittaṃ uppannaṃ hoti, tasmiṃyeva khaṇe paccayasamavāye hetumhi ca sati phassādayopi
analyzed: kusalam cittam uppannam hoti tasmiṃ yeva khaṇe paccaya samavāye hetumhi ca sati phassa ādayaḥ api
translated: arises, and at that same moment there is contact, etc., too, when there is concurrence of conditions and a cause.

original: hontīti. Tadatthajotanatthanti adhikaraṇatthassa bhāvenabhāvalakkhaṇatthassa ca dīpanatthaṃ.
analyzed: honti iti tad attha jotana ttham ti adhikaraṇa atthassa bhāvenabhāva lakkhaṇa tthassa ca dīpana ttham
translated: The purpose of the words “to show that meaning” is to show the meaning of the function of the basis and the meaning of the characteristic of non-existence.🔽Here in this Discipline:

original: Idha panāti imasmiṃ vinaye. Hetuattho karaṇattho ca sambhavatīti “annena vasati,
analyzed: idha panāti imasmin vinaye hetu attho karaṇa attho ca sambhavati iti annena vasati
translated: the meaning of cause and the meaning of instrument are possible. As in such passages as “He lives by alms”🔽and “He lives by knowledge,”

original: vijjāya vasatī”tiādīsu viya hetuattho “pharasunā chindati, kudālena khaṇatī”tiādīsu
analyzed: vijjāya vasati itiādīsu pharasunā chindati kudālena khaṇati itiādīsu
translated: and as in such passages as “He cuts with an axe” and “He digs with a spade,”

original: viya karaṇattho ca sambhavati. Kathaṃ sambhavatīti āha “yo hi so”tiādi. Tena samayena🔽hetubhūtena karaṇabhūtenāti ettha pana taṃtaṃvatthuvītikkamova sikkhāpadapaññattiyā
analyzed: viya karaṇa attho ca sambhavati katham sambhavati iti āha yaḥ hi saḥ iti ādi tena samayena  hetu bhūtena karaṇa bhūtena ati ettha pana taṃ taṃ vatthu vītikkamaḥ u sikkhāpada paññattiyā
translated: the meaning of cause and the meaning of instrument are possible. How is it possible? He said “For that” and so on.🔽At that time🔽by the cause that was and by the instrument that was: here, however, the transgression of the various bases is both the cause and the instrument for the announcement of the training precept.

original: hetu ceva karaṇañca. Tathā hi yadā bhagavā sikkhāpadapaññattiyā paṭhamameva tesaṃ
analyzed: hetu ca iva karaṇam ca tathā hi yadā bhagavā sikkhāpada paññattiyā paṭhamam eva tesam
translated: For when the Blessed One first announced the training precept

original: tesaṃ tattha tattha taṃtaṃsikkhāpadapaññattihetubhūtaṃ vītikkamaṃ apekkhamāno viharati,
analyzed: tesam tattha tattha taṃ taṃ sikkhāpada paññatti hetu bhūtam vītikkamam apekkhamānaḥ viharati
translated: He lives looking for the transgression that is the cause for the announcement of the particular training rule here and there.

original: tadā taṃ taṃ vītikkamaṃ apekkhitvā tadatthaṃ vasatīti siddho vatthuvītikkamassa hetubhāvo
analyzed: tadā tam tam vītikkamam apekkhitvā tad attham vasati iti siddhaḥ vatthu vītikkamassa hetu bhāvaḥ
translated: Then, looking for that transgression, he lives for that purpose. So the cause-relation of the basis-transgression is established,

original: “annena vasati, annaṃ apekkhitvā tadatthāya vasatī”tiādīsu viya. Sikkhāpadapaññattikāle🔽pana teneva pubbasiddhena vītikkamena sikkhāpadaṃ paññapetīti sikkhāpadapaññattiyā
analyzed: annena vasati annam apekkhitvā tad atthāya vasati itiādīsu viya sikkhāpada paññatti kāle  pana tena iva pubba siddhena vītikkamena sikkhāpadam paññapeti iti sikkhāpada paññattiyā
translated: just as in such passages as “He lives by food, looking for food, living for that purpose.”🔽But at the time of announcing the training rule,

original: sādhakatamattā karaṇabhāvopi vītikkamasseva siddho “asinā chindatī”tiādīsu viya.
analyzed: sādhakatama ttā karaṇa bhāvaḥ api vītikkamassa iva siddhaḥ asinā chindati iti ādīsu
translated: he announces the training rule by means of that previously established transgression. So the instrument-relation of the basis-transgression is established by the mere fact of its being the means of announcing the training rule,🔽just as in such passages as “He cuts with a knife.”

original: Vītikkamaṃ pana apekkhamāno teneva saddhiṃ tannissayakālampi apekkhitvā viharatīti
analyzed: vītikkamam pana apekkhamāno tena iva saddhim tad nissaya kālam pi apekkhitvā viharati iti
translated: But looking for the transgression, he lives looking for the time that is its basis.

original: kālassapi idha hetubhāvo vutto, sikkhāpadaṃ paññapento ca taṃ taṃ vītikkamakālaṃ
analyzed: kālassa api idha hetu bhāvaḥ vutto sikkhāpadam paññapento ca tam tam vītikkama kālam
translated: So the time is said to be the cause here. And when he announces the training rule,

original: anatikkamitvā teneva kālena sikkhāpadaṃ paññapetīti vītikkamanissayassa kālassapi
analyzed: an atikkamitvā tena iva kālena sikkhāpadam paññapeti iti vītikkama nissayassa kālassa api
translated: he announces the training rule by means of that time without exceeding the time of the transgression. So the time that is the basis of the transgression🔽is also said to be the cause.

original: karaṇabhāvo vutto, tasmā iminā pariyāyena kālassapi hetubhāvo karaṇabhāvo ca labbhatīti🔽vuttaṃ “tena samayena hetubhūtena karaṇabhūtenā”ti. Nippariyāyato pana vītikkamoyeva
analyzed: karaṇa bhāvaḥ vuttaḥ tasmai iminā pariyāyena kālassa api hetu bhāvaḥ karaṇa bhāvo ca labbhati iti  vuttam tena samayena hetu bhūtena karaṇa bhūtena ati nippariyāyataḥ pana
translated: The meaning of instrument is stated, and so it is in this way that the meaning of cause and the meaning of instrument are applicable to the time.🔽That is why it is said, “At that time, as cause and as instrument.” But in the ultimate sense, the transgression itself

original: hetubhūto karaṇabhūto ca. So hi vītikkamakkhaṇe hetu hutvā pacchā sikkhāpadapaññāpane karaṇampi hotīti.
analyzed: hetu bhūto karaṇa bhūto ca saḥ hi vītikkama khaṇe hetu hutvā pacchā sikkhāpada paññāpane karaṇam pi hoti iti
translated: is both the cause and the instrument. For it is the cause at the moment of the transgression, and afterwards, at the proclamation of the training precept, it is the instrument.

original: Sikkhāpadāni paññāpayantoti vītikkamaṃ pucchitvā bhikkhusaṅghaṃ sannipātāpetvā otiṇṇavatthukaṃ
analyzed: sikkhāpadāni paññāpayanto ti vītikkamam pucchitvā bhikkhu saṅgham sannipātāpetvā otiṇṇa vatthukam
translated: “Proclaiming the training precepts”: after asking about the transgression, he assembles the Sangha of monks, and after questioning the person who has committed the offense about the basis of the offense

original: puggalaṃ paṭipucchitvā vigarahitvā ca taṃ taṃ vatthuṃ otiṇṇakālaṃ anatikkamitvā teneva🔽kālena karaṇabhūtena sikkhāpadāni paññāpayanto. Sikkhāpadapaññattihetuñca apekkhamānoti
analyzed: puggalam paṭipucchitvā vigarahitvā ca tam tam vatthum otiṇṇa kālam an atikkamitvā tena iva  kālena karaṇa bhūtena sikkhāpadāni paññāpayantaḥ sikkhāpada paññatti hetuñca apekkhamāno ti
translated: and censuring him, he proclaims the training precepts at that very time, with that as the instrument, without exceeding the time of the transgression.

original: tatiyapārājikādīsu viya sikkhāpadapaññattiyā hetubhūtaṃ taṃ taṃ vatthuṃ vītikkamasamayaṃ
analyzed: tatiya pārājika ādīsu viya sikkhāpada paññattiyāḥ hetu bhūtam tam tam vatthum vītikkama samayam
translated: “And taking into account the reason for the proclamation of the training precepts”: the basis of the offense that is the cause for the proclamation of the training precepts, such as in the case of the third offense entailing expulsion and so on, is the transgression itself at the time of the transgression.

original: apekkhamāno tena samayena hetubhūtena bhagavā tattha tattha vihāsīti attho. “Sikkhāpadāni
analyzed: apekkhamānaḥ tena samayena hetu bhūtena bhagavā tattha tattha vihāsi iti attho sikkhāpadāni
translated: The meaning is that the Blessed One lived there at that time, looking to the occasion as the cause. “When he was laying down training rules”

original: paññāpayanto sikkhāpadapaññattihetuñca apekkhamāno”ti vacanato “tena samayena karaṇabhūtena
analyzed: paññāpayantaḥ sikkhāpada paññatti hetuñca apekkhamāno ti vacanataḥ tena samayena karaṇa bhūtena
translated: means “when he was looking to the occasion as the cause for laying down training rules.” Although it should be said “at that time, looking to the occasion as the cause or as the occasion,”

original: hetubhūtenā”ti evaṃ vattabbepi paṭhamaṃ “hetubhūtenā”ti vacanaṃ idha hetuatthassa🔽adhippetattā vuttaṃ. Bhagavā hi verañjāyaṃ viharanto therassa sikkhāpadapaññattiyācanahetubhūtaṃ
analyzed: hetu bhūtena ati evam vattabbe pi paṭhamam hetu bhūtena ati vacanam idha hetu atthassa  adhippeta ttā vuttam bhagavā hi verañjāyam viharantaḥ therassa sikkhāpada paññatti yācana hetu bhūtam
translated: still the words “looking to the occasion as the cause” are said here because the meaning of cause is intended.🔽For the Blessed One lived there at that time, looking to the occasion as the cause, that is, the time of reflection that was the cause for the elder’s request for the laying down of training rules, while staying at Verañjā.

original: parivitakkasamayaṃ apekkhamāno tena samayena hetubhūtena vihāsīti tīsupi gaṇṭhipadesu
analyzed: parivitakka samayam apekkhamānaḥ tena samayena hetu bhūtena vihāsi iti tīsu pi gaṇṭhi padesu
translated: Thus it is said in all three passages.

original: vuttaṃ. Kiṃ panettha yutticintāya, ācariyassa idha kamavacanicchā natthīti evametaṃ
analyzed: vuttam kim pana ittha yutti cintāya ācariyassa idha kama vacana icchā natthi iti evam etam
translated: But what is the use of reasoning here? The teacher’s wish is to be taken as the criterion.

original: gahetabbaṃ. Teneva dīghanikāyaṭṭhakathāyampi “tena samayena hetubhūtena karaṇabhūtenā”tiādinā
analyzed: gahetabbam tena iva tena samayena hetu bhūtena karaṇa bhūtena ati ādinā
translated: That is why in the Dīgha-nikāya Commentary too it is said: “At that time, looking to the occasion as the cause or as the occasion.”

original: ayameva anukkamo vutto. Na hi tattha paṭhamaṃ “hetubhūtenā”ti vacanaṃ idha “tena
analyzed: ayam eva anukkamaḥ vuttaḥ na hi tattha paṭhamam hetu bhūtena ati vacanam idha tena
translated: This is the order given. For the words “through the state of cause” are not stated first here.

original: samayena verañjāyaṃ viharatī”ti ettha hetuatthassa adhippetabhāvadīpanatthaṃ vuttaṃ.🔽“Sikkhāpadāni paññāpayanto hetubhūtena karaṇabhūtena samayena vihāsi, sikkhāpadapaññattihetuñca🔽apekkhamāno hetubhūtena samayena vihāsīti evamettha sambandho kātabbo”tipi vadanti.
analyzed: samayena verañjāyam viharati iti ettha hetu atthassa adhippeta bhāva dīpana attham vuttam  sikkhāpadāni paññāpayantaḥ hetu bhūtena karaṇa bhūtena samayena vihāsi sikkhāpada paññatti hetuñca  apekkhamānaḥ hetu bhūtena samayena vihāsi iti evam ettha sambandhaḥ kātabbā iti pi vadanti
translated: This is the sequence given. For the words “with the reason” are not said here in order to show that the reason is intended in the words “at that time he was living at Verañjā.”🔽“When he was laying down the training rules he lived at that time with the reason, with the function, and he lived with the reason, looking for the reason for laying down the training rules,” so they say.

original: Tadatthajotanatthanti hetuatthassa karaṇatthassa vā dīpanatthaṃ. Idhāti imasmiṃ vinaye.🔽Hoti cetthāti ettha imasmiṃ padese yathāvuttatthasaṅgahavasena ayaṃ gāthā hoti. Aññatrāti suttābhidhammesu.
analyzed: tad attha jotana ttham ti hetu atthassa karaṇa tthassa vā dīpana ttham idha ati imasmin vinaye  hoti ca itthā ati ettha imasmin padese yathā vutta attha saṅgaha vasena ayam gāthā hoti aññatra ati sutta abhidhammesu
translated: “In order to show the meaning of reason, the meaning of function”: in order to show the meaning of reason, the meaning of function. “Herein”: in this Discipline.🔽“If there is”: in this passage, this verse is in order to include the meaning stated thus. “Elsewhere”: in the Suttas and the Abhidhamma.

original: Porāṇāti aṭṭhakathācariyā. Abhilāpamattabhedoti vacanamattena viseso. Tena suttavinayesu
analyzed: porāṇā ati aṭṭhakathā cariyā abhilāpa matta bhedo ti vacana mattena viseso tena sutta vinayesu
translated: “The ancients”: the teachers of the commentaries. “The difference is merely verbal”: the difference is merely in the words. Therefore, in the Suttas and the Vinaya,

original: vibhattivipariṇāmo katoti dasseti. Parato atthaṃ vaṇṇayissāmāti parato “itipi so
analyzed: vibhatti vipariṇāmaḥ kataḥ iti dasseti paratas attham vaṇṇayissāma ati paratas iti pi saḥ
translated: He shows that the change of case has been made.

original: bhagavā”tiādinā āgataṭṭhāne vaṇṇayissāma. Verañjāyanti ettha “balikaraggahaṇena janassa🔽pīḷābhāvato niddosattā vigato rajo assāti verañjā, serivāṇijajātake devadattassa🔽veruppannapadese katattā veraṃ ettha jātanti verañjā, paviṭṭhapaviṭṭhe naṭasamajjādīhi🔽khādanīyabhojanīyālaṅkārādīhi ca vividhehi upakaraṇehi rañjanato vividhehi rañjayatīti🔽verañjā, paṭipakkhe abhibhavitvā katabhāvato veraṃ abhibhavitvā jātāti verañjā, verañjassa
analyzed: bhagavā ati ādinā āgata ṭṭhāne vaṇṇayissāma verañjāyanti ettha bali kara ggahaṇena janassa  pīḷā bhāvataḥ niddosa ttā vigataḥ rajaḥ assa ati verañjā seri vāṇija jātake devadattassa  vera uppanna padese kata ttā veram ettha jātanti verañjā paviṭṭha paviṭṭhe naṭa sa majja ādīhi  khādanīya bhojanīya alaṅkāra ādīhi ca vividhehi upakaraṇehi rañjanataḥ vividhehi rañjayati iti  verañjā paṭipakkhe abhibhavitvā kata bhāvataḥ veram abhibhavitvā jātā ati verañjā verañjassa
translated: We shall comment on the meaning later on, in the place where the passage beginning “Thus indeed he is the Exalted One” occurs.

original: nāma isino assamaṭṭhāne katattā verañjā”ti evamādinā keci vaṇṇayanti. Kiṃ iminā,
analyzed: nāma isinaḥ assama ṭṭhāne katattā verañjāti evamādinā keci vaṇṇayanti kim iminā
translated: In Verañjā: here some comment thus: “Because of the absence of danger to people by the seizure of the ploughshare, dust is absent, thus it is dustless (rajo virato = rañjo); because of the occurrence of enmity here, it is Verañjā, in the place where Devadatta’s enmity arose in the Serivāṇijajātaka; because of the delighting of those who have entered in by various means, such as actors, etc., and by various requisites, such as food, drink, ornaments, etc., it delights in various ways, thus it is Verañjā; because of the arising of enmity after overcoming opponents, it is Verañjā, after arising by overcoming enmity; because of the occurrence in the hermitage of the sage named Verañja, it is Verañjā.” What is the use of this?

original: nāmamattametaṃ tassa nagarassāti dassento āha “verañjāti aññatarassa nagarassetaṃ
analyzed: nāmam attam etam tassa nagarassa ati dassentaḥ āha verañjā ati aññatarassa nagarassa etam
translated: Showing that this is merely the name of that city, he said: “Verañjā is the name of a certain city.

original: adhivacana”nti. Samīpatthe bhummavacananti “gaṅgāyaṃ gāvo caranti, kūpe gaggakula”ntiādīsu🔽viya. Avisesenāti “pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati. Paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja🔽viharati. Mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati. Sabbanimittānaṃ amanasikārā
analyzed: adhivacananti samīpa atthe bhumma vacananti gaṅgā ayam gāvaḥ caranti kūpe gagga kulanti ādīsu  viya avisesena ati pātimokkha saṃvara saṃvutaḥ viharati paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja  viharati mettā sahagatena cetasā ekam disam pharitvā viharati sabba nimittānam a manasikārā
translated: As in such passages as ‘Cows graze in the Ganges’ and ‘The Brahmajāla is in the Kūṭa’ .

original: animittaṃ cetosamādhiṃ samāpajjitvā viharatī”tiādīsu viya saddantarasannidhānasiddhena
analyzed: animittam cetaḥ samādhim samāpajjitvā viharati itiādīsu
translated: Without distinction: without the distinction being made by the mention of a different term, as in the following passages: ‘Dwelt restrained by the restraint of the Pātimokkha’ , ‘entered upon and dwelt in the first jhāna’ , ‘dwelt pervading one direction with his heart endued with loving- kindness’ , ‘having entered upon the odourless concentration of mind, dwelled in it’ .

original: visesaparāmasanena vinā. Atha vā avisesenāti na visesena, vihārabhāvasāmaññenāti attho.
analyzed: visesa parāmasanena vinā atha vā avisesena ati na visesena vihāra bhāva sāmaññena ati attho
translated: Or alternatively, without distinction means without making a distinction; the meaning is, by the mere fact of their being abidings.

original: Iriyāpatha…pe… vihāresūti iriyāpathavihāro dibbavihāro brahmavihāro ariyavihāroti
analyzed: vihāresu uti iriyāpatha vihāraḥ dibba vihāraḥ brahma vihāraḥ ariya vihāro
translated: In the postures, etc.: the ‘posture-abiding’ , the ‘divine abiding’ , the ‘Brahma-abiding’ , and the ‘noble abiding’ .

original: etesu catūsu vihāresu. Tattha iriyanaṃ pavattanaṃ iriyā, kāyappayogo kāyikakiriyā.
analyzed: etesu catūsu vihāresu tattha iriyanam pavattanam iriyā kāya ppayogo kāyika kiriyā
translated: Herein, the ‘posture’ is the going, moving about, occurring, bodily action, bodily function.

original: Tassā pavattanupāyabhāvato iriyāya pathoti iriyāpatho, ṭhānanisajjādi. Na hi ṭhānanisajjādīhi
analyzed: tassā pavatta nupāya bhāvataḥ iriyāya patho ti iriyāpathaḥ ṭhāna nisajja ādi na hi ṭhāna nisajja ādīhi
translated: It is the ‘path’ of the posture because it is the means to its occurrence, thus it is the ‘posture-path’ ; it is standing, sitting, etc.,🔽for it is by means of standing, sitting, etc.,

original: avatthāhi vinā kañci kāyikakiriyaṃ pavattetuṃ sakkā. Ṭhānasamaṅgī vā hi kāyena kiñci🔽kareyya gamanādīsu aññatarasamaṅgī vāti. Viharaṇaṃ, viharati etenāti vā vihāro, iriyāpathova
analyzed: avatthāhi vinā kañci kāyika kiriyam pavattetum sakkā ṭhāna samaṅgī vā hi kāyena kiñci  kareyya gamana ādīsu aññatara samaṅgī vā ati viharaṇam viharati etena ati vā vihāraḥ iriyāpatha uva
translated: and no bodily action can be performed without a posture. Or alternatively, he would be without a posture if he were without any one of the postures beginning with going.🔽The abode is the posture, which is so called because one dwells in it, or because one goes by it.

original: vihāro iriyāpathavihāro, so ca atthato ṭhānanisajjādiākārappavatto catusantatirūpappabandhova.🔽Divi bhavo dibbo, tattha bahulappavattiyā brahmapārisajjādidevalokabhavoti attho.
analyzed: vihāro iriyāpatha vihāro so ca atthataḥ ṭhāna nisajja ādi ākāra ppavatto catu santati rūpa ppabandho va  divi bhavaḥ dibbaḥ tattha bahula ppavattiyā brahma pārisajja ādi deva loka bhavaḥ ti attho
translated: The abode of the divine is the divine abode. The divine abode is the posture, which is so called because it is the cause of the divine, or because it is the abode of the divine.🔽The divine is that which exists in the heavens, which is the divine world consisting of the Brahmā’s Retinue, etc., because it exists there in abundance.

original: Tattha yo dibbānubhāvo tadatthāya saṃvattatīti vā dibbo, abhiññābhinīhāravasena mahāgatikattā
analyzed: tattha yaḥ dibba anubhāvaḥ tad atthāya saṃvattati iti vā dibbaḥ abhiññā abhinīhāra vasena mahāgatikattā
translated: Herein, it is the divine because it is the cause of the divine, or it is the divine because it is the cause of the divine.

original: vā dibbo, dibbo ca so vihāro cāti dibbavihāro, dibbabhāvāvaho vā vihāro dibbavihāro,
analyzed: vā dibbaḥ dibbaḥ ca so vihāro ca ati dibbavihāro dibba bhāva āvahaḥ vā vihāraḥ dibbavihāro
translated: The divine abode is the divine abode, which is the cause of the divine state, or the abode of the divine.

original: mahaggatajjhānāni. Āruppasamāpattiyopi hi ettheva saṅgahaṃ gacchanti. Nettiyaṃ pana
analyzed: mahaggata jhānāni āruppa samāpattiyaḥ pi hi ettha iva saṅgaham gacchanti nettiyam pana
translated: The divine abodes are the jhānas of the fine-material sphere. The immaterial attainments are included here too. But in the Netti it is said:

original: “catasso āruppasamāpattiyo āneñjavihāro”ti vuttaṃ, taṃ mettājhānādīnaṃ brahmavihāratā
analyzed: catasso āruppa samāpattiyaḥ āneñja vihāro ti vuttam tam mettā jhāna ādīnam brahmavihāra tā
translated: “The four immaterial attainments are the abode of imperturbability” is said. This is the state of the divine abidings such as loving-kindness, etc.

original: viya tāsaṃ bhāvanāvisesabhāvaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Aṭṭhakathāsu pana dibbabhāvāvahasāmaññato🔽tāpi “dibbavihārā”tveva vuttā. Brahmānaṃ vihārā brahmavihārā, brahmāno vā vihārā
analyzed: viya tāsam bhāvanā visesa bhāvam sandhāya vuttam aṭṭhakathāsu pana dibba bhāva āvaha sāmaññato  tā api vuttā brahmānam vihārāḥ brahmavihārāḥ brahmānaḥ vā vihārā
translated: “The four immaterial attainments are the divine abiding of imperturbability” is said. That is said with reference to their being a special kind of development, like the divine abiding of the divine abidings consisting in the jhāna of loving-kindness, and so on. But in the commentaries they are called “divine abidings” too, because they cause a divine, that is, a heavenly, mode of life.

original: brahmavihārā, hitūpasaṃharādivasena pavattiyā brahmabhūtā seṭṭhabhūtā vihārāti attho,
analyzed: brahmavihārāḥ pavattiyā brahma bhūtā seṭṭha bhūtā vihārā ti attho
translated: The divine abidings of the Brahmās are the divine abidings of the Brahmās, or the divine abidings of the Brahmās are the divine abidings of the Brahmās. The meaning is: abidings that are divine, that is, supreme, in being manifested by means of the arousing of will for welfare, and so on.

original: mettājhānādikā catasso appamaññāyo. Ariyā uttamā vihārāti ariyavihārā, anaññasādhāraṇattā🔽ariyānaṃ vā vihārā ariyavihārā, catasso phalasamāpattiyo. Visesato pana rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānaṃ
analyzed: mettā jhāna ādikā catasso appamaññāyaḥ ariyāḥ uttamāḥ vihārā ati ariya vihārā anañña sādhāraṇa ttā  ariyānam vā vihārā ariya vihārā catasso phala samāpattiyaḥ visesato pana rūpāvacara catuttha jhānam
translated: The four divine abidings are the four measureless states consisting in the jhāna of loving-kindness, and so on.

original: catasso appamaññāyo catutthajjhānikaphalasamāpatti ca bhagavato dibbabrahmaariyavihārā.
analyzed: catasso appamaññāyo catutthajjhānika phala samāpatti ca bhagavataḥ dibba brahma ariya vihārā
translated: The noble abidings are the four jhānas of the fine-material sphere. But the divine, Brahmā, and noble abidings of the Blessed One are the fourth jhāna of the fine-material sphere, the four measureless states, and the fourth jhāna as fruition attainment.

original: Aññataravihārasamaṅgīparidīpananti yathāvuttavihāresu aññataravihārasamaṅgībhāvaparidīpanaṃ.
analyzed: aññatara vihāra samaṅgī paridīpanam ti yathā vutta vihāresu aññatara vihāra samaṅgī bhāva paridīpanam
translated: “The exposition of the possession of a certain abode” is the exposition of the possession of a certain one of the abodes mentioned above.

original: Bhagavā hi lobhadosamohussannakāle loke tassa sakāya paṭipattiyā vinayanatthaṃ dibbabrahmaaayavihāre
analyzed: bhagavā hi lobha dosa mohuḥ sanna kāle loke tassa sakāya paṭipattiyā vinayana attham dibba brahma aaya vihāre
translated: For when greed, hatred, and delusion are rampant in the world, the Blessed One, in order to train people in his own practice,🔽enters upon the divine, the brahma, and the noble abodes.

original: upasampajja viharati. Tathā hi yadā sattā kāmesu vippaṭipajjanti, tadā kira bhagavā🔽dibbena vihārena viharati tesaṃ alobhakusalamūluppādanatthaṃ “appeva nāma imaṃ paṭipattiṃ
analyzed: upasampajja viharati tathā hi yadā sattā kāmesu vippaṭipajjanti tadā kira bhagavā  dibbena vihārena viharati tesam alobha kusala mūla uppādana tham appa eva nāma imam paṭipattim
translated: For when beings are addicted to sensual pleasures, the Blessed One, it seems,

original: disvā ettha ruciṃ uppādentā kāmesu virajjeyyu”nti. Yadā pana issariyatthaṃ sattesu
analyzed: disvā ettha rucim uppādentā kāmesu virajjeyyunti yadā pana issariya ttham sattesu
translated: dwells in the divine abodes in order to arouse in them the wholesome root of non-greed, thinking: “Perhaps they will take delight in this practice and become free from greed for sensual pleasures.”

original: vippaṭipajjanti, tadā pana brahmavihārena viharati tesaṃ adosakusalamūluppādanatthaṃ
analyzed: vippaṭipajjanti tadā pana brahmavihārena viharati tesam adosa kusala mūla uppādana ttham
translated: But when beings are addicted to power, he dwells in the brahmavihāras in order to arouse in them the wholesome root of non-hatred, thinking:

original: “appeva nāma imaṃ paṭipattiṃ disvā ettha ruciṃ uppādetvā adosena dosaṃ vūpasameyyu”nti.
analyzed: appā iva nāma imam paṭipattim disvā ettha rucim uppādetvā adosena dosam vūpasameyyunti
translated: “Perhaps they will take delight in this practice and, through non-hatred, will suppress hatred.”

original: Yadā pana pabbajitā dhammādhikaraṇaṃ vivadanti, tadā ariyavihārena viharati tesaṃ
analyzed: yadā pana pabbajitāḥ dhamma adhikaraṇam vivadanti tadā ariya vihārena viharati tesam
translated: But when the monks dispute a legal question on the True Idea, then he lives the life of a Noble One

original: amohakusalamūluppādanatthaṃ “appeva nāma imaṃ paṭipattiṃ disvā tattha ruciṃ uppādetvā🔽amohena mohaṃ vūpasameyyu”nti. Evañca katvā imehi dibbabrahmaariyavihārehi sattānaṃ
analyzed: amoha kusala mūla uppādana tham appa eva nāma imam paṭipattim disvā tattha rucim uppādetvā  amohena moham vūpasameyyunti evañca katvā imehi dibba brahma ariya vihārehi sattānam
translated: in order to arouse in them the profitable root non-delusion, thinking “ Perhaps they will arouse interest in this practice and

original: vividhaṃ hitasukhaṃ harati upaharati upaneti janeti uppādetīti “viharatī”ti vuccati.
analyzed: vividham hita sukham harati upaharati upaneti janeti uppādeti iti viharati iti vuccati
translated: suppress delusion by non-delusion.” And when he has done so, then he is said to “ live the life” in that he carries to, carries out, brings, generates, various kinds of welfare and pleasure for beings by means of these divine, heavenly, and noble lives.

original: Iriyāpathavihārena pana na kadāci na viharati taṃ vinā attabhāvapariharaṇābhāvato,
analyzed: iriyāpatha vihārena pana na kadācid na viharati tam vinā atta bhāva pariharaṇa abhāvataḥ
translated: But he never fails to live the life of posture, since without that there is no maintaining of the selfhood.

original: tatoyeva ca dibbavihārādīnampi sādhāraṇo iriyāpathavihāroti āha “idha panā”tiādi.
analyzed: ca dibba vihāra ādīnam pi sādhāraṇaḥ iriyāpatha vihāro ti āha idha pana atiādi
translated: And since the life of posture is common to the divine life, etc., too, he said “ Herein, however, ” etc.

original: Iriyāpathasamāyogaparidīpananti itaravihārasamāyogaparidīpanassa visesavacanassa
analyzed: iriyāpatha samāyoga paridīpananti itara vihāra samāyoga paridīpanassa visesa vacanassa
translated: As the demonstration of the association with the posture: since there is no special expression of the demonstration of the association with the other lives,

original: abhāvato iriyāpathasamāyogaparidīpanassa ca atthasiddhattā vuttaṃ. Asmiṃ pana pakkhe
analyzed: abhāvataḥ iriyāpatha samāyoga paridīpanassa ca attha siddhattā vuttam asmin pana pakkhe
translated: and since the demonstration of the association with the posture is established in meaning, it is said. But in this case

original: viharatīti ettha vi-saddo vicchedatthajotano, haratīti neti pavattetīti attho, vicchinditvā🔽haratīti vuttaṃ hoti. Tattha kassa kena vicchindanaṃ, kathaṃ kassa pavattananti antolīnacodanaṃ🔽sandhāyāha “so hī”tiādi. Soti bhagavā. Yadipi bhagavā ekenapi iriyāpathena cirataraṃ🔽kālaṃ attabhāvaṃ pavattetuṃ sakkoti, tathāpi upādinnakasarīrassa nāma ayaṃ sabhāvoti
analyzed: viharati iti ettha visaddaḥ viccheda attha jotanaḥ harati iti na iti pavatteti iti atthaḥ vicchinditvā  harati iti vuttam hoti tattha kassa kena vicchindanam katham kassa pavattanam ti antolīna codanam  sandhāya āha saḥ hi itiādi saḥ iti bhagavā yadi api bhagavā ekena api iriyāpathena cirataram  kālam atta bhāvam pavattetum sakkoti tathā api upādinnaka sarīrassa nāma ayam sabhāvaḥ ti
translated: “He abides” : here the prefix vi- indicates the meaning of separation; the meaning is that he “takes away” , i.e., he causes to go. What is meant is that he “takes away” , i.e., causes to go, after having separated. Here, whose separation? By what? How? Whose occurrence?🔽With reference to this implied question, the Exalted One says “For he” , etc. “He” refers to the Exalted One. Although the Exalted One is able to cause his person to occur for a long time by means of a single posture, still this is the nature of a person who has assumed a material body.

original: dassetuṃ “ekaṃ iriyāpathabādhana”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Aparipatantanti apatantaṃ. Yasmā🔽pana bhagavā yattha katthaci vasanto vineyyānaṃ dhammaṃ desento nānāsamāpattīhi ca🔽kālaṃ vītināmento vasatīti sattānaṃ attano ca vividhaṃ hitasukhaṃ harati upaneti,🔽tasmā vividhaṃ haratīti viharatīti evampettha attho veditabbo.
analyzed: dassetum ekam iriyāpatha bādhana ntiādi vuttaṃ aparipatantam ti apatantam yasmā 🔽pana bhagavā yattha katthaci vasantaḥ vineyyānam dhammaṃ desentaḥ nānā samāpattīhi ca 🔽kālam vasati iti sattānam attano ca vividham hita sukham harati upaneti 🔽tasmai vividham harati iti viharati iti evam pi ittha atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: “He abides” : the prefix vi- in viharati signifies “discernment” . The meaning is that he “takes away” , he “leads” . What is meant is that he “takes away” , having discerned. Herein, whose taking away of what is discerned? How does he lead? The Blessed One, it seems, is able to maintain his person for a very long time in one posture. Nevertheless, “one posture” is said in order to show that this is the nature of one who has taken up a material body. He does not fall down. But since the Blessed One abides wherever he lives, teaching the Dhamma to those who can be trained, and spending his time in the various attainments, he takes away, he brings, various kinds of welfare and pleasure to beings and to himself. Therefore the meaning here should be understood thus: he abides because he takes away various things.

original: Naḷerupucimandamūleti ettha vaṇṇayanti – naḷerūti tasmiṃ rukkhe adhivatthayakkhassetaṃ🔽adhivacanaṃ, tasmā tena adhivattho pucimando “naḷerussa pucimando naḷerupucimando”ti🔽vuccati. Atha vā naḷe ruhattā jātattā naḷeru. Susiramettha naḷasaddena vuccati, tasmā🔽rukkhasusire jātattā naḷeru ca so pucimando cāti naḷerupucimandoti vuccati. Naḷavane
analyzed: naḷeru pucimandamūlā iti ettha vaṇṇayanti naḷerū ti tasmin rukkhe adhivattha yakkhassa etam  adhivacanam tasmā tena adhivatthaḥ pucimandaḥ naḷerussa pucimandaḥ naḷeru pucimando ti  vuccati atha vā naḷe ruhattā jāta ttā naḷeru susiram ettha naḷa saddena vuccati tasmā  rukkha susire jāta ttā naḷeru ca so pucimando ca ati naḷeru pucimando ti vuccati naḷa vane
translated: Naḷerupucimandamūlaṃ: here they explain it thus: Naḷeru is a designation for the yakkha who resides in that tree. Therefore the tree is called “naḷerussa pucimando” . Or alternatively, it is a naḷeru because it is born having grown in a reed, and a reed is called a naḷa here. Therefore it is called a naḷeru and a pucimando because it is born in a hollow of a reed tree. In a reed grove

original: ruhattā jātattā vā naḷeru. Naḷavane kira so pucimandarukkho jāto. Urunaḷo pucimando🔽naḷerupucimando. Urusaddo cettha mahantapariyāyo, naḷasaddo susirapariyāyo, tasmā🔽mahantena susirena samannāgato pucimando naḷerupucimandoti vuccatīti. Ācariyo pana🔽kimettha bahubhāsitenāti ekamevatthaṃ dassento “naḷeru nāma yakkho”tiādimāha.
analyzed: ruhattā jāta ttā vā naḷeru naḷa vane kira so pucimanda rukkhaḥ jātaḥ uru naḷaḥ pucimando 🔽naḷeru pucimando urusaddo ca ittha mahanta pariyāyaḥ naḷasaddo susira pariyāyo tasmā 🔽mahantena susirena samannāgato pucimando naḷerupucimando ti vuccati iti ācariyo pana 🔽kim ettha bahu bhāsitena ati ekam eva attham dassentaḥ naḷeru nāma yakkhaḥ ti ādim āha
translated: Naḷerupucimandamūlaṃ: here they explain it as follows. Naḷeru is a designation for the yakkha who dwelt in that tree. Therefore the tree is called “naḷerussa pucimando” . Or alternatively, it is a naḷeru because it grew in a reed bed. A reed bed is here called a “naḷa” . Therefore it is called a naḷeru because it grew in a reed bed, and it is a pucimanda tree, thus it is called a naḷerupucimanda . Or alternatively, it is a naḷeru because it grew in a reed forest. It seems that this tree grew in a reed forest. It is a pucimanda tree with a large reed hollow, thus it is called a naḷerupucimanda . The word uru has the meaning of “large,” and the word naḷa has the meaning of “hollow.” Therefore it is called a naḷerupucimanda because it is a pucimanda tree with a large hollow. But the teacher says: “What is the use of talking much here? He shows the meaning in brief, saying: ‘The naḷeru is a yakkha.’ ”

original: Mūla-saddo ettha samīpavacano adhippeto, na mūlamūlādīsu vattamānoti dassento āha
analyzed: mūla saddaḥ ettha samīpa vacanaḥ adhippetaḥ na mūla mūla ādīsu vattamānaḥ iti dassentaḥ āha
translated: The word “root” here is intended to signify “neighborhood,” not what occurs in the sense of “root-root,” etc. Showing this, he said

original: “mūlanti samīpa”ntiādi. Nippariyāyena sākhādimato saṅghātassa suppatiṭṭhitabhāvasādhane🔽avayavavisese pavattamāno mūlasaddo yasmā taṃsadisesu tannissaye padese ca ruḷhīvasena
analyzed: mūlam ti samīpa ntiādi nippariyāyena sākhādimato saṅghātassa su patiṭṭhita bhāva sādhane  avayava visese pavattamānaḥ mūla saddaḥ yasmā tad sadisesu tad nissaye padese ca ruḷhī vasena
translated: “Root is neighborhood,” etc. The word “root” occurring in the particular part that is the means of establishing the well-establishedness of the collection beginning with branch in the primary sense

original: pariyāyato pavattati, tasmā “mūlāni uddhareyyā”ti ettha nippariyāyato mūlaṃ adhippetanti
analyzed: pariyāyataḥ pavattati tasmai mūlāni uddhareyyāti ettha nippariyāyataḥ mūlam adhippetanti
translated: occurs figuratively in the sense of the place that is the support of that. Therefore, in the passage “he should pull out the roots,” the root is intended in the primary sense.

original: ekena mūlasaddena visesetvā āha “mūlamūle dissatī”ti yathā “dukkhadukkhaṃ, rūparūpa”nti🔽ca. Asādhāraṇahetumhīti asādhāraṇakāraṇe. Lobho hi lobhasahagataakusalacittuppādasseva
analyzed: ekena mūla saddena visesetvā āha mūla mūle dissati iti yathā dukkha dukkham rūpa rūpanti  ca asādhāraṇa hetumhi iti asādhāraṇa kāraṇe lobhaḥ hi lobha sahagata akusala cittuppādassa iva
translated: Distinguishing it by means of the single word “root,” he said “The root-root is seen.” Just as “painful-pain” and “form-form.”🔽The uncommon causes: the uncommon reasons. For greed is the cause of only the unprofitable consciousness accompanied by greed,

original: hetuttā asādhāraṇo, tasmā lobhasahagatacittuppādānameva āveṇike nesaṃ suppatiṭṭhitabhāvasādhanato
analyzed: hetu tā asādhāraṇaḥ tasmā lobha sahagata citta uppādānam eva āveṇike na isam su patiṭṭhita bhāva sādhanato
translated: and so it is uncommon. Therefore, only the consciousness accompanied by greed is their uncommon cause, since it is the means of establishing their well-establishedness.

original: mūlaṭṭhena upakārake paccayadhammaviseseti attho. Atha vā yathā alobhādayo kusalābyākatasādhāraṇā,
analyzed: mūla ṭṭhena upakārake paccaya dhamma visese iti atthaḥ atha vā yathā alobha ādayaḥ kusala abyākata sādhāraṇā
translated: Or alternatively, while non-greed, etc., are shared by the profitable and the indeterminate,

original: lobhādayo pana tathā na honti akusalasseva sādhāraṇattāti asādhāraṇakāraṇaṃ. Atha
analyzed: lobha ādayaḥ pana tathā na honti akusalassa iva sādhāraṇa ttā ati asādhāraṇa kāraṇam atha
translated: greed, etc., are not shared thus since they are shared only by the unprofitable. So they are an unshared cause.

original: vā ādīsūti ettha ādi-saddena alobhādīnampi kusalābyākatamūlānaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo.🔽Tesupi hi alobhādikusalamūlaṃ akusalābyākatehi asādhāraṇattā asādhāraṇakāraṇaṃ, tathā
analyzed: vā ādīsu iti ettha ādi saddena alobha ādīnam pi kusala abyākata mūlānam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo  hi alobha ādi kusala mūlam akusala abyākatehi asādhāraṇa ttā asādhāraṇa kāraṇam tathā
translated: Or alternatively, in the phrase “and so on” the “and so on” should be regarded as including the roots of the profitable and the indeterminate, which are non-greed, etc.,🔽since the profitable root of non-greed, etc., is an unshared cause since it is not shared by the unprofitable and the indeterminate,🔽and likewise the indeterminate root of non-greed, etc., is not shared by the other two.

original: alobhādiabyākatamūlampi itaradvayehi asādhāraṇattāti. Nivāteti vātarahite padese,
analyzed: alobha ādi abyākata mūlam nivātā iti vāta rahite padese
translated: In a windless place: in a place free from wind,🔽or in the absence of wind.🔽They fall: the reading is also ayameva vā pāṭho.

original: vātassa abhāve vā. Patantīti nipatanti, ayameva vā pāṭho. Ramaṇīyoti manuñño. Pāsādikoti
analyzed: vātassa abhāve vā patanti iti nipatanti ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ ramaṇīyo ti manuñño pāsādiko ti
translated: Delightful: agreeable.🔽Inspiring confidence:🔽causing confidence to arise, is the meaning.

original: pasādāvaho, pasādajanakoti attho. Ādhipaccaṃ kurumāno viyāti sambandho.
analyzed: pasāda āvahaḥ pasāda janakaḥ iti atthaḥ ādhipaccam kurumānaḥ viya ati sambandhaḥ
translated: The construction is: acting as a dominant condition as if.

original: Tatthāti “tena samayena buddho bhagavā verañjāyaṃ viharati naḷerupucimandamūle”ti
analyzed: tattha ati tena samayena buddhaḥ bhagavā verañjāyam viharati naḷeru puci manda mūla iti
translated: There: “At that time the Blessed One was living at Verañjā at the root of the Naḷeru-tree yonder” .

original: yaṃ vuttaṃ, tattha. Siyāti kassaci evaṃ parivitakko siyā, vakkhamānākārena kadāci🔽codeyya vāti attho. Yadi tāva bhagavātiādīsu codakassāyamadhippāyo – “pāṭaliputte🔽pāsāde vasatī”tiādīsu viya adhikaraṇādhikaraṇaṃ yadi bhaveyya, tadā “verañjāyaṃ viharati🔽naḷerupucimandamūle”ti adhikaraṇadvayaniddeso yutto siyā, imesaṃ pana bhinnadesattā
analyzed: yam vuttam tattha siyā ti kassaci evam parivitakkaḥ siyā vakkhamāna ākārena kadāci  codeyya vā ati atthaḥ yadi tāva bhagavā ati ādīsu codakassa ayam adhippāyaḥ pāṭaliputte  pāsāde vasati itiādīsu adhikaraṇa adhikaraṇam yadi tadā verañjāyam viharati  naḷeru puci manda mūla iti adhikaraṇa dvaya niddesaḥ yuttaḥ siyā imesam pana bhinna desa ttā
translated: “It might be thought” : this is a thought that might occur to someone. The meaning is: “He might accuse at some time in the way he is about to accuse.”🔽If, first, the accuser’s intention is this: “Just as it is said that the Blessed One ‘dwells in the Pāsāda at Pāṭaliputta,’ so too, if the place of the dispute were the same, then it would be proper to specify both places, saying ‘He dwells in Verañjā at the root of the Nigrodha tree.’ But since these are different places, it is not proper to specify both.”

original: na yutto ubhayaniddesoti. Atha tattha viharatīti yadi naḷerupucimandamūle viharati.🔽Na vattabbanti nānāṭhānabhūtattā verañjānaḷerupucimandamūlānaṃ “tena samayenā”ti
analyzed: na yuttaḥ ubhaya niddeso ti atha tattha viharati iti yadi naḷeru puci manda mūle viharati  na vattabbanti nānā ṭhāna bhūta ttā verañjā naḷeru puci manda mūlānam tena samayena ati
translated: If, secondly, the accuser’s intention is this: “If he dwells at the root of the Nigrodha tree, then he does not dwell in Verañjā,”

original: ca vuttattāti adhippāyo. Idāni codako tameva attano adhippāyaṃ “na hi sakkā”tiādinā
analyzed: ca vutta ttā ti adhippāyaḥ idāni codakaḥ tam eva attanaḥ adhippāyam na hi sakkā iti ādinā
translated: the meaning is: “It cannot be said that he dwells in both places, because they are different places.” The accuser now reveals his own intention, saying “It cannot be said,” etc.

original: vivarati. Verañjānaḷerupucimandamūlānaṃ bhūmibhāgavasena bhinnattāyeva hi na sakkā
analyzed: bhūmi bhāga vasena bhinna ttāya iva hi na sakkā
translated: The meaning is: “It cannot be said that he dwells in both places, because Verañjā and the root of the Nigrodha tree are different places, and because it is said ‘at that time.’“

original: ubhayattha teneva samayena viharituṃ, “ubhayattha teneva samayenā”ti ca vuttattā
analyzed: ubhayattha tena iva samayena viharitum ubhayattha tena iva samayena ati ca vutta ttā
translated: and that he dwelt on both occasions at the same time,

original: nānāsamaye vihāro avāritoti veditabbo.
analyzed: nānā samaye vihāraḥ a vāritaḥ ti veditabbo
translated: and that he dwelt on both occasions at the same time, it must be understood that he did not dwell on different occasions.

original: Itaro sabbametaṃ aviparītamatthaṃ ajānantena tayā vuttanti dassento “na kho panetaṃ
analyzed: itaraḥ sabbam etam aviparītam attham a jānantena tayā vuttan ti dassento na kho pana itam
translated: The other, showing that all this was said by you who do not know the meaning correctly, said, “But it should not be regarded thus.”

original: evaṃ daṭṭhabba”ntiādimāha. Tattha etanti “verañjāyaṃ viharati naḷerupucimandamūle”ti
analyzed: evam daṭṭhabba nti ādim āha tattha etat ti verañjāyam viharati naḷeru puci manda mūla iti
translated: Herein, this means this statement, “He was staying at Verañjā at the foot of a tree in a threshing-sleet.”

original: etaṃ vacanaṃ. Evanti “yadi tāva bhagavā”tiādinā yaṃ taṃ bhavatā coditaṃ, taṃ atthato
analyzed: etam vacanam yadi tāva bhagavā ati ādinā yam tam bhavatā coditam tam atthataḥ
translated: Thus means that what you have asked about in the passage beginning, “If the Blessed One was staying at Verañjā,” should not be regarded as having that meaning.

original: evaṃ na kho pana daṭṭhabbaṃ, na ubhayattha apubbaṃ acarimaṃ vihāradassanatthanti
analyzed: evam na kho pana daṭṭhabbam na ubhayattha apubbam acarimam vihāra dassana atthanti
translated: The meaning is that it should not be regarded as showing that he dwelt on both occasions at the same time, not before and not after.

original: attho. Idāni attanā yathādhippetaṃ aviparītamatthaṃ tassa ca paṭikacceva vuttabhāvaṃ
analyzed: idāni attanā yathā adhippetam aviparītam attham tassa ca vutta bhāvam
translated: Now, in order to make it clear that the meaning he himself had in mind was not that, and that he had already stated it,

original: tena ca appaṭividdhataṃ pakāsento “nanu avocumha samīpatthe bhummavacana”ntiādimāha.
analyzed: tena ca appaṭividdha tam pakāsentaḥ nanu avocumha samīpa atthe bhumma vacana nti ādim āha
translated: and that it had not been understood by the other, he said, “But did we not say that the locative case has the sense of proximity?”

original: Goyūthānīti gomaṇḍalāni. Evampi naḷerupucimandamūle viharaticceva vattabbaṃ, na verañjāyanti,
analyzed: go yūthāni iti go maṇḍalāni evam pi naḷeru puci manda mūle viharati icca iva vattabbam na verañjāyanti
translated: Goyūthānīti gomaṇḍalāni. Evampi naḷerupucimandamūle viharaticceva vattabbaṃ, na verañjāyanti,

original: tasmā samīpādhikaraṇatthavasena ubhayathā nidānakittane kiṃ payojananti codanaṃ manasi
analyzed: ubhayathā nidāna kittane kim codanam manasi
translated: tasmā samīpādhikaraṇatthavasena ubhayathā nidānakittane kiṃ payojananti codanaṃ manasi

original: nidhāyāha “gocaragāmanidassanattha”ntiādi. Assāti bhagavato.
analyzed: nidhāya āha gocara gāma nidassana ttha ntiādi assa ati bhagavataḥ
translated: nidhāyāha “gocaragāmanidassanattha”ntiādi. Assāti bhagavato.

original: Avassañcettha gocaragāmakittanaṃ kattabbaṃ. Yathā hi naḷerupucimandamūlakittanaṃ
analyzed: avassan ca ittha gocara gāma kittanam kattabbam yathā hi naḷeru puci manda mūla kittanam
translated: Avassañcettha gocaragāmakittanaṃ kattabbaṃ. Yathā hi naḷerupucimandamūlakittanaṃ

original: pabbajitānuggahakaraṇādianekappayojanaṃ, evaṃ gocaragāmakittanampi gahaṭṭhānuggahakaraṇādivividhappayojananti
analyzed: pabbajita anuggaha karaṇa ādi aneka ppayojanam evam gocara gāma kittanam pi gahaṭṭha anuggaha karaṇa ādi vividha ppayojanan ti
translated: pabbajitānuggahakaraṇādianekappayojanaṃ, evaṃ gocaragāmakittanampi gahaṭṭhānuggahakaraṇādivividhappayojananti

original: dassento “verañjākittanenā”tiādimāha. Tattha gahaṭṭhānuggahakaraṇanti tesaṃ tattha
analyzed: dassentaḥ verañjā kittanena ati ādim āha tattha gaha ṭṭha anuggaha karaṇam ti tesam tattha
translated: dassento “verañjākittanenā”tiādimāha. Tattha gahaṭṭhānuggahakaraṇanti tesaṃ tattha

original: paccayaggahaṇena upasaṅkamanapayirupāsanādīnaṃ okāsadānena dhammadesanāya saraṇesu
analyzed: paccaya ggahaṇena okāsa dānena dhamma desanāya saraṇesu
translated: paccayaggahaṇena upasaṅkamanapayirupāsanādīnaṃ okāsadānena dhammadesanāya saraṇesu

original: sīlesu ca patiṭṭhāpanena yathūpanissayaṃ uparivisesādhigamāvahanena ca gahaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: sīlesu ca patiṭṭhāpanena yathūpanissayam upari visesa adhigama āvahanena ca gaha ṭṭhānam
translated: sīlesu ca patiṭṭhāpanena yathūpanissayaṃ uparivisesādhigamāvahanena ca gahaṭṭhānaṃ

original: anuggahakaraṇaṃ. Pabbajitānuggahakaraṇanti uggahaparipucchānaṃ kammaṭṭhānānuyogassa
analyzed: anuggaha karaṇam pabbajita anuggaha karaṇam ti uggaha paripucchānam kammaṭṭhāna anuyogassa
translated: and helping. Helping those gone forth means helping with the work of learning and questioning, with the practice of meditation subjects,

original: ca anurūpavasanaṭṭhānapariggahenettha pabbajitānaṃ anuggahakaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: ca anurūpa vasana ṭṭhāna pariggahena ittha pabbajitānam anuggaha karaṇam
translated: and helping. Helping those gone forth: here helping those gone forth is by providing a suitable place for learning, questioning, and the practice of the meditation subject.

original: Paccayaggahaṇeneva paccayaparibhogasiddhito āha “tathā purimena…pe… vivajjananti.
analyzed: paccaya ggahaṇena iva paccaya paribhoga siddhitaḥ āha tathā
translated: Since the use of requisites is accomplished by the mere acceptance of them, he says, “Likewise, with the next … avoidance.”

original: Tattha purimenāti verañjāvacanena. Āhito ahaṃmāno etthāti attā, attabhāvo. Tassa🔽kilamatho kilantabhāvo attakilamatho, attapīḷā attadukkhanti vuttaṃ hoti, tassa anuyogo🔽karaṇaṃ attakilamathānuyogo, upavāsakaṇṭakāpassayaseyyādinā attano dukkhuppādananti
analyzed: tattha purimena ati verañjā vacanena āhitaḥ ahaṃmānaḥ ettha ati attā atta bhāvaḥ tassa  kilamatho kilantabhāvaḥ attakilamatho attapīḷā attadukkhanti vuttam hoti tassa anuyogo  karaṇam atta kilamatha anuyogaḥ upavāsa kaṇṭaka apassaya seyya ādinā attanaḥ dukkha uppādanan ti
translated: Herein, the next is the invitation at Verañjā. The self is what is here called “I,” the individual essence.🔽The fatigue of that is the state of being fatigued,🔽the state of being tired; what is meant is, the pain, the suffering, of the self. The pursuit of that is the doing of that,

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Tassa vivajjanaṃ attakilamathānuyogavivajjanaṃ. Antogāme vasantānaṃ
analyzed: vuttam hoti tassa vivajjanam atta kilamatha anuyoga vivajjanam antogāme vasantānam
translated: what is meant is, the production of one’s own pain by such things as fasting, lying on a bed of rough hides, and so on. The avoidance of that is the avoidance of the pursuit of the pain of the self.

original: anicchantānampi visabhāgarūpādiārammaṇadassanādisambhavato bahigāme patirūpaṭṭhāne
analyzed: an icchantānam pi visa bhāga rūpa ādi ārammaṇa dassana ādi sambhavataḥ bahigāme patirūpa ṭhāne
translated: Since even those who do not want to see visible objects, etc., when they live in a village, are bound to see, hear, or touch visible objects, etc., of a kind to arouse cankers, he said “in a suitable place outside a village.”

original: vasantānaṃ tadabhāvato āha “pacchimena vatthukāmappahānato”tiādi. Tattha pacchimenāti
analyzed: tad abhāvataḥ āha pacchimena vatthu kāma ppahānato tiādi tattha pacchimena ati
translated: “By the abandoning of the objects of sense desire” and so on. Herein, “by the western” is

original: naḷerupucimandamūlavacanena. Kilesakāmassa vatthubhūtattā rūpādayo pañca kāmaguṇā🔽vatthukāmo, tassa pahānaṃ vatthukāmappahānaṃ. Kāmasukhallikānuyogavivajjanupāyadassananti
analyzed: kilesa kāmassa rūpa ādayo pañca kāma guṇā  vatthu kāmaḥ tassa pahānam vatthu kāma ppahānam kāma sukhallikā anuyoga vivajjana upāya dassanam ti
translated: by the words “naḷeru” , “pucimanda” , and “mūla” . The five strands of sense pleasure, namely, visible forms, etc., are the objects of sense desire🔽because they are the objects of sense desire as defilement. The abandoning of that is the abandoning of the objects of sense desire. The “showing of the means for avoiding devotion to indulgence in sense pleasures” is

original: vatthukāmesu kilesakāmasaṃyuttassa sukhassa yogo anuyogo anubhavo, tassa parivajjane upāyadassanaṃ.🔽Sayameva gocaragāmaṃ upasaṅkamitvā attano dhammassavanānurūpabhabbapuggalānaṃ dassanato🔽dhammadesanāya kālo sampatto nāma hotīti dhammadesanāya abhiyogo viññāyatīti āha
analyzed: vatthu kāmesu kilesa kāma saṃyuttassa sukhassa yogaḥ anuyogaḥ anubhavaḥ tassa parivajjane upāya dassanam  sayam eva gocara gāmam upasaṅkamitvā attanaḥ dhamma ssavana anurūpa bhabba puggalānam dassanato  dhamma desanāya kālo sampattaḥ nāma hoti iti dhamma desanāya abhiyogaḥ viññāyati iti āha
translated: the means for avoiding the enjoyment, devotion, indulgence, and inclination towards the pleasure associated with the defilement of sense desire in the objects of sense desire.🔽Having gone to the village for alms by himself, he shows by his own conduct that the time has come for the teaching of the Dhamma, since he has seen people who are capable of understanding the Dhamma and who are suitable to hear the Dhamma.

original: “purimena ca dhammadesanābhiyoga”nti. Dhammadesanāya saussāhabhāvo dhammadesanābhiyogo.
analyzed: purimena ca dhamma desanā abhiyogam ti dhamma desanāya saussāha bhāvaḥ dhamma desanā abhiyogaḥ
translated: Therefore it is said: “By the devotion to the teaching of the Dhamma by the first.” The devotion to the teaching of the Dhamma is the eagerness for the teaching of the Dhamma.

original: Bahigāme vivittokāse vasantassa ākiṇṇavihārābhāvato kāyavivekādīsu adhimutti tappoṇatā
analyzed: bahigāme vivitta ukāse vasantassa ākiṇṇa vihāra abhāvataḥ kāya viveka ādīsu adhimutti tad poṇa tā
translated: Since he lives in a secluded place outside the village, his devotion to bodily seclusion, etc., is evident because he has no crowded living.

original: viññāyatīti āha “pacchimena vivekādhimutti”nti.
analyzed: viññāyati iti āha pacchimena viveka adhimuttim ti
translated: Hence it is said: “By the last, devotion to seclusion.”

original: Dhammadesanābhiyogavivekādhimuttīnaṃ hetubhūtā eva karuṇāpaññā dhammadesanāya upagamanassa
analyzed: dhamma desanā abhiyoga viveka adhimuttīnam hetu bhūtā eva karuṇā paññā dhamma desanāya upagamanassa
translated: Compassion and understanding, which are the causes of devotion to the seclusion of teaching the Dhamma, are the reasons for his going to teach the Dhamma and for his returning from it.

original: tato apagamanassa kāraṇabhūtā hontīti āha “purimena karuṇāya upagamana”ntiādi. Karuṇāpaññāyeva
analyzed: tatas apagamanassa kāraṇa bhūtāḥ honti iti āha purimena karuṇāya upagamana ntiādi karuṇā paññāya iva
translated: Hence it is said: “By the first, going by way of compassion” and so on.

original: hi anantaradukassa hetū honti. Etena ca karuṇāya upagamanaṃ na lābhādinimittaṃ, paññāya
analyzed: hi anantara dukassa hetū honti etena ca karuṇāya upagamanam na lābha ādi nimittam paññāya
translated: For compassion and understanding are the reasons for his going and returning.

original: apagamanaṃ na virodhādinimittanti upagamanāpagamanānaṃ nirupakkilesataṃ vibhāvibhanti
analyzed: apagamanam na virodha ādi nimittam
translated: And by this it is shown that his going is not for the sake of gain, etc., and his returning is not because of opposition, etc.🔽The purity of his going and returning should be understood.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Adhimuttatanti tanninnabhāvaṃ. Nirupalepananti anupalepanaṃ anallīyanaṃ.
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam adhimutta tanti tad ninna bhāvam nirupalepananti anupalepanam an allīyanam
translated: “Devotion” means being intent on it. “Uncontaminated” means unsoiled, unattached.

original: Dhammikasukhāpariccāganimittanti ettha dhammikasukhaṃ nāma anavajjasukhaṃ. Tañhi
analyzed: dhammika sukha a pariccāga nimittan ti ettha dhammika sukham nāma anavajja sukham tat hi
translated: “The reason for not giving up the pleasure of Dhamma”: the pleasure of Dhamma is blameless pleasure.

original: dhammikaṃ lābhaṃ paṭicca uppannattā “dhammikasukha”nti vuccati. Uttarimanussadhammābhiyoganimittaṃ
analyzed: dhammikam lābham paṭicca uppanna ttā dhammika sukhanti vuccati uttari manussa dhamma abhiyoga nimittam
translated: It is called “happiness in accordance with the Dhamma” because it arises in dependence on gain in accordance with the Dhamma. The construction is: “The reason for the happiness of the higher abidings is the abundance of service to men and to deities.”

original: phāsuvihāranti sambandho. Manussānaṃ upakārabahulatanti paccayapaṭiggahaṇadhammadesanādivasena🔽upakārabahulataṃ. Devatānaṃ upakārabahulataṃ janavivittatāya. Pacurajanavivittañhi
analyzed: phāsu vihāram ti sambandhaḥ manussānam upakāra bahula tanti paccaya paṭiggahaṇa dhamma desanā ādi vasena  upakāra bahula tam devatānam upakāra bahula tam jana vivitta tāya pacura jana vivittam hi
translated: Abundance of service to men: the abundance of service to men is through the practice of accepting requisites and teaching the Dhamma, etc.🔽Abundance of service to deities: through the absence of crowds of men. For deities think that a place devoid of crowds of men is suitable for them to visit.

original: ṭhānaṃ devā upasaṅkamitabbaṃ maññanti. Loke saṃvaḍḍhabhāvanti āmisopabhogena saṃvaḍḍhitabhāvaṃ.
analyzed: ṭhānam devāḥ upasaṅkamitabbam maññanti loke saṃvaḍḍha bhāvanti āmisa upabhogena saṃvaḍḍhita bhāvam
translated: Increase in the world: the state of being increased through the use of requisites.

original: Ekapuggaloti ettha ekoti dutiyādipaṭikkhepattho gaṇanaparicchedo. Puggaloti sammutikathā,
analyzed: eka puggalo ti ettha ekaḥ iti dutiya ādi paṭikkhepa atthaḥ gaṇana paricchedaḥ puggalo ti sammuti kathā
translated: One person: here the word “one” is a numeral, a means of enumeration, excluding a second, etc. The word “person” is a conventional expression,

original: na paramatthakathā. Buddhassa hi bhagavato duvidhā desanā sammutidesanā paramatthadesanā
analyzed: na paramattha kathā buddhassa hi bhagavataḥ duvidhā desanā sammuti desanā paramattha desanā
translated: not an ultimate-truth expression. For the Blessed One’s teaching is twofold: conventional expressions and ultimate-truth expressions.

original: cāti. Ayamattho pana heṭṭhā vitthāritovāti idha na vuccati. Eko ca so puggalo cāti
analyzed: ca ati ayam attho pana heṭṭhā vitthāritaḥ uvā ti idha na vuccati ekaḥ ca so puggalo ca ati
translated: But this meaning has been explained in detail below, so we do not comment on it here. He is one and a person,

original: ekapuggalo. Kenaṭṭhena ekapuggalo? Asadisaṭṭhena guṇavisiṭṭhaṭṭhena asamasamaṭṭhena.
analyzed: eka puggalaḥ kena ṭṭhena eka puggalaḥ asadisa ṭṭhena guṇa visiṭṭha ṭṭhena asamasama ṭṭhena
translated: He is one person. In what sense is he one person? In the sense of being incomparable, in the sense of being distinguished by special qualities, and in the sense of being the equal of the unequalled.🔽For he is incomparable in the sense of being incomparable with others by reason of the special qualities of the requisites of enlightenment and the special qualities of a Buddha,

original: So hi dasannaṃ pāramīnaṃ paṭipāṭiyā āvajjanaṃ ādiṃ katvā bodhisambhāraguṇehi ceva🔽buddhaguṇehi ca sesamahājanena asadisoti asadisaṭṭhenapi ekapuggalo. Ye cassa te🔽guṇā, tepi aññasattānaṃ guṇehi visiṭṭhāti guṇavisiṭṭhaṭṭhenapi ekapuggalo. Purimakā
analyzed: saḥ hi dasannam pāramīnam paṭipāṭiyā āvajjanam ādim katvā bodhi sambhāra guṇehi ca iva  buddha guṇehi ca sesa mahājanena asadisaḥ ti eka puggalaḥ ye ca ssa te  guṇā te pi añña sattānam guṇehi visiṭṭhā ati guṇa visiṭṭha ṭṭhena pi eka puggalaḥ purimakā
translated: beginning with the act of adverting in the order of the ten perfections.🔽And those special qualities of his are distinguished by being superior to the qualities of other beings. Thus he is one person in the sense of being distinguished by special qualities.

original: sammāsambuddhā sabbasattehi asamā, tehi saddhiṃ ayameva eko rūpakāyaguṇehi ceva nāmakāyaguṇehi
analyzed: sammāsambuddhāḥ sabba sattehi asamā tehi saddhim ayam eva ekaḥ rūpa kāya guṇehi ca iva nāma kāya guṇehi
translated: The former Perfectly Enlightened Ones were unequalled by all beings. He is equal to them in the sense of being equal to them in the special qualities of the physical body and the special qualities of the verbal body.

original: ca samoti asamasamaṭṭhenapi ekapuggalo. Loketi sattaloke.
analyzed: ca samaḥ iti asama sama ṭṭhena pi eka puggalaḥ loke iti satta loke
translated: Thus he is one person in the sense of being the equal of the unequalled. In the world of beings:

original: Uppajjamāno uppajjatīti idaṃ pana ubhayampi vippakatavacanameva. Uppajjanto bahujanahitatthāya
analyzed: uppajjamānaḥ uppajjati iti idam pana ubhayam pi vippakata vacanam eva uppajjantaḥ bahu jana hita tthāya
translated: He is born for the welfare of the world, he is born for the good of the world, he is born for the welfare and good of the world.🔽This is the meaning here: he is born for the welfare of the world, not for any other reason.

original: uppajjati, na aññena kāraṇenāti evaṃ panettha attho veditabbo. Evarūpañcettha lakkhaṇaṃ
analyzed: uppajjati na aññena kāraṇena ati evam pana ittha atthaḥ veditabbo evarūpam ca ittha lakkhaṇam
translated: The characteristic here is this:

original: na sakkā etaṃ aññena saddalakkhaṇena paṭibāhituṃ. Apica uppajjamāno nāma, uppajjati
analyzed: na sakkā etam aññena sadda lakkhaṇena paṭibāhitum apica uppajjamānaḥ nāma uppajjati
translated: It is not possible to exclude it by any other characteristic of sound.🔽Moreover, the distinction here should be understood as follows: “arising” is the arising of what arises,

original: nāma, uppanno nāmāti ayamettha bhedo veditabbo. Esa hi dīpaṅkarapādamūlato laddhabyākaraṇo
analyzed: nāma uppannaḥ nāma ati ayam ettha bhedaḥ veditabbaḥ esa hi dīpaṅkara pāda mūlataḥ laddha byākaraṇaḥ
translated: the arisen. For this one, who had received his prophecy at the feet of Dīpaṅkara,

original: buddhakārakadhamme pariyesanto dasa pāramiyo disvā “ime dhammā mayā pūretabbā”ti
analyzed: buddha kāraka dhamme pariyesantaḥ dasa pāramiyaḥ disvā ime dhammā mayā pūretabbā ati
translated: while seeking the states that lead to Buddhahood, saw the ten perfections and thought, “These are the states that I must fulfill.”🔽Having thus made a vow, he was “arising” while fulfilling the perfection of giving,

original: katasanniṭṭhāno dānapāramiṃ pūrentopi uppajjamāno nāma. Sīlapāramiṃ…pe… upekkhāpāraminti
analyzed: kata sanniṭṭhānaḥ dāna pāramim pūrentaḥ api uppajjamānaḥ nāma sīla pāramim pe upekkhā pāramim ti
translated: while fulfilling the perfection of virtue … the perfection of equanimity,

original: imā dasa pāramiyo pūrentopi, dasa upapāramiyo pūrentopi uppajjamāno nāma. Dasa paramatthapāramiyo
analyzed: imāḥ dasa pāramiyaḥ pūrentaḥ api dasa upapāramiyaḥ pūrentaḥ api uppajjamānaḥ nāma dasa paramattha pāramiyaḥ
translated: while fulfilling the ten minor perfections, while fulfilling the ten major perfections,

original: pūrentopi uppajjamāno nāma. Pañca mahāpariccāge pariccajantopi uppajjamāno nāma.
analyzed: pūrentaḥ api uppajjamānaḥ nāma pañca mahāpariccāge pariccajantaḥ api uppajjamānaḥ nāma
translated: while making the five great relinquishments,

original: Ñātatthacariyaṃ lokatthacariyaṃ buddhatthacariyaṃ pūrayamānopi uppajjamāno nāma.
analyzed: ñāta ttha cariyam loka ttha cariyam buddha ttha cariyam pūrayamānaḥ api uppajjamānaḥ nāma
translated: while fulfilling the practice of what is beneficial for oneself, the practice of what is beneficial for others, and the practice of what is beneficial for both,

original: Kappasatasahassādhikāni cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni buddhakārake dhamme matthakaṃ pāpentopi
analyzed: kappa sata sahassa adhikāni cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni buddha kārake dhamme matthakam pāpentaḥ pi
translated: while bringing to completion the states that lead to Buddhahood for four incalculables and a hundred thousand eons,

original: uppajjamāno nāma. Vessantarattabhāvaṃ pahāya tusitapure paṭisandhiṃ gahetvā saṭṭhivassasatasahassādhikā
analyzed: uppajjamānaḥ nāma vessanta ratta bhāvam pahāya tusitapure paṭisandhim gahetvā saṭṭhi vassa sata sahassa adhikā
translated: “Arisen” means: after abandoning the state of Vessantara, taking rebirth-linking in the Tusita heaven, and remaining there for 7,700,000 years,🔽he was still “arisen.” After being requested by the gods,

original: sattapaṇṇāsa vassakoṭiyo tiṭṭhantopi uppajjamāno nāma. Devatāhi yācito pañca mahāvilokanāni
analyzed: satta paṇṇāsa vassa koṭiyaḥ tiṭṭhantaḥ api uppajjamānaḥ nāma devatāhi yācito pañca mahā vilokanāni
translated: looking at the five great sights, and taking rebirth-linking in Queen Maya’s womb,

original: viloketvā māyādeviyā kucchismiṃ paṭisandhiṃ gaṇhantopi, anūnādhike dasa māse gabbhavāsaṃ
analyzed: viloketvā māyādeviyā kucchismim paṭisandhim gaṇhantaḥ api anūna adhike dasa māse gabbha vāsam
translated: and remaining there for nine or ten months,

original: vasantopi uppajjamāno nāma. Ekūnatiṃsa vassāni agāramajjhe tiṭṭhantopi uppajjamāno
analyzed: vasantaḥ api uppajjamānaḥ nāma ekūnatiṃsa vassāni agāra majjhe tiṭṭhantaḥ api uppajjamānaḥ
translated: he was still “arisen.” After remaining in the world for 29 years,

original: nāma. Kāmesu ādīnavaṃ nekkhamme ca ānisaṃsaṃ disvā rāhulabhaddassa jātadivase channasahāyo
analyzed: nāma kāmesu ādīnavam nekkhamme ca ānisaṃsam disvā rāhulabhaddassa jāta divase channa sahāyaḥ
translated: he was still “arisen.” After seeing the danger in sensual pleasures and the benefits of renunciation, and on the day of Rahula’s birth, leaving with Channa as his companion,

original: kaṇḍakaṃ assavaramāruyha nikkhamantopi uppajjamāno nāma. Tīṇi rajjāni atikkamanto
analyzed: kaṇḍakam assavaram āruyha nikkhamantaḥ api uppajjamānaḥ nāma tīṇi rajjāni atikkamantaḥ
translated: mounting the horse Kanthaka, and departing, he was still “arisen.” After crossing the three city gates,

original: anomanaditīre pabbajantopi uppajjamāno nāma. Chabbassāni mahāpadhānaṃ karontopi uppajjamāno
analyzed: anomanadi tīre pabbajantaḥ api uppajjamānaḥ nāma cha bassāni mahāpadhānam karontaḥ api uppajjamānaḥ
translated: and going forth on the bank of the river Anomā, he was still “arisen.” After doing the great struggle for six years,🔽he was still “arisen.”

original: nāma. Paripākagate ñāṇe oḷārikaṃ āhāraṃ āharantopi uppajjamāno nāma. Sāyanhasamaye
analyzed: nāma paripāka gate ñāṇe oḷārikam āhāram āharantaḥ api uppajjamānaḥ nāma sāyanha samaye
translated: and when the knowledge of maturity has arisen, he is called “arisen” even though he is eating coarse food.🔽At the time of the full moon of the month of Āsāḷhi,

original: visākhapuṇṇamāyaṃ mahābodhimaṇḍaṃ āruyha mārabalaṃ vidhametvā paṭhamayāme pubbenivāsaṃ
analyzed: visākhapuṇṇa māyam mahā bodhimaṇḍam āruyha māra balam vidhametvā paṭhama yāme pubbenivāsam
translated: after ascending the Great Enlightenment Tree, and after destroying the army of Māra, he is called “arisen” even though he is recollecting his previous lives in the first watch of the night,

original: anussaritvā majjhimayāme dibbacakkhuṃ parisodhetvā pacchimayāmasamanantare dvādasaṅgaṃ
analyzed: anussaritvā majjhima yāme dibba cakkhum parisodhetvā pacchima yāma samanantare dvādasaṅgam
translated: and after purifying the divine eye in the middle watch of the night, and after comprehending the twelve-fold dependent origination in direct and reverse order in the last watch of the night,

original: paṭiccasamuppādaṃ anulomapaṭilomato sammasitvā sotāpattimaggaṃ paṭivijjhantopi uppajjamāno
analyzed: paṭiccasamuppādam anuloma paṭilomataḥ sammasitvā sotāpatti maggam paṭivijjhantaḥ api uppajjamānaḥ
translated: he is called “arisen” even though he is penetrating the path of stream-entry.

original: nāma. Sotāpattiphalakkhaṇepi sakadāgāmiphalakkhaṇepi anāgāmiphalakkhaṇepi uppajjamāno
analyzed: nāma sotāpatti pha lakkhaṇe pi sakadāgāmi pha lakkhaṇe pi anāgāmi pha lakkhaṇe pi uppajjamāno
translated: He is called “arisen” even though he is penetrating the fruit of stream-entry, the fruit of once-returning, and the fruit of non-returning.

original: nāma. Arahattamaggakkhaṇe pana uppajjati nāma. Arahattaphalakkhaṇe uppanno nāma.
analyzed: nāma arahatta magga kkhaṇe pana uppajjati nāma arahatta phala kkhaṇe uppannaḥ nāma
translated: But at the moment of the path of arahatship he is called “arisen,” and at the moment of the fruit of arahatship he is called “arisen and arisen.”

original: Buddhānañhi sāvakānaṃ viya na paṭipāṭiyā iddhividhañāṇādīni uppajjanti, saheva pana
analyzed: buddhānam hi sāvakānam viya na paṭipāṭiyā iddhividha ñāṇa ādīni uppajjanti saha iva pana
translated: For, unlike the disciples, the supernormal powers, the knowledge of others’ minds, and so on do not arise in succession for the Buddhas,🔽but with the path of arahatship alone the whole mass of special qualities, such as the knowledge of omniscience, has already been reached. Therefore,

original: arahattamaggena sakalopi sabbaññutaññāṇādi guṇarāsi āgatova nāma hoti, tasmā nibbattasabbakiccattā
analyzed: arahatta maggena sakalaḥ api sabbaññuta ññāṇa ādi guṇa rāsi āgataḥ iva nāma hoti tasmā nibbatta sabba kicca ttā
translated: because all his duties have been performed,

original: arahattaphalakkhaṇe uppanno nāma hoti. Imasmimpi sutte arahattaphalakkhaṇaṃyeva sandhāya
analyzed: arahatta phalakkhaṇe uppannaḥ nāma hoti imasmim pi sutte arahatta phalakkhaṇam yeva sandhāya
translated: it is called “arisen” at the moment of the fruition of Arahantship. In this sutta too,🔽“arisen” is said with reference to the moment of the fruition of Arahantship.

original: “uppajjatī”ti vuttaṃ. Uppanno hotīti ayañhettha attho.🔽Bahujanahitāyāti mahājanassa hitatthāya uppajjati. Bahujanasukhāyāti mahājanassa
analyzed: uppajjati iti vuttam uppannaḥ hoti iti ayam ha ittha atthaḥ  bahu jana hitāya ati mahā janassa hita atthāya uppajjati bahu jana sukhāya ati mahā janassa
translated: The meaning is: “it has arisen.”🔽For the welfare of the multitude: for the welfare of the great multitude.🔽For the happiness of the multitude: for the happiness of the great multitude.

original: sukhatthāya uppajjati. Lokānukampāyāti sattalokassa anukampaṃ paṭicca uppajjati.
analyzed: sukha atthāya uppajjati loka anukampāya ati satta lokassa anukampam paṭicca uppajjati
translated: Out of compassion for the world: out of compassion for the world of beings.🔽For which world of beings?

original: Katarasattalokassāti? Yo tathāgatassa dhammadesanaṃ sutvā amatapānaṃ pivi, dhammaṃ
analyzed: katara satta lokassa ati yaḥ tathāgatassa dhamma desanam sutvā amata pānam dhammaṃ
translated: For those who have listened to the Tathāgata’s teaching of the Dhamma and have drunk the deathless drink, who have penetrated the Dhamma.

original: paṭivijjhi, tassa. Bhagavatā hi mahābodhimaṇḍe sattasattāhaṃ vītināmetvā bodhimaṇḍā
analyzed: tassa bhagavatā hi mahā bodhimaṇḍe satta satta aham vītināmetvā bodhimaṇḍā
translated: For after the Exalted One had spent seven weeks at the Great Bodhi Tree, he went to the Deer Park at Isipatana and set rolling the Wheel of the Dhamma with the sutta called “The Setting in Motion of the Wheel of the Dhamma” :

original: isipatanaṃ āgamma “dveme, bhikkhave, antā pabbajitena na sevitabbā”ti dhammacakkappavattanasuttante
analyzed: isipatanam āgamma dve me bhikkhave antāḥ pabbajitena na sevitabbā ti dhammacakkappavattana suttante
translated: “Monks, these two extremes should not be followed by one who has gone forth into homelessness.

original: desite āyasmatā aññāsikoṇḍaññattherena saddhiṃ aṭṭhārasakoṭisaṅkhā brahmāno amatapānaṃ
analyzed: desite āyasmatā aññāsikoṇḍañña ttherena saddhim aṭṭhārasa koṭi saṅkhāḥ brahmānaḥ amata pānam
translated: ” When this sutta was taught, eighteen koṭis of Brahmās, together with the venerable Aññā-Koṇḍañña, drank the deathless drink,

original: piviṃsu, etassa sattalokassa anukampāya uppanno. Pañcamadivase anattalakkhaṇasuttantapariyosāne🔽pañcavaggiyattherā arahatte patiṭṭhahiṃsu, etassapi sattalokassa anukampāya uppanno.
analyzed: piviṃsu etassa satta lokassa anukampāya uppanno pañcama divase anattalakkhaṇa suttanta pariyosāne  pañcavaggiya therāḥ arahatte patiṭṭhahiṃsu etassa api satta lokassa anukampāya uppanno
translated: and they drank it, and he arose for the sake of having compassion on the world of creatures. On the fifth day, at the conclusion of the Discourse on the Characteristic of Non-Self,🔽the Elder of the Group-of-Five was established in Worthiness, and he arose for the sake of having compassion on the world of creatures.

original: Tato yasadārakappamukhe pañcapaṇṇāsa purise arahatte patiṭṭhāpesi, tato kappāsikavanasaṇḍe🔽tiṃsa bhaddavaggiye tayo magge ca phalāni ca sampāpesi, etassapi sattalokassa anukampāya
analyzed: tatas yasa dāra kappa mukhe pañcapaṇṇāsa purise arahatte patiṭṭhāpesi tatas kappāsikavana saṇḍe  tiṃsa bhaddavaggiye tayaḥ magge ca phalāni ca sampāpesi etassa api satta lokassa anukampāya
translated: Then at the head of the Yasa’s Mother and Father he established fifty-five people in Worthiness, then in the Cotton-tree Island

original: uppanno. Gayāsīse ādittapariyāyapariyosāne jaṭilasahassaṃ arahatte patiṭṭhāpesi,
analyzed: uppannaḥ gayāsīse āditta pariyāya pariyosāne jaṭila sahassam arahatte patiṭṭhāpesi
translated: he ripened the thirty good people in the three Paths and the three Fruits, and he arose for the sake of having compassion on the world of creatures. At the Gayā Head, at the conclusion of the Discourse on the Burning, he established a thousand yogis in Worthiness,

original: tato laṭṭhivane bimbisārappamukhā ekādasa nahutā brāhmaṇagahapatikā satthu dhammadesanaṃ
analyzed: tatas laṭṭhivane bimbisāra pamukhāḥ ekādasa nahutāḥ brāhmaṇa gahapatikā satthu dhamma desanam
translated: then in the Bamboo Wood, with King Bimbisāra at the head, eleven myriads of brāhmaṇas and householders, after hearing the Teacher’s Dhamma Teaching,

original: sutvā sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhahiṃsu, ekaṃ nahutaṃ saraṇesu patiṭṭhitaṃ. Tirokuṭṭaanumodanāvasāne
analyzed: sutvā sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhahiṃsu ekam nahutam saraṇesu patiṭṭhitam tirokuṭṭa anumodanā avasāne
translated: were established in the Fruit of Stream Entry, and one myriads were established in the Refuges. At the conclusion of the Rejoicing Across the Walls

original: caturāsītiyā pāṇasahassehi amatapānaṃ pītaṃ. Sumanamālākārasamāgame caturāsītiyā,🔽dhanapālasamāgame dasahi pāṇasahassehi, khadiraṅgārajātakasamāgame caturāsītiyā pāṇasahassehi,
analyzed: caturāsītiyā pāṇa sahassehi amata pānam pītam sumana mālākāra samāgame caturāsītiyā  dhanapāla samāgame dasahi pāṇa sahassehi khadiraṅgāra jātaka samāgame caturāsītiyā pāṇa sahassehi
translated: and eighty-four thousand beings drank the Deathless Drink. At the meeting of the Sumanamālaka, eighty-four thousand,🔽at the meeting of Dhanapala, ten thousand beings, at the meeting of the Khadiraṅgara Birth, eighty-four thousand beings,

original: jambukaājīvakasamāgame caturāsītiyāva, ānandaseṭṭhisamāgame caturāsītiyāva pāṇasahassehi🔽amatapānaṃ pītaṃ. Pāsāṇakacetiye pārāyanasuttakathādivase cuddasa koṭiyo amatapānaṃ
analyzed: jambuka ājīvaka samāgame ānanda seṭṭhi samāgame pāṇa sahassehi  amata pānam pītam pāsāṇaka cetiye pārāyana sutta kathā divase cuddasa koṭiyaḥ amata pānam
