translated: But why should the Blessed One prove his own state of being a Perfect One? He does so out of great compassion for others,🔽since it is not within the province of others to do so. Herein, the following sutta passages prove the meaning: “I am the one in the world who is rightly self-awakened, who is supremely worthy of offerings in the world with its deities” ,🔽and “I am the one in the world who is rightly self-awakened, who has perfectly realized the truth, who teaches the truth, who is the Accomplished and Fully Enlightened One” ,

original: suttapadāni, idameva ca “abhiññeyya”ntiādi suttapadaṃ etassa atthassa sādhakaṃ. Tattha🔽abhiññeyyanti iminā dukkhasaccamāha, bhāvetabbanti maggasaccaṃ. Ca-saddo panettha
analyzed: sutta padāni idam eva ca sutta padam etassa atthassa sādhakam tattha 🔽abhiññeyyam ti iminā dukkha saccam āha bhāvetabbam ti magga saccam ca saddaḥ pana ittha
translated: and “I am the one in the world who is rightly self-awakened, who has perfectly realized the truth, who teaches the truth, who is the Accomplished and Fully Enlightened One” ,🔽and “I am the one in the world who is rightly self-awakened, who has perfectly realized the truth, who teaches the truth, who is the Accomplished and Fully Enlightened One” ,🔽and “I am the one in the world who is rightly self-awakened, who has perfectly realized the truth, who teaches the truth, who is the Accomplished and Fully Enlightened One” ,🔽and “I am the one in the world who is rightly self-awakened, who has perfectly realized the truth, who teaches the truth, who is the Accomplished and Fully Enlightened One” ,🔽and “I am the one in the world who is rightly self-awakened, who has perfectly realized the truth, who teaches the truth, who is the Accomplished and Fully Enlightened One” ,🔽and “I am the one in the world who is rightly self-awakened, who has perfectly realized the truth, who teaches the truth, who is the Accomplished and Fully Enlightened One” ,🔽and “I am the one in the world who is rightly self-awakened, who has perfectly

original: avuttasamuccayattho, tena sacchikātabbassa gahaṇaṃ veditabbaṃ. Atha vā abhiññeyyanti
analyzed: a vutta samuccaya tthaḥ tena sacchikātabbassa gahaṇam veditabbam atha vā
translated: The meaning of the word “known” is that of being included in the known.🔽Or else, by the word “to be directly known” he shows the things to be fully understood and the things to be realized.

original: imināva pārisesañāyena pariññeyyadhamme sacchikātabbadhamme ca dasseti. Tasmā buddhosmīti
analyzed: iminā ava pārisesa ñāyena pariññeyya dhamme sacchikātabba dhamme ca dasseti tasmā buddhaḥ asmi iti
translated: Therefore, I am enlightened.

original: yasmā cattāri saccāni mayā buddhāni, saccavinimuttañca kiñci ñeyyaṃ natthi, tasmā
analyzed: cattāri saccāni mayā buddhāni sacca vinimuttañca kiñci ñeyyam na atthi tasmā
translated: And since the four truths have been discovered by me, and there is nothing else to be known apart from the truths,🔽therefore I am enlightened with regard to all that is to be known. The meaning is: I have discovered.

original: sabbampi ñeyyaṃ buddhosmi, abbhaññāsinti attho. Selasuttaṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana idaṃ vuttaṃ –
analyzed: sabbam pi ñeyyam buddhaḥ asmi abbhaññāsin ti attho selasutta ṭṭhakathāyam pana idam vuttam
translated: But in the Sela Sutta Commentary it is said:

original: “Abhiññeyyanti vijjā ca vimutti ca. Bhāvetabbaṃ maggasaccaṃ. Pahātabbaṃ samudayasaccaṃ.
analyzed: abhiññeyyanti vijjā ca vimutti ca bhāvetabbam magga saccam pahātabbam samudaya saccam
translated: “‘To be directly known’: the knowledge and freedom. ‘To be developed’: the truth of the path. ‘To be abandoned’: the truth of the origin.

original: Hetuvacanena pana phalasiddhito tesaṃ phalāni nirodhasaccadukkhasaccānipi vuttāneva
analyzed: hetu vacanena pana phala siddhitaḥ tesam phalāni nirodha sacca dukkha saccāni pi vuttāni eva
translated: But since the fruit is implied by the mention of the cause, the fruits of these truths, namely, the truths of cessation and suffering, are also included.🔽Thus what is to be realized has been realized, what is to be fully understood has been fully understood.

original: honti. Evaṃ sacchikātabbaṃ sacchikataṃ, pariññātabbaṃ pariññātanti idampettha saṅgahitamevāti🔽catusaccabhāvanaṃ catusaccabhāvanāphalañca vimuttiṃ dassento ‘bujjhitabbaṃ bujjhitvā
analyzed: honti evam sacchikātabbam sacchikatam pariññātabbam pariññātam ti idam pa ittha saṅgahitam eva ati 🔽catu sacca bhāvanam catu sacca bhāvanā phalam ca vimuttim dassentaḥ bujjhitabbam bujjhitvā
translated: Therefore, having discovered what is to be discovered,

original: buddho jātosmī’ti yuttahetunā buddhabhāvaṃ sādhetī”ti.
analyzed: buddhaḥ jātaḥ asmi iti yutta hetunā buddha bhāvam sādha iti iti
translated: He proves the state of Buddhahood by the right reason that he has become a Buddha.”

original: Tattha vijjāti maggavijjā vuttā ukkaṭṭhaniddesena. Vimuttīti phalavimutti. Kāmañcettha🔽maggavijjāpi bhāvetabbabhāvena gahitā, sabbepi pana sabhāvadhammā abhiññeyyāti vijjāya
analyzed: tattha vijjā ti magga vijjā vuttā ukkaṭṭha niddesena vimutti iti phala vimutti kāmañca ittha  magga vijjā api bhāvetabba bhāvena gahitā sabbe pi pana sabhāva dhammā vijjāya
translated: Herein, the word “knowledge” is said with the highest reference to the path-knowledge. “Liberation” is the fruition-liberation.🔽But here the path-knowledge is included in the sense of what is to be developed. And all the dhammas in their individual essences are to be directly known. So the state of being directly knowable is said of knowledge.

original: abhiññeyyabhāvo vutto. Imināva nayena sabbesampi abhiññeyyabhāvo vutto evāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: abhiñeyya bhāvaḥ vuttaḥ iminā ava nayena sabbesam pi abhiññeyya bhāvaḥ vuttaḥ evā ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: And the state of being directly knowable of all should be understood in this way.

original: Phalena vinā hetubhāvasseva abhāvato hetuvacanena phalasiddhi vuttāti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: phalena vinā hetu bhāvassa iva abhāvataḥ hetu vacanena phala siddhi vuttā iti veditabbam
translated: And it should be understood that the fruition is said to be included in the word “cause” because there is no cause without fruition.

original: Nirodhassa hi sampāpanena maggassa hetubhāvo, dukkhassa nibbattanena taṇhāya samudayabhāvoti.🔽Evaṃ saccavasena sāmaññato vuttamatthaṃ dvārārammaṇehi saddhiṃ dvārappavattadhammehi
analyzed: nirodhassa hi sampāpanena maggassa hetu bhāvaḥ dukkhassa nibbattanena taṇhāya samudaya bhāvaḥ ti  evam sacca vasena sāmaññataḥ vuttam attham dvāra ārammaṇehi saddhim dvāra ppavatta dhammehi
translated: For the state of being a cause of the path is by the path’s reaching cessation, and the state of being a source of craving is by craving’s reaching suffering.🔽So the meaning stated in general terms by the truths is shown by the words “and also” , etc., after it has been analyzed by the truths themselves together with the doors and objects and the dhammas that occur with the doors, and by the aggregates, etc.

original: ceva khandhādīhi ca saccavaseneva vibhajitvā dassetuṃ “apicā”tiādi āraddhaṃ. Mūlakāraṇabhāvenāti
analyzed: ca iva khandha ādīhi ca sacca vasena iva vibhajitvā dassetum api ca atiādi āraddham mūla kāraṇa bhāvena ati
translated: “As the root cause” means as the cause of the root.

original: santesupi avijjādīsu aññesu kāraṇesu tesampi mūlabhūtakāraṇabhāvena. Taṇhā hi kammassa
analyzed: santesu pi avijjā ādīsu aññesu kāraṇesu tesam pi mūla bhūta kāraṇa bhāvena taṇhā hi kammassa
translated: and in the presence of other causes such as ignorance, etc., it is the root cause of them. For craving is the principal cause of the diversity of suffering because it is the cause of the diversity of kamma and because it becomes the ally of ignorance.🔽It is the origination of suffering because it is the origination of kamma and defilements.🔽It is the origination of kamma because it is the cause of the diversity of kamma.🔽It is the origination of defilements because it is the cause of the diversity of defilements.🔽It is the origination of kamma and defilements because it is the cause of the diversity of kamma and defilements.🔽It is the origination of the world because it is the cause of the diversity of the world.🔽It is the origination of suffering because it is the cause of the diversity of suffering.🔽It is the origination of the world because it is the cause of the diversity of the world.🔽It is the origination of suffering because it is the cause of the diversity of suffering.🔽It is the origination of the world because it is the cause of the diversity of the world.

original: vicittabhāvahetuto sahāyabhāvūpagamanato ca dukkhavicittatāya padhānakāraṇaṃ. Samuṭṭhāpikāti
analyzed: vicitta bhāva hetutaḥ sahāya bhāva upagamanataḥ ca dukkha vicitta tāya padhāna kāraṇam samuṭṭhāpikā ati
translated: It is the origination of suffering because it is the cause of the diversity of suffering.

original: uppādikā. Purimataṇhāti purimabhavasiddhā taṇhā. Ubhinnanti cakkhussa taṃsamudayassa
analyzed: uppādikā purima taṇhā āti purima bhava siddhā taṇhā cakkhussa tad samudayassa
translated: It is the origination of the world because it is the cause of the diversity of the world.🔽It is the origination of suffering because it is the cause of the diversity of suffering.

original: ca. Appavattīti appavattinimittaṃ. Nirodhappajānanāti sacchikiriyābhisamayavasena
analyzed: ca appavatti iti appavatti nimittam nirodha ppajānanā ati sacchikiriyā abhisamaya vasena
translated: It is the origination of the world because it is the cause of the diversity of the world.

original: nirodhassa paṭivijjhanā. Ekekapaduddhārenāti “cakkhuṃ cakkhusamudayo cakkhunirodho”tiādinā
analyzed: nirodhassa ekeka paduddhārena ati cakkhum cakkhu samudayaḥ cakkhu nirodhaḥ iti ādinā
translated: It is the origination of suffering because it is the cause of the diversity of suffering.🔽It is the origination of the world because it is the cause of the diversity of the world.🔽It is the origination of suffering because it is the cause of the diversity of suffering.🔽It is the origination of the world because it is the cause of the diversity of the world.

original: ekekakoṭṭhāsaniddhāraṇena. Taṇhāyapi pariññeyyabhāvasabbhāvato upādānakkhandhogadhattā
analyzed: ekeka koṭṭhāsa niddhāraṇena pariññeyya bhāva sabbhāvataḥ
translated: It is the origination of suffering because it is the cause of the diversity of suffering.🔽It is the origination of the world because it is the cause of the diversity of the world.🔽It is the origination of suffering because it is the cause of the diversity of suffering.🔽It is the origination of the world because it is the cause of the diversity of the world.

original: saṅkhāradukkhabhāvato ca dukkhasaccasaṅgahaṃ dassetuṃ “rūpataṇhādayo cha taṇhākāyā”ti🔽vuttaṃ, tasmā vattamānabhave taṇhā khandhapariyāpannattā saṅkhāradukkhabhāvato ca
analyzed: saṅkhāra dukkha bhāvato ca dukkha sacca saṅgaham dassetum rūpa taṇhā ādayaḥ cha taṇhā kāyā ti 🔽vuttam tasmā vattamāna bhave taṇhā khandha pariyāpanna ttā saṅkhāra dukkha bhāvato ca
translated: It is the origination of suffering because it is the cause of the diversity of suffering.🔽It is the origination of the world because

original: dukkhasaccaṃ. Yasmiṃ pana attabhāve sā uppajjati, tassa attabhāvassa mūlakāraṇabhāvena🔽samuṭṭhāpikā purimabhavasiddhā taṇhā samudayasaccanti gahetabbā.
analyzed: dukkha saccam yasmim pana atta bhāve sā uppajjati tassa atta bhāvassa mūla kāraṇa bhāvena  samuṭṭhāpikā purima bhava siddhā taṇhā samudaya saccan ti gahetabbā
translated: should be taken as the truth of the origin since it is the source of that selfhood.

original: Kasiṇānīti kasiṇārammaṇikajjhānāni. Dvattiṃsākārāti dvattiṃsa koṭṭhāsā tadārammaṇajjhānāni🔽ca. Nava bhavāti kāmabhavo rūpabhavo arūpabhavo saññībhavo asaññībhavo nevasaññīnāsaññībhavo
analyzed: kasiṇāni iti kasiṇa ārammaṇika jhānāni dvattiṃsa ākārā ati dvattiṃsa koṭṭhāsā tad ārammaṇa jhānāni  ca nava kāma bhavaḥ rūpa bhavaḥ arūpa bhavo saññībhavaḥ asaññībhavaḥ nevasaññīnāsaññībhavo
translated: The kasiṇas: the jhānas with the kasiṇas as their object. The thirty-two aspects: the thirty-two parts, and the jhānas with those as their objects.

original: ekavokārabhavo catuvokārabhavo pañcavokārabhavoti nava bhavā. Tattha bhavatīti bhavo,
analyzed: ekavokāra bhavo catuvokāra bhavo pañcavokāra bhavo ti nava bhavā tattha bhavati iti bhavo
translated: The nine kinds of being: the nine kinds of being, namely, sensual-desire being, fine-material being, immaterial being, percipient being, non-percipient being, neither-percipient-nor-non-percipient being, single being, multiple being, and space-ending being. Herein, being is existence .

original: kāmarāgasaṅkhātena kāmena yutto bhavo, kāmasaṅkhāto vā bhavo kāmabhavo, ekādasa kāmāvacarabhūmiyo.🔽Kāme pahāya rūparāgasaṅkhātena rūpena yutto bhavo, rūpasaṅkhāto vā bhavo rūpabhavo,
analyzed: kāma rāga saṅkhātena kāmena yuttaḥ bhavo kāma saṅkhātaḥ vā bhavaḥ kāma bhavaḥ ekādasa kāmāvacara bhūmiyaḥ  kāme pahāya rūpa rāga saṅkhātena rūpena yuttaḥ bhavaḥ rūpa saṅkhātaḥ vā bhavaḥ rūpa bhavaḥ
translated: Sensual-desire being is the existence associated with desire in the sense of lust for sense desires, or it is the existence called sensual desire, which is the eleven sense-desire-plane grounds.

original: soḷasa rūpāvacarabhūmiyo. Kāmañca rūpañca pahāya arūparāgasaṅkhātena arūpena yutto
analyzed: soḷasa rūpāvacara bhūmiyaḥ kāmam ca rūpam pahāya arūpa rāga saṅkhātena arūpena yuttaḥ
translated: Fine-material being is the existence associated with materiality in the sense of the fine-material jhānas, or it is the existence called fine-material, which is the sixteen fine-material-plane grounds.🔽Having abandoned sense desires and fine-materiality, immaterial being is the existence associated with the immaterial states, or it is the existence called immaterial, which is the four immaterial-plane grounds.

original: bhavo, arūpasaṅkhāto vā bhavo arūpabhavo, catasso āruppabhūmiyo. Saññāvataṃ bhavo🔽saññībhavo, saññā vā ettha bhave atthīti saññībhavo, so kāmabhavo ca asaññībhavamutto🔽rūpabhavo ca nevasaññīnāsaññībhavamutto arūpabhavo ca hoti. Na saññībhavo asaññībhavo,
analyzed: bhavaḥ arūpa saṅkhātaḥ vā bhavaḥ arūpa bhavo catasso āruppa bhūmiyaḥ saññāvatam bhavo  saññībhavo saññā va ettha bhave atthi iti saññībhavo so kāma bhavo ca a saññībhava mutto  rūpa bhavo ca nevasaññīnāsaññībhava mutto arūpa bhavo ca hoti na saññībhavaḥ asaññībhavo
translated: Or else, the kind of becoming that is called “non-material” is the non-material becoming, that is, the four immaterial levels. 10. Becoming with perception🔽is the kind of becoming that is called “with perception” because perception is present there. It is the kind of becoming that is material, that is, the sense-desire becoming, and that is without perception, that is, the non-material becoming, that is, the four immaterial levels. 11. Becoming without perception is the kind of becoming that is without perception.

original: so rūpabhavekadeso. Oḷārikattābhāvato nevasaññā, sukhumattassa sabbhāvato nāsaññāti
analyzed: so rūpa bhava ekadesaḥ oḷārika ttā abhāvataḥ na ivasaññā sukhuma ttassa sabbhāvataḥ na asaññā ati
translated: It is one part of the material becoming. 12. Becoming neither with nor without perception

original: nevasaññānāsaññā, tāya yutto bhavo nevasaññānāsaññābhavo. Atha vā oḷārikāya saññāya🔽abhāvā sukhumāya ca bhāvā nevasaññā nāsaññā asmiṃ bhaveti nevasaññānāsaññābhavo,🔽so arūpabhavekadeso. Ekena rūpakkhandhena vokiṇṇo bhavo, ekena vā vokāro assa bhavassāti
analyzed: neva saññā na asaññā tāya yuttaḥ bhavaḥ neva saññā na asaññā bhavaḥ atha vā oḷārikāya saññāya  abhāvā sukhumāya ca bhāvā nevasaññā na asaññā asmin bhaveti nevasaññā nāsañña bhavo  saḥ arūpa bhava eka desaḥ ekena rūpakkhandhena vokiṇṇaḥ bhavaḥ ekena vā vokāraḥ assa bhavassa ati
translated: is the kind of becoming that is neither with nor without perception. It is one part of the non-material becoming. 13. Becoming with one station🔽is the kind of becoming that is mixed with one material aggregate or that has one station, that is, the kind of becoming that is without perception. 14. Becoming with four stations

original: ekavokārabhavo, so asaññībhavo. Catūhi arūpakkhandhehi vokiṇṇo bhavo, catūhi vā vokāro
analyzed: eka vokāra bhavo so asaññībhavaḥ catūhi arūpa kkhandhehi vokiṇṇaḥ bhavaḥ catūhi vā vokāro
translated: is the kind of becoming that is mixed with four immaterial aggregates or that has four stations, that is, the kind of becoming that is neither with nor without perception.

original: assa bhavassāti catuvokārabhavo, so arūpabhavo eva. Pañcahi khandhehi vokiṇṇo bhavo,
analyzed: assa bhavassa ati catuvokāra bhavo so arūpa bhavaḥ eva pañcahi khandhehi vokiṇṇaḥ bhavo
translated: “His becoming is of one kind” means that his becoming is of the fourfold becoming, which is the non-material becoming.

original: pañcahi vā vokāro assa bhavassāti pañcavokārabhavo, so kāmabhavo ca rūpabhavekadeso
analyzed: pañcahi vā vokāraḥ assa bhavassa ati pañca vokāra bhavo so kāma bhavo ca rūpa bhava eka deso
translated: “His becoming is of five kinds” means that his becoming is of the five kinds of becoming, which is the five aggregates of clinging.

original: ca hoti. Vokāroti vā khandhānametamadhivacanaṃ, tasmā eko vokāro assa bhavassāti🔽ekavokārabhavoti evamādināpettha attho veditabbo. Cattāri jhānānīti aggahitārammaṇavisesāni
analyzed: ca hoti vokāro iti vā khandhānam etam adhivacanam tasmai ekaḥ vokāraḥ assa bhavassa ati  ekavokāra bhavaḥ ti evamādinā api ittha attho veditabbo cattāri jhānāni iti aggahita ārammaṇa visesāni
translated: Or the word “becoming” is a designation for the aggregates, thus “His becoming is of one kind” means that he has one kind of becoming.🔽“His becoming is of five kinds” means that he has five kinds of becoming.🔽“The four jhānas” are the four jhānas of the fine-material sphere, which are not distinguished by their objects.

original: cattāri rūpāvacarajjhānāni. Vipākajjhānānaṃ vā etaṃ gahaṇaṃ. Ettha ca kusaladhammānaṃ
analyzed: cattāri rūpāvacara jhānāni vipāka jhānānam vā etam gahaṇam ettha ca kusala dhammānam
translated: Or this refers to the resultant jhānas.

original: upanissayabhūtā taṇhāsamuṭṭhāpikā purimataṇhāti veditabbā. Kiriyadhammānaṃ pana yattha
analyzed: upanissaya bhūtā taṇhā samuṭṭhāpikā purima taṇhā ti veditabbā kiriya dhammānam pana yattha
translated: And here the craving that is the condition for the profitable states should be understood as the former craving that generates the latter craving.

original: te kiriyadhammā uppajjanti, tassa attabhāvassa kāraṇabhūtā taṇhā. Anulomatoti ettha
analyzed: te kiriya dhammā uppajjanti tassa atta bhāvassa kāraṇa bhūtā taṇhā anulomataḥ ti ettha
translated: But in the case of the inoperative states, the craving is that which is the condition for the existence in which the inoperative states occur.

original: “saṅkhārā dukkhasaccaṃ, avijjā samudayasacca”nti iminā anukkamena yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: saṅkhārāḥ dukkha saccam avijjā samudaya saccan ti iminā anukkamena yojetabbam
translated: “In forward order”: here the formations should be construed as the truth of suffering and ignorance as the truth of origin.

original: Anubuddhoti bujjhitabbadhammassa anurūpato buddho. Tenāti yasmā sāmaññato visesato🔽ca ekekapaduddhārena sabbadhamme buddho, tasmā vuttaṃ. Kiṃ vuttanti āha “sammā sāmañca🔽sabbadhammānaṃ buddhattā”ti, sabbassapi ñeyyassa sabbākārato aviparītaṃ sayameva🔽abhisambuddhattāti attho. Imināssa paropadesarahitassa sabbākārena sabbadhammāvabodhanasamatthassa
analyzed: anubuddhaḥ ti bujjhitabba dhammassa anurūpataḥ buddhaḥ tena ati yasmā sāmaññataḥ visesataḥ  ca ekeka pada uddhārena sabba dhamme buddhaḥ tasmai vuttam kim vuttan ti āha sammā sāmañca  sabba dhammānam buddha ttā ati sabbassa api ñeyyassa sabba ākārataḥ aviparītam sayam eva  abhisambuddha ttā ti attho iminā assa para upadesa rahitassa sabba ākārena sabba dhamma avabodhana samatthassa
translated: “Awakened” : awakened in conformity with the dhammas to be awakened to. “Therefore” : because he is awakened to all dhammas in general and in particular

original: ākaṅkhappaṭibaddhavuttino anāvaraṇañāṇasaṅkhātassa sabbaññutaññāṇassa adhigamo dassito.
analyzed: ākaṅkha paṭibaddha vuttinaḥ anāvaraṇa ñāṇa saṅkhātassa sabbaññuta ññāṇassa adhigamaḥ dassito
translated: by the removal of each term. “What is said?” : he says, “because of his being fully and rightly awakened to all dhammas.” The meaning is: because he has himself fully and non-misleadingly awakened to all that is to be known in all its modes. By this he shows the attainment of the knowledge called omniscience, which is unobstructed knowledge occurring in accordance with desire, and which is capable of comprehending all dhammas in all their modes without depending on the instruction of another.

original: Nanu ca sabbaññutaññāṇato aññaṃ anāvaraṇañāṇaṃ, aññathā “cha asādhāraṇañāṇāni buddhañāṇānī”ti
analyzed: nanu ca sabbaññu tad ññāṇataḥ aññam anāvaraṇa ñāṇam aññathā cha asādhāraṇa ñāṇāni buddha ñāṇāni iti
translated: But is not unobstructed knowledge different from omniscience? Otherwise, the statement “The six kinds of knowledge not shared by disciples are the knowledge of a Buddha” would be contradicted?

original: vacanaṃ virujjheyyāti? Na virujjhati visayappavattibhedavasena aññehi asādhāraṇabhāvadassanatthaṃ
analyzed: vacanam virujjheyyāti na virujjhati visaya ppavatti bheda vasena aññehi a sādhāraṇa bhāva dassana attham
translated: It is not contradicted, for it is shown in order to demonstrate that they are not shared by others because of the difference in their range and mode of occurrence.

original: ekasseva ñāṇassa dvidhā vuttattā. Ekameva hi taṃ ñāṇaṃ anavasesasaṅkhatāsaṅkhatasammutidhammavisayatāya
analyzed: ekassa iva ñāṇassa dvidhā vutta ttā ekam eva hi tam ñāṇam anavasesa saṅkhata asaṅkhata sammuti dhamma visaya tāya
translated: because it is said in two ways of a single knowledge. For that is a single knowledge, since it has as its domain all conditioned and unconditioned things, both as individual and as general characteristics.

original: sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ, tattha ca āvaraṇābhāvato nissaṅgacāramupādāya anāvaraṇañāṇanti
analyzed: sabbaññuta ññāṇam tattha ca āvaraṇa abhāvataḥ nissaṅga cāram upādāya anāvaraṇa ñāṇam ti
translated: It is called knowledge of omniscience because there is no obstruction to it anywhere.

original: vuttaṃ. Yathāha paṭisambhidāyaṃ “sabbaṃ saṅkhatamasaṅkhataṃ anavasesaṃ jānātīti sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ,
analyzed: vuttam yathā āha paṭisambhidā ayam sabbam saṅkhatam asaṅkhatam anavasesam jānāti iti sabbaññuta ññāṇam
translated: As it is said in the Paṭisambhidā: “It knows all that is formed and unformed without remainder, thus it is knowledge of omniscience.🔽There is no obstruction here, thus it is unobstructed knowledge” .

original: tattha āvaraṇaṃ natthīti anāvaraṇañāṇa”ntiādi. Tasmā natthi nesaṃ atthato bhedo,
analyzed: tattha āvaraṇam natthi iti anāvaraṇa ñāṇa ntiādi tasmā natthi na īsam atthatas bhedaḥ
translated: So there is no difference in meaning between them.

original: ekantena cetaṃ evamicchitabbaṃ. Aññathā sabbaññutānāvaraṇañāṇānaṃ sādhāraṇatā asabbadhammārammaṇatā
analyzed: ekantena ca itam evam icchitabbam aññathā sabbaññu tā anāvaraṇa ñāṇānam sādhāraṇa tā asabba dhamma ārammaṇa tā
translated: But this must be admitted in this way without reservation. Otherwise, it would follow that the knowledge of omniscience and the unobstructed knowledge would be common to all and would not have all things as their object.

original: ca āpajjeyya. Na hi bhagavato ñāṇassa aṇumattampi āvaraṇaṃ atthi, anāvaraṇañāṇassa
analyzed: ca āpajjeyya na hi bhagavataḥ ñāṇassa aṇumattam pi āvaraṇam atthi anāvaraṇa ñāṇassa
translated: For there is not the slightest obstruction to the Blessed One’s knowledge.

original: asabbadhammārammaṇabhāve yattha taṃ na pavattati, tatthāvaraṇasabbhāvato anāvaraṇabhāvoyeva
analyzed: asabba dhamma ārammaṇa bhāve yattha tam na pavattati tattha āvaraṇa sabbhāvataḥ
translated: If the knowledge that has all things as its object were not unobstructed knowledge, then it would follow that there would be an obstruction in that place where it does not occur, and that would be contrary to its being unobstructed.

original: na siyā. Atha vā pana hotu aññameva anāvaraṇañāṇaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇato, idha pana sabbattha🔽appaṭihatavuttitāya anāvaraṇañāṇanti sabbaññutaññāṇameva adhippetaṃ, tassa cādhigamanena
analyzed: na siyā atha vā pana hotu aññam eva anāvaraṇa ñāṇam sabbaññuta ññāṇato idha pana sabbattha  appaṭihata vutti tāya anāvaraṇa ñāṇam eva adhippetam tassa ca adhigamanena
translated: It is not so. Or let it be so. But here the knowledge of the way of access is intended as the knowledge of omniscience itself, since it occurs without obstruction everywhere.

original: bhagavā sabbaññū sabbavidū sammāsambuddhoti ca vuccati na sakiṃyeva sabbadhammāvabodhanato.🔽Tathā ca vuttaṃ paṭisambhidāyaṃ “vimokkhantikametaṃ buddhānaṃ bhagavantānaṃ bodhiyā
analyzed: bhagavā sabbaññū sabba vidū sammāsambuddhaḥ ti ca vuccati na sakiṃyeva sabba dhamma avabodhanato  tathā ca vuttam paṭisambhidā ayam vimokkha antikam etam buddhānam bhagavantānam bodhiyā
translated: And by the attainment of that knowledge the Exalted One is called omniscient, all-seeing, fully enlightened, not because of the mere understanding of all dhammas at one time.

original: mūle saha sabbaññutaññāṇassa paṭilābhā sacchikā paññatti yadidaṃ buddho”ti. Sabbadhammāvabodhanasamatthañāṇasamadhigamena
analyzed: mūle saha sabbaññu ta ññāṇassa paṭilābhā sacchikā paññatti yat idam buddhaḥ iti sabba dhamma avabodhana samattha ñāṇa samadhigamena
translated: And it is said in the Paṭisambhidā: “This is a designation based on realization that belongs to the Buddhas, the Blessed Ones, at the root of the Bodhi Tree, with the attainment of the knowledge of omniscience, namely, ‘Buddha.’ ”

original: hi bhagavato santāne anavasesadhamme paṭivijjhituṃ samatthatā ahosīti.
analyzed: hi bhagavato santāne anavasesa dhamme paṭivijjhitum samattha tā ahosi iti
translated: For by the attainment of the knowledge capable of understanding all dhammas, the Exalted One became able to penetrate all dhammas without exception.

original: Etthāha – kiṃ panidaṃ ñāṇaṃ pavattamānaṃ sakiṃyeva sabbasmiṃ visaye pavattati, udāhu
analyzed: ettha āha kim panidam ñāṇam pavattamānam sakiṃyeva sabbasmin visaye pavattati udāhu
translated: Here it may be asked: Does this knowledge occur in all its objects at one time, or does it occur in succession?

original: kamenāti. Kiñcettha – yadi tāva sakiṃyeva sabbasmiṃ visaye pavattati, atītānāgatapaccuppannaajjhattabahiddhādibhedabhinnānaṃ🔽saṅkhatadhammānaṃ asaṅkhatasammutidhammānañca ekajjhaṃ upaṭṭhāne dūrato cittapaṭaṃ🔽pekkhantassa viya paṭivibhāgenāvabodho na siyā, tathā sati “sabbe dhammā anattā”ti
analyzed: kamena ati kiñca ittha yadi tāva sa kiṃyeva sabbasmin visaye pavattati atīta anāgata paccuppanna ajjhatta bahiddha ādi bheda bhinnānam  saṅkhata dhammānam asaṅkhata sammuti dhammānam ca ekajjham upaṭṭhāne dūratas citta paṭam  pekkhantassa viya paṭivibhāgena avabodho na siyā tathā sati sabbe dhammā anattā ti
translated: when all conditioned and unconditioned dhammas, which are divided into past, future, present, internal, external, etc.,🔽appear together, the knowledge of the Blessed One would not be able to discern them individually, like a person looking at a variegated cloth from a distance.

original: vipassantānaṃ anattākārena viya sabbadhammā anirūpitarūpena bhagavato ñāṇassa visayā🔽hontīti āpajjati. Yepi “sabbañeyyadhammānaṃ ṭhitalakkhaṇavisayaṃ vikapparahitaṃ sabbakālaṃ🔽buddhānaṃ ñāṇaṃ pavattati, tena te sabbavidūti vuccanti, evañca katvā ‘caraṃ samāhito
analyzed: vipassantānam anatta ākārena viya sabba dhammāḥ anirūpita rūpena bhagavataḥ ñāṇassa visayāḥ  honti iti āpajjati ye pi sabba ñeyya dhammānam ṭhita lakkhaṇa visayam vikappa rahitam sabbakālam  buddhānam ñāṇam pavattati tena te sabba vidū ti vuccanti evam ca katvā caram samāhitaḥ
translated: If that were so, then all dhammas would be the object of the Blessed One’s knowledge in an undifferentiated form, just as they are the object of the insight of those who contemplate “all dhammas are non-self.”

original: nāgo, tiṭṭhantopi samāhito’ti idampi vacanaṃ suvuttaṃ hotī”ti vadanti, tesampi vuttadosā
analyzed: nāgaḥ tiṭṭhantaḥ api samāhitaḥ ti idam pi vacanam su vuttam hoti iti vadanti tesam pi vutta dosā
translated: Some say: “The knowledge of the Buddhas occurs at all times without conceptual proliferation in regard to the characteristic of the stability of all dhammas that are to be known. Therefore they are called ‘omniscient.’ Thus the statement ‘The elephant is concentrated when walking, standing, sleeping, and waking’ is well said.”🔽But they too are subject to the same fault.

original: nātivatti, ṭhitalakkhaṇārammaṇatāya ca atītānāgatasammutidhammānaṃ tadabhāvato ekadesavisayameva
analyzed: na ativatti ṭhita lakkhaṇa ārammaṇa tāya ca atīta anāgata sammuti dhammānam tad abhāvataḥ eka desa visayam eva
translated: And since the past and future, which are conventionally existent dhammas, and the unconditioned, which is a non-existent, do not have the characteristic of presence, the Exalted One’s knowledge would have only a partial object.

original: bhagavato ñāṇaṃ siyā, tasmā sakiṃyeva ñāṇaṃ pavattatīti na yujjati.🔽Atha kamena sabbasmiṃ visaye ñāṇaṃ pavattatīti. Evampi na yujjati. Na hi jātibhūmisabhāvādivasena
analyzed: bhagavataḥ ñāṇam siyā tasmā sakiṃya iva ñāṇam pavattati iti na yujjati  atha kamena sabbasmim visaye ñāṇam pavattati iti evam pi na yujjati na hi jāti bhūmi sabhāva ādi vasena
translated: Therefore it is not proper to say that his knowledge occurs only once.🔽If it is said that his knowledge occurs in succession with regard to all objects, that is not proper either. For when the knowable, which is differentiated in many ways by way of species, plane, nature, etc.,

original: disādesakālādivasena ca anekabhedabhinne ñeyye kamena gayhamāne tassa anavasesappaṭivedho🔽sambhavati apariyantabhāvato ñeyyassa. Ye pana “atthassa avisaṃvādanato ñeyyassa
analyzed: disā desa kāla ādi vasena ca aneka bheda bhinne ñeyye kamena gayhamāne tassa anavasesa paṭivedho  sambhavati a pariyanta bhāvataḥ ñeyyassa ye pana atthassa a visaṃvādanataḥ ñeyyassa
translated: and by way of direction, place, time, etc., is apprehended in succession, it is impossible to penetrate it completely,

original: ekadesaṃ paccakkhaṃ katvā sesepi evanti adhimuccitvā vavatthāpanena sabbaññū bhagavā,
analyzed: eka desam paccakkham katvā sese pi evanti adhimuccitvā vavatthāpanena sabbaññū bhagavā
translated: because the knowable is infinite. But those who say: “The Exalted One is omniscient because he has penetrated all dhammas by way of determining them through conviction, having directly known one part of the knowable and then concluding: ‘So are the rest’ because his knowledge is not contradicted with regard to the meaning of that part”

original: tañca ñāṇaṃ na anumānañāṇaṃ saṃsayābhāvato. Saṃsayānubaddhañhi loke anumānañāṇa”nti
analyzed: tat ca ñāṇam na anumāna ñāṇam saṃsaya abhāvataḥ saṃsaya anubaddham hi loke anumāna ñāṇam ti
translated: and who say: “That knowledge is not inferential knowledge, because there is no doubt. For in the world, inferential knowledge is accompanied by doubt” —

original: vadanti, tesampi taṃ na yuttaṃ. Sabbassa hi appaccakkhabhāve atthāvisaṃvādanena ñeyyassa
analyzed: vadanti tesam pi tam na yuttam sabbassa hi appaccakkha bhāve attha avisaṃvādanena ñeyyassa
translated: their position is not proper either. For if all dhammas are not directly known, then the Exalted One’s knowledge is contradicted with regard to the meaning of the rest of the knowable,

original: ekadesaṃ paccakkhaṃ katvā sesepi evanti adhimuccitvā vavatthāpanassa asambhavato.
analyzed: eka desam paccakkham katvā sese pi evanti adhimuccitvā vavatthāpanassa asambhavato
translated: because it is impossible to define by determining thus, ‘I have seen one part and I have not seen the other.’

original: Yañhi taṃ sesaṃ, taṃ appaccakkhanti.
analyzed: yat hi tam sesam tam appaccakkhanti
translated: For what is left is not seen.🔽But if that is seen, then what is left is not so.

original: Atha tampi paccakkhaṃ tassa sesabhāvo eva na siyāti? Sabbametaṃ akāraṇaṃ. Kasmā?
analyzed: atha tam pi paccakkham tassa sesa bhāvaḥ eva na siyāti sabbam etam akāraṇam kasmā
translated: All this is beside the point. Why?

original: Avisayavicāraṇabhāvato. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā – “buddhavisayo, bhikkhave, acinteyyo
analyzed: avisaya vicāraṇa bhāvataḥ vuttam ha etam bhagavatā buddha visayaḥ bhikkhave a cinteyyaḥ
translated: Because it is not a matter for consideration. For this is said by the Blessed One: “The domain of the Buddhas is inconceivable, bhikkhus,🔽inconceivable is the domain of the Buddhas. It is not to be thought about

original: na cintetabbo, yo cinteyya, ummādassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti. Idaṃ panettha sanniṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: na cintetabbaḥ yaḥ cinteyya ummādassa vighātassa bhāgī assa ati idam pana ittha sanniṭṭhānam
translated: by thought. Whoever should think about it, his head would split asunder” .🔽This is the conclusion here:

original: – yaṃ kiñci bhagavatā ñātuṃ icchitaṃ sakalaṃ ekadeso vā, tattha tattha appaṭihatavuttitāya
analyzed: yam kiñci bhagavatā ñātum icchitam sakalam eka desaḥ vā tattha tattha appaṭihata vutti tāya
translated: whatever the Blessed One wishes to know, whether in its entirety or in part,

original: paccakkhato ñāṇaṃ pavattati niccasamādhānañca vikkhepābhāvato. Ñātuṃ icchitassa ca
analyzed: paccakkhataḥ ñāṇam pavattati nicca samādhānam ca vikkhepa abhāvataḥ ñātum icchitassa ca
translated: his knowledge occurs with regard to it by way of direct knowledge because of his unobstructed seeing of it here and there.

original: sakalassa avisayabhāve tassa ākaṅkhappaṭibaddhavuttitā na siyā, ekantenevassā icchitabbā
analyzed: sakalassa a visaya bhāve tassa ākaṅkha paṭibaddha vutti tā na siyā ekantena iva assā icchitabbā
translated: And if the entire object of his wish were not to be his domain, his occurrence of knowledge would not be dependent on his wish. It must be admitted that it is entirely his domain.

original: “sabbe dhammā buddhassa bhagavato āvajjanappaṭibaddhā ākaṅkhappaṭibaddhā manasikārappaṭibaddhā
analyzed: sabbe dhammā buddhassa bhagavataḥ āvajjana ppaṭibaddhāḥ ākaṅkha ppaṭibaddhāḥ manasikāra ppaṭibaddhāḥ
translated: “All dhammas are bound up with the Blessed One’s adverting, bound up with his wish, bound up with his attention,

original: cittuppādappaṭibaddhā”ti vacanato. Atītānāgatavisayampi bhagavato ñāṇaṃ anumānāgamatakkagahaṇavirahitattā paccakkhameva.
analyzed: cittuppāda paṭibaddhā ti vacanataḥ atīta anāgata visayam pi bhagavataḥ ñāṇam anumāna āgama takka gahaṇa virahita ttā paccakkham eva
translated: bound up with the arising of his cognizance” . And the Blessed One’s knowledge of the past and future is also direct-known, not inferred, deduced, or received from another,

original: Nanu ca etasmimpi pakkhe yadā sakalaṃ ñātuṃ icchitaṃ, tadā sakiṃyeva sakalavisayatāya🔽anirūpitarūpena bhagavato ñāṇaṃ pavatteyyāti vuttadosā nātivattiyevāti? Na, tassa
analyzed: nanu ca etasmin pi pakkhe yadā sakalam ñātum icchitam tadā sakala visaya tāya  anirūpita rūpena bhagavataḥ ñāṇam pavatteyya iti vutta dosā na ativattiyā iva ati na tassa
translated: But surely in this case too, when he wants to know the whole of something, then since the whole of the objective field is at one time the object of his knowledge,

original: visodhitattā. Visodhito hi so buddhavisayo acinteyyoti. Aññathā pacurajanañāṇasamānavuttitāya
analyzed: visodhita ttā visodhitaḥ hi so buddha visayaḥ acinteyyaḥ ti aññathā pacura jana ñāṇa samāna vutti tāya
translated: his knowledge would occur without distinguishing the aspects, and so the fault stated does not fail to apply? No; because that objective field is purified. For that objective field of the Enlightened One is purified and inconceivable. Otherwise, since it would occur in the same way as the knowledge of ordinary people,

original: buddhānaṃ bhagavantānaṃ ñāṇassa acinteyyatā na siyā, tasmā sakaladhammārammaṇampi
analyzed: buddhānam bhagavantānam ñāṇassa acinteyya tā na siyā tasmā sakala dhamma ārammaṇam pi
translated: the knowledge of the Enlightened Ones, the Blessed Ones, would not be inconceivable. So although it has all dhammas as its object,

original: taṃ ekadhammārammaṇaṃ viya suvavatthāpiteyeva te dhamme katvā pavattatīti idamettha
analyzed: tam eka dhamma ārammaṇam viya te dhamme katvā pavattati iti idam ettha
translated: it occurs only after defining those dhammas as if they had each a single aspect.

original: acinteyyaṃ, “yāvatakaṃ ñeyyaṃ, tāvatakaṃ ñāṇaṃ. Yāvatakaṃ ñāṇaṃ, tāvatakaṃ ñeyyaṃ.
analyzed: acinteyyam yāvatakam ñeyyam tāvatakam ñāṇam yāvatakam ñāṇam tāvatakam ñeyyam
translated: “As far as there is the knowable, there is knowledge. As far as there is knowledge, there is the knowable.

original: Ñeyyapariyantikaṃ ñāṇaṃ, ñāṇapariyantikaṃ ñeyya”nti evamekajjhaṃ visuṃ sakiṃ kamena
analyzed: ñeyya pariyantikam ñāṇam ñāṇa pariyantikam evam ekajjham visum sakim kamena
translated: The knowable is the limit of knowledge, knowledge is the limit of the knowable” .

original: vā icchānurūpaṃ sammā sāmaṃ sabbadhammānaṃ buddhattā sammāsambuddho.🔽Vijjāhīti ettha vindiyaṃ vindatīti vijjā, yāthāvato upalabbhatīti attho. Attano vā
analyzed: vā icchā anurūpam sammā sāmam sabba dhammānam buddha ttā sammāsambuddhaḥ  vijjāhi iti ettha vindiyam vindati iti vijjā yāthāvataḥ upalabbhati iti atthaḥ attanaḥ vā
translated: Thus he is “fully enlightened” because he has discovered, has penetrated, has made his own, has fully understood, all things in all aspects simultaneously,🔽all at once, according to his wish.🔽“He has knowledge of the realization” : here “realization” is “knowledge” because it finds , the meaning is that it obtains things as they are.

original: paṭipakkhassa vijjhanaṭṭhena vijjā, tamokkhandhādikassa padālanaṭṭhenāti attho. Tato
analyzed: paṭipakkhassa vijjhana ṭhena vijjā tamaḥ khandha ādikassa padālana ṭṭhena ati attho tatas
translated: Or alternatively, it is “knowledge” because it is the act of knowing one’s own self or because it is the act of knowing the opposite of that . The meaning is that it is the act of breaking up the mass of darkness, etc.

original: eva attano visayassa viditakaraṇaṭṭhenapi vijjā. Sampannattāti samannāgatattā paripuṇṇattā
analyzed: eva attanaḥ visayassa vidita karaṇa ṭṭhena api vijjā sampanna ttā ati samannāgata ttā paripuṇṇa ttā
translated: And precisely for that reason it is also “knowledge” because it makes its own objective field known.🔽“Endowed with” : possessing, or fully endowed with, the meaning is that it is not deficient.

original: vā, avikalattāti attho. Tatrāti ambaṭṭhasutte. Manomayiddhiyāti ettha “idha bhikkhu🔽imamhā kāyā aññaṃ kāyaṃ abhinimmināti rūpiṃ manomayaṃ sabbaṅgapaccaṅgaṃ ahīnindriya”nti
analyzed: vā avikala ttā ti attho tatra ati ambaṭṭha sutte manaḥ maya iddhiyā iti ettha idha bhikkhu 🔽imamhā kāyā aññam kāyam abhinimmināti rūpim manaḥ mayam sabbaṅga paccaṅgam
translated: “There” : in the Ambattha Sutta .🔽“Supernormal power” : here “supernormal power” is “the ability to cause manifold manifestations by resolving , ‘Let there be!’” and “the ability to act in various ways by resolving , ‘Let there be!’”

original: iminā nayena āgatā iddhi sarīrabbhantare aññasseva jhānamanena nibbattattā manomayassa
analyzed: iminā nayena āgatā iddhi sarīra abbhantare aññassa iva jhāna manena nibbatta ttā manaḥ mayassa
translated: and so on. The supernormal power that has come about in this way is that of the mind-made body, since it is produced by this jhāna, which is different from the supernormal power that is produced by the supernormal power of the fourth jhāna.

original: sarīrassa nibbattivasena pavattā manomayiddhi nāma. Cha abhiññāti āsavakkhayañāṇena
analyzed: sarīrassa nibbatti vasena pavattā manaḥ maya iddhi nāma cha abhiññāti āsava kkhaya ñāṇena
translated: The psychic power that has come about in this way is called “psychic-power-as-mind-made” because it occurs by way of the production of a mind-made body, which is produced by this jhāna, and is different from the physical body.

original: saddhiṃ iddhividhādikā pañcābhiññāyo. Tissannaṃ aṭṭhannañca vijjānaṃ tattha tattha🔽sutte gahaṇaṃ veneyyajjhāsayavasenāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Satta saddhammā nāma saddhā hirī
analyzed: saddhim iddhividha ādikā pañca abhiññāyaḥ tissannam aṭṭhannam ca vijjānam tattha tattha  sutte gahaṇam veneyya ajjhāsaya vasena ati daṭṭhabbam satta saddhammāḥ nāma saddhā hirī
translated: The six kinds of direct-knowledge are the five beginning with psychic power together with knowledge of the destruction of the taints.🔽The inclusion of the three and the eight kinds of knowledge in the various suttas should be understood to be according to the inclinations of those to be trained.🔽The seven kinds of good doctrinal-tradition are faith, conscience, shame, learning, energy, mindfulness, and understanding.

original: ottappaṃ bāhusaccaṃ vīriyaṃ sati paññā ca. Ye sandhāya vuttaṃ “idha bhikkhu saddho🔽hoti, hirimā, ottappī, bahussuto, āraddhavīriyo, upaṭṭhitassati, paññavā hotī”ti.
analyzed: ottappam bāhusaccam vīriyam sati paññā ca ye sandhāya vuttam idha bhikkhu saddho  hoti hirimā ottappī bahu ssutaḥ āraddha vīriyaḥ upaṭṭhita sati paññavā hoti iti
translated: It is with reference to these that it is said: “Here a bhikkhu has faith, conscience, shame, learning, energy, mindfulness, and understanding” .

original: Cattāri jhānānīti yāni kānici cattāri rūpāvacarajjhānāni.
analyzed: cattāri jhānāni iti yāni kānici cattāri rūpāvacara jhānāni
translated: The four jhānas are any of the four jhānas of the fine-material sphere.

original: Kasmā panettha sīlādayoyeva pannarasa “caraṇa”nti vuttāti codanaṃ sandhāyāha “imeyeva
analyzed: kasmā pana ittha vuttā iti codanam sandhāya āha imeyā iva
translated: But why are only the fifteen beginning with virtue called “conduct”?

original: hī”tiādi. Tena tesaṃ sikkhattayasaṅgahato nibbānupagamane ekaṃsato sādhanabhāvamāha.
analyzed: hi itiādi tena tesam sikkhattaya saṅgahataḥ nibbāna upagamane ekaṃsataḥ sādhana bhāvam āha
translated: “The Blessed One is the one who has attained extinction by means of the three trainings” .

original: Idāni tadatthasādhanāya āgamaṃ dassento “yathāhā”tiādimāha. Bhagavātiādi vuttassevatthassa
analyzed: idāni tad attha sādhanāya āgamam dassentaḥ yathā āha atiādim āha bhagavā atiādi
translated: Now, in order to show the scriptural evidence for the establishment of the meaning of that , he says “Yathāha” , etc. The Blessed One, etc., is said by way of conclusion of the meaning already stated.

original: nigamanavasena vuttaṃ. Nanu cāyaṃ vijjācaraṇasampadā sāvakesupi labbhatīti? Kiñcāpi
analyzed: nigamana vasena vuttam nanu ca ayam vijjā caraṇa sampadā sāvakesu pi labbhati iti kiñcā api
translated: But is not this perfection of knowledge and virtue to be found also in disciples? Although it is to be found,

original: labbhati, na pana tathā, yathā bhagavatoti dassetuṃ “tattha vijjāsampadā”tiādi vuttaṃ.🔽Āsavakkhayavijjāya sabbaññubhāvasiddhito āha “vijjāsampadā bhagavato sabbaññutaṃ
analyzed: labbhati na pana tathā yathā bhagavato ti dassetum tattha vijjā sampadā tiādi vuttam  āsava kkhaya vijjāya sabbaññu bhāva siddhitaḥ āha vijjā sampadā bhagavataḥ sabbaññu tam
translated: it is not, however, in the same way as in the Blessed One. In order to show this, it is said “Tattha vijjāsampadā” , etc.🔽Since the knowledge of the destruction of the taints establishes omniscience, it is said “The perfection of knowledge of the Blessed One stands, having fulfilled omniscience” .

original: pūretvā ṭhitā”ti. Catūsu jhānesu antogadhabhāvena caraṇadhammapariyāpannattā karuṇābrahmavihārassa
analyzed: pūretvā ṭhitā ati catūsu jhānesu antogadha bhāvena caraṇa dhamma pariyāpanna ttā karuṇā brahmavihārassa
translated: Since the divine abiding of compassion is included among the four jhānas and is a state of virtue,

original: yathārahaṃ tassa ca mahākaruṇāsamāpattivasena asādhāraṇasabhāvassa bhagavati upalabbhanato
analyzed: yathāraham tassa ca mahā karuṇā samāpatti vasena asādhāraṇa sabhāvassa bhagavati upalabbhanato
translated: and since the Blessed One possesses the great compassion as a unique state, which is found in him by way of the attainment of great compassion,

original: āha “caraṇasampadā mahākāruṇikataṃ pūretvā ṭhitā”ti. Yathā sattānaṃ anatthaṃ parivajjetvā
analyzed: āha caraṇa sampadā mahā kāruṇika tam pūretvā ṭhitā ati yathā sattānam anattham parivajjetvā
translated: He said: “The perfection of conduct is fulfilled by the state of great compassion.”

original: atthe niyojanaṃ paññāya vinā na hoti, evaṃ nesaṃ atthānatthajānanaṃ satthu karuṇāya
analyzed: atthe niyojanam paññāya vinā na hoti evam na īsam attha anattha jānanam satthu karuṇāya
translated: Just as the avoidance of harm to beings and the direction of them to what is beneficial are not possible without wisdom, so too the knowledge of what is beneficial and harmful to them is not possible without the Teacher’s compassion.

original: vinā na hotīti ubhayampi ubhayattha sakiccakameva siyā. Yattha pana yassā padhānabhāvo,
analyzed: vinā na hoti iti ubhayam pi ubhayattha sa kiccakam eva siyā yattha pana yassā padhāna bhāvaḥ
translated: Thus both are able to perform their respective functions in both instances. But where one predominates,

original: taṃ dassetuṃ “so sabbaññutāyā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Yathā taṃ vijjācaraṇasampannoti ettha
analyzed: tam dassetum saḥ sabbaññu tāya itiādi vuttam yathā tam vijjā ācaraṇa sampannaḥ ti ettha
translated: that is pointed out by the words “He, having attained omniscience” and so on. Just as in the passage “Endowed with knowledge and conduct”

original: tanti nipātamattaṃ, yathā aññopi vijjācaraṇasampanno niyojeti, tathā ayanti attho.🔽Tena vijjācaraṇasampannassevāyaṃ āveṇikā paṭipattīti dasseti. Sā panāyaṃ satthu vijjācaraṇasampadā
analyzed: tatti nipāta mattam yathā aññaḥ api vijjā caraṇa sampannaḥ tathā ayanti attho  tena vijjā caraṇa sampannassa iva ayam āveṇikā paṭipatti iti dasseti sā pana ayam satthu vijjā caraṇa sampadā
translated: the word “thus” is merely a particle, so too here the word “thus” means “in the same way as one endowed with knowledge and conduct directs.”🔽He shows that this is the unique practice of one endowed with knowledge and conduct.🔽But this perfection of knowledge and conduct of the Teacher is the sole cause of the disciples’ right practice, which is the culmination of the Dispensation.

original: sāsanassa niyyānikatāya sāvakānaṃ sammāpaṭipattiyā ekantakāraṇanti dassetuṃ “tenassā”tiādi
analyzed: sāsanassa niyyānika tāya sāvakānam sammā paṭipattiyāḥ ekanta kāraṇanti dassetum tena assa atiādi
translated: To show this, he said “Therefore, in the Dispensation of the Teacher” and so on.

original: vuttaṃ. Tattha attantapādayoti ādi-saddena parantapaubhayantapā gahitā. Sesaṃ suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: vuttam tattha attantapa ādayo ti ādi saddena parantapa aubhayantapā gahitā sesam su viññeyyam eva
translated: Herein, the words “killing oneself” are a collective term for “killing others,” “killing both,” and so on. The rest is easily intelligible.

original: Ettha ca vijjāsampadāya satthu paññāmahattaṃ pakāsitaṃ hoti, caraṇasampadāya karuṇāmahattaṃ.
analyzed: ettha ca vijjā sampadāya satthu paññā mahattam pakāsitam hoti caraṇa sampadāya karuṇā mahattam
translated: And here the greatness of the Master’s understanding is revealed by the perfection of his knowledge, and the greatness of his compassion is revealed by the perfection of his conduct.🔽Of these, the Blessed One’s attainment of the sovereignty of the Dhamma is due to his understanding, and his sharing of the Dhamma is due to his compassion.

original: Tesu paññāya bhagavato dhammarajjappatti, karuṇāya dhammasaṃvibhāgo. Paññāya saṃsāradukkhanibbidā,
analyzed: tesu paññāya bhagavataḥ dhamma rajja ppatti karuṇāya dhamma saṃvibhāgaḥ paññāya saṃsāra dukkha nibbidā
translated: He is disgusted with the suffering of the round of rebirths by his understanding,🔽and he endures the suffering of the round of rebirths by his compassion. He knows the suffering of others by his understanding,

original: karuṇāya saṃsāradukkhasahanaṃ. Paññāya paradukkhaparijānanaṃ, karuṇāya paradukkhapatikārārambho.
analyzed: karuṇāya saṃsāra dukkha sahanam paññāya para dukkha parijānanam karuṇāya para dukkha patikāra ārambhaḥ
translated: and he undertakes to remove the suffering of others by his compassion.🔽He is intent on Nibbāna by his understanding,

original: Paññāya parinibbānābhimukhabhāvo, karuṇāya tadadhigamo. Paññāya sayaṃ taraṇaṃ, karuṇāya
analyzed: paññāya parinibbāna abhimukha bhāvaḥ karuṇāya tad adhigamaḥ paññāya sayam taraṇam karuṇāya
translated: and he attains it by his compassion. He crosses over the flood by his understanding,🔽and he causes others to cross over it by his compassion. He succeeds in becoming a Buddha by his understanding,

original: paresaṃ tāraṇaṃ. Paññāya buddhabhāvasiddhi, karuṇāya buddhakiccasiddhi. Karuṇāya
analyzed: paresam tāraṇam paññāya buddha bhāva siddhi karuṇāya buddha kicca siddhi karuṇāya
translated: and he succeeds in fulfilling the duties of a Buddha by his compassion.🔽Or alternatively, his intentness on the round of rebirths is due to his compassion while he is a Bodhisatta,

original: vā bodhisattabhūmiyaṃ saṃsārābhimukhabhāvo, paññāya tattha anabhirati, tathā karuṇāya
analyzed: vā bodhisatta bhūmiyam saṃsāra abhimukha bhāvo paññāya tattha an abhirati tathā karuṇāya
translated: and his lack of delight in it is due to his understanding. Likewise his intentness on the round of rebirths is due to his compassion while he is a Buddha,

original: paresaṃ abhiṃsāpanaṃ, paññāya sayaṃ parehi abhāyanaṃ. Karuṇāya paraṃ rakkhanto attānaṃ
analyzed: paresam abhiṃsāpanam paññāya sayam parehi abhāyanam karuṇāya param rakkhantaḥ attānam
translated: and not deceiving others by his wisdom. He protects others by his compassion,

original: rakkhati, paññāya attānaṃ rakkhanto paraṃ rakkhati. Tathā karuṇāya aparantapo, paññāya
analyzed: rakkhati paññāya attānam rakkhantaḥ param rakkhati tathā karuṇāya aparantapaḥ paññāya
translated: and he protects himself by his wisdom. Thus he is not tormented by himself through compassion,

original: anattantapo, tena attahitāya paṭipannādīsu catūsu puggalesu catutthapuggalabhāvo
analyzed: tena atta hitāya paṭipanna ādīsu catūsu puggalesu catuttha puggala bhāvaḥ
translated: and he is not tormented by others through wisdom. Thus the fourth kind of person, who practices for the benefit of himself and others, is established.

original: siddho hoti. Tathā karuṇāya lokanāthatā, paññāya attanāthatā. Karuṇāya cassa ninnatābhāvo,
analyzed: siddhaḥ hoti tathā karuṇāya loka nātha tā paññāya atta nātha tā karuṇāya cassa ninna tā bhāvo
translated: And thus he is a protector of the world through compassion, and a protector of himself through wisdom. He is humble through compassion,

original: paññāya unnamābhāvo. Tathā karuṇāya sabbasattesu janitānuggaho, paññānugatattā na
analyzed: paññāya unnama abhāvo tathā karuṇāya sabba sattesu janita anuggaho paññā anugata ttā na
translated: and exalted through wisdom. And thus he is devoted to the service of all beings through compassion,

original: ca na sabbattha virattacitto, paññāya sabbadhammesu virattacitto, karuṇānugatattā
analyzed: ca na sabbattha viratta citto paññāya sabba dhammesu viratta citto karuṇā anugata ttā
translated: and his mind is not unattached anywhere through his wisdom. His mind is unattached to all things through wisdom,🔽and he is not unengaged in the service of all beings through his compassion.

original: na ca na sabbasattānuggahāya pavatto. Yathā hi karuṇā bhagavato sinehasokavirahitā,
analyzed: na ca na sabba satta anuggahāya pavattaḥ yathā hi karuṇā bhagavataḥ sineha soka virahitā
translated: For just as the Blessed One’s compassion is free from affection and free from sorrow,

original: evaṃ paññā ahaṃkāramamaṃkāravinimuttāti aññamaññavisodhitā paramavisuddhā guṇavisesā
analyzed: evam paññā ahaṃkāra mamaṃkāra vinimuttā ati añña mañña visodhitā parama visuddhā guṇa visesā
translated: so his wisdom is free from the conceit “I am” and from the conceit “mine.” Thus his special qualities, purified by their mutual purification, are supremely purified.

original: vijjācaraṇasampadāhi pakāsitāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: vijjā ācaraṇa sampadā hi pakāsitā iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: and it should be regarded as the light of the world because it illuminates the world with the perfection of knowledge and conduct.

original: Idāni sugatoti imassa atthaṃ dassento āha “sobhanagamanattā”tiādi. “Gate ṭhite”tiādīsu
analyzed: idāni sugataḥ ti imassa attham dassentaḥ āha sobhana gamana ttā atiādi gate ṭhita iti ādīsu
translated: Now, in order to show the meaning of “well gone” he said “because of good going” and so on. In the passage beginning “in going, in standing”

original: gamanampi gatanti vuccatīti āha “gamanampi hi gatanti vuccatī”ti. Sobhananti subhaṃ,
analyzed: gamanam pi gatanti vuccati iti āha gamanam pi hi gatanti vuccati iti sobhanam ti subham
translated: he said “for going is also called ‘gone’” because going is also called “gone.” “Good” is “beautiful” ;

original: subhabhāvo visuddhatāya, visuddhatā dosavigamenāti āha “parisuddhamanavajja”nti.
analyzed: subha bhāvaḥ visuddha tāya visuddha tā dosa vigamena ati āha parisuddham anavajjanti
translated: its beauty is purity, and purity is the absence of hate, thus he said “pure and blameless.”

original: Gamanañca nāma bahuvidhanti idhādhippetaṃ gamanaṃ dassento “ariyamaggo”ti āha. So
analyzed: gamanam ca nāma bahuvidhan ti idha adhippetam gamanam dassentaḥ ariya maggo ti āha so
translated: And “going” is of many kinds, thus in order to show the kind of going intended here he said “the Noble Eightfold Path.”

original: hi nibbānassa gati adhigamoti ca katvā gataṃ gamananti ca vuccati. Idāni tasseva🔽gamane kāraṇaṃ dassetuṃ “tena hesā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Khemaṃ disanti nibbānaṃ. Asajjamānoti
analyzed: hi nibbānassa gati adhigamaḥ ti ca katvā gatam gamananti ca vuccati idāni tassa eva  gamane kāraṇam dassetum tena ha isā tiādi vuttam khemam disanti nibbānam asajjamāno ti
translated: For that is called “gone” and “going” because it is the destination and the arrival at Nibbāna.

original: paripanthābhāvena sugatigamanepi asajjanto saṅgaṃ akaronto, pageva itarattha. Atha
analyzed: paripanthā bhāvena sugati gamane pi a sajjantaḥ saṅgam a karontaḥ pagā iva atha
translated: Now, in order to show the reason for that kind of going he said “therefore it is said” and so on. The “safe direction” is Nibbāna. “Without impediment” means without obstruction, thus without making contact, not only in going to a good destination but also in the other case.

original: vā ekāsane nisīditvā khippābhiññāvaseneva catunnampi maggānaṃ paṭiladdhabhāvato asajjamāno🔽abajjhanto gato. Yaṃ gamanaṃ gacchanto sabbagamanatthaṃ āvahati, sabbañca anuttaraṃ
analyzed: vā eka āsane nisīditvā khippa abhiññā vasena iva catunnam pi maggānam paṭiladdha bhāvataḥ a sajjamānaḥ  a bajjhantaḥ gataḥ yam gamanam gacchantaḥ sabba gamana attham āvahati sabbam ca anuttaram
translated: and he went without hesitation, without wavering, sitting in one seat, because he had attained all the four paths by the method of quick direct-knowledge.

original: sampattiṃ āvahati, tadeva sobhanaṃ nāma, tena ca bhagavā gatoti āha “iti sobhanagamanattā🔽sugato”ti sobhanattho susaddoti katvā.
analyzed: sampattim āvahati tat eva sobhanam nāma tena ca bhagavā gataḥ iti āha iti  sugataḥ ti sobhana attho su saddo ti katvā
translated: The going that he went by bringing about all the kinds of going and by bringing about all the unsurpassed kinds of success is called “beautiful” . And because he went by that, he is the “Blessed One” .

original: Asundarānaṃ dukkhānaṃ saṅkhārappavattīnaṃ abhāvato accantasukhattā ekantato sundaraṃ
analyzed: asundarānam dukkhānam saṅkhāra ppavattīnam abhāvataḥ accanta sukhattā ekantataḥ sundaram
translated: The unformed element is called “beautiful” because it is the absence of all kinds of ugly suffering that occurs in formations and because it is supremely beautiful, being entirely beautiful.

original: nāma asaṅkhatā dhātūti āha “sundarañcesa ṭhānaṃ gato amataṃ nibbāna”nti. Tenāha bhagavā
analyzed: nāma asaṅkhatā dhātu iti āha sundaram ca isa ṭhānam gataḥ amatam nibbānam ti tena āha bhagavā
translated: He has gone to the beautiful place, the deathless Nibbāna” . That is why the Blessed One said:🔽“Nibbāna is the highest bliss” .

original: “nibbānaṃ paramaṃ sukha”nti. Sammāti suṭṭhu. Suṭṭhu gamanañca nāma paṭipakkhena anabhibhūtassa
analyzed: nibbānam paramam sukhanti sammā ati suṭṭhu suṭṭhu gamanam ca nāma paṭipakkhena an abhibhūtassa
translated: “Rightly” : rightly gone. Rightly gone is the going of one who is not overcome by his opposites.

original: gamananti āha “pahīne kilese puna apaccāgacchanto”ti, pahīnānaṃ puna asamudācāravasena
analyzed: gamanam iti āha pahīne kilese puna a paccāgacchantā iti pahīnānam puna asamudācāra vasena
translated: He has gone, having abandoned the defilements, without returning again” . He has gone, having abandoned the defilements, without their reappearing.

original: apaccāgacchanto. Vuttamevatthaṃ āgamaṃ dassetvā vibhāvento āha “vuttañceta”ntiādi.🔽Etanti tena tena maggena pahīnakilesānaṃ puna apaccāgamanaṃ, idañca sikhāppattaṃ
analyzed: a paccāgacchantaḥ vuttam eva attham āgamam dassetvā vibhāventaḥ āha vuttam cetaḥ iti ādi  etat ti tena tena maggena pahīna kilesānam puna apaccāgamanam idam ca sikhāppattam
translated: Having shown the meaning stated already by means of the Thread, he now, in the Vibhaòga, says “But it is said” , etc.🔽“That” is the non-coming back again of the defilements abandoned by each of the paths, and this coming rightly is the rightness of the path that is successful by means of the way of coming rightly.

original: sammāgamanaṃ, yāya āgamanīyapaṭipadāya siddhaṃ, sāpi sammāgamanamevāti evampi bhagavā
analyzed: sammāgamanam yāya āgamanīya paṭipadāya siddham sā api sammāgamanam eva ati evam pi bhagavā
translated: So too the Blessed One is “well-gone” in this way.🔽In order to show this he says “He has gone rightly” , etc.

original: sugatoti dassetuṃ “sammā vā āgato”tiādi vuttaṃ. Sammāpaṭipattiyāti sammāsambodhiyā🔽sampāpane aviparītapaṭipattiyā. Sabbalokassa hitasukhameva karontāti etena mahābodhiyā
analyzed: sugataḥ ti dassetum sammā vā āgataḥ tiādi vuttam sammā paṭipattiyā ti sammāsambodhiyā  sampāpane a viparīta paṭipattiyā sabba lokassa hita sukham eva karontā ati etena mahā bodhiyā
translated: In the right way is in the right practice that brings about right self-awakening.

original: paṭipadā avibhāgena sabbasattānaṃ sabbadā hitasukhāvahabhāveneva pavattatīti dasseti.
analyzed: paṭipadā avibhāgena sabba sattānam sabbadā hita sukha āvaha bhāvena iva pavattati iti dasseti
translated: In the welfare and happiness of all the world: by this he shows that the practice of the Great Way of Development 1 goes on occurring only as the source of welfare and happiness for all creatures at all times without distinction.

original: Sassataṃ ucchedanti ime ante anupagacchanto gatoti etena paṭiccasamuppādagatiṃ dasseti.
analyzed: ime ante an upagacchantaḥ gataḥ ti etena paṭiccasamuppāda gatim dasseti
translated: Not gone to the extreme of eternalism or to the extreme of annihilationism: by this he shows the way of dependent origination.

original: Kāmasukhaṃ attakilamathanti ime anupagacchanto gatoti etena ariyamaggagatiṃ dasseti.
analyzed: kāma sukham atta kilamathanti ime an upagacchantaḥ gataḥ ti etena ariya magga gatim dasseti
translated: Not gone to sense-desire pleasures or to self-torment: by this he shows the way of the Noble Path.

original: Tatrāti yuttaṭṭhāne yuttasseva bhāsane. Nipphādetabbe sādhetabbe cetaṃ bhummaṃ. Abhūtanti
analyzed: tatra ati yutta ṭṭhāne yuttassa iva bhāsane nipphādetabbe sādhetabbe ca itam bhummam a bhūta ti
translated: Herein, in the right place is in the right place for speaking. The state of being is the state of being accomplished and achieved.🔽Not true:

original: abhūtatthaṃ. Atthamukhena hi vācāya abhūtatā bhūtatā vā. Atacchanti tasseva vevacanaṃ.
analyzed: a bhūta ttham attha mukhena hi vācāya a bhūta tā bhūta tā vai a tacchanti tassa iva vevacanam
translated: not true in meaning. For the untruth or truth of speech is in its meaning. It is a synonym for “not true.”

original: Anatthasaṃhitanti diṭṭhadhammikena samparāyikena vā anatthena saṃhitaṃ anatthasaṃhitaṃ,
analyzed: anattha saṃhitanti diṭṭhadhammikena samparāyikena vā anatthena saṃhitam anattha saṃhitam
translated: Not conducive to welfare: connected with what is not conducive to welfare, either in this life or in the life to come, it is connected with what is not conducive to welfare,

original: anatthāvahaṃ. Na atthoti anattho, atthassa paṭipakkho abhāvo ca, tena saṃhitaṃ, pisuṇavācaṃ
analyzed: anattha āvaham na attho ti anatthaḥ atthassa paṭipakkhaḥ abhāvaḥ ca tena saṃhitam pisuṇa vācam
translated: it brings what is not conducive to welfare. Not welfare is what is not conducive to welfare, the opposite of welfare, and the absence of welfare. Connected with that, connected with malicious speech

original: samphappalāpañcāti attho. Evamettha catubbidhassapi vacīduccaritassa saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo.🔽Ettha ca paṭhamā vācā sīlavantaṃ “dussīlo”ti, acaṇḍālādiṃ “caṇḍālo”tiādinā bhāsamānassa
analyzed: attho evam ettha catubbidhassa api vacī duccaritassa saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo  ettha ca paṭhamā vācā sīlavantam dussīlaḥ ti a caṇḍāla ādim caṇḍāla uti ādinā bhāsamānassa
translated: and connected with chatter, is what is meant. So the inclusion of all the four kinds of verbal misconduct should be understood here.🔽And here the first kind of speech should be regarded as that of one who speaks thus: “The virtuous man is unvirtuous” or “The man who is not an outcaste is an outcaste,”

original: daṭṭhabbā. Dutiyā dussīlaṃ “dussīlo”ti, caṇḍālādimeva “caṇḍālo”tiādinā avinayena
analyzed: daṭṭhabbā dutiyā dussīlam dussīlaḥ uti caṇḍāla ādim eva caṇḍāla uti ādinā avinayena
translated: and so on. The second kind should be regarded as that of one who speaks thus: “The unvirtuous man is unvirtuous” or “The outcaste is an outcaste,” and so on, without using the proper form of expression.

original: bhāsamānassa. Tatiyā nerayikādikassa nerayikādibhāvavibhāvanīkathā yathā “āpāyiko
analyzed: bhāsamānassa tatiyā nerayika ādikassa nerayika ādi bhāva vibhāvanī kathā yathā āpāyikaḥ
translated: The third kind should be regarded as the talk of one who makes it known that one in hell, for instance, is in hell, saying: “He is in hell” or “He is in the animal realm” or “He is in the realm of ghosts.”

original: devadatto nerayiko”tiādikā. Catutthī “vedavihitena yaññavidhinā pāṇātipātādikataṃ
analyzed: devadattaḥ na īrayikā iti ādikā catutthī veda vihitena yañña vidhinā
translated: “Devadatta is bound for the states of deprivation” . The fourth is such statements as “By the performance of the sacrifice laid down in the Vedas, there is killing, stealing, lying, and so on.

original: sugatiṃ āvahatī”ti lokassa byāmohanakathā. Pañcamī bhūtena pesuññupasaṃhārā kathā.
analyzed: sugatim āvahati iti lokassa byāmohana kathā pañcamī bhūtena pesuññu pasaṃhārā kathā
translated: “Devadatta is bound for hell” , etc., is the fourth. The fifth is talk that misleads the world, such as the statement “By the performance of the sacrifice laid down in the Vedas, killing living beings, etc.,

original: Chaṭṭhā yuttapattaṭṭhāne pavattitā dānasīlādikathā veditabbā. Evaṃ sammā gadattāti🔽yathāvuttaṃ abhūtādiṃ vajjetvā bhūtaṃ tacchaṃ atthasaṃhitaṃ piyaṃ manāpaṃ tato eva🔽sammā suṭṭhu gadanato sugato. Āpāthagamanamattena kassaci appiyampi hi bhagavato🔽vacanaṃ piyaṃ manāpameva atthasiddhiyā lokassa hitasukhāvahattā. Ettha pana da-kārassa
analyzed: chaṭṭhā yutta pattaṭṭhāne pavatti tā dāna sīla ādi kathā veditabbā evam sammā gadatta ati  yathāvuttam abhūta ādim vajjetvā bhūtam tat śam attha saṃhitam piyam manāpam tatas eva  sammā suṭṭhu gadanataḥ sugataḥ āpātha gamana mattena kassaci appiyam pi hi bhagavato  vacanam piyam manāpam eva attha siddhiyā lokassa hita sukha āvaha tā ettha pana dakārassa
translated: leads to a happy destiny” . The sixth should be understood as the talk about generosity, virtue, etc., that occurs in the proper context.🔽Thus he is the One who speaks well:🔽he is the One who goes well because he speaks well, because he speaks what is factual, true, meaningful, agreeable, and pleasing, avoiding what is not factual, etc., as stated above. For even what is disagreeable to some is agreeable and pleasing to the world because it accomplishes their welfare, since it brings about their benefit and happiness.

original: ta-kāraṃ katvā “sugato”ti vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: takāram katvā sugataḥ iti vuttam ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: Here the letter da should be taken as equivalent to the letter ta, and the word sugato should be understood as formed with the root gam plus the suffix -ato.

original: Aparo nayo – sobhanaṃ gataṃ gamanaṃ etassāti sugato. Bhagavato hi veneyyajanupasaṅkamanaṃ
analyzed: aparaḥ nayaḥ sobhanam gatam gamanam etassa ati sugataḥ bhagavataḥ hi veneyya jana upasaṅkamanam
translated: Another method: he is the One who goes well because his going, his approach to those who are ready to be trained,

original: ekantena tesaṃ hitasukhanipphādanato sobhanaṃ bhaddakaṃ. Tathā lakkhaṇānubyañjanappaṭimaṇḍitarūpakāyatāya
analyzed: ekantena tesam hita sukha nipphādanato sobhanam bhaddakam tathā lakkhaṇa anubyañjana ppaṭimaṇḍita rūpa kāya tāya
translated: It is beautiful, excellent, in that it produces the welfare and happiness of beings exclusively.

original: dutavilambitakhalitānukaḍḍhananippīḷanukkuṭikakuṭilākulatādidosavirahitaṃ vilāsitarājahaṃsavasabhavāraṇamigarājagamanaṃ🔽kāyagamanaṃ ñāṇagamanañca vipulanimmalakaruṇāsativīriyādiguṇavisesahitamabhinīhārato
analyzed: duta vilambita khalita anukaḍḍhana nippīḍa nukkuṭika kuṭila ākula tā ādi dosa virahitam vilāsita rājahaṃsa vasabha vāraṇa miga rāja gamanam  kāya gamanam ñāṇa gamanam ca vipula nimmala karuṇā sati vīriya ādi guṇa visesa hitam abhinīhārato
translated: And so too is his bodily and mental movement, which is free from the faults of being slow, delayed, unsteady, dragging, painful, stooping, crooked, or agitated, and which is graceful like that of the royal swan, the leader of the herd of cattle, or the king of beasts.

original: yāva mahābodhi anavajjatāya sattānaṃ hitasukhāvahatāya ca sobhanameva. Atha vā sayambhūñāṇena🔽sakalampi lokaṃ pariññābhisamayavasena parijānanto sammā gato avagatoti sugato. Tathā🔽lokasamudayaṃ pahānābhisamayavasena pajahanto anuppattidhammataṃ āpādento sammā gato
analyzed: yāva mahā bodhi anavajja tāya sattānam hita sukha avahatāya ca sobhanam eva atha vā sayambhu ñāṇena  sakalam pi lokam pariññā abhisamaya vasena parijānanto sammā gataḥ avagataḥ iti sugataḥ tathā  loka samudayam pahāna abhisamaya vasena pajahantaḥ an uppatti dhamma tam āpādentaḥ sammā gataḥ
translated: And his bodily and mental movement, accompanied by the special qualities of vast, stainless, compassionate, mindful, energetic, and other such qualities, is beautiful from the time of his great aspiration until the time of his great enlightenment, in that it is irreproachable and brings welfare and happiness to beings.🔽Or else, he is well gone because he has gone rightly, having fully known the entire world by way of the full-understanding of penetration.🔽And so too, he is well gone because he has gone rightly, having abandoned the origin of the world by way of the full-understanding of abandoning, and having brought about its non-arising.

original: atītoti sugato. Lokanirodhaṃ nibbānaṃ sacchikiriyābhisamayavasena sammā gato adhigatoti
analyzed: atītaḥ iti sugataḥ loka nirodham nibbānam sacchikiriyā abhisamaya vasena sammā gataḥ adhigataḥ iti
translated: He is well gone because he has gone rightly, having realized the cessation of the world, Nibbāna, by way of the full-understanding of realization.

original: sugato. Lokanirodhagāminiṃ paṭipadaṃ bhāvanābhisamayavasena sammā gato paṭipannoti
analyzed: sugataḥ loka nirodha gāminim paṭipadam bhāvanā abhisamaya vasena sammā gataḥ paṭipanno ti
translated: He is the One Gone to Wholeness of Understanding in the Cessation of the World by way of the Realization of Development.🔽He is the One Gone to Wholeness of Understanding in the Way Leading to the Cessation of the World by way of the Realization of Development.🔽He is the One Gone to Wholeness of Understanding in the Way Leading to the Cessation of the World by way of the Realization of Development.🔽He is the One Gone to Wholeness of Understanding in the Way Leading to the Cessation of the World by way of the Realization of Development.

original: sugato. Tathā yaṃ imassa sadevakassa lokassa diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ🔽pariyesitaṃ ñātaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, sabbaṃ taṃ hatthatale āmalakaṃ viya sammā🔽paccakkhato gato abbhaññāsīti sugato.🔽Idāni lokavidūti imassa atthaṃ pakāsento āha “sabbathā viditalokattā”tiādi. Tattha
analyzed: sugataḥ tathā yam imassa sa devakassa lokassa diṭṭham sutam mutam viññātam pattam  pariyesitam ñātam anuvicaritam manasā sabbam tam hattha tale āmalakam viya sammā  paccakkhatas gataḥ abbhaññāsi iti sugataḥ  idāni loka vidū ti imassa attham pakāsentaḥ āha sabbathā vidita loka ttā atiādi tattha
translated: He is the One Gone to Wholeness of Understanding in the Way Leading to the Cessation of the World by way of the Realization of Development.🔽He is the One Gone to Wholeness of Understanding in the Way Leading to the Cessation of the World by way of the Realization of Development.🔽He is the One Gone to Wholeness of Understanding in the Way Leading to the Cessation of the World by way of the Realization of Development.🔽He is the One Gone to Wholeness of Understanding in the Way Leading to the Cessation of the World by way of the Realization of Development.

original: sabbathāti sabbappakārena, yo yo loko yena yena pakārena veditabbo, tena tena pakārenāti🔽attho. Te pana pakāre dassetuṃ “sabhāvato”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha sabhāvatoti dukkhasabhāvato.
analyzed: sabbathā ati sabbappakārena yaḥ yaḥ lokaḥ yena yena pakārena veditabbaḥ tena tena pakārena ati  atthaḥ te pana pakāre dassetum sabhāvato tiādi vuttam tattha sabhāvato ti dukkha sabhāvato
translated: He is the One Gone to Wholeness of Understanding in the Way Leading to the Cessation of the World by way of the Realization of Development.🔽He is the One Gone to Wholeness of Understanding in the Way Leading to the Cessation of the World by way of the Realization of Development.🔽He is the One Gone to Wholeness of Understanding in the Way Leading to the Cessation of the World by way of the Realization of Development.🔽He is the One Gone to Wholeness of Understanding in the Way Leading to the Cessation of the World by way of the Realization of Development.🔽He is the One Gone to Wholeness of Understanding in the Way Leading to the Cessation of the World by way of the Realization of Development.🔽He is the One Gone to Wholeness of Understanding in the Way Leading to the Cessation of the World by way of the Realization of Development.🔽He is the One Gone to Wholeness of Understanding in the Way Leading to the Cessation of the World by way of the Realization of Development.

original: Sabbo hi loko dukkhasabhāvo. Yathāha “saṃkhittena pañcupādānakkhandhā dukkhā”ti.
analyzed: sabbaḥ hi lokaḥ dukkha sabhāvaḥ yathā āha saṃkhittena pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ dukkhā ti
translated: He is the One Gone to Wholeness of Understanding in the Way Leading to the Cessation of the World by way of the Realization of Development.🔽He is the One

original: Samudayatoti yato samudeti, tato taṇhādito. Nirodhatoti yattha so nirujjhati, tato
analyzed: samudayato ti yatas samudeti tatas taṇhā āditaḥ nirodhato ti yattha saḥ nirujjhati tatas
translated: “In terms of origination”: from where it originates, from craving, etc. “In terms of cessation”: where it ceases,

original: visaṅkhārato. Nirodhūpāyatoti yena vidhinā so nirodho pattabbo, tato ariyamaggato
analyzed: visaṅkhārataḥ nirodha upāyataḥ ti yena vidhinā saḥ nirodho pattabbaḥ tatas ariya maggato
translated: in the cessation of formations. “In terms of the means to cessation”: by what means it ceases, by the noble path.

original: ito aññassa pakārassa abhāvā. Iti “sabbathā lokaṃ avedī”ti vatvā tadatthasādhakaṃ
analyzed: itas aññassa pakārassa abhāvā iti sabbathā lokam avedi iti vatvā tad attha sādhakam
translated: Because there is no other way. Thus, having said, “In every way he has understood the world,” he shows a sutta that proves that meaning, saying, “Where, friend,” etc.

original: suttaṃ dassento “yattha kho, āvuso”tiādimāha. Idañca suttaṃ “yattha kho, bhante,
analyzed: suttam dassentaḥ yattha kho āvuso ti ādim āha idam ca suttam yattha kho bhante
translated: And this sutta was spoken by the Exalted One in reply to a question asked by the god Rohiṇṇaka concerning the destiny of the world of space, thus: “Where, venerable sir,

original: na jāyati…pe… na upapajjati, sakkā nu kho so, bhante, gamanena lokassa anto ñātuṃ🔽vā daṭṭhuṃ vā pāpuṇituṃ vā”ti okāsalokassa gatiṃ sandhāya rohitadevaputtena puṭṭho🔽bhagavā abhāsi. Tattha na jāyatītiādinā ujukaṃ jātiādīni paṭikkhipitvā na cavati
analyzed: na jāyati pe na upapajjati sakkā nu kho so bhante gamanena lokassa antaḥ ñātum  vā daṭṭhum vā pāpuṇitum vā ati okāsa lokassa gatim sandhāya rohitadevaputtena puṭṭhaḥ  bhagavā abhāsi tattha na jāyati iti ādinā ujukam jāti ādīni paṭikkhipitvā na cavati
translated: one is not born … does not pass away … does not reappear, is it possible to know the world’s end by travelling?”

original: na upapajjatīti padadvayena aparāparaṃ cavanupapatanāni paṭikkhipati. Keci pana “na
analyzed: na upapajjati iti pada dvayena apara aparam cava nupapatanāni paṭikkhipati keci pana na
translated: Here, by the words “is not born,” etc., he directly denies birth, etc. By the two phrases “does not pass away” and “does not reappear” he denies passing away and reappearance in succession.

original: jāyatītiādi gabbhaseyyakādivasena vuttaṃ, itaraṃ opapātikavasenā”ti vadanti. Tanti
analyzed: jāyati itiādi gabbhaseyyaka ādi vasena vuttam itaram opapātika vasena ati vadanti
translated: “Tanti” means “without birth and so on.”🔽“Gamanena” means “by walking.”

original: jātiādirahitaṃ. Gamanenāti padasā gamanena. Lokassantanti saṅkhāralokassa antabhūtaṃ
analyzed: jāti ādi rahitam gamanena ati padasā gamanena saṅkhāra lokassa anta bhūtam
translated: “Lokassanta” means “Nibbana, which is the end of the world of formations.”

original: nibbānaṃ. Ñāteyyanti jānitabbaṃ. Daṭṭheyyanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Patteyyanti pattabbaṃ.
analyzed: nibbānam ñāteyyanti jānitabbam daṭṭheyyanti daṭṭhabbam patteyyanti pattabbam
translated: “Ñāteyyanti” means “should be known.” “Daṭṭheyyanti” means “should be seen.” “Patteyyanti” means “should be reached.”

original: “Ñātāyaṃ diṭṭhāyaṃ pattāya”nti vā pāṭho, tattha gamanena lokassantaṃ ñātā ayaṃ diṭṭhā
analyzed: ñātā ayam diṭṭhā ayam pattāyanti vā tattha gamanena lokaḥ antam ñātā ayam diṭṭhā
translated: “Ñātāyaṃ diṭṭhāyaṃ pattāya” is another reading. The meaning is: I do not say that by walking one can reach the end of the world and know it, see it, and reach it.

original: ayaṃ pattā ayanti na vadāmīti attho. Ayanti nibbānatthiko.
analyzed: ayam pattā ayanti na vadāmi iti atthaḥ ayanti nibbānatthiko
translated: “Ayanti” means “one who is intent on Nibbana.”

original: Kāmaṃ padasā gamanena gantvā lokassantaṃ ñātuṃ daṭṭhuṃ pattuṃ vā na sakkā, api ca🔽parimitaparicchinnaṭṭhāne taṃ paññāpetvā dassemīti dassento “api cā”tiādimāha. Tattha
analyzed: kāmam padasā gamanena gantvā lokaḥ santam ñātum daṭṭhum pattum vā na sakkā api ca  parimita paricchinna ṭhāne tam paññāpetvā dassemi iti dassentaḥ api ca atiādim āha tattha
translated: “Although it is not possible to know, see, or reach the end of the world by walking,🔽nevertheless, in order to show it by pointing to a limited, circumscribed place, he said ‘Api ca’ .

original: byāmamatte kaḷevareti byāmappamāṇe attabhāve. Iminā rūpakkhandhaṃ dasseti. Sasaññimhīti
analyzed: byāma matte kaḷevare ti byāma ppamāṇe atta bhāve iminā rūpa kkhandham dasseti sa saññimhi iti
translated: ‘Byāmamatte kaḷevare’ means ‘in a body one byāma in size.’ This shows the material form aggregate. ‘Sasaññimhi’ means ‘in one who has perception.’

original: saññāya sahite. Iminā saññāsīsena vedanādayo tayo khandhe dasseti saññāsahitattā🔽eva. Samanaketi saviññāṇaketi attho. Iminā viññāṇakkhandhaṃ dasseti, aviññāṇake pana
analyzed: saññāya sahite iminā saññā sīsena vedanā ādayo tayo khandhe dasseti saññā sahita ttā  eva samanakā iti sa viññāṇakā iti atthaḥ iminā viññāṇa kkhandham dasseti aviññāṇake pana
translated: With perception, etc. He shows the three aggregates of feeling, etc., by this perception aggregate, because they are associated with perception.🔽With a living being, etc. The meaning is: with consciousness. He shows the consciousness aggregate by this, because it is impossible to point out a mere collection of materiality originated by temperature in one without consciousness.

original: utusamuṭṭhānarūpasamudāyamatte paññāpetuṃ na sakkāti adhippāyo. Lokanti khandhādilokaṃ.🔽Lokanirodhanti tassa lokassa nirujjhanaṃ nibbānameva vā. Nibbānampi hi khandhe paṭicca
analyzed: utu samuṭṭhāna rūpa samudāya matte paññāpetum na sakkā ati adhippāyaḥ lokanti khandha ādi lokam  loka nirodham ti tassa lokassa nirujjhanam nibbānam eva vā nibbānam pi hi khandhe paṭicca
translated: The world: the world of the aggregates, etc.🔽The world’s end: the cessation of that world, or else only Nibbāna. For Nibbāna is also pointed out in the body itself, since it is pointed out in dependence on the aggregates.

original: paññāpanato sarīrasmiṃyeva paññāpeti. Adesampi hi taṃ yesaṃ nirodho, tesaṃ vasena
analyzed: paññāpanato sarīrasmiṃ yeva paññāpeti adesam pi hi tam yesam nirodho tesam vasena
translated: For even in the place where it is not, it is pointed out by the term “end” in dependence on the place where it is,

original: desatopi upacāravasena niddisīyati yathā “cakkhuṃ loke piyarūpaṃ sātarūpaṃ, etthesā🔽taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati, ettha nirujjhamānā nirujjhatī”ti.
analyzed: desatas pi upacāra vasena niddisīyati yathā cakkhum loke piya rūpam sāta rūpam ettha īsā  taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati ettha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati iti
translated: just as the world is pointed out by the term “world” in dependence on the eye, etc., in the passage: “In the world, bhikkhus, the eye is called the world. In the world the eye is called the world” .

original: Gamanenāti pākatikagamanena. Lokassantoti saṅkhāralokassa anto antakiriyāya hetubhūtaṃ
analyzed: gamanena ati pākatika gamanena lokassa antaḥ ti saṅkhāra lokassa antaḥ anta kiriyāya hetu bhūtam
translated: By going: by ordinary going. The world’s end: the cause for the ending of the world of formations.

original: nibbānaṃ. Kudācananti kadācipi. Appatvāti aggamaggena anadhigantvā. Pamocananti pamutti🔽nissaraṇaṃ. Tasmāti yasmā lokantaṃ appatvā vaṭṭadukkhato mutti natthi, tasmā. Haveti
analyzed: nibbānam kudācana nti ap patvā ati aggamaggena an adhigantvā pamocana nti pamutti  nissaraṇam tasmā iti yasmai ap patvā vaṭṭa dukkhataḥ mutti natthi tasmai hava iti
translated: Nibbana. Kudacani: at any time. Appatva: without having reached. Pamocan: the deliverance, the escape. Tasmati: because. Have:🔽

original: nipātamattaṃ. Lokavidūti sabhāvādito sabbaṃ lokaṃ vijānanto. Sumedhoti sundarapañño.🔽Lokantagūti pariññābhisamayena lokaṃ viditvā pahānābhisamayena lokantagū.
