Maggabrahmacariyassa🔽pariniṭṭhitattā vusitabrahmacariyo. Sabbesaṃ kilesānaṃ samitattā catusaccadhammānaṃ🔽vā abhisamitattā samitāvī. Nāsīsatīti na pattheti, yathā imaṃ lokaṃ, evaṃ parañca
analyzed: nipāta mattam loka vidū iti sabhā vāditaḥ sabbam lokam vijānantaḥ sumedhaḥ iti sundara pañño  lokantagū ti pariññā abhisamayena lokam viditvā pahāna abhisamayena lokantagū magga brahmacariyassa  pariniṭṭhita ttā vusita brahmacariyaḥ sabbesam kilesānam samita ttā catu sacca dhammānam  vai abhisamitattā samitāvī na āsīsati iti na yathā imam lokam evam parañca
translated: Nibbana. Kudacani: at any time. Appatva: without having reached by the path to its culmination. Pamocananti: the deliverance, the escape. Tasmā: because there is no deliverance from the suffering of the round without reaching the end of the world. Have: is merely a particle. Lokavidu: the one who knows the world in all its modes. Sumedha: of beautiful wisdom.

original: lokaṃ nāsīsati appaṭisandhikattā.
analyzed: lokam na āsīsati appaṭisandhika ttā
translated: Lokantagū: the one who has gone to the end of the world by the end-making knowledge of abandoning after knowing the world by the end-making knowledge of full understanding. Vusitabrahmacariyo: the one who has lived the life of purity because he has completed the path to purity. Samitavī: the one who has burned up the defilements or who has burned up the four noble truths. Nāsīsati: does not long for. As for this world, so for the other world, he does not long for it because he does not form any kamma that would lead to rebirth.

original: Evaṃ yadipi lokavidutā anavasesato dassitā sabhāvādito dassitattā, loko pana ekadeseneva
analyzed: evam yadi pi loka vidu tā anavasesataḥ dassitā sabhāva āditaḥ dassita ttā loko pana eka desena iva
translated: Thus, although the knowledge of the world has been shown without remainder, the world has been shown only in part

original: vuttoti taṃ anavasesato dassetuṃ “api ca tayo lokā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha indriyabaddhānaṃ🔽khandhānaṃ samūho santāno ca sattaloko. Rūpādīsu sattavisattatāya satto, lokīyati🔽ettha kusalākusalaṃ tabbipāko cāti loko. Anindriyabaddhānaṃ rūpādīnaṃ samūho santāno🔽ca okāsaloko lokīyanti ettha jaṅgamā thāvarā ca tesañca okāsabhūtoti katvā. Tadādhāratāya
analyzed: vuttaḥ ti tam anavasesataḥ dassetum api ca tayo lokā ti ādi vuttam tattha indriya baddhānam  khandhānam samūhaḥ santāno ca satta lokaḥ rūpa ādīsu satta visatta tāya sattaḥ lokīyati  ettha kusala akusalam tad vipākaḥ ca ati lokaḥ anindriya baddhānam rūpa ādīnam samūhaḥ santāno  ca okāsa lokaḥ ettha jaṅgamā thāvarā ca tesam ca okāsa bhūtā iti katvā tad ādhāra tāya
translated: In order to show that without exception, he said, “Furthermore, the world is threefold. ” Herein, the collection and continuity of aggregates bound up with faculties is the world of beings. It is a being because of the seven or twenty kinds of beings, and it is a world because good and bad and the result of good and bad are found here. The collection and continuity of materiality, etc., not bound up with faculties is the world of the physical basis. It is a world because the moving and unmoving creatures are found here. And it is a world because it is the physical basis for those beings.🔽

original: hesa “bhājanaloko”tipi vuccati. Ubhayepi khandhā saṅkhāraloko paccayehi saṅkharīyanti🔽lujjanti palujjanti cāti. Āhāraṭṭhitikāti paccayaṭṭhitikā, paccayāyattavuttikāti🔽attho. Paccayattho hettha āhārasaddo “ayamāhāro anuppannassa vā kāmacchandassa uppādāyā”tiādīsu
analyzed: hesa bhājana lokaḥ ti pi vuccati ubhaye pi khandhā saṅkhāra lokaḥ paccayehi saṅkharīyanti 🔽lujjanti palujjanti ca ati āhāra ṭṭhitikā ati paccaya ṭṭhitikā paccaya āyatta vuttikā ati 🔽atthaḥ paccaya tthaḥ ha ittha āhāra saddaḥ ayam āhāraḥ anuppannassa vā kāmacchandassa uppādāya ati ādīsu
translated: In order to show that without exception, he said, “Moreover, the three worlds are … .” Herein, the collection and continuity of aggregates bound up with faculties is the world of beings. It is a being because it is made up of seven or seventeen kinds of material and immaterial states. It is a world because profitable and unprofitable kamma and their results occur here. The collection and continuity of the material states not bound up with faculties is the world of the physical basis. It is a world because the moving and unmoving creatures occur here. Or alternatively, it is a world because it is the physical basis for those beings. It is called the “receptacle world” because it is the support for that. Both kinds of aggregates are the world of formations because they are formed and broken up and fall to pieces through conditions. “It is maintained by nutriment” : it is maintained by conditions. The meaning is that it exists dependent on conditions. Here the word “nutriment” has the meaning of condition, as in the passage: “This nutriment is a condition for the arising of unarisen greed” , and so on.

original: viya. Evañhi “sabbe sattā”ti iminā asaññasattāpi pariggahitā honti. Sā panāyaṃ āhāraṭṭhitikatā
analyzed: viya evam hi sabbe sattā ti iminā asañña sattā api pariggahitāḥ honti sā pana ayam āhāra ṭṭhitika tā
translated: for in this way the “all beings” includes the non-percipient beings too.

original: nippariyāyato saṅkhāradhammo, na sattadhammoti āha “āhāraṭṭhitikāti āgataṭṭhāne saṅkhāraloko veditabbo”ti.
analyzed: nippariyāyataḥ saṅkhāra dhammaḥ na satta dhammaḥ ti āha āhāra ṭṭhitikā ati āgata ṭṭhāne saṅkhāra loko veditabbo ti
translated: This “maintenance by nutriment” is a state of things that is a formation, not a living being, in the ultimate sense. That is why it is said: “The world of formations should be understood in the place where ‘maintenance by nutriment’ occurs” .

original: Yadi evaṃ “sabbe sattā”ti idaṃ kathanti? Puggalādhiṭṭhānadesanāti nāyaṃ doso. Kasmā
analyzed: yadi evam sabbe sattā ati idam kathanti puggala adhiṭṭhāna desanā ati na ayam doso kasmā
translated: If that is so, why is it said, “All beings”?—There is no fault here, since the teaching is given with reference to persons.

original: pana bhagavā katthaci puggalādhiṭṭhānaṃ katvā dhammaṃ deseti, katthaci dhammādhiṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: pana bhagavā katthaci puggala adhiṭṭhānam katvā dhammam deseti katthaci dhamma adhiṭṭhānam
translated: But why does the Exalted One sometimes teach the Dhamma with reference to persons and sometimes with reference to things?

original: katvā dhammaṃ desetīti? Desanāvilāsato veneyyajjhāsayato ca. Desanāvilāsappattā hi
analyzed: katvā dhammam deseti iti desanā vilāsataḥ veneyya jjhāsayataḥ ca desanā vilāsa pattā hi
translated: He does so in order to display the variety of teaching methods and in order to suit the inclinations of those to be trained.🔽For the Exalted Buddhas, who have attained the variety of teaching methods,

original: buddhā bhagavanto, te yathāruci katthaci puggalādhiṭṭhānaṃ katvā katthaci dhammādhiṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: buddhāḥ bhagavanto te yathāruci katthaci puggala adhiṭṭhānam katvā katthaci dhamma adhiṭṭhānam
translated: teach the Dhamma sometimes with reference to persons and sometimes with reference to things, according to their inclination.

original: katvā dhammaṃ desenti. Ye vā pana veneyyā sāsanakkamaṃ anotiṇṇā, tesaṃ puggalādhiṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: katvā dhammaṃ desenti ye vā pana veneyyā sāsana kkamam a notiṇṇā tesam puggala adhiṭṭhānam
translated: Or else, those to be trained who have not yet crossed the threshold of the Dispensation are taught with reference to persons.

original: desanaṃ desenti. Ye ca otiṇṇā, tesaṃ dhammādhiṭṭhānaṃ. Sammutisaccavisayā puggalādhiṭṭhānā🔽desanā, itarā paramatthasaccavisayā. Purimā karuṇānukūlā, itarā paññānukūlā. Saddhānusārīgottānaṃ🔽vā purimā. Te hi puggalappamāṇikā, pacchimā dhammānusārīgottānaṃ. Saddhācaritatāya🔽vā lokādhipatīnaṃ vasena puggalādhiṭṭhānā, paññācaritatāya dhammādhipatīnaṃ vasena
analyzed: desanam desenti ye ca otiṇṇā tesam dhamma adhiṭṭhānam sammuti sacca visayā puggala adhiṭṭhānā  desanā itarā paramattha sacca visayā purimā karuṇā anukūlā itarā paññā anukūlā saddhā anusārīga uttānam  vā purimā te hi puggala ppamāṇikā pacchimā dhamma anusārīga uttānam saddhā carita tāya  vā loka adhipatīnam vasena puggala adhiṭṭhānā paññā carita tāya dhamma adhipatīnam vasena
translated: and the teaching of the Truths is the footing for those who have entered upon the way. The teaching with the individual as its ground has the conventional truth for its domain,🔽the other has the ultimate truth for its domain. The former is favourable to compassion, the other to understanding. Or the former is for those who are followers by faith,🔽the latter for those who are followers by understanding. Or the former is for those who are of the type that gauges the individual, the latter for those who are of the type that gauges the True Idea.🔽Or the former is for those whose temperament is faith, the latter for those whose temperament is understanding. Or the former is in the mode of the world-regent type, the latter in the mode of the Truth-finder type.

original: veditabbo”ti. Yāvatā candimasūriyā pariharantīti yattake ṭhāne candimasūriyā parivattanti

translated: As far as the sun and moon revolve: in as much a place as the sun and moon revolve

original: paribbhamanti. Disā bhanti virocamānāti tesaṃ paribbhamaneneva tā tā disā pabhassarā
analyzed: paribbhamanti disāḥ bhanti virocamānā ati tesam paribbhamanena iva tā tā disā pabhassarā
translated: and move around. The directions shine, shining brightly: by their moving around, those directions are bright

original: hutvā virocanti. Atha vā disāti upayogabahuvacanaṃ, tasmā sayaṃ virocamānā candimasūriyā
analyzed: hutvā virocanti atha vā upayoga bahuvacanam sayam virocamānā candima sūriyā
translated: and shine. Or else, “directions” is a plural of respect; thus the sun and moon, shining themselves,

original: yattakā disā bhanti sobhenti obhāsayantīti attho. Tāva sahassadhā lokoti tattakena🔽pamāṇena sahassappakāro okāsaloko, sahassalokadhātuyoti attho. “Tāvasahassavā”ti
analyzed: yattakāḥ disāḥ bhanti sobhenti obhāsayanti iti attho tāva sahassadhā loko ti tattakena  pamāṇena sahassa ppakāro okāsa loko sahassa lokadhātuyo ti attho tāva sahassavā ti
translated: shine, are beautiful, illuminate as much as the directions as there are. The meaning is: “as far as.”

original: vā pāṭho, tāva tattakaṃ sahassaṃ assa atthīti tāvasahassavā. Etthāti sahassalokadhātusaṅkhāte loke.
analyzed: vā tāva tattakam sahassam assa atthi iti ettha ati sahassa lokadhātu saṅkhāte loke
translated: The world system of a thousand worlds: the world system of a thousand worlds is of such a measure; the meaning is: a world system of a thousand worlds. “Tāvasahassavā” is another reading, which means: “he who has a thousand of such a measure.” Here: in the world system of a thousand worlds.

original: Tampīti tividhampi lokaṃ. Sabbathā avedīti sabbappakārato paṭivijjhi. Kathaṃ paṭivijjhīti
analyzed: tam pi iti tividham pi lokam sabbathā avedi iti sabba ppakārataḥ paṭivijjhi katham paṭivijjhi iti
translated: That too: the threefold world. I penetrated completely: I penetrated in every way. How did he penetrate?

original: āha “tathā hī”tiādi. Tathā hissāti imassa “sabbathā vidito”ti etena sambandho. Assāti
analyzed: āha tathā hi itiādi tathā hi ssa ati imassa sabbathā viditaḥ ti etena sambandho assa ati
translated: He says “Tathā hī” , etc. The meaning of “Tathā hī” is connected with “Sabbathā vidito” . “Assa” is

original: anena bhagavatā. Eko loko sabbe sattā āhāraṭṭhitikāti yāya puggalādhiṭṭhānāya kathāya
analyzed: anena bhagavatā ekaḥ lokaḥ sabbe sattā āhāra ṭṭhitikā ati yāya puggala adhiṭṭhānāya kathāya
translated: the Blessed One. “Eko loko” : in the discourse on the basis of the person,

original: sabbesaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ paccayāyattavuttitā vuttā, tāya sabbo saṅkhāraloko ekavidho
analyzed: sabbesam saṅkhārānam paccaya āyatta vutti tā vuttā tāya sabbaḥ saṅkhāra lokaḥ ekavidhaḥ
translated: which states that all formations exist in dependence on conditions, all the world of formations is of one kind,

original: pakārantarassa abhāvato. Dve lokātiādīsupi imināva nayena attho veditabbo. Nāmaggahaṇena🔽cettha nibbānassa aggahaṇaṃ tassa alokasabhāvattā. Nanu ca “āhāraṭṭhitikā”ti ettha🔽paccayāyattavuttitāya maggaphaladhammānampi lokatā āpajjatīti? Nāpajjati pariññeyyānaṃ
analyzed: pakāra antarassa abhāvataḥ dve loka ati ādīsu pi iminā ava nayena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ nāma ggahaṇena  ca ittha nibbānassa aggahaṇam tassa a loka sabhāva ttā nanu ca āhāra ṭṭhitikā ti ettha  paccaya āyatta vutti tāya magga phala dhammānam pi loka tā āpajjati iti na āpajjati pariññeyyānam
translated: because there is no other world. The meaning of “Dve lokā” , etc., should be understood in the same way. The non-grasping of nibbāna by the term “name”🔽is because nibbāna is not of the nature of light. But is it not the case that the states of the path and fruit are also included in the world by the statement “They exist in dependence on nutriment”

original: dukkhasaccadhammānaṃ idha lokoti adhippetattā. Atha vā na lujjati na palujjatīti
analyzed: dukkha sacca dhammānam idha loko ti adhippeta ttā atha vā na lujjati na palujjati iti
translated: because they exist in dependence on conditions? They are not included, because the world is intended here as the states of the truth of suffering, which are to be fully understood.🔽Or alternatively, that which is grasped does not exist in that way,

original: yo gahito tathā na hoti, so lokoti taṃgahaṇarahitānaṃ lokuttarānaṃ natthi lokatā.
analyzed: yaḥ gahito tathā na hoti so tad gahaṇa rahitānam lokuttarānam natthi loka tā
translated: and therefore the supramundane states, which are devoid of that grasping, are not the world.

original: Tisso vedanāti sukhadukkhaupekkhāvasena. Cattāro āhārāti kabaḷīkārāhāro phassāhāro
analyzed: tissaḥ vedanā ti sukha dukkha aupekkhā vasena cattāraḥ āhārāti kabaḷīkāra āhāro phassa āhāro
translated: “Three kinds of feeling”: pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant.

original: manosañcetanāhāro viññāṇāhāroti cattāro āhārā. Tattha kabaḷīkārāhāro ojaṭṭhamakaṃ
analyzed: manaḥ sañcetanā āhāraḥ viññāṇa āhāro ti cattāro āhārā tattha kabaḷīkāra āhāraḥ ojaṭṭhamakam
translated: “Four kinds of nutriment”: physical food, gross or subtle; contact; mental volition; and consciousness.🔽Herein, physical food is nutriment because it nourishes the octad-with-nutritive-essence.🔽Contact is nutriment because it nourishes the three kinds of feeling.

original: rūpaṃ āharatīti āhāro. Phasso tisso vedanā āharatīti āhāro. Manosañcetanā tīsu bhavesu
analyzed: rūpam āharati iti āhāro phasso tissaḥ vedanāḥ āharati iti āhāraḥ manaḥ sañcetanā tīsu bhavesu
translated: Mental volition is nutriment because it nourishes rebirth-linking in the three kinds of becoming.

original: paṭisandhiṃ āharatīti āhāro. Viññāṇaṃ paṭisandhikkhaṇe nāmarūpaṃ āharatīti āhāro.
analyzed: paṭisandhim āharati iti āhāraḥ viññāṇam paṭisandhi kkhaṇe nāma rūpam āharati iti āhāraḥ
translated: Consciousness is nutriment because it nourishes mentality-materiality at the moment of rebirth-linking.🔽The aggregates that are the objects of clinging are called “the aggregates as objects of clinging.”

original: Upādānānaṃ ārammaṇabhūtā khandhā upādānakkhandhā. Cha ajjhattikāni āyatanānīti cakkhāyatanādimanāyatanapariyantāni.🔽Satta viññāṇaṭṭhitiyoti nānattakāyā nānattasaññino, nānattakāyā ekattasaññino, ekattakāyā
analyzed: upādānānam ārammaṇa bhūtā khandhāḥ upādāna kkhandhāḥ cha ajjhattikāni āyatanāni iti cakkhāyatana ādi manāyatana pariyantāni  satta viññāṇa ṭṭhitiyaḥ ti nānatta kāyāḥ nānatta saññinaḥ nānatta kāyāḥ ekatta saññinaḥ ekatta kāyāḥ
translated: The six internal sense bases are the eye-base, etc., down to the mind-base.

original: nānattasaññino, ekattakāyā ekattasaññino, heṭṭhimā ca tayo āruppāti imā satta “viññāṇaṃ
analyzed: nānatta saññino ekatta kāyāḥ ekatta saññino heṭṭhimā ca tayo āruppā ti imā satta viññāṇaṃ
translated: The seven stations of consciousness are the four pericope-beginnings beginning, “Those beings called ‘ corporeal beings’ with multiplicity of body and multiplicity of perception” , and the three immaterial states.

original: tiṭṭhati etthāti viññāṇaṭṭhitiyo”ti vuccanti. Tattha nānattaṃ kāyo etesaṃ, nānatto
analyzed: tiṭṭhati ettha ati viññāṇa ṭṭhitiyaḥ vuccanti tattha nānattam kāyaḥ etesam nānattaḥ
translated: They are called stations of consciousness because consciousness stands on them. Herein, there are different bodies in these, thus they are different-bodied ;

original: vā kāyo etesanti nānattakāyā, nānattasaññā etesaṃ atthīti nānattasaññino. Iminā nayena
analyzed: vā kāyaḥ etesanti nānatta kāyāḥ nānatta saññāḥ etesam atthi iti nānatta saññinaḥ iminā nayena
translated: or they have different bodies, thus they are different-bodied. They have different perceptions, thus they are different-percipient.

original: sesapadesupi attho veditabbo.
analyzed: sesa padesu pi atthaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: The meaning should be understood in this way in each instance.

original: Sabbe manussā chakāmāvacarā ca devā ekacce ca vinipātikā “nānattakāyā nānattasaññino”ti🔽vuccanti. Aparimāṇesu hi cakkavāḷesu aparimāṇānaṃ manussānaṃ vaṇṇasaṇṭhānādivasena
analyzed: sabbe manussā cha kāmāvacarā ca devā ekacce ca vinipātikā nānatta kāyāḥ nānatta saññino ti  vuccanti aparimāṇesu hi cakkavāḷesu aparimāṇānam manussānam vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna ādi vasena
translated: All human beings and all deities of the sense-sphere and some beings in the lower realms are called “different-bodied and different-percipient.”🔽For there is no two beings alike among the infinite human beings in the infinite world-spheres,

original: dvepi ekasadisā natthi. Yepi katthaci yamakabhātaro vaṇṇena vā saṇṭhānena vā ekasadisā
analyzed: dve pi eka sadisāḥ natthi ye pi katthaci yamaka bhātaraḥ vaṇṇena vā saṇṭhānena vā eka sadisāḥ
translated: even twins are not alike in the way they look or in their character or in the timbre of their voices, and so on.

original: honti, tesampi ālokitavilokitakathitahasitagamanaṭhānādīhi viseso hotiyeva, paṭisandhisaññā
analyzed: honti tesam pi ālokita vilokita kathita hasita gamana ṭhāna ādīhi visesaḥ hotiyā iva paṭisandhi saññā
translated: And their rebirth-linking consciousnesses are of three kinds, namely, due to profitable, unprofitable, and functional action.

original: ca nesaṃ tihetukāpi duhetukāpi ahetukāpi hoti, tasmā sabbepi manussā nānattakāyā
analyzed: ca nesam ti hetukā api du hetukā api ahetukā api hoti tasmā sabbe pi manussā nānatta kāyā
translated: So all human beings are different-bodied and different-percipient.

translated: And among the gods of the sensual-sphere heaven some have a blue body, some a yellow one, and so on,

original: paṭisandhisaññā ca nesaṃ duhetukāpi tihetukāpi hoti, tasmā tepi nānattakāyā nānattasaññino.
analyzed: paṭisandhi saññā ca nesam du hetukā api ti hetukā api hoti tasmā te pi nānatta kāyāḥ nānatta saññinaḥ
translated: and their rebirth-linking perception is due to two causes or to three causes. That is why they too are various in body and various in perception.

analyzed: ekacce vinipātikā pana catu apāya vinimuttakā uttara mātā yakkhinī piyaṅkara mātā dhamma guttā ati

analyzed: evamādayaḥ daṭṭhabbāḥ etesam hi odātaka āḷam aṅgura chavi sāma vaṇṇa ādi vasena ca iva kisa thūla rassa dīgha ādi vasena
translated: For their bodies are various as to colour, such as white, black, crimson, pale, variegated, and so on, and as to shape, such as short, fat, tall, thin, and so on,

analyzed: ca kāyaḥ nānā hoti manussānam viya ti hetuka duhetuka ahetuka vasena paṭisandhi saññā api  te pana devāḥ viya na mahesakkhāḥ kapaṇa manussāḥ viya appesakkhāḥ dullabha ghāsa chādanāḥ

analyzed: sukha samussayataḥ vinipatita ttā sukha samussayataḥ vinipātaḥ etesam atthi iti vinipātikā ati  vuttā sati api deva bhāve dibba sampattiyāḥ abhāvataḥ ye pana ittha ti hetukā tesam dhamma abhisamayaḥ api

analyzed: hoti piyaṅkara mātā hi yakkhinī paccūsa samaye anuruddha therassa dhammam sajjhāyato sutvā
translated: and she said:🔽“Do not make a sound, Piyaṅkara,

original: “Mā saddaṃ kari piyaṅkara, bhikkhu dhammapadāni bhāsati;
analyzed: mā saddam kari piyaṅkara bhikkhu dhamma padāni bhāsati
translated: The bhikkhu is reciting Dhamma-words.🔽Besides, if we understand the Dhamma-words,
