analyzed: apica dhamma padam vijāniya paṭipajjema hitāya no siyā
translated: We might practice for our good.🔽“We will restrain ourselves from killing breathing things,

original: “Pāṇesu ca saṃyamāmase, sampajānamusā na bhaṇāmase;
analyzed: pāṇesu ca saṃyamāmase sampajāna musā na bhaṇāmase
translated: And we will not tell a conscious lie.🔽We will train ourselves in good conduct,

original: Sikkhema susīlyamattano, api muccema pisācayoniyā”ti. –
analyzed: sikkhema susīlya mattano api muccema pisāca yoniyā ati
translated: And we will escape from the ghost realm.”

original: Evaṃ puttakaṃ saññāpetvā taṃ divasaṃ sotāpattiphalaṃ pattā. Uttaramātā pana bhagavato
analyzed: evam puttakam saññāpetvā tam divasam sotāpatti phalam pattā uttara mātā pana bhagavataḥ
translated: Having thus instructed her son, she reached the fruit of stream-entry that same day. But Uttara’s mother, it seems, became a stream-enterer on hearing the Blessed One

original: dhammaṃ sutvāva sotāpannā jātā. Evamimepi kāyassa ceva paṭisandhisaññāya ca nānattā
analyzed: dhammam sutvā va sotāpannāḥ jātāḥ evam ime pi kāyassa ca iva paṭisandhi saññāya ca nānattā
translated: preach the Dhamma. So these beings, too, are different in body and in perception.

original: “nānattakāyā nānattasaññino”tveva saṅkhyaṃ gacchanti.🔽Brahmapārisajjabrahmapurohitamahābrahmasaṅkhātā pana hīnamajjhimapaṇītabhedabhinnena
analyzed: nānatta kāyāḥ nānatta saññinā uta eva saṅkhyam gacchanti  brahma pārisajja brahmapurohita mahābrahma saṅkhātā pana hīna majjhima paṇīta bheda bhinnena
translated: They are reckoned as “having different bodies and different perceptions.”

original: paṭhamajjhānena nibbattā brahmakāyikā ceva catūsu apāyesu sattā ca “nānattakāyā ekattasaññino”ti
analyzed: paṭhama jhānena nibbattā brahmakāyikā ca iva catūsu apāyesu sattā ca nānatta kāyāḥ ekatta saññino ti
translated: But those called the retinue of Brahmā, the ministers of Brahmā, and the great Brahmās, who are reborn in the first jhāna that is divided into inferior, medium, and superior, and also the beings in the four lower worlds, are called “having different bodies but the same perception.”

original: vuccanti. Etesu hi brahmakāyikesu brahmapurohitānaṃ kāyo brahmapārisajjehi pamāṇato
analyzed: vuccanti etesu hi brahmakāyikesu brahmapurohitānam kāyaḥ brahma pārisajjehi pamāṇataḥ
translated: For among these Brahmās, the bodies of the ministers of Brahmā are more vast in size than those of the retinue of Brahmā,

original: vipulataro hoti, mahābrahmānaṃ kāyo pana brahmapurohitehipi pamāṇato vipulataro hoti.🔽Kāmañca nesaṃ pabhāvasenapi kāyo heṭṭhimaheṭṭhimehi uḷārataro hoti, taṃ pana idha
analyzed: vipulataraḥ hoti mahābrahmānam vipulataraḥ hoti  kāyaḥ heṭṭhima heṭṭhimehi uḷārataraḥ hoti tam pana idha
translated: and the body of the great Brahmā is more vast than those of the ministers of Brahmā.🔽And, if it is wished, their bodies are more and more sublime in appearance than those below, but that is immeasurable here.

original: appamāṇaṃ. Tathā hi parittābhādīnaṃ parittasubhādīnañca kāye satipi pabhāvematte
analyzed: appamāṇam tathā hi paritta ābha ādīnam paritta subha ādīnam ca kāye
translated: For although the radiance of the Parittābhā, etc., and the Parittasubhā, etc., is only in their bodies,

original: ekattavaseneva vavatthapīyatīti “ekattakāyā”tveva te vuccanti. Evamime brahmakāyikā
analyzed: ekatta vasena iva vavatthapīyati iti ekatta kāyāḥ tu eva te vuccanti evam ime brahmakāyikā
translated: they are still defined only in terms of unity, thus they are called “having the same bodies.” So these Brahmās

original: kāyassa nānattā paṭhamajjhānavipākavasena pana paṭisandhisaññāya ca ekattā nānattakāyā
analyzed: kāyassa nānattā paṭhamajjhāna vipāka vasena pana paṭisandhi saññāya ca ekattā nānatta kāyā
translated: But because of the diversity of their bodies and the unity of their rebirth-linking perception in the fine-material sphere, they are “diverse in body but identical in perception. ”🔽And just as they are, so are beings in the four lower hells.

original: ekattasaññino. Yathā ca te, evaṃ catūsu apāyesu sattā. Nirayesu hi kesañci gāvutaṃ,
analyzed: ekatta saññinaḥ yathā ca te evam catūsu apāyesu sattāḥ nirayesu hi kesañci
translated: For in the hells some are a league high,

original: kesañci aḍḍhayojanaṃ, kesañci yojanaṃ attabhāvo hoti, devadattassa pana yojanasatiko
analyzed: kesañci aḍḍha yojanam kesañci yojanam atta bhāvaḥ hoti devadattassa pana yojana satiko
translated: some a half league, and some a league. But Devadatta was born a league high.

original: jāto. Tiracchānesupi keci khuddakā, keci mahantā, pettivisayepi keci saṭṭhihatthā,
analyzed: tiracchānesu pi keci khuddakā keci mahantā petti visaye pi keci
translated: And among animals some are small, some are big. Among ghosts some are sixty hands high,

original: keci asītihatthā honti, keci suvaṇṇā, keci dubbaṇṇā, tathā kālakañcikā asurā. Api🔽cettha dīghapiṭṭhikapetā nāma saṭṭhiyojanikāpi honti, paṭisandhisaññā pana sabbesampi
analyzed: keci asīti hatthāḥ honti keci suvaṇṇā keci dubbaṇṇā tathā kālakañcikāḥ asurāḥ api  ca ittha dīghapiṭṭhika petāḥ nāma saṭṭhi yojanikā api honti paṭisandhi saññā pana sabbesam pi
translated: some eighty. And some are fair, some are ugly, as are the Kālakañja asuras.🔽For the ghosts called “Long-ribbed” are sixty leagues high. But the rebirth-linking perception of all these beings is non-root-cause resultant of unprofitable kamma.

original: akusalavipākāhetukāva hoti. Iti āpāyikāpi “nānattakāyā ekattasaññino”tveva saṅkhyaṃ gacchanti.
analyzed: akusala vipākā ahetukā ava hoti iti āpāyikā api nānatta kāyāḥ ekatta saññinā utvā iva saṅkhyam gacchanti
translated: So those in states of loss are reckoned as “diverse in body but identical in perception. ”

original: Dutiyajjhānabhūmikā pana parittābhā appamāṇābhā ābhassarā “ekattakāyā nānattasaññino”ti
analyzed: dutiya jhāna bhūmikā pana paritta ābhā appamāṇa ābhā ābhassarāḥ ekatta kāyāḥ nānatta saññino ti
translated: But the Parittābhā, Appamāṇābhā, and Ābhassarā deities, who are in the plane of the second jhāna, are “identical in body but diverse in perception. ”

original: vuccanti. Nesañhi sabbesaṃ kāyo ekappamāṇova hoti, paṭisandhisaññā pana dutiyatatiyajjhānavipākavasena nānā hoti.
analyzed: vuccanti nesam hi sabbesam kāyo eka ppamāṇaḥ va hoti paṭisandhi saññā pana dutiya tatiya jhāna vipāka vasena nānā hoti
translated: For all of them the body is of the same size, but the rebirth-linking consciousness is different in the case of those of the second and third jhānas.

original: Parittasubhā appamāṇasubhā subhakiṇhā pana tatiyajjhānabhūmikā ekattakāyā ekattasaññino.
analyzed: paritta subhāḥ appamāṇa subhāḥ subha kiṇhāḥ pana tatiya jhāna bhūmikāḥ ekatta kāyāḥ ekatta saññino
translated: The Parittasubhas have limited beauty, the Appamāṇasubhas have immeasurable beauty, and the Subhakiṇhas have the beauty of the third jhāna. They have single bodies and single perceptions.

original: Tesaṃ vuttanayena kāyassa ceva catutthajjhānavipākavasena paṭisandhisaññāya ca ekattā.
analyzed: tesam vutta nayena kāyassa ca iva catuttha jhāna vipāka vasena paṭisandhi saññāya ca ekattā
translated: For them the body is the same in the way already stated, and the rebirth-linking consciousness is the same in being the result of the third jhāna.

original: “Vehapphalāpi imaṃyeva catutthaviññāṇaṭṭhitiṃ bhajanti kāyassa ceva pañcamajjhānavipākavasena🔽paṭisandhisaññāya ca ekarūpattā. Suddhāvāsā pana apunarāvattanato vivaṭṭapakkhe ṭhitā,
analyzed: vehapphalā api imam yeva catuttha viññāṇa ṭṭhitim bhajanti kāyassa ca iva pañcama jhāna vipāka vasena  paṭisandhi saññāya ca eka rūpa ttā suddhāvāsā pana a punar āvattanataḥ vivaṭṭa pakkhe ṭhitā
translated: The Vehapphalas have the same kind of body, for their rebirth-linking consciousness is the result of the fourth jhāna.

original: na sabbakālikā. Kappasatasahassampi asaṅkhyeyyampi buddhasuññe loke nuppajjanti,
analyzed: na sabba kālikā kappa sata sahassam pi asaṅkhyeyyam pi buddha suññe loke na uppajjanti
translated: But their perceptions are single because their rebirth-linking consciousness is of a single kind. The Suddhāvāsas are not always arising. They do not arise in a world system when it is empty of a Buddha,

original: soḷasakappasahassabbhantare buddhesu uppajjantesuyeva uppajjanti, dhammacakkappavattissa
analyzed: soḷasa kappa sahassa abbhantare buddhesu uppajjantesu yeva uppajjanti dhammacakka ppavattissa
translated: but they arise only when Buddhas have appeared in the sixteen inhabited world systems. They arise when the wheel of the Dhamma is set rolling.

original: bhagavato khandhāvāraṭṭhānasadisā honti, tasmā neva viññāṇaṭṭhitiṃ, na sattāvāsaṃ🔽bhajantī”ti vadanti. Mahāsīvatthero pana “na kho pana so sāriputta āvāso sulabharūpo,
analyzed: bhagavataḥ khandhāvāra ṭṭhāna sadisāḥ honti tasmā na iva viññāṇa ṭṭhitim na sattāvāsam  bhajanti iti vadanti mahāsīva theraḥ pana na kho pana so sāriputte āvāso sulabha rūpo
translated: They are like the Blessed One’s dwelling place in the Khandhâgiri Mountain, and therefore they do not belong to the station of beings or to the station of consciousness. ”

original: yo mayā anāvuṭṭhapubbo iminā dīghena addhunā aññatra suddhāvāsehi devehī”ti iminā
analyzed: yaḥ mayā an āvuṭṭha pubbaḥ iminā dīghena addhunā aññatra suddha āvāsehi devehi iti iminā
translated: But the Elder Mahāsīva says that the expression “a dwelling place where I have not dwelt before” in the passage, “Sāriputta, it is not easy to find a dwelling place where I have not dwelt before during this long stretch of time, except in the case of the gods of the Pure Abodes” ,

original: suttena “suddhāvāsāpi catutthaviññāṇaṭṭhitiṃ catutthasattāvāsaṃ bhajantī”ti vadati,
analyzed: suttena suddhāvāsā api catuttha viññāṇa ṭṭhitim catuttha sattā vāsam bhajanti iti vadati
translated: shows that the Pure Abodes belong to the fourth station of consciousness and to the fourth station of beings.

original: taṃ appaṭibāhiyattā suttassa anuññātaṃ. Tasmā asaññasattaṃ apanetvā parittasubhādīsu
analyzed: tam suttassa anuññātam tasmai asañña sattam apanetvā paritta subha ādīsu
translated: This statement is accepted because it cannot be refuted. Therefore, with the exception of the non-percipient beings, the beings in the nine abodes beginning with the Limited-Beauty Brahmās

original: akaniṭṭhapariyosānāsu navasu bhūmīsu sattā “ekattakāyā ekattasaññino”ti gahetabbā.
analyzed: akaniṭṭha pariyosānāsu navasu bhūmīsu sattāḥ ekatta kāyāḥ ekatta saññinaḥ ti gahetabbā
translated: should be included in the category of “those who are single in body and multiple in perception. ”🔽The non-percipient beings, however, do not belong to this category because they are devoid of consciousness.

original: Asaññasattā pana viññāṇābhāvā ettha saṅgahaṃ na gacchanti. Tathā hi anuppanne buddhe
analyzed: asañña sattā pana viññāṇa abhāvāḥ ettha saṅgaham na gacchanti tathā hi anuppanne buddhe
translated: For when the Buddha had not yet arisen,

original: titthāyatane pabbajitā vāyokasiṇe parikammaṃ katvā catutthajjhānaṃ nibbattetvā tato
analyzed: titthāyatane pabbajitā vāyokasiṇe parikammam katvā catuttha jjhānam nibbattetvā tatas
translated: some ascetics went forth into homelessness in the non-Buddhist religions and, after performing the preliminary work on the air kasiṇa, they produced the fourth jhāna.

original: vuṭṭhāya “dhī cittaṃ, dhī cittaṃ, cittassa nāma abhāvoyeva sādhu. Cittañhi nissāya
analyzed: vuṭṭhāya dhī cittam dhī cittam cittassa nāma sādhu cittam hi nissāya
translated: and on emerging he thinks, “Well done, mind, well done! It is good indeed that consciousness has disappeared.

original: vadhabandhādipaccayaṃ dukkhaṃ uppajjati, citte asati nattheta”nti khantiṃ ruciṃ uppādetvā
analyzed: vadha bandha ādi paccayam dukkham uppajjati citte asati nattha itanti khantim rucim uppādetvā
translated: For it is owing to consciousness that suffering comes to be. When there is no consciousness, suffering does not come to be.” He arouses desire to act and to practise in this way,

original: aparihīnajjhānā kālaṃ katvā rūpapaṭisandhivasena asaññabhave nibbattanti. Yo yassa
analyzed: a parihīna jjhānā kālam katvā rūpa paṭisandhi vasena asañña bhave nibbattanti yaḥ yassa
translated: and he is reborn in the non-percipient realm by means of a material rebirth-linking.

original: iriyāpatho manussaloke paṇihito ahosi, so tena iriyāpathena nibbattitvā pañca kappasatāni🔽ṭhito vā nisinno vā nipanno vā hoti. Evaṃ cittavirāgabhāvanāvasena tesaṃ tattha viññāṇuppatti🔽na hotīti viññāṇābhāvato viññāṇaṭṭhitiṃ te na bhajanti. Nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ pana
analyzed: iriyāpathaḥ manussa loke paṇihitaḥ ahosi saḥ tena iriyāpathena nibbattitvā pañca kappa satāni  ṭhitaḥ vā nisinnaḥ vā nipannaḥ vā hoti evam citta virāga bhāvanā vasena tesam tattha viññāṇa uppatti  na hoti iti viññāṇa abhāvataḥ viññāṇa ṭṭhitim te na bhajanti na ivasaññānāsaññāyatanam pana
translated: He is born in the posture in which he passed away in the human world, and he remains standing or sitting or lying down for five hundred eons.🔽Thus there is no rebirth-linking consciousness in this case, and so they do not frequent a station for consciousness.

original: yatheva saññāya, evaṃ viññāṇassapi sukhumattā viññāṇaṭṭhitīsu saṅgahaṃ na gacchati.
analyzed: yathā iva saññāyaḥ evam viññāṇassa api sukhuma tā viññāṇa ṭṭhitīsu saṅgaham na gacchati
translated: The base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, however, is not included among the stations for consciousness because consciousness is subtle there, as it is in perception.

original: Tañhi saññāya viya viññāṇassapi saṅkhārāvasesasukhumabhāvappattattā paribyattaviññāṇakiccābhāvato🔽neva viññāṇaṃ, na ca sabbaso aviññāṇaṃ hotīti nevaviññāṇā nāviññāṇaṃ, tasmā paripphuṭaviññāṇakiccavantīsu
analyzed: tat hi saññāya viya viññāṇassa api saṅkhāra avasesa sukhuma bhāva ppatta ttā paribyatta viññāṇa kicca abhāvato  na iva viññāṇam na ca sabbasas aviññāṇam hoti iti na ivaviññāṇāḥ na aviññāṇam tasmā paripphuṭa viññāṇa kiccavantīsu
translated: For it is neither consciousness nor not-consciousness, since it is like perception, and since it has reached the state of subtle residual formations, and since it is devoid of the function of manifest consciousness.🔽So it is neither consciousness nor not-consciousness. Therefore it is not included among the stations of consciousness that have the function of manifest consciousness.

original: viññāṇaṭṭhitīsu saṅgahaṃ na gacchati. Tasmā vinipātikehi saddhiṃ chakāmāvacaradevā🔽manussā ca nānattakāyā nānattasaññino, paṭhamajjhānabhūmikā apāyasattā ca nānattakāyā
analyzed: viññāṇa ṭṭhitīsu saṅgaham na gacchati tasmai vinipātikehi saddhim cha kāma avacara devā  manussā ca nānatta kāyā nānatta saññino paṭhama jhāna bhūmikā apāya sattā ca nānatta kāyā
translated: So the gods of the six sense-sphere heavenly worlds together with the fallen creatures,

original: ekattasaññino, dutiyajjhānabhūmikā ekattakāyā nānattasaññino, tatiyajjhānabhūmikā🔽asaññasattaṃ vajjetvā sesā catutthajjhānabhūmikā ca ekattakāyā ekattasaññinoti imā
analyzed: ekatta saññinaḥ dutiya jhāna bhūmikāḥ ekatta kāyāḥ nānatta saññinaḥ tatiya jhāna bhūmikāḥ  asaññasattam vajjetvā sesā catuttha jhāna bhūmikā ca ekatta kāyāḥ ekatta saññino ti imā
translated: and human beings, have different bodies and different perceptions; the beings in the sense-sphere worlds of the first jhāna have different bodies but the same perception; the beings in the sense-sphere worlds of the second jhāna have the same bodies but different perceptions;🔽and the beings in the sense-sphere worlds of the third jhāna and those in the fourth jhāna except the non-percipient beings have the same bodies and the same perceptions.

original: catasso viññāṇaṭṭhitiyo nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ vajjetvā ākāsānañcāyatanādiheṭṭhimāruppattayena
analyzed: catasso viññāṇa ṭṭhitiyaḥ nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam vajjetvā
translated: These are the four stations of consciousness. The base consisting of boundless space, etc., together with the non-percipient beings make

original: saddhiṃ “satta viññāṇaṭṭhitiyo”ti veditabbā.
analyzed: saddhim satta viññāṇa ṭṭhitiyaḥ ti veditabbā
translated: seven stations of consciousness.

original: Aṭṭha lokadhammāti lābho alābho yaso ayaso nindā pasaṃsā sukhaṃ dukkhanti ime aṭṭha
analyzed: aṭṭha loka dhammā ati lābhaḥ alābhaḥ yasaḥ ayasaḥ nindā pasaṃsā sukham dukkhanti ime aṭṭha
translated: The eight worldly ideas are gain, loss, fame, loss of fame, dispraise, praise, pleasure, and pain.

original: lokassa dhammattā lokadhammā. Ime hi sattalokassa avassaṃbhāvino dhammā, tasmā etehi
analyzed: lokassa dhamma ttā loka dhammāḥ ime hi satta lokassa avassaṃbhāvinaḥ dhammā tasmai etehi
translated: These are called worldly ideas because they are the ideas of the world.🔽These are ideas that are bound to occur in the world of beings, and so there is no being at all that is exempt from them.

original: vinimutto nāma koci satto natthi. Te hi aparāparaṃ kadāci lokaṃ anupatanti, kadāci🔽te loko ca anupatati. Vuttampi cetaṃ “aṭṭhime, bhikkhave, lokadhammā lokaṃ anuparivattanti,
analyzed: vinimuttaḥ nāma koci satto natthi te hi apara aparam kadāci lokam anupatanti kadāci  te lokaḥ ca anupatati vuttam pi ca itam aṭṭhime bhikkhave loka dhammā lokam anuparivattanti
translated: Sometimes they occur in the world in succession, and sometimes the world occurs in succession in them.🔽And this is said: “Bhikkhus, the eight worldly ideas revolve around the world, and the world revolves around these eight worldly ideas” .

original: loko ca aṭṭha lokadhamme anuparivattatī”ti. Ghāsacchādanādīnaṃ laddhi, tāni eva vā
analyzed: loko ca aṭṭha loka dhamme anuparivattati iti ghāsa chādana ādīnam tāni eva vā
translated: Gain is the acquisition of food, clothing, etc., or it is what is acquired.

original: laddhabbato lābho. Tadabhāvo alābho. Lābhaggahaṇena cettha tabbisayo anurodho gahito,
analyzed: laddhabbataḥ lābhaḥ tad abhāvaḥ alābhaḥ lābha ggahaṇena ca ittha tad visayaḥ anurodhaḥ gahitaḥ
translated: Loss is the absence of gain. And here, by the word “gain” its object, namely, approval, is included,

original: alābhaggahaṇena virodho. Evaṃ yasādīsupi tabbisayaanurodhavirodhānaṃ gahaṇaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: alābha ggahaṇena virodhaḥ evam yasa ādīsu pi tad visaya anurodha virodhānam gahaṇam veditabbam
translated: and by the word “loss” its object, namely, disapproval, is included. So too with fame, etc., where their objects, namely, approval and disapproval, should be understood as included.

original: Lābhe pana āgate alābho āgatoyeva hotīti lābho ca alābho ca vutto. Yasādīsupi eseva
analyzed: lābhe pana āgate alābhaḥ āgataḥ yeva hoti iti lābho ca alābho ca vutto yasa ādīsu pi esā iva
translated: But when gain has come, loss has come too, so “gain and loss” is said. And so with the rest.

original: nayo. Tathā ca lohite sati tadupaghātavasena pubbo viya lābhādīsu anurodhe sati alābhādīsu
analyzed: nayo tathā ca lohite sati tad upaghāta vasena pubbaḥ viya lābha ādīsu anurodhe sati alābha ādīsu
translated: and the method. And so, when there is blood, the body is as if it were full of pus, and when there is compliance with gain, etc., the body is as if it were full of excrement, because of the loss of the non-compliance with loss, etc.

original: virodho laddhāvasaro eva hoti.🔽Nava sattāvāsāti heṭṭhā vuttasattaviññāṇaṭṭhitiyo eva asaññasattacatutthāruppehi🔽saddhiṃ “nava sattāvāsā”ti vuccanti. Sattā āvasanti etesūti sattāvāsā, nānattakāyanānattasaññīādibhedā
analyzed: virodhaḥ laddha avasaraḥ eva hi iti  nava satta āvāsā ti heṭṭhā vutta satta viññāṇa ṭṭhitiyaḥ eva asañña satta catuttha āruppehi  saddhim nava sattāvāsā ati vuccanti sattāḥ āvasanti etesu iti sattāvāsāḥ nānatta kāya nānatta saññī ādi bhedā
translated: And so too, when there is blood, the putrescence, like the pus, gets an opportunity to spread when there is compliance with gain, etc., and so on with the rest.🔽Nine abodes of beings: the nine abodes of beings are the same as the nine abodes of beings stated above in the Description of the Aggregates .🔽The nine abodes of beings are so called because beings dwell in them.

original: sattanikāyā. Te hi sattanikāyā tappariyāpannānaṃ sattānaṃ tāya eva tappariyāpannatāya
analyzed: satta nikāyā te hi satta nikāyā tad pariyāpannānam sattānam tāya eva tad pariyāpanna tāya
translated: They are the nine kinds of beings classed according to the four jhānas in the four states of existence beginning with the base consisting of boundless space, and the four kinds of beings classed according to the four jhānas in the four divine abodes.

original: ādhāro viya vattabbataṃ arahanti samudāyādhāratāya avayavassa yathā “rukkhe sākhā”ti.
analyzed: ādhāraḥ viya vattabba tam arahanti samudāya ādhāra tāya avayavassa yathā rukkhe sākhā ati
translated: They are called abodes of beings because they are fit to be called abodes of beings that are included in them, as the base is fit to be called an abode of the parts that are included in it, like the parts of a tree.

original: Suddhāvāsānampi sattāvāsaggahaṇe kāraṇaṃ heṭṭhā vuttameva.
analyzed: suddhāvāsānam pi sattāvāsa ggahaṇe kāraṇam heṭṭhā vuttam eva
translated: The reason for the inclusion of the pure abodes among the abodes of beings has already been given .

original: Dasāyatanānīti arūpasabhāvaṃ manāyatanaṃ rūpārūpādimissakaṃ dhammāyatanañca ṭhapetvā
analyzed: dasa āyatanāni iti arūpa sabhāvam manāyatanam rūpa arūpa ādi missakam dhammāyatanañca ṭhapetvā
translated: Ten bases: the mind base and the mental-data base, omitting the immaterial form, and the form base consisting of the remaining kinds of form, that is, visible form, etc.,

original: kevalaṃ rūpadhammānaṃyeva vasena cakkhāyatanādayo pañca, rūpāyatanādayo pañcāti dasāyatanāni
analyzed: kevalam vasena cakkhu āyatana ādayo pañca rūpa āyatana ādayo pañca ati dasa āyatanāni
translated: The five beginning with the eye base are stated in terms of material dhammas only, and the five beginning with the visible-data base are stated in terms of material dhammas only.

original: vuttāni, manāyatanadhammāyatanehi pana saddhiṃ tāniyeva “dvādasāyatanānī”ti vuttāni.
analyzed: vuttāni manāyatana dhammāyatanehi pana saddhim tāniyā iva dvādasa āyatanāni iti vuttāni
translated: But with the addition of the mind base and mental-data base, they are called “twelve bases.”🔽But why are the eye, etc., called “bases”?

original: Kasmā panettha cakkhādayo “āyatanānī”ti vuccanti? Āyatanato āyānaṃ vā tananato āyatassa
analyzed: kasmā pana ittha cakkha ādayo āyatanāni iti vuccanti āyatanataḥ āyānam vā tananataḥ āyatassa
translated: Because of basing, or because of extending, or because of leading,🔽they are called “bases” .

original: ca nayanato āyatanāni. Cakkhurūpādīsu hi taṃtaṃdvārārammaṇā cittacetasikā dhammā
analyzed: ca nayanataḥ āyatanāni cakkhu rūpa ādīsu hi taṃ taṃ dvāra ārammaṇāḥ citta cetasikāḥ dhammāḥ
translated: For in the eye, visible data, etc., the dhammas of consciousness and its concomitants

original: sena sena anubhavanādinā kiccena āyatanti uṭṭhahanti ghaṭanti vāyamanti, te ca pana
analyzed: sena sena anubhavana ādinā kiccena āyatanti uṭṭhahanti ghaṭanti vāyamanti te ca pana
translated: extend, arise, occur, by means of the several kinds of function consisting of experiencing, etc.,

original: āyabhūte dhamme etāni tanonti vitthārenti, idañca anamatagge saṃsāre pavattaṃ ativiya
analyzed: āya bhūte dhamme etāni tanonti vitthārenti idam ca anamatagge saṃsāre pavattam ativiya
translated: and they extend the dhammas that are the bases, they spread them out,

original: āyataṃ saṃsāradukkhaṃ yāva na nivattati, tāva nayanti pavattayanti, tasmā “āyatanānī”ti
analyzed: āyatam saṃsāra dukkham yāva na nivattati tāva nayanti pavattayanti tasmai āyatanāni iti
translated: and they lead on, they cause to occur, this suffering of the round of rebirths, which is so long because it is beginningless, as long as it does not subside. That is why they are called “bases.”

original: vuccanti. Api ca nivāsaṭṭhānaṭṭhena ākaraṭṭhena samosaraṇaṭṭhena sañjātidesaṭṭhena
analyzed: vuccanti api ca nivāsa ṭṭhāna ṭṭhena ākara ṭṭhena samosaraṇa ṭṭhena sañjāti desa ṭṭhena
translated: Moreover, they are called “bases” in the sense of a place of abode, in the sense of a storehouse, in the sense of a meeting place, in the sense of a locality of birth,

original: kāraṇaṭṭhena ca āyatanāni. Tathā hi loke “issarāyatanaṃ vāsudevāyatana”ntiādīsu nivāsaṭṭhānaṃ🔽āyatananti vuccati. “Suvaṇṇāyatanaṃ rajatāyatana”ntiādīsu ākaro. Sāsane pana “manorame🔽āyatane, sevanti naṃ vihaṅgamā”tiādīsu samosaraṇaṭṭhānaṃ. “Dakkhiṇāpatho gunnaṃ āyatana”ntiādīsu
analyzed: kāraṇa ṭṭhena ca āyatanāni tathā hi loke issara āyatanam vāsudeva āyatana nti ādīsu nivāsa ṭṭhānam  āyatananti vuccati suvaṇṇa āyatanam rajata āyatana nti ādīsu ākaro sāsane pana manorame  āyatane sevanti nam vihaṅgamā tiādīsu samosaraṇa ṭṭhānam dakkhiṇāpathaḥ gunnam āyatana ntiādīsu
translated: And the bases are bases in the sense of cause. For in ordinary usage what is a place of dwelling is called a “base,”🔽as in such passages as “The base of the overlord,” “The base of Vāsudeva.” And in such passages as “The base of gold,” “The base of silver,” it is a form. In the scriptures, what is a place of meeting is called a “base,” as in the passage, “The birds frequent the base that is delightful” . And what is a place of origin is called a base, as in the passage, “The southern region is the base of the geese” .🔽🔽

original: sañjātideso. “Tatra tatreva sakkhibhabbataṃ pāpuṇāti sati satiāyatane”tiādīsu kāraṇaṃ🔽āyatananti vuccati. Cakkhuādīsu ca te te cittacetasikā dhammā nivasanti tadāyattavuttitāyāti
analyzed: tatra tatra iva sakkhibhabbatam pāpuṇāti sati sati āyatana iti ādīsu kāraṇam  āyatanam ti vuccati cakkhu ādīsu ca te te citta cetasikāḥ dhammāḥ nivasanti tad āyatta vutti tāya ati
translated: And the bases are so called in the sense of cause. For in ordinary usage what is a place of resort is called a “base” in such passages as “The king’s base” and “The Vāsudeva base” . And what is a form is called a “base” in such passages as “The gold base” and “The silver base” . And in the scriptures what is a place of resort is called a “base” in such passages as “The birds resort to the delightful base” . And what is a place of birth is called a “base” in such passages as “The southern region is the base of the geese” . And what is a cause is called a “base” in such passages as “He attains to the ability to be a witness , directly knowing and fathoming each base as it is” . And the eye, etc., are the place of resort of the various kinds of eye-consciousness, etc., because the latter occur in dependence on them.🔽So the eye, etc., are their place of resort. And they are the form of the eye, etc., because they are dependent on them and because they are their object.

original: cakkhādayo tesaṃ nivāsaṭṭhānaṃ. Cakkhādīsu ca te ākiṇṇā tannissitattā tadārammaṇattā🔽cāti cakkhādayova nesaṃ ākaro. Tattha tattha vatthudvārārammaṇavasena samosaraṇato
analyzed: cakkhu ādayo tesam nivāsa ṭṭhānam cakkhu ādīsu ca te ākiṇṇā tad nissita ttā tad ārammaṇa ttā 🔽ca ati cakkha ādayaḥ va na isam ākaro tattha tattha vatthu dvāra ārammaṇa vasena samosaraṇato
translated: So the eye, etc., are their form. And they are the place of resort of the various kinds of eye-consciousness, etc., because they are the resort of the latter in the sense of a basis, a door, and an object.

original: cakkhādayova nesaṃ samosaraṇaṭṭhānaṃ. Tannissayārammaṇabhāvena tattheva uppattito
analyzed: cakkha ādayo va nesam samosaraṇa ṭṭhānam tad nissaya ārammaṇa bhāvena tattha eva uppattito
translated: The eye, etc., are their meeting place because they arise there by way of being its support and object.🔽The eye, etc., are their birthplace because they arise there.

original: cakkhādayova nesaṃ sañjātideso. Cakkhādīnaṃ abhāve abhāvato cakkhādayova nesaṃ kāraṇanti
analyzed: cakkha ādayo uva na isam sañjā atideso cakkha ādīnam abhāve abhāvato cakkha ādayo uva na isam kāraṇanti
translated: The eye, etc., are their cause because they do not exist when the eye, etc., do not exist.

original: yathāvuttenatthena cakkhu ca taṃ āyatanañcāti cakkhāyatanaṃ. Evaṃ sesānipi.
analyzed: yathā vuttena atthena cakkhu ca tam āyatanam ca ati cakkhāyatanam evam sesāni pi
translated: Thus the eye is an āyatana in the sense stated. So too the rest.

original: Imāneva pana dvādasāyatanāni cakkhuviññāṇādichaviññāṇehi saddhiṃ aṭṭhārasa vidahanādito🔽“dhātuyo”ti vuccanti. Tathā hi cakkhādīsu ekeko dhammo yathāsambhavaṃ vidahati, dhīyate,
analyzed: imāni eva pana dvādasa āyatanāni cakkhu viññāṇa ādi cha viññāṇehi saddhim aṭṭhārasa vidahana āditaḥ  dhātuyaḥ ti vuccanti tathā hi cakkha ādīsu ekekaḥ dhammaḥ yathāsambhavam vidahati dhīyate
translated: These twelve bases together with the six kinds of consciousness beginning with eye-consciousness are called the eighteen elements .

original: vidhānaṃ, vidhīyate etāya, ettha vā dhīyatīti dhātūti vuccati. Lokiyā hi dhātuyo🔽kāraṇabhāvena vavatthitāva hutvā suvaṇṇarajatādidhātuyo viya suvaṇṇarajatādiṃ, anekappakāraṃ
analyzed: vidhānam vidhīyate etāya ettha vā dhīyati iti vuccati lokiyāḥ hi dhātuyaḥ  kāraṇa bhāvena hutvā suvaṇṇa rajata ādi dhātuyaḥ viya suvaṇṇa rajata ādim aneka ppakāram
translated: For each of the things beginning with the eye is called an element because it illuminates , is accumulated , is a kind of illumination , is illuminated , or is accumulated here .

original: saṃsāradukkhaṃ vidahanti, bhārahārehi ca bhāro viya sattehi dhīyanti dhārīyanti,
analyzed: saṃsāra dukkham vidahanti bhāra hārehi ca bhāraḥ viya sattehi dhīyanti dhārīyanti
translated: For mundane elements are distinguished by their function as causes, and like the elements earth, water, fire, and air, they illuminate various kinds of mundane suffering, and they are accumulated and borne by beings, like a load is borne by a beast of burden.

original: dukkhavidhānamattameva cetā avasavattanato. Etāhi ca kāraṇabhūtāhi saṃsāradukkhaṃ
analyzed: dukkha vidhāna mattam eva cetāḥ etāhi ca kāraṇa bhūtāhi saṃsāra dukkham
translated: And because of these reasons, the suffering of the round of rebirths

original: sattehi anuvidhīyati, tathāvihitañca taṃ etāsveva dhīyati ṭhapīyati, tasmā “dhātuyo”ti
analyzed: anuvidhīyati tathā vihitam ca tam etāsu eva dhīyati tasmā
translated: is distributed among beings, and it is distributed in them, is placed in them, in this way, thus they are called “elements” .

original: vuccanti. Api ca yathā titthiyānaṃ attā nāma sabhāvato natthi, na evametā, etā pana
analyzed: vuccanti api ca yathā titthiyānam attā nāma sabhāvataḥ natthi na evam etāḥ etā pana
translated: Besides, just as there is no such thing as a self in the sense of an individual essence in the views of the sectarians, so too these elements are not that;🔽but they are called elements because they each maintain their own individual essence.

original: attano sabhāvaṃ dhārentīti dhātuyo. Yathā ca loke vicittā haritālamanosilādayo selāvayavā
analyzed: sabhāvam dhārenti iti dhātuyaḥ yathā ca loke vicittāḥ haritāla manosila ādayaḥ sela avayavā
translated: And just as variegated pieces of ore such as red chalk, malachite, etc.,

original: “dhātuyo”ti vuccanti, evametāpi dhātuyo viya dhātuyo. Vicittā hetā ñāṇañeyyāvayavāti.
analyzed: dhātuyaḥ ti vuccanti evam etā api dhātuyaḥ viya dhātuyaḥ vicittāḥ hetāḥ ñāṇa ñeyya avayavā ti
translated: are called “elements” in the world, so too these elements are called elements in the same way as those are.

original: Yathā vā sarīrasaṅkhātassa samudāyassa avayavabhūtesu rasasoṇitādīsu aññamaññavisabhāgalakkhaṇaparicchinnesu
analyzed: yathā vā sarīra saṅkhātassa samudāyassa avayava bhūtesu rasa soṇita ādīsu aññamañña visabhāga lakkhaṇa paricchinnesu
translated: Or just as the term “element” is used for the various kinds of blood, phlegm, etc., which are distinguished by their specific characteristics as different from each other and are components of the body called the “organism,”

original: dhātusamaññā, evametesupi pañcakkhandhasaṅkhātassa attabhāvassa avayavesu dhātusamaññā
analyzed: dhātu samaññā evam etesu pi pañca kkhandha saṅkhātassa atta bhāvassa avayavesu dhātu samaññā
translated: so too the term “element” is used for these five aggregates, which are components of the individual existence called the “personality.”

original: veditabbā. Aññamaññavisabhāgalakkhaṇaparicchinnā hete cakkhādayoti. Api ca dhātūti🔽nijjīvamattassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Tathā hi bhagavā “chadhāturo ayaṃ bhikkhu puriso”tiādīsu
analyzed: veditabbāḥ añña mañña visabhāga lakkhaṇa paricchinnāḥ ha ite cakkha ādayaḥ ti api ca dhātu uti  nijjīva mattassa itam adhivacanam tathā hi bhagavā cha dhāturaḥ ayam bhikkhu purisa iti ādīsu
translated: and they should be recognized as such. For they are delimited by the individual essences of their respective dissimilar characteristics.🔽Again, dhātu is a term for mere life-faculty. For the Exalted One taught the dhātus with the purpose of removing the perception of a living being, as in the passage beginning, “Bhikkhu, this person is made up of six dhātus” .

original: jīvasaññāsamūhananatthaṃ dhātudesanamakāsi. Tasmā nijjīvaṭṭhenapi dhātuyoti vuccanti.
analyzed: jīva saññā samūhanana attham dhātu desanam akāsi tasmā nijjīva ṭṭhena api dhātuyo ti vuccanti
translated: Therefore they are called dhātus in the sense of being devoid of life.

original: Ettha ca “āhāraṭṭhitikā”ti paccayāyattavuttitāvacanena saṅkhārānaṃ aniccatā, tāya
analyzed: ettha ca āhāra ṭṭhitikā ati paccaya āyatta vutti tā vacanena saṅkhārānam anicca tā tāya
translated: And here the words “they are the condition for the maintenance of nutriment” show the impermanence of formations by the statement that they exist in dependence on conditions.

original: ca “yadaniccaṃ taṃ dukkhaṃ, yaṃ dukkhaṃ tadanattā”ti vacanato dukkhānattatā ca pakāsitā🔽hontīti tīṇipi sāmaññalakkhaṇāni gahitāni. Nāmanti cattāro arūpino khandhā, te ca🔽atthato phassādayo. Rūpanti bhūtupādāyarūpāni, tāni ca atthato pathavīādayoti aviseseneva
analyzed: ca yat aniccam tam dukkham yat dukkham tat anattā ati vacanataḥ dukkha anatta tā ca pakāsitā  honti iti sāmañña lakkhaṇāni gahitāni cattāro arūpino khandhā te ca  atthataḥ phassa ādayaḥ bhūta upādāya rūpāni tāni ca atthataḥ pathavī ādayaḥ ti avisesena iva
translated: And by that impermanence their suffering and their not-self are also shown, according to the rule, “What is impermanent is suffering; what is suffering is not-self.”🔽Thus the three general characteristics are included. “Mind-and-matter” : the four immaterial aggregates and the materiality aggregate. And they are, in fact, contact, etc., and the primary and derived materiality.

original: salakkhaṇato saṅkhārā gahitā. Taggahaṇeneva ye te savisesā kusalādayo hetuādayo ca,
analyzed: sa lakkhaṇato saṅkhārāḥ gahitā tad gahaṇena iva ye te sa visesā kusala ādayaḥ hetu ādayaḥ ca
translated: Without distinction they are included by the words “characterized by the three characteristics.” And by their inclusion, the wholesome, etc., and the causes, etc., which are distinguished in various ways, are also included.

original: tepi gahitā eva hontīti āha “iti ayaṃ saṅkhāralokopi sabbathā vidito”ti.
analyzed: te api gahitāḥ eva honti iti āha iti ayam saṅkhāra lokaḥ api sabbathā viditaḥ ti
translated: They are included in the world of formations.

original: Evaṃ saṅkhāralokassa sabbathā viditabhāvaṃ dassetvā idāni sattalokassapi sabbathā🔽viditabhāvaṃ dassento “yasmā panesā”tiādimāha. Tattha āsayaṃ jānātīti āgamma cittaṃ🔽seti etthāti āsayo migāsayo viya. Yathā migo gocarāya gantvā paccāgantvā tattheva
analyzed: evam saṅkhāra lokassa sabbathā vidita bhāvam dassetvā idāni satta lokassa api sabbathā  vidita bhāvam dassentaḥ yasmā pana isā ati ādim āha tattha āsayam jānāti iti āgamma cittam  sā iti ettha ati āsayaḥ miga āsayaḥ viya yathā migaḥ gocarāya gantvā paccā āgantvā tattha iva
translated: Having shown the world of formations to be fully understood, he now shows the world of beings to be fully understood too.

original: vanagahane sayatīti so tassa āsayo, evaṃ aññathā pavattitvāpi cittaṃ āgamma yattha
analyzed: vana gahane sayati iti so tassa āsayo evam aññathā pavattitvā api cittam āgamma yattha
translated: Herein, he knows the inclination: the mind rests having come to this, thus it is an inclination, like the lair of a deer. Just as a deer, having gone out to graze, returns to its lair in the jungle and rests there, so too, the mind, having occurred in various ways, is said to rest where it comes to.

original: seti, so tassa āsayoti vuccati. So pana sassatadiṭṭhiādivasena catubbidho. Vuttañca –
analyzed: sā iti saḥ tassa āsayo ti vuccati so pana sassata diṭṭhi ādi vasena catubbidhaḥ vuttam ca
translated: That is of four kinds as the eternalist view, the annihilationist view, the view that accords with what is, and the knowledge of what is. It is said:

original: “Sassatucchedadiṭṭhī ca, khanti cevānulomikā;
analyzed: ca khanti ca iva ānulomikā
translated: “The eternalist view, the annihilationist view,🔽The view that accords with what is, and the knowledge of what is:

original: Yathābhūtañca yaṃ ñāṇaṃ, etaṃ āsayasaddita”nti.
analyzed: yathābhūtam ca yam etam
translated: This is called the inclination.”

original: Tattha sabbadiṭṭhīnaṃ sassatucchedadiṭṭhīhi saṅgahitattā sabbepi diṭṭhigatikā sattā
analyzed: tattha sabba diṭṭhīnam sassatu cheda diṭṭhīhi saṅgahita ttā sabbe pi diṭṭhi gatikā sattā
translated: Herein, since all views are included in the eternalist view and the annihilationist view, all beings who are theorists are included in the four inclinations.

original: imā eva dve diṭṭhiyo sannissitā. Yathāha “dvayanissito khvāyaṃ kaccāna loko yebhuyyena
analyzed: imāḥ eva dve diṭṭhiyaḥ sannissitāḥ yathā āha dvaya nissitaḥ khvā ayam kaccāna lokaḥ yebhuyyena
translated: These two views are based on the two theories of eternalism and annihilationism. As it is said: “Kaccana, this world is generally based upon a duality,

original: atthitañceva natthitañcā”ti. Atthitāti hi sassataggāho adhippeto, natthitāti ucchedaggāho.🔽Ayaṃ tāva vaṭṭanissitānaṃ puthujjanānaṃ āsayo, vivaṭṭanissitānaṃ pana suddhasattānaṃ
analyzed: atthitañca iva na atthitañca ati atthita ati hi sassata ggāhaḥ adhippetaḥ na atthita ati uccheda ggāhaḥ  ayam tāva vaṭṭa nissitānam puthujjanānam āsayaḥ vivaṭṭa nissitānam pana suddha sattānam
translated: upon assertion and denial. ”1 For the theory of existence is intended to represent eternalism, and the theory of non-existence annihilationism.🔽This is the inclination of worldlings who are based on the round of rebirths. But the inclination of beings who are based on the cessation of the round is twofold:

original: anulomikā khanti yathābhūtañāṇanti duvidho āsayo. Tattha “anulomikā khanti vipassanāñāṇaṃ,
analyzed: anulomikā khanti yathā bhūta ñāṇanti duvidho āsayo tattha anulomikā khanti vipassanā ñāṇaṃ
translated: the inclination to conformity and the inclination to the knowledge of things as they really are. Herein, the inclination to conformity is insight knowledge,

original: yathābhūtañāṇaṃ pana maggañāṇa”nti sammohavinodaniyā vibhaṅgaṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: yathā bhūta ñāṇam pana magga ñāṇan ti sammohavinodaniyā vibhaṅga ṭṭhakathāyam vuttam
translated: and the knowledge of things as they really are is path knowledge. This is said in the Sammohavinodani commentary on the Vibhanga.

original: Taṃ catubbidhampi sattānaṃ āsayaṃ jānāti, jānanto ca tesaṃ diṭṭhigatānaṃ tesañca
analyzed: tam catubbidham pi sattānam āsayam jānāti jānanto ca tesam diṭṭhigatānam tesam ca
translated: He knows the inclination of beings in these four ways. And knowing it, he knows even the moment when the inclinations to the views and to the

original: ñāṇānaṃ appavattikkhaṇepi jānāti. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: ñāṇānam appavatti khaṇe pi jānāti vuttam ha etam
translated: knowledges do not occur. For this is said:

original: “Kāmaṃ sevantaññeva jānāti ‘ayaṃ puggalo kāmagaruko kāmāsayo kāmādhimutto’ti, kāmaṃ sevantaññeva jānāti ‘ayaṃ puggalo nekkhammagaruko nekkhammāsayo nekkhammādhimutto”’tiādi.
analyzed: kāmam sevantañca eva jānāti ayam puggalo kāma garukaḥ kāma āsayaḥ kāma adhimuttaḥ iti kāmam sevantañca eva jānāti ayam puggalo nekkhamma garukaḥ nekkhamma āsayaḥ nekkhamma adhimuttaḥ tiādi
translated: “He knows one who indulges in sense desires as one who is keen on sense desires, as one who is addicted to sense desires, as one who is bent on sense desires. He knows one who abstains from sense desires as one who is keen on renunciation, as one who is addicted to renunciation, as one who is bent on renunciation” .

original: Anusayaṃ jānātīti anu anu sayantīti anusayā, anurūpaṃ kāraṇaṃ labhitvā uppajjantīti🔽attho. Etena nesaṃ kāraṇalābhe uppajjanārahataṃ dasseti. Appahīnā hi kilesā kāraṇalābhe🔽sati uppajjanti. Ke pana te? Kāmarāgādayo satta anāgatā kilesā, atītā paccuppannā
analyzed: anusayam jānāti iti anu anu sayanti iti anusayāḥ anurūpam kāraṇam labhitvā uppajjanti iti  attho etena nesam kāraṇa lābhe uppajjana araha tam dasseti appahīnāḥ hi kilesā kāraṇa lābhe  sati uppajjanti ke pana te kāma rāga ādayaḥ satta anāgatā kilesā atītā paccuppannā
translated: He knows the underlying tendency : the underlying tendencies are so called because they lie underlying and because they lie in wait ; the meaning is that they arise when they get a suitable object.🔽This shows that they are ready to arise when they get a suitable object. For defilements that have not been abandoned arise when a suitable object is obtained.

original: ca taṃsabhāvattā tathā vuccanti. Na hi dhammānaṃ kālabhedena sabhāvabhedo atthi,
analyzed: ca tad sabhāva ttā tathā vuccanti na hi dhammānam kāla bhedena sabhāva bhedaḥ atthi
translated: But which are they? They are the seven future defilements beginning with greed for sense desires. The past and present ones are called that because they have that as their individual essence. For there is no difference in individual essence of states according to the division of time.

original: taṃ sattavidhaṃ anusayaṃ tassa tassa sattassa santāne paroparabhāvena pavattamānaṃ jānāti.
analyzed: tam sattavidham anusayam tassa tassa sattassa santāne para upara bhāvena pavattamānam jānāti
translated: He knows that sevenfold underlying tendency occurring in the continuity of such and such a person as superior or inferior.

original: Caritaṃ jānātīti ettha caritanti sucaritaduccaritaṃ. Tañhi vibhaṅge caritaniddese
analyzed: caritam jānāti iti ettha caritan ti su carita duccaritam tat hi vibhaṅge carita niddese
translated: He knows the way of behaviour : here the way of behaviour is good behaviour and bad behaviour. For that is called “the way of behaviour” in the Description of the Way of Behaviour in the Vibhaṅga:

original: niddiṭṭhaṃ. Atha vā caritanti cariyā veditabbā. Tā pana rāgadosamohasaddhābuddhivitakkavasena
analyzed: niddiṭṭham atha vā caritanti cariyā veditabbā tā pana rāga dosa moha saddhā buddhi vitakka vasena
translated: The kinds of temperament have been demonstrated. Or alternatively, “temperament” should be understood as “habit.” But that is of six kinds as being due to lust, hate, delusion, faith, understanding, and thinking.

original: cha mūlacariyā, tāsaṃ apariyanto antarabhedo, saṃsaggabhedo pana tesaṭṭhividho. Taṃ
analyzed: cha mūla cariyā tāsam a pariyantaḥ antara bhedo saṃsagga bhedo pana tesaṭṭhividho taṃ
translated: These are the six basic kinds of temperament. The analysis of them is infinite. But the analysis of them by association is of thirty-six kinds.

original: caritaṃ sabhāvato saṃkilesato vodānato samuṭṭhānato phalato nissandatoti evamādinā pakārena jānāti.
analyzed: caritam sabhāvataḥ saṃkilesataḥ vodānataḥ samuṭṭhānataḥ phalataḥ nissandato ti evamādinā pakārena jānāti
translated: He knows that temperament as to individual essence, as to defilement, as to cleansing, as to source, as to fruit, as to outcome, and so on.

original: Adhimuttiṃ jānātīti ettha adhimuttīti ajjhāsayadhātu. Sā duvidhā hīnādhimutti paṇītādhimuttīti.
analyzed: adhimuttim jānāti iti ettha adhimutti iti ajjhāsaya dhātu sā duvidhā hīna adhimutti paṇīta adhimutti iti
translated: As to “knowing the inclination”: the inclination is the element of underlying tendency. It is of two kinds as low and exalted.

original: Yāya hīnādhimuttikā sattā hīnādhimuttikeyeva sevanti, paṇītādhimuttikā ca paṇītādhimuttike
analyzed: hīna adhimuttikā sattā hīna adhimuttike iva sevanti paṇīta adhimuttikā ca paṇīta adhimuttike
translated: By means of the low inclination beings resort only to those of low inclination, and those of exalted inclination only to those of exalted inclination.

original: eva. Sace hi ācariyupajjhāyā na sīlavanto honti, saddhivihārikā sīlavanto honti,🔽te attano ācariyupajjhāyepi na upasaṅkamanti, attanā sadise sāruppabhikkhūyeva upasaṅkamanti.
analyzed: eva sace hi ācariya upajjhāyāḥ na sīlavantaḥ honti saddhivihārikā sīlavantaḥ honti 🔽te attano ācariya upajjhāye pi na upasaṅkamanti attanā sadise sāruppa bhikkhūyā iva upasaṅkamanti
translated: For if the teachers and preceptors are not virtuous, the pupils and disciples will not be virtuous either.🔽And if the pupils and disciples are virtuous, the teachers and preceptors will not be virtuous either.

original: Sace ācariyupajjhāyā sāruppabhikkhū, itare asāruppā, tepi na ācariyupajjhāye upasaṅkamanti,🔽attanā sadise hīnādhimuttike eva upasaṅkamanti. Tipiṭakacūḷābhayatthero kira nāgadīpe
analyzed: sace ācariya upajjhāyā sāruppa bhikkhū itare asāruppā te pi na ācariya upajjhāye upasaṅkamanti  attanā sadise hīna adhimuttike eva upasaṅkamanti tipiṭakacūḷābhaya theraḥ kira nāgadīpe
translated: If the preceptor and teacher are proper monks and the others are not, they do not approach the preceptor and teacher;🔽they approach those who are like themselves, who are of low aspiration. The Elder Tipiṭaka Cūḷa Abhaya, it seems, was going to the Island of the Nāgas to worship the Tooth Relic together with five hundred monks.

original: cetiyavandanāya pañcahi bhikkhusatehi saddhiṃ gacchanto ekasmiṃ gāme manussehi nimantito
analyzed: cetiya vandanāya pañcahi bhikkhu satehi saddhim gacchantaḥ ekasmin gāme manussehi nimantitaḥ
translated: On the way he was invited by people in a certain village.

original: therena ca saddhiṃ eko asāruppabhikkhu atthi, dhuravihārepi eko asāruppabhikkhu atthi,
analyzed: therena ca saddhim ekaḥ asāruppa bhikkhu atthi dhuravihāre pi ekaḥ asāruppa bhikkhu atthi
translated: There was a certain improper monk who came with the elder, and there was another improper monk in the monastery where they stayed overnight.

original: bhikkhusaṅghesu gāmaṃ osarantesu te ubho janā kiñcāpi āgantukena nevāsiko, nevāsikena🔽vā āgantuko na diṭṭhapubbo, evaṃ santepi ekato hutvā hasitvā hasitvā kathayamānā
analyzed: bhikkhu saṅghesu gāmam osarantesu te ubho janā kiñca api āgantukena nevāsikaḥ nevāsikena  vā āgantukaḥ na diṭṭha pubbaḥ evam sante pi ekatas hutvā hasitvā hasitvā kathayamānā
translated: When the monks went into the village, these two, though they had never seen each other before,

original: aṭṭhaṃsu. Thero disvā “sammāsambuddhena jānitvā dhātusaṃyuttaṃ kathita”nti āha. Evamayaṃ
analyzed: theraḥ disvā sammāsambuddhena jānitvā dhātu saṃyuttam kathitan ti āha evam ayam
translated: stood together laughing and talking. The elder saw them and said, “The Fully Enlightened One knew about this and said in the Discourse on Elements: ‘The world is led by what is seen’ .

original: hīnādhimuttikādīnaṃ aññamaññopasevanādiniyāmikā ajjhāsayadhātu ajjhāsayabhāvo adhimuttīti
analyzed: hīna adhimuttika ādīnam aññamañña upasevana ādi niyāmikā ajjhāsaya dhātu ajjhāsaya bhāvaḥ adhimutti iti
translated: ” So this is the state of being of the inclination of the underlying tendency to resort to what is low, etc., which is called “aspiration” .

original: vuccati, taṃ adhimuttiṃ jānāti. “Imassa adhimutti hīnā, imassa paṇītā. Tatthāpi imassa🔽mudu, imassa mudutarā, imassa mudutamā”tiādinā paṭivijjhati. Adhimuttiyā pana tikkhamudubhāvādiko
analyzed: vuccati tam adhimuttim jānāti imassa adhimutti hīnā imassa paṇītā tattha api imassa  mudu imassa mudutarā imassa mudutamā ti ādinā paṭivijjhati adhimuttiyā pana tikkha mudu bhāva ādiko
translated: He knows the inclination of the person’s mind. He knows whether it is low or lofty, and whether it is soft, softer, or softest. He penetrates it in this way. But the sharpness or dullness of the inclination, etc.,

original: indriyānaṃ tikkhamudubhāvādinā veditabbo.
analyzed: indriyānam tikkha mudu bhāva ādinā veditabbo
translated: he knows the inclination. “This inclination is low, this is high. There too this is soft, this is softer, this is softest.” He penetrates thus. But the keenness or dullness of the faculties should be understood as the keenness or dullness of the inclination.

original: Apparajakkheti paññāmaye akkhimhi appaṃ parittaṃ rāgadosamoharajaṃ etesanti apparajakkhā,
analyzed: apparajakkhā iti paññā maye akkhimhi appam parittam rāga dosa moha rajam etesanti apparajakkhā
translated: Of little dust: they have little dust, that is, little lust, hate and delusion, in the eye of understanding, which is made of understanding;

original: appaṃ vā rāgādirajaṃ etesanti apparajakkhā, anussadarāgādirajā sattā. Te apparajakkhe.🔽Mahārajakkheti etthāpi eseva nayo, ussadarāgādirajā mahārajakkhā. Jānātīti “imassa
analyzed: appam vā rāga ādi rajam etesanti apparajakkhāḥ anussada rāga ādi rajā sattā te apparajakkhe  mahārajakkhā iti ettha api esā iva nayaḥ ussada rāga ādi rajā mahārajakkhā jānāti iti imassa
translated: or they have little dust of lust, etc., in them, thus they are of little dust; they are beings with little dust of lust, etc.; he knows those of little dust.

original: rāgarajo appo, imassa dosarajo appo”tiādinā apparajakkhādike jānāti.
analyzed: rāga rajaḥ appaḥ imassa dosa rajaḥ appaḥ iti ādinā appa rajakkha ādike jānāti
translated: Of much dust: here too the same explanation applies; they are of much dust; he knows those of much dust thus: “In this one the dust of lust is slight, in this one the dust of hate is slight,” and so on.🔽Of keen faculties: he knows those endowed with keen faith, etc.

original: Tikkhindriyeti tikhiṇehi saddhādīhi indriyehi samannāgate. Mudindriyeti mudukehi
analyzed: tikkha indriya iti tikhiṇehi saddhā ādīhi indriyehi samannāgate mud indriya iti mudukehi
translated: Of dull faculties: he knows those endowed with dull faith, etc.

original: saddhādīhi indriyehi samannāgate. Ubhayatthāpi upanissayabhūtindriyāni adhippetāni.🔽Svākāreti sundarākāre, kalyāṇapakatike vivaṭṭajjhāsayeti attho. Yesaṃ vā āsayādayo
analyzed: saddhā ādīhi indriyehi samannāgate ubhayattha api upanissaya bhūti indriyāni adhippetāni  su ākāra iti sundara ākāre kalyāṇa pakatike vivaṭṭat hāsayā iti atthaḥ yesam vā āsaya ādayaḥ
translated: and endowed with the faculties of faith, etc. In both cases it is the faculties that are intended as the conditions.🔽“Of good disposition”: of beautiful disposition, of good nature, of open disposition is the meaning. Or alternatively,

original: ākārā koṭṭhāsā sundarā, te svākārā. Viparītā dvākārā. Suviññāpayeti sammattaniyāmaṃ
analyzed: ākārā koṭṭhāsā sundarā te su ākārā viparītā dvi ākārā su viññāpaya iti sammatta niyāmam
translated: those whose disposition, etc., are beautiful are of good disposition. The opposite kind are of bad disposition. “Easy to talk to”: easy to admonish, easy to teach, easy to talk to, easy to talk with, is the meaning.

original: viññāpetuṃ sukare saddhe paññavante ca, ye vā kathitaṃ kāraṇaṃ sallakkhenti, sukhena🔽sakkā honti viññāpetuṃ, te suviññāpayā. Viparītā duviññāpayā. Bhabbe abhabbeti ettha
analyzed: viññāpetum sukare saddhe paññavante ca ye vā kathitam kāraṇam sallakkhenti sukhena  sakkā honti viññāpetum te su viññāpayā viparītā du viññāpayā bhabbe a bhabbā iti ettha
translated: Or alternatively, those who understand the reason for what is said are easy to talk to, easy to admonish, easy to teach, easy to talk with,

original: ye ariyamaggappaṭivedhassa anucchavikā upanissayasampannā kammāvaraṇakilesāvaraṇavipākāvaraṇarahitā,
analyzed: ye ariya magga ppaṭivedhassa anucchavikā upanissaya sampannā kamma āvaraṇa kilesa āvaraṇa vipāka āvaraṇa rahitā
translated: because they can be talked with easily. The opposite kind are difficult to talk to. “Capable and incapable”: here those who are endowed with the conditions that are suitable for penetrating the noble path, who are free from the obscurations consisting in kamma, defilements, and kamma result,

original: te bhabbā. Viparītā abhabbā. Tasmāti yasmā bhagavā aparimāṇe satte āsayādito anavasesetvā
analyzed: te bhabbāḥ viparītāḥ abhabbā tasmā iti yasmai bhagavā aparimāṇe satte āsaya āditas an avasesetvā
translated: are capable. The opposite kind are incapable. “Therefore”: because the Exalted One knows without exception the dispositions, etc., of immeasurable beings,

original: jānāti, tasmā assa bhagavato sattalokopi sabbathā vidito.
analyzed: jānāti tasmai assa bhagavataḥ satta lokaḥ api sabbathā viditaḥ
translated: therefore the world of beings is also known in all ways by the Exalted One.

original: Nanu ca sattesu pamāṇādipi jānitabbo atthīti? Atthi, tassa pana jānanaṃ na nibbidāya
analyzed: nanu ca sattesu pamāṇa ādi api jānitabbaḥ atthi iti atthi tassa pana jānanam na nibbidāya
translated: But is it not necessary to know the measure of beings? It is necessary, but the knowing of that does not lead to dispassion,

original: virāgāya nirodhāyāti idha na gahitaṃ, bhagavato pana tampi suviditaṃ suvavatthāpitameva,
analyzed: virāgāya nirodhāya ati na gahitam bhagavataḥ pana tat su viditam
translated: to fading away of lust, to cessation, to peace, to direct knowledge, to enlightenment, to Nibbāna, thus it is not included here. But the Blessed One knows it well and has well investigated it,

original: payojanābhāvā desanaṃ nāruḷhaṃ. Tena vuttaṃ –🔽“Atha kho bhagavā parittaṃ nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsuṃ āropetvā bhikkhū āmantesi – ‘taṃ🔽kiṃ maññatha, bhikkhave, katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ yo vāyaṃ mayā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ
analyzed: payojana abhāvāḥ desanam na āruḷham tena vuttam  atha kho bhagavā parittam nakha sikhāyam paṃsum āropetvā bhikkhū āmantesi tam  kim maññatha bhikkhave katamam nu kho bahutaram yaḥ vā ayam mayā parittaḥ nakha sikhāyam
translated: but he has not expounded it because there is no purpose in doing so. Hence it was said:

original: paṃsu āropito, ayaṃ vā mahāpathavī”’tiādi.🔽Evaṃ sattalokassapi sabbathā viditabhāvaṃ dassetvā idāni okāsalokassapi tatheva viditabhāvaṃ
analyzed: āropitaḥ ayam vā mahā pathavī iti ādi  evam satta lokassa api sabbathā vidita bhāvam dassetvā idāni okāsa lokassa api tathā iva vidita bhāvam
translated: “Then the Blessed One took up a little bit of soil with his fingernail and addressed the bhikkhus thus: ‘Bhikkhus, what do you think, which is more: the little bit of soil that I have taken up with my fingernail or this great earth? ‘”

original: dassento āha “yathā ca sattaloko”tiādi. Okāsalokopi sabbathā viditoti sambandho.
analyzed: dassentaḥ āha yathā ca sattaloka uti ādi okāsa lokaḥ api sabbathā viditaḥ ti sambandho
translated: Having thus shown that he knows the world of beings in all ways, he now said, “And as the world of beings” in order to show that he knows the world of elements in all ways too. The construction is: “The world of elements is known in all ways by the Tathāgata.”

original: Cakkavāḷanti lokadhātu. Sā hi nemimaṇḍalasadisena cakkavāḷapabbatena samantato parikkhittattā
analyzed: cakkavāḷanti lokadhātu sā hi nemi maṇḍala sadisena cakkavāḷa pabbatena samantataḥ parikkhitta ttā
translated: The world-sphere is the world-system. For that is surrounded all around by the Cakkavāḷa mountain, which is like the rim of a wheel.

original: “cakkavāḷa”nti vuccati. Aḍḍhuḍḍhānīti upaḍḍhacatutthāni, tīṇi satāni paññāsañcāti
analyzed: cakkavāḷanti vuccati aḍḍhuḍḍhāni iti upaḍḍha catutthāni tīṇi satāni paññāsan ca ati
translated: “The world-sphere” is said. “The high mountains” are the three hundred and fifty.

original: attho. Nahutānīti dasasahassāni. Saṅkhātāti kathitā. Yasmā pathavī nāmāyaṃ tiriyaṃ
analyzed: attho nahutāni iti dasa sahassāni saṅkhātā ati kathitā yasmā pathavī nāma ayam tiriyam
translated: The meaning is: “ten thousand” is “many.” “The measure” is the description. Since this earth is

original: aparicchinnā, tasmā “ettakaṃ bahalattena, saṅkhātāyaṃ vasundharā”ti bahalatoyeva
analyzed: aparicchinnā tasmai ettakam vasundharā ati bahala toyā iva
translated: unbounded in extent, therefore the extent is described as “the measure of this earth-holding (sea) is just so much.”

original: paricchedo vutto. Nanu cakkavāḷapabbatehi taṃtaṃcakkavāḷapathavī paricchinnāti? Na🔽tadaññacakkavāḷapathaviyā ekābaddhabhāvato. Tiṇṇaṃ tiṇṇañhi pattānaṃ antarāḷasadise
analyzed: paricchedaḥ vuttaḥ nanu cakkavāḷa pabbatehi tat tat cakkavāḷa pathavī paricchinnā ati na  tad añña cakkavāḷa pathaviyāḥ eka ābaddha bhāvato tiṇṇam tiṇṇam hi pattānam antarāḷa sadise
translated: But is it not bounded by the world-sphere mountains and the world-sphere earth?

original: tiṇṇaṃ tiṇṇaṃ lokadhātūnaṃ antareyeva pathavī natthi lokantaranirayabhāvato, cakkavāḷapabbatānaṃ
analyzed: tiṇṇam tiṇṇam lokadhātūnam antareya iva pathavī natthi loka antara niraya bhāvato cakkavāḷa pabbatānam
translated: No, because it is not connected with the other world-sphere earth. For there is no earth between the three, three world-spheres,

original: pana cakkavāḷapabbatantarehi sambaddhaṭṭhāne pathavī ekābaddhāva, vivaṭṭakāle saṇṭhahamānāpi
analyzed: pana cakkavāḷa pabbata antarehi sambaddha ṭṭhāne pathavī vivaṭṭa kāle saṇṭhahamānā api
translated: like the space between the leaves of a palm-leaf. But the earth is connected in the places where the world-sphere mountains are connected with the world-sphere mountains,

original: pathavī yathāsaṇṭhitapathaviyā ekābaddhāva saṇṭhahati.
analyzed: pathavī yathā saṇṭhita pathaviyā eka ābaddhā ava saṇṭhahati
translated: and when the earth is settling at the time of world-reconstruction, it settles as if it were connected with the earth that has already settled.

original: Saṇṭhitīti heṭṭhā uparito cāti sabbaso ṭhiti. Evaṃ saṇṭhiteti evaṃ avaṭṭhite. Etthāti
analyzed: saṇṭhiti iti heṭṭhā uparitas ca ati sabbaso evam saṇṭhitā iti evam avaṭṭhite ettha ati
translated: ‘It is settled’: it is settled all round below and above. ‘Thus settled’: thus not unseated. ‘Here’:

original: cakkavāḷe. Ajjhogāḷhoti ogāhitvā anupavisitvā ṭhito. Accuggato tāvadevāti tattakameva
analyzed: cakkavāḷe ajjhogāḷhaḥ ti ogāhitvā anupavisitvā ṭhitaḥ accuggataḥ tāvat eva ati tattakam eva
translated: in the world-sphere. ‘Immersed’: having gone under, having penetrated, it stands. ‘Just so high’: just that much,

original: caturāsīti yojanasatasahassāniyeva uggato. Na kevalañcettha ubbedhova, atha kho āyāmavitthārāpissa
analyzed: caturāsīti yojana sata sahassāniyā iva uggataḥ na kevalam ca ittha ubbedhaḥ uva atha kho āyāma vitthārā api issa
translated: just eighty-four hundred thousand leagues. And not only is it so much in height, but also in length and breadth

original: tattakāyeva. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: tattakāya iva vuttam ha etam
translated: it is just that much. For this is said:

original: “Sineru, bhikkhave, pabbatarājā caturāsīti yojanasahassāni āyāmena, caturāsīti yojanasahassāni vitthārenā”ti.🔽Sinerupabbatuttamoti pabbatesu uttamo, pabbatoyeva vā uttamo pabbatuttamo, sinerusaṅkhāto
analyzed: sineru bhikkhave pabbata rājā caturāsīti yojana sahassāni āyāmena caturāsīti yojana sahassāni vitthārena ati  sineru pabbata uttamaḥ ti pabbatesu uttamaḥ pabbataḥ yā iva vai uttamaḥ pabbata uttamaḥ sineru saṅkhātaḥ
translated: ‘Bhikkhus, Sineru, the king of mountains, is eighty-four hundred thousand leagues long and eighty-four hundred thousand leagues broad’ .

original: pabbatuttamo sinerupabbatuttamo, sinerupabbatarājāti vuttaṃ hoti. Tassa ca pācīnapassaṃ
analyzed: pabbata uttamaḥ sineru pabbata uttamaḥ sineru pabbata rājā iti vuttam hoti tassa ca pācīnapassam
translated: ‘Sineru, the supreme mountain’: supreme among mountains, or supreme, the best, among mountains is ‘supreme mountain’. Sineru, which is called ‘the supreme mountain’, is ‘Sineru, the supreme mountain’. That is, ‘Sineru, the king of mountains’. And the eastern side of that

original: rajatamayaṃ, tasmā tassa pabhāya ajjhottharantiyā pācīnadisāya samuddodakaṃ khīraṃ
analyzed: rajata mayam tasmā tassa pabhāya ajjhottharantiyā pācīna disāya samudda udakam khīram
translated: is made of silver. Therefore, because it is covered by the radiance of that, the water of the ocean in the eastern direction appears as milk.

original: viya paññāyati. Dakkhiṇapassaṃ pana indanīlamaṇimayaṃ, tasmā dakkhiṇadisāya samuddodakaṃ🔽yebhuyyena nīlavaṇṇaṃ hutvā paññāyati, tathā ākāsaṃ. Pacchimapassaṃ phalikamayaṃ.🔽Uttarapassaṃ suvaṇṇamayaṃ. Cattāro samuddāpi sinerurasmīhi eva paricchinnā. Tathā
analyzed: viya paññāyati dakkhiṇa passam pana inda nīla maṇi mayam tasmā dakkhiṇa disāya samudda udakam  yebhuyyena nīla vaṇṇam hutvā paññāyati tathā ākāsam pacchima passam phalika mayam  uttara passam suvaṇṇa mayam cattāro samuddā api eva paricchinnā tathā
translated: And so the sky appears blue. The western side is made of crystal.🔽The northern side is made of gold. The four oceans are bounded by the mountains.

original: hi pubbadakkhiṇapassehi nikkhantā rajatamaṇirasmiyo ekato hutvā mahāsamuddapiṭṭhena🔽gantvā cakkavāḷapabbataṃ āhacca tiṭṭhanti, dakkhiṇapacchimapassehi nikkhantā maṇiphalikarasmiyo,
analyzed: hi pubba dakkhiṇa passehi nikkhantāḥ rajata maṇi rasmiyaḥ ekatas hutvā mahā samudda piṭṭhena  gantvā cakkavāḷa pabbatam āhacca tiṭṭhanti dakkhiṇa pacchima passehi nikkhantāḥ maṇi phalika rasmiyo
translated: For the rays of silver and gems that issue from the east and south meet together, and after going by the back of the ocean,🔽they stand touching the Cakkavāḷa mountain. The rays of gems and crystal that issue from the south and west,

original: pacchimuttarapassehi nikkhantā phalikasuvaṇṇarasmiyo, uttarapācīnapassehi nikkhantā
analyzed: pacchimuttara passehi nikkhantā phalika suvaṇṇa rasmiyaḥ uttara pācīna passehi nikkhantā
translated: the rays of crystal and gold that issue from the west and north,

original: suvaṇṇarajatarasmiyo ekato hutvā mahāsamuddapiṭṭhena gantvā cakkavāḷapabbataṃ āhacca
analyzed: suvaṇṇa rajata rasmiyaḥ ekatas hutvā mahā samudda piṭṭhena gantvā cakkavāḷa pabbatam āhacca
translated: and the rays of gold and silver that issue from the north and east meet together, and after going by the back of the ocean,

original: tiṭṭhanti, tāsaṃ rasmīnaṃ antaresu cattāro mahāsamuddā honti.
analyzed: tiṭṭhanti tāsam rasmīnam antaresu cattāraḥ mahā samuddāḥ honti
translated: they stand touching the Cakkavāḷa mountain. Between these rays are the four great oceans.

original: Tatoti sinerussa heṭṭhā upari ca vuttappamāṇato. Upaḍḍhupaḍḍhenāti upaḍḍhena upaḍḍhena.
analyzed: tatas ti sinerussa heṭṭhā upari ca vutta ppamāṇataḥ upaḍḍhupaḍḍhena ati upaḍḍhena upaḍḍhena
translated: ‘Beyond that’: beyond the extent stated for the lower and upper slopes of Sineru. ‘By a half each time’: by a half each time.

original: Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – dvācattālīsa yojanasahassāni samudde ajjhogāḷho tattakameva upari
analyzed: idam vuttam hoti dvācattālīsa yojana sahassāni samudde ajjhogāḷhaḥ tattakam eva upari
translated: What is meant is this. The ocean is forty-two thousand leagues in depth, and Yugandhara is forty-two thousand leagues in height above the ocean.

original: uggato yugandharapabbato, ekavīsati yojanasahassāni mahāsamudde ajjhogāḷho tattakameva
analyzed: uggataḥ yugandhara pabbataḥ ekavīsati yojana sahassāni mahā samudde ajjhogāḷho tattakam eva
translated: Iṣādhara is twenty-one thousand leagues in depth in the ocean and the same in height above it.

original: ca upari uggato īsadharo pabbatoti iminā nayena sesesupi upaḍḍhupaḍḍhappamāṇatā veditabbā.
analyzed: ca upari uggataḥ īsadharaḥ pabbato ti iminā nayena sesesu pi upaḍḍha upaḍḍha ppamāṇa tā veditabbā
translated: And so with the rest, each half the size of the one below it.

original: Yathā mahāsamuddo yāva cakkavāḷapādamūlā anupubbaninno, evaṃ yāva sinerupādamūlāti
analyzed: yathā mahā samuddaḥ yāva cakkavāḷa pāda mūlā anupubba ninnaḥ evam yāva sineru pāda mūlā ati
translated: Just as the ocean slopes gradually down to the bottom of the Cakkavāḷa, so it slopes gradually down to the bottom of Sineru.

original: heṭṭhā sineruppamāṇato upaḍḍhappamāṇopi yugandharapabbato pathaviyaṃ suppatiṭṭhito,🔽evaṃ īsadharādayopīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ “mahāsamuddo, bhikkhave, anupubbaninno
analyzed: heṭṭhā sineru ppamāṇataḥ upaḍḍha ppamāṇaḥ api yugandhara pabbataḥ pathaviyam su patiṭṭhitaḥ  evam īsadhara ādayaḥ api iti daṭṭhabbam vuttam ha etam mahā samuddaḥ bhikkhave anupubba ninnaḥ
translated: Yugandhara, which is half the size of Sineru, is well established on the earth.🔽And so are Iṣādhara and the rest. For this is said: ‘Bhikkhus, the ocean slopes gradually, inclines gradually, tends gradually downwards, does not plunge precipitately’ .

original: anupubbapoṇo anupubbapabbhāro”ti. Sineruyugandharādīnaṃ antare sīdantarasamuddā nāma
analyzed: anupubba poṇaḥ anupubba pabbhāraḥ iti sineru yugandhara ādīnam antare sīdantara samuddāḥ nāma
translated: Between Sineru and Yugandhara, etc., there are the ‘intervening oceans’ .

original: honti. Tattha kira udakaṃ sukhumaṃ morapattamattampi pakkhittaṃ patiṭṭhātuṃ na sakkoti
analyzed: honti tattha kira udakam su khumam mora patta mattam pi pakkhittam patiṭṭhātum na sakkoti
translated: Herein, it seems, the water is so fine that even a leaf of a myrobalan fruit dropped into it does not stay afloat but sinks at once.

original: sīdateva, tasmā te sīdasamuddā nāma vuccanti. Te pana vitthārato yathākkamaṃ sineruādīnaṃ
analyzed: tasmā te sīdasamuddāḥ nāma vuccanti te pana vitthārataḥ yathākkamam
translated: So they are called “sinking seas.” They are, it is said, respectively the same in size as Sineru, etc., in breadth.

original: accuggamasamānapaamāṇāti vadanti. Ajjhogāḷhuggatāti ajjhogāḷhā ca uggatā ca. Brahāti mahantā.
analyzed: vadanti ajjhogāḷha uggatā ati ajjhogāḍhā ca uggatā ca mahantā
translated: Ajjhogāḷhuggatā means both deep and high. Brahā means great.

translated: Sinerussa samantato means all round Sineru, that is to say, surrounding it.🔽Yugandhara is situated surrounding Sineru. Īsadhara surrounds that.

original: parikkhipitvā ṭhito yugandharo, taṃ parikkhipitvā īsadharo. Evaṃ taṃ taṃ parikkhipitvā🔽ṭhitā “sinerussa samantato”ti vuttā. Katthaci pana “sineruṃ parikkhipitvā assakaṇṇo
analyzed: parikkhipitvā ṭhitaḥ yugandharaḥ tam parikkhipitvā īsadharaḥ evam tam tam parikkhipitvā  ṭhitā sinerussa samantataḥ ti vuttā katthaci pana sinerum parikkhipitvā assa kaṇṇaḥ
translated: And so with the rest, each surrounding the one next to Sineru.🔽That is why it is said, “All round Sineru.” But in some places the order is given as follows:

original: nāma pabbato patiṭṭhito, taṃ parikkhipitvā vinatako nāma pabbato”ti evaṃ aññoyeva
analyzed: nāma pabbato patiṭṭhitaḥ tam parikkhipitvā vinatakaḥ nāma pabbataḥ ti evam aññaḥ yeva
translated: Assakaṇṇa is situated surrounding Sineru. Vinataka is situated surrounding that.🔽And so with the rest, each surrounding the one next to Sineru.

original: anukkamo āgato. Tathā hi nimijātake –

translated: For in the Nimi Jātaka it is said:

analyzed: sahassa yuttam haya vāhim dibba yānam adhiṭṭhitaḥ
translated: “He mounted a celestial chariot Drawn by a thousand thoroughbreds,

analyzed: yāyamānaḥ mahā rājā addā sīdantare nage
translated: The Great King, while being led, saw the mountains in the middle of the ocean,

analyzed: sūtam ime ke nāma pabbatā ti
translated: and having seen, he addressed the charioteer, saying: “What are these mountains called?”

analyzed: evam nimi mahā rājena puṭṭhena mātali deva puttena
translated: Thus asked by the Great King, the Devaputta Mātali said:

analyzed: sudassanaḥ karavīkaḥ īsadharaḥ yugandharaḥ
translated: “Sudassana, Karavīka, Īsadhara, Yugandhara,

translated: Nemindhara, Vinataka, Assakaṇṇa, and the great mountain Brahmā.

analyzed: tesam pi antare ekaḥ sīdantara mahā samuddaḥ nemindharassa anantare vinatakaḥ nāma so  nemindharataḥ uccataraḥ tesam pi antare ekaḥ sīdantara mahā samuddaḥ vinatakassa anantare
translated: Between them is the ocean between the two. Next to the Nemindhara is the mountain called Vinataka, which is🔽higher than the Nemindhara. Between them is the ocean between the two. Next to the Vinataka is the mountain called

translated: These seven oceans and seven mountain-ranges are in a straight line, rising in pairs, like steps to the world of the gods.”

analyzed: yojanānam satān uccaḥ himavā pañca pabbatā iti himavā pabbataḥ pañca yojana satāni uccaḥ  ubbedhaḥ ti attho tattha himavanti hima pāta samaye hima yutta tāya himam assa atthi iti

analyzed: vatthūnam ca giraṇataḥ girī iti ca vuccati yojanānam sahassāni tīṇi  yojanānam tīṇi sahassāni āyāmato ca vitthārato ca ati attho āyāmato ca vitthārato
translated: It is three thousand leagues in height and breadth,🔽the meaning is, it is three thousand leagues in height and three thousand leagues in breadth.
