analyzed: katham adhigata nti kammaṭṭhānam pucchati tadā saḥ attanaḥ udāna byākaraṇa gātham bhāsati
translated: “How did you come to know?” he asks about the meditation subject. Then he recites his own verse of appreciative appreciation.

original: Evamidaṃ gandhamādanakūṭaṃ paccekabuddhānaṃ āvāsaṭṭhānaṃ hotīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: evam idam gandhamādanakūṭam paccekabuddhānam āvāsa ṭṭhānam hoti iti veditabbam
translated: So it should be understood that the peak of Gandhamādana is the abode of the Independent Buddhas.

original: Kelāsakūṭaṃ pana rajatamayaṃ. Sabbāni cetāni citrakūṭādīni sudassanena samānubbedhasaṇṭhānāni
analyzed: kelāsakūṭam pana rajata mayam sabbāni cetāni citrakūṭa ādīni sudassanena samānubbedha saṇṭhānāni
translated: But the peak of Kelāsa is made of silver. And all these peaks, Cittakūṭa and the rest, are like Sumanakūṭa in height and shape.

original: tameva saraṃ paṭicchādetvā ṭhitāni. Sabbāni pana puthulato paññāsayojanāni, āyāmato🔽pana ubbedhato viya dviyojanasatānevāti vadanti. Tāni sabbāni devānubhāvena nāgānubhāvena
analyzed: tam eva saram paṭicchādetvā ṭhitāni sabbāni pana puthulataḥ paññāsa yojanāni āyāmataḥ  pana ubbedhataḥ viya dvi yojana satāni eva ati vadanti tāni sabbāni deva anubhāvena nāga anubhāvena
translated: They stand enclosing that lake. But all of them are fifty leagues in breadth and🔽two hundred and fifty leagues in length, it is said.

original: ca ṭhassanti, nadiyo ca tesu sandanti, taṃ sabbampi udakaṃ anotattameva pavisati,
analyzed: ca nadiyaḥ ca tesu sandanti tam sabbam pi udakam anotattam eva pavisati
translated: But all of them stand by the power of the devas and the power of the nāgas. Rivers flow in them, and all that water drains away into the Anotatta Lake.

original: candimasūriyā dakkhiṇena vā uttarena vā gacchantā pabbatantarena tattha obhāsaṃ karonti,
analyzed: candima sūriyā dakkhiṇena vā uttarena vā gacchantā pabbata antarena tattha obhāsam karonti
translated: When the moon and sun go by the south or by the north, they illuminate there by the light of the mountain peaks.

original: ujuṃ gacchantā na karonti, tenevassa “anotatta”nti saṅkhā udapādi. Tattha ratanamayamanuññasopānasilātalāni
analyzed: ujum gacchantā na karonti tena iva assa saṅkhā udapādi tattha ratana maya manuñña sopāna silā talāni
translated: and so it came to be called Anotatta, “Unheated.” There are bathing places there with steps made of precious stones,

original: nimmacchakacchapāni phalikasadisanimmalūdakāni nhānatitthāni tadupabhogīsattānaṃ🔽sādhāraṇakammunāva suppaṭiyattāni susaṇṭhitāni honti, yesu buddhapaccekabuddhakhīṇāsavā
analyzed: nimmaccha kacchapāni phalika sadisa nimmala udakāni nhāna titthāni tad upabhogī sattānam  suppaṭiyattāni su saṇṭhitāni honti yesu buddha paccekabuddha khīṇa āsavā
translated: with no crocodiles or alligators, with water as smooth as a mirror, and the bathing places are well laid out and well arranged, being the common property of all who use them.

original: ca iddhimanto ca isayo nhāyanti, devayakkhādayo uyyānakīḷaṃ kīḷanti.🔽Tassa catūsu passesu sīhamukhaṃ hatthimukhaṃ assamukhaṃ usabhamukhanti cattāri mukhāni
analyzed: ca iddhimanto ca isayaḥ nhāyanti deva yakkha ādayaḥ uyyāna kīḷam kīḷanti  tassa catūsu passesu sīha mukham hatthi mukham assa mukham usabha mukhanti cattāri mukhāni
translated: Here Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, and disciples who have destroyed the corruptions bathe, and also devas, yakkhas, and so on, who enjoy supernormal power, and they make merry in the pleasure groves.

original: honti, yehi catasso nadiyo sandanti. Sīhamukhena nikkhantanadītīre sīhā bahutarā🔽honti, hatthimukhādīhi hatthiassausabhā. Puratthimadisato nikkhantanadī anotattaṃ
analyzed: honti yehi catasso nadiyaḥ sandanti sīha mukhena nikkhanta nadī tīre sīhāḥ bahutarā  honti hatthi mukha ādīhi hatthi assa usabhā puratthima disataḥ nikkhanta nadī anotattam
translated: It has four faces, an elephant’s, a horse’s, a bull’s, and a lion’s, from which four rivers flow. On the bank of the river flowing from the lion’s face lions are numerous,

original: tikkhattuṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā itarā tisso nadiyo anupagamma pācīnahimavanteneva amanussapathaṃ
analyzed: tikkhattum padakkhiṇam katvā itarāḥ tissaḥ nadiyaḥ an upagamma pācīna himavantena iva amanussa patham
translated: and so on. The river flowing from the east has three bends and does not go to the other three rivers but flows straight to the Himalayas by the way of the non-human beings’ path.

original: gantvā mahāsamuddaṃ pavisati. Pacchimadisato ca uttaradisato ca nikkhantanadiyopi
analyzed: gantvā mahā samuddam pavisati pacchima disatas ca uttara disatas ca nikkhanta nadiyo pi
translated: and after going, it enters the great ocean. Rivers flowing from the west and north

original: tatheva padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pacchimahimavanteneva uttarahimavanteneva ca amanussapathaṃ
analyzed: tathā iva padakkhiṇam katvā pacchima himavantena iva uttara himavantena iva ca amanussa patham
translated: after going round to the right, go by the southern and northern Himālaya mountains respectively,

original: gantvā mahāsamuddaṃ pavisanti. Dakkhiṇadisato nikkhantanadī pana taṃ tikkhattuṃ padakkhiṇaṃ🔽katvā dakkhiṇena ujukaṃ pāsāṇapiṭṭheneva saṭṭhi yojanāni gantvā pabbataṃ paharitvā
analyzed: gantvā mahā samuddam pavisanti dakkhiṇa disatas nikkhanta nadī pana tam tikkhattum padakkhiṇam  katvā dakkhiṇena ujukam pāsāṇa piṭṭhena iva saṭṭhi yojanāni gantvā pabbatam paharitvā
translated: and after going, they enter the great ocean. But the river flowing from the south, after going round to the right three times,🔽goes straight south by the rock-slab, and after going sixty leagues, it strikes the mountain,

original: vuṭṭhāya parikkhepena tigāvutappamāṇā udakadhārā hutvā ākāsena saṭṭhi yojanāni gantvā🔽tiyaggaḷe nāma pāsāṇe patitā, pāsāṇo udakadhārāvegena bhinno. Tattha paññāsayojanappamāṇā
analyzed: vuṭṭhāya parikkhepena udaka dhārāḥ hutvā ākāsena saṭṭhi yojanāni gantvā  tiyaggaḷe nāma pāsāṇe patitā pāsāṇaḥ udaka dhārā vegena bhinnaḥ tattha paññāsa yojana ppamāṇā
translated: and after emerging, it becomes a water-fall sixty leagues high, and after going through the sky,🔽it falls on a rock called Tiya-gaḷa, and the rock is split by the force of the water-fall. There a great lotus-pond called Tiya-gaḷa is formed, fifty leagues in extent,

original: tiyaggaḷā nāma mahāpokkharaṇī jātā, mahāpokkharaṇiyā kūlaṃ bhinditvā pāsāṇaṃ pavisitvā
analyzed: tiyaggaḷā nāma mahā pokkharaṇī jātā mahā pokkharaṇiyā kūlam bhinditvā pāsāṇam pavisitvā
translated: and after splitting the bank of the great lotus-pond, it enters the rock,

original: saṭṭhi yojanāni gatā, tato ghanapathaviṃ bhinditvā umaṅgena saṭṭhi yojanāni gantvā
analyzed: saṭṭhi yojanāni gatā tatas ghana pathavim bhinditvā umaṅgena saṭṭhi yojanāni gantvā
translated: and after going sixty leagues, it splits the solid earth, and after going sixty leagues with the current of the river,

original: viñjhaṃ nāma tiracchānapabbataṃ paharitvā hatthatale pañcaṅgulisadisā pañcadhārā
analyzed: viñjham nāma tiracchāna pabbatam paharitvā hattha tale pañca aṅguli sadisā pañca dhārā
translated: The stream called Viñjha, after striking the mountain called Tiriya, flows in five streams like the five fingers of a hand.

original: hutvā pavattati. Sā tikkhattuṃ anotattaṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā gataṭṭhāne “āvaṭṭagaṅgā”ti
analyzed: hutvā pavattati sā tikkhattum anotattam padakkhiṇam katvā gata ṭṭhāne āvaṭṭagaṅgā ati
translated: After going round the Anotatta Lake three times to the right, the stream called Āvaṭṭa flows out from the place where it entered.

original: vuccati, ujukaṃ pāsāṇapiṭṭhena saṭṭhi yojanāni gataṭṭhāne “kaṇhagaṅgā”ti, ākāsena
analyzed: vuccati ujukam pāsāṇa piṭṭhena saṭṭhi yojanāni gata ṭṭhāne kaṇhagaṅgā ti ākāsena
translated: The stream called Kaṇha flows in a straight line for sixty leagues on the surface of the rock.🔽The stream called Ākāsa flows for sixty leagues through the air.

original: saṭṭhi yojanāni gataṭṭhāne “ākāsagaṅgā”ti, tiyaggaḷapāsāṇe paññāsayojanokāse ṭhitā
analyzed: saṭṭhi yojanāni gata ṭṭhāne ākāsagaṅgā ati tiyaggaḷa pāsāṇe paññāsa yojana ukāse ṭhitā
translated: The stream called Tiyaggaḷa flows for fifty leagues in the space between the rock called Tiyaggaḷa and the rock called Tiyaggaḷa.

original: “tiyaggaḷapokkharaṇī”ti, kūlaṃ bhinditvā pāsāṇaṃ pavisitvā saṭṭhi yojanāni gataṭṭhāne🔽“bahalagaṅgā”ti, umaṅgena saṭṭhi yojanāni gataṭṭhāne “umaṅgagaṅgā”ti vuccati. Viñjhaṃ
analyzed: tiyaggaḷapokkharaṇī iti kūlam bhinditvā pāsāṇam pavisitvā saṭṭhi yojanāni gata ṭṭhāne  bahalagaṅgā ti umaṅgena saṭṭhi yojanāni gata ṭṭhāne umaṅgagaṅgā ti vuccati viñjham
translated: The stream called Bahala flows for sixty leagues after entering the rock and splitting it.🔽The stream called Umaṅga flows for sixty leagues through the Umaṅga mountain.

original: nāma tiracchānapabbataṃ paharitvā pañcadhārā hutvā pavattaṭṭhāne pana gaṅgā yamunā
analyzed: nāma tiracchāna pabbatam paharitvā pañca dhārāḥ hutvā pavatta ṭṭhāne pana gaṅgā yamunā
translated: The stream called Viñjha, after striking the mountain called Tiriya, flows in five streams. The place where it flows in five streams is called the five streams.

original: aciravatī sarabhū mahīti pañcadhā saṅkhyaṃ gatā. Evametā pañca mahānadiyo himavantato pabhavanti.
analyzed: aciravatī sarabhū mahī iti pañcadhā saṅkhyam gatāḥ evam etā pañca mahā nadiyaḥ upabhavanti
translated: The five streams are called Gaṅgā, Yamunā, Aciravatī, Sarabhū, and Mahī. Thus these five great rivers originate from the Himalayas.

original: Chaddantadahassa pana majjhe dvādasayojanappamāṇe ṭhāne sevālo vā paṇakaṃ vā natthi,🔽maṇikkhandhavaṇṇaṃ udakameva santiṭṭhati, tadanantaraṃ yojanavitthataṃ suddhakallahāravanaṃ
analyzed: chaddanta dahassa pana majjhe dvādasa yojana ppamāṇe ṭhāne sevālaḥ vā paṇakam vā natthi  maṇi khandha vaṇṇam udakam eva santiṭṭhati tad anantaram yojana vitthatam suddha kallahāra vanam
translated: But in the middle of the elephant’s mouth, in a place twelve leagues across, there is no lotus-pool or lotus-lake,🔽only water the colour of the ruby. Next to that is a forest of pure kallahāra lotuses a league in extent,

original: taṃ udakaṃ parikkhipitvā ṭhitaṃ, tadanantaraṃ yojanavitthatameva suddhanīluppalavanaṃ
analyzed: tam udakam parikkhipitvā ṭhitam tad anantaram yojana vitthatam eva suddha nīluppala vanam
translated: which surrounds the water. Next to that is a forest of pure blue lotuses a league in extent,

original: taṃ parikkhipitvā ṭhitaṃ, yojanayojanavitthatāneva rattuppalasetuppalarattapadumasetapadumakumudavanāni
analyzed: tam parikkhipitvā ṭhitam yojana yojana vitthatānā iva rattuppala setuppala rattapaduma setapaduma kumuda vanāni
translated: which surrounds it. And there are forests of red lotuses, of white lotuses, and of kumuda flowers, each a league in extent,

original: purimaṃ purimaṃ parikkhipitvā ṭhitāni, imesaṃ pana sattannaṃ vanānaṃ anantaraṃ sabbesampi🔽kallahārādīnaṃ vasena vomissakavanaṃ yojanavitthatameva tāni parikkhipitvā ṭhitaṃ,
analyzed: purimam purimam parikkhipitvā ṭhitāni imesam pana sattannam vanānam anantaram sabbesam pi  kallahāra ādīnam vasena vomissaka vanam yojana vitthatam eva tāni parikkhipitvā ṭhitam
translated: surrounding the previous one. Next to these seven forests is a mixed forest a league in extent, which surrounds them all.

original: tadanantaraṃ nāgānaṃ kaṭippamāṇe udake yojanavitthatameva rattasālivanaṃ, tadanantaraṃ
analyzed: tad anantaram nāgānam udake yojana vitthatam eva ratta sāli vanam tad anantaram
translated: This is made up of kallahāras and the rest. Next to that is a forest of red rice a league in extent, in water up to the elephants’ mouths. Next to that is a forest of palm trees a league in extent,

original: udakapariyante nīlapītalohitodātasurabhisukhumakusumasamākiṇṇaṃ khuddakagacchavananti
analyzed: udaka pariyante nīla pīta lohita udāta surabhi sukhuma kusuma samākiṇṇam khuddaka gaccha vananti
translated: and at the edge of the water, strewn with little flowers of blue, yellow, red, and white, and with little trees and bushes.

original: imāni dasa vanāni yojanayojanavitthatāneva. Tato khuddakarājamāsamahārājamāsamuggavanaṃ,🔽tadanantaraṃ tipusaeḷālukaalābukumbhaṇḍavallivanāni, tato pūgarukkhappamāṇaṃ ucchuvanaṃ,🔽tato hatthidantappamāṇaphalaṃ kadalivanaṃ, tato sālavanaṃ, tadanantaraṃ cāṭippamāṇaphalaṃ
analyzed: imāni dasa vanāni tatas khuddaka rāja māsa mahārāja māsamugga vanam  tad anantaram tipusa eḷāluka alābu kumbhaṇḍa valli vanāni tatas pūga rukkha ppamāṇam ucchuvanam  tatas hatthi danta ppamāṇa phalam kadali vanam tatas sāla vanam tad anantaram ca āṭi ppamāṇa phalam
translated: These ten forests are each ten leagues in extent. Beyond them is the Great Mountain,🔽and beyond that the forest of Tipu, the forest of Saela, the forest of Alabu, the forest of Kumbhandavalli, the forest of Ucchuva,

original: panasavanaṃ, tato madhuraphalaṃ ambavanaṃ, tato ciñcavanaṃ, tato kapiṭṭhavanaṃ, tato
analyzed: panasa vanam tatas madhura phalam amba vanam tatas ciñca vanam tatas kapiṭṭha vanam tatas
translated: the forest of Kadali, the forest of Sala, the forest of Panasa, the forest of Mango, the forest of Cinca, the forest of Kapittha,

original: vomissako mahāvanasaṇḍo, tato veṇuvanaṃ, veṇuvanaṃ pana parikkhipitvā satta pabbatā
analyzed: vomissakaḥ mahā vana saṇḍaḥ tatas veṇu vanam veṇu vanam pana parikkhipitvā satta pabbatā
translated: the forest of Vomissaka, the forest of Bamboo. The forest of Bamboo is surrounded by seven mountains.

original: ṭhitā, tesaṃ bāhirantato paṭṭhāya paṭhamo cūḷakāḷapabbato nāma, dutiyo mahākāḷapabbato
analyzed: ṭhitā tesam bāhirantataḥ paṭṭhāya paṭhamo cūḷakāḷapabbataḥ nāma dutiyaḥ mahākāḷa pabbato
translated: The first mountain outside is called Culakala, the second Mahākala,

original: nāma, tato udakapassapabbato nāma, tato candapassapabbato nāma, tato sūriyapassapabbato
analyzed: nāma tatas udakapassapabbataḥ nāma tatas candapassapabbataḥ nāma tatas sūriyapassapabbataḥ
translated: the third Udakapassapabbata, the fourth Candapassapabbata, the fifth Sūriyapassapabbata,🔽the sixth Vejayanta, and the seventh is called Yugandhara. The forest of Bamboo is ten leagues in extent, and the mountains are also ten leagues in extent.

original: nāma, tato maṇipassapabbato nāma, sattamo suvaṇṇapassapabbato nāma. So ubbedhato
analyzed: nāma tatas maṇipassapabbataḥ nāma sattamaḥ suvaṇṇapassapabbataḥ nāma saḥ ubbedhataḥ
translated: the seventh is the Golden Peak. It is seven leagues high,

original: sattayojaniko chaddantadahaṃ parikkhipitvā pattassa mukhavaṭṭi viya ṭhito. Tassa
analyzed: satta yojanikaḥ chat danta daham parikkhipitvā pattassa mukha vaṭṭi viya ṭhitaḥ tassa
translated: and it stands surrounding the Lake of Chaddanta like the rim of a saucer.

original: abbhantarimapassaṃ suvaṇṇavaṇṇaṃ, tato nikkhantena obhāsena chaddantadaho samuggatabālasūriyo
analyzed: abbhantarima passam suvaṇṇa vaṇṇam tatas nikkhantena obhāsena chaddanta daho samuggata bāla sūriyaḥ
translated: Inside it is a mountain of golden colour, and the light that comes from it makes the Lake of Chaddanta look like the rising sun.

original: viya hoti. Bāhirimapabbatesu pana eko ubbedhato cha yojanāni, eko pañca, eko cattāri,
analyzed: viya hoti bāhirima pabbatesu pana ekaḥ ubbedhato cha yojanāni ekaḥ pañca eko cattāri
translated: But the outer mountains are six leagues high, five leagues high, four leagues high,

original: eko tīṇi, eko dve, eko yojanaṃ.
analyzed: ekaḥ tīṇi ekaḥ dve ekaḥ yojanam
translated: three leagues high, two leagues high, and one league high.

original: Evaṃ sattapabbataparikkhittassa pana tassa dahassa pubbuttarakaṇṇe udakavātappaharaṇokāse
analyzed: evam satta pabbata parikkhittassa pana tassa dahassa pubbuttara kaṇṇe udaka vāta ppaharaṇa ukāse
translated: Now, in the north-east corner of the lake, in a place where the wind and rain are kept out,

original: mahānigrodharukkho, tassa khandho parikkhepato pañcayojaniko, ubbedhato sattayojaniko.
analyzed: mahānigrodha rukkhaḥ tassa khandho parikkhepataḥ pañca yojanikaḥ ubbedhataḥ satta yojanikaḥ
translated: there is a great banyan tree. Its trunk is five leagues round and seven leagues high.

original: Catūsu disāsu catasso sākhāyo chachayojanikā, uddhaṃ uggatasākhāpi chayojanikāva.
analyzed: catūsu disāsu catasso sākhāyaḥ cha cha yojanikāḥ uddham uggata sākhā api cha yojanikā ava
translated: It has four branches, each six leagues long, and the branch that grows upwards is also six leagues long.

original: Iti so mūlato paṭṭhāya ubbedhena terasayojaniko sākhānaṃ orimantato yāva pārimantā🔽dvādasayojaniko aṭṭhahi pārohasahassehi paṭimaṇḍito muṇḍamaṇipabbato viya vilāsamāno🔽tiṭṭhati. Chaddantadahassa pana pacchimadisābhāge suvaṇṇapabbate dvādasayojanikā
analyzed: iti saḥ mūlataḥ paṭṭhāya ubbedhena terasa yojanikaḥ sākhānam orimantataḥ yāva pārimantā  dvādasa yojanikaḥ aṭṭhahi pāroha sahassehi paṭimaṇḍitaḥ muṇḍa maṇi pabbataḥ viya vilāsamānaḥ  tiṭṭhati chaddanta dahassa pana pacchima disā bhāge suvaṇṇa pabbate dvādasa yojanikā
translated: So it is thirteen leagues high from the base to the top, and twelve leagues across from east to west.🔽It is adorned with eight terraces and shines like the Mount of Jewels.🔽And in the south-west corner of the elephant’s mouth there is a golden mountain, twelve leagues high,

original: kañcanaguhā. Chaddanto nāgarājā vassāratte aṭṭhasahassanāgaparivuto kañcanaguhāyaṃ
analyzed: kañcanaguhā chaddantaḥ nāga rājā vassāratte aṭṭha sahassa nāga parivutaḥ kañcanaguhāyaṃ
translated: with a golden cave twenty-four leagues long. The elephant king Chaddanta lives in the golden cave with his retinue of eight thousand elephants during the rainy season,

original: vasati, gimhakāle udakavātaṃ sampaṭicchamāno mahānigrodhamūle pārohantare tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: vasati gimha kāle udaka vātam sampaṭicchamānaḥ mahānigrodha mūle pārohantare tiṭṭhati
translated: and during the hot season he stands in the elephant’s foot-print at the root of the great banyan tree, fanning the water wind.

original: Mandākiniyā pana majjhe pañcavīsatiyojanamatte ṭhāne sevālo vā paṇakaṃ vā natthi,🔽phalikavaṇṇaṃ udakameva hoti, tato paraṃ pana nāgānaṃ kaṭippamāṇe udake aḍḍhayojanavitthataṃ
analyzed: mandākiniyāḥ pana majjhe pañcavīsati yojana matte ṭhāne sevālaḥ vā paṇakam vā natthi  phalika vaṇṇam udakam eva hoti tatas param pana nāgānam kaṭi ppamāṇe udake aḍḍha yojana vitthatam
translated: But in the middle of the Mandakini Lake, in a place twenty-five leagues long, there is no mud or sand,🔽but the water is the colour of coral. Beyond that, in water up to the elephants’ hips, a league and a half wide,🔽there is a white lotus-pool surrounding the water. The lotus stalks are the size of plough handles,

original: setapadumavanaṃ taṃ udakaṃ parikkhipitvā ṭhitaṃ. Tattha muḷālaṃ naṅgalasīsamattaṃ
analyzed: setapadumavanam tam udakam parikkhipitvā ṭhitam tattha muḷālam naṅgala sīsa mattam
translated: and the flowers are the size of cartwheels.

original: hoti, bhisaṃ mahābheripokkharappamāṇaṃ hoti. Tassa ekekasmiṃ pabbantare āḷhakappamāṇaṃ
analyzed: hoti bhisam mahā bheri pokkhara ppamāṇam hoti tassa ekekasmim pabbantare āḷhaka ppamāṇam
translated: and the size of the great lake is the size of the great drum. In each of its openings there is milk

original: khīraṃ hoti. Padumānaṃ pupphasamaye vāto reṇuvaṭṭiṃ uṭṭhāpetvā paduminīpattesu ṭhapeti,
analyzed: khīram hoti padumānam puppha samaye vātaḥ reṇu vaṭṭim uṭṭhāpetvā paduminī pattesu ṭhapeti
translated: the size of a water pot. When the lotus flowers are in bloom, the wind raises up a dust-cloud and places it on the lotus leaves,

original: tattha udakaphusitāni patanti, tato ādiccapākena paccitvā pakkaayoghaṭikā viya pokkharamadhu
analyzed: tattha udaka phusitāni patanti tatas ādicca pākena paccitvā pakka ayoghaṭikā viya pokkhara madhu
translated: and there the water-drops fall, and then, having been heated by the sun’s heat, it stands like a cooked sugar-ball in the lake,

original: tiṭṭhati, tadanantaraṃ tāvamahantameva rattapadumavanaṃ, tadanantaraṃ rattakumudavanaṃ,
analyzed: tiṭṭhati tad anantaram tāva mahantam eva ratta paduma vanam tad anantaram ratta kumuda vanam
translated: and after that there is a lotus-wood of the same size as the great lake, and after that a water-lily wood,

original: tadanantaraṃ setakumudavanaṃ, tadanantaraṃ nīluppalavanaṃ, tadanantaraṃ rattuppalavanaṃ,🔽tadanantaraṃ sugandhasālivanaṃ, tadanantaraṃ eḷālukaalābukumbhaṇḍādīni madhurarasāni
analyzed: tad anantaram seta kumuda vanam tad anantaram nīluppala vanam tad anantaram rattuppala vanam  tad anantaram sugandha sāli vanam tad anantaram eḷāluka alābu kumbhaṇḍa ādīni madhura rasāni
translated: after that a white water-lily wood, after that a blue lotus wood, after that a red lotus wood,🔽after that a sugar-cane wood, after that creepers and fruits such as the eḷāluka, āḷābu, and kumbhaṇḍa, which have a sweet juice,

original: valliphalāni, tadanantaraṃ aḍḍhayojanavitthatameva ucchuvanaṃ, tattha pūgarukkhakkhandhappamāṇaṃ
analyzed: valli phalāni tad anantaram aḍḍha yojana vitthatam eva ucchuvanam tattha pūga rukkha kkhandha ppamāṇam
translated: after that a forest of sugar-cane, which is half a league in extent, and there the sugar-cane is the size of a tree trunk,🔽and after that a forest of sugar-cane, which is a league in extent, and there the sugar-cane is the size of a pillar.

original: ucchu. Tadanantaraṃ kadalivanaṃ, yato duve pakkāni khādantā kilamanti. Tadanantaraṃ
analyzed: tad anantaram kadali vanam yatas duve pakkāni khādantā kilamanti tad anantaram
translated: and then the plantain grove, where they were tired by eating two ripe ones. Then

original: cāṭippamāṇaphalaṃ panasavanaṃ, tadanantaraṃ ambavanaṃ, jambuvanaṃ, kapiṭṭhavananti
analyzed: cāṭippamāṇaphalam panasa vanam tad anantaram amba vanam jambu vanam kapiṭṭha vanam iti
translated: the bread-fruit grove, the size of a chatta, then the mango grove, the rose-apple grove, and the bread-fruit grove.

original: saṅkhepato tasmiṃ dahe khāditabbayuttakaṃ phalaṃ nāma natthīti na vattabbaṃ. Iti🔽imasmiṃ himavati vijjamānakasattamahāsarappabhutīnaṃ pamāṇasaṇṭhānādibhedaṃ sabbameva
analyzed: saṅkhepataḥ tasmin dahe khāditabba yuttakam phalam nāma natthi iti na vattabbam iti  imasmin himavati vijjamānaka satta mahāsara ppabhutīnam pamāṇa saṇṭhāna ādi bhedam sabbam eva
translated: In short, it cannot be said that there is no fruit there fit to be eaten.

original: visesaṃ bhagavā sabbathā avedi aññāsi paṭivijjhiyevāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: visesam bhagavā sabbathā avedi aññāsi paṭivijjhiya iva ati daṭṭhabbam
translated: So it should be regarded that the Blessed One has known, has understood, has penetrated in all ways the measure, shape, etc., of all the great mountains and the rest that exist in this Himalayas.

original: Tipañcayojanakkhandhaparikkhepāti pannarasayojanappamāṇakkhandhaparikkhepā, khandhassa🔽pariṇāho pannarasayojanappamāṇoti vuttaṃ hoti. Nagavhayāti nagasaddena avhātabbā,
analyzed: ti pañca yojana khandha parikkhepā ti pannarasa yojana ppamāṇa khandha parikkhepā khandhassa  pariṇāhaḥ pannarasa yojana ppamāṇaḥ ti vuttam hoti naga vhayā iti naga saddena a vhātabbā
translated: It has a breadth of three and a half leagues: it has a breadth of fifteen leagues; what is meant is that the breadth of it is fifteen leagues.

original: rukkhābhidhānāti attho. Rukkho hi na gacchatīti nagoti vuccati. Nagavhayā jambūti
analyzed: rukkha abhidhānā ti atthaḥ rukkhaḥ hi na gacchati iti nagaḥ iti vuccati naga vhayā jambu ti
translated: It is called “Nagavibhrama” : it is to be called “Nagavibhrama” ; what is meant is that it is the name for a tree. For a tree is called “naga” because it does not go . It is called “Nagavibhrama” because it is the name for a tree.

original: yojetabbaṃ. Paññāsayojanakkhandhasākhāyāmāti ubbedhato paññāsayojanappamāṇakkhandhāyāmā
analyzed: yojetabbam paññāsa yojana kkhandha sākhā āyāmā ati ubbedhataḥ paññāsa yojana ppamāṇa kkhandha āyāmā
translated: It should be yoked. It has a trunk and branches fifty leagues in extent: it has a trunk fifty leagues in height,

original: ubbedhato samantato ca paññāsayojanasākhāyāmā ca. Tato eva satayojanavitthiṇṇā, tāvadeva
analyzed: ubbedhataḥ samantataḥ ca paññāsa yojana sākhā āyāmā ca tatas eva sata yojana vitthiṇṇā tāvat eva
translated: and branches fifty leagues in extent all round. It is thirty leagues in girth,

original: ca uggatā. Jamburukkhassa hi mūlato paṭṭhāya yāva sākhāviṭapā, tāva paṇṇāsa yojanāni,🔽tato parampi ujukaṃ uggatasākhā paṇṇāsa yojanāni, samantato ca ekekā sākhā paṇṇāsa
analyzed: ca uggatā jambu rukkhassa hi mūlataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva sākhā viṭapā tāva paṇṇāsa yojanāni  tatas parampi ujukam uggata sākhā paṇṇāsa yojanāni samantataḥ ca ekekā sākhā paṇṇāsa
translated: and it rises thirty leagues. For the tree is fifty leagues from the base of the trunk to the end of the branches and foliage,🔽and the branches and foliage rise up thirty leagues straight out from it, and each branch extends thirty leagues all round.

original: paṇṇāsa yojanāni vaḍḍhitāni. Tāsu pana mahantā mahantā nadiyo sandanti, tāsaṃ nadīnaṃ
analyzed: paṇṇāsa yojanāni vaḍḍhitāni tāsu pana mahantāḥ mahantāḥ nadiyaḥ sandanti tāsam nadīnam
translated: But in it there are great rivers flowing between the branches, and on both banks of these rivers

original: ubhayatīre jambupakkānaṃ patitaṭṭhāne suvaṇṇaṅkurā uṭṭhahanti, te nadījalena vuyhamānā🔽anupubbena mahāsamuddaṃ pavisanti, tatoyeva jambunadiyaṃ nibbattattā “jambunada”nti
analyzed: ubhaya tīre jambu pakkānam patita ṭṭhāne suvaṇṇa aṅkurāḥ uṭṭhahanti te nadī jalena vuyhamānā  anupubbena mahā samuddam pavisanti tatoyā iva jambunadiyam nibbatta ttāḥ jambu nadanti
translated: golden shoots spring up where the rose-apple fruits fall. Being washed down by the river water,🔽they eventually enter the great ocean. That gold is called “Jambunadi gold”

original: taṃ suvaṇṇaṃ vuccati.
analyzed: tat suvaṇṇam vuccati
translated: because it comes from the river Jambu.

original: Yassānubhāvenāti yassā mahantatā kappaṭṭhāyikādippakārena pabhāvena. Yañcetaṃ jambuyā🔽pamāṇaṃ, etadeva asurānaṃ cittapāṭaliyā, garuḷānaṃ simbalirukkhassa, aparagoyāne
analyzed: yassa anubhāvena ati yassā mahanta tā kappaṭṭhāyikā ādi ppakārena pabhāvena  pamāṇam etat eva asurānam cittapāṭaliyāḥ garuḷānam simbali rukkhassa aparagoyāne
translated: ‘By whose power’: by whose greatness, by whose power lasting for an eon, and so on.

original: kadambassa, uttarakurūsu kapparukkhassa, pubbavidehe sirīsassa, tāvatiṃsesu pāricchattakassāti. Tenāhu porāṇā –
analyzed: kadambassa uttarakurūsu kapparukkhassa pubbavidehe sirīsassa tāvatiṃsesu pāricchattakassa ati tena āhu porāṇā
translated: And the measure of the Rose-Apple Tree is the same as that of the Citrapāṭali for the Asuras, the Simbali Tree for the Garuḍas, the Kadamba Tree for the people of Aparagoyāna, the Kappa Tree for the people of Uttarakuru, the Sīrisha Tree for the people of Pubbavideha, and the Pāricchattaka Tree for the Thirty-Three Gods. Therefore the Ancients said:

original: “Pāṭalī simbalī jambū, devānaṃ pārichattako;
analyzed: pāṭalī simbalī jambū devānam pārichattakaḥ
translated: ‘Pāṭali, Simbali, Rose-Apple, and the Thirty-Three’s Pāricchattaka,

original: Kadambo kapparukkho ca, sirīsena bhavati sattama”nti. ;
analyzed: kadambaḥ kapparukkho ca sirīsena bhavati
translated: Kadamba, Kappa Tree, and Sīrisha—these are the seven.’

original: Ettha sirīsena bhavati sattamanti ettha sirīsenāti paccatte karaṇavacanaṃ. Sattamanti liṅgavipallāsena vuttaṃ, sirīso bhavati sattamoti attho.
analyzed: ettha sirīsena bhavati sattamanti ettha sirīsena ati paccatte karaṇa vacanam sattamanti liṅga vipallāsena vuttam sirīsaḥ bhavati sattamaḥ ti attho
translated: Herein, the words ‘and the Sīrisha’ are a locative case used adverbially. The word ‘seven’ is stated with a change of gender. The meaning is ‘the Sīrisha is the seventh.’

original: Cakkavāḷasiluccayoti cakkavāḷapabbato. Parikkhipitvā taṃ sabbaṃ, lokadhātumayaṃ ṭhitoti
analyzed: cakkavāḷa siluccayo ti cakkavāḷa pabbataḥ parikkhipitvā tam sabbam lokadhātu mayam ṭhito ti
translated: ‘The world-sphere mountains’: the Cakkavāḷa mountains. ‘Standing all around, surrounding the whole’:

original: heṭṭhā vuttaṃ sabbampi taṃ parikkhipitvā cakkavāḷasiluccayo patiṭṭhito, ayaṃ ekā
analyzed: heṭṭhā vuttam sabbam pi tam parikkhipitvā cakkavāḷa siluccayaḥ patiṭṭhitaḥ ayam ekā
translated: all that has been stated above is surrounded by the Cakkavāḷa mountains, which stand all around.

original: lokadhātu nāmāti attho. Ma-kāro padasandhivasena āgato. “Taṃ sabbaṃ lokadhātuṃ parikkhipitvā🔽ayaṃ cakkavāḷasiluccayo ṭhito”ti evampettha sambandhaṃ vadanti, evaṃ vuttepi cakkavāḷapabbatopi
analyzed: lokadhātu nāma ati atthaḥ makāraḥ pada sandhi vasena āgataḥ tam sabbam lokadhātum parikkhipitvā  ayam cakkavāḷa siluccayaḥ ṭhitaḥ ti evam pa ittha sambandham vadanti evam vutte api cakkavāḷa pabbataḥ pi
translated: “This circular mountain-chain stands surrounding all that world-sphere” —

original: lokadhātuyevāti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: lokadhātuyā iva ati veditabbam
translated: so they explain the connection here. But even if that is so, the Cakkavāḷa mountain should be understood as being in the world-sphere too.

original: Tatthāti tissaṃ lokadhātuyaṃ. Candamaṇḍalaṃ ekūnapaññāsayojananti ujukaṃ āyāmato
analyzed: tattha ati tissam canda maṇḍalam ujukam āyāmataḥ
translated: “There” means in that world-sphere. The moon’s disk is forty-nine leagues across.

original: vitthārato ubbedhato ca ekūnapaññāsayojanaṃ, parimaṇḍalato pana tīhi yojanehi ūnadiyaḍḍhasatayojanaṃ.
analyzed: vitthārataḥ ubbedhataḥ ca ekūna paññāsa yojanam parimaṇḍalataḥ pana tīhi yojanehi ūna diyaṭṭha sata yojanam
translated: Straight across, it is forty-nine leagues in extent, and in circumference it is four hundred and fifty leagues.

original: Sūriyamaṇḍalaṃ paññāsayojananti etthāpi candamaṇḍale vuttanayeneva ujukaṃ paññāsayojananti🔽veditabbaṃ, parimaṇḍalato pana diyaḍḍhasatayojanaṃ.
analyzed: sūriya maṇḍalam paññāsa yojanan ti ettha api canda maṇḍale vutta nayena iva ujukam paññāsa yojanan ti  veditabbam parimaṇḍalato pana diyat ha sata yojanam
translated: The sun’s disk is fifty leagues. Here too it should be understood that straight across it is fifty leagues,🔽and in circumference it is five hundred leagues.

original: Tesu pana candamaṇḍalaṃ heṭṭhā, sūriyamaṇḍalaṃ upari, antarā nesaṃ yojanaṃ hoti.
analyzed: tesu pana canda maṇḍalam heṭṭhā sūriya maṇḍalam upari antarā yojanam hoti
translated: The moon’s disk is below the sun’s disk, and the distance between them is a league.

original: Candassa heṭṭhimantato sūriyassa uparimantaṃ yojanasataṃ hoti, candavimānaṃ anto🔽maṇimayaṃ, bahi rajatena parikkhittaṃ, anto ca bahi ca sītalameva hoti. Sūriyavimānaṃ
analyzed: candassa heṭṭhimantataḥ sūriyassa uparimantam yojana satam hoti canda vimānam antar  maṇi mayam bahi rajatena parikkhittam antar ca bahi ca sītalam eva hoti sūriya vimānam
translated: The moon is a hundred leagues below the sun and a hundred leagues above us. The moon’s mansion is🔽made of crystal inside and surrounded by silver outside. It is cool both inside and out. The sun’s mansion is

original: anto kanakamayaṃ, bāhiraṃ phalikaparikkhittaṃ hoti, anto ca bahi ca uṇhameva. Cando
analyzed: antar kanaka mayam bāhiram phalika parikkhittam hoti antar ca bahi ca uṇham eva cando
translated: made of gold inside and surrounded by quartz outside. It is hot both inside and out. The moon

original: ujukaṃ saṇikaṃ gacchati. So hi amāvāsiyaṃ sūriyena saddhiṃ gacchanto divase divase
analyzed: ujukam saṇikam gacchati saḥ hi amāvāsiyam sūriyena saddhim gacchantaḥ divase divase
translated: moves smoothly and slowly. For on the new-moon day it moves with the sun, and as it does so it is

original: thokaṃ thokaṃ ohīyanto puṇṇamāsiyaṃ upaḍḍhamaggato ohīyati, tiriyaṃ pana sīghaṃ gacchati.
analyzed: thokam thokam ohīyantaḥ puṇṇamāsiyam upaḍḍha maggataḥ ohīyati tiriyam pana sīgham gacchati
translated: gradually overtaken by the sun. On the full-moon day it is half a league behind the sun, but it moves faster🔽across the sky.

original: Tathā hesa ekasmiṃ māse kadāci dakkhiṇato, kadāci uttarato dissati, candassa ubhosu
analyzed: tathā ha isaḥ ekasmin māse kadāci dakkhiṇatas kadāci uttaratas dissati candassa ubhosu
translated: Thus sometimes in a month it is seen to the south of the stars, sometimes to the north. The stars

original: passesu nakkhattatārakā gacchanti, cando dhenu viya vacchaṃ taṃ taṃ nakkhattaṃ upasaṅkamati,
analyzed: passesu nakkhatta tārakāḥ gacchanti candaḥ dhenu viya vaccham tam tam nakkhattam upasaṅkamati
translated: move on both sides of the moon, and the moon approaches each constellation in turn like a cow approaching

original: nakkhattāni pana attano gamanaṭṭhānaṃ na vijahanti, attano vīthiyāva gacchanti. Sūriyassa
analyzed: nakkhattāni pana attanaḥ gamana ṭṭhānam na vijahanti attanaḥ vīthiyā ava gacchanti sūriyassa
translated: her calves. But the constellations do not leave their places; they move in their own orbits. The sun🔽moves in the same way as the moon.

original: pana ujukaṃ gamanaṃ sīghaṃ, tiriyaṃ gamanaṃ dandhaṃ. Tiriyaṃ gamanaṃ nāma dakkhiṇadisato
analyzed: pana ujukam gamanam sīgham tiriyam gamanam dandham tiriyam gamanam nāma dakkhiṇa disataḥ
translated: But the straight-on movement is quick, the crosswise movement is slow. The crosswise movement is from the south-east to the north-west.

original: uttaradisāya, uttaradisato dakkhiṇadisāya gamanaṃ, taṃ dandhaṃ chahi chahi māsehi ijjhanato.🔽Sūriyo kāḷapakkhauposathe candena saheva gantvā tato paraṃ pāṭipadadivase yojanānaṃ
analyzed: uttara disāya uttara disatas dakkhiṇa disāya gamanam tam dandham chahi chahi māsehi  sūriyaḥ kāḷapakkha uposathe candena saha iva gantvā tatas param pāṭipada divase
translated: But the movement is quick when straight, slow when oblique. Movement is oblique when from the south to the north or from the north to the south. That is slow because it succeeds only after six or seven months.

original: satasahassaṃ candamaṇḍalaṃ ohāya gacchati attano sīghagāmitāya tassa ca dandhagāmitāya,🔽atha cando lekhā viya paññāyati. Tato parampi pakkhassa dutiyāya yojanānaṃ satasahassaṃ🔽candamaṇḍalaṃ ohāya gacchati. Evaṃ divase divase yāva sukkapakkhauposathadivasā satasahassaṃ
analyzed: sata sahassam canda maṇḍalam ohāya gacchati attano sīgha gāmitāya tassa ca dandha gāmitāya  atha candaḥ lekhā viya paññāyati tato param pi pakkhassa dutiyāya yojanānam sata sahassam  canda maṇḍalam ohāya gacchati evam divase divase yāva sukka pakkha uposatha divasā sata sahassam
translated: The sun, after going with the moon on the Observance day of the waning fortnight, leaves the moon’s orb a hundred thousand leagues away on the following day of the waxing fortnight,🔽because of its own speed and because of the moon’s slowness.🔽Then the moon appears as if marked with a line. After that, for the second fortnight, the moon leaves a hundred thousand leagues a day,

original: satasahassaṃ ohāya gacchati, atha cando anukkamena vaḍḍhitvā uposathadivase paripuṇṇo
analyzed: sata sahassam ohāya gacchati atha candaḥ anukkamena vaḍḍhitvā uposatha divase paripuṇṇaḥ
translated: until the Observance day of the waxing fortnight. Then the moon, increasing gradually, is full on the Observance day of the waxing fortnight.

original: hoti. Anukkamena vaḍḍhanañcettha uparibhāgato patitasūriyālokatāya heṭṭhato pavattāya🔽sūriyassa dūrabhāvena divase divase anukkamena parihāyamānāya attano chāyāya vasena
analyzed: hoti anukkamena vaḍḍhanam ca ittha upari bhāgataḥ patita sūriya āloka tāya heṭṭhatas pavattāya  sūriyassa dūra bhāvena divase divase anukkamena parihāyamānāya attano chāyāya vasena
translated: and it is to be understood that the moon’s appearance is like that of a circle of light that gradually increases in size as it moves down from the upper part of the sky,

original: anukkamena caṇḍamaṇḍalappadesassa vaḍḍhamānassa viya dissamānatāyāti veditabbaṃ,🔽tasmā anukkamena vaḍḍhitvā viya uposathadivase puṇṇamāyaṃ paripuṇṇamaṇḍalo hutvā
analyzed: anukkamena caṇḍa maṇḍala ppadesassa vaḍḍhamānassa viya dissamāna tāya ati veditabbam  tasmai anukkamena vaḍḍhitvā viyas uposatha divase puṇṇamāyam paripuṇṇa maṇḍalaḥ hutvā
translated: and that gradually diminishes in size as the sun moves away from it day by day,🔽and that gradually increases in size as the area of the circle of light increases.🔽So that on the Uposatha day of the bright half of the lunar half-month it appears as a full circle.

original: dissati. Atha sūriyo pāṭipadadivase yojanānaṃ satasahassaṃ dhāvitvā puna candamaṇḍalaṃ
analyzed: dissati atha sūriyaḥ pāṭipada divase yoja nānam sata sahassam dhāvitvā puna canda maṇḍalam
translated: Then on the following day, the fifteenth, the sun runs a hundred thousand leagues and again catches up with the moon.

original: gaṇhāti candassa dandhagatitāya attano ca sīghagatitāya, tathā dutiyāya satasahassanti
analyzed: gaṇhāti candassa dandha gati tāya attano ca sīgha gati tāya tathā dutiyāya
translated: Because of the slowness of the moon’s movement and the speed of the sun’s,

original: evaṃ yāva uposathadivasā satasahassaṃ satasahassaṃ dhāvitvā gaṇhāti. Atha cando anukkamena
analyzed: evam yāvaḥ uposatha divasā sata sahassam sata sahassam dhāvitvā gaṇhāti atha candaḥ anukkamena
translated: and so on, until on the Uposatha day of the dark half of the lunar half-month the sun runs a hundred thousand leagues and again catches up with the moon.

original: hāyitvā kāḷapakkhauposathadivase sabbaso na paññāyati, anukkamena hāyamānatā cettha
analyzed: hāyitvā kāḷapakkha auposatha divase sabbasas na paññāyati anukkamena hāyamāna tā ca ittha
translated: Then the moon gradually diminishes in size and on the Uposatha day of the dark half of the lunar half-month it is not seen at all.🔽And the gradual diminishing in size is

original: anukkamena vaḍḍhamānatāya vuttanayena veditabbā. Tattha pana chāyāya hāyamānatāya
analyzed: anukkamena vaḍḍhamāna tāya vutta nayena veditabbā tattha pana chāyāya hāyamāna tāya
translated: and it should be understood in the way already described.

original: maṇḍalaṃ vaḍḍhamānaṃ viya dissati, idha ca chāyāya vaḍḍhamānatāya maṇḍalaṃ hāyamānaṃ
analyzed: maṇḍalam vaḍḍhamānam viya dissati idha ca chāyāya vaḍḍhamāna tāya maṇḍalam hāyamānam
translated: But here the moon’s disk appears to be diminishing as the shadow increases,

original: viya dissati, tasmā anukkamena hāyitvā viya uposathadivase sabbaso na paññāyati.
analyzed: viya dissati tasmai anukkamena hāyitvā viya uposatha divase sabbasas na paññāyati
translated: and on the uposatha day it does not appear at all as if it were diminishing in a special way.

original: Candaṃ heṭṭhā katvā sūriyo upari hoti, mahatiyā pātiyā khuddakabhājanaṃ viya candamaṇḍalaṃ🔽pidhīyati, majjhanhike gehacchāyā viya candassa chāyā na paññāyati. So chāyāya apaññāyamānāya

analyzed: dvīsu eva dīpesu eka ppahārena ubhayam ekekāya disāya nava nava yojana sata sahassāni
translated: but in the other two continents it does both. In each of the two directions it is nine hundred thousand leagues.

original: andhakāravidhamanampi imināva nayena daṭṭhabbaṃ. Imasmiñhi dīpe ṭhitamajjhanhikavelāyaṃ
analyzed: andhakāra vidhamanam pi iminā ava nayena daṭṭhabbam imasmin hi dīpe ṭhitam ajjhanhika velāyam
translated: The dispelling of darkness should be understood in the same way. For at midday in this continent

original: pubbavidehavāsīnaṃ atthaṅgamanavasena upaḍḍhaṃ sūriyamaṇḍalaṃ paññāyatīti pubbavidehe
analyzed: pubbavideha vāsīnam atthaṅgamana vasena upaḍḍham sūriya maṇḍalam paññāyati iti pubbavidehe
translated: in Pubbavideha the sun’s disk appears half immersed in the ocean,🔽so it dispels the darkness in the place nine hundred thousand leagues distant in Pubbavideha

original: navayojanasatasahassappamāṇe ṭhāne andhakāraṃ vidhamitvā ālokaṃ dasseti, tathā aparagoyāne
analyzed: nava yojana sata sahassa ppamāṇe ṭhāne andhakāram vidhamitvā ālokam dasseti tathā apara goyāne
translated: and gives light there. Likewise in Aparagoyāna,

original: uggamanavasena tatthāpi upaḍḍhasseva paññāyamānattā. Pubbavidehānaṃ pana atthaṅgamite
analyzed: uggamana vasena tattha api upaḍḍhassa iva paññāyamāna ttā pubbavidehānam pana atthaṅgamite
translated: because it appears there also as half immersed in rising. But when it has set in Pubbavideha,

original: na paññāyatīti dvīsu dīpesu sabbattha andhakāraṃ vidhamitvā ālokaṃ dasseti aparagoyānepi
analyzed: na paññāyati iti dvīsu dīpesu sabbattha andhakāram vidhamitvā ālokam dasseti apara go yāne pi
translated: It is not seen. It is the sun that dispels the darkness everywhere in the two continents and shines,

original: uggate sūriye sabbattha andhakāravidhamanato.
analyzed: uggate sūriye sabbattha andhakāra vidhamanato
translated: and in the western continent as well.

original: Pātubhavantā ca candimasūriyā ekatova loke pātubhavanti, tesu sūriyo paṭhamataraṃ
analyzed: pātubhavantā ca candima sūriyā ekatas uva loke pātubhavanti tesu sūriyo paṭhamataraṃ
translated: The moon and sun appear in the world together. The sun is seen first,

original: paññāyati. Paṭhamakappikānañhi sattānaṃ sayaṃpabhāya antarahitāya andhakāro ahosi.
analyzed: paññāyati paṭhama kappikānam hi sattānam sayaṃpabhāya antarahitāya andhakāraḥ ahosi
translated: for when the first generation of beings had lost their self-luminosity, there was darkness.

original: Te bhītatasitā “bhaddakaṃ vatassa, sace añño āloko bhaveyyā”ti cintayiṃsu. Tato mahājanassa
analyzed: te bhīta tasitāḥ bhaddakam vatassa sace aññaḥ ālokaḥ bhaveyya ati cintayiṃsu tatas mahājanassa
translated: They were frightened and terrified, thinking, “How good it would be if some light appeared!” Then the sun’s disk arose,

original: sūrabhāvaṃ janayamānaṃ sūriyamaṇḍalaṃ uṭṭhahi, tenevassa “sūriyo”ti nāmaṃ ahosi.🔽Tasmiṃ divasaṃ ālokaṃ katvā atthaṅgamite puna andhakāro ahosi. Te bhītatasitā “bhaddakaṃ
analyzed: sūra bhāvam janayamānam sūriya maṇḍalam uṭṭhahi tena iva assa sūriyaḥ iti nāmam ahosi  tasmin divasam ālokam katvā atthaṅgamite puna andhakāraḥ ahosi te bhīta tasitā bhaddakam
translated: generating heat for the multitude, and so it got its name “sun” .

original: vatassa, sace añño āloko uppajjeyyā”ti cintayiṃsu. Atha nesaṃ chandaṃ ñatvā viya
analyzed: vatassa sace aññaḥ āloko uppajjeyya ati cintayiṃsu atha nesam chandam ñatvā viya
translated: When it had disappeared after lighting up the day, there was darkness again. They were frightened and terrified, thinking, “How good it would be if some light appeared!” Then, as if knowing their wish,🔽the moon’s disk arose,

original: candamaṇḍalaṃ uṭṭhahi, tenevassa “cando”ti nāmaṃ ahosi. Evaṃ candimasūriyesu pātubhūtesu
analyzed: canda maṇḍalam uṭṭhahi tena iva assa cando ti nāmam ahosi evam candima sūriyesu pātubhūtesu
translated: The moon’s disk arose, and that is why it is called “moon” . When the moon and sun had arisen,

original: nakkhattāni tārakarūpāni pātubhavanti, tato pabhuti rattindivā paññāyanti. Anukkamena
analyzed: nakkhattāni tāraka rūpāni pātubhavanti tatas pabhuti rattiṃdivā paññāyanti anukkamena
translated: the constellations and the stars became manifest in the form of lights. Then day and night became known, and after that

original: ca māsaḍḍhamāsautusaṃvaccharā jāyanti. Candimasūriyānaṃ pana pātubhūtadivaseyeva
analyzed: ca jāyanti candima sūriyānam
translated: the half-month, the month, the season, and the year. But on the very day that the moon and sun became manifest,

original: sinerucakkavāḷahimavantapabbatā cattāro ca dīpā pātubhavanti, te ca kho apubbaṃ acarimaṃ
analyzed: sineru cakkavāḷa himavanta pabbatā cattāro ca dīpā pātubhavanti te ca kho apubbam a carimam
translated: the Sineru world-sphere, the Cakkavāḷa range of mountains, the Himalaya range, and the four great continents became manifest. And they became manifest all at once, not successively.

original: phagguṇapuṇṇamadivaseyeva pātubhavantīti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: pātubhavanti iti veditabbam
translated: It should be understood that they became manifest on the full-moon day of the month of Phagguna .

original: Yasmā cettha “ekaṃ cakkavāḷaṃ āyāmato ca vitthārato ca yojanānaṃ dvādasa satasahassāni
analyzed: yasmai ca ittha ekam cakkavāḷam āyāmataḥ ca vitthārataḥ ca dvādasa sata sahassāni
translated: But since it is said in the commentary, “A world-sphere is twelve hundred thousand leagues in breadth and width,

original: tīṇi sahassāni cattāri satāni paññāsañca yojanānī”ti aṭṭhakathāyaṃ vuttaṃ, tasmā
analyzed: tīṇi sahassāni cattāri satāni paññāsañca yojanāni iti aṭṭhakathāyam vuttam tasmā
translated: three thousand, four hundred and fifty leagues in height,”

original: vuttappamāṇato imassa cakkavāḷassa sinerupatiṭṭhitokāse caturāsīti yojanasahassāni
analyzed: vutta ppamāṇataḥ imassa cakkavāḷassa sineḥ upatiṭṭhita ukāse caturāsīti yojana sahassāni
translated: the space occupied by Sineru in this world-sphere is eighty-four thousand leagues.

original: parato yāva cakkavāḷapabbatā uttaradisābhāgappamāṇañca pahāya imissā dakkhiṇadisāya –
analyzed: paratas yāva cakkavāḷa pabbatāḥ uttara disā bhāga ppamāṇañca pahāya imissā dakkhiṇa disāya
translated: and the southern direction is the same as the western direction.

original: Sinerucakkavāḷānaṃ, antaraṃ parimāṇato;
analyzed: antaram parimāṇataḥ
translated: The distance between the Yugandhara and the Cakkavāḷa mountains🔽is five hundred thousand leagues,

original: Pañca satasahassāni, sahassānūnasaṭṭhi ca.
analyzed: pañca sata sahassāni ca
translated: and sixty thousand leagues besides.🔽And seven hundred leagues should be known,

original: Satāni satta ñeyyāni, pañcavīsuttarāni ca;
analyzed: satāni satta ñeyyāni pañcavīsuttarāni ca
translated: and five hundred and twenty-five besides.🔽The sun’s path is called the “middle one”

original: Majjhavīthigato nāma, tattha vemajjhago ravi.
analyzed: majjhavīthigataḥ nāma tattha vemajjhagaḥ
translated: because it is in the middle of the two.

original: Majjhato yāva merumhā, cakkavāḷānamantare;🔽Vemajjhago yadā hoti, ubhayantagato tadā.
analyzed: majjhataḥ yāva merumhā cakkavāḷānam antare  vemajjha gaḥ yadā hoti ubhaya anta gataḥ tadā
translated: When it is in the middle between the Yugandhara and the Cakkavāḷa mountains,🔽then it is in the “middle one.”

original: Majjhato yāva merumhā, cakkavāḷā ca pabbatā;🔽Duve satasahassāni, sahassānūnasīti ca.
analyzed: majjhataḥ yāva merumhā cakkavāḷā ca pabbatā  duve sata sahassāni ca
translated: When it is between the Yugandhara and the Cakkavāḷa mountains,🔽then it is two hundred thousand leagues,🔽and eighty thousand leagues besides.🔽There are eight hundred and sixty-two leagues,

original: Aṭṭhasataṃ duve saṭṭhi, yojanāni dvigāvutaṃ;
analyzed: aṭṭhasatam duve yojanāni dvigāvutam
translated: and two-and-a-half besides.

original: Ubhato antato meru-cakkavāḷānamantare.🔽Ekaṃ satasahassañca, sahassānūnatālīsaṃ;
analyzed: ubhatas antatas meru cakka vāḷānam antare  ekam sata sahassañca
translated: The circle of the middle path🔽is twenty-one hundred thousand leagues,🔽and thirty-one thousand leagues besides.

original: Navasatānekatiṃsa, yojanāni ca gāvutaṃ.🔽Pamāṇato samantā ca, maṇḍalaṃ majjhavīthiyā;
analyzed: nava satā anekatiṃsa yojanāni ca gāvutam  pamāṇataḥ ca maṇḍalam majjha vīthiyā
translated: And twenty-nine hundred leagues,

original: Satasahassānūnavīsa, sahassānekatiṃsa ca.
analyzed: ca
translated: and three hundred and twenty-five besides.

original: Satamekañca viññeyyaṃ, pañcasattati uttaraṃ;
analyzed: viññeyyam pañca sattati uttaram
translated: And one hundred and fifty-six, and seventy-five besides,

original: Dakkhiṇaṃ uttarañcāpi, gacchanto pana bhāṇumā.
analyzed: dakkhiṇam uttaram ca api gacchantaḥ pana
translated: He travels, shining, to the south and north.

original: Majjhavīthippamāṇena, maṇḍaleneva gacchati;🔽Gacchanto ca panevaṃ so, oruyhoruyha heṭṭhato.
analyzed: majjha vīthi ppamāṇena maṇḍalena iva gacchati  ca pana ivam saḥ oruyha uruyha heṭṭhataḥ
translated: He travels by the middle way, as it were, by a circle,🔽And as he travels thus, he descends and descends below,

original: Āruyhāruyha uddhañca, yato gacchati sabbadā;
analyzed: āruyha āruyhaḥ uddhan ca yatas gacchati sabbadā
translated: And ascends and ascends above, wherever he goes always;

original: Tato gativasenassa, dūramaddhānamāsi taṃ.
analyzed: tatas gati vasena assa dūram addhānam āsi tam
translated: So his path is long by the reckoning of the way he goes.

original: Tiṃsa satasahassāni, yojanāni pamāṇato;
analyzed: tiṃsa sata sahassāni yojanāni pamāṇataḥ
translated: It is thirty-six hundred thousand leagues

original: Tasmā so parito yāti, tattakaṃva dine dine.
analyzed: saḥ paritas yāti dine dine
translated: in measure, so he travels all round it in just that time each day.

original: Sahassamekaṃ pañcasataṃ, catupaññāsayojanaṃ;
analyzed: sahassam ekam pañca satam catu paññāsa yojanam
translated: One thousand, five hundred, and forty-five leagues,

original: Tigāvutaṃ terasūsabhaṃ, tettiṃsa ratanāni ca.
analyzed: tigāvutam terasūsabham tettiṃsa ratanāni ca
translated: three-quarters, thirteen, a bull, thirty-three, and jewels,

original: Aṭṭhaṅgulāni ca tiriyaṃ, gacchatekadine ravi;
analyzed: aṭṭhaṅgulāni ca gacchatā eka dine ravi
translated: eight inches across, the sun travels in one day.

original: Chatālīsasahassāni, cha satāni tigāvutaṃ.
analyzed: chatālīsa sahassāni cha satāni tigāvutam
translated: Forty-eight thousand, six hundred, three-quarters,

original: Yojanānaṃ titālīsaṃ, māsenekena gacchati;
analyzed: yojanānam titālīsam māsena ekena gacchati
translated: thirty leagues, in one month he travels

original: Tenavutisahassāni, dvisataṃ sattasīti ca.
analyzed: tenavuti sahassāni dvisatam sattasīti ca
translated: in that time twenty thousand, two hundred, seventy-seven,

original: Gāvutāni duve cāpi, dvīhi māsehi gacchati;
analyzed: gāvutāni duve ca api dvīhi māsehi gacchati
translated: and two-thirds, in two months he travels

original: Imāya gatiyā anta-vīthito vīthiantimaṃ.
analyzed: imāya anta vīthitaḥ
translated: in this way from the middle of the way to the end of the way.

original: Gacchati chahi māsehi, timāsehi ca majjhimaṃ;
analyzed: gacchati chahi māsehi ti māsehi ca majjhimam
translated: And in three months to the mountain Sineru.

original: Sinerusantike anta-vīthito pana bhāṇumā;
analyzed: sineru santike anta vīthitaḥ pana
translated: But the moon, from the street near Sineru,

original: Āgacchanto dvimāsehi, assa dīpassa majjhago.
analyzed: āgacchantaḥ dvi māsehi assa dīpassa majjhago
translated: Comes in two months to the middle of the island.🔽Therefore, from the middle of the Sihala Island,

original: Tasmā sīhaḷadīpassa, majjhato meruantaraṃ;
analyzed: tasmā sīhaḷadīpassa majjhatas meru antaram
translated: To the space between the mountains,

original: Duve satasahassāni, dvisatenādhikāni tu.
analyzed: duve sata sahassāni dvi satena adhikāni tu
translated: There are two hundred and twenty thousand,

original: Tettiṃsañca sahassāni, aṭṭhārasa tigāvutaṃ;
analyzed: tettiṃsan ca sahassāni aṭṭhārasa tigāvutam
translated: And eighteen thousand and three hundred and twenty.🔽That is the extent of the world-sphere,

original: Cakkavāḷantarañcassa, dīpasseva ca majjhato.
analyzed: cakkavāḷa antarañcassa dīpassa iva ca majjhataḥ
translated: And the middle of the island.

original: Tīṇi satasahassāni, sahassāni chavīsati;
analyzed: tīṇi sata sahassāni sahassāni chavīsati
translated: There are three hundred and twenty-six thousand,

original: Cha uttarāni pañceva, satānekañca gāvutanti.
analyzed: uttarāni pañca iva satān ekaṃ ca
translated: And five hundred and one hundred and twenty.

original: Evamettha ayampi viseso veditabbo.
analyzed: evam ettha ayam pi visesaḥ veditabbo
translated: Thus this distinction should be understood here.

original: Tāvatiṃsabhavanaṃ dasasahassayojananti ettha tettiṃsa sahapuññakārino ettha nibbattāti
analyzed: tāvatiṃsa bhavanam dasa sahassa yojanam ti ettha tettiṃsa saha puñña kārino ettha nibbattā ti
translated: As for the statement “The Tāvatiṃsa divine world is ten thousand leagues,” there are thirty-three who have performed merit together and are reborn there.

original: taṃsahacaritaṭṭhānaṃ tettiṃsaṃ, tadeva tāvatiṃsaṃ, taṃ nivāso etesanti tāvatiṃsā,
analyzed: tad sahacarita ṭṭhānam tettiṃsam tat eva tāvatiṃsam tam nivāso tāvatiṃsā
translated: The place where they live together is thirty-three, that is Tāvatiṃsa, and they are Tāvatiṃsa because that is their abode.

original: devā, tesaṃ bhavanaṃ tāvatiṃsabhavanaṃ. Tathā hi maghena māṇavena saddhiṃ macalagāmake
analyzed: devā tesam bhavanam tāvatiṃsa bhavanam tathā hi maghena māṇavena saddhim macalagāmake
translated: They are gods, and their world is Tāvatiṃsa. Thus, together with the student Magha, in the village of Macala,

original: kālaṃ katvā tattha uppanne tettiṃsa devaputte upādāya assa devalokassa ayaṃ paṇṇatti
analyzed: kālam katvā tattha uppanne tettiṃsa deva putte upādāya assa deva lokassa ayam paṇṇatti
translated: and the name of the Thirty-Three is derived from the fact that when he was reborn there he was the thirty-third of the gods reborn there.

original: jātāti vadanti. Atha vā yasmā sesacakkavāḷesupi cha kāmāvacaradevalokā atthi. Vuttampi
analyzed: jātā iti vadanti atha vā yasmā sesa cakkavāḷesu pi cha kāmāvacara deva lokāḥ atthi vuttam pi
translated: Or alternatively, since there are also six sense-sphere divine worlds in other world-spheres,

original: cetaṃ “sahassaṃ cātumahārājikānaṃ sahassaṃ tāvatiṃsāna”nti. Tasmā nāmapaṇṇattiyevesā
analyzed: ca itam sahassam cātumahārājikānam sahassam tāvatiṃsānam ti tasmā nāma paṇṇattiyā iva esā
translated: and this is said: “A thousand of the Gods of the Four Kings, a thousand of the Thirty-Three” ,🔽it can be understood that this is a name-pentad for that divine world.

original: tassa devalokassāti veditabbā. Dasasahassayojananti idaṃ pana sakkapuraṃ sandhāya
analyzed: tassa deva lokassa ati veditabbā dasa sahassa yojanam ti idam pana sakkapuram sandhāya
translated: As to “ten thousand leagues”: this should be understood as said of Sakka’s city,

original: vuttanti veditabbaṃ. Tathā hi tāvatiṃsakāyikā devā atthi pabbataṭṭhakā, atthi ākāsaṭṭhakā,
analyzed: vuttam iti veditabbam tathā hi tāvatiṃsa kāyikāḥ devāḥ atthi pabbata ṭṭhakāḥ atthi ākāsa ṭṭhakā
translated: for there are gods of the Thirty-Three living on the mountain and in the sky,

original: tesaṃ paramparā cakkavāḷapabbataṃ pattā, tathā cātumahārājikānaṃ yāmādīnañca. Ekadevalokepi
analyzed: tesam paramparā cakkavāḷa pabbatam pattā tathā cātumahārājikānam yāma ādīnam ca eka deva loke pi
translated: and their succession reaches the world-sphere mountain. So too, that of the Four Kings, the Yāma gods, and so on. For in a single divine world

original: hi devānaṃ paramparā cakkavāḷapabbataṃ appattā nāma natthi. Idaṃ pana tāvatiṃsabhavanaṃ
analyzed: hi devānam paramparā cakkavāḷa pabbatam appattā nāma natthi idam pana tāvatiṃsa bhavanam
translated: there are no gods whose succession does not reach the world-sphere mountain. But this city of the Thirty-Three

original: sinerussa uparimatale dasasahassayojanike ṭhāne patiṭṭhitanti veditabbaṃ. Tassa pācīnapacchimadvārānaṃ
analyzed: sinerussa uparima tale dasa sahassa yojanike ṭhāne patiṭṭhitanti veditabbam tassa pācīna pacchima dvārānam
translated: it should be understood that it is established on the upper surface of Sineru, in a place ten thousand leagues across. The distance between the eastern and western gates of it is

original: antarā dasayojanasahassaṃ hoti, tathā dakkhiṇuttaradvārānaṃ. Taṃ kho pana nagaraṃ
analyzed: antarā dasa yojana sahassam hoti tathā tam kho pana nagaram
translated: ten thousand leagues, and so too the distance between the southern and northern gates. That city

original: dvārasahassayuttaṃ ahosi ārāmapokkharaṇīpaṭimaṇḍitaṃ.🔽Tassa majjhe tiyojanasatubbedhehi, dhajehi paṭimaṇḍito sattaratanamayo sattayojanasatubbedho
analyzed: dvāra sahassa yuttam ahosi ārāma pokkharaṇī paṭimaṇḍitam  tassa majjhe ti yojana satubbedhehi dhajehi paṭimaṇḍitaḥ satta ratana mayaḥ satta yojana satubbedhaḥ
translated: was endowed with a thousand gates and was adorned with parks and lotus-pools.

original: sakkassa vejayanto nāma pāsādo. Tattha suvaṇṇayaṭṭhīsu maṇidhajā ahesuṃ, maṇiyaṭṭhīsu🔽suvaṇṇadhajā, pavāḷayaṭṭhīsu muttadhajā, muttayaṭṭhīsu pavāḷadhajā, sattaratanamayāsu
analyzed: sakkassa vejayantaḥ nāma pāsādo tattha suvaṇṇa yaṭṭhīsu maṇi dhajāḥ ahesuṃ maṇi yaṭṭhīsu  suvaṇṇa dhajā pavāḷa yaṭṭhīsu mutta dhajā mutta yaṭṭhīsu pavāḷa dhajā satta ratana mayāsu
translated: In the middle of it was Sakka’s palace called Vejayanta, which was built of the seven precious substances, was seven hundred leagues high, and was adorned with banners a hundred leagues high. On the golden pillars there were jeweled banners, on the jeweled pillars

original: yaṭṭhīsu sattaratanamayā dhajā.
analyzed: yaṭṭhīsu satta ratana mayāḥ dhajā
translated: there were golden banners, on the coral pillars there were pearl banners, on the pearl pillars there were coral banners, and on the pillars made of the seven precious substances there were banners made of the seven precious substances.

original: Diyaḍḍhayojanasatāyāmo vejayantaratho. Tassa hi pacchimanto paṇṇāsayojano, majjhe
analyzed: diyaḍḍha yojana sata āyāmaḥ vejayantaratho tassa hi pacchimantaḥ paṇṇāsa yojanaḥ majjhe
translated: The Vejayanta chariot was two hundred and fifty leagues long. For its western end was fifty leagues, and its middle

original: rathapañjaro paṇṇāsayojano, rathasandhito yāva rathasīsā paṇṇāseva yojanāni. Tadeva
analyzed: ratha pañjaraḥ paṇṇāsa yojanaḥ ratha sandhitaḥ yāva ratha sīsā paṇṇāsā iva yojanāni tat eva
translated: The chariot-fence is fifty leagues in extent, and the distance from the chariot-pole to the chariot-front is also fifty leagues.

original: pamāṇaṃ diguṇaṃ katvā “tiyojanasatāyāmo”tipi vadantiyeva. Tasmiṃ yojanikapallaṅko
analyzed: pamāṇam diguṇam katvā tasmin yojanika pallaṅkaḥ
translated: They say that the extent of the chariot-bed is two hundred and fifty leagues.

original: atthato tiṭṭhati. Tattha tiyojanikaṃ setacchattaṃ, ekasmiṃyeva yuge sahassaājaññayuttaṃ.
analyzed: atthatas tiṭṭhati tattha ti yojanikam seta chattam ekasmiṃ yeva yuge sahassa ājañña yuttam
translated: The white parasol stands on the chariot-bed, and it is yoked to a thousand thoroughbreds.

original: Sesālaṅkārassa pamāṇaṃ natthi. Dhajo panassa aḍḍhatiyāni yojanasatāni uggato, yassa
analyzed: sesa alaṅkārassa pamāṇam natthi dhajaḥ panassa aḍḍhatiyāni yojana satāni uggataḥ yassa
translated: The other ornaments have no fixed size. But the flag-staff rises two hundred and fifty leagues,

original: vātāhatassa pañcaṅgikatūriyasseva saddo niccharati.

analyzed: sakkassa pana erāvaṇaḥ nāma hatthī diyaḍḍha yojana satikaḥ saḥ api na hi
translated: Sakka’s elephant, named E rahawn, is two and a half leagues high. He too is a deity.

original: devalokasmiṃ tiracchānagatā honti, tasmā so uyyānakīḷāya nikkhamanakāle attabhāvaṃ
analyzed: deva lokasmim tiracchāna gatāḥ honti tasmai saḥ uyyāna kīḷāya nikkhamana kāle atta bhāvam
translated: For there are no animals in the deva world. So when he goes out to play in the pleasure garden he abandons his own form

analyzed: vijahitvā diyaḍḍha yojana satikaḥ erāvaṇaḥ nāma hatthī hoti saḥ tettiṃsa kumbhe māpeti

analyzed: āvaṭṭena gāvuta aḍḍha yojana ppamāṇe sabbesam majjhe sakkassa atthāya sudassanam nāma

analyzed: tiṃsa yojanikam kumbham māpeti tassa upari dvādasa yojanikaḥ ratana maṇḍapaḥ hoti tattha
translated: 32 leagues high, and above it a jeweled pavilion 12 leagues high. In between,

original: antarantarā sattaratanamayā yojanubbedhā dhajā uṭṭhahanti. Pariyante kiṅkiṇikajālā
analyzed: antar antarā satta ratana mayāḥ dhajāḥ uṭṭhahanti pariyante kiṅkiṇika jālā
translated: standards of the seven precious things, a league high, are erected. At the edge, nets of little bells

analyzed: olambanti yassa manda vāta īritassa pañcaṅgika tūriya sadda sadisaḥ dibba gīta saddaḥ viya
translated: hang down, and when stirred by a gentle breeze, they give forth a sound like the sound of the five-fold musical instrument, like the sound of divine music.

original: ravo niccharati. Maṇḍapamajjhe sakkassa yojaniko maṇipallaṅko paññatto hoti, tattha
analyzed: ravaḥ niccharati maṇḍapa majjhe sakkassa yojanikaḥ maṇi pallaṅkaḥ paññattaḥ hoti tattha
translated: In the middle of the pavilion, a jeweled couch 1 league high is prepared for Sakka, where he sits.

analyzed: sakkaḥ nisīdati tettiṃsāya kumbhānam ekekasmin kumbhe satta satta dante māpeti tesu

analyzed: ekekaḥ paṇṇāsa yojana āyāmaḥ ekekasmin ca ittha dante satta satta pokkharaṇiyaḥ honti ekekāya

analyzed: pokkharaṇiyā satta satta paduminīgacchāḥ ekekasmin gacche satta satta pupphāni honti

translated: So too are the Nandana Grove and the Phārusaka Grove. Sakka, surrounded by the bevies of celestial nymphs, descends into the sixty-league Golden Palace,

analyzed: tassa mūle saṭṭhi yojana āyāmā paññāsa yojana vitthārā pañcadasa yojana ubbedhā

When the pāricchattaka coral tree is in flower there is no need to climb up to it or to take a goad and prod it or to take a basket and pick the flowers. The flowers fall on to the ground by themselves,

translated: just make as if you are drinking.” They did so. The resident deities drank the perfume-drink, which was brought in golden beakers,🔽as much as they wanted, and, intoxicated, they lay down here and there on the golden ground. Sakka had them seized by the feet and thrown

analyzed: tattha dvinnam dvinnam deva asura nagara anaṃ antarā ati attho dve kira  nagarāni yuddhena gahetum a sakkuṇeyya tāya ayujjhapurāni nāma jātāni yadā hi asurā
