original: asuranagaraṃ pavisitvā dvāre pihite sakkānaṃ satasahassampi kiñci kātuṃ na sakkoti.
analyzed: asura nagaram pavisitvā dvāre pihite sakkānam sata sahassam pi kiñci kātum na sakkoti
translated: cannot do anything to them. When the gods are powerful, then the titans flee and enter the city of the titans and shut the gates. Then even a hundred thousand Sakkas cannot do anything to them.

original: Iti imāni dve nagarāni ayujjhapurāni nāma. Tesaṃ antarā etesu uragādīsu pañcasu ṭhānesu
analyzed: iti imāni dve nagarāni ayujjhapurāni nāma tesam antarā etesu uraga ādīsu pañcasu ṭhānesu
translated: So these two cities are called “that cannot be attacked.” Between them, in these five places beginning with the snake,

original: sakkena ārakkhā ṭhapitā. Tattha uragasaddena nāgā gahitā. Te udake mahabbalā honti,
analyzed: sakkena ārakkhā ṭhapitā tattha uraga saddena nāgāḥ gahitā te udake mahabbalāḥ honti
translated: Sakka set up a guard there. The serpents were caught by the sound of the serpent-demon. They are very powerful in the water,

original: tasmā sinerussa paṭhamālinde etesaṃ ārakkhā. Sinerussa kira samantato bahalato puthulato
analyzed: tasmā sinerussa paṭhama alinde etesam ārakkhā sinerussa kira samantataḥ bahalataḥ puthulataḥ
translated: therefore, the guard of these is on the first terrace of Sineru. It is said that all around Sineru, in thickness and breadth,

original: ca pañcayojanasahassaparimāṇāni cattāri paribhaṇḍāni tāvatiṃsabhavanassa ārakkhāya🔽nāgehi garuḷehi kumbhaṇḍehi yakkhehi ca adhiṭṭhitāni. Tehi kira sinerussa upaḍḍhaṃ🔽pariyādinnaṃ, etāniyeva ca sinerussa ālindāni mekhalāni ca vuccanti. Karoṭisaddena
analyzed: ca pañca yojana sahassa parimāṇāni cattāri paribhaṇḍāni tāvatiṃsa bhavanassa ārakkhāya  nāgehi garuḷehi kumbhaṇḍehi yakkhehi ca adhiṭṭhitāni tehi kira sinerussa upaḍḍham  pariyādinnam ca sinerussa ālindāni mekhalāni ca vuccanti karoṭi saddena
translated: the four outer walls are five thousand leagues in extent. They are occupied by the gods of the Thirty-three for the protection of their abode.🔽It is said that they have taken over half of Sineru. These are called the terraces and the girdles of Sineru. By the sound of the crow,

original: supaṇṇā gahitā. Tesaṃ kira karoṭi nāma pānabhojanaṃ, tena nāmaṃ labhiṃsu, dutiyālinde
analyzed: supaṇṇā gahitā tesam kira karoṭi nāma pāna bhojanam tena nāmam labhiṃsu dutiyālinde
translated: the Supaṇṇas were caught. It is said that their food and drink is called a crow, therefore they got their name. The guard of these is on the second terrace.

original: tesaṃ ārakkhā. Payassahārīsaddena kumbhaṇḍā gahitā. Dānavarakkhasā kira te, tatiyālinde
analyzed: tesam ārakkhā payassahārī saddena kumbhaṇḍā gahitā dānava rakkhasā kira te tatiyā alinde
translated: By the sound of the Payas-harīta, the Kumbhaṇḍas were caught. It is said that they are Dānavas and Rākṣasas. The guard of these is on the third terrace.

original: tesaṃ ārakkhā. Madanayutasaddena yakkhā gahitā. Visamacārino kira te yuddhasoṇḍā,
analyzed: tesam ārakkhāḥ madana yuta saddena yakkhāḥ gahitāḥ visama cārinaḥ kira te yuddha soṇḍā
translated: By the sound of the Madana-yuta, the Yakkhas were caught. It is said that they are of uneven conduct, warriors in battle,

original: catutthālinde tesaṃ ārakkhā. Caturo ca mahatthāti cattāro mahārājāno vuttā. Te hi🔽sinerussa tasmiṃ tasmiṃ passe yugandharādīsu pañcasataparittadīpaparivāre mahādīpe
analyzed: catuttha alinde tesam ārakkhā caturo ca cattāro mahā rājānaḥ vuttā te hi  sinerussa tasmim tasmim passe yugandhara ādīsu pañca sata paritta dīpa parivāre mahā dīpe
translated: and the fourth terrace is their protection.🔽The four great treasures are the four Great Kings. For they are called “great treasures” because of the great treasure that has to be ruled by them in the four world-spheres of Yugandhara, etc., which are the four great islands surrounded by five hundred medium-sized islands and by the lesser islands.

original: ca sāsitabbassa mahato atthassa vasena “mahatthā”ti vuccanti, pañcamālinde tesaṃ ārakkhā.
analyzed: ca sāsitabbassa mahataḥ atthassa vasena mahatthā ati vuccanti pañcamālinde tesam ārakkhā
translated: And the fifth terrace is their protection.

original: Te pana asurā āyuvaṇṇayasaissariyasampattīhi tāvatiṃsasadisāva. Tasmā antarā attānaṃ
analyzed: te pana asurāḥ āyu vaṇṇaya saissariya sampattīhi tāvatiṃsa sadisā ava tasmai antarā
translated: But the asuras are equal to the Tāvatiṃsa in their life span, complexion, fame, and sovereignty. Therefore, not recognizing themselves

original: ajānitvā pāṭaliyā pupphitāya “nayidaṃ devanagaraṃ, tattha pāricchattako pupphati,
analyzed: a jānitvā pāṭaliyā pupphitāya na yidam devanagaram tattha pāricchattakaḥ pupphati
translated: in the flowering pāṭalī tree, they said, “This is not the city of the gods. There the pāricchattaka tree flowers,

original: idha pana cittapāṭalī, jarasakkena mayaṃ suraṃ pāyetvā vañcitā, devanagarañca no
analyzed: idha pana cittapāṭalī jarasakkena mayam suram vañcitā deva nagaram ca no
translated: but here the citrapāṭalī. We have been deceived by the old Sakka after he had made us drink liquor. He has taken our city of the gods.

original: gahitaṃ, gacchāma tena saddhiṃ yujjhissāmā”ti hatthiassarathe āruyha suvaṇṇarajatamaṇiphalakāni
analyzed: gahitam gacchāma tena saddhim yujjhissāma ati hatthi assa rathe āruyha suvaṇṇa rajata maṇi phalakāni
translated: Let us go and fight with him.” They mounted their elephants and horses and chariots, taking with them golden, silver, and gem-studded shields,

original: gahetvā yuddhasajjā hutvā asurabheriyo vādentā mahāsamudde udakaṃ dvidhā bhinditvā
analyzed: gahetvā yuddha sajjāḥ hutvā asura bheriyaḥ vādentāḥ mahā samudde udakam dvidhā bhinditvā
translated: and, ready for battle, they beat the asura drums and split the ocean in two.

original: uṭṭhahanti. Te deve vuṭṭhe vammikamakkhikā vammikaṃ viya sineruṃ abhiruhituṃ ārabhanti.🔽Atha nesaṃ paṭhamaṃ nāgehi saddhiṃ yuddhaṃ hoti. Tasmiṃ kho pana yuddhe na kassaci
analyzed: uṭṭhahanti te deve vuṭṭhe vammika makkhikāḥ vammikam viya sinerum abhiruhitum ārabhanti  atha na isam paṭhamam nāgehi saddhim yuddham hoti tasmim kho pana yuddhe na kassaci
translated: and they rise up. When the gods have risen, they begin to climb Sineru as the ants do the ant-hill.🔽And in that battle no one’s skin or hide or flesh or sinews or bones are cut,

original: chavi vā cammaṃ vā chijjati, na lohitaṃ uppajjati, kevalaṃ kumārakānaṃ dārumeṇḍakayuddhaṃ
analyzed: chavi vā cammam vā chijjati na lohitam uppajjati kevalam kumārakānam dāru meṇḍaka yuddham
translated: nor does blood appear. It is just a case of terrifying each other, like boys playing with wooden swords.

original: viya aññamaññaṃ santāsanamattameva hoti. Koṭisatāpi koṭisahassāpi nāgā tehi saddhiṃ
analyzed: viya aññamaññam santāsana mattam eva hoti koṭi satā api koṭi sahassā api nāgā tehi saddhim
translated: Even though a hundred or a thousand koṭis of nāgas fight with them,

original: yujjhitvā asurapuraṃyeva pavesetvā nivattanti. Sace pana asurā balavanto honti, atha
analyzed: yujjhitvā asura puraṃyā iva pavesetvā nivattanti sace pana asurāḥ balavantaḥ honti atha
translated: the asuras drive them back into the asura city and then return there themselves. But if the asuras are strong,

original: nāgā osakkitvā dutiye ālinde supaṇṇehi saddhiṃ ekato hutvā yujjhanti. Esa nayo supaṇṇādīsupi.🔽Yadā pana tāni pañcapi ṭhānāni asurā maddanti, tadā ekato sampiṇḍitānipi tāni pañca
analyzed: nāgāḥ osakkitvā dutiye ālinde supaṇṇehi saddhim ekatas hutvā yujjhanti esa nayaḥ supaṇṇa ādīsu pi  yadā pana tāni ṭhānāni asurāḥ maddanti tadā ekatas sampiṇḍitāni pi tāni pañca
translated: then the nāgas retreat and join forces with the supaṇṇas on the second terrace and fight together with them. The same method applies in the case of the supaṇṇas and the rest.

original: balāni osakkanti. Atha cattāro mahārājāno gantvā sakkassa pavattiṃ ārocenti. Sakko
analyzed: balāni osakkanti atha cattāraḥ mahā rājānaḥ gantvā sakkassa pavattim ārocenti sakko
translated: But when the asuras attack all five places, then all five armies combined retreat. Then the Four Great Kings go and report the matter to Sakka.

original: tesaṃ vacanaṃ sutvā diyaḍḍhayojanasatikaṃ vejayantarathaṃ āruyha sayaṃ vā nikkhamati,
analyzed: tesam vacanam sutvā diyaḍḍha yojana satikam vejayanta ratham āruyha sayam vā nikkhamati
translated: and after hearing their words he either goes out himself in the Vejayanta chariot, which is two and a half leagues high,

original: ekaṃ vā puttaṃ peseti. Ekasmiṃ pana divase evaṃ nikkhamitvā asure yuddhena abbhuggantvā
analyzed: ekam vā puttam peseti ekasmin pana divase evam nikkhamitvā asure yuddhena abbhut gantvā
translated: or he sends one of his sons. But on one occasion, after going out in this way and defeating the asuras in battle,

original: samudde pakkhipitvā catūsu dvāresu attanā sadisā paṭimā māpetvā ṭhapeti, tasmā asurā
analyzed: samudde pakkhipitvā catūsu dvāresu attanā sadisā paṭimā māpetvā ṭhapeti tasmai asurā
translated: he threw them into the ocean and had statues of himself made at the four gates and placed there. Therefore,

original: nāgādayo jinitvā āgatāpi indapaṭimā disvā “sakko nikkhanto”ti palāyanti. Iti surānaṃ
analyzed: nāga ādayaḥ jinitvā āgatā api inda paṭimāḥ disvā sakko nikkhanto ti palāyanti iti
translated: when the asuras, nāgas, and so on, have been defeated and have come back, when they see the statue of Indra, they think, “Sakka has come out,” and they flee. Thus the asuras

original: paṭipakkhāti asurā, vepacittipahārādādayo, tesaṃ bhavanaṃ asurabhavanaṃ. Taṃ pana
analyzed: asurāḥ tesam bhavanam asura bhavanam tam pana
translated: are the enemies of the gods. Vepacitti, Pahārāda, and so on, are asuras. Their abode is the asura abode. But that

original: āyāmato ca vitthārato ca dasasahassayojananti dassetuṃ “tathā asurabhavana”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: āyāmato ca vitthārato ca dasa sahassa yojanan ti dassetum tathā asura bhavanan ti vuttam
translated: is ten thousand leagues in length and breadth. Thus the asura abode is ten thousand leagues.

original: Avīcimahānirayo jambudīpo cāti etthāpi tathā-saddo yojetabbo, avīcimahānirayo jambudīpo
analyzed: avīci mahānirayaḥ ca ati ettha api tathā saddaḥ yojetabbaḥ avīci mahānirayaḥ jambudīpo
translated: The Avīci great hell and the Rose-Apple Land. Here too the word thus should be construed. The Avīci great hell and the Rose-Apple Land

original: ca tathā dasasahassayojanamevāti attho. Ettha ca avīcimahānirayassa abbhantaraṃ āyāmena
analyzed: ca tathā dasa sahassa yojanam eva ati attho ettha ca avīci mahānirayassa abbhantaram āyāmena
translated: are thus ten thousand leagues. The meaning is: they are ten thousand leagues in length and breadth. And here, inside the Avīci great hell, in length and breadth,

original: ca vitthārena ca yojanasataṃ hoti, lohapathavī lohachadanaṃ ekekā ca bhitti navanavayojanikā🔽hoti. Puratthimāya bhittiyā acci uṭṭhahitvā pacchimaṃ bhittiṃ gahetvā taṃ vinivijjhitvā🔽parato yojanasataṃ gacchati. Sesadisāsupi eseva nayo. Iti jālapariyantavasena āyāmavitthārato
analyzed: ca vitthārena ca yojana satam hoti loha pathavī loha chadanam ekekā ca bhitti nava nava yojanikā  hoti puratthimāya bhittiyā acci uṭṭhahitvā pacchimam bhittim gahetvā tam vinivijjhitvā  paratas yojana satam gacchati iti jāla pariyanta vasena āyāma vitthārato
translated: and it is a hundred leagues in extent. The iron surface of the earth is the iron floor. Each wall is nine hundred leagues high.

original: aṭṭhārasayojanādhikāni tīṇi yojanasatāni honti, parikkhepena nava yojanasatāni catupaṇṇāsañca
analyzed: aṭṭhārasa yojana adhikāni tīṇi yojana satāni honti parikkhepena nava yojana satāni catu paṇṇāsam ca
translated: When the flames arise and seize hold of the eastern wall, they cross over to the western wall, burning through it and going a hundred leagues beyond. The same happens in the other directions. So, as far as the extent of the net of flames is concerned, it is three hundred and eighteen leagues in length and breadth,

original: yojanāni. Samantā pana ussadehi saddhiṃ dasayojanasahassaṃ hoti. Kasmā panesa narako🔽“avīcī”ti saṅkhyaṃ gatoti? Vīci nāma antaraṃ vuccati, tattha ca aggijālānaṃ vā sattānaṃ
analyzed: yojanāni samantā pana ussadehi saddhim dasa yojana sahassam hoti kasmā pana isa narakaḥ  avīci iti saṅkhyam gataḥ ti nāma antaram vuccati tattha ca aggi jālānam vā sattānam
translated: and by perimeter it is nine hundred and sixty-eight leagues. But with the surrounding mountains it is ten thousand leagues all round. But why is this hell called “Avīci”?🔽The word “avīci” is said to mean “without interval.” There is no interval, that is to say, no break, in the net of flames or in the suffering of the beings there. That is why it is called “Avīci.”

original: vā dukkhassa vā antaraṃ natthi, tasmā so “avīcī”ti saṅkhyaṃ gato. Tassa hi puratthimabhittito
analyzed: vā dukkhassa vā antaram natthi tasmā so avīci iti saṅkhyam gataḥ tassa hi puratthima bhittitaḥ
translated: For when the flames arise and seize hold of the eastern wall,

original: jālā uṭṭhahitvā saṃsibbamānayojanasataṃ gantvā bhittiṃ vinivijjhitvā parato yojanasataṃ🔽gacchati. Sesadisāsupi eseva nayo. Evaṃ jālānaṃ nirantaratāya avīci. Abbhantare panassa
analyzed: jālā uṭṭhahitvā saṃsibbamāna yojana satam gantvā bhittim vinivijjhitvā paratas yojana satam  gacchati esa iva nayaḥ evam jālānam nirantara tāya avīci abbhantare panassa
translated: The flames rise up and spread out a hundred leagues, and after piercing the walls, they go out a hundred leagues in all directions. This is the meaning of “uninterrupted” (avīci). But inside it🔽

original: yojanasatike ṭhāne nāḷiyaṃ koṭṭetvā pūritatipupiṭṭhaṃ viya sattā nirantarā, “imasmiṃ
analyzed: yojana satike ṭhāne nāḷiyam koṭṭetvā pūrita tipu piṭṭham viya sattāḥ nirantarāḥ imasmin
translated: The flames rise up and spread out to a hundred leagues, and then they break through the wall and go out beyond it for a hundred leagues. The same happens in the other directions. Thus it is ‘unbroken’ because of the unbroken continuity of the flames.

original: ṭhāne satto atthi, imasmiṃ ṭhāne natthī”ti na vattabbaṃ, gacchantānaṃ ṭhitānaṃ nisinnānaṃ
analyzed: ṭhāne sattaḥ atthi imasmin ṭhāne natthi iti na vattabbam gacchantānam ṭhitānam nisinnānam
translated: And the beings there are packed together without any interstice, like sesame seeds in a sesame pod. They cannot be said to be ‘here’ or ‘there.’

original: nipannānañca paccamānānaṃ anto natthi, gacchantā ṭhite vā nisinne vā nipanne vā na
analyzed: nipannānam ca paccamānānam antaḥ natthi gacchantā ṭhite vā nisinne vā nipanne vā na
translated: They cannot go about, stand, sit, or lie down.

original: bādhenti. Evaṃ sattānaṃ nirantaratāya avīci. Kāyadvāre pana cha upekkhāsahagatāni🔽cittāni uppajjanti, ekaṃ dukkhasahagataṃ. Evaṃ santepi yathā jivhāgge cha madhubindūni
analyzed: bādhenti evam sattānam nirantara tāya avīci kāya dvāre pana cha upekkhā sahagatāni  cittāni uppajjanti ekam dukkha sahagatam evam sante pi yathā jivhā agge cha madhu bindūni
translated: They are all on fire, and yet they are not consumed, because of the kamma of beings.🔽Six kinds of consciousness accompanied by equanimity arise in the body door, and one kind accompanied by pain.

original: ṭhapetvā ekasmiṃ tambalohabindumhi ṭhapite anudahanabalavatāya tadeva paññāyati,
analyzed: ṭhapetvā ekasmin tamba loha bindumhi ṭhapite anudahana balavatāya tat eva paññāyati
translated: Even so, just as when six drops of honey are placed on the tip of the tongue and one drop of poison, the latter is overpowered by the honey and cannot be felt,

original: itarāni abbohārikāni honti, evaṃ anudahanabalavatāya dukkhamevettha nirantaraṃ, itarāni🔽abbohārikānīti evaṃ dukkhassa nirantaratāya avīcīti vuccati. “Ayañca avīcimahānirayo
analyzed: itarāni abbohārikāni honti evam anudahana balavatāya dukkham eva itthā nirantaram itarāni  abbohārikāni iti evam dukkhassa nirantara tāya avīci iti vuccati ayam ca avīci mahānirayo
translated: The rest are not so. Thus it is because of the absence of any interval of pleasure that it is called Avīci, ‘Uninterrupted’.

original: jambudīpassa heṭṭhā patiṭṭhito”ti vadanti.
analyzed: jambudīpassa heṭṭhā patiṭṭhito ti vadanti
translated: And this great hell Avīci is established beneath this very Rose-Apple Isle, they say.

original: Jambudīpo pana āyāmato ca vitthārato ca dasasahassayojanaparimāṇo. Tattha ca catusahassayojanappamāṇo
analyzed: jambudīpo pana āyāmato ca vitthārato ca dasa sahassa yojana parimāṇaḥ tattha ca catu sahassa yojana ppamāṇaḥ
translated: But the Rose-Apple Isle is ten thousand leagues in extent both ways, and of that

original: padeso tadupabhogīsattānaṃ puññakkhayā udakena ajjhotthaṭo “samuddo”ti saṅkhyaṃ gato.🔽Tisahassayojanappamāṇe manussā vasanti, tisahassayojanappamāṇe himavā patiṭṭhitoti veditabbo.
analyzed: padesaḥ tad upabhogī sattānam puñña kkhayā udakena ajjhotthaṭaḥ samuddaḥ iti saṅkhyam gataḥ  ti sahassa yojana ppamāṇe manussāḥ vasanti ti sahassa yojana ppamāṇe himavā patiṭṭhito iti veditabbaḥ
translated: a region four thousand leagues in extent is submerged beneath the water. That is called the ‘ocean’.

original: Aparagoyānaṃ sattasahassayojanantiādīsu āyāmato ca vitthārato ca pamāṇaṃ dassitanti
analyzed: apara goyānam satta sahassa yojana nti ādīsu āyāmato ca vitthārato ca pamāṇam dassitanti
translated: Human beings live in the three thousand leagues that are above the water. And the Himalayas are to be found in the three thousand leagues of land, it should be understood.

original: veditabbaṃ. Tattha jambudīpo sakaṭasaṇṭhāno, channavutiyā paṭṭanakoṭisatasahassehi
analyzed: veditabbam tattha jambudīpo sakaṭa saṇṭhāno channavutiyā paṭṭana koṭi sata sahassehi
translated: In the case of the other continents, the extent should be understood as stated. There the Rose-Apple Isle is shaped like a chariot, and it has nine hundred and ninety-one leagues of coves and inlets.

original: chapaṇṇāsaratanāgārehi navanavutiyā doṇamukhasatasahassehi tikkhattuṃ tesaṭṭhiyā
analyzed: chapaṇṇāsa rata nāgārehi nava navutiyā doṇa mukha sata sahassehi tikkhattum tesaṭṭhiyā
translated: with 990,000,000 bejewelled palm-leaf buildings, three times 36,000

original: nagarasahassehi ca samannāgato. Jambudīpe kira ādito tesaṭṭhimattāni nagarasahassāni
analyzed: nagara sahassehi ca samannāgataḥ jambudīpe kira āditas tesaṭṭhimattāni nagara sahassāni
translated: and with 990,000,000 Chapaṇṇasara Jewel-houses, and with 36,000 cities. In the Rose-Apple Land, it seems, 36,000 cities were first built,

original: uppannāni, tathā dutiyaṃ, tathā tatiyaṃ. Tāni pana sampiṇḍetvā satasahassaṃ, tato
analyzed: uppannāni tathā dutiyam tathā tatiyam tāni pana sampiṇḍetvā sata sahassam tatas
translated: and then a second 36,000, and then a third. When these are added together, they make 100,000,

original: paraṃ asīti sahassāni ca nava sahassāni ca honti. Doṇamukhanti ca mahānagarassa āyuppattiṭṭhānabhūtaṃ
analyzed: param asīti sahassāni ca nava sahassāni ca honti doṇamukhanti ca mahānagarassa āyu ppatti ṭṭhāna bhūtam
translated: and after that there are 89,000 more. The “Jewel-house” is the meditation room that is the means for the city’s survival.🔽The Western Continent is the shape of a half-moon,

original: padhānagharaṃ vuccati. Aparagoyāno ādāsasaṇṭhāno, pubbavideho aḍḍhacandasaṇṭhāno,🔽uttarakuru pīṭhasaṇṭhāno. “Taṃtaṃnivāsīnaṃ taṃtaṃparivāradīpavāsīnañca manussānaṃ
analyzed: padhānagharam vuccati aparagoyānaḥ ādāsa saṇṭhāno pubbavidehaḥ aḍḍhacanda saṇṭhāno  uttarakuru manussānam
translated: the Northern Continent is the shape of a chair.

original: mukhampi taṃtaṃsaṇṭhāna”nti vadanti.
analyzed: mukham pi vadanti
translated: They say that the faces of the people who live there and of those who live in the other continents are the same shape as the continents.

original: Api cettha uttarakurukānaṃ puññānubhāvasiddho ayampi viseso veditabbo. Tattha kira
analyzed: api ca ittha uttarakurukānam puñña anubhāva siddho ayam pi visesaḥ veditabbaḥ tattha kira
translated: But this difference should be understood as established by the power of the merit of those who live in the Northern Continent. For it seems that

original: tesu tesu padesesu ghananicitapattasañchannasākhāpasākhā kūṭāgārupamā manoramā rukkhā
analyzed: tesu tesu padesesu ghana nicita patta sañchanna sākhā apasākhā kūṭāgāra upamāḥ manoramāḥ rukkhāḥ
translated: The trees are delightful, with branches and twigs covered with thick foliage, like a peaked house.

original: tesaṃ manussānaṃ nivesanakiccaṃ sādhenti. Yattha sukhaṃ nivasanti, aññepi tattha
analyzed: tesam manussānam nivesana kiccam sādhenti yattha sukham nivasanti aññe api tattha
translated: They serve the purpose of dwellings for the people. Wherever they live happily,

original: rukkhā sujātā sabbadāpi pupphitaggā tiṭṭhanti. Jalāsayāpi vikasitapadumapuṇḍarīkasogandhikādipupphasañchannā
analyzed: rukkhā su jātā sabbadā api pupphi taggā tiṭṭhanti jalāsayā api vikasita paduma puṇḍarīka sogandhika ādi puppha sañchannā
translated: the trees are well-formed and always stand with flowering tops. The water-basins are covered with blooming paduma, puṇḍarīka, sogandhika, and other flowers,

original: sabbakālaṃ paramasugandhā samantato pavāyantā tiṭṭhanti.
analyzed: sabbakālam parama sugandhā samantataḥ pavāyantā tiṭṭhanti
translated: always standing with the most fragrant scent pervading everywhere.

original: Sarīrampi tesaṃ atidīghatādidosarahitaṃ ārohapariṇāhasampannaṃ jarāya anabhibhūtattā🔽valitapalitādidosavirahitaṃ yāvatāyukaṃ aparikkhīṇajavabalaparakkamasobhameva hutvā
analyzed: sarīram pi ati dīgha tā ādi dosa rahitam āroha pariṇāha sampannam jarāya  valita palita ādi dosa virahitam yāvatāyukam a parikkhīṇa java bala parakkama sobham eva hutvā
translated: Their bodies are free from being too tall or too short, and have the perfection of height and width. Because they are not overcome by old age,🔽they are free from the faults of wrinkles, grey hair, and so on. As long as they live, they stand with undiminished speed, strength, and beauty,

original: tiṭṭhati. Anuṭṭhānaphalūpajīvitāya na ca tesaṃ kasivaṇijjādivasena āhārapariyeṭṭhivasena
analyzed: tiṭṭhati anuṭṭhāna phala upajīvitāya na ca tesam kasi vaṇijja ādi vasena āhāra pariyeṭṭhi vasena
translated: living off the fruits of their efforts. They do not have to search for food through farming, trade, and so on,

original: dukkhaṃ atthi, tato eva na dāsadāsīkammakarādipariggaho atthi. Na ca tattha sītuṇhaḍaṃsamakasavātātapasarīsapavāḷādiparissayo
analyzed: dukkham atthi tatas eva na dāsa dāsī kammakara ādi pariggahaḥ atthi na ca tattha sītuṇha ḍaṃsa makasa vāta ātapa sarīsa pavāḷa ādi parissayaḥ
translated: and because of that there is no keeping of slaves, servants, and so on. And there is no affliction there of cold, heat, gadflies, flies, wind, sun, and creeping things,

original: atthi. Yathā nāmettha gimhānaṃ pacchime māse paccūsavelāyaṃ samasītuṇho utu hoti,
analyzed: atthi yathā nāma ittha gimhānam pacchime māse paccūsavelāyam utu hoti
translated: as there is here in the last month of the Rains, in the cold weather, in the middle of the day.

original: evameva sabbakālaṃ tattha samasītuṇhova utu hoti, na ca nesaṃ koci upaghāto vihesā vā uppajjati.🔽Akaṭṭhapākimameva sāliṃ akaṇaṃ athusaṃ suddhaṃ sugandhaṃ taṇḍulaphalaṃ niddhūmaṅgārena🔽agginā pacitvā paribhuñjanti. Tattha kira jotikapāsāṇā nāma honti, atha te tayo pāsāṇe
analyzed: evam eva sabbakālam tattha hoti na ca nesam koci upaghātaḥ vihesā vā uppajjati  sālim akaṇam athusam suddham su gandham taṇḍula phalam niddhūma aṅgārena  agginā pacitvā paribhuñjanti tattha kira jotikapāsāṇāḥ nāma honti atha te tayo pāsāṇe
translated: But there the weather is always neither cold nor hot, like the weather in this country in the middle of the second month of the Rains. And they have no affliction or discomfort.🔽They eat only rice that is free from powder, husk and dust, which has been washed clean, and it is cooked with no fuel other than fire.🔽There are stones called ‘lamps’ there, it seems; they put the cooking-pot on three of them,

original: ṭhapetvā tattha ukkhaliṃ āropenti, pāsāṇehi tejo samuṭṭhahitvā taṃ pāceti, añño sūpo🔽vā byañjano vā na hoti, bhuñjantānaṃ cittānukūloyevassa raso hoti. Taṃ pana bhuñjantānaṃ
analyzed: ṭhapetvā tattha ukkhalim āropenti pāsāṇehi tejaḥ samuṭṭhahitvā tam pāceti aññaḥ sūpo 🔽vā byañjanaḥ vā na hoti bhuñjantānam citta anukūlaḥ yeva assa rasaḥ hoti tam pana bhuñjantānam
translated: and the heat produced by the contact of the stones cooks it. There is no soup or curry, only the rice, and the flavour is just right for their taste.

original: nesaṃ kuṭṭhaṃ gaṇḍo kilāso soso kāso apamāro jaroti evamādiko na koci rogo uppajjati.
analyzed: kuṭṭham gaṇḍo kilāso sosaḥ kāso apamāro jaroti evamādikaḥ na koci rogaḥ uppajjati
translated: No one has any disease such as leprosy, boils, eczema, diabetes, coughs, fevers, or tumours.

original: Te taṃ ṭhānaṃ sampattānaṃ dentiyeva, macchariyacittaṃ nāma neva hoti, buddhapaccekabuddhādayopi
analyzed: te tam ṭhānam sampattānam dentiyā iva mad śariya cittam nāma na iva hoti buddha paccekabuddha ādayaḥ api
translated: They give to anyone who arrives there. They do not have a miserly mind. Even the Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, etc.,

original: mahiddhikā tattha gantvā piṇḍapātaṃ gaṇhanti. Na ca te khujjā vā vāmanā vā kāṇā vā
analyzed: tattha gantvā piṇḍapātam gaṇhanti na ca te khujjāḥ vā vāmanāḥ vā kāṇāḥ vā
translated: who have great psychic power, go there and take alms. And they are not hunchbacked, dwarfed, one-eyed,

original: kuṇī vā khañjā vā pakkhahatā vā vikalaṅgā vā vikalindriyā vā honti.🔽Itthiyopi tattha nātidīghā nātirassā nātikisā nātithūlā nātikāḷikā nāccodātā sobhaggappattarūpā
analyzed: kuṇī vā khañjāḥ vā pakkha hatāḥ vā vikalaṅgāḥ vā vikalindriyāḥ vā honti  itthiyaḥ pi tattha na ati dīghā na ati rassā na ati kisā na ati thūlā na ati kāḷikā na accodātā sobhagga ppatta rūpā
translated: lame, crippled, paralysed, or deformed.🔽The women there are not too tall or too short, too fat or too thin, too dark or too fair. They have perfect beauty.

original: honti. Tathā hi dīghaṅgulī tambanakhā alambathanā tanumajjhā puṇṇacandamukhī visālakkhī
analyzed: honti tathā hi dīghaṅgulī tambanakhā alambathanā tanumajjhā puṇṇacandamukhī visālakkhī
translated: They have long fingers, copper-coloured nails, rounded limbs, slender waists, faces like the full moon, expansive eyes,

original: mudugattā sahibhorū odātadantā gambhīranābhī tanujaṅghā dīghanīlavellitakesī puthulasussoṇī
analyzed: mudu gattā sahibha ūrū odāta dantā gambhīra nābhī tanu jaṅghā dīgha nīla vellita kesī puthula sussoṇī
translated: smooth skin, well-proportioned limbs, white teeth, deep navels, slender calves, long dark hair, and full-bosomed breasts.

original: nātilomā nālomā subhagā utusukhasamphassā saṇhā sakhilasambhāsā nānābharaṇavibhūsitā
analyzed: na atilomā na alomā subhagā utu sukha samphassā saṇhā sa khila sambhāsā nānā ābharaṇa vibhūsitā
translated: They are not hairy, nor are they hairless. They are lovely, with a pleasant touch like the utpala flower, gentle, and easy to talk with. They are adorned with various ornaments.

original: vicaranti, sabbadāpi soḷasavassuddesikā viya honti.
analyzed: vicaranti sabbadā api soḷasa vassuddesikāḥ viya honti
translated: and the women are always sixteen years old.

original: Purisāpi pañcavīsativassuddesikā viya, na puttā mātādīsu rajjanti, ayaṃ tattha dhammatā.
analyzed: purisāḥ api pañcavīsati vassuddesikāḥ viya na puttāḥ mātā ādīsu rajjanti ayam tattha dhamma tā
translated: And the men are always twenty-five years old. They do not lust after their mothers and so on. This is the rule there.

original: Sattāhikameva ca tattha itthipurisā kāmaratiyā viharanti, tato vītarāgā viya yathāsukhaṃ
analyzed: sattāhikam eva ca tattha itthi purisā kāma ratiyā viharanti tatas vīta rāgāḥ yathāsukham
translated: And there the women and men live together for sensual pleasures for only seven days. Then they go their way like those who are free from lust.

original: gacchanti, na tattha idha viya gabbhokkantimūlakaṃ gabbhapariharaṇamūlakaṃ vā dukkhaṃ🔽vijāyanamūlakaṃ vā dukkhaṃ hoti, rattakañcukato kañcanapaṭimā viya dārakā mātukucchito
analyzed: gacchanti na tattha idha viya gabbha ukkanti mūlakam gabbha pariharaṇa mūlakam vā dukkham  vijāyana mūlakam vā dukkham hoti ratta kañcukato kañcana paṭimāḥ viya dārakāḥ mātukucchito
translated: There is no suffering there due to conception, no suffering due to bearing in the womb, no suffering due to birth, as here.

original: amakkhitā eva semhādinā sukheneva nikkhamanti, ayaṃ tattha dhammatā. Mātā pana puttaṃ
analyzed: a makkhitāḥ eva semha ādinā sukhena iva nikkhamanti ayam tattha dhamma tā mātā pana puttam
translated: The children come out of the mother’s womb unsoiled by excrement and so on, like the figures in a picture. This is the rule there. But when the mother

original: vā dhītaraṃ vā vijāyitvā tesaṃ vicaraṇakappadese ṭhapetvā anapekkhā yathāruci gacchati.
analyzed: vā dhītaram vā vijāyitvā tesam vicaraṇaka ppadese ṭhapetvā anapekkhā yathāruci gacchati
translated: has given birth to a son or a daughter, she puts them down in a place where children can walk and goes her way without concern, as she pleases.

original: Tesaṃ tattha sayitānaṃ ye passanti purisā vā itthiyo vā, te attano aṅguliyo upanāmenti,
analyzed: tesam tattha sayitānam ye passanti purisāḥ vā itthiyaḥ vā te attanaḥ aṅguliyaḥ upanāmenti
translated: And those who see them there, whether men or women, put their fingers into their mouths,

original: tesaṃ kammabalena tato khīraṃ pavattati, tena te dārakā yāpenti. Evaṃ pana vaḍḍhantā
analyzed: tesam kamma balena tatas khīram pavattati tena te dārakāḥ yāpenti evam pana vaḍḍhantā
translated: But as they grow up,

original: katipayadivaseyeva laddhabalā hutvā dārikā itthiyo upagacchanti, dārakā purise.
analyzed: katipaya divase iya iva laddhabalāḥ hutvā dārikāḥ itthiyaḥ upagacchanti
translated: after a few days they become strong enough to walk, and the girls become women and the boys become men.

original: Kapparukkhato eva ca tesaṃ tattha vatthābharaṇāni nipphajjanti. Nānāvirāgavaṇṇavicittāni
analyzed: kappa rukkhataḥ eva ca tesam tattha vattha ābharaṇāni nipphajjanti nānā virāga vaṇṇa vicittāni
translated: And garments and ornaments appear for them from the Kappa tree.

original: hi vatthāni sukhumāni mudusukhasamphassāni tattha tattha kapparukkhesu olambantāni🔽tiṭṭhanti. Nānāvidharaṃsijālasamujjalavividhavaṇṇaratanavinaddhāni anekavidhamālākammalatākammabhittikammavicittāni🔽sīsūpagagīvūpagakaṭūpagahatthūpagapādūpagāni sovaṇṇamayāni ābharaṇāni ca kapparukkhato
analyzed: hi vatthāni sukhumāni mudu sukha samphassāni tattha tattha kappa rukkhesu olambantāni  tiṭṭhanti nānāvidha raṃsi jāla samujjala vividha vaṇṇa ratana vinaddhāni anekavidha mālā kamma latā kamma bhitti kamma vicittāni  sīsūpaga gīvūpaga kaṭūpaga hatthūpaga pādūpagāni sovaṇṇa mayāni ābharaṇāni ca kappa rukkhato
translated: For there are garments of various colours, fine, delicate, soft, pleasant to the touch, hanging in the trees.🔽And there are golden ornaments, with strings of various jewels, with various colours of embroidery, with various patterns of lattice-work, with various patterns of wreaths, with various patterns of creeper-work, with various patterns of wall-work,

original: olambanti. Tathā vīṇāmudiṅgapaṇavasammatāḷasaṅkhavaṃsavetāḷaparivārādīni vallakīpabhautikāni
analyzed: tathā vīṇā mudiṅga paṇava sammatāḷa saṅkha vaṃsa vetāḷa parivāra ādīni valla kīpa bhautikāni
translated: hanging in the trees. And there are various kinds of musical instruments, such as lutes, flutes, drums, horns, conches, cymbals, and tambourines.

original: tūriyabhaṇḍānipi tato olambanti. Tattha ca bahū phalarukkhā kumbhamattāni phalāni
analyzed: tūriya bhaṇḍāni pi tatas olambanti tattha ca bahū kumbha mattāni phalāni
translated: and musical instruments hang down from it. And there are many fruit trees there, bearing fruit the size of water-pots,

original: phalanti, madhurarasāni yāni paribhuñjitvā te sattāhampi khuppipāsāhi na bādhīyanti.
analyzed: phalanti madhura rasāni yāni paribhuñjitvā te sattāham pi khuppipāsāhi na bādhīyanti
translated: with a sweet taste, by eating which those beings are not troubled by hunger and thirst for a week.

original: Najjopi tattha suvisuddhajalā supatitthā ramaṇīyā akaddamā vālukatalā nātisītā nātiuṇhā🔽surabhigandhīhi jalajapupphehi sañchannā sabbakālaṃ surabhī vāyantiyo sandanti, na🔽tattha kaṇṭakinā kakkhaḷagacchalatā honti, akaṇṭakā pupphaphalasacchannā eva honti,
analyzed: najjā upi tattha su visuddha jalā su patitthā ramaṇīyā a kaddamā vāluka talā na ati sītā na ati uṇhā  surabhi gandhīhi jala ja pupphehi sañchannā sabbakālam surabhī vāyantiyaḥ sandanti na  tattha kaṇṭakinā kakkhaḷaga chalatāḥ honti akaṇṭakā puppha phala sacchannāḥ eva honti
translated: There are also lotus ponds there, with very clear water, good fords, delightful, free from mud, with sandy banks, not too cold, not too hot,🔽covered with fragrant water-borne flowers, with a sweet scent all the time, blowing gently. There are no thorny trees or rough grass or creepers,

original: candananāgarukkhā sayameva rasaṃ paggharanti. Nahāyitukāmā ca nadītitthe ekajjhaṃ🔽vatthābharaṇāni ṭhapetvā nadiṃ otaritvā nahāyitvā uttiṇṇā uttiṇṇā upariṭṭhimaṃ upariṭṭhimaṃ
analyzed: candana nāga rukkhā sayam eva rasam paggharanti nahāyitu kāmā ca nadī titthe ekajjham  vattha ābharaṇāni ṭhapetvā nadim otaritvā nahāyitvā uttiṇṇā uttiṇṇā upariṭṭhimam upariṭṭhimam
translated: only smooth trees and grass and creepers, covered with flowers and fruits. Sandalwood trees exude their essence by themselves. And those who wish to bathe go to the banks of the rivers,

original: vatthābharaṇaṃ gaṇhanti, na tesaṃ evaṃ hoti “idaṃ mama, idaṃ parassā”ti. Tato eva
analyzed: vattha ābharaṇam gaṇhanti na tesam evam hoti idam mama idam parassa ati tatas eva
translated: put down their clothes and ornaments in one place, enter the water, bathe, come out, and take up the clothes and ornaments that were nearest to them, without any thought of “This is mine, that is another’s.”

original: na tesaṃ koci viggaho vā vivādo vā, sattāhikā eva ca nesaṃ kāmaratikīḷā hoti, tato
analyzed: na tesam koci viggahaḥ vā vivādaḥ vā sattāhikāḥ eva ca na isam kāma rati kīḷā hoti tatas
translated: They have no quarrels or disputes. Their enjoyment of sensual pleasures lasts only seven days, after which they go about as if they were free from passion.

original: vītarāgā viya vicaranti. Yattha ca rukkhe sayitukāmā honti, tattheva sayanaṃ upalabbhati.
analyzed: vīta rāgāḥ viya vicaranti yattha ca rukkhe sayitu kāmāḥ honti tattha iva sayanam upalabbhati
translated: Wherever they want to sleep, there they find a bed.

original: Mate ca satte na rodanti na socanti, tañca maṇḍayitvā nikkhipanti. Tāvadeva ca tathārūpā
analyzed: mate ca satte na rodanti na socanti tat ca maṇḍayitvā nikkhipanti tāvat eva ca tathārūpā
translated: When a being dies, they do not weep or lament. They adorn the corpse and lay it down. Then

original: sakuṇā upagantvā mataṃ dīpantaraṃ nenti, tasmā susānaṃ vā asuciṭṭhānaṃ vā tattha
analyzed: sakuṇāḥ upagantvā matam dīpa antaram nenti tasmā su sānam vā asuci ṭṭhānam vā tattha
translated: birds come and carry it off to another island. Therefore there is no cemetery or place of impurity there.

original: natthi, na ca tato matā nirayaṃ vā tiracchānayoniṃ vā pettivisayaṃ vā upapajjanti.
analyzed: natthi na ca tatas matāḥ nirayam vā tiracchāna yonim vā petti visayam vā upapajjanti
translated: Nor do those who die there fall into hell, the animal realm, or the sphere of afflicted spirits.

original: “Dhammatāsiddhassa pañcasīlassa ānubhāvena te devaloke nibbattantī”ti vadanti. Vassasahassameva
analyzed: dhammatā siddhassa pañcasīlassa ānubhāvena te deva loke nibbattanti iti vadanti vassa sahassam eva
translated: They say that they are reborn in the heavenly world by the power of the five precepts established by nature.

original: ca nesaṃ sabbakālaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ, sabbametaṃ nesaṃ pañcasīlaṃ viya dhammatāsiddhamevāti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ca nesam sabba kālam āyu ppamāṇam sabbam etam nesam pañcasīlam viya dhamma tā siddham eva ati veditabbam
translated: Their life span is one thousand years, and all this should be understood as established by nature, like their five precepts.

original: Tadantaresūti tesaṃ cakkavāḷānaṃ antaresu. Lokantarikanirayāti lokānaṃ lokadhātūnaṃ
analyzed: tad antaresu iti tesam cakkavāḷānam antaresu lokantarika nirayā ati lokānam lokadhātūnam
translated: In the spaces between them: in the spaces between those world-spheres. The hells called “Between” are the hells that are in the spaces between the world-spheres.

original: antaro vivaro lokantaro, tattha bhavā lokantarikā, nirayā. Tiṇṇañhi sakaṭacakkānaṃ🔽pattānaṃ vā aññamaññaṃ āsannabhāvena ṭhapitānaṃ antarasadisesu tiṇṇaṃ tiṇṇaṃ cakkavāḷānaṃ
analyzed: antaraḥ vivaraḥ lokantaro tattha bhavāḥ lokantarikāḥ nirayāḥ tiṇṇam hi sakaṭa cakkānaṃ  pattānam vā aññamaññam āsanna bhāvena ṭhapitānam antara sadisesu tiṇṇam tiṇṇam cakkavāḷānam
translated: For the spaces between the world-spheres are the spaces, the gaps, between the world-spheres, the world-systems.🔽The hells that are there are called “Between.”

original: antaresu ekeko lokantarikanirayo. So pana parimāṇato aṭṭhayojanasahassappamāṇo hoti
analyzed: antaresu ekekaḥ lokantarika nirayo so pana parimāṇato aṭṭha yojana sahassa ppamāṇaḥ hoti
translated: Each of these hells is eight thousand leagues in extent.🔽It is always open, not closed off above or below by anything.

original: niccavivaṭo heṭṭhā upari ca kenaci na pihito. Yathā hi heṭṭhā udakassa pidhāyikā
analyzed: nicca vivaṭaḥ heṭṭhā upari ca kenacid na pihitaḥ yathā hi heṭṭhā udakassa pidhāyikā
translated: Just as there is no earth below to close off the water,🔽so too, there is no world-sphere mountain or world-sphere ocean above to close off the hells called “Between.”

original: pathavī natthīti asaṃvutā lokantarikanirayā, evaṃ uparipi cakkavāḷesu viya devavimānānaṃ🔽abhāvato asaṃvutā apihitā cakkhuviññāṇuppattinivāraṇasamatthena ca andhakārena samannāgatā.
analyzed: pathavī natthi iti asaṃvutāḥ lokantarika nirayāḥ evam upari pi cakkavāḷesu viya deva vimānānam  abhāvataḥ asaṃvutā apihitā cakkhu viññāṇa uppatti nivāraṇa samatthena ca andhakārena samannāgatā
translated: They are not closed off by the absence of divine palaces as in the case of the world-spheres.🔽They are not closed off by the absence of the sun and moon as in the case of the great hell Sañjīva.🔽They are not closed off by the absence of the eye-consciousness element as in the case of the hells called “Between.”

original: Tattha kira cakkhuviññāṇaṃ na jāyati ālokassa abhāvato. Tīsu dīpesu ekappahārena
analyzed: tattha kira cakkhu viññāṇam na jāyati ālokassa abhāvato tīsu dīpesu eka ppahārena
translated: They are not closed off by the absence of the eye-consciousness element as in the case of the hells called “Between.”

original: ālokakaraṇasamatthāpi candimasūriyā tattha ālokaṃ na dassenti. Te hi yugandharasamappamāṇe🔽ākāsappadese vicaraṇato cakkavāḷapabbatassa vemajjhena vicaranti, cakkavāḷapabbatañca
analyzed: āloka karaṇa samatthā api candima sūriyā tattha ālokam na dassenti te hi yugandhara sama ppamāṇe  ākāsa ppadese vicaraṇataḥ cakkavāḷa pabbatassa vemajjhena vicaranti cakkavāḷa pabbatam ca
translated: and the moon and sun, which are able to make light, do not give light there. For the moon and sun move in the region of the sky, which is 1,600,000 leagues distant,

original: atikkamma lokantarikanirayā, tasmā te tattha ālokaṃ na dassentīti cakkhuviññāṇaṃ
analyzed: atikkamma lokantarika nirayā tasmā te tattha ālokam na dassenti iti cakkhu viññāṇam
translated: and they move 1,600,000 leagues away from the central mountain, the Cakkavāḷa, and they do not give light beyond the Cakkavāḷa mountain.

original: nuppajjati. Yadā pana sabbaññubodhisattassa paṭisandhiggahaṇādīsu obhāso uppajjati,
analyzed: na uppajjati yadā pana sabbaññu bodhisattassa paṭisandhi ggahaṇa ādīsu obhāsaḥ uppajjati
translated: Therefore eye-consciousness does not arise there. But when the light arises in the conception, etc., of the omniscient Bodhisatta,

original: tadā cakkhuviññāṇaṃ uppajjati. “Aññepi kira bho santi sattā idhūpapannā”ti taṃ divasaṃ🔽aññamaññaṃ passanti. Ayaṃ pana obhāso ekaṃ yāgupānamattampi na tiṭṭhati, accharāsaṅghāṭamattameva
analyzed: tadā cakkhu viññāṇam uppajjati aññe pi kira bho santi sattāḥ idha upapannāḥ ti tam divasam  aññam aññam passanti ayam pana obhāsaḥ ekam yāgu pāna mattam pi na tiṭṭhati accharā saṅghāṭa mattam eva
translated: then eye-consciousness arises, and on that day they see each other, saying, ‘So, there are other beings here too!’

original: vijjobhāso viya niccharitvā “kiṃ ida”nti bhaṇantānaṃyeva antaradhāyati.
analyzed: kim idanti antaradhāyati
translated: But this light does not last even for the time of eating a meal. It is like a flash of lightning. It disappears even as they are saying, ‘What was that?’🔽But what kind of kamma do beings there perform that they are reborn there?

original: Kiṃ pana kammaṃ katvā tattha sattā nibbattantīti? Bhāriyaṃ dāruṇaṃ garukaṃ mātāpitūnaṃ
analyzed: kim pana kammam katvā tattha sattāḥ nibbattanti iti bhāriyam dāruṇam garukam mātā pitūnam
translated: They perform heavy, violent, and protracted kamma

original: dhammikasamaṇabrāhmaṇānañca upari aparādhaṃ aññañca divase divase pāṇavadhādiṃ sāhasikakammaṃ
analyzed: dhammika samaṇa brāhmaṇānam ca upari aparādham aññam ca divase divase pāṇa vadha ādim sāhasika kammam
translated: and the crime against the virtuous ascetics and brāhmaṇas, and other violent actions day by day, such as killing living creatures,

original: katvā uppajjanti tambapaṇṇidīpe abhayacoranāgacorādayo viya. Tesaṃ attabhāvo tigāvutiko🔽hoti, vaggulīnaṃ viya dīghanakhā honti. Te rukkhe vagguliyo viya nakhehi cakkavāḷapāde
analyzed: katvā uppajjanti tamba paṇṇi dīpe abhaya cora nāga cora ādayaḥ viya tesam atta bhāvo tigāvutikaḥ  hoti vaggulīnam viya dīgha nakhāḥ honti te rukkhe vagguliyaḥ viya nakhehi cakkavāḷa pāde
translated: and they commit crimes of violence such as killing living beings, etc., against righteous recluses and brahmans and others, day by day. They are born in the human world in the island of Tambapaṇṇi as the Abhaya robbers, the Nāga robbers, etc. Their bodies are three gavutas in size,

original: lagganti, yadā saṃsappantā aññamaññassa hatthapāsagatā honti, atha “bhakkho no laddho”ti🔽maññamānā khādanatthaṃ gaṇhituṃ upakkamantā viparivattitvā lokasandhārake udake patanti,🔽vāte paharantepi madhukaphalāni viya chijjitvā udake patanti, patitamattāva accantakhāre
analyzed: lagganti yadā saṃsappantā aññamaññassa hattha pāsa gatāḥ honti atha bhakkhaḥ no laddhaḥ ti  maññamānā khādana attham gaṇhitum upakkamantā viparivattitvā loka sandhārake udake patanti  vāte paharante api madhuka phalāni chijjitvā udake patanti
translated: and their nails are long like the claws of a vaggulī bird. They cling to the edge of the Cakkavāḷa mountain with their nails like vaggulīs clinging to a tree. When they are in contact with each other as they crawl along, thinking “We have got our food,”🔽they try to seize each other to eat. But they fall into the water that supports the world, turning over and over.

original: udake piṭṭhapiṇḍaṃ viya vilīyanti atisītalabhāvato ātapasantāpābhāvena. Atisītalabhāvameva
analyzed: udake piṭṭha piṇḍam viya vilīyanti ati sītala bhāvataḥ ātapa santāpa abhāvena ati sītala bhāvam eva
translated: When the wind strikes them, they break up like madhuka fruits and fall into the water. As soon as they fall into the extremely caustic water, they dissolve like a lump of sugar candy, because of the extreme coldness of the water and the absence of any heat of the sun.

original: hi sandhāya accantakhāratā vuttā. Na hi taṃ kappasaṇṭhahanaudakaṃ sampattikaramahāmeghavuṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: hi sandhāya accanta khāra tā vuttā na hi tam kappa saṇṭhahana audakam sampatti kara mahā megha vuṭṭham
translated: and it is with reference to this that the extreme hardness is mentioned. For that water which is used for soaking cotton is not the great rain-shower that brings the season of world-ending fire.

original: pathavīsandhārakaṃ kappavināsakaudakaṃ viya khāraṃ bhavituṃ arahati. Tathā hi sati🔽pathavīpi vilīyeyya, tesaṃ vā pāpakammabalena petānaṃ pakatiudakassa pubbakheḷabhāvāpatti
analyzed: pathavī sandhārakam kappa vināsaka odakam viya khāram bhavitum arahati tathā hi sati  pathavī pi vilīyeyya tesam vā pāpa kamma balena petānam pakati udakassa pubba kheḷa bhāva āpatti
translated: For it is in this sense that the word “extremely caustic” is used. For that water which is used for wetting cotton is not caustic enough to destroy the world as the water that falls from the great clouds at the end of a world-cycle is.🔽If it were, the earth itself would be dissolved.🔽Or just as the water for the ghosts becomes phlegm through the power of their evil kamma, so that water becomes caustic for them.

original: viya tassa udakassa tadā khārabhāvappatti hotīti vuttaṃ “accantakhāre udake piṭṭhapiṇḍaṃ viya vilīyantī”ti.
analyzed: viya tassa udakassa tadā khāra bhāva ppatti hoti iti vuttam accanta khāre udake piṭṭha piṇḍam viya vilīyanti iti
translated: That is why it is said, “They dissolve like a lump of dough in extremely caustic water.”

original: Anantānīti aparimāṇāni, “ettakānī”ti aññehi minituṃ asakkuṇeyyāni. Tāni ca bhagavā
analyzed: anantāni iti aparimāṇāni ettakāni iti aññehi minitum a sakkuṇeyyāni tāni ca bhagavā
translated: “Infinite”: immeasurable. They cannot be measured by others as “so many.” The Blessed One

original: anantena buddhañāṇena avedi “ananto ākāso, ananto sattanikāyo, anantāni cakkavāḷānī”ti.
analyzed: anantena buddha ñāṇena avedi anantaḥ ākāsaḥ anantaḥ satta nikāyaḥ anantāni cakkavāḷāni iti
translated: knows them by means of his infinite knowledge of a Buddha. “Infinite is space, infinite is the company of beings, infinite are the world-systems, infinite are the Buddhas who arise.”

original: Tividhampi hi anantaṃ buddhañāṇena paricchindati sayampi anantattā. Yāvatakañhi ñeyyaṃ,
analyzed: tividham pi hi anantam buddha ñāṇena paricchindati sayam pi ananta ttā yāvatakam hi ñeyyam
translated: For the infinite is discerned by the knowledge of a Buddha in all three of these senses. And the knowledge of a Buddha is infinite in itself, as far as objects of knowledge are concerned,

original: tāvatakaṃ ñāṇaṃ. Yāvatakaṃ ñāṇaṃ, tāvatakameva ñeyyaṃ. Ñeyyapariyantikaṃ ñāṇaṃ, ñāṇapariyantikaṃ🔽ñeyyanti. Tena vuttaṃ “anantena buddhañāṇena avedī”tiādi. Anantatā cassa anantañeyyappaṭivijjhaneneva
analyzed: tāvatakam ñāṇam yāvatakam ñāṇam tāvatakam eva ñeyyam ñeyya pariyantikam ñāṇam ñāṇa pariyantikam  ñeyyam ti tena vuttam anantena buddha ñāṇena avedi itiādi ananta tā cassa ananta ñeyya paṭivijjhanena iva
translated: and the knowledge is only so much. The knowable is only so much as the knowledge is. The knowledge is bounded by the knowable, and the knowable is bounded by the knowledge.🔽Thus it was said above: ‘The measureless is known by the measureless knowledge of the Enlightened One’ . And its measurelessness should be understood as measureless by the penetration of the measureless knowable,

original: veditabbā tattha appaṭihatacārattā. Idāni yathāvuttamatthaṃ nigamento āha “evamassa
analyzed: veditabbā tattha appaṭihata cāra ttā idāni yathāvuttam attham nigamentaḥ āha evam assa
translated: because it has unimpeded access there. Now, in order to conclude the meaning already dealt with, he said:

original: okāsalokopi sabbathā vidito”ti.
analyzed: okāsa lokaḥ api sabbathā vidito ti
translated: ‘Thus the world of space is known in all ways.’

original: Api cettha vivaṭṭādīnampi viditatā vattabbā, tasmā vivaṭṭādayopi ādito pabhuti evaṃ
analyzed: api ca ittha vivaṭṭa ādīnam pi vidita tā vattabbā tasmā vivaṭṭa ādayaḥ api āditas evam
translated: But here the knowing of the world’s revolution and so on should be mentioned too. So the revolution and so on should be understood in this way from the beginning:

original: veditabbā – saṃvaṭṭo saṃvaṭṭaṭṭhāyī vivaṭṭo vivaṭṭaṭṭhāyīti kappassa cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni.
analyzed: veditabbā saṃvaṭṭaḥ saṃvaṭṭa ṭṭhāyī vivaṭṭaḥ vivaṭṭa ṭṭhāyī iti kappassa cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni
translated: revolution, revolution-site, dissolution, dissolution-site, and the four incalculables of an eon.

original: Tattha saṃvaṭṭanaṃ vinassanaṃ saṃvaṭṭo, vinassamāno asaṅkhyeyyakappo. So pana atthato
analyzed: tattha saṃvaṭṭanam vinassanam saṃvaṭṭaḥ vinassamānaḥ asaṅkhyeyya kappaḥ saḥ pana atthataḥ
translated: Herein, revolution is the destruction, the revolution, of the world. The incalculable eon that is being destroyed is the revolution-site. But that is in fact

original: kāloyeva, tadā pavattamānasaṅkhāravasenassa vināso veditabbo. Saṃvaṭṭato uddhaṃ tathāṭhāyīkālo
analyzed: kālaḥ yā iva tadā pavattamāna saṅkhāra vasena assa vināsaḥ veditabbaḥ saṃvaṭṭataḥ uddham tathā ṭhāyī kālaḥ
translated: only the time; its destruction should be understood as occurring by means of the formations that occur at that time. The time that remains after the revolution🔽and before the formation of the world is the dissolution-site.

original: saṃvaṭṭaṭṭhāyī. Vivaṭṭanaṃ nibbattanaṃ vaḍḍhanaṃ vā vivaṭṭo, vaḍḍhamāno asaṅkhyeyyakappo.
analyzed: saṃvaṭṭa ṭṭhāyī vivaṭṭanam nibbattanam vaḍḍhanam vā vivaṭṭaḥ vaḍḍhamānaḥ asaṅkhyeyya kappaḥ
translated: The expansion is the creation, or the growth, of the world. The world-system expands during the incalculable period during which it grows.

original: Sopi atthato kāloyeva, tadā pavattamānasaṅkhāravasenassa vaḍḍhi veditabbā. Vivaṭṭato
analyzed: saḥ api atthataḥ kālaḥ yā iva tadā pavattamāna saṅkhāra vasena assa vaḍḍhi veditabbā vivaṭṭataḥ
translated: This is really just time, but its growth is to be understood as the growth of the formations occurring during that time.🔽The time during which the world remains expanded after its creation is the time of the world’s expansion.

original: uddhaṃ tathāṭhāyīkālo vivaṭṭaṭṭhāyī. Tattha tayo saṃvaṭṭā tejosaṃvaṭṭo āposaṃvaṭṭo
analyzed: uddham tathā ṭhāyī kālaḥ vivaṭṭa ṭṭhāyī tattha tayo tejosaṃvaṭṭo āposaṃvaṭṭo
translated: There are three kinds of dissolution: dissolution by fire, dissolution by water, and dissolution by wind.

original: vāyosaṃvaṭṭoti. Tisso saṃvaṭṭasīmā ābhassarā subhakiṇhā vehapphalāti. Yadā kappo🔽tejena saṃvaṭṭati, tadā ābhassarato heṭṭhā agginā ḍayhati. Yadā āpena saṃvaṭṭati,
analyzed: vāyosaṃvaṭṭā tissaḥ saṃvaṭṭa sīmāḥ ābhassarā subhakiṇhā vehapphalā ti yadā kappo  tejena saṃvaṭṭati tadā heṭṭhā agginā ḍayhati yadā āpena saṃvaṭṭati
translated: There are three limits to the world-system: the Brahmā-world, the Subhakiṇha realm, and the Vehapphala realm.🔽When the world is dissolved by fire, it burns from the Brahmā-world downwards. When it is dissolved by water, it dissolves from the Subhakiṇha realm downwards.

original: tadā subhakiṇhato heṭṭhā udakena vilīyati. Yadā vāyunā saṃvaṭṭati, tadā vehapphalato🔽heṭṭhā vātena viddhaṃsati.🔽Vitthārato pana tīsupi saṃvaṭṭakālesu ekaṃ buddhakkhettaṃ vinassati. Buddhakkhettaṃ
analyzed: tadā subha kiṇhataḥ heṭṭhā udakena vilīyati yadā vāyunā saṃvaṭṭati tadā vehapphalato  heṭṭhā vātena viddhaṃsati  vitthārato pana tīsu pi saṃvaṭṭa kālesu ekam buddhakkhettam vinassati buddhakkhettam
translated: When it is dissolved by wind, it is destroyed from the Vehapphala realm downwards.🔽But in all three cases of dissolution the destruction is of a single world-sphere.

original: nāma tividhaṃ hoti jātikkhettaṃ āṇākkhettaṃ visayakkhettañca. Tattha jātikkhettaṃ
analyzed: nāma tividham hoti jāti khettam āṇā kkhettam visaya kkhettam ca tattha jāti kkhettam
translated: A world-sphere is of three kinds: a sphere of a single birth, a sphere of a single rule, and a sphere of a single perception.

original: dasasahassacakkavāḷapariyantaṃ hoti, yaṃ tathāgatassa paṭisandhiggahaṇādīsu kampati.
analyzed: dasa sahassa cakkavāḷa pariyantam hoti yam tathāgatassa paṭisandhi ggahaṇa ādīsu kampati
translated: It extends as far as the ten-thousand world-systems, which shake when a Perfect One takes conception in his mother’s womb and so on.

original: Yattake hi ṭhāne tathāgatassa paṭisandhiñāṇādiñāṇānubhāvo puññaphalasamuttejito saraseneva
analyzed: yattake hi ṭhāne tathāgatassa paṭisandhi ñāṇa ādi ñāṇa anubhāvaḥ puñña phala samuttejito sa rasena iva
translated: For the influence of the knowledge of conception, etc., in a Perfect One extends as far as the extent of the fruit of his merit,

original: paṭivijambhati, taṃ sabbampi buddhaṅkurassa nibbattanakkhettaṃ nāmāti buddhakkhettanti
analyzed: paṭivijambhati tam sabbam pi buddha aṅkurassa nibbattana khettam nāma ati buddha kkhettanti
translated: and that is called the “field of the Buddha sprout’s production” .

original: vuccati. Āṇākkhettaṃ pana koṭisatasahassacakkavāḷapariyantaṃ, yattha ratanasuttaṃ
analyzed: vuccati āṇā khettam pana koṭi sata sahassa cakkavāḷa pariyantam yattha ratana suttam
translated: The “field of command” extends as far as a hundred thousand koṭis of world-spheres, where the influence of the Ratana Sutta,

original: khandhaparittaṃ dhajaggaparittaṃ āṭānāṭiyaparittaṃ moraparittanti imesaṃ parittānaṃ
analyzed: khandha parittam dhajagga parittam āṭānāṭiya parittam mora parittam ti imesam parittānam
translated: the Khandha Paritta, the Dhajagga Paritta, the Ātānātiya Paritta, and the Mora Paritta

original: ānubhāvo vattati. Iddhimā hi cetovasippatto āṇākkhettapariyāpanne yattha katthaci🔽cakkavāḷe ṭhatvā attano atthāya parittaṃ katvā tattheva aññaṃ cakkavāḷaṃ gatopi kataparitto
analyzed: ānubhāvaḥ vattati iddhimā hi cetaḥ vasi pattaḥ āṇā khetta pariyāpanne yattha katthaci  cakkavāḷe ṭhatvā attanaḥ atthāya parittam katvā tattha iva aññam cakkavāḷam gataḥ api kata parittaḥ
translated: is felt. For one who has supernormal power and has attained mental mastery can perform a paritta for his own benefit anywhere within the field of his command, in whatever world-sphere he may be standing,

original: eva hoti. Ekacakkavāḷe ṭhatvā sabbasattānaṃ atthāya paritte kate āṇākkhette sabbasattānampi
analyzed: eva hoti eka cakkavāḷe ṭhatvā sabba sattānam atthāya paritte kate āṇā khette sabba sattānam pi
translated: and it will be effective even if he goes to another world-sphere. And when a paritta is performed for all beings by one who stands in one world-sphere, it is effective for all beings in the field of command.

original: abhisambhuṇāteva parittānubhāvo tattha devatāhi parittānaṃ sampaṭicchitabbato, tasmā
analyzed: paritta anubhāvaḥ tattha devatāhi parittānam tasmā
translated: and the deities there are of little power, since they are satisfied with little.

original: taṃ āṇākkhettanti vuccati. Visayakkhettaṃ pana anantaṃ aparimāṇaṃ. Anantāparimāṇesu
analyzed: tat āṇākkhettanti vuccati visaya kkhettam pana anantam aparimāṇam ananta aparimāṇesu
translated: Therefore it is called the field of command. But the field of cognizance is infinite, immeasurable.

original: hi cakkavāḷesu yaṃ yaṃ tathāgato ākaṅkhati, taṃ taṃ jānāti ākaṅkhappaṭibaddhavuttitāya
analyzed: hi cakkavāḷesu yam yam tathāgataḥ ākaṅkhati tam tam jānāti ākaṅkha paṭibaddha vutti tāya
translated: For the Tathāgata knows whatever he wishes in the infinite, immeasurable world systems, because the knowledge of a Buddha occurs according to wish.

original: buddhañāṇassa. Evametesu tīsu buddhakkhettesu ekaṃ āṇākkhettaṃ vinassati, tasmiṃ
analyzed: buddha ñāṇassa evam etesu tīsu buddhakkhettesu ekam āṇā kkhettam vinassati tasmin
translated: So when one of these three fields of the Enlightened One is destroyed, then the field of cognizance is destroyed too.

original: pana vinassante jātikkhettaṃ vinaṭṭhameva hoti. Vinassantampi ekatova vinassati,
analyzed: pana vinassante jāti khettam vinaṭṭham eva hoti vinassantam pi ekatas va vinassati
translated: But when it is being destroyed, it is destroyed all together,

original: saṇṭhahantampi ekatova saṇṭhahati, tassevaṃ vināso saṇṭhahanañca veditabbaṃ.🔽Yasmiṃ samaye kappo agginā nassati, āditova kappavināsakamahāmegho uṭṭhahitvā koṭisatasahassacakkavāḷe
analyzed: saṇṭhahantam pi ekatas va saṇṭhahati tassa ivam vināsaḥ saṇṭhahanam ca veditabbam  yasmin samaye kappaḥ agginā nassati āditas va kappa vināsaka mahā meghaḥ uṭṭhahitvā koṭi sata sahassa cakkavāḷe
translated: and when it is being formed, it is formed all together. This is how its destruction and formation should be understood.🔽When the aeon is being destroyed by fire, a world-ending rain-cloud forms and pours down rain on the hundred thousand million world-spheres all together.

original: ekaṃ mahāvassaṃ vassati, manussā tuṭṭhā sabbabījāni nīharitvā vapanti, sassesu pana
analyzed: ekam mahā vassam vassati manussā tuṭṭhā sabba bījāni nīharitvā vapanti sassesu pana
translated: The people are pleased and they gather all the seeds and sow them. But the crops

original: gokhāyitamattesu jātesu gadrabharavaṃ ravanto ekabindumpi na vassati, tadā pacchinnapacchinnameva🔽hoti vassaṃ. Idaṃ sandhāya hi bhagavatā “hoti so, bhikkhave, samayo yaṃ bahūni vassāni
analyzed: go khāyita mattesu jātesu gadrabha ravam ravantaḥ eka bindum pi na vassati tadā pacchinna pacchinnam eva  hoti vassam idam sandhāya hi bhagavatā hoti saḥ bhikkhave samayaḥ yam bahūni vassāni
translated: When they have been eaten by the cows, the clouds, crying out like asses, do not rain even a drop, and then the rains are broken off.

original: bahūni vassasatāni bahūni vassasahassāni bahūni vassasatasahassāni devo na vassatī”ti
analyzed: bahūni vassa satāni bahūni vassa sahassāni bahūni vassa sata sahassāni devaḥ na vassati iti
translated: It is with reference to this that the Blessed One said: “Bhikkhus, there comes a time when for many years, for many hundreds of years, for many thousands of years, for many hundreds of thousands of years, no rain falls” .

original: vuttaṃ. Vassūpajīvinopi sattā kālaṃ katvā parittābhādibrahmaloke nibbattanti, pupphaphalūpajīviniyo
analyzed: vuttam vassu upajīvinaḥ api sattā kālam katvā paritta ābha ādi brahmaloke nibbattanti puppha phala upajīviniyaḥ
translated: Beings who live on the rains and deities who live on flowers and fruits die and are reborn in the Brahmā-world of Streaming- radiance, and so on.

original: ca devatā. Evaṃ dīghe addhāne vītivatte tattha tattha udakaṃ parikkhayaṃ gacchati,
analyzed: ca devatā evam dīghe addhāne vītivatte tattha tattha udakam parikkhayam gacchati
translated: Thus, when a long period has passed, the water in those places is exhausted.

original: athānupubbena macchakacchapāpi kālaṃ katvā brahmaloke nibbattanti nerayikasattāpi.
analyzed: atha anupubbena maccha kacchapāḥ api kālam katvā brahmaloke nibbattanti nerayika sattā api
translated: Then, gradually, the fishes and turtles die and are reborn in the Brahmā-world, and so are the beings in hell.

original: Tattha nerayikā sattamasūriyapātubhāve vinassantīti eke.
analyzed: tattha nerayikā sattama sūriya pātubhāve vinassanti iti eke
translated: Some say that the beings in hell perish when the seventh sun appears.

original: Jhānaṃ pana vinā natthi brahmaloke nibbatti, etesañca keci dubbhikkhapīḷitā, keci
analyzed: jhānam pana vinā natthi brahmaloke nibbatti etesam ca keci dubbhikkha pīḷitā keci
translated: But there is no rebirth in the Brahmā-world without jhāna, and some of these beings are oppressed by hunger and thirst.

original: abhabbā jhānādhigamāya, te kathaṃ tattha nibbattantīti? Devaloke paṭiladdhajjhānavasena.
analyzed: abhabbāḥ jhāna adhigamāya te katham tattha nibbattanti iti deva loke paṭiladdha jhāna vasena
translated: They are incapable of attaining jhāna. How then do they come to be reborn there? Through jhāna acquired in the deva world.

original: Tadā hi “vassasatasahassassa accayena kappavuṭṭhānaṃ bhavissatī”ti lokabyūhā nāma
analyzed: tadā hi vassa sata sahassassa accayena kappa vuṭṭhānam bhavissati iti lokabyūhā nāma
translated: For at that time the gods of the sense sphere called Lokagavesi,

original: kāmāvacaradevā muttasirā vikiṇṇakesā rudammukhā assūni hatthehi puñchamānā rattavatthanivatthā🔽ativiya virūpavesadhārino hutvā manussapathe vicarantā evaṃ ārocenti “mārisā mārisā
analyzed: kāma avacara devāḥ mutta sirāḥ vikiṇṇa kesāḥ rudam mukhāḥ assūni hatthehi puñchamānāḥ rattavattha nivatthā  virūpa vesa dhārinaḥ hutvā manussa pathe vicarantāḥ evam ārocenti mārisāḥ mārisā
translated: who have the power of knowing the world’s duration, appear with dishevelled hair and disarrayed garments, weeping with tearful faces,🔽and they proclaim: “Friends, after a hundred thousand years the world will be destroyed.

original: ito vassasatasahassassa accayena kappavuṭṭhānaṃ bhavissati, ayaṃ loko vinassissati,
analyzed: itas vassa sata sahassassa accayena kappa vuṭṭhānam bhavissati ayam lokaḥ vinassissati
translated: Friends, after a hundred thousand years the world will be destroyed.

original: mahāsamuddopi ussussissati, ayañca mahāpathavī sineru ca pabbatarājā ḍayhissanti
analyzed: mahā samuddaḥ upi ussussissati ayam ca mahā pathavī sineru ca pabbata rājā ḍayhissanti
translated: The great ocean will dry up and disappear, this great earth with its mountains and forests will be consumed and vanish,

original: vinassissanti, yāva brahmalokā lokavināso bhavissati, mettaṃ mārisā bhāvetha, karuṇaṃ,
analyzed: vinassissanti yāva brahma lokāḥ loka vināsaḥ bhavissati mettam mārisā bhāvetha karuṇam
translated: the world will be destroyed, and the destruction will extend as far as the Brahmā-world.

original: muditaṃ, upekkhaṃ mārisā bhāvetha, mātaraṃ upaṭṭhahatha, pitaraṃ upaṭṭhahatha, kule
analyzed: muditam upekkham mārisāḥ bhāvetha mātaram upaṭṭhahatha pitaram upaṭṭhahatha kule
translated: Therefore, friends, develop loving-kindness, compassion, gladness, and equanimity. Serve your mothers and fathers,🔽serve ascetics and brahmins.”

original: jeṭṭhāpacāyino hothā”ti. Te pana devā lokaṃ byūhenti sampiṇḍentīti “lokabyūhā”ti
analyzed: jeṭṭha apacāyinaḥ hotha ati te pana devāḥ lokam byūhenti sampiṇḍenti iti lokabyūhā ati
translated: These gods are called “world-illuminators” because they illuminate the world, making it all one flood of light.

original: vuccanti. Te kira disvā manussā yattha katthaci ṭhitāpi nisinnāpi saṃvegajātā sambhamappattāva
analyzed: vuccanti te kira disvā manussāḥ yattha katthaci ṭhitā api nisinnā api saṃvega jātā sambhama ppattā ava
translated: When people see them, they are seized with such a sense of urgency that they immediately

original: hutvā tesaṃ āsanne ṭhāne sannipatanti.
analyzed: hutvā tesam āsanne ṭhāne sannipatanti
translated: gather together in a place near where the gods have stood.🔽How do they know that the aeon is ending? “They are prompted by natural law,” say the teachers.

original: Kathaṃ panete kappavuṭṭhānaṃ jānantīti? “Dhammatāya sañcoditā”ti ācariyā. “Tādisanimittadassanenā”ti
analyzed: katham pana ete kappa vuṭṭhānam jānanti iti dhammatāya sañcoditā ati ācariyā tādisa nimitta dassanena ati
translated: “By the appearance of such portents,” say some.🔽“By the deities of the Brahma-world,” say others.

original: eke. “Brahmadevatāhi uyyojitā”ti apare. Tesaṃ pana vacanaṃ sutvā yebhuyyena manussā
analyzed: eke brahmadevatāhi apare tesam pana vacanam sutvā yebhuyyena manussā
translated: When they hear the gods’ words, most people

original: ca bhummadevatā ca saṃvegajātā aññamaññaṃ muducittā hutvā mettādīni puññāni karitvā
analyzed: ca bhummadevatā ca saṃvega jātā aññam aññam mudu cittā hutvā mettā ādīni puññāni karitvā
translated: and the deities of the earth are seized with a sense of urgency. They become tender-hearted towards each other and make merit by performing acts of loving kindness, etc.

original: devaloke nibbattanti. Tattha dibbasudhābhojanaṃ bhuñjitvā tato vāyokasiṇe parikammaṃ
analyzed: deva loke nibbattanti tattha dibba sudhā bhojanam bhuñjitvā tatas vāyokasiṇe parikammam
translated: As a result, they are reborn in the divine world. There they enjoy divine food and drink. Then, after performing the preliminary work on the air kasiṇa,

original: katvā jhānaṃ paṭilabhanti. Devānaṃ kira sukhasamphassavātaggahaṇapaacayena vāyokasiṇe
analyzed: katvā jhānam paṭilabhanti devānam kira sukha samphassa vāta ggahaṇa paacayena vāyo kasiṇe
translated: they attain jhāna by means of the air kasiṇa. It is said that they attain jhāna by apprehending the air that is pleasant to the touch and that is produced by the gods’ blessing.

original: jhānāni sukheneva ijjhanti. Tadaññe pana āpāyikā sattā aparāpariyavedanīyena kammena
analyzed: jhānāni sukhena iva ijjhanti tad aññe pana āpāyikā sattā apara apariya vedanīyena kammena
translated: and the jhānas are successful for them with ease. But other beings who are doomed to an unhappy rebirth,

original: devaloke nibbattanti. Aparāpariyavedanīyakammarahito hi saṃsāre saṃsaranto nāma satto🔽natthi. Tepi tattha tatheva jhānaṃ paṭilabhanti. Evaṃ devaloke paṭiladdhajjhānavasena
analyzed: deva loke nibbattanti apara apariya vedanīya kamma rahitaḥ hi saṃsāre saṃsarantaḥ nāma satto  natthi te pi tattha tathā iva jhānam paṭilabhanti evam deva loke paṭiladdha jhāna vasena
translated: are reborn in the world of the gods through kamma to be experienced in a future life.🔽For there is no being who wanders in saṃsāra without kamma to be experienced in a future life.🔽And they too obtain the jhāna there in the same way. Thus all are reborn in the Brahmā-world by obtaining the jhāna in the world of the gods.

original: sabbepi brahmaloke nibbattanti. Idañca yebhuyyavasena vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sabbe api brahma loke nibbattanti idam ca yebhuyya vasena vuttam
translated: And this is said in the majority of cases.

original: Keci pana “apāyasattā saṃvaṭṭamānalokadhātūhi aññesu lokadhātūsupi nibbattanti. Na🔽hi sabbe apāyasattā tadā rūpārūpabhavesu uppajjantīti sakkā viññātuṃ apāyesu dīghāyukānaṃ
analyzed: keci pana apāya sattā saṃvaṭṭamāna lokadhātūhi aññesu lokadhātūsu pi nibbattanti na  hi sabbe apāya sattā tadā rūpa arūpa bhavesu uppajjanti iti sakkā viññātum apāyesu dīgha āyukānam
translated: But some beings doomed to an unhappy rebirth are reborn in other world-spheres when the world-sphere is destroyed.🔽For it cannot be known that all beings doomed to an unhappy rebirth are reborn in the fine-material and immaterial kinds of existence, since it is impossible for them to be reborn in the divine world of long-lived deities.

original: devalokūpapattiyā asambhavato. Niyatamicchādiṭṭhiko pana vinassamānepi kappe nirayato
analyzed: deva loka upapattiyāḥ asambhavataḥ niyatam icchādiṭṭhiko pana vinassamāne pi kappe nirayato
translated: But one who is definitely of wrong view is not released from hell even when the aeon is being destroyed,

original: na muccatiyeva, tasmā so tattha anibbattitvā piṭṭhicakkavāḷe nibbattati. Niyatamicchādiṭṭhiyā
analyzed: na muccatiyā iva tasmā saḥ tattha a nibbattitvā piṭṭhi cakkavāḷe nibbattati niyatam icchā diṭṭhiyā
translated: so he is reborn in the outer iron rim of the world-sphere without being reborn there.

original: hi samannāgatassa bhavato vuṭṭhānaṃ nāma natthi. Tāya hi samannāgatassa neva saggo
analyzed: hi samannāgatassa bhavataḥ vuṭṭhānam nāma natthi tāya hi samannāgatassa na iva saggo
translated: For one who possesses this there is no escape from existence. For one who possesses this there is neither heaven

original: atthi, na maggo, tasmā so saṃvaṭṭamānacakkavāḷato aññattha niraye nibbattitvā paccati.
analyzed: atthi na maggo tasmā so saṃvaṭṭamāna cakkavāḷataḥ aññattha niraye nibbattitvā paccati
translated: nor the path. Therefore he is reborn in hell elsewhere than the world-sphere that is breaking up and is tormented there.

original: Kiṃ pana piṭṭhicakkavāḷaṃ na jhāyatīti? Jhāyati. Tasmiṃ jhāyamānepi esa ākāse ekasmiṃ
analyzed: kim pana piṭṭhi cakkavāḷam na jhāyati iti jhāyati tasmin jhāyamāne pi ākāse ekasmin
translated: But does the world-sphere that is the rim of the ocean not burn? It burns. But when it burns, he is tormented in space

original: padese paccatī”ti vadanti.
analyzed: padese paccati iti vadanti
translated: in one place.”

original: Vassūpacchedato pana uddhaṃ dīghassa addhuno accayena dutiyo sūriyo pātubhavati,
analyzed: vassu upacchedataḥ pana uddham dīghassa addhunaḥ accayena dutiyaḥ sūriyaḥ pātubhavati
translated: But after the cessation of the rains, at the end of a long period, a second sun appears.

original: pātubhūte pana tasmiṃ neva rattiparicchedo, na divāparicchedo paññāyati. Eko sūriyo
analyzed: pātubhūte pana tasmin na iva ratti paricchedaḥ na divā paricchedaḥ paññāyati ekaḥ sūriyo
translated: But when it has appeared, neither the division into day and night nor the division into month and half-month is evident. One sun

original: uṭṭheti, eko atthaṃ gacchati, avicchinnasūriyasantāpova loko hoti. Yathā ca kappavuṭṭhānakālato
analyzed: uṭṭheti ekaḥ attham gacchati avicchinna sūriya santāpaḥ uva lokaḥ hoti yathā ca kappa vuṭṭhāna kālato
translated: rises and the other sets without interruption. The world is as though continuously bathed in sunlight. And just as the sun’s mansion that appeared before the end of the aeon was occupied by a sun god,

original: pubbe uppannasūriyavimāne sūriyadevaputto hoti, evaṃ kappavināsakasūriye natthi.
analyzed: pubbe uppanna sūriya vimāne sūriyadeva putto hoti evam kappa vināsaka sūriye natthi
translated: so there is no sun god in the sun that appears at the end of the aeon.

original: Kappavuṭṭhānakāle pana yathā aññe kāmāvacaradevā, evaṃ sūriyadevaputtopi jhānaṃ nibbattetvā
analyzed: kappa vuṭṭhāna kāle pana yathā aññe kāmāvacara devāḥ evam sūriyadeva puttaḥ api jhānam nibbattetvā
translated: But at the time of the world’s contraction, the sun god, like the other sense-desire-world gods, produces jhāna and is reborn in the Brahmā-world.

original: brahmalokaṃ upapajjati. Sūriyamaṇḍalaṃ pana pabhassaratarañceva tejavantatarañca🔽hutvā pavattati. Taṃ antaradhāyitvā aññameva uppajjatīti apare. Tattha pakatisūriye
analyzed: brahma lokam upapajjati sūriya maṇḍalam pana pabhassarataram ca iva tejavantataram ca  hutvā pavattati tam antaradhāyitvā aññam eva uppajjati iti apare tattha pakati sūriye
translated: But the sun’s disk appears more radiant and more powerful🔽and it sets and another one appears.

original: vattamāne ākāse valāhakāpi dhūmasikhāpi vattanti, kappavināsakasūriye vattamāne vigatadhūmavalāhakaṃ
analyzed: vattamāne ākāse valāhakā api dhūma sikhā api vattanti kappa vināsaka sūriye vattamāne vigata dhūma valāhakam
translated: But others say that while the normal sun is shining, clouds and smoke appear in the sky, but when the sun that destroys the world is shining, the sky is clear and cloudless like a polished looking glass.

original: ādāsamaṇḍalaṃ viya nimmalaṃ nabhaṃ hoti. Ṭhapetvā pañca mahānadiyo sesakunnadiādīsu udakaṃ sussati.
analyzed: ādāsa maṇḍalam viya nimmalam nabham hoti ṭhapetvā pañca mahānadiyaḥ sesa kunnadi ādīsu udakam sussati
translated: Except for the five great rivers, the water in the rest of the rivers and so on dries up.

original: Tatopi dīghassa addhuno accayena tatiyo sūriyo pātubhavati, yassa pātubhāvā mahānadiyopi sussanti.
analyzed: tatas api dīghassa addhunaḥ accayena tatiyaḥ sūriyaḥ pātubhavati yassa pātubhāvā mahā nadiyaḥ api sussanti
translated: After the passing of a very long time, a third sun appears, and as a result the water in the great rivers dries up.

original: Tatopi dīghassa addhuno accayena catuttho sūriyo pātubhavati, yassa pātubhāvā himavati
analyzed: tatas api dīghassa addhunaḥ accayena catutthaḥ sūriyo pātubhavati yassa pātubhāvā himavati
translated: After the passing of a very long time, a fourth sun appears, and as a result the water in Lake Anotatta dries up.

original: mahānadīnaṃ pabhavā sīhappapātadaho mandākinīdaho kaṇṇamuṇḍadaho rathakāradaho anotattadaho
analyzed: mahā nadīnam pabhavā sīha ppapāta dahaḥ mandākinī dahaḥ kaṇṇamuṇḍa dahaḥ rathakāra dahaḥ anotatta dahaḥ
translated: the source of the great rivers, the Sīhappapāta waterfall, the Mandākinī waterfall, the Kaṇṇamuṇḍa waterfall, the Rathakāra waterfall, the Anotatta waterfall,

original: chaddantadaho kuṇāladahoti ime satta mahāsarā sussanti.
analyzed: chaddantadaho kuṇāladaho ti ime satta mahā sarā sussanti
translated: The seven great lakes dry up: the Lake Anotatta, the Lake Mandākinī, the Lake Kaṇṇamuṇḍa, the Lake Rathakāra, the Lake Chaddanta, the Lake Kuṇāla, and the Lake Mandaviṭapaka.🔽After the passing of a very long period, a fifth sun appears.

original: Tatopi dīghassa addhuno accayena pañcamo sūriyo pātubhavati, yassa pātubhāvā anupubbena mahāsamudde aṅgulipabbatemanamattampi udakaṃ na saṇṭhāti.
analyzed: tatas api dīghassa addhunaḥ accayena pañcamaḥ sūriyaḥ pātubhavati yassa pātubhāvā anupubbena mahā samudde udakam na saṇṭhāti
translated: With its appearance, the water in the great ocean does not remain even as much as a drop on the tip of a blade of grass.🔽After the passing of a very long period, a sixth sun appears.

original: Tatopi dīghassa addhuno accayena chaṭṭho sūriyo pātubhavati, yassa pātubhāvā sakalacakkavāḷaṃ🔽ekadhūmaṃ hoti pariyādinnasinehaṃ dhūmena. Yāya hi āpodhātuyā tattha tattha pathavīdhātu
analyzed: tatas api dīghassa addhunaḥ accayena chaṭṭho sūriyo pātubhavati yassa pātubhāvā sakala cakkavāḷam  eka dhūmam hoti dhūmena hi āpodhātuyā tattha tattha pathavīdhātu
translated: With its appearance, the entire world-sphere🔽becomes one vast flame.

original: ābandhattā sampiṇḍitā hutvā tiṭṭhati, sā chaṭṭhasūriyapātubhāvena parikkhayaṃ gacchati.
analyzed: sampiṇḍitā hutvā tiṭṭhati sā chaṭṭha sūriya pātubhāvena parikkhayam gacchati
translated: The water element, by which the earth element is held together and remains compact, is exhausted by the appearance of the sixth sun.

original: Yathā cidaṃ, evaṃ koṭisatasahassacakkavāḷānipi.
analyzed: yathā ca idam evam koṭi sata sahassa cakkavāḷāni pi
translated: And just as this happens here, so it happens in a hundred thousand koṭis of world-spheres.

original: Tatopi dīghassa addhuno accayena sattamo sūriyo pātubhavati, yassa pātubhāvā sakalacakkavāḷaṃ
analyzed: tatas api dīghassa addhunaḥ accayena sattamaḥ sūriyo pātubhavati yassa pātubhāvā sakala cakkavāḷam
translated: And so, after the lapse of a long period, a seventh sun appears. With its appearance the whole universe,

original: ekajālaṃ hoti saddhiṃ koṭisatasahassacakkavāḷehi, yojanasatikādibhedāni sinerukūṭāni
analyzed: eka jālam hoti saddhim koṭi sata sahassa cakkavāḷehi yojana satika ādi bhedāni sineru kūṭāni
translated: including a hundred thousand times a hundred thousand worlds, becomes a single flaming furnace. The peaks of Sineru, a hundred leagues high,

original: palujjitvā ākāseyeva antaradhāyanti. Sā aggijālā uṭṭhahitvā cātumahārājike gaṇhāti.🔽Tattha kanakavimānaratanavimānamaṇivimānāni jhāpetvā tāvatiṃsabhavanaṃ gaṇhāti. Etenevūpāyena
analyzed: palujjitvā ākāseya iva antaradhāyanti sā aggi jālā uṭṭhahitvā cātumahārājike gaṇhāti  kanaka vimāna ratana vimāna maṇi vimānāni jhāpetvā tāvatiṃsa bhavanam gaṇhāti etena iva upāyena
translated: and the rest, crumble away and vanish in the sky. The flames rise up and seize the world of the Four Kings.🔽There they burn the golden palaces, the jewelled palaces, and the crystal palaces, and then they seize the world of the Thirty-three. In the same way

original: yāva paṭhamajjhānabhūmiṃ gaṇhāti, tattha tayopi brahmaloke jhāpetvā ābhassare āhacca
analyzed: yāva paṭhamajjhāna bhūmim gaṇhāti brahmaloke jhāpetvā ābhassare
translated: they seize the worlds of the Yāma gods, the gods of the Tusita heaven, the gods who delight in creating, the gods who wield power over others’ creations, the first jhāna level, the second jhāna level, the third jhāna level, and the fourth jhāna level. There they burn the three worlds of the Brahmā-gods and then stop at the Ābhassara world.

original: tiṭṭhati. Sā yāva aṇumattampi saṅkhāragataṃ atthi, tāva na nibbāyati. Sabbasaṅkhāraparikkhayā
analyzed: tiṭṭhati sā yāva aṇumattam pi saṅkhāra gatam atthi tāva na nibbāyati sabba saṅkhāra parikkhayā
translated: They do not go out as long as there is the subtlest trace of formations left. But with the complete exhaustion of all formations

original: pana sappitelajjhāpanaggisikhā viya chārikampi anavasesetvā nibbāyati. Heṭṭhāākāsena
analyzed: pana sappi tela jjhāpana aggisikhā viya chārikam pi an avasesetvā nibbāyati heṭṭhā ākāsena
translated: they go out without leaving so much as a smouldering ember, like a lamp that burns out for want of oil. The space below and the space above

original: saha upariākāso eko hoti mahandhakāro.
analyzed: ekaḥ hoti mahandhakāraḥ
translated: become a single expanse of blinding darkness.

original: Evaṃ ekamasaṅkhyeyyaṃ ekaṅgaṇaṃ hutvā ṭhite lokasannivāse lokassa saṇṭhānatthāya
analyzed: evam ekam asaṅkhyeyyam ekaṅgaṇam hutvā ṭhite loka sannivāse lokassa saṇṭhāna tthāya
translated: So long as the world remains thus, with its single enclosure, for the sake of the distribution of the world’s population,

original: devo vassituṃ ārabhati, āditova antaraṭṭhake himapāto viya hoti. Tato kaṇamattā taṇḍulamattā🔽muggamāsabadaraāmalakaeḷālukakumbhaṇḍaalābumattā udakadhārā hutvā anukkamena usabhadveusabhaaḍḍhagāvutagāvutaaḍḍhayojanayojanadviyojana…pe…
analyzed: devaḥ vassitum ārabhati āditas va antaraṭṭhake hima pāto viya hoti tatas kaṇa mattā taṇḍula mattā  mugga māsa badara āmalaka eḷāluka kumbhaṇḍa alābu mattāḥ udaka dhārāḥ hutvā anukkamena usabha dveusabha aḍḍhagāvutagāvuta aḍḍhayojana yojana dviyojana pe
translated: rain begins to fall from a cloud called “Universal” , like a shower of stones in a cement mixer. Then the rain-drops become the size of peas, the size of beans,

original: yojanasatayojanasahassamattā hutvā koṭisatasahassacakkavāḷagabbhantaraṃ yāva avinaṭṭhabrahmalokā
analyzed: yojana sata yojana sahassa mattāḥ hutvā koṭi sata sahassa cakkavāḷa gabbhantaram yāva a vinaṭṭha brahma lokā
translated: the size of mung beans, the size of jujube stones, the size of mangoes, the size of balls of thread, the size of cartwheels, the size of a yoke, the size of a yoke-tie, the size of a ploughshare, the size of a ploughpole, the size of a league, the size of a hundred leagues, the size of a thousand leagues, and they fill the interior of a world-sphere of a thousand worlds, which is not destroyed,

original: pūretvā antaradhāyati. Taṃ udakaṃ heṭṭhā ca tiriyañca vāto samuṭṭhahitvā ghanaṃ karoti
analyzed: pūretvā antaradhāyati tam udakam heṭṭhā ca tiriyañca vātaḥ samuṭṭhahitvā ghanam karoti
translated: and then they disappear. The wind that arises below and to the side of that water compresses it

original: parivaṭumaṃ paduminīpatte udakabindusadisaṃ.
analyzed: parivaṭumam paduminī patte udaka bindu sadisam
translated: like a drop of water on a lotus leaf.
