translated: And because the Bodhisatta was the first man in the world’s most wonderful position,

original: ādiṃ katvā khattiyamaṇḍale saṇṭhite anupubbena brāhmaṇādayopi vaṇṇā saṇṭhahiṃsu.
analyzed: ādim katvā khattiya maṇḍale saṇṭhite anupubbena brāhmaṇa ādayaḥ api vaṇṇāḥ saṇṭhahiṃsu
translated: and when the warrior-nobility had settled down, the brahmins and the rest of the people gradually settled down too.

original: Tattha kappavināsakamahāmeghato yāva jālopacchedo, idamekamasaṅkhyeyyaṃ saṃvaṭṭoti
analyzed: tattha kappa vināsaka mahā meghataḥ yāva jāla upacchedaḥ idam ekam asaṅkhyeyyam saṃvaṭṭoti
translated: Herein, from the time of the great cloud heralding the world’s destruction until the breaking of the netting is one incalculable, which is called a “contraction.”

original: vuccati. Kappavināsakajālopacchedato yāva koṭisatasahassacakkavāḷaparipūrako sampattimahāmegho,
analyzed: vuccati kappa vināsaka jāla upacchedataḥ yāva koṭi sata sahassa cakkavāḷa paripūrako sampatti mahā megho
translated: From the time of the great cloud heralding the world’s destruction until the great cloud heralding the world’s expansion appears, filling a hundred thousand koṭis of worlds,

original: idaṃ dutiyamasaṅkhyeyyaṃ saṃvaṭṭaṭṭhāyīti vuccati. Sampattimahāmeghato yāva candimasūriyapātubhāvo,
analyzed: idam dutiyam asaṅkhyeyyam saṃvaṭṭa ṭhāyi iti vuccati sampatti mahā meghataḥ yāva candima sūriya pātubhāvaḥ
translated: is the second incalculable, which is called a “contraction-interval.” From the time of the great cloud heralding the world’s expansion until the appearance of the moon and sun

original: idaṃ tatiyamasaṅkhyeyyaṃ vivaṭṭoti vuccati. Candimasūriyapātubhāvato yāva puna kappavināsakamahāmegho,
analyzed: idam tatiyam asaṅkhyeyyam vivaṭṭo ti vuccati candima sūriya pātubhāvataḥ yāva puna
translated: is the third incalculable, which is called an “expansion.” From the appearance of the moon and sun until the great cloud heralding the world’s destruction appears again

original: idaṃ catutthamasaṅkhyeyyaṃ vivaṭṭaṭṭhāyīti vuccati. Vivaṭṭaṭṭhāyīasaṅkhyeyyaṃ catusaṭṭhiantarakappasaṅgahaṃ.
analyzed: idam catuttham asaṅkhyeyyam vivaṭṭa ṭṭhāyī iti vuccati vivaṭṭa ṭṭhāyī asaṅkhyeyyam catur aṭṭhi antara kappa saṅgaham
translated: is the fourth incalculable, which is called an “expansion-interval.” The “expansion-interval” incalculable includes sixty-four intermediate world-systems.

original: “Vīsatiantarakappasaṅgaha”nti keci. Sesāsaṅkhyeyyāni kālato tena samappamāṇāneva.
analyzed: vīsati antara kappa saṅgahanti keci sesa asaṅkhyeyyāni kālato tena
translated: Some say it includes twenty intermediate world-systems. The other incalculables are the same length as this one.

original: Imāni cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni eko mahākappo hoti. Evaṃ tāva agginā vināso ca saṇṭhahanañca veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: imāni cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni ekaḥ mahā kappaḥ hoti evam tāva agginā vināsaḥ ca saṇṭhahanañca veditabbam
translated: These four incalculables make one great eon. This is how the destruction by fire and the re-forming of the world should be understood.

original: Yasmiṃ pana samaye kappo udakena nassati, āditova kappavināsakamahāmegho vuṭṭhahitvāti
analyzed: yasmin pana samaye kappaḥ udakena nassati āditas va kappa vināsaka mahā meghaḥ vuṭṭhahitvā ati
translated: But when the world is to be destroyed by water, a great rain-cloud heralding the world’s destruction forms in the sky.

original: pubbe vuttanayeneva vitthāretabbaṃ. Ayaṃ pana viseso – yathā tattha dutiyasūriyo,
analyzed: pubbe vutta nayena iva vitthāretabbam ayam pana visesaḥ yathā tattha dutiya sūriyaḥ
translated: The rest should be understood in the way already described. But there is this difference. Just as there is a second sun there,

original: evamidha kappavināsako khārudakamahāmegho vuṭṭhāti. So ādito sukhumaṃ sukhumaṃ vassanto🔽anukkamena mahādhārāhi koṭisatasahassacakkavāḷānaṃ pūrento vassati. Khārudakena phuṭṭhaphuṭṭhā🔽pathavīpabbatādayo vilīyanti, udakaṃ samantato vātehi dhārīyati. Pathaviyā heṭṭhimantato
analyzed: evam idha kappa vināsakaḥ khārudaka mahā megho vuṭṭhāti saḥ āditas sukhumam sukhumam vassanto  anukkamena mahā dhārāhi koṭi sata sahassa cakkavāḷānam pūrentaḥ vassati khāru dakena phuṭṭha phuṭṭhā  pathavī pabbata ādayaḥ vilīyanti udakam samantataḥ vātehi dhārīyati pathaviyāḥ heṭṭhimantataḥ
translated: so here a great rain-cloud heralding the world’s destruction rises up. It rains continuously🔽for a long time, at first in a fine drizzle and gradually in ever-increasing downpours. As it rains, it fills up the depressions in the earth with water.🔽When the depressions are full, it fills up the level places. When the level places are full, the water overflows into the depressions of the world-sphere.

original: pabhuti yāva dutiyajjhānabhūmiṃ udakaṃ gaṇhāti. Tena hi khārudakena phuṭṭhaphuṭṭhā
analyzed: yāva dutiya jhāna bhūmim udakam gaṇhāti tena hi khāru dakena phuṭṭha phuṭṭhā
translated: When these are full, it overflows into the higher world-sphere.

original: pathavīpabbatādayo udake pakkhittaloṇasakkharā viya vilīyanteva, tasmā pathavīsandhārakaudakena
analyzed: pathavī pabbata ādayaḥ udake pakkhitta loṇa sakkharāḥ viya vilīyanta iva tasmā pathavī sandhāraka odakena
translated: and the earth, mountains, etc., dissolve like salt thrown into water. Therefore some say that the water that supports the earth

original: saddhiṃ ekūdakameva taṃ hotīti keci. Apare pana “pathavīsandhārakaudakaṃ taṃ sandhārakavāyukkhandhañca
analyzed: ekūdakam eva tam hoti iti keci apare pana pathavī sandhāraka odakam tam sandhāraka vāyu khandham ca
translated: becomes one with the water that supports the kasiṇa. But others say that the water that supports the earth and the air element that supports the water

original: anavasesato vināsetvā sabbattha sayameva eko ghanabhūto tiṭṭhatī”ti vadanti, taṃ🔽yuttaṃ. Upari pana chapi brahmaloke vilīyāpetvā subhakiṇhe āhacca tiṭṭhati, taṃ yāva
analyzed: anavasesataḥ vināsetvā sabbattha sayam eva ekaḥ ghana bhūto tiṭṭhati iti vadanti tam  upari pana brahmaloke vilīya apetvā subha kiṇhe āhacca tiṭṭhati tam yāva
translated: are completely destroyed, and the water stands everywhere as one, solid, compact mass.

original: aṇumattampi saṅkhāragataṃ atthi, tāva na vūpasammati, udakānugataṃ pana sabbaṃ saṅkhāragataṃ
analyzed: aṇumattam pi saṅkhāra gatam atthi tāva na vūpasammati udaka anugatam pana sabbam saṅkhāra gatam
translated: This is the correct explanation. But after dissolving the six sense-sphere worlds above it, it stands pressing on the Subhakiṇha Brahmā-world. It does not subside as long as there is any formed thing, however minute, left. But it completely overpowers all formed things and suddenly subsides, disappears,

original: abhibhavitvā sahasā vūpasammati, antaradhānaṃ gacchati. Heṭṭhāākāsena saha upariākāso
analyzed: abhibhavitvā sahasā antaradhānam gacchati heṭṭhāākāsena saha upariākāsaḥ
translated: after the water has disappeared, the space that was occupied by the water becomes one vast darkness.

original: eko hoti mahandhakāroti sabbaṃ vuttasadisaṃ. Kevalaṃ panidha ābhassarabrahmalokaṃ
analyzed: ekaḥ hoti mahandhakāro ti sabbam vutta sadisam kevalam panidhe ābhassara brahma lokam
translated: The rest is as already stated. But here the Ābhassara Brahmā-world

original: ādiṃ katvā loko pātubhavati. Subhakiṇhato cavitvā ābhassaraṭṭhānādīsu sattā nibbattanti.🔽Tattha kappavināsakamahāmeghato yāva kappavināsakakhārudakopacchedo, idamekamasaṅkhyeyyaṃ.
analyzed: ādim katvā loko pātubhavati subha kiṇhataḥ cavitvā ābhassara ṭṭhāna ādīsu sattāḥ nibbattanti  kappa vināsaka mahā meghataḥ yāva kappa vināsaka khārudaka upacchedaḥ idam ekam asaṅkhyeyyam
translated: From the Subhakiṇha hell beings are reborn in the Ābhassara Brahmā-world, and so on.🔽Herein, from the time of the great cloud heralding the world’s destruction up till the cessation of the salt-water sea is the first incalculable.

original: Udakupacchedato yāva sampattimahāmegho, idaṃ dutiyamasaṅkhyeyyaṃ. Sampattimahāmeghato
analyzed: udak upacchedataḥ yāva sampatti mahā meghaḥ idam dutiyam asaṅkhyeyyam sampatti mahā meghato
translated: From the cessation of the salt-water sea up till the great cloud heralding the world’s reappearance is the second incalculable. From the great cloud heralding the world’s reappearance

original: yāva candimasūriyapātubhāvo, idaṃ tatiyamasaṅkhyeyyaṃ. Candimasūriyapātubhāvato yāva
analyzed: idam tatiyam asaṅkhyeyyam candima sūriya pātubhāvataḥ yāva
translated: up till the reappearance of the sun and moon is the third incalculable. From the reappearance of the sun and moon

original: kappavināsakamahaāmegho, idaṃ catutthamasaṅkhyeyyaṃ. Imāni cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni
analyzed: idam catuttham asaṅkhyeyyam imāni cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni
translated: up till the great cloud heralding the world’s destruction is the fourth incalculable. These four incalculables

original: eko mahākappo hoti. Evaṃ udakena vināso ca saṇṭhahanañca veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ekaḥ mahā kappaḥ hoti evam udakena vināsaḥ ca saṇṭhahanam ca veditabbam
translated: make one great eon. This is how the destruction by water and the remaining of the water should be understood.

original: Yasmiṃ samaye kappo vātena nassati, āditova kappavināsakamahāmegho vuṭṭhahitvāti
analyzed: yasmin samaye kappaḥ vātena nassati āditas va kappa vināsaka mahā meghaḥ vuṭṭhahitvā ati
translated: When the eon is to be destroyed by air, a great cloud heralding the world’s destruction appears at the beginning as described in the Description of the Eon.

original: pubbe vuttanayeneva vitthāretabbaṃ. Ayaṃ pana viseso – yathā tattha dutiyasūriyo,
analyzed: pubbe vutta nayena iva vitthāretabbam ayam pana visesaḥ yathā tattha dutiya sūriyaḥ
translated: But there is this difference. There is a second sun in the case of the destruction by fire,

original: evamidha kappavināsanatthaṃ vāto samuṭṭhāti. So paṭhamaṃ thūlarajaṃ uṭṭhāpeti, tato
analyzed: evam idha kappa vināsana attham vāto samuṭṭhāti saḥ paṭhamam thūla rajam uṭṭhāpeti tatas
translated: Thus the wind arises here for the purpose of destroying the aeon. It first raises up coarse dust,

original: saṇharajaṃ sukhumavālikaṃ thūlavālikaṃ sakkharapāsāṇādayoti yāvakūṭāgāramatte pāsāṇe
analyzed: saṇhara jam sukhuma vālikam thūla vālikam yāvakūṭāgāra matte pāsāṇe
translated: then fine dust, fine sand, coarse sand, gravel, rocks, etc., up to the size of a hut.

original: visamaṭṭhāne ṭhitamahārukkhe ca uṭṭhāpeti. Te pathavito nabhamuggatā na puna patanti,
analyzed: visama ṭṭhāne ṭhita mahā rukkhe ca uṭṭhāpeti te pathavitaḥ nabham uggatāḥ na puna patanti
translated: The rocks that stand on uneven ground and the great trees it raises up do not fall down again after rising up from the earth and going into the sky,

original: tattheva cuṇṇavicuṇṇā hutvā abhāvaṃ gacchanti. Athānukkamena heṭṭhā mahāpathaviyā
analyzed: tattha iva cuṇṇa vicuṇṇāḥ hutvā abhāvam gacchanti atha anukkamena heṭṭhā mahā pathaviyā
translated: but they are smashed to powder and vanish there and then. Then gradually the wind rises up from the great earth below,

original: vāto samuṭṭhahitvā pathaviṃ parivattetvā uddhaṃ mūlaṃ katvā ākāse khipati. Yojanasatappamāṇāpi🔽pathavippadesā dviyojanatiyojanacatuyojanapañcayojanachayojanasattayojanappamāṇāpi
analyzed: vātaḥ samuṭṭhahitvā pathavim parivattetvā uddham mūlam katvā ākāse khipati yojana sata ppamāṇā api  patha vippadesā dvi yojana ti yojana catu yojana pañca yojana cha yojana satta yojana ppamāṇā api
translated: overturns the earth, makes it into a ball, and hurls it into the sky. Even places in the earth a hundred leagues wide🔽are smashed to pieces, and hurled into the sky by the force of the wind, and they are smashed to powder and vanish there and then, being two, three, four, five, six, or seven leagues wide.

original: pabhijjitvā vātavegukkhittā ākāseyeva cuṇṇavicuṇṇā hutvā abhāvaṃ gacchanti. Cakkavāḷapabbatampi
analyzed: pabhijjitvā vāta vegu khittāḥ ākāseya iva cuṇṇa vicuṇṇāḥ hutvā abhāvam gacchanti cakkavāḷa pabbatam pi
translated: The Cakkavāḷa and Sineru mountains

original: sinerupabbatampi vāto ukkhipitvā ākāse khipati. Te aññamaññaṃ abhihantvā cuṇṇavicuṇṇā
analyzed: sineru pabbatam pi vātaḥ ukkhipitvā ākāse khipati te aññam aññam abhihantvā cuṇṇa vicuṇṇā
translated: are hurled into the sky by the wind and smashed to powder and vanish there and then, after striking against each other.

original: hutvā vinassanti. Etenevūpāyena bhūmaṭṭhakavimānāni ca ākāsaṭṭhakavimānāni ca vināsento
analyzed: hutvā vinassanti etena iva upāyena bhūma aṭṭhaka vimānāni ca ākāsa aṭṭhaka vimānāni ca vināsento
translated: and they are destroyed. In the same way he destroys the earth-bound and space-bound mansions,

original: chakāmāvacaradevaloke vināsetvā koṭisatasahassacakkavāḷāni vināseti. Tattha cakkavāḷā
analyzed: cha kāmāvacara deva loke vināsetvā koṭi sata sahassa cakkavāḷāni vināseti tattha cakkavāḷā
translated: and after destroying the sense-desire-world gods’ abodes he destroys a hundred thousand koṭis of world-spheres. There the world-spheres

original: cakkavāḷehi, himavantā himavantehi, sinerū sinerūhi aññamaññaṃ samāgantvā cuṇṇavicuṇṇā
analyzed: cakkavāḷehi himavantā himavantehi sinerū sinerūhi aññamaññam samāgantvā cuṇṇa vicuṇṇā
translated: collide with one another, the Himalayas with the Himalayas, Sinerus with Sinerus, and they are ground to powder and destroyed.

original: hutvā vinassanti. Pathavito yāva tatiyajjhānabhūmi vāto gaṇhāti, navapi brahmaloke
analyzed: hutvā vinassanti pathavitaḥ yāva tatiya jhāna bhūmi vātaḥ gaṇhāti nava api brahma loke
translated: From the earth up to the plane of the third jhāna the wind takes hold, and after destroying the nine abodes of the Brahmas,

original: vināsetvā vehapphale āhacca tiṭṭhati. Evaṃ pathavīsandhārakaudakena taṃsandhārakavātena
analyzed: vināsetvā vehapphale āhacca tiṭṭhati evam pathavī sandhāraka odakena taṃ sandhāraka vātena
translated: it stops at the Vehapphala Brahma-world. Thus the water that supports the earth and the wind that supports the water

original: ca saddhiṃ sabbasaṅkhāragataṃ vināsetvā sayampi vinassati avaṭṭhānassa kāraṇābhāvato.
analyzed: ca saddhim sabba saṅkhāra gatam vināsetvā sayam pi vinassati avaṭṭhānassa kāraṇa abhāvato
translated: and all formations are destroyed together with the earth, and they are themselves destroyed, because there is no cause for their non-destruction.

original: Heṭṭhāākāsena saha upariākāso eko hoti mahandhakāroti sabbaṃ vuttasadisaṃ. Idha pana
analyzed: heṭṭhā ākāsena saha upari ākāso ekaḥ hoti mahā andhakāro ti sabbam vutta sadisam idha pana
translated: The space below and the space above become one, and it is all pitch dark. All this is as already described. But here

original: subhakiṇhabrahmalokaṃ ādiṃ katvā loko pātubhavati. Vehapphalato cavitvā subhakiṇhaṭṭhānādīsu
analyzed: subha kiṇha brahma lokam ādim katvā loko pātubhavati vehapphalataḥ cavitvā subha kiṇha ṭṭhāna ādīsu
translated: the world reappears beginning with the Subhakiṇha Brahma-world. Beings fall from the Vehapphala Brahma-world and are reborn in the Subhakiṇha Brahma-world, and so on.

original: sattā nibbattanti. Tattha kappavināsakamahāmeghato yāva kappavināsakavātupacchedo,
analyzed: sattāḥ nibbattanti tattha kappa vināsaka mahā meghataḥ yāva kappa vināsaka vāta upacchedo
translated: Beings are reborn there.

original: idamekamasaṅkhyeyyaṃ. Vātupacchedato yāva sampattimahāmegho, idaṃ dutiyamasaṅkhyeyyantiādi
analyzed: idam ekam asaṅkhyeyyam vāta upacchedataḥ sampatti mahā meghaḥ idam dutiyam asaṅkhyeyya ntiādi
translated: Herein, from the time of the great cloud heralding the world’s destruction until the cutting off of the wind disk is the first incalculable. From the cutting off of the wind disk until the reappearance of the great cloud heralding the world’s re-creation is the second incalculable.

original: vuttanayameva. Evaṃ vātena vināso ca saṇṭhahanañca veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: vutta nayam eva evam vātena vināso ca saṇṭhahanam ca veditabbam
translated: The rest is as already stated. This is how the world’s destruction by wind should be understood.

original: Atha kiṃkāraṇā evaṃ loko vinassati. Yadipi hi saṅkhārānaṃ ahetuko sarasanirodho vināsakābhāvato,
analyzed: atha kiṃkāraṇā evam lokaḥ vinassati yadi api hi saṅkhārānam ahetukaḥ sa rasa nirodhaḥ vināsaka abhāvato
translated: But why is the world destroyed in this way? Although the cessation of formations is not due to a cause, since there is no destruction,

original: santānanirodho pana hetuvirahito natthi. Yathā taṃ sattanikāyesūti bhājanalokassapi
analyzed: santāna nirodhaḥ pana hetu virahitaḥ natthi yathā tam satta nikāyesu iti bhājana lokassa api
translated: there is no cessation of the continuity of formations without a cause. As in the case of the continuity of beings,

original: sahetukena vināsena bhavitabbaṃ, tasmā kimevaṃ lokavināse kāraṇanti? Akusalamūlaṃ
analyzed: sa hetukena vināsena bhavitabbam tasmā kim evam loka vināse kāraṇan ti akusala mūlam
translated: so the world of physical environment must be destroyed by a cause. So what is the cause of the world’s destruction?🔽The cause is the root of unprofit.

original: kāraṇaṃ. Yathā hi tattha nibbattanakasattānaṃ puññabalena paṭhamaṃ loko vivaṭṭati,
analyzed: kāraṇam yathā hi tattha nibbattanaka sattānam puñña balena paṭhamam lokaḥ vivaṭṭati
translated: For just as the world is re-created by the power of the merit of the beings who are to be reborn there,

original: evaṃ tesaṃ pāpakammabalena saṃvaṭṭati, tasmā akusalamūlesu ussannesu evaṃ loko vinassati.
analyzed: evam tesam pāpa kamma balena saṃvaṭṭati tasmai akusala mūlesu ussannesu evam lokaḥ vinassati
translated: so it is destroyed by the power of their evil kamma. So the world is destroyed when the root of unprofit is prominent.

original: Yathā hi rāgadosamohānaṃ adhikabhāvena yathākkamaṃ rogantarakappo satthantarakappo🔽dubbhikkhantarakappoti ime tividhā antarakappā vivaṭṭaṭṭhāyimhi asaṅkhyeyyakappe
analyzed: yathā hi rāga dosa mohānam adhika bhāvena yathākkamam rogantara kappo satthantara kappo  dubbhikkha antara kappaḥ ti ime tividhāḥ antara kappāḥ vivaṭṭa ṭṭhāyimhi asaṅkhyeyya kappe
translated: For just as the three kinds of eons, namely, the eon of formations, the eon of world contraction, and the eon of world expansion, arise in the asaṅkhyeya eon of evolution through the predominance of greed, hatred, and delusion, respectively,

original: jāyanti. Evamete yathāvuttā tayo saṃvaṭṭā rāgādīnaṃ adhikabhāveneva honti.🔽Tattha rāge ussannatare agginā vinassati, dose ussannatare udakena vinassati. Dose
analyzed: jāyanti evam ete yathā vuttā tayo saṃvaṭṭāḥ rāga ādīnam adhika bhāvena iva honti  tattha rāge ussannatare agginā vinassati dose ussannatare udakena vinassati dose
translated: so these three kinds of world-systems occur through the predominance of greed, etc., respectively.

original: hi ussannatare adhikatarena dosena viya tikkhatarena khārudakena vināso yuttoti.🔽Keci pana “dose ussannatare agginā, rāge udakenā”ti vadanti, tesaṃ kira ayamadhippāyo
analyzed: hi ussannatare adhikatarena dosena viya tikkhatarena khārudakena vināsaḥ yutto ti  keci pana dose ussannatare agginā rāge udakena ati vadanti tesam kira ayam adhippāyaḥ
translated: Herein, when greed is predominant the world is destroyed by fire. When hatred is predominant it is destroyed by water. For it is proper that the world should be destroyed by water, which is like the excess of hatred, which is sharp and violent.

original: – pākaṭasattusadisassa dosassa aggisadisatā, apākaṭasattusadisassa rāgassa khārudakasadisatā
analyzed: pākaṭa sattu sadisassa dosassa aggi sadisa tā apākaṭa sattu sadisassa rāgassa khāru udaka sadisa tā
translated: But some say that when greed is predominant the world is destroyed by water and when hatred is predominant it is destroyed by fire. Their idea is that it is proper that hatred, which is like a manifest fire, should be destroyed by fire, and that greed, which is like a latent fire, should be destroyed by water.🔽When delusion is predominant it is destroyed by wind.

original: ca yuttāti. Mohe pana ussannatare vātena vinassati. Evaṃ vinassantopi ca nirantarameva
analyzed: ca yuttā ati mohe pana ussannatare vātena vinassati evam vinassantaḥ api ca nirantaram eva
translated: And although it is destroyed in this way, it is nevertheless uninterrupted.

original: satta vāre agginā nassati, aṭṭhame vāre udakena, puna satta vāre agginā, aṭṭhame🔽udakenāti evaṃ aṭṭhame aṭṭhame vāre vinassanto sattakkhattuṃ udakena vinassitvā puna
analyzed: satta vāre agginā nassati aṭṭhame vāre udakena puna satta vāre agginā aṭṭhame  udakena ati evam aṭṭhame aṭṭhame vāre vinassantaḥ satta kkhattum udakena vinassitvā punar
translated: It is destroyed by fire seven times, and then by water, and then again by fire seven times, and then by water.🔽Thus it is destroyed by water after the seventh destruction by fire. Then it is destroyed by fire seven times, and then by water.

original: satta vāre agginā nassati. Ettāvatā tesaṭṭhi kappā atītā honti. Etthantare udakena🔽nassanavāraṃ sampattampi paṭibāhitvā laddhokāso vāto paripuṇṇacatusaṭṭhikappāyuke
analyzed: satta vāre agginā nassati ettāvatā tesaṭṭhi kappā atītā honti etthantare udakena  nassana vāram sampattam pi paṭibāhitvā laddha ukāsaḥ vāto paripuṇṇa catusaṭṭhi kappāyuke
translated: By that time seventy-two eons have passed. In the interval the wind destroys the world after preventing the destruction by water that would otherwise have taken place.

original: subhakiṇhe viddhaṃsento lokaṃ vināseti. Ettha pana rāgo sattānaṃ bahulaṃ pavattatīti
analyzed: subha kiṇhe lokam vināseti ettha pana rāgaḥ sattānam bahulam pavattati iti
translated: The wind destroys the world after obtaining an opportunity when the life span is thirty-four thousand years.🔽Here lust is the most prevalent passion in beings.

original: aggivasena bahuso lokavināso veditabbo. Iti evaṃ imehi kāraṇehi vinassitvā saṇṭhahantaṃ
analyzed: aggi vasena bahusas loka vināsaḥ veditabbaḥ iti evam imehi kāraṇehi vinassitvā saṇṭhahantam
translated: Therefore it should be understood that the world is mostly destroyed by fire.

original: saṇṭhahitvā ṭhitañca okāsalokaṃ bhagavā yāthāvato avedīti evampissa sabbathā okāsaloko🔽viditoti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: saṇṭhahitvā ṭhitam ca okāsa lokam bhagavā yāthāvataḥ avedi iti evam pi sabbathā okāsa lokaḥ  viditaḥ ti daṭṭhabbam
translated: Thus the Blessed One has understood the world as it is in its destruction and reconstitution,🔽and as it is in its remaining after reconstitution. Therefore it should be understood that he is “one who knows the world in all its aspects.”

original: Yaṃ pana heṭṭhā vuttaṃ “sabbathā viditalokattā lokavidū”ti, idāni taṃ nigamento āha
analyzed: yam pana heṭṭhā vuttam sabbathā vidita loka ttā loka vidu iti idāni tam nigamentaḥ āha
translated: But in order to conclude the exposition of the world that was begun above with the words, “Because he has understood the world in all its aspects he is one who knows the world” , he said:

original: “evaṃ sabbathā viditalokattā lokavidū”ti. Tattha sabbathāti lakkhaṇādippabhedato
analyzed: evam sabbathā vidita loka ttā loka vidū ti tattha sabbathā ati lakkhaṇa ādi ppabhedato
translated: “Because he has thus penetrated the world in all ways he is the knower of the worlds.” Herein, in all ways means🔽in the way of the world of formations by way of the characteristics, etc.,🔽in the way of the world of beings by way of the abodes, etc., and

original: saṅkhāralokassa, āsayādippabhedato sattalokassa, parimāṇasaṇṭhānādippabhedato okāsalokassāti
analyzed: saṅkhāra lokassa āsaya ādi ppabhedato satta lokassa parimāṇa saṇṭhāna ādi ppabhedato okāsa lokassa ati
translated: in the way of the world of location by way of the measure, shape, etc., of the world-receptacle.

original: evaṃ sabbappakārena viditalokattāti attho.
analyzed: evam sabba ppakārena vidita loka ttā iti attho
translated: The meaning is that he has penetrated the world in all its modes.

original: Idāni anuttaroti padassa atthaṃ saṃvaṇṇento āha “attano pana guṇehī”tiādi. Tattha
analyzed: idāni anuttaraḥ ti padassa attham saṃvaṇṇentaḥ āha attanaḥ pana guṇehi itiādi tattha
translated: Now, commenting on the meaning of the word unsurpassed, the commentator says, “Because of his own special qualities,” etc. Herein,🔽his own means in the sense of “not another’s,” i.e., his own. Special qualities means his own special qualities.

original: attanoti nissakkatthe sāmivacanametaṃ, attatoti attho. Guṇehi attano visiṭṭhatarassāti
analyzed: attanaḥ iti nissakka tthe sāmi vacanam etam attataḥ iti atthaḥ guṇehi attanaḥ visiṭṭhatarassa ati
translated: The construction is: because of his own special qualities, he is unsurpassed.

original: sambandho. Taraggahaṇañcettha “anuttaro”ti padassa atthaniddesatāya kataṃ, na visiṭṭhassa
analyzed: sambandhaḥ tara gahaṇam ca ittha anuttarā ti padassa attha niddesa tāya katam na visiṭṭhassa
translated: The word “indeed” is stated to show the meaning of the word “unsurpassed,” not to show the existence of a superior,

original: kassaci atthitāya. Sadevake hi loke sadisakappopi nāma koci tathāgatassa natthi,
analyzed: kassaci atthitāya sa devake hi loke sadisa kappaḥ api nāma koci tathāgatassa natthi
translated: for in the world with its gods there is no one equal to the Tathāgata, much less a superior.

original: kuto sadiso, visiṭṭhe pana kā kathā. Kassacīti kassacipi. Abhibhavatīti sīlasampadāya
analyzed: kutas sadisaḥ visiṭṭhe pana kā kathā kassaci iti kassaci pi abhibhavati iti sīla sampadāya
translated: What to say of a superior? What to say of an equal? He surpasses means he surpasses by the perfection of virtue,

original: upanissayabhūtānaṃ hirottappamettākaruṇānaṃ visesapaccayānaṃ saddhāsativīriyapaññānañca
analyzed: upanissaya bhūtānam hirā uttappa mettā karuṇānam visesa paccayānam saddhā sati vīriya paññānam ca
translated: and of faith, mindfulness, energy, and understanding,

original: ukkaṃsappattiyā samudāgamato paṭṭhāya na aññasādhāraṇo savāsanapaṭipakkhassa pahīnattā
analyzed: ukkaṃsa ppattiyā samudāgamataḥ paṭṭhāya na añña sādhāraṇaḥ sa vāsana paṭipakkhassa pahīna ttā
translated: from the time of the acquisition of the supreme excellence, and because of the abandoning of the opponent qualities together with their latent tendencies, which is not shared by others,

original: ukkaṃsapāramippatto satthu sīlaguṇo, tena bhagavā sadevakaṃ lokaṃ aññadatthu abhibhuyya
analyzed: ukkaṃsa pārami pattaḥ satthu sīla guṇo tena bhagavā sa devakam lokam añña datthu abhibhuyya
translated: the Master’s virtue has reached the perfection of excellence. Therefore the Blessed One, having overcome the world with its deities,

original: pavattati, na sayaṃ kenaci abhibhuyyatīti adhippāyo. Evaṃ samādhiguṇādīsupi yathārahaṃ
analyzed: pavattati na sayam kenacid abhibhuyyati iti adhippāyaḥ evam samādhi guṇa ādīsu pi yathāraham
translated: goes on his way. The intention is that he is not himself overcome by anyone. So too in the case of the Master’s excellence in concentration, etc.,

original: vattabbaṃ. Sīlādayo cete lokiyalokuttaramissakā veditabbā, vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ pana
analyzed: vattabbam sīla ādayaḥ ca ite lokiya lokuttara missakāḥ veditabbāḥ vimutti ñāṇa dassanam pana
translated: it should be said in each instance as is appropriate. Virtue, etc., should be understood as mundane and supramundane mixed together. But the knowledge and vision of liberation is

original: lokiyaṃ kāmāvacarameva.
analyzed: lokiyam kāmāvacaram eva
translated: mundane and belongs to the sense sphere only.

original: Yadi evaṃ kathaṃ tena sadevakaṃ lokaṃ abhibhavatīti? Tassapi ānubhāvato asadisattā.
analyzed: yadi evam katham tena sa devakam lokam abhibhavati iti tassa api ānubhāvataḥ asadisa ttā
translated: If that is so, how is it that he overcomes the world with its deities? Because of its incomparable power.

original: Tampi hi visayato pavattito pavattiākārato ca uttaritarameva. Tañhi anaññasādhāraṇaṃ
analyzed: tat pi hi visayataḥ pavattitaḥ pavatti ākārato ca uttaritaram eva tat hi anañña sādhāraṇam
translated: For that too is superior in object, in occurrence, and in mode of occurrence.

original: satthu vimuttiguṇaṃ ārabbha pavattati, pavattamānañca atakkāvacaraṃ paramagambhīraṃ🔽saṇhaṃ sukhumaṃ sātisayaṃ paṭipakkhadhammānaṃ suppahīnattā suṭṭhu pākaṭaṃ vibhūtataraṃ🔽katvā pavattati, sammadeva ca vasībhāvassa pāpakattā bhavaṅgaparivāsassa ca atiparittakattā
analyzed: satthu vimutti guṇam ārabbha pavattati pavattamānam ca a takka avacaram parama gambhīram  saṇham su khumam sa atisayam paṭipakkha dhammānam su pahīna ttā suṭṭhu pākaṭam vibhūtataram  katvā pavattati sammat eva ca vasībhāvassa pāpa kattā bhavaṅga parivāsassa ca ati paritta kattā
translated: It occurs in reference to the special quality of the Master’s deliverance. And while it is occurring, it does so in a way that is quite evident, quite clear, quite distinct, because it is extremely profound and hard to see since it is beyond the scope of discursive reasoning, and because it is extremely pure since it is well rid of opposing qualities.

original: lahu lahu pavattatīti.
analyzed: lahu lahu pavattati iti
translated: And it occurs rapidly, rapidly, because it is well developed and because the life-continuum is extremely brief.

original: Evaṃ sīlādiguṇehi bhagavato uttaritarassa abhāvaṃ dassetvā idāni sadisassapi abhāvaṃ
analyzed: evam sīla ādi guṇehi bhagavataḥ uttaritarassa abhāvam dassetvā idāni sadisassa api abhāvam
translated: Having thus shown that there is no one superior to the Exalted One in virtue of such special qualities as those of virtue, etc., the poet now sets forth the absence of anyone equal to him,

original: dassetuṃ “sīlaguṇenapi asamo”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha asamoti ekasmiṃ kāle natthi etassa🔽sīlādiguṇena samo sadisoti asamo. Tathā asamehi samo asamasamo. Asamā vā samā etassāti
analyzed: dassetum sīla guṇena api asamaḥ tiādi vuttam tattha asamaḥ ti ekasmin kāle natthi etassa  sīla ādi guṇena samaḥ sadisaḥ iti asamaḥ tathā asamehi samaḥ asamasamaḥ asamāḥ vā samāḥ etassa ati
translated: saying “In virtue he is not equalled” , etc. Herein, not equalled is not equalled by one in virtue, etc., at one time.🔽Not equalled by one equal is not equalled by one equal to one equal.🔽Or alternatively, not equalled by one not equalled is not equalled by one not equalled by one equal.

original: asamasamo. Sīlādiguṇena natthi etassa paṭimāti appaṭimo. Sesapadadvayepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: asamasamaḥ sīla ādi guṇena na atthi etassa paṭimā ati appaṭimaḥ sesa pada dvaye pi esa iva nayo
translated: In virtue he has no equal is there is no one equal to him in virtue, etc.🔽The same method of explanation applies in the case of the other two terms.

original: Tattha upamāmattaṃ paṭimā, sadisūpamā paṭibhāgo, yugaggāhavasena ṭhito paṭipuggaloti veditabbo.🔽Na kho panāhaṃ bhikkhave samanupassāmītiādīsu mama samantacakkhunā hatthatale āmalakaṃ🔽viya sabbaṃ lokaṃ passantopi tattha sadevake…pe… pajāya attano attato sīlasampannataraṃ
analyzed: tattha upamā mattam paṭimā sadisūpamā paṭibhāgaḥ yuga ggāha vasena ṭhitaḥ paṭipuggalaḥ ti veditabbo  na kho pana aham bhikkhave samanupassāmi iti ādīsu mama samanta cakkhunā hattha tale āmalakam  viya sabbam lokam passantaḥ api tattha sa deva kepe pajāya attanaḥ attataḥ sīla sampannataram
translated: Herein, the image is the counterpart in measure, the reflection is the counterpart in likeness, and the counterpart in person should be understood as standing for the counterpart in yoke-fellowship.

original: sampannatarasīlaṃ kañcipi puggalaṃ na kho pana passāmi tādisassa abhāvatoti adhippāyo.
analyzed: sampannatara sīlam kañcipi puggalam na kho pana passāmi tādisassa abhāvato ti adhippāyaḥ
translated: As to the words, “Bhikkhus, I do not see that form, whether of a deity or of a human being, by which that bliss might be surpassed” , the intention is this. Although I see the whole world with my all-seeing eye as clearly as a myrobalan fruit on the palm of my hand, I do not see any person whatsoever, whether a deity or a human being, in whom virtue is more fulfilled than in me.

original: Aggappasādasuttādīnīti ettha –
analyzed: agga ppasāda sutta ādīni iti ettha
translated: As to the words, “The Discourse on Supreme Confidence, etc.,”

original: “Yāvatā, bhikkhave, sattā apadā vā dvipadā vā catuppadā vā bahuppadā vā rūpino vā🔽arūpino vā saññino vā asaññino vā nevasaññīnāsaññino vā, tathāgato tesaṃ aggamakkhāyati🔽arahaṃ sammāsambuddho. Ye, bhikkhave, buddhe pasannā, agge te pasannā. Agge kho pana
analyzed: yāvatā bhikkhave sattāḥ apadāḥ vā dvipadāḥ vā catuppadāḥ vā bahuppadāḥ vā rūpinaḥ vā  arūpinaḥ vā saññinaḥ vā asaññinaḥ vā nevasaññīna asaññinaḥ vā tathāgataḥ tesam aggam akkhāyati  araham sammāsambuddhaḥ ye bhikkhave buddhe pasannāḥ agge te pasannāḥ agge kho pana
translated: “Bhikkhus, whatever beings there are, whether footless or with two feet, four feet, or many feet, whether having form or formless,

original: pasannānaṃ aggo vipāko hotī”ti –
analyzed: pasannānam aggaḥ vipākaḥ hoti iti
translated: whether consisting of mind or not consisting of mind, the Tathāgata, the Arahant, the Perfectly Enlightened One is declared the chief among them. Those who have confidence in the Buddha have confidence in the foremost. Now, confidence in the foremost, bhikkhus, has a great reward when fully developed. ”

original: Idaṃ aggappasādasuttaṃ. Ādi-saddena –
analyzed: idam aggappasāda suttam ādi saddena
translated: This is the Discourse on the Foremost Kind of Confidence. The word “etc.” refers to such passages as:

original: “Sadevake, bhikkhave, loke…pe… sadevamanussāya tathāgato abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthu daso vasavattī, tasmā tathāgatoti vuccatī”ti –
analyzed: sa devake bhikkhave lokepe sa deva manussāya tathāgataḥ an abhibhūtaḥ añña datthu dasaḥ vasa vattī tasmā tathāgataḥ iti vuccati iti
translated: “Bhikkhus, in the world with its deities, its Mara s, its Brahma s, in this generation with its ascetics and brahmins, with its devas and humans, the Tathagata is the unconquered, the unvanquished, the wielder of unbounded power. Therefore he is called the Tathagata. ”

original: Evamādīni suttapadāni veditabbāni. Ādikā gāthāyoti –
analyzed: evamādīni sutta padāni veditabbāni ādikā gāthāyaḥ ti
translated: These are the passages that should be understood as referring to the first kind of confidence. The first kind of verse:

original: “Ahañhi arahā loke, ahaṃ satthā anuttaro;
analyzed: aham hi arahā loke aham satthā anuttaraḥ
translated: “I am the one who is perfected in the world, I am the supreme teacher;

original: Ekomhi sammāsambuddho, sītibhūtosmi nibbuto. ;
analyzed: ekaḥ amhi sammāsambuddhaḥ sīti bhūtaḥ asmi nibbutaḥ
translated: I alone am a fully enlightened Buddha, cooled, and released.

original: “Danto damayataṃ seṭṭho, santo samayataṃ isi;
analyzed: dantaḥ damayatam seṭṭhaḥ santaḥ samayatam isi
translated: “I am the tamed among the tamed, the sage among those who merge,

original: Mutto mocayataṃ aggo, tiṇṇo tārayataṃ varo.🔽“Nayimasmiṃ loke parasmiṃ vā pana,🔽Buddhena seṭṭho sadiso ca vijjati;
analyzed: muttaḥ mocayatam aggaḥ tiṇṇaḥ tārayatam varaḥ  nayimasmin loke parasmin vā pana  buddhena seṭṭhaḥ sadisaḥ ca vijjati
translated: The freed among the freed, the released among the released.

original: Āhuneyyānaṃ paramāhutiṃ gato,
analyzed: āhuneyyānam paramāhutim gataḥ
translated: “In this world with its deities, its Mara s, its Brahma s, in this generation with its ascetics and brahmins, with its devas and humans, the Buddha is the one who is unsurpassed, the Teacher of gods and humans.

original: Puññatthikānaṃ vipulapphalesina”nti. –🔽Evamādikā gāthā vitthāretabbā.
analyzed: puññatthikānam vipula phala esinam ti  evamādikā gāthā vitthāretabbā
translated: He is the Buddha, the Blessed One.”🔽The verses beginning with these should be elaborated.

original: Purisadammasārathītiādīsu damitabbāti dammā, damituṃ araharūpā. Purisā ca te dammā
analyzed: purisa damma sārathi iti ādīsu damitabbā ati dammāḥ damitum araha rūpā purisā ca te dammā
translated: As to “the trainer of those who can be trained,” etc.: they are to be tamed , thus they are to be trained ; they are of a kind to be tamed. They are men , and they are to be trained.

original: cāti purisadammā. Visesanassa cettha paranipātaṃ katvā niddeso, dammapurisāti attho.
analyzed: ca ati purisa dammāḥ visesanassa ca ittha para nipātam katvā niddesaḥ damma purisā ti attho
translated: “Men to be tamed” : the word “men” is stated by way of the highest limit, the meaning being “men to be tamed and women to be tamed.”

original: “Satipi mātugāmassapi dammabhāve purisaggahaṇaṃ ukkaṭṭhaparicchedavasenā”ti vadanti.
analyzed: sati pi mātugāmassa api damma bhāve purisa ggahaṇam ukkaṭṭha pariccheda vasena ati vadanti
translated: “Although women are also to be tamed, the word ‘men’ is used by way of the highest limit,” they say.

original: Sāretīti imassa atthaṃ dassento āha “dametī”tiādi. Tattha dametīti sameti, kāyasamādīhi
analyzed: sāreti iti imassa attham dassentaḥ āha dameti itiādi tattha dameti iti sameti kāyasama ādīhi
translated: “Tames” : in order to show the meaning of this word, the Master said “subdues” and so on. Herein, “subdues” means “makes even,” “unifies” by means of the unification of body, speech, and mind.🔽“Yojetī” means “to yoke.”

original: yojetīti attho. Taṃ pana kāyasamādīhi yojanaṃ yathārahaṃ tadaṅgavinayādīsu patiṭṭhāpanaṃ
analyzed: yoja iti iti attho tam pana kāya sama ādīhi yojanam yathāraham tad aṅga vinaya ādīsu patiṭṭhāpanam
translated: “Vinayati” means “to establish in the right way by means of the unification of body, speech, and mind.”

original: hotīti āha “vinetīti vuttaṃ hotī”ti. Adantāti idaṃ sabbena sabbaṃ damataṃ anupagatā
analyzed: hoti iti āha vinā iti iti vuttam hoti iti adantā ati idam sabbena sabbam damatam anupagatā
translated: “Adanta” means “not completely tamed.”

original: purisadammāti vuttāti katvā vuttaṃ. Ye pana vippakatadammabhāvā sabbathā dametabbataṃ
analyzed: purisa dammā ati vuttā ati katvā vuttam ye pana vippakata damma bhāvā sabbathā
translated: “Purisadammasārathī” means “the leader of men to be tamed.”

original: nātivattā, tepi purisadammā eva, yato te satthā dameti. Bhagavā hi visuddhasīlassa
analyzed: na ativattā te pi purisa dammāḥ eva yatas te satthā dameti bhagavā hi visuddha sīlassa
translated: “But those who, because of their complete lack of taming, are not to be tamed at all, are also men to be tamed, since the Master tames them.”

original: paṭhamajjhānaṃ ācikkhati, paṭhamajjhānalābhino dutiyajjhānantiādinā tassa tassa uparūpari
analyzed: paṭhama jhānam ācikkhati paṭhama jhāna lābhinaḥ dutiya jhāna nti ādinā tassa tassa upari upari
translated: For the Master teaches the first jhāna to one who has purified virtue, and the second jhāna to one who has attained the first jhāna, and so on.

original: visesaṃ ācikkhanto ekadesena dantepi sameti. Teneva vuttaṃ visuddhimagge “api ca
analyzed: visesam ācikkhantaḥ eka desena dante pi sameti tena iva vuttam visuddhimagge api ca
translated: and when he points out the difference, he does so by way of the taming of the teeth. That is why it is said in the Visuddhimagga:

original: so bhagavā visuddhasīlādīnaṃ paṭhamajjhānādīni sotāpannādīnañca uttarimaggappaṭipadaṃ
analyzed: saḥ bhagavā visuddha sīla ādīnam paṭhama jhāna ādīni sotāpanna ādīnam ca uttari magga ppaṭipadam
translated: “And when the Blessed One points out the path to the further shore for those whose virtue is purified, etc.,🔽and for stream-enterers, etc., he does so by way of the taming of the teeth.”

original: ācikkhanto dantepi dametiyevā”ti. Atha vā sabbena sabbaṃ adantā ekadesena dantā ca
analyzed: ācikkhantaḥ dante pi ati atha vā sabbena sabbam adantāḥ eka desena dantā ca
translated: Or alternatively, those who are not tamed at all and those who are tamed only in part🔽should be understood as included here by the word “untamed.”

original: idha adantaggahaṇeneva saṅgahitāti veditabbaṃ. Dametuṃ yuttāti damanārahā.🔽Tiracchānapurisātiādīsu uddhaṃ anuggantvā tiriyaṃ añcitā gatā vaḍḍhitāti tiracchānā,
analyzed: idha a danta ggahaṇena iva saṅgahitā iti veditabbam dametum yuttā ati damana arahā  tiracchāna purisa ati ādīsu uddham anuggantvā tiriyam añcitā gatā vaḍḍhitā ati tiracchānā
translated: Worth taming: fit to be tamed.🔽Animals and men, etc.: those who have gone, reached, or arrived at a state of growth that is extended across, spread out, or extended in breadth, are called “animals” .

original: devamanussādayo viya uddhaṃ dīghaṃ ahutvā tiriyaṃ dīghāti attho. Tiracchānāyeva purisā
analyzed: deva manussa ādayaḥ viyas uddham dīgham a hutvā tiriyam tiracchānāya iva purisā
translated: The meaning is that they are not tall like gods and men, but are tall across. Those who are animals and men are “animals and men.”

original: tiracchānapurisā. Manassa ussannatāya manussā. Satisūrabhāvabrahmacariyayogyatādiguṇavasena
analyzed: tiracchāna purisā manassa ussanna tāya manussā sati sūra bhāva brahmacariya yogya tā ādi guṇa vasena
translated: Men: those who are puffed up with conceit. Those whose minds are developed with the special qualities of being fit for the celibate life, etc.,

original: upacitamānasā ukkaṭṭhaguṇacittā. Ke pana te? Jambudīpavāsino sattavisesā. Tenāha bhagavā –
analyzed: upacita mānasāḥ ukkaṭṭha guṇa cittāḥ ke pana te jambudīpa vāsinaḥ satta visesā tena āha bhagavā
translated: are “developed-minded.” But who are they? The seven kinds of human beings who live in the Rose-Apple Island. Hence the Blessed One said:

original: “Tīhi, bhikkhave, ṭhānehi jambudīpakā manussā uttarakuruke ca manusse adhiggaṇhanti deve ca tāvatiṃse. Katamehi tīhi? Sūrā satimanto idha brahmacariyavāso”ti.🔽Tathā hi buddhā bhagavanto paccekabuddhā aggasāvakā mahāsāvakā cakkavattino aññe
analyzed: tīhi bhikkhave ṭhānehi jambudīpakāḥ manussāḥ uttarakuruke ca manusse adhiggaṇhanti deve ca tāvatiṃse katamehi tīhi sūrā satimantaḥ idha brahmacariya vāsā iti  tathā hi buddhāḥ bhagavantaḥ paccekabuddhāḥ aggasāvakāḥ mahāsāvakā cakkavattino aññe
translated: “Monks, in three respects the human beings of Jambudīpa surpass the human beings of Uttarakuru and the Tāvatiṃsa devas. In what three respects? They are brave, mindful, and live the holy life here.”

original: ca mahānubhāvā sattā tattheva uppajjanti. Tehi samānarūpāditāya pana saddhiṃ parittadīpavāsīhi🔽itaramahādīpavāsinopi manussātveva paññāyiṃsūti eke. Apare pana bhaṇanti – lobhādīhi🔽ca alobhādīhi ca sahitassa manassa ussannatāya manussā. Ye hi sattā manussajātikā,
analyzed: ca mahā anubhāvā sattā tattha iva uppajjanti tehi samāna rūpa āditāya pana saddhim paritta dīpa vāsīhi  itara mahā dīpa vāsinaḥ api eke apare pana bhaṇanti lobha ādīhi  ca alobha ādīhi ca sahitassa manassa ussanna tāya manussāḥ ye hi sattāḥ manussa jātikā
translated: For it is there that Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, chief disciples, great disciples, Wheel-turning Monarchs, and other greatly powerful beings arise. But others say that the inhabitants of the other great continents are also human beings, since they resemble human beings here.

original: tesu visesato lobhādayo alobhādayo ca ussannā, te lobhādiussannatāya apāyamaggaṃ,
analyzed: tesu visesataḥ lobha ādayaḥ alobha ādayaḥ ca ussannā te lobha ādi ussanna tāya apāya maggam
translated: But still others say that they are human beings because of the predominance of greed, etc., and non-greed, etc., in their minds. For those beings who are human beings have greed, etc., and non-greed, etc., in abundance. Among them, those in whom greed, etc., predominate fill the lower worlds,

original: alobhādiussannatāya sugatimaggaṃ nibbānagāmimaggañca pūrenti, tasmā lobhādīhi alobhādīhi
analyzed: alobha ādi ussanna tāya sugati maggam nibbāna gāmi maggañca pūrenti tasmā lobha ādīhi alobha ādīhi
translated: while those in whom non-greed, etc., predominate fill the happy destinies and the path to Nibbāna. Therefore, because of the predominance of greed, etc., and non-greed, etc.,

original: ca sahitassa manassa ussannatāya parittadīpavāsīhi saddhiṃ catumahādīpavāsino sattavisesā
analyzed: ca sahitassa manassaḥ ussanna tāya paritta dīpa vāsīhi saddhim catu mahā dīpa vāsinaḥ satta visesā
translated: and because of the abundance of the mind associated with it, the inhabitants of the four great continents are called “humans” in contrast to the inhabitants of the small islands.

original: manussāti vuccanti. Lokiyā pana “manuno apaccabhāvena manussā”ti vadanti. Manu nāma
analyzed: manussā ti vuccanti lokiyā pana manuno apacca bhāvena manussā ti vadanti manu nāma
translated: But according to the worldlings, “humans” are so called because they are the offspring of Manu.

original: paṭhamakappiko lokamariyādāya ādibhūto hitāhitavidhāyako sattānaṃ pituṭṭhāniyo, yo
analyzed: paṭhama kappikaḥ lokam ariyādāya ādi bhūtaḥ hita ahita vidhāyakaḥ sattānam pitu ṭṭhāniyaḥ yaḥ
translated: Manu was the first being in the world, the first to appear at the beginning of the aeon, the one who discovered the means of subsistence for beings, the one who acted like a father to them,

original: sāsane mahāsammatoti vuccati, paccakkhato paramparāya ca tassa ovādānusāsaniyaṃ ṭhitā
analyzed: sāsane mahāsammato ti vuccati paccakkhataḥ paramparāya ca tassa ovāda anusāsaniyam ṭhitā
translated: and who is called the Great Elect in the Dispensation. Those who abide by his advice and instruction, both directly and by tradition,🔽are called “humans” because they are like his children. That is why they are also called “men” .

original: tassa puttasadisatāya manussā mānusāti ca vuccanti. Tato eva hi te māṇavā “manujā”ti🔽ca voharīyanti, manussā ca te purisā cāti manussapurisā.🔽Amanussapurisāti ettha na manussāti amanussā. Taṃsadisatā ettha jotīyati. Tena manussattamattaṃ
analyzed: tassa putta sadisa tāya manussāḥ mānusāḥ ati ca vuccanti tatas eva hi te māṇavāḥ manujāḥ ti  ca voharīyanti manussā ca te purisā ca ati manussa purisā  amanussa purisā ti ettha na manussā ati amanussā tad sadisa tā ettha jotīyati tena manussa ttamattam
translated: “Humans” are also called “men” .

original: natthi, aññaṃ samānanti yakkhādayo amanussāti adhippetā. Na ye keci manussehi aññe,
analyzed: na atthi aññam samānanti yakkha ādayaḥ amanussāḥ ti adhippetāḥ na ye keci manussehi aññe
translated: “Non-human men” : they are not humans , thus they are non-humans . Their similarity to humans is implied. Thus they are called “non-humans” because they have nothing in common with humans except the mere fact of being human. They are not called “non-humans” just because they are different from humans.

original: tathā tiracchānapurisānaṃ visuṃ gahaṇaṃ kataṃ. Yakkhādayo eva ca niddiṭṭhā. Apalālo
analyzed: tathā tiracchāna purisānam visum gahaṇam katam yakkha ādayaḥ eva ca niddiṭṭhāḥ apalālo
translated: and so the animals are mentioned separately. And only the yakkhas, etc., are mentioned.🔽Apalāla,

original: himavantavāsī, cūḷodaramahodarā nāgadīpavāsino, aggisikhadhūmasikhā sīhaḷadīpavāsino
analyzed: himavanta vāsī cūḷodara mahodarāḥ nāga dīpa vāsinaḥ aggisikha dhūmasikhāḥ sīhaḷa dīpa vāsinaḥ
translated: who lived in the Himalayas, Cūḷodara and Mahodara, who lived in the island of Laṅkā, and Aggisikha and Dhūmasikha, who lived in the island of Siṅgala,

original: nibbisā katā dosavisassa vinodanena. Tenāha “saraṇesu ca sīlesu ca patiṭṭhāpitā”ti.
analyzed: nibbisā katā dosa visassa vinodanena tena āha saraṇesu ca sīlesu ca patiṭṭhāpitā ti
translated: were made free from poison by removing the poison of hatred. Hence it is said: “They were established in the refuges and in virtue.”

original: Kūṭadantādayoti ādi-saddena ghoramukhaupāligahapatiādīnaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Sakkādayoti
analyzed: kūṭadanta ādayo ti ādi saddena ghoramukha aupāli gahapati ādīnam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo sakka ādayo ti
translated: Kūṭadanta, etc.: the word “etc.” should be understood to include Ghoramukha, Upāli, the householder, and others. Sakka, etc.:

original: ādi-saddena ajakalāpayakkhabakabrahmādīnaṃ saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Etesaṃ pana damanaṃ
analyzed: ādi saddena aja kalāpa yakkha baka brahma ādīnam saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo etesam pana damanam
translated: the word “etc.” should be understood to include Aṅkura, the yakkha, the brahmin Bakaratta, and others. But the taming of these beings

original: tattha tattha vuttanayeneva sakkā viññātunti atippapañcabhāvato idha na vuccati.
analyzed: tattha tattha vutta nayena iva sakkā viññātun ti atippapañca bhāvataḥ idha na vuccati
translated: can be known in the way stated in each case. Therefore, because it would be too much, it is not stated here.

original: Idañcettha suttaṃ vitthāretabbanti idaṃ kesīsuttaṃ “vinītā vicitrehi vinayanūpāyehī”ti
analyzed: idam ca ittha suttam vitthāretabbam ti idam kesī suttam vinītāḥ vicitrehi vinaya nūpāyehi iti
translated: This sutta should be expanded: this Kesī Sutta should be expanded in the sense of “tamed by various methods of taming,”

original: etasmiṃ atthe vitthāretabbaṃ yathārahaṃ saṇhādīhi upāyehi vinayanassa dīpanato.
analyzed: etasmin atthe vitthāretabbam yathāraham saṇha ādīhi upāyehi vinayanassa dīpanataḥ
translated: because it shows the taming by the appropriate methods such as persuasion, etc.

original: Atthapadanti atthābhibyañjanakaṃ padaṃ, vākyanti attho. Vākyena hi atthābhibyatti,🔽na nāmādipadamattena, ekapadabhāvena ca anaññasādhāraṇo satthu purisadammasārathibhāvo
analyzed: attha padanti attha abhibyañjanakam padam vākyanti atthaḥ vākyena hi attha abhibyatti  na nāma ādi pada mattena eka pada bhāvena ca anañña sādhāraṇaḥ satthu purisa damma sārathi bhāvo
translated: “The word ‘meaning’ is the word that expresses the meaning; the ‘phrase’ is the meaning.

original: dassito hoti. Tenāha “bhagavā hī”tiādi. Aṭṭha disāti aṭṭha samāpattiyo. Tā hi aññamaññaṃ
analyzed: dassitaḥ hoti tena āha bhagavā hi itiādi aṭṭha disā ati aṭṭha samāpattiyo tāḥ hi aññamaññam
translated: For the meaning is expressed by the phrase, not by the mere word beginning with the name. And the fact that the Master is the charioteer of men to be tamed is shown by the single word ‘Lord,’ which is not shared by others.

original: sambandhāpi asaṃkiṇṇabhāvena dissanti apadissanti, disā viyāti vā disā. Asajjamānāti
analyzed: sambandhā api a saṃkiṇṇa bhāvena dissanti apadissanti disā viyāti vā disā a sajjamānā ati
translated: ‘The eight directions’: the eight attainments. For these, though mutually related, are seen and unseen as being unmixed, like the directions.

original: na sajjamānā vasībhāvappattiyā nissaṅgacārā. Dhāvantīti javanavuttiyogato dhāvanti.🔽Ekaṃyeva disaṃ dhāvatīti attano kāyaṃ aparivattantoti adhippāyo, satthārā pana damitā
analyzed: na sajjamānāḥ vasībhāva ppattiyā nissaṅga cārāḥ dhāvanti iti javana vutti yogataḥ dhāvanti  ekam yā iva disam dhāvati iti attanaḥ kāyam a parivattanto ti adhippāyaḥ satthārā pana damitā
translated: ‘Without stumbling’: without stumbling, without faltering, in the attainment of mastery. ‘Running’: running by the union of swiftness.🔽‘Running in one direction’: the intention is that without turning his own body around. But the tamed men to be tamed run in the eight directions by the Master’s power.

original: purisadammā ekiriyāpatheneva aṭṭha disā dhāvanti. Tenāha “ekapallaṅkeneva nisinnā”ti.
analyzed: purisa dammāḥ eka iriyāpathena iva aṭṭha disā dhāvanti tena āha eka pallaṅkena iva nisinnā iti
translated: That is why it is said, ‘seated cross-legged.’

original: Aṭṭha disāti ca nidassanamattametaṃ lokiyehi agatapubbaṃ nirodhasamāpattidisaṃ amatadisañca pakkhandanato.🔽Diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikaparamatthehītiādīsu diṭṭhadhammo vuccati paccakkho attabhāvo,
analyzed: aṭṭha disā ti ca nidassanam attam etam lokiyehi a gata pubbam nirodha samāpatti disam amata disam ca pakkhandanato  diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika paramatthehi itiādīsu diṭṭhadhammaḥ vuccati paccakkhaḥ atta bhāvo
translated: And the words “in the eight directions” are said merely by way of illustration, since he has penetrated the direction of the attainment of cessation and the deathless direction never before penetrated by worldlings.🔽In the passage beginning “in the highest sense for the here and now and the future” , the “here and now” is one’s present visible state of being.

original: tattha niyuttoti diṭṭhadhammiko, idhalokattho. Kammakilesavasena samparetabbato sammā🔽gantabbato samparāyo, paraloko. Tattha niyuttoti samparāyiko, paralokattho. Paramo
analyzed: tattha niyuttaḥ ti diṭṭhadhammiko idha loka attho kamma kilesa vasena samparetabbataḥ sammā  gantabbataḥ samparāyaḥ para lokaḥ tattha niyuttaḥ ti samparāyikaḥ para loka atthaḥ paramaḥ
translated: One who is bound to it is “one for the here and now” , meaning one for this world. The “future” is so called because one can go there by means of right action and right conduct.🔽One who is bound to it is “one for the future” , meaning one for the other world. The “highest” is the supreme; the “sense” is Nibbāna.

original: uttamo attho paramattho, nibbānaṃ. Tehi diṭṭhadhammikasamparāyikaparamatthehi. Yathārahanti
analyzed: uttamaḥ atthaḥ paramatthaḥ nibbānam tehi diṭṭhadhammika samparāyika paramatthehi yathā arahanti
translated: In the highest sense for the here and now and the future. As is fitting:

original: yathānurūpaṃ, tesu tesu atthesu yo yo puggalo yaṃ yaṃ arahati, tadanurūpaṃ. Anusāsatīti
analyzed: yathānurūpam tesu tesu atthesu yaḥ yaḥ puggalaḥ yam yam arahati tad anurūpam anusāsati iti
translated: as is appropriate, as each one deserves in the various matters. He instructs:

original: vineti tasmiṃ tasmiṃ atthe patiṭṭhāpeti. Saha atthena vattatīti sattho, bhaṇḍamūlena
analyzed: vinā iti tasmin tasmin atthe patiṭṭhāpeti saha atthena vattati iti satthaḥ bhaṇḍa mūlena
translated: he trains, he establishes in the various matters. The “sense” is that which occurs together with the matter;

original: vaṇijjāya desantaraṃ gacchanto janasamūho. Hitupadesādivasena paripāletabbo sāsitabbo
analyzed: vaṇijjāya desantaram gacchantaḥ jana samūhaḥ hita upadesa ādi vasena paripāletabbaḥ sāsitabbaḥ
translated: A caravan is a large group of people traveling to another country for trade. They are to be protected and instructed by means of helpful advice, etc.

original: so etassa atthīti satthā satthavāho niruttinayena. So viya bhagavāti āha “satthā
analyzed: saḥ etassa atthi iti satthā satthavāhaḥ nirutti nayena saḥ viya bhagavā iti āha satthā
translated: The Blessed One has that, thus he is the Caravan-Leader. He is the Caravan-Leader in the sense of the leader of the caravan.

original: viyāti satthā, bhagavā satthavāho”ti.
analyzed: viyāti satthā bhagavā satthavāhā iti
translated: He is like the Caravan-Leader, thus he is the Caravan-Leader. The Blessed One is the Caravan-Leader.

original: Idāni tamatthaṃ niddesapāḷinayena dassetuṃ “yathā satthavāho”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha
analyzed: idāni tam attham niddesa pāḷi nayena dassetum yathā satthavāhaḥ tiādi vuttam tattha
translated: Now, in order to show that meaning by the method of the Niddesa, it is said: “As the Caravan-Leader” and so on. Herein,

original: sattheti satthike jane. Kaṃ udakaṃ tārenti etthāti kantāro, nirudako araññappadeso.
analyzed: satthā iti satthike jane kam udakam tārenti ettha ati kantāraḥ nirudakaḥ arañña ppadeso
translated: in the wilderness means in a wilderness area devoid of water.

original: Ruḷhīvasena pana itaropi araññappadeso tathā vuccati. Corakantāranti corehi adhiṭṭhitakantāraṃ,
analyzed: ruḷhī vasena pana itaraḥ api arañña ppadeso tathā vuccati cora kantāram ti corehi adhiṭṭhita kantāram
translated: But by the method of the wilderness being infested, the other wilderness area is also called a wilderness. A wilderness infested by thieves is a wilderness inhabited by thieves.

original: tathā vāḷakantāraṃ. Dubbhikkhakantāranti dullabhabhikkhaṃ kantāraṃ. Tāretīti akhemantaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: tathā vāḷa kantāram dubbhikkha kantāram ti dullabha bhikkham kantāram tāreti iti a khemanta ṭṭhānam
translated: Likewise, a wilderness infested by wild beasts is a wilderness infested by wild beasts. A wilderness infested by famine is a wilderness where alms are difficult to obtain.🔽He crosses over means he goes beyond a place that is not safe.

original: atikkāmeti. Uttāretītiādi upasaggena padaṃ vaḍḍhetvā vuttaṃ. Atha vā uttāretīti khemantabhūmiṃ
analyzed: atikkāmā iti uttāreti itiādi upasaggena padam vaḍḍhetvā vuttam atha vā uttāreti iti khemanta bhūmim
translated: He rescues means he brings to safety. The word is extended by the prefix ut. Or else, he rescues means he brings to the place of safety.

original: upanento tāreti. Nittāretīti akhemantaṭṭhānato nikkhāmento tāreti. Patāretīti pariggahetvā
analyzed: upanentaḥ tāreti nittāreti iti akhemanta ṭṭhānataḥ nikkhāmentaḥ tāreti patāreti iti pariggahetvā
translated: He rescues by bringing across. He rescues by taking across: he rescues by taking out from the place of danger. He rescues by carrying across: he rescues by carrying across, by taking hold of,

original: tāreti, hatthena pariggahetvā tāreti viya tāretīti attho. Sabbampetaṃ tāraṇuttāraṇādi
analyzed: tāreti hatthena pariggahetvā tāreti viya tāreti iti atthaḥ sabbam petam tāraṇa uttāraṇa ādi
translated: as though he were carrying across by taking hold of with his hand. All this means that he rescues by bringing across, by taking across, by carrying across,

original: khemaṭṭhāne ṭhapanamevāti āha “khemantabhūmiṃ sampāpetī”ti. Satteti veneyyasatte.
analyzed: khema ṭṭhāne ṭhapanam eva ati āha khemanta bhūmim sampāpeti iti satta iti veneyya satte
translated: by establishing in the place of safety. He establishes in the place of safety: he causes to reach the plane of safety. Beings: beings to be trained.

original: Mahāgahanatāya mahānatthatāya dunnittharatāya ca jātiyeva kantāro jātikantāro, taṃ jātikantāraṃ.
analyzed: mahā gahana tāya mahānattha tāya dunnitthara tāya ca jātiyā iva kantāraḥ jāti kantāro tam jāti kantāram
translated: The jungle of birth is a jungle because it is a great thicket, a great wilderness, and difficult to get through. He rescues from the jungle of birth.

original: Ukkaṭṭhaparicchedavasenāti ukkaṭṭhasattaparicchedavasena. Devamanussā eva hi ukkaṭṭhasattā,
analyzed: ukkaṭṭha pariccheda vasena ati ukkaṭṭha satta pariccheda vasena deva manussāḥ eva hi ukkaṭṭha sattā
translated: By the delimitation of the highest: by the delimitation of the highest beings. For only gods and human beings are the highest beings,🔽not animals, etc.,

original: na tiracchānādayo. Etanti “devamanussāna”nti etaṃ vacanaṃ. Bhabbapuggalaparicchedavasenāti
analyzed: na tiracchāna ādayaḥ etat ti deva manussānam ti etam vacanam bhabba puggala pariccheda vasena ati
translated: The word “gods and human beings” is the word “ettha.” By the delimitation of the person capable: by the delimitation of the person capable of entering upon the way to rightness.

original: sammattaniyāmokkamanassa yogyapuggalassa paricchindanavasena. Bhagavatoti nissakke
analyzed: yogya puggalassa paricchindana vasena bhagavataḥ ti nissakke
translated: The Blessed One: the Blessed One, the Blessed One.

original: sāmivacanaṃ yathā “upajjhāyato ajjhetī”ti. Bhagavato santike vāti attho. Upanissayasampattinti
analyzed: sāmi vacanam yathā upajjhāyataḥ ajjheti iti bhagavato santike vā ati atthaḥ upanissaya sampattinti
translated: The word “his” is like the expression “from the preceptor” . The meaning is: “in the presence of the Blessed One.” “The condition for the attainment of the path and fruit”:

original: tihetukapaṭisandhiādikaṃ maggaphalādhigamassa balavakāraṇaṃ. Gaggarāyāti gaggarāya
analyzed: ti hetuka paṭisandhi ādikam magga phala adhigamassa balava kāraṇam gaggarāya ati gaggarāya
translated: the strong cause for the acquisition of the path and fruit, such as the rebirth-linking consciousness accompanied by the three roots of good. “In the Gaggarā lake”:

original: nāma rañño deviyā, tāya vā kāritattā “gaggarā”ti laddhanāmāya. Sare nimittaṃ aggahesīti
analyzed: nāma raññaḥ deviyā tāya vā kārita ttā gaggarā ati laddha nāmāya sare nimittam aggahesi iti
translated: the lake belonging to King Gaggarā, or the lake named after the queen of King Gaggarā. “He took a sign from the water”:

original: “dhammo eso vuccatī”ti dhammasaññāya sare nimittaṃ gaṇhi, gaṇhanto ca pasannacitto🔽parisapariyante nipajji. Sannirumbhitvā aṭṭhāsīti tassa sīse daṇḍassa ṭhapitabhāvaṃ
analyzed: dhammo eso vuccati iti dhamma saññāya sare nimittam gaṇhi gaṇhanto ca pasanna citto  parisa pariyante nipajji sannirumbhitvā aṭṭhāsi iti tassa sīse daṇḍassa ṭhapita bhāvaṃ
translated: he took a sign by means of the perception of water, thinking “water is being spoken of.” And while taking it, he was full of confidence.🔽He lay down at the edge of the assembly. “He stood pressing down on it”:

original: apassanto tattha daṇḍaṃ uppīḷetvā aṭṭhāsi. Maṇḍūkopi daṇḍe ṭhapitepi uppīḷitepi dhammagatena
analyzed: a passantaḥ tattha daṇḍam uppīḍetvā aṭṭhāsi maṇḍūko pi daṇḍe ṭhapite api uppīḍite api dhamma gatena
translated: not seeing the stick placed on his head, he stood pressing down on the stick there. Even when the stick was placed on him and pressed down, the frog,

original: pasādena vissaramakarontova kālamakāsi. Devaloke nibbattasattānaṃ ayaṃ dhammatā,
analyzed: pasādena vissaram akarontā iva kālam akāsi deva loke nibbatta sattānam ayam dhamma tā
translated: through his confidence in the Dhamma, did not move at all but died. This is the nature of beings reborn in the deva world,🔽that they recollect: “From where have I been reborn here? What did I do there?” Therefore,

original: yā “kutohaṃ idha nibbatto, tattha kinnu kho kammamakāsi”nti āvajjanā. Tasmā attano
analyzed: yā kutas aham idha nibbattaḥ tattha kinnu kho kammam akāsinti āvajjanā tasmai attanaḥ
translated: “Where have I been reborn now? What was the kamma I did there?”

original: purimabhavassa diṭṭhattā āha “are ahampi nāma idha nibbatto”ti. Bhagavato pāde sirasā🔽vandīti kataññutāsaṃvaḍḍhitena pemagāravabahumānena vandi.
analyzed: purima bhavassa diṭṭha ttā āha are aham pi nāma idha nibbattaḥ ti bhagavato pāde sirasā  vandi iti kataññu tā saṃvaḍḍhitena pema gārava bahu mānena vandi
translated: Since he had seen his previous existence, he said: “I too was reborn here.”🔽He worshipped the Blessed One’s feet with his head: he worshipped with great love, respect and honour, which were increased by his gratitude.

original: Jānantova pucchīti mahājanassa kammaphalaṃ buddhānubhāvañca paccakkhaṃ kātukāmo bhagavā
analyzed: jānantaḥ iva pucchi iti mahājanassa kamma phalam buddha anubhāvañca paccakkham kātu kāmaḥ bhagavā
translated: He asked, though he knew: the Blessed One asked with the verse “Who is worshipping my feet?” in order to make it clear to the multitude that he knew the result of kamma and the Blessed One’s power.

original: “ko me vandatī”ti gāthāya pucchi. Tattha koti devanāgayakkhagandhabbādīsu ko, katamoti
analyzed: kaḥ me vandati iti gāthāya pucchi tattha kaḥ iti deva nāga yakkha gandhabba ādīsu kaḥ katamaḥ ti

original: attho. Meti mama. Pādānīti pāde. Iddhiyāti imāya evarūpāya deviddhiyā. Yasasāti iminā

original: edisena yasena ca parivārena ca. Jalanti vijjotamāno. Abhikkantenāti ativiya kantena

translated: meaning “the water is his pasture.” For even though some water-dwellers, such as the tortoise, etc., are not water-pastured,

analyzed: mama samīpam āgantvā daṇḍam olubbha tiṭṭhantaḥ mama sīse daṇḍam sannirumbhitvā mama māresi iti attho  sitam katvā iti tathā parittatarena api puñña anubhāvena evam ativiya uḷārāḥ lokiya lokuttara sampattiyaḥ

translated: This is the method of the Niddesa. original: Yathā paṇṇasosā vātā “paṇṇasusā”ti vuccanti, evaṃ bodhetā pajāyāti buddho hetukattuvasena.🔽Hetuattho cettha antonīto. Sabbaññutāya buddhoti sabbadhammabujjhanasamatthāya buddhiyā

translated: Just as in the world winds that blow away the chaff are called “chaff-blowers” , so too the Blessed One is awakened because he has awakened the people. original: buddhoti attho. Sabbadassāvitāya buddhoti sabbadhammabodhanasamatthāya buddhiyā buddhoti

translated: He is awakened because he has himself awakened to the supreme perfect enlightenment, not because he is awakened by others.🔽The meaning is, he is awakened because he has himself awakened to the supreme perfect enlightenment.🔽He is awakened because he has destroyed non-awakening and acquired awakening. Awakening is the same as enlightenment.

original: anatthantaraṃ. Tattha yathā rattaguṇayogato ratto paṭo, evaṃ buddhaguṇayogato buddhoti🔽ñāpanatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Tato paraṃ buddhoti netaṃ nāmantiādi atthānugatāyaṃ paññattīti
analyzed: anatthantaram tattha yathā ratta guṇa yogataḥ rattaḥ paṭaḥ evam buddha guṇa yogataḥ buddhaḥ iti  ñāpana attham vuttam tatas param buddhaḥ ti na etam nāma nti ādi attha anugatā ayam paññattī iti
translated: Herein, just as a cloth is called “red” because of the possession of the quality of redness, so too the Blessed One is called “awakened” because of the possession of the quality of awakening.

original: bodhanatthaṃ vuttanti evamettha imināpi kāraṇena bhagavā buddhoti veditabbo.

translated: This is said in order to show the meaning of “awakened.”🔽The rest is stated in order to show the meaning of “Blessed.”🔽Now, in order to show the meaning of “Blessed,” he said, “Blessed is a term for the Blessed One.”

original: Idāni bhagavāti imassa atthaṃ dassento āha “bhagavāti idaṃ panassā”tiādi. Tattha
analyzed: idāni bhagavā iti imassa attham dassentaḥ āha bhagavā ti idam panassa atiādi tattha

original: assāti bhagavato. Guṇavisiṭṭhasattuttamagarugāravādhivacananti sabbehi sīlādiguṇehi

translated: It is a term for the most excellent being distinguished by special qualities, for one who is revered with the highest reverence.

original: visiṭṭhassa tato eva sabbasattehi uttamassa garuno gāravavasena vuccamānavacanametaṃ
analyzed: visiṭṭhassa tatas eva sabba sattehi uttamassa garunaḥ gārava vasena vuccamāna vacanam etam

translated: and he is the supreme one in the accomplishment of the means for the complete removal of all misfortune and for the bestowal of all the happiness that is in accordance with it, and in the accomplishment of the means for the highest and most excellent welfare.

original: aparimāṇānaṃ sattānaṃ uttamaṃ gāravaṭṭhānanti.🔽Bhagavāti vacanaṃ seṭṭhanti seṭṭhavācakaṃ vacanaṃ seṭṭhaguṇasahacaraṇato “seṭṭha”nti🔽vuttaṃ. Atha vā vuccatīti vacanaṃ, attho, tasmā yo “bhagavā”ti vacanena vacanīyo

original: attho, so seṭṭhoti attho. Bhagavāti vacanamuttamanti etthāpi eseva nayo. Gāravayuttoti

analyzed: uppannaḥ mānaḥ iddhimadaḥ nāma  yasa madaḥ pana agārikena api anagārikena api dīpetabbaḥ agārikaḥ api hi ekaccaḥ aṭṭhārasasu
translated: This is called conceit due to success.🔽But conceit due to possessions can be illustrated by both a layman and one gone forth. For a layman, for example, may be the head of a guild or a corporation. He thinks, “I am the head of a guild or a corporation. I am the one who appoints and dismisses. I am the one who gives and takes away.”🔽Or a layman may be a king. He thinks, “I am a king. I can do as I like. I am not subject to anyone else.”

original: seṇīsu ekissā jeṭṭhako hoti, tassa “avasese purise ahaṃ paṭṭhapemi, ahaṃ vicāremī”ti,🔽anagārikopi ekacco katthaci jeṭṭhako hoti, tassa “avasesā bhikkhū mayhaṃ ovāde vattanti,🔽ahaṃ jeṭṭhako”ti majjanavasena uppanno māno yasamado nāma. “Avasesā sattā dussīlā,
analyzed: seṇīsu ekissā jeṭṭhakaḥ hoti tassa avasese purise aham paṭṭhapemi aham vicāremi iti  anagāriko pi ekacco katthaci jeṭṭhakaḥ hoti tassa avasesā bhikkhū mayham ovāde vattanti  aham jeṭṭhako ti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ yasamadaḥ nāma avasesā sattā dussīlā
translated: Or a layman may be a landowner. He thinks, “I am a landowner. I can do as I like with my land. I am not subject to anyone else.”🔽Or a layman may be rich. He thinks, “I am rich. I have great wealth and property. I can do as I like. I am not subject to anyone else.”🔽Or a layman may be a master of the Vedas. He thinks, “I am a master of the Vedas. I am a master of the three Vedas. I am skilled in phonetics and grammar, in rituals and sacrifices, and in the interpretation of the marks of an exceptional man. I am skilled in the language of the Brahmins. I am a master of the mantras. I am skilled in the methods of teaching the mantras. I am a great scholar, a great man, a brilliant expounder, eloquent, with a ready tongue. I can explain the mantras, teach the mantras, and expound the mantras. I can go to a gathering, take a seat, and explain the mantras. I can resolve the questions of those who come to me. I can enter a gathering and refute the arguments of others. I can win a debate. I can make others understand. I can make the hairs of my listeners stand on end. I can make them laugh. I can make them cry. I can make them get up from their seats. I can make them go away. I can make them come back. I can make them do what I want.”

original: ahaṃ pana sīlavā”ti majjanavasena uppanno māno sīlamado nāma. “Avasesānaṃ sattānaṃ🔽kukkuṭassa udakapānamattepi kāle cittekaggatā natthi, ahaṃ pana upacārappanānaṃ lābhī”ti
analyzed: aham pana sīlavāti majjana vasena uppannaḥ māno sīla madaḥ nāma avasesānam sattānam 🔽kukkuṭassa udaka pāna matte pi kāle citta ekagga tā natthi aham pana upacāra ppanānam lābhī iti
translated: Or a layman may be a master of the five branches of knowledge. He thinks, “I am a master of the five branches of knowledge. I am skilled in the language of the Brahmins. I am a great scholar, a great man, a brilliant expounder, eloquent, with a

original: majjanavasena uppanno māno jhānamado nāma. “Avasesā sattā nissippā, ahaṃ sippavā”ti
analyzed: majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ jhānamadaḥ nāma avasesāḥ sattāḥ nissippāḥ aham sippavā ati
translated: Conceit arisen through the thought “I am superior” is called “conceit due to vanity.”🔽Conceit arisen through the thought “I am skilled” is called “conceit due to skill.”🔽Conceit arisen through the thought “I am tall” is called “conceit due to height.”

original: majjanavasena uppanno māno sippamado nāma. “Avasesā sattā rassā, ahaṃ dīgho”ti majjanavasena🔽uppanno māno ārohamado nāma. “Avasesā sattā rassā vā honti dīghā vā, ahaṃ nigrodhaparimaṇḍalo”ti🔽majjanavasena uppanno māno pariṇāhamado nāma. “Avasesānaṃ sattānaṃ sarīrasaṇṭhānaṃ
analyzed: majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ sippamadaḥ nāma avasesā sattā rassāḥ aham dīghaḥ ti majjana vasena  uppannaḥ mānaḥ āroha madaḥ nāma avasesā sattā rassāḥ vā honti dīghāḥ vā aham nigrodhaparimaṇḍalā ti  majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ pariṇāha madaḥ nāma avasesānam sattānam sarīra saṇṭhānam
translated: Conceit arisen through the thought “I am well-proportioned” is called “conceit due to proportion.”🔽Conceit arisen through the thought “I am handsome” is called “conceit due to beauty.”🔽Conceit arisen through the thought “I am powerful” is called “conceit due to power.”🔽Conceit arisen through the thought “I am rich” is called “conceit due to wealth.”🔽Conceit arisen through the thought “I am free from bonds” is called “conceit due to freedom.”🔽Conceit arisen through the thought “I am famous” is called “conceit due to fame.”🔽Conceit arisen through the thought “I am respected” is called “conceit due to respect.”

original: virūpaṃ bībhacchaṃ, mayhaṃ pana manāpaṃ pāsādika”nti majjanavasena uppanno māno saṇṭhānamado🔽nāma. “Avasesānaṃ sattānaṃ sarīre bahū dosā, mayhaṃ pana sarīre kesaggamattampi vajjaṃ
analyzed: virūpam bībhaccham mayham pana manāpam pāsādikam ti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ saṇṭhāna madaḥ  nāma avasesānam sattānam sarīre bahū dosāḥ mayham pana sarīre kesagga mattam pi vajjam
translated: Conceit arisen through the thought “I am happy” is called “conceit due to happiness.”🔽Conceit arisen through the thought “I am healthy” is called “conceit due to health.”🔽Conceit arisen through the thought “I am young” is called “conceit due to youth.”

original: natthī”ti majjanavasena uppanno māno pāripūrimado nāma. Evamayaṃ sabbopi jātiādiṃ
analyzed: natthi iti majjana vasena uppannaḥ mānaḥ pāripūri madaḥ nāma evam ayam sabbaḥ api jāti ādim
translated: Conceit arisen through the thought “I am a householder” is called “conceit due to being a householder.”🔽Conceit arisen through the thought “I am a monk” is called “conceit due to being a monk.”🔽Conceit arisen through the thought “I am a virtuous monk” is called “conceit due to virtue.”🔽Conceit arisen through the thought “I am a monk who has attained jhāna” is called “conceit due to jhāna.”🔽Conceit arisen through the thought “I am a monk who has attained insight” is called “conceit due to insight.”🔽Conceit arisen through the thought “I am a monk who has attained arahantship” is called “conceit due to attainment.”🔽Conceit arisen through the thought “I am a monk who has attained the analytical knowledges” is called “conceit due to the analytical knowledges.”🔽Conceit arisen through the thought “I am a monk who has attained the discriminations” is called “conceit due to the discriminations.”🔽Conceit arisen through the thought “I am a monk who has attained the fruits of

original: nissāya majjanākāravasappavatto māno idha “mado”ti vutto. Kāmaguṇesu cittassa vossaggo
analyzed: nissāya majjana ākāra vasa ppavatto mānaḥ idha mado ti vuttaḥ kāma guṇesu cittassa vossaggo
translated: Conceit is called “drunkenness” here in the sense of the conceit that arises in one who is intoxicated.

original: pamādo, pañcasu kāmaguṇesu satiyā aniggaṇhitvā cittassa vossajjanaṃ, sativirahoti🔽vuttaṃ hoti. Taṇhāvijjā pākaṭāyeva.
analyzed: pamādaḥ pañcasu kāmaguṇesu satiyā a niggaṇhitvā cittassa vossajjanam sati viraho ti  vuttam hoti taṇhā vijjā pākaṭāya iva
translated: Negligence is the giving up of the mind to the five strands of sense pleasure without restraint by mindfulness.🔽Craving and ignorance are evident.🔽And greed, etc., are included in the three roots of unskillfulness.

original: Lobhādayo ca puna tividhākusalamūlanti tikavasena gahitā. Duccaritādīsupi tividha-saddo
analyzed: lobha ādayo ca puna tika vasena gahitāḥ duccarita ādīsu pi tividha saddo
translated: The word “threefold” should be construed with each of the terms beginning with “bad conduct.”

original: paccekaṃ yojetabbo. Tattha kāyaduccaritādīni tividhaduccaritāni. Taṇhāsaṃkilesādayo🔽tividhasaṃkilesā. Rāgamalādayo malīnabhāvakarattā tividhamalāni. Rāgādayo hi cittaṃ
analyzed: paccekam yojetabbo tattha kāya duccarita ādīni tividha duccaritāni taṇhā saṃkilesa ādayo  tividha saṃkilesāḥ rāga mala ādayaḥ tividha malāni rāga ādayaḥ hi cittam
translated: Herein, the three kinds of bad conduct are bodily bad conduct, etc.🔽The three kinds of defilements are the defilement of craving, etc.

original: malīnaṃ karonti, malaṃ gāhāpenti, tasmā “malānī”ti vuccanti. “Rāgo visamaṃ, doso
analyzed: malīnam karonti malam tasmā malāni iti vuccanti rāgaḥ visamam dosaḥ
translated: The three kinds of stains are the stain of lust, etc. For lust, etc., make the mind stained, they cause it to take on a stain, and so they are called “stains.”

original: visamaṃ, moho visama”nti evaṃ vuttā rāgādayo “kāyavisamaṃ vacīvisamaṃ manovisama”nti
analyzed: visamam mohaḥ visamanti evam vuttāḥ rāga ādayaḥ kāya visamam vacī visamam manaḥ visamanti
translated: “Lust is uneven, hate is uneven, delusion is uneven” . These are called “unevenness of body, unevenness of speech, unevenness of mind” .
