original: ca sattā pakkhalanti, pakkhalitā ca sāsanatopi sugatitopi patanti, tasmā pakkhalanapātahetubhāvato🔽“visamānī”ti vuccanti. “Kāmasaññā byāpādasaññā vihiṃsāsaññā”ti evamāgatā kāmādipaṭisaṃyuttā
analyzed: ca sattā pakkhalanti pakkhalitā ca sāsanataḥ pi sugatitaḥ pi patanti tasmā pakkhalana pāta hetu bhāvato  visamāni iti vuccanti kāma saññā byāpāda saññā vihiṃsā saññā ati evam āgatā kāma ādi paṭisaṃyuttā
translated: So too, bodily misconduct, etc., are the three kinds of unevenness. But these are called “unevennesses” because beings fall into lust, etc., and into bodily misconduct, etc., and having fallen, they fall away from the true Dhamma and from heaven.🔽The perceptions associated with lust, etc., are the three kinds of perceptions stated thus: “Perceptions of sensual desire, perceptions of ill will, perceptions of cruelty” .

original: saññā tividhasaññā. Tathā “kāmavitakko byāpādavitakko vihiṃsāvitakko”ti evamāgatā
analyzed: saññā tividha saññā tathā kāma vitakkaḥ byāpāda vitakkaḥ vihiṃsā vitakkaḥ iti evam āgatā
translated: So too, the three kinds of applied thoughts are stated thus: “Applied thought concerned with sensual desire, applied thought concerned with ill will, applied thought concerned with cruelty” .

original: tividhavitakkā. Taṇhāpapañco diṭṭhipapañco mānapapañcoti ime tividhapapañcā. Vaṭṭasmiṃ
analyzed: tividha vitakkā taṇhā papañcaḥ diṭṭhi papañcaḥ māna papañco ti ime tividha papañcāḥ vaṭṭasmin
translated: The three kinds of diffuseness are craving- diffuseness, conceit- diffuseness, and view- diffuseness.

original: satte papañcentīti taṇhādayo “papañcā”ti vuccanti.🔽Catubbidhavipariyesātiādīsu catubbidha-saddo paccekaṃ yojetabbo. Tattha aniccādīni
analyzed: satte papañcenti iti taṇhā ādayaḥ vuccanti  catubbidha vipariyesa atiādīsu catubbidha saddo paccekam yojetabbo tattha anicca ādīni
translated: Craving, etc., are called “diffusenesses” because they diffuse beings in the round of rebirths.🔽In the case of the fourfold perversion, etc., the word “fourfold” should be construed with each . Herein, the four perversions are so called because they misapprehend their objects as permanent, etc., in the way beginning:

original: vatthūni niccantiādinā nayena viparītato esantīti vipariyesā. “Anicce niccanti saññāvipariyeso
analyzed: vatthūni niccanti ādinā nayena viparītataḥ esanti iti vipariyesā anicce niccanti saññā vipariyeso
translated: “What is impermanent is apprehended as permanent” .

original: cittavipariyeso diṭṭhivipariyeso, dukkhe sukhanti saññāvipariyeso cittavipariyeso🔽diṭṭhivipariyeso, asubhe subhanti saññāvipariyeso cittavipariyeso diṭṭhivipariyeso,
analyzed: citta vipariyesaḥ diṭṭhi vipariyesaḥ dukkhe sukhanti saññā vipariyesaḥ citta vipariyeso  diṭṭhi vipariyesaḥ asubhe subhanti saññā vipariyesaḥ citta vipariyesaḥ diṭṭhi vipariyeso
translated: There is perversion of cognizance, perversion of view, and perversion of perception in the case of one who regards what is suffering as happiness.🔽There is perversion of cognizance, perversion of view, and perversion of perception in the case of one who regards what is foul as beautiful.

original: anattani attāti saññāvipariyeso cittavipariyeso diṭṭhivipariyeso”ti evamāgatā dvādasa
analyzed: anattani attā iti saññā vipariyeso citta vipariyeso diṭṭhi vipariyeso ti evam āgatā dvādasa
translated: The perversion of view is the perversion of view. The perversion of perception is the perversion of perception. The perversion of mind is the perversion of mind. The perversion of view is the perversion of view. The perversion of perception is the perversion of perception. The perversion of mind is the perversion of mind. The perversion of view is the perversion of view” .

original: vipallāsā catunnaṃ aniccādivatthūnaṃ vasena “catubbidhavipariyesā”ti vuttā. Ettha🔽pana cittakiccassa dubbalaṭṭhāne diṭṭhivirahitāya akusalasaññāya sakakiccassa balavakāle
analyzed: vipallāsā catunnam anicca ādi vatthūnam vasena catubbidha vipariyesā ati vuttā ettha  pana citta kiccassa dubbala ṭṭhāne diṭṭhi virahitāya akusala saññāya saka kiccassa balava kāle
translated: These twelve perversions are called “the four perversions” according to the four grounds, impermanence, etc.🔽But here the perversion of perception should be understood as the unprofitable perception devoid of view, which is strong at the time of its own function, which is weak in the function of mind.

original: saññāvipallāso veditabbo, diṭṭhivirahitasseva akusalacittassa sakakiccassa balavakāle
analyzed: saññā vipallāsaḥ veditabbaḥ diṭṭhi virahitassa iva akusala cittassa saka kiccassa balava kāle
translated: The perversion of mind is the unprofitable consciousness devoid of view, which is strong at the time of its own function.

original: cittavipallāso, diṭṭhisampayuttacitte diṭṭhivipallāso. Tasmā sabbadubbalo saññāvipallāso,
analyzed: citta vipallāsaḥ diṭṭhi sampayutta citte diṭṭhi vipallāso tasmā sabba dubbalaḥ saññā vipallāso
translated: The perversion of view is in consciousness associated with view. Therefore the perversion of perception is the weakest,

original: tato balavataro cittavipallāso, sabbabalavataro diṭṭhivipallāso. Ajātabuddhidārakassa
analyzed: tatas balavataraḥ citta vipallāso sabba balavataraḥ diṭṭhi vipallāso ajātabuddhi dārakassa
translated: the perversion of mind is stronger than that, and the perversion of view is strongest of all. In the case of a child who has not yet learned to speak,

original: kahāpaṇadassanaṃ viya saññā ārammaṇassa upaṭṭhānākāramattagahaṇato. Gāmikapurisassa
analyzed: kahāpaṇa dassanam viya saññā ārammaṇassa upaṭṭhāna ākāra matta gahaṇato gāmika purisassa
translated: Perception is like the man’s seeing the coins, because it merely apprehends the aspect of the object’s appearance.🔽Consciousness is like the man’s seeing the coins, because it accomplishes the penetration of the characteristics.

original: kahāpaṇadassanaṃ viya cittaṃ lakkhaṇappaṭivedhassapi sampādanato. Kammārassa mahāsaṇḍāsena🔽ayogahaṇaṃ viya diṭṭhi abhinivesaparāmasanato. Tattha cattāro diṭṭhivipallāsā, aniccānattesu🔽niccantiādivasappavattā cattāro saññācittavipallāsāti ime aṭṭha vipallāsā sotāpattimaggena
analyzed: kahāpaṇa dassanam viya cittam lakkhaṇa ppaṭivedhassa api sampādanato kammārassa mahā saṇḍāsena  ayoga haṇam viya diṭṭhi abhinivesa parāmasanato tattha cattāro diṭṭhi vipallāsāḥ anicca anattesu  cattāro saññā citta vipallāsā ti ime aṭṭha vipallāsā sotāpatti maggena
translated: View is like the smith’s taking up the iron, because it clings to the object by over-estimation.🔽Herein, the four perversions of view, which occur as “permanent in what is impermanent,” etc.,🔽and the four perversions of perception and consciousness, which occur as “beautiful in what is ugly,” etc., are abandoned by the path of stream-entry.

original: pahīyanti. Asubhe subhanti saññācittavipallāsā sakadāgāmimaggena tanukā honti, anāgāmimaggena
analyzed: pahīyanti asubhe saññā citta vipallāsā sakadāgāmi maggena tanukāḥ honti anāgāmi maggena
translated: The perversions of perception and consciousness as “beautiful in what is ugly” are weakened by the path of once-return and abandoned by the path of non-return.

original: pahīyanti. Dukkhe sukhanti saññācittavipallāsā arahattamaggena pahīyantīti veditabbā.
analyzed: pahīyanti dukkhe sukhanti saññā citta vipallāsāḥ arahatta maggena pahīyanti iti veditabbā
translated: The perversions of perception and consciousness as “pleasant in what is painful” should be understood as abandoned by the path of Arahantship.🔽The four taints, which are given as “the taint of sensual desire, the taint of being, the taint of view, the taint of ignorance” ,

original: “Kāmāsavo bhavāsavo diṭṭhāsavo avijjāsavo”ti evamāgatā kāmataṇhādayo cattāro āsavanti
analyzed: kāma āsavaḥ bhava āsavaḥ diṭṭha āsavaḥ avijjā āsavaḥ ti evam āgatā kāma taṇhā ādayo cattāro
translated: are sensual desire, etc.

original: cakkhuādito sandanti pavattantīti āsavā. Kiñcāpi cakkhuādito kusalādīnampi pavatti🔽atthi, kāmāsavādayo eva pana vaṇato yūsaṃ viya paggharaṇakaasucibhāvena sandanti,
analyzed: cakkhu āditaḥ sandanti pavattanti iti āsavā kiñcā api cakkhu āditaḥ kusala ādīnam pi  atthi kāma āsava ādayaḥ eva pana vaṇataḥ yūsam viya paggharaṇaka asuci bhāvena sandanti
translated: “They flow from the eye, etc.,” thus they are defilements . And although there is also occurrence of the profitable, etc., from the eye, etc.,🔽nevertheless only the taints of sensual desire, etc., are called “defilements” because of their nature as impure effluence, like pus from a boil.

original: tasmā te eva “āsavā”ti vuccanti. Tattha hi paggharaṇakaasucimhi niruḷho āsavasaddoti.🔽Atha vā dhammato yāva gotrabhuṃ, okāsato yāva bhavaggaṃ savanti gacchanti ārammaṇakaraṇavasena
analyzed: tasmā te eva āsavā ti vuccanti tattha hi paggharaṇaka asucimhi niruḷhaḥ āsava saddo ti  atha vā dhammataḥ yāva gotrabhum okāsataḥ yāva bhavaggam savanti gacchanti ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena
translated: For the word “defilement” is fixed by usage in the sense of impure effluence.

original: pavattantīti āsavā, ete dhamme etañca okāsaṃ antokaritvā pavattantīti attho. Avadhiattho
analyzed: pavattanti iti āsavāḥ ete dhamme etam ca okāsam antokaritvā pavattanti iti atthaḥ avadhi attho
translated: Or alternatively, they flow, they go, by becoming objects of craving, thus they are defilements . The meaning is that they occur making that and those states their object and that and those physical bases.

original: hi ā-kāro. Avadhi ca mariyādābhividhibhedato duvidho. Tattha mariyādaṃ kiriyaṃ bahikatvā
analyzed: hi ākāraḥ avadhi ca mariyādā abhividhi bhedataḥ duvidhaḥ tattha mariyādam kiriyam bahika tvā
translated: For the prefix ā- has the sense of a limit, and a limit is twofold, as a boundary and as an occurrence. Herein, it occurs by making a boundary, by keeping outside,🔽as in the words, “The rain has fallen outside the village” . But it occurs by making an occurrence, by pervading,

original: pavattati yathā “āpāṭaliputtaṃ vuṭṭho devo”ti, abhividhi pana kiriyaṃ byāpetvā pavattati
analyzed: pavattati yathā āpāṭaliputtam vuṭṭhaḥ devaḥ ti abhividhi pana kiriyam byāpetvā pavattati
translated: as in the words, “The rain has fallen over the island” .

original: yathā “ābhavaggaṃ bhagavato yaso pavattatī”ti, abhividhiattho cāyaṃ ā-kāro idha gahito,
analyzed: yathā ābha vaggam bhagavataḥ yasaḥ pavattati iti abhividhi attho ca ayam ākāraḥ idha gahito
translated: and here the prefix ā- is taken in the sense of the intensive.

original: tasmā te dhamme tañca okāsaṃ antokaritvā ārammaṇakaraṇavasena savantīti “āsavā”ti🔽vuccanti. Cirapārivāsiyaṭṭhena madirādayo āsavā viyātipi āsavā. Lokasmiñhi cirapārivāsikā
analyzed: tasmā te dhamme tam ca okāsam antokaritvā ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena savanti iti  vuccanti cirapārivāsiya ṭṭhena madirā ādayaḥ āsavāḥ āsavāḥ lokasmin hi cirapārivāsikā
translated: Therefore, taking those states and that opportunity as internal, they are called “cankers” in the sense of being made an object of contemplation.🔽And they are cankers in the sense of long remaining in the world, like the cankers of wine, etc.,🔽for in the world the cankers of wine, etc., are called “cankers” in the sense of long remaining.

original: madirādayo “āsavā”ti vuccanti. Yadi ca cirapārivāsiyaṭṭhena āsavā, eteyeva bhavitumarahanti.
analyzed: madirā ādayaḥ āsavā ti vuccanti yadi ca cira pārivāsiya ṭṭhena āsavāḥ bhavitum arahanti
translated: And if they are cankers in the sense of long remaining, only these can be so.

original: Vuttañhetaṃ “purimā, bhikkhave, koṭi na paññāyati avijjāya, ito pubbe avijjā nāhosī”tiādi.
analyzed: vuttam ha etam purimā bhikkhave koṭi na paññāyati avijjāya itas pubbe avijjā na ahosi itiādi
translated: For this is said: “Bhikkhus, there is no reckoning of a beginning point for this suffering of beings … for this saṃsāra … for this mentality-materiality … for this consciousness … for these saṃsāric propensities. Before this craving arose, bhikkhus, did consciousness come to be reckoned as ‘with a footing’ or ‘without a footing’?”

original: Aññesu pana yathāvutte dhamme okāsañca ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavattamānesu mānādīsu ca
analyzed: aññesu pana yathā vutte dhamme okāsam ca ārammaṇam katvā pavattamānesu māna ādīsu ca
translated: But when the states mentioned above and the opportunity are present, and when such things as conceit, etc., are present,

original: vijjamānesu attattaniyādiggāhavasena abhibyāpanaṃ madanakaraṇavasena āsavasadisatā
analyzed: vijjamānesu atta tta niyā diggāha vasena abhibyāpanam madana karaṇa vasena āsava sadisa tā
translated: then the canker-like quality of these states is due to their being manifested by the assumption of self, etc., and to their intoxicating,

original: ca etesaṃyeva, na aññesanti dvīsupi atthavikappesu etesuyeva āsavasaddo niruḷhoti
analyzed: ca etesam yeva na aññesanti dvīsu pi attha vikappesu etesu yeva āsava saddo niruḷho ti
translated: and so the word “canker” is established in these two senses only,

original: daṭṭhabbo. Āyataṃ vā saṃsāradukkhaṃ savanti pasavantītipi āsavā. Na hi taṃ kiñci
analyzed: daṭṭhabbo āyatam vā saṃsāra dukkham savanti pasavanti iti pi āsavāḥ na hi tam kiñci
translated: and it flows out, it causes to flow out, the suffering of the round of rebirths, thus it is a canker .

original: saṃsāradukkhaṃ atthi, yaṃ āsavehi vinā uppajjeyya.
analyzed: saṃsāra dukkham atthi yam āsavehi vinā uppajjeyya
translated: For there is no suffering of the round of rebirths that arises without cankers.

original: “Abhijjhā kāyagantho byāpādo kāyagantho sīlabbataparāmāso kāyagantho idaṃsaccābhiniveso
analyzed: abhijjhā kāya ganthaḥ byāpādaḥ kāya ganthaḥ sīlabbata parāmāsaḥ kāya ganthaḥ idaṃsacca abhinivesaḥ
translated: “Covetousness is a bodily tie, ill will is a bodily tie, misapprehension of virtue and duty is a bodily tie, misapprehension of a view is a bodily tie” .

original: kāyagantho”ti evamāgatā abhijjhādayo cattāro yassa saṃvijjanti, taṃ cutipaṭisandhivasena🔽vaṭṭasmiṃ ganthenti ghaṭentīti ganthā. “Kāmogho bhavogho diṭṭhogho avijjogho”ti evamāgatā
analyzed: kāyagantho ti evam āgatāḥ abhijjhā ādayo cattāro yassa saṃvijjanti tam cuti paṭisandhi vasena  vaṭṭasmim ganthenti ghaṭenti iti ganthā kāma oghaḥ bhava oghaḥ diṭṭha oghaḥ avijja oghaḥ ti evam āgatā
translated: The four beginning with covetousness that are included here tie one to the round of rebirths by means of decease and rebirth linking, thus they are ties .

original: cattāro kāmataṇhādayo yassa saṃvijjanti, taṃ vaṭṭasmiṃ ohananti osīdāpentīti oghā.
analyzed: cattāro kāma taṇhā ādayaḥ yassa saṃvijjanti tam vaṭṭasmin ohananti osīdāpenti iti oghā
translated: The four beginning with craving for sense desires that are included here in the passage, “The flood of sense desires, the flood of becoming, the flood of views, the flood of ignorance” , draw one into the round of rebirths, they cause one to sink down in it, thus they are floods .

original: Teyeva “kāmayogo bhavayogo diṭṭhiyogo avijjāyogo”ti evamāgatā vaṭṭasmiṃ yojentīti
analyzed: te yeva kāma yogaḥ bhava yogaḥ diṭṭhi yogaḥ avijjā yogo ti evam āgatāḥ vaṭṭasmim yojenti iti
translated: The same four, in the passage, “The yoke of sense desires, the yoke of becoming, the yoke of views, the yoke of ignorance” , yoke one to the round of rebirths, thus they are yokes .

original: yogā. Ariyā etāya na gacchantīti agati, sā chandādivasena catubbidhā. “Cīvarahetu

analyzed: vā bhikkhuno taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati iti evam āgatā cattāro taṇhuppādā tattha  iti bhava abhava hetu uti ettha iti iti nidassane nipātaḥ yathā cīvara ādi hetu evam bhava abhava hetu pi iti

original: attho. Bhavābhavoti cettha paṇītapaṇītatarāni telamadhuphāṇitādīni adhippetāni. Kāmupādānādīni cattāri upādānāni.
analyzed: atthaḥ bhava abhavaḥ ti ca ittha paṇīta paṇītatarāni tela madhu phāṇita ādīni adhippetāni kāma upādāna ādīni cattāri upādānāni
translated: “Or craving arises in a bhikkhu when he is seeking a particular kind of robe, alms food, resting place, or requisite of a monk” means that craving arises in a bhikkhu when he is seeking a particular kind of robe, alms food, resting place, or requisite of a monk.🔽“Or craving arises in a bhikkhu when he is seeking a particular kind of robe, alms food, resting place, or requisite of a monk” means that craving arises in a bhikkhu when he is seeking a particular kind of robe, alms food, resting place, or requisite of a monk.🔽“Or craving arises in a bhikkhu when he is seeking a particular kind of robe, alms food, resting place, or requisite of a monk” means that craving arises in a bhikkhu when he is seeking a particular kind of robe, alms food, resting place, or requisite of a monk.

original: Pañca cetokhilātiādīsu “buddhe kaṅkhati, dhamme, saṅghe, sikkhāya kaṅkhati, sabrahmacārīsu🔽kupito hoti anattamano āhatacitto khilajāto”ti evamāgatāni pañca cetokhilāni, ceto🔽khilayati thaddhabhāvaṃ āpajjati etehīti cetokhilāni. Vinibandhādīsupi pañca-saddo
analyzed: pañca cetokhilāti ādīsu buddhe kaṅkhati dhamme saṅghe sikkhāya kaṅkhati sabrahmacārīsu 🔽kupitaḥ hoti an atta manaḥ āhata cittaḥ khila jātaḥ iti evam āgatāni pañca cetaḥ khilāni cetaḥ 🔽khilayati thaddha bhāvam āpajjati etehi iti cetokhilāni vinibandha ādīsu pi pañca saddaḥ
translated: “Or craving arises in a bhikkhu when he is seeking a particular kind of robe, alms food, resting place, or requisite of a monk” means that craving arises in a bhikkhu when he is seeking a particular kind of robe, alms food

original: paccekaṃ yojetabbo. “Kāme avītarāgo hoti, kāye avītarāgo, rūpe avītarāgo, yāvadatthaṃ
analyzed: paccekam yojetabbo kāme a vīta rāgaḥ hoti kāye a vīta rāgaḥ rūpe a vīta rāgaḥ yāvadattham
translated: They should be taken separately. “He is not free from lust for sensual pleasures, not free from lust for the body, not free from lust for forms, and he eats as much as he likes up to the extent of his stomach’s capacity,

analyzed: udarāvadehakam bhuñjitvā seyya sukham passa sukham middha sukham anuyuttaḥ viharati
translated: and he lives devoted to the pleasure of sleep, the pleasure of sloth, the pleasure of lying down, the pleasure of the right side, and he lives devoted to the pleasure of society,

analyzed: aññataram devanikāyam paṇidhāya brahmacariyam carati iti āgatā pañca cittam bandhitvā  muṭṭhiyam katvā viya gaṇhanti iti cetaḥ vinibandhāḥ ete hi taṇhā ppavatti bhāvataḥ kusala ppavattiyā
translated: and he lives the holy life aiming at some order of gods thus: ‘By this rite or vow or mortification or spiritual life I shall become a god or one of the gods’ ” .🔽If it be said: “They are taken as though they were a lump in the mind’s field of consciousness,”

But in the sense of the meaning of the words🔽they are the mind’s bonds since the mind is bound by them, is restrained by them, in the sense of the non-beautiful.🔽The five beginning with sensual desire are hindrances in the sense of obstructing profitable states.

original: kusaladhamme nīvārenti āvarantīti nīvaraṇāni. Rūpābhinandanādayo pañcābhinandanā.
analyzed: kusala dhamme āvaranti iti nīvaraṇāni rūpa abhinandana ādayaḥ pañca abhinandanā

analyzed: imāni cha vivāda mūlāni yasmai kuddhaḥ vā sandiṭṭhi parāmāsī vā sandiṭṭhi parāmasitāya
translated: These are the six roots of disputes. Because one who is angry or who is dominated by anger, etc.,

analyzed: kalaham viggaham vivādam āpajjati tasmā kodha ādayaḥ cha vivāda mūlāni iti vuccanti
translated: or who is obstinate and who is dominated by his own views, enters into a dispute, a quarrel, a contention, therefore anger, etc., are called the six roots of disputes.

original: Rūpataṇhāsaddataṇhādayo cha taṇhākāyā. Kāmarāgapaṭighadiṭṭhivicikicchābhavarāgamānāvijjā
analyzed: rūpa taṇhā sadda taṇhā ādayaḥ cha taṇhā kāyā kāma rāga paṭigha diṭṭhi vicikicchā bhava rāga māna a vijjā
translated: The six bases of craving are craving for visible forms, craving for sounds, etc. The seven underlying tendencies are lust for sensual pleasure, resentment, conceit, lust for existence, ignorance,  and views.

original: sattānusayā. Thāmagataṭṭhena appahīnaṭṭhena ca anusentīti anusayā. Micchādiṭṭhimicchāsaṅkappamicchāvācāmicchākammantamicchāājīvamicchāvāyāmamicchāsatimicchāsamādhī aṭṭha micchattā.

translated: They are called underlying tendencies because they underlie and because they have not been abandoned. The eight wrongnesses are wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong concentration.

original: “Taṇhaṃ paṭicca pariyesanā, pariyesanaṃ paṭicca lābho, lābhaṃ paṭicca vinicchayo,
analyzed: taṇham paṭicca pariyesanā pariyesanam paṭicca lābhaḥ lābham paṭicca vinicchayaḥ
translated: Craving is a condition for seeking, seeking is a condition for gain, gain is a condition for decision,

analyzed: vinicchayam paṭicca chanda rāgaḥ chanda rāgam paṭicca ajjhosānam ajjhosānam paṭicca
translated: decision is a condition for desire and lust, desire and lust is a condition for determination, determination is a condition for attachment, attachment is a condition for possessiveness,

analyzed: pariggahaḥ pariggaham paṭicca macchariyam macchariyam paṭicca ārakkhaḥ ārakkha adhikaraṇam
translated: and hoarding, and because of hoarding there is stinginess, and because of stinginess there is guarding of property, and because of guarding of property

analyzed: daṇḍa ādāna sattha ādāna kalaha viggaha vivāda tuvaṃ tuvaṃ pesuñña musāvādāḥ aneke pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ
translated: there arise the taking up of the stick, the taking up of the sword, quarrels, disputes, arguments, strife, abuse, lying, and many bad unwholesome things.

analyzed: dhammā sambhavanti iti evam āgatā pariyesana ādayaḥ nava taṇhā mūlakā tattha taṇham paṭicca ati
translated: ” So the nine beginning with seeking are rooted in craving. Herein, “with craving as condition” means

analyzed: taṇham nissāya pariyesanā ati rūpa ādi ārammaṇa pariyesanā sā hi taṇhāya sati hoti
translated: with craving as support. “Seeking” is seeking for objects such as visible forms. That is present when there is craving. “Gain” is

analyzed: rūpa ādi ārammaṇa paṭilābho saḥ hi pariyesanāya sati hoti vinicchayo ti idha vitakko
translated: the obtaining of objects such as visible forms. That is present when there is seeking. “Determination” is applied thought .

analyzed: adhippetaḥ lābham labhitvā hi iṭṭha aniṭṭham sundara asundaram ca vitakkena iva vinicchinati
translated: For when one has gained something, it is only by applied thought that he determines what is desirable and undesirable, beautiful and ugly, in it,

translated: thinking: “This much will be for the purpose of visible forms, this much for the purpose of sounds, etc.,

analyzed: mayham bhavissati ettakam parassa ettakam paribhuñjissāmi ettakam nidahissāmi iti
translated: this much will be for me, this much for others, this much I shall use, this much I shall store up.”

original: Tena vuttaṃ “lābhaṃ paṭicca vinicchayo”ti. Chandarāgoti evaṃ akusalavitakkena vitakkite
analyzed: tena vuttam lābham paṭicca vinicchayaḥ ti chanda rāgaḥ ti evam akusala vitakkena vitakkite
translated: So it is said: “From gain comes decision.”

analyzed: vatthusmim dubbala rāgo ca balava rāgo ca uppajjati chando ti hi idha dubbala rāgassa adhivacanam
translated: “From lust for sensual desires comes decision”: when a thing has been thought about with unwholesome thought, lust for sensual desires arises in a weak or strong form. For “lust” here is a term for weak lust.

original: Ajjhosānanti ahaṃ mamanti balavasanniṭṭhānaṃ. Pariggahoti taṇhādiṭṭhivasena pariggahakaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: ajjhosānam ti aham mama nti balava sanniṭṭhānam pariggaho ti taṇhā diṭṭhi vasena pariggaha karaṇam
translated: “From adherence” : the strong form of the determination “I am” and “mine.” “From grasping” : the act of grasping by way of craving and views.

original: Macchariyanti parehi sādhāraṇabhāvassa asahanatā. Tenevassa porāṇā evaṃ vacanatthaṃ
analyzed: mat śariyanti parehi sādhāraṇa bhāvassa a sahana tā porāṇāḥ evam vacana attham
translated: “From avarice” : the inability to bear sharing with others. Hence the ancients gave this explanation of the meaning of the word:

analyzed: vadanti idam acchariyam mayham eva hotu mā aññassa acchariyam hotu uti pavatta ttā

original: ārakkhahetūti attho. Daṇḍādānādīsu paranisedhanatthaṃ daṇḍassa ādānaṃ daṇḍādānaṃ.

original: Ekatodhārādino satthassa ādānaṃ satthādānaṃ. Kalahoti kāyakalahopi vācākalahopi.🔽Purimo purimo virodho viggaho. Pacchimo pacchimo vivādo. Tuvaṃ tuvanti agāravavacanaṃ, tvaṃ tvanti attho.
analyzed: ekatodhāra ādino satthassa ādānam sattha ādānam kalaho ti kāya kalahaḥ api vācā kalahaḥ api  purimaḥ purimaḥ virodhaḥ viggahaḥ pacchimaḥ pacchimaḥ vivādo tuvam tuvanti agārava vacanam tvam tuvanti attho
translated: The taking up of the knife is the taking up of the weapon. Quarrel is a quarrel with the body or a quarrel with speech.🔽The first is the first disagreement, the second is the first dispute. You you is a word of disrespect, the meaning is you you.

original: Pāṇātipātaadinnādānakāmesumicchācāramusāvādapisuṇavācāpharusavācāsamphappalāpaabhijjhābyāpādamicchādiṭṭhī
analyzed: pāṇa atipāta a dinna ādāna kāmesu micchā ācāra musā vāda pisuṇa vācā pharusa vācā sampha ppalāpa abhijjhā byāpāda micchā diṭṭhī
translated: Killing living beings, taking what is not given, sexual misconduct, false speech, malicious speech, harsh speech, gossip, covetousness, ill will, and wrong view.

original: dasa akusalakammapathā. Cattāro sassatavādā cattāro ekaccasassatavādā cattāro antānantikā
analyzed: dasa akusala kammapathā cattāro sassata vādā cattāro ekacca sassata vādā cattāro anta anantikā
translated: These are the ten unwholesome courses of action. There are four eternalist views, four partial eternalist views, four annihilationist views,

original: cattāro amarāvikkhepikā dve adhiccasamuppannikā soḷasa saññīvādā aṭṭha asaññīvādā
analyzed: cattāro amarāvikkhepikāḥ dve adhiccasamuppannikā soḷasa saññīvādāḥ aṭṭha asaññīvādāḥ
translated: four who proclaim the infinite, two who proclaim chance origination, sixteen who proclaim perception, eight who proclaim non-perception,

original: aṭṭha nevasaññīnāsaññīvādā satta ucchedavādā pañca paramadiṭṭhadhammanibbānavādāti
analyzed: aṭṭha nevasaññī nāsaññī vādā satta uccheda vādā pañca parama diṭṭhadhamma nibbāna vādā ati
translated: eight who proclaim neither perception nor non-perception, seven who proclaim annihilation, and five who proclaim nibbāna here and now.

original: etāni dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhigatāni. Rūpataṇhādichataṇhāyeva paccekaṃ kāmataṇhābhavataṇhāvibhavataṇhāvasena
analyzed: etāni dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhi gatāni rūpa taṇhā ādi cha taṇhāya iva paccekam kāma taṇhā bhava taṇhā vibhava taṇhā vasena
translated: These are the sixty-two views. Craving for form, etc., are each divided into craving for sensual pleasure, craving for becoming, and craving for non-becoming.

original: aṭṭhārasa honti. Tathā hi rūpārammaṇā taṇhā, rūpe vā taṇhāti rūpataṇhā, sā kāmarāgabhāvena
analyzed: aṭṭhārasa honti tathā hi rūpa ārammaṇā taṇhā rūpe vā taṇhā ati rūpa taṇhā sā kāma rāga bhāvena
translated: So there are eighteen. For craving with materiality as its object is craving for materiality, or craving in regard to materiality.🔽This occurs as sensual craving when it occurs enjoying materiality.

original: rūpaṃ assādentī pavattamānā kāmataṇhā, sassatadiṭṭhisahagatarāgabhāvena “rūpaṃ niccaṃ🔽dhuvaṃ sassata”nti evaṃ assādentī pavattamānā bhavataṇhā, ucchedadiṭṭhisahagatarāgabhāvena
analyzed: rūpam assādentī pavattamānā kāma taṇhā sassata diṭṭhi sahagata rāga bhāvena rūpam niccam  dhuvam evam assādentī pavattamānā bhava taṇhā uccheda diṭṭhi sahagata rāga bhāvena
translated: It occurs as craving for existence when it occurs enjoying materiality thus, “Materiality is permanent, stable, eternal, not subject to change” .

original: “rūpaṃ ucchijjati vinassati pecca na bhavatī”ti evaṃ assādentī pavattamānā vibhavataṇhāti
analyzed: rūpam ucchijjati vinassati pecca na bhavati iti evam assādentī pavattamānā vibhava taṇhāti
translated: It occurs as craving for extermination when it occurs enjoying materiality thus, “Materiality is annihilated, destroyed, and does not exist after death” .

original: evaṃ tividhā hoti. Yathā ca rūpataṇhā, evaṃ saddataṇhādayopīti etāni aṭṭhārasa taṇhāvicaritāni
analyzed: evam tividhā hoti yathā ca rūpa taṇhā evam sadda taṇhā ādayaḥ api iti etāni aṭṭhārasa taṇhā vicaritāni
translated: So it is of three kinds. And just as craving for materiality is threefold, so too are craving for sound, and the rest. Thus there are eighteen kinds of craving’s occurrence.

original: honti, tāni ajjhattarūpādīsu aṭṭhārasa, bahiddhārūpādīsu aṭṭhārasāti chattiṃsa, iti
analyzed: honti tāni ajjhatta rūpa ādīsu aṭṭhārasa bahiddhā rūpa ādīsu aṭṭhārasa ati chattiṃsa iti
translated: These are eighteen in the case of internal materiality, and eighteen in the case of external materiality, making thirty-six.

original: atītāni chattiṃsa, anāgatāni chattiṃsa, paccuppannāni chattiṃsāti aṭṭhasatataṇhāvicaritāni,
analyzed: atītāni chattiṃsa anāgatāni chattiṃsa paccuppannāni chattiṃsa ati aṭṭha sata taṇhā vicaritāni
translated: So there are thirty-six in the past, thirty-six in the future, and thirty-six in the present, making one hundred and eight kinds of craving’s occurrence.

original: aṭṭhuttarasatataṇhāvicaritānīti attho. Pabheda-saddo paccekaṃ sambandhitabbo. Tatthāyaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhuttara sata taṇhā vicaritāni iti attho pabheda saddo paccekam sambandhitabbo tattha ayam
translated: the meaning is, they are the eighty-eight kinds of search by means of craving. The word “kinds” should be construed with each of the terms. Here is the construction:

original: yojanā “lobhappabhedo dosappabhedo yāva aṭṭhasatataṇhāvicaritappabhedo”ti. Sabbadarathapariḷāhakilesasatasahassānīti
analyzed: yojanā lobha ppabhedaḥ dosa ppabhedaḥ yāva aṭṭha sata taṇhā vicarita ppabhedo ti sabbadaratha pariḷāha kilesa sata sahassāni iti
translated: “The kinds of greed, the kinds of hate, … down to … the kinds of search by means of the eighty-eight kinds of craving.”🔽All the hundred thousand kinds of grief and fever of beings:

original: sabbāni sattānaṃ darathapariḷāhakarāni kilesānaṃ anekāni satasahassāni. Ārammaṇādivibhāgato
analyzed: sabbāni sattānam daratha pariḷāha karāni kilesānam anekāni sata sahassāni ārammaṇa ādi vibhāgato
translated: all the many hundred thousands of defilements that cause beings’ grief and fever. For the defilements have an endless variety of divisions according to the distinctions of object, etc.,

original: hi pavattiākāravibhāgato ca anantappabhedā kilesā.
analyzed: hi pavatti ākāra vibhāgataḥ ca ananta ppabhedā kilesā
translated: and according to the distinctions of mode of appearance.

original: Saṅkhepato vātiādīsu sampati āyatiñca sattānaṃ anatthāvahattā māraṇaṭṭhena vibādhanaṭṭhena🔽kilesāva māroti kilesamāro. Vadhakaṭṭhena khandhāva māroti khandhamāro. Tathā hi
analyzed: saṅkhepataḥ vāti ādīsu āyatim ca sattānam anattha āvaha tā māraṇa ṭhena vibādhana ṭṭhena  kilesa ava māro ti kilesa māraḥ vadha kaṭṭhena khandha ava māro ti khandha māro tathā hi
translated: The “Mara of defilements” is so called because the defilements are a “Mara” in the sense of killing and in the sense of obstructing, since they bring about the destruction of beings in this way and that both in the present and in the future.🔽The “Mara of aggregates” is so called because the aggregates are a “Mara” in the sense of slaying. For this is said: “He does not understand as it really is ‘form that is to be slain’ … down to … ‘consciousness that is to be slain’” .

original: vuttaṃ “vadhakaṃ rūpaṃ, vadhakaṃ rūpanti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānātī”tiādi. Jātijarādimahābyasananibbattanena
analyzed: vuttam vadhakam rūpam vadhakam rūpanti yathābhūtam na pajānāti itiādi jāti jarā ādi mahā byasana nibbattanena
translated: And because they are the source of the great calamities of birth, ageing, and so on,

original: abhisaṅkhārova māro abhisaṅkhāramāro. Saṃkilesanimittaṃ hutvā guṇamāraṇaṭṭhena devaputtova
analyzed: abhisaṅkhāraḥ uva māraḥ abhisaṅkhāra māraḥ saṃkilesa nimittam hutvā guṇa māraṇa ṭṭhena deva putto va
translated: Mara as a formation is the Mara of formations. Mara as a god is the Mara of the gods, in the sense of killing off the special qualities by becoming a sign of corruption.

original: māroti devaputtamāro. Sattānaṃ jīvitassa jīvitaparikkhārānañca jānikaraṇena mahābādharūpattā
analyzed: māro ti devaputta māro sattānam jīvitassa jīvita parikkhārānam ca jāni karaṇena mahā bādha rūpa ttā
translated: Mara as death is the Mara of death, in the sense of being a great affliction because of causing the loss of life and of the requisites of life for beings.

original: maccu eva māroti maccumāro. Tattha samucchedappahānavasena sabbaso appavattikaraṇena
analyzed: maccu eva māro ti maccumāro tattha samuccheda pahāna vasena sabbaso appavatti karaṇena
translated: Herein, he broke the Mara of defilements by making it not occur at all by means of the abandoning consisting in cutting off;

original: kilesamāraṃ, samudayappahānapariññāvasena khandhamāraṃ, sahāyavekallakaraṇavasena🔽sabbaso appavattikaraṇena abhisaṅkhāramāraṃ, balavidhamanavisayātikkamanavasena devaputtamaccumārañca
analyzed: kilesa māram samudaya ppahāna pariññā vasena khandha māram sahāya vekalla karaṇa vasena  sabbaso appavatti karaṇena abhisaṅkhāra māram bala vidhamana visaya atikkamana vasena devaputta maccu māram ca
translated: he broke the Mara of aggregates by means of full-understanding of the abandoning consisting in exhaustion;🔽he broke the Mara of formations by making it not occur at all by means of the lack of a companion;🔽and he broke the Mara of the gods and the Mara of death by means of the shaking off of power and the surmounting of the objective field. The meaning is that he made them split in two.

original: abhañji, bhagge akāsīti attho. Parissayānanti upaddavānaṃ.
analyzed: abhañji bhagge akāsi iti attho parissayānam ti upaddavānam
translated: Of dangers: of calamities.

original: Satapuññajalakkhaṇadharassāti aneka sata puñña nibbattamahā purisalakkhaṇadharassa.
analyzed: sata puñña ja lakkhaṇa dharassa ati aneka sata puñña nibbatta mahā purisa lakkhaṇa dharassa
translated: Who bears the marks produced by a hundred merits: who bears the great man’s marks produced by a hundred merits.

original: Ettha hi “kevalaṃ satamattena puññakammena ekekalakkhaṇaṃ nibbatta”nti imamatthaṃ
analyzed: ettha hi kevalam sata mattena puñña kammena ekeka lakkhaṇam nibbattanti imam attham
translated: For the meaning of this is this: “Each mark is produced by a hundred merits only.”

original: na rocayiṃsu aṭṭhakathācariyā “evaṃ sante yo koci buddho bhaveyyā”ti, anantāsu pana🔽lokadhātūsu yattakā sattā, tehi sabbehi paccekaṃ satakkhattuṃ katāni dānādīni puññakammāni
analyzed: na rocayiṃsu aṭṭhakathā cariyāḥ evam sante yaḥ koci buddhaḥ bhaveyyāti anantāsu pana  lokadhātūsu yattakā sattā tehi sabbehi paccekam sata kkhattum katāni dāna ādīni puñña kammāni
translated: The teachers of the commentaries did not accept this, saying: “If that were so, anyone could become a Buddha.” But they accepted the meaning as follows:

original: yattakāni, tato ekekaṃ puññakammaṃ mahāsattena sataguṇaṃ kataṃ satanti adhippetanti
analyzed: yattakāni tatas ekekam puñña kammam mahāsattena sataguṇam katam satanti adhippetanti
translated: “The Blessed One has performed each of the meritorious deeds such as giving, etc., a hundred times as many times as there are living beings in the countless world systems.”

original: imamatthaṃ rocayiṃsu. Tasmā idha sata-saddo bahubhāvapariyāyo, na saṅkhyāvisesavacanoti
analyzed: imam attham rocayiṃsu tasmai idha sata saddaḥ bahu bhāva pariyāyaḥ na saṅkhyā visesa vacanā ti
translated: The word sata here is to be understood as a term for a multitude, not as a term for a particular number,🔽just as in such passages as “a hundred and one gods” .

original: daṭṭhabbo “satagghaṃ sataṃ devamanussā”tiādīsu viya. Rūpakāyasampatti dīpitā hoti
analyzed: daṭṭhabbo sataggham satam deva manussa ati ādīsu viya rūpa kāya sampatti dīpitā hoti
translated: The perfection of the material body is shown🔽because it is the basis for the other perfections of fruit. The perfection of the material body is shown🔽because it is the basis for the other perfections of fruit. The word “shown” should be supplied in each case.

original: itarāsaṃ phalasampadānaṃ mūlabhāvato adhiṭṭhānabhāvato ca. Dīpitā hotīti idaṃ dhammakāyasampattītiādīsupi
analyzed: itarāsam phala sampadānam mūla bhāvataḥ adhiṭṭhāna bhāvataḥ ca dīpitā hoti iti idam dhammakāya sampatti iti ādīsu pi
translated: The perfection of the Dhamma body is shown

original: yojetabbaṃ. Tattha pahānasampadāpubbakattā ñāṇasampadādīnaṃ dhammakāyasampatti dīpitā
analyzed: yojetabbam tattha pahāna sampadā pubbaka ttā ñāṇa sampadā ādīnam dhammakāya sampatti dīpitā
translated: because the perfection of the knowledge, etc., is preceded by the perfection of relinquishment.

original: hotīti veditabbaṃ. Lokiyasarikkhakānaṃ bahumatabhāvoti ettha bhāgyavantatāya lokiyānaṃ🔽bahumatabhāvo, bhaggadosatāya sarikkhakānaṃ bahumatabhāvoti yojetabbaṃ. Evaṃ ito
analyzed: hoti iti veditabbam lokiya sarikkhakānam bahu mata bhāvaḥ ti ettha bhāgyavanta tāya lokiyānam  bahu mata bhāvaḥ bhagga dosa tāya sa rikkhakānam bahu mata bhāvaḥ ti yojetabbam evam itas
translated: should be understood. The respect of worldlings and of those like oneself: here the respect of worldlings should be construed as due to the possession of good fortune, and the respect of those like oneself as due to the absence of faults.

original: paresupi yathākkamaṃ yojanā veditabbā.🔽Puññavantaṃ gahaṭṭhā khattiyādayo abhigacchanti, pahīnadosaṃ dosavinayāya dhammaṃ
analyzed: paresu pi yathākkamam yojanā veditabbā  puññavantam gahaṭṭhāḥ khattiya ādayaḥ abhigacchanti pahīna dosam dosa vinayāya dhammaṃ
translated: and this should be understood. The respect of worldlings who are fortunate and of those who are like oneself who have abandoned faults: here the respect of worldlings who are fortunate should be construed as the respect of worldlings who are fortunate, and the respect of those who are like oneself who have abandoned faults should be construed as the respect of those who are like oneself who have abandoned faults. The construction should be understood in this way also in the following instances.

original: desetīti pabbajitā tāpasaparibbājakādayo abhigacchantīti āha “gahaṭṭhapabbajitehi🔽abhigamanīyatā”ti. Abhigatānañca tesaṃ kāyacittadukkhāpanayane paṭibalabhāvo āmisadānadhammadānehi🔽upakārasabbhāvato rūpakāyaṃ tassa pasādacakkhunā, dhammakāyaṃ paññācakkhunā disvā
analyzed: deseti iti pabbajitā tāpasa paribbājaka ādayaḥ abhigacchanti iti āha gaha ṭṭha pabbajitehi  abhigamanīya tā ati abhigatānam ca tesam kāya citta dukkha apanayane paṭibala bhāvaḥ āmisa dāna dhamma dānehi  upakāra sabbhāvataḥ rūpa kāyam tassa pasāda cakkhunā dhamma kāyam paññā cakkhunā disvā
translated: The respect of householders and of those gone forth: householders such as nobles, etc., who are fortunate go to one who is virtuous, and ascetics such as those who are wanderers go to one who has abandoned faults and teaches the Dhamma for the removal of faults.🔽Thus it should be understood. The ability to dispel the bodily and mental pain of those who approach one: having seen with the eye of confidence the material body of one who is able to help by giving material things and the Dhamma, and having seen with the eye of wisdom the Dhamma body of one who is able to help by giving the Dhamma, one should understand that he dispels the twofold pain of those who approach him because he is fortunate.

original: dukkhadvayassa paṭippassambhanatoti veditabbo. Bhāgyavantatāya upagatānaṃ āmisadānaṃ
analyzed: dukkha dvayassa paṭippassambhanataḥ ti veditabbaḥ bhāgyavanta tāya upagatānam āmisa dānam
translated: The giving of material things to those who approach one because they are fortunate,

Adhiṭṭhānādivasena icchitanipphādanaṃ pākammaṃ. Sayaṃvasitā issarabhāvo🔽īsitā. Iddhividhe vasībhāvo vasitā. Ākāsena vā gacchato aññaṃ vā kiñci karoto yattha🔽katthaci vosānappatti yatthakāmāvasāyitā. “Kumārakarūpādidassana”ntipi vadanti. Evamidaṃ
analyzed: ime saṅgahitā tattha kāyassa aṇu bhāva karaṇam aṇimā ākāse gamana ādīnam  araha bhāvena lahu bhāvaḥ laghimā mahattam mahimā kāyassa mahanta tā āpādanam iṭṭha desassa  pāpuṇanam patti adhiṭṭhāna ādi vasena icchita nipphādanam pākammam sayaṃvasi tā issara bhāvo  īsitā iddhividhe vasībhāvaḥ vasitā ākāsena vā gacchataḥ aññam vā kiñci karotaḥ yattha  katthaci vosāna ppatti vadanti evam idam
translated: These six are included in the category of supernormal powers. Herein, the making of the body small is the “diminution” . The lightness of the body by virtue of the state of an Arahant, which is the condition for walking on water without breaking through it, etc., is the “lightness” . The making of the body large is the “greatness” . The reaching of a desired place is the “wishing” . The production of what is desired by resolution, etc., is the “agency” . The sovereignty of one who is self-dependent is the “lordship” . The mastery of the kinds of supernormal power is the “mastery” . The ability to alight anywhere one wishes when travelling through the air or when doing anything else is the “will-to-power” . Some say that the “will-to-power” is the showing of the form of a young man, etc. This is how the exposition should be understood here as to meaning.🔽As to order:🔽

original: aṭṭhavidhaṃ lokiyasammataṃ issariyaṃ. Taṃ pana bhagavato iddhividhantogadhaṃ anaññasādhāraṇañcāti🔽āha “sabbakāraparipūraṃ atthī”ti. Tathā lokuttaro dhammo atthīti sambandho. Evaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhavidham lokiya sammatam issariyam tam pana bhagavataḥ anañña sādhāraṇam ca ati  āha sabba kāra paripūram atthi iti tathā lokuttaraḥ dhammo atthi iti sambandhaḥ evam
translated: These six are included in the category of psychic power. Herein, the making of the body small is the “diminution” . The lightness of the body by virtue of the state of an Arahant, which is the condition for walking on water as though on land, etc., is the “lightness” . The making of the body large is the “greatness” . The reaching of a desired place is the “reaching” . The production of what is desired by resolution, etc., is the “wielding power” . The sovereignty of self-mastery is the “mastery” . The mastery of psychic power is the “mastery of psychic power” . The ability to go wherever one wishes, either through the air or by some other means, is the “wishing” . Some say that the “wishing” is the seeing of the forms of young men, etc. Thus this psychic power is accepted in the world as eightfold. But the psychic power of the Blessed One is fulfilled in all its aspects, and it is not shared by others. Therefore it is said: “There is psychic power fulfilled in all its aspects.” Likewise, there is the supramundane Dhamma. The word “there is” is to be construed with each clause.

original: yasādīsupi atthi-saddo yojetabbo.
analyzed: yasa ādīsu pi atthi saddaḥ yojetabbaḥ
translated: The word “there is” should be construed in the same way with “glory,” etc.

original: Kesañci yaso padesavutti ayathābhūtaguṇasannissayattā aparisuddho ca hoti, na evaṃ🔽tathāgatassāti dassetuṃ “lokattayabyāpako”ti vuttaṃ. Tattha idha adhigatasatthuguṇānaṃ
analyzed: kesañci ayathābhūta guṇa sannissaya ttā aparisuddho ca hoti na evam  tathāgatassa iti dassetum loka ttaya byāpakaḥ iti vuttam tattha idha adhigata satthu guṇānam
translated: Some people’s fame is confined to a limited area because it is based on qualities that are not real. But the Tathāgata’s fame is not like that.

original: āruppe uppannānaṃ “itipi so bhagavā”tiādinā bhagavato yaso pākaṭo hotīti āha “lokattayabyāpako”ti.
analyzed: āruppe uppannānam saḥ bhagavān iti ādinā bhagavataḥ yasaḥ pākaṭaḥ hoti iti āha loka ttaya byāpakaḥ ti
translated: In order to show this, it is said that it “spreads throughout the three worlds.” Here, the fame of the Blessed One, “Thus indeed is the Blessed One,” becomes evident through the qualities of the Teacher that are attained in the immaterial world.

original: Yathābhuccaguṇādhigatoti yathābhūtaguṇehi adhigato. Ativiya parisuddhoti yathābhūtaguṇādhigatattā🔽eva accantaparisuddho. Sabbākāraparipūrāti anavasesalakkhaṇānubyañjanādisampattiyā
analyzed: yathābhucca guṇa adhigataḥ iti yathābhūta guṇehi adhigataḥ ativiya parisuddhaḥ ti yathābhūta guṇa adhigata ttā  eva accanta parisuddhaḥ sabba ākāra paripūrā ati anavasesa lakkhaṇa anubyañjana ādi sampattiyā
translated: “Attained through real qualities” means attained through real qualities. “Extremely pure” means extremely purified,🔽because of the attainment of real qualities. “Complete in every aspect” means complete in all aspects through the possession of the characteristics, secondary marks, etc., without exception.

original: sabbākārehi paripuṇṇā. Sabbaṅgapaccaṅgasirīti sabbesaṃ aṅgapaccaṅgānaṃ sobhā. Yaṃ
analyzed: sabba ākārehi paripuṇṇā sabbaṅga paccaṅga sirī iti sabbesam aṅga paccaṅgānam sobhā yam
translated: “Beauty of every limb and every minor part” means the beauty of all the limbs and minor parts.🔽Whatever is desired and wished for by him,

original: yaṃ etena icchitaṃ patthitanti “tiṇṇo tāreyya”ntiādinā yaṃ yaṃ etena lokanāthena
analyzed: yam etena icchitam tiṇṇo tāreyyanti ādinā yam yam etena lokanāthena
translated: whatever is desired and wished for by this one, the Lord of the World,

original: manovacīpaṇidhānavasena icchitaṃ kāyapaṇidhānavasena patthitaṃ. Tathevāti paṇidhānānurūpameva.
analyzed: manaḥ vacī paṇidhāna vasena icchitam kāya paṇidhāna vasena patthitam tathā iva ati paṇidhāna anurūpam eva
translated: and what is wished for by means of the resolution of mind and speech is what is resolved upon by means of the resolution of body. “Just so” means “in accordance with the resolution.”

original: Sammāvāyāmasaṅkhāto payattoti vīriyapāramibhāvappatto ariyamaggapariyāpanno ca sammāvāyāmasaṅkhāto ussāho.
analyzed: sammāvāyāma saṅkhāto payatto ti vīriya pārami bhāva ppatto ariya magga pariyāpanno ca sammāvāyāma saṅkhātaḥ ussāhaḥ
translated: “Endowed with right endeavour” means endowed with the perfection of energy, and right endeavour is the energy included in the noble path.

original: Kusalādīhi bhedehīti sabbattikadukapadasaṅgahitehi kusalādippabhedehi. Paṭiccasamuppādādīhīti
analyzed: kusala ādīhi bhedehi iti sabba ttika duka pada saṅgahitehi kusala ādi ppabhedehi paṭiccasamuppāda ādīhi iti
translated: “By means of the different kinds of profitable, etc.”: by means of the different kinds of profitable, etc., included in the three and four categories. “By means of dependent origination, etc.”:🔽by means of the dependent origination, etc., included in the three and four categories. By the word “etc.,”

original: ādi-saddena na kevalaṃ vibhaṅgapāḷiyaṃ āgatā satipaṭṭhānādayova saṅgahitā, atha kho
analyzed: ādi saddena na kevalam vibhaṅga pāḷiyam āgatā sati paṭṭhāna ādayaḥ iva saṅgahitāḥ atha kho
translated: not only the foundations of mindfulness, etc., given in the Vibhaṅga text are included, but also

original: saṅgahādayo samayavimuttādayo ṭhapanādayo tikapaṭṭhānādayo ca saṅgahitāti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: saṅgaha ādayo samaya vimutta ādayo ṭhapana ādayo tika paṭṭhāna ādayo ca saṅgahitā iti veditabbam
translated: the summaries, the kinds of deliverance, the kinds of resoluteness, the foundations of success, etc., are included.

original: Pīḷanasaṅkhatasantāpavipariṇāmaṭṭhena vā dukkhamariyasaccantiādīsu pīḷanaṭṭho taṃsamaṅgino
analyzed: pīḷana saṅkhata santāpa vipariṇāma ṭṭhena vā dukkham ariya saccanti ādīsu pīḷana ṭṭho tad samaṅginaḥ
translated: “The noble truth of suffering, etc., in the sense of oppressing, burning, and changing,” etc.: the meaning of oppressing is the oppressing of a being that is a member of that .

original: sattassa hiṃsanaṃ avipphārikatākaraṇaṃ. Saṅkhataṭṭho samecca saṅgamma sambhūya paccayehi
analyzed: sattassa hiṃsanam a vipphārika tā karaṇam saṅkhata ṭṭhaḥ samecca saṅgamma sambhūya paccayehi
translated: The meaning of formed is that they are formed by coming together, by assembling, by combination, by the concurrence of conditions.

original: katabhāvo. Santāpaṭṭho dukkhadukkhatādīhi santāpanaṃ paridahanaṃ. Vipariṇāmaṭṭho
analyzed: kata bhāvaḥ santāpa ṭṭhaḥ dukkha dukkha tā ādīhi santāpanam paridahanam vipariṇāma ṭṭhaḥ
translated: The characteristic of burning is burning, consuming, by the suffering of pain, etc.,

original: jarāya maraṇena cāti dvidhā vipariṇāmetabbatā. Samudayassa āyūhanaṭṭho dukkhassa
analyzed: jarāya maraṇena ca ati dvidhā vipariṇāmetabba tā samudayassa dukkhassa
translated: The characteristic of change is the state of being liable to change in two ways, through ageing and through death.🔽The characteristic of accumulating is the heaping up of suffering by the accumulation of kamma, which is the cause of suffering.

original: nibbattanavasena sampiṇḍanaṃ. Nidānaṭṭho “idaṃ taṃ dukkha”nti nidassentassa viya
analyzed: nibbattana vasena sampiṇḍanam nidānaṭṭhaḥ idam tam dukkhan ti nidassentassa viya
translated: The characteristic of revealing is the revealing of suffering as “this is suffering,” like one who points out that “this is gold.”🔽The characteristic of binding is the binding of suffering by the suffering of the round of rebirths.

original: samuṭṭhāpanaṃ. Saṃyogaṭṭho saṃsāradukkhena saṃyojanaṃ. Palibodhaṭṭho maggādhigamassa🔽nivāraṇaṃ. Nirodhassa nissaraṇaṭṭho sabbūpadhīnaṃ paṭinissaggasabhāvattā tato vinissaṭatā,
analyzed: samuṭṭhāpanam saṃyoga ṭṭhaḥ saṃsāra dukkhena saṃyojanam palibodha ṭṭhaḥ magga adhigamassa  nivāraṇam nirodhassa nissaraṇa ṭṭhaḥ sabba upadhīnam paṭinissagga sabhāva tā tatas vinissaṭa tā
translated: The characteristic of obstructing is the obstructing of the attainment of the path.🔽The characteristic of escape is the escape from all the kinds of assuming, or it is the sign of the escape from that.🔽The characteristic of seclusion is the state of being dissociated from all formations.

original: taṃnissaraṇanimittatā vā. Vivekaṭṭho sabbasaṅkhāravisaṃyuttatā. Asaṅkhataṭṭho kenacipi🔽paccayena anabhisaṅkhatatā. Amataṭṭho niccasabhāvattā maraṇābhāvo, sattānaṃ maraṇābhāvahetutā
analyzed: tad nissaraṇa nimitta tā vā viveka ṭhaḥ sabba saṅkhāra visaṃyutta tā asaṅkhata ṭṭhaḥ kenacipi  paccayena an abhisaṅkhata tā amataṭṭhaḥ nicca sabhāva ttā maraṇa abhāvaḥ sattānam maraṇa abhāva hetu tā
translated: The characteristic of the unformed is the state of being unformed by any condition.🔽The characteristic of the deathless is the state of being permanent, the absence of death, or the state of being the cause of the absence of death in beings.🔽The characteristic of outlet is the state of being the outlet from the suffering of the round of rebirths.

original: vā. Maggassa niyyānaṭṭho vaṭṭadukkhato nikkamanaṭṭho. Hetuattho nibbānassa sampāpakabhāvo.
analyzed: vā maggassa niyyāna aṭṭhaḥ vaṭṭa dukkhataḥ nikkamana aṭṭhaḥ hetu atthaḥ nibbānassa sampāpaka bhāvaḥ
translated: The characteristic of cause is the state of being the cause of the realization of Nibbāna.

original: Dassanaṭṭho accantasukhumassa nibbānassa sacchikaraṇaṃ. Ādhipateyyaṭṭho catusaccadassane
analyzed: dassana aṭṭhaḥ accanta sukhumassa nibbānassa sacchikaraṇam ādhipateyya ṭṭhaḥ catu acca dassane
translated: The meaning of seeing is the realization of the most refined bliss, Nibbāna.

original: sampayuttānaṃ ādhipaccakaraṇaṃ, ārammaṇādhipatibhāvo vā visesato maggādhipativacanato.
analyzed: sampayuttānam ādhipacca karaṇam ārammaṇa adhipati bhāvaḥ vā visesataḥ magga adhipati vacanato
translated: The meaning of predominance is the predominance of the associated states in the seeing of the four truths, or else the predominance of the object, since the path is called “predominant” in particular.🔽For although the jhānas, etc., have predominance over their objects,

original: Satipi hi jhānādīnaṃ ārammaṇādhipatibhāve “jhānādhipatino dhammā”ti evamādiṃ avatvā
analyzed: sati api hi jhāna ādīnam ārammaṇa adhipati bhāve jhāna adhipatino dhammā ti evamādim avatvā
translated: nevertheless, instead of saying “dhammas that are predominant through jhāna” and so on,🔽the Exalted One says “dhammas that are predominant through the path.”

original: “maggādhipatino dhammā”icceva vuttaṃ, tasmā viññāyati “atthi maggassa ārammaṇādhipatibhāve
analyzed: magga adhipatino vuttam tasmā viññāyati atthi maggassa ārammaṇa adhipati bhāve
translated: Therefore it is known that there is a difference in the predominance of the path over its object.

original: viseso”ti. Eteyeva ca pīḷanādayo soḷasākārāti vuccanti.
analyzed: visesaḥ ti ca pīḷana ādayo soḷasa ākārā ti vuccanti
translated: And these same sixteen aspects beginning with suffering are called the “divine abidings,” the “brahma-faring,” and the “noble abidings.”

original: Dibbabrahmaariyavihāretiādīsu kasiṇādiārammaṇāni rūpāvacarajjhānāni dibbavihāro.
analyzed: dibba brahma ariya vihāra iti ādīsu kasiṇa ādi ārammaṇāni rūpāvacara jhānāni dibba vihāro
translated: The jhānas of the fine-material sphere, which have as their object the kasiṇa and so on, are the “divine abidings” .🔽The jhānas of the four divine abodes beginning with loving-kindness are the “brahma-faring” .

original: Mettādijjhānāni brahmavihāro. Phalasamāpatti ariyavihāro. Kāmehi vivekaṭṭhakāyatāvasena
analyzed: mettā ādi jhānāni brahmavihāro phala samāpatti ariya vihāro kāmehi viveka ṭṭha kāya tā vasena
translated: The attainment of fruition is the “noble abiding” .🔽The unification of mind by seclusion of the body is bodily seclusion.🔽The unification of mind by seclusion from the hindrances, etc., is mental seclusion.

original: ekībhāvo kāyaviveko. Paṭhamajjhānādinā nīvaraṇādīhi vivittacittatā cittaviveko. Upadhiviveko
analyzed: ekībhāvaḥ kāya vivekaḥ paṭhama jhāna ādinā nīvaraṇa ādīhi vivitta citta tā citta vivekaḥ upadhi vivekaḥ
translated: Seclusion from acquisitions is

original: nibbānaṃ. Upadhīti cettha cattāro upadhī kāmupadhi khandhupadhi kilesupadhi abhisaṅkhārupadhīti.🔽Kāmāpi hi “yaṃ pañca kāmaguṇe paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṃ somanassaṃ, ayaṃ kāmānaṃ assādo”ti
analyzed: nibbānam upadhi iti ca ittha cattāraḥ upadhī kāma upadhi khandha upadhi kilesa upadhi abhisaṅkhāra upadhi iti  hi yam pañca kāmaguṇe paṭicca uppajjati sukham somanassam ayam kāmānam assādo ti
translated: Nibbāna. Herein, the four kinds of clinging are clinging to sense desires, clinging to views, clinging to rules and vows, and clinging to a doctrine of self.🔽For sense desires are called “clinging” in the sense of “Herein sense desires are clung to” ,🔽since they are the footing for the pleasure and joy that arise with the five strands of sense desire as object,

original: evaṃ vuttassa sukhassa adhiṭṭhānabhāvato upadhīyati ettha sukhanti iminā vacanatthena
analyzed: evam vuttassa sukhassa adhiṭṭhāna bhāvataḥ upadhīyati ettha sukhan ti iminā vacana tthena
translated: and are thus described as “the gratification of sense desires” .

original: “upadhī”ti vuccanti, khandhāpi khandhamūlakassa dukkhassa adhiṭṭhānabhāvato, kilesāpi🔽apāyadukkhassa adhiṭṭhānabhāvato, abhisaṅkhārāpi bhavadukkhassa adhiṭṭhānabhāvato
analyzed: upadhi iti vuccanti khandhā api khandha mūlakassa dukkhassa adhiṭṭhāna bhāvato kilesā api  apāya dukkhassa adhiṭṭhāna bhāvataḥ bhava dukkhassa adhiṭṭhāna bhāvataḥ
translated: The aggregates are called “clinging” in the sense of “Herein the aggregates are clung to” since they are the footing for the suffering rooted in the aggregates.🔽The defilements are called “clinging” in the sense of “Herein the defilements are clung to” since they are the footing for the suffering of the states of loss.🔽The determinations are called “clinging” in the sense of “Herein the determinations are clung to” since they are the footing for the suffering of the round of rebirths.

original: vuttanayena “upadhī”ti vuccanti. Imehi pana catūhi upadhīhi vivittatāya nibbānaṃ
analyzed: vutta nayena upadhi iti vuccanti imehi pana catūhi upadhīhi vivitta tāya nibbānam
translated: And it is because of its isolation from these four kinds of clinging that Nibbāna is called

original: “upadhiviveko”ti vuccati.
analyzed: upadhi vivekaḥ ti vuccati
translated: “isolation from clinging.”

original: Suññatākārena nibbānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavatto ariyamaggo suññatavimokkho. So hi
analyzed: suññata ākārena nibbānam ārammaṇam katvā pavattaḥ ariya maggo suññata vimokkho so hi
translated: The noble path that occurs making Nibbāna its object by means of the void aspect is the void deliverance. For

original: suññatāya dhātuyā uppannattā suññato, kilesehi ca vimuttattā vimokkho. Eteneva nayena
analyzed: suññatāya dhātuyāḥ uppanna ttā suññataḥ kilesehi ca vimutta ttā vimokkho etena iva nayena
translated: It is void because it has arisen in the void element, and it is liberation because of being liberated from defilements.🔽In the same way, the liberation of the desireless is the liberation that occurs making the desireless Nibbāna its object.

original: appaṇihitākārena nibbānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavatto appaṇihitavimokkho. Animittākārena🔽nibbānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavatto animittavimokkho. Atha vā suññatānupassanāsaṅkhātāya
analyzed: appaṇihita ākārena nibbānam ārammaṇam katvā pavattaḥ appaṇihita vimokkho animitta ākārena  nibbānam ārammaṇam katvā pavattaḥ animitta vimokkhaḥ atha vā suññatā anupassanā saṅkhātāya
translated: The signless liberation is the liberation that occurs making the signless Nibbāna its object.

original: anattānupassanāya vasena paṭiladdho ariyamaggo āgamanavasena “suññatavimokkho”ti
analyzed: anatta anupassanāya vasena paṭiladdhaḥ ariya maggo āgamana vasena suññata vimokkho ti
translated: Or alternatively, the noble path that is reached by means of the insight into voidness called “contemplation of voidness”

original: vuccati. Tathā appaṇihitānupassanāsaṅkhātāya dukkhānupassanāya vasena paṭiladdho
analyzed: vuccati tathā appaṇihita anupassanā saṅkhātāya dukkha anupassanāya vasena paṭiladdhaḥ
translated: is called the void liberation because it is the arrival. In the same way, the desireless liberation is the noble path that is reached by means of the insight into the desireless called “contemplation of pain.”

original: appaṇihitavimokkho. Animittānupassanāsaṅkhātāya aniccānupassanāya vasena paṭiladdho
analyzed: appaṇihita vimokkhaḥ animitta anupassanā saṅkhātāya anicca anupassanāya vasena paṭiladdhaḥ
translated: And the signless liberation is the noble path that is reached by means of the insight into the signless called “contemplation of impermanence.”

original: “animittavimokkho”ti veditabbo. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: a nimitta vimokkhaḥ ti veditabbaḥ vuttam ha etam
translated: For this is said:

original: “Aniccato manasikaronto adhimokkhabahulo animittavimokkhaṃ paṭilabhati, dukkhato
analyzed: aniccataḥ manasikarontaḥ adhimokkha bahulaḥ a nimitta vimokkham paṭilabhati dukkhataḥ
translated: “One who gives attention to impermanence, being abundant in resolution, obtains the signless liberation. One who gives attention to pain … obtains the desireless liberation. One who gives attention to impermanence … obtains the void liberation” .

original: manasikaronto passaddhibahulo appaṇihitavimokkhaṃ paṭilabhati, anattato manasikaronto🔽vedabahulo suññatavimokkhaṃ paṭilabhatī”ti.🔽Aññeti lokiyaabhiññādike.🔽Kilesābhisaṅkhāravasena bhavesu paribbhamanaṃ, tañca taṇhāpadhānanti āha “taṇhāsaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: manasikaronto passaddhi bahulaḥ appaṇihita vimokkham paṭilabhati anattataḥ manasikaronto  veda bahulaḥ suññata vimokkham paṭilabhati iti  aññā iti lokiya abhiññā ādike  kilesa abhisaṅkhāra vasena bhavesu paribbhamanam tat ca taṇhā apadhānam ti āha taṇhā saṅkhātam
translated: and he attains the signless deliverance of mind.🔽He attains the emptiness deliverance of mind.”🔽“Other” means mundane direct-knowledge, etc.🔽Wandering in the kinds of becoming through the formations of defilement, and that is dominated by craving, thus he said “formed by craving”🔽

translated: Another method: He is the Blessed One because he is the possessor of parts, because he is the possessor of what is eaten, because he is the possessor of a portion, because he is the possessor of a portion, because he is the possessor of what is eaten, because he is the possessor of a portion, because he is the possessor of a portion.

original: Bhāgavā bhatavā bhāge, bhage ca vani bhattavā;
analyzed: bhāgavā bhatavā bhāge bhage ca vani bhattavā
translated: He is the possessor of parts, the possessor of what is eaten, the possessor of a portion,

original: Bhage vami tathā bhāge, vamīti bhagavā jino.
analyzed: bhage tathā bhāge vami iti bhagavā jinaḥ
translated: and the possessor of a portion, the possessor of what is eaten, the possessor of a portion, and the possessor of a portion.

original: Tattha kathaṃ bhāgavāti bhagavā? Ye te sīlādayo dhammakkhandhā guṇakoṭṭhāsā, te anaññasādhāraṇā
analyzed: tattha katham bhāgavā ati bhagavā ye te sīla ādayaḥ dhamma kkhandhāḥ guṇa koṭṭhāsā te anañña sādhāraṇā
translated: Herein, how is it that he is the possessor of parts? The aggregates of states beginning with virtue, which are the component parts of the noble one’s states, are not shared by others,

original: niratisayā tathāgatassa atthi upalabbhanti. Tathā hissa sīlaṃ samādhi paññā vimutti
analyzed: niratisayā tathāgatassa atthi upalabbhanti tathā hissa sīlam samādhi paññā vimutti
translated: they are unsurpassed, and they exist and are found in the Perfect One. For his virtue, concentration, understanding, deliverance,

original: vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ, hirī ottappaṃ, saddhā vīriyaṃ, sati sampajaññaṃ, sīlavisuddhi
analyzed: vimutti ñāṇa dassanam hirī ottappam saddhā vīriyam sati sampajaññam sīla visuddhi
translated: knowledge and vision of deliverance, conscience, shame, faith, energy, mindfulness, full awareness, purification of virtue,

original: diṭṭhivisuddhi, samatho vipassanā, tīṇi kusalamūlāni, tīṇi sucaritāni, tayo sammāvitakkā,
analyzed: diṭṭhi visuddhi samathaḥ vipassanā tīṇi kusala mūlāni tīṇi su caritāni tayo sammāvitakkā
translated: purification of consciousness, serenity, insight, three kinds of good conduct, three kinds of right reflection,

original: tisso anavajjasaññā, tisso dhātuyo, cattāro satipaṭṭhānā, cattāro sammappadhānā,
analyzed: tisso anavajja saññā tisso dhātuyo cattāro sati paṭṭhānā cattāro sammappadhānā
translated: three kinds of right knowledge, three kinds of good wishes, three kinds of right mindfulness, three kinds of concentration, four establishments of mindfulness, four right efforts,

original: cattāro iddhipādā, cattāro ariyamaggā, cattāri ariyaphalāni, catasso paṭisambhidā,
analyzed: cattāraḥ iddhipādā cattāro ariya maggā cattāri ariya phalāni catasso paṭisambhidā
translated: the four bases of spiritual success, the four noble paths, the four noble fruits, the four discriminations,

original: catuyoniparicchedakañāṇāni, cattāro ariyavaṃsā, cattāri vesārajjañāṇāni, pañca padhāniyaṅgāni,
analyzed: catu yoni paricchedaka ñāṇāni cattāraḥ ariya vaṃsā cattāri vesārajja ñāṇāni pañca padhāniyaṅgāni
translated: the four kinds of knowledge that bring about the delimitation of the sense-spheres, the four noble traditions, the four kinds of knowledge of self-confidence, the five factors of striving,

original: pañcaṅgiko sammāsamādhi, pañcañāṇiko sammāsamādhi, pañcindriyāni, pañca balāni, pañca
analyzed: pañcaṅgikaḥ sammāsamādhi pañcañāṇikaḥ sammāsamādhi pañca indriyāni pañca balāni pañca
translated: the five-factored right concentration, the five-factored right concentration with knowledge, the five faculties, the five powers,

original: nissāraṇīyā dhātuyo, pañca vimuttāyatanañāṇāni, pañca vimuttiparipācanīyā saññā,
analyzed: nissāraṇīyāḥ dhātuyaḥ pañca vimutta āyatana ñāṇāni pañca vimutti paripācanīyā saññā
translated: the five elements of escape, the five kinds of knowledge of the bases of spiritual success, the five perceptions that mature in deliverance,

original: cha anussatiṭṭhānāni, cha gāravā, cha nissāraṇīyā dhātuyo, cha satatavihārā, cha
analyzed: cha anussati ṭṭhānāni cha gāravā cha nissāraṇīyāḥ dhātuyaḥ cha satata vihārā cha
translated: the six instances of recolletedness, the six kinds of respect, the six elements of escape, the six kinds of constant abiding,

original: anuttariyāni, chanibbedhabhāgiyā saññā, cha abhiññā, cha asādhāraṇañāṇāni, satta
analyzed: anuttariyāni cha nibbedha bhāgiyā saññā cha abhiññā cha asādhāraṇa ñāṇāni satta
translated: the six unsurpassed things, the six kinds of perception that lead to penetration, the six kinds of direct knowledge, the six kinds of knowledge not held in common, the seven

original: aparihānīyā dhammā, satta ariyadhanāni, satta bojjhaṅgāni, satta sappurisadhammā,
analyzed: a parihānīyāḥ dhammā satta ariya dhanāni satta bojjhaṅgāni satta sappurisa dhammā
translated: things that are not to be despised, the seven kinds of wealth of the noble ones, the seven factors of enlightenment, the seven ideas proper to a true man,

original: satta nijjaravatthūni, satta saññā, sattadakkhiṇeyyapuggaladesanā, sattakhīṇāsavabaladesanā,
analyzed: satta nijjara vatthūni satta saññā satta dakkhiṇeyya puggala desanā satta khīṇāsava bala desanā

original: aṭṭhapaññāpaṭilābhahetudesanā, aṭṭha sammattāni, aṭṭhalokadhammātikkamo, aṭṭha ārambhavatthūni,

original: aṭṭhaakkhaṇadesanā, aṭṭha mahāpurisavitakkā, aṭṭhaabhibhāyatanadesanā, aṭṭha vimokkhā,
analyzed: aṭṭha akkhaṇa desanā aṭṭha mahāpurisa vitakkāḥ aṭṭha abhibha āyatana desanāḥ aṭṭha vimokkhā
translated: the teaching of the eight inopportune times, the eight thoughts of a great man, the teaching of the eight bases of mastery, the eight liberations,

original: nava yonisomanasikāramūlakā dhammā, nava pārisuddhipadhāniyaṅgāni, navasattāvāsadesanā,
analyzed: nava yoni soma nasikāra mūlakā dhammā nava pārisuddhi padhā niyaṅgāni nava sattāvāsa desanā
translated: the nine things rooted in proper attention, the nine factors of striving for purity, the teaching of the nine abodes of beings,

original: nava āghātappaṭivinayā, nava saññā, nava nānattā, nava anupubbavihārā, dasa nāthakaraṇā
analyzed: nava āghātappaṭivinayāḥ nava saññāḥ nava nānattāḥ nava anupubbavihārāḥ dasa nāthakaraṇā
translated: the nine ways of overcoming annoyance, the nine kinds of perception, the nine kinds of variety, the nine successive abidings, the ten ideas that serve as the basis for mindfulness,

original: dhammā, dasa kasiṇāyatanāni, dasa kusalakammapathā, dasa sammattāni, dasa ariyavāsā,
analyzed: dhammā dasa kasiṇa āyatanāni dasa kusala kamma pathāḥ dasa sammattāni dasa ariya vāsā
translated: the ten kasiṇa bases, the ten profitable courses of action, the ten right ways, the ten dwellings of the noble ones,

original: dasa asekkhadhammā, dasa tathāgatabalāni, ekādasa mettānisaṃsā, dvādasa dhammacakkākārā,
analyzed: dasa asekkha dhammāḥ dasa tathāgata balāni ekādasa mettā nisaṃsāḥ dvādasa dhamma cakka ākārā
translated: the ten ideas of one beyond training, the ten powers of a Tathāgata, the eleven benefits of loving-kindness, the twelve aspects of the Wheel of the True Idea,

original: terasa dhutaguṇā, cuddasa buddhañāṇāni, pañcadasa vimuttiparipācanīyā dhammā, soḷasavidhā
analyzed: terasa cuddasa buddha ñāṇāni pañcadasa vimutti paripācanīyāḥ dhammāḥ soḷasavidhā
translated: the thirteen ascetic practices, the fourteen kinds of knowledge of a Buddha, the fifteen ideas that ripen in liberation, the sixteen kinds of

original: ānāpānassati, soḷasa aparantapanīyā dhammā, aṭṭhārasa buddhadhammā, ekūnavīsati paccavekkhaṇañāṇāni,🔽catucattālīsa ñāṇavatthūni, paññāsa udayabbayañāṇāni, paropaṇṇāsa kusaladhammā, sattasattati
analyzed: āna apāna ssati soḷasa aparantapanīyāḥ dhammāḥ aṭṭhārasa buddha dhammāḥ ekūnavīsati paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇāni  catucattālīsa ñāṇa vatthūni paññāsa udaya bbaya ñāṇāni paropaṇṇāsa kusala dhammā satta sattati
translated: Mindfulness of breathing, the sixteen modes of contemplation of repulsiveness, the eighteen principal qualities of the Buddha, the nineteen kinds of knowledge to be reviewed,🔽the forty-four bases of knowledge, the fifty kinds of knowledge of rise and fall, the sixty-one profitable ideas, the seventy-seven bases of knowledge,

original: ñāṇavatthūni, catuvīsatikoṭisatasahassasamāpattisañcārimahāvajirañāṇaṃ, anantanayasamantapaṭṭhānapavicayapaccavekkhaṇadesanāñāṇāni,
analyzed: ñāṇa vatthūni catuvīsati koṭi sata sahassa samāpatti sañcāri mahāvajira ñāṇam ananta naya samanta paṭṭhāna pavicaya paccavekkhaṇa desanā ñāṇāni
translated: the great knowledge of the wielder of the mighty sword that travels through the four-and-twenty koṭis of attainments, the knowledge of the survey of the infinite, the knowledge of the survey of the directions, the knowledge of the survey of the plane, the knowledge of the survey of reviewing,

original: tathā anantāsu lokadhātūsu anantānaṃ sattānaṃ āsayādivibhāvanañāṇāni cāti evamādayo
analyzed: tathā anantāsu lokadhātūsu anantānam sattānam āsaya ādi vibhāvana ñāṇāni ca ati evamādayaḥ
translated: and likewise the knowledge of distinguishing the dispositions, etc., of the infinite beings in the infinite world-spheres,

original: anantāparimāṇabhedā anaññasādhāraṇā niratisayā guṇabhāgā guṇakoṭṭhāsā saṃvijjanti🔽upalabbhanti, tasmā yathāvuttavibhāgā guṇabhāgā assa atthīti bhāgavāti vattabbe ākārassa
analyzed: ananta aparimāṇa bhedāḥ anañña sādhāraṇāḥ niratisayāḥ guṇa bhāgāḥ guṇa koṭṭhāsā saṃvijjanti  upalabbhanti tasmā yathā vutta vibhāgāḥ guṇa bhāgāḥ assa atthi iti vattabbe ākārassa
translated: all these, which are of infinite and measureless kinds and are not shared by others, are the incomparable special qualities, the special qualities’ parts, the special qualities’ aspects.🔽They are present, they are found, in him. So it is because he has these special qualities’ parts that he can be called ‘ one who has special qualities’s parts’ . But the ‘ a ’ in ‘ Bhagavā ’ is made long to suit the metre,

original: rassattaṃ katvā “bhagavā”ti vutto. Evaṃ tāva bhāgavāti bhagavā.
analyzed: rassattam katvā bhagavā iti vuttaḥ evam tāva bhāgavā ati bhagavā
translated: as in the words ‘ bhagavati ’ and ‘ bhagavato ’ . This is how he is ‘ Blessed ’ in the sense of having special qualities’ parts.

original: Yasmā sīlādayo sabbe, guṇabhāgā asesato;
analyzed: sīla ādayaḥ sabbe guṇa bhāgāḥ asesato
translated: Because he has all special qualities,

original: Vijjanti sugate tasmā, bhagavāti pavuccati.🔽Kathaṃ bhatavāti bhagavā? Ye te sabbalokahitāya ussukkamāpannehi manussattādike aṭṭha🔽dhamme samodhānetvā sammāsambodhiyā katamahābhinīhārehi mahābodhisattehi paripūretabbā
analyzed: vijjanti sugate tasmai bhagavā ati pavuccati  katham bhatavā ati bhagavā ye te sabba loka hitāya ussukkam āpannehi manussa tta ādike aṭṭha  dhamme samodhānetvā sammāsambodhiyā kata mahā abhinīhārehi mahā bodhisattehi paripūretabbā
translated: Therefore, since they exist in the One Well-Gone, He is called the Blessed One.🔽How is it that the Blessed One is the One who has gone to the end of the wholesome? The Blessed One has gone to the end of the wholesome dhammas that are to be developed by the Great Beings who have taken up the eight dhammas beginning with human birth, which are the means to the welfare of the whole world,

original: dānapāramī sīlanekkhammapaññāvīriyakhantisaccaadhiṭṭhānamettāupekkhāpāramīti dasa
analyzed: dāna pāramī sīla nekkhamma paññā vīriya khanti sacca adhiṭṭhāna mettā upekkhā pāramī iti dasa
translated: and who have made the great aspiration for the supreme enlightenment.

original: pāramiyo dasa upapāramiyo dasa paramatthapāramiyoti samatiṃsa pāramiyo, dānādīni🔽cattāri saṅgahavatthūni, cattāri adhiṭṭhānāni, attapariccāgo nayanadhanarajjaputtadārapariccāgoti
analyzed: pāramiyaḥ dasa upapāramiyaḥ dasa paramattha pāramiyaḥ ti pāramiyaḥ dāna ādīni  cattāri saṅgaha vatthūni cattāri adhiṭṭhānāni atta pariccāgaḥ nayana dhana rajja putta dāra pariccāgaḥ ti
translated: These are the ten pāramīs, the ten upapāramīs, and the ten paramatthapāramīs, making thirty pāramīs in all.🔽The four bases of beneficence, the four foundations, the five great relinquishments, the five great sacrifices,

original: pañca mahāpariccāgā, pubbayogo, pubbacariyā, dhammakkhānaṃ, ñātatthacariyā, lokatthacariyā,
analyzed: pañca mahā pariccāgā pubba yogaḥ pubba cariyā dhamma kkhānam ñāta ttha cariyā loka ttha cariyā
translated: the preliminary practice, the practice of the past, the practice of the future, the practice of the present, the practice of the known, the practice of the world,

original: buddhatthacariyāti evamādayo saṅkhepato vā puññasambhārañāṇasambhārā buddhakarā dhammā,
analyzed: buddhattha cariyā ti evamādayo saṅkhepataḥ vā puñña sambhāra ñāṇa sambhārāḥ buddha karāḥ dhammāḥ
translated: and the practice of the Buddha—in brief, the dhammas that lead to Buddhahood, the accumulation of merit and the accumulation of knowledge—

original: te mahābhinīhārato paṭṭhāya kappānaṃ satasahassādhikāni cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni yathā
analyzed: te mahā abhinīhārataḥ paṭṭhāya kappānam sata sahassa adhikāni cattāri asaṅkhyeyyāni yathā
translated: From the time of their great aspiration, for four incalculables and a hundred thousand great aeons, they were reborn in the world of the gods, and in the human world, in the families of nobles, brahmins, and householders, and they were reborn in the families of Universal Monarchs.

original: hānabhāgiyā saṃkilesabhāgiyā ṭhitibhāgiyā vā na honti, atha kho uttaruttari visesabhāgiyāva
analyzed: hāna bhāgiyā saṃkilesa bhāgiyā ṭhiti bhāgiyāḥ vā na honti atha kho uttaruttari visesa bhāgiyāḥ ava
translated: From the time of the Great Aspiration, for four incalculable ages and a hundred thousand aeons, he did not become one who was subject to loss, subject to corruption, or subject to stagnation, but rather he became one who was subject to increase, subject to improvement, and subject to excellence.

original: honti, evaṃ sakkaccaṃ nirantaraṃ anavasesato bhatā sambhatā assa atthīti bhatavāti🔽bhagavā niruttinayena ta-kārassa ga-kāraṃ katvā. Atha vā bhatavāti teyeva yathāvutte
analyzed: honti evam sakkaccam nirantaram anavasesataḥ bhatā sambhatā assa atthi iti bhatavā ati  bhagavā nirutti nayena takārassa gakāram katvā atha vā yathā vutte
translated: Thus he was one who was well-developed, well-matured, well-perfected, in the sense of being without remainder, without exception, without fail, continuously, and with full attention.🔽Therefore he is the Blessed One (bhagavā) in the sense of one who has been well-developed (bhatavā).🔽Or alternatively, he is the Blessed One (bhagavā) in the sense of one who has filled (bhari) and caused to overflow (sambhari) those things that lead to Buddhahood, which were mentioned above, and has perfected (paripūresi) them, in the way already stated.

original: buddhakare dhamme vuttanayena bhari sambhari, paripūresīti attho. Evampi bhatavāti bhagavā.
analyzed: buddha kare dhamme vutta nayena bhari sambhari paripūresi iti atthaḥ evam pi bhatavā ati bhagavā
translated: Thus he is the Blessed One (bhagavā) in this way also.

original: Yasmā sambodhiyā sabbe, dānapāramiādike;
analyzed: yasmā sambodhiyā sabbe dāna pārami ādike
translated: And because he has developed all the requisites for enlightenment,

original: Sambhāre bhatavā nātho, tasmāpi bhagavā mato.
analyzed: sambhāre bhatavā nātho tasmā api bhagavā mataḥ
translated: The perfection of giving and the rest, the Lord is called the Blessed One (bhagavā).🔽How is he the Blessed One (bhagavā) in the sense of one who has taken up (vanī) what is to be taken up (bhāga)?

original: Kathaṃ bhāge vanīti bhagavā? Ye te catuvīsatikoṭisatasahassasaṅkhā devasikaṃ vaḷañjanakasamāpattibhāgā,
analyzed: katham bhāge vani iti bhagavā ye te catuvīsati koṭi sata sahassa saṅkhāḥ devasikam vaḷañjanaka samāpatti bhāgāḥ
translated: The Blessed One has taken up the thirty-two hundred and four hundred thousand kinds of jhāna that are to be taken up.

original: te anavasesato lokahitatthaṃ attano ca diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāratthaṃ niccakappaṃ vani
analyzed: te anavasesataḥ loka hita attham attano ca diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihāra attham nicca kappam
translated: He has had recourse to, served, attended much upon, the forest-dwellings, which are the means to the welfare of the world and to his own abiding in bliss visible here and now, for a long time, constantly, and in all ways.

original: bhaji sevi bahulamakāsīti bhāge vanīti bhagavā. Atha vā abhiññeyyadhammesu kusalādīsu
analyzed: bhaji sevi bahulam akāsi iti bhāge vani iti bhagavā atha vā abhiññeyya dhammesu kusala ādīsu
translated: He has had recourse to the forest-dwellings, thus he is the Blessed One .🔽Or alternatively, the four kinds of things to be directly known, namely, the profitable, etc.,

original: khandhādīsu ca ye te pariññeyyādivasena saṅkhepato vā catubbidhā abhisamayabhāgā,🔽vitthārato pana “cakkhu pariññeyyaṃ, sotaṃ pariññeyyaṃ…pe… jarāmaraṇaṃ pariññeyya”ntiādinā🔽aneke pariññeyyabhāgā, “cakkhussa samudayo pahātabbo…pe… jarāmaraṇassa samudayo pahātabbo”tiādinā

original: ca anekabhedā bhāvetabbabhāgā ca dhammā vuttā, te sabbe vani bhaji yathārahaṃ gocarabhāvanāsevanānaṃ

original: vasena sevi. Evampi bhāge vanīti bhagavā. Atha vā ye ime sīlādayo dhammakkhandhā
analyzed: vasena bhāge atha vā ye ime sīla ādayo dhamma kkhandhā

original: Evampi bhāge vanīti bhagavā.

original: bhajīyantīti bhagā, lokiyalokuttarasampattiyo. Tattha lokiye tāva tathāgato sambodhito
