original: devānaṃ sahabyata”ntiādi. Chakāmāvacaradevalokassa savisesaṃ mārassa vase vattanato
analyzed: devānam sahabyatanti ādi cha kāmāvacara deva lokassa sa visesam mārassa vase vattanato
translated: Because he conducts himself in the company of the gods of the sense-sphere worlds with their ruler Mara,

original: āha “samārakaggahaṇena chakāmāvacaradevaloko”ti. Arūpībrahmalokassa visuṃ gahitattā
analyzed: āha sa māraka ggahaṇena arūpī brahma lokassa visum
translated: he says: “The sense-sphere worlds with their ruler Mara” . Because the formless Brahma worlds are mentioned separately,

original: āha “rūpī brahmaloko”ti. Catuparisavasenāti khattiyaparisā, brāhmaṇagahapatisamaṇacātumahārājikatāvatiṃsamārabrahmaparisāti
analyzed: āha rūpī brahma lokā iti catu parisa vasena ati khattiya parisā brāhmaṇa gahapati samaṇa cātumahārājika tāvatiṃsa māra brahma parisā ati
translated: he says: “The form-sphere Brahma worlds” . By the four assemblies: the assembly of nobles, the assembly of Brahmins, the assembly of householders, the assembly of ascetics, the assembly of the gods of the Four Great Kings, the assembly of the gods of the Thirty-three, the assembly of Mara, the assembly of the Brahmas.

original: imāsu aṭṭhasu parisāsu khattiyādicatuparisavasena. Itarā pana catasso parisā samārakaggahaṇena gahitā evāti.
analyzed: imāsu aṭṭhasu parisāsu khattiya ādi catu parisa vasena itarā pana catasso parisā samāraka ggahaṇena gahitā eva ati
translated: Herein, the four assemblies of nobles, etc., are mentioned by the four assemblies. But the other four assemblies are included by the mention of the sense-sphere worlds with their ruler Mara.

original: Kathaṃ panettha catuparisavasena manussaloko gahito? “Sassamaṇabrāhmaṇi”nti iminā
analyzed: katham pana ittha catu parisa vasena manussa lokaḥ gahitaḥ iminā
translated: But how is the human world included by the four assemblies?🔽By the words “with ascetics and Brahmins”

original: samaṇaparisā brāhmaṇaparisā ca gahitā honti, “sadevamanussa”nti iminā khattiyaparisā
analyzed: samaṇa parisā brāhmaṇa parisā ca gahitāḥ honti sa deva manussānti iminā khattiya parisā
translated: the assembly of ascetics and the assembly of Brahmins are included, and by the words “with gods and men”🔽the assembly of nobles and the assembly of householders are included. But by the words “with the world” these very four assemblies are mentioned,

original: gahapatiparisā ca gahitā, “paja”nti iminā pana imāyeva catasso parisā vuttā, catuparisasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: gahapati parisā ca gahitā pajanti iminā pana imāya eva catasso parisā vuttā catu parisa saṅkhātam
translated: and the human world is included by the four assemblies.

original: pajanti vuttaṃ hoti, kathaṃ pana sammutidevehi saha manussaloko gahito? Etthāpi “sassamaṇabrāhmaṇi”nti
analyzed: pajanti vuttam hoti katham pana sammuti devehi saha manussa lokaḥ gahitaḥ ettha api
translated: “The people” is said. But how is the human world included with the gods of popular conception? Here too, “with ascetics and brahmans”

original: iminā samaṇabrāhmaṇā gahitā, “sadevamanussa”nti iminā sammutidevasaṅkhātā khattiyā,
analyzed: iminā samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ gahitā sa deva manussanti iminā sammuti deva saṅkhātā khattiyā
translated: includes ascetics and brahmans. “With gods and men” includes the nobles who are called gods of popular conception,

original: gahapatisuddasaṅkhātā avasesamanussā ca gahitā honti. Ito pana aññesaṃ manussasattānaṃ
analyzed: gahapati sudda saṅkhātāḥ avasesa manussā ca gahitāḥ honti itas pana aññesam manussa sattānam
translated: and the rest of the human beings who are called householders and outcastes. But since there are no other human beings than these,

original: abhāvato “paja”nti iminā catūhi pakārehi ṭhitā eteyeva manussasattā vuttāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: abhāvataḥ pajanti iminā catūhi pakārehi ṭhitāḥ ete yeva manussa sattā vuttā iti daṭṭhabbam
translated: it should be understood that “the people” refers to these very human beings who are established in four modes.

original: Evaṃ vikappadvayepi pajāggahaṇena catuparisādivasena ṭhitānaṃ manussānaṃyeva gahitattā🔽idāni “paja”nti iminā avasesasatte saṅgahetvā dassetukāmo āha “avasesasabbasattaloko
analyzed: evam vikappa dvaye pi pajā ggahaṇena catu parisā divasena ṭhitānam manussānam yeva gahita ttā  idāni pajanti iminā avasesa satte saṅgahetvā dassetu kāmaḥ āha avasesa sabba satta lokaḥ
translated: Thus, in both cases of distinction, since only human beings who are established as the four assemblies, etc., are included by the word “people,”

original: vā”ti. Tattha nāgagaruḷādivasena avasesasattaloko veditabbo. Etthāpi catuparisavasena
analyzed: vā ti tattha nāga garuḷa ādi vasena avasesa satta lokaḥ veditabbaḥ ettha api catu parisa vasena
translated: now, in order to show that the rest of the beings are included by the word “people,” he says, “or the rest of the world of all beings.” Here the rest of the world of beings should be understood as nāgas, garuḍas, etc. Here too,

original: sammutidevehi vā saha avasesasabbasattaloko vāti yojetabbaṃ. Catuparisasahito avasesasuddhanāgasupaṇṇanerayikādisattaloko,
analyzed: sammuti devehi vā saha avasesa sabba satta lokaḥ vā ati yojetabbam catu parisa sahitaḥ avasesa suddha nāga supaṇṇa nerayika ādi satta lokaḥ
translated: Or else the rest of the world of beings can be taken as consisting of the world of beings together with the gods of the sense sphere.

original: catudhā ṭhitamanussasahito vā avasesanāgasupaṇṇanerayikādisattaloko gahitoti vuttaṃ hoti.🔽Ettāvatā bhāgaso lokaṃ gahetvā yojanaṃ dassetvā idāni tena tena visesena abhāgaso
analyzed: catudhā ṭhita manussa sahitaḥ vā avasesa nāga supaṇṇa nerayika ādi satta lokaḥ gahitaḥ iti vuttam hoti  ettāvatā bhāgasaḥ lokam gahetvā yojanam dassetvā idāni tena tena visesena abhāgasaḥ
translated: Or else the rest of the world of beings can be taken as consisting of the world of beings together with the gods of the sense sphere and the gods of the fine-material sphere.🔽So far, having shown the world by way of its parts, he now says “Or else” in order to show the world by way of its whole.

original: lokaṃ gahetvā yojanaṃ dassetuṃ “apicetthā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha ukkaṭṭhaparicchedatoti
analyzed: lokam gahetvā yojanam dassetum apica itthā atiādi vuttam tattha ukkaṭṭha paricchedato ti
translated: Herein, by the highest limit is meant by the highest range of the world.

original: ukkaṃsagativijānanena. Pañcasu hi gatīsu devagatipariyāpannāva seṭṭhā, tatthāpi arūpino
analyzed: ukkaṃsa gati vijānanena pañcasu hi gatīsu deva gati pariyāpannā ava seṭṭhā tattha api arūpino
translated: For of the five kinds of destiny the divine destiny is the best. And of that too the immaterial world is the highest,

original: dūrasamussāritakilesadukkhatāya santapaṇītaāneñjavihārasamaṅgitāya ativiya dīghāyukatāyāti
analyzed: dūra samussārita kilesa dukkha tāya santa paṇīta āneñja vihāra samaṅgi tāya dīgha āyuka tāya ati
translated: because of the peace and excellence of its abiding in the imperturbable, and because of the extreme length of its life span.

original: evamādīhi visesehi ativiya ukkaṭṭhā. Brahmā mahānubhāvoti dasasahassiyaṃ mahābrahmuno
analyzed: evamādīhi visesehi ativiya ukkaṭṭhā brahmā mahā anubhāvo ti dasa sahassiyam mahābrahmuno
translated: Brahmā is of great power in the ten-thousandfold world system.

original: vasena vadati. “Ukkaṭṭhaparicchedato”ti hi vuttaṃ. Anuttaranti seṭṭhaṃ navalokuttaraṃ.
analyzed: vasena vadati ukkaṭṭha paricchedataḥ ti hi vuttam anuttaran ti seṭṭham nava lokuttaram
translated: and he speaks of it as “the highest” because it is the highest limit.🔽The order of sequence: the order of sequence of the meanings and of the words.

original: Anusandhikkamoti atthānañceva padānañca anusandhānukkamo. Porāṇā panettha evaṃ vaṇṇayanti
analyzed: anusandhi kkamo ti atthānam ca iva padānam ca anusandhā anukkamo porāṇā pana ittha evam vaṇṇayanti
translated: But the Ancients explain it as follows:

original: – sadevakanti devatāhi saddhiṃ avasesaṃ lokaṃ. Samārakanti mārena saddhiṃ avasesaṃ🔽lokaṃ. Sabrahmakanti brahmehi saddhiṃ avasesaṃ lokaṃ. Evaṃ sabbepi tibhavūpage satte
analyzed: sa devakanti devatāhi saddhim avasesam lokam sa mārakanti mārena saddhim avasesam  lokam sabrahmakam ti brahmehi saddhim avasesam lokam evam sabbe api ti bhava upage satte
translated: “With the devas”: with the rest of the world together with the deities.🔽“With Māra and Brahmā”: with the rest of the world together with Māra and Brahmā.🔽“With recluses and brahmans”: with the rest of the world together with recluses and brahmans.

original: devamārabrahmasahitatāsaṅkhātehi tīhi pakārehi “sadevaka”ntiādīsu tīsu padesu pakkhipitvā
analyzed: deva māra brahma sahita tā saṅkhātehi tīhi pakārehi sa deva kanti ādīsu tīsu padesu pakkhipitvā
translated: Thus he includes all beings in the three worlds under the three terms “with the devas,” etc., which are respectively called “with the three kinds of high rank.”

original: puna dvīhi padehi pariyādiyanto “sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussa”nti āha.
analyzed: puna dvīhi padehi sa samaṇa brāhmaṇim pajam sa deva manussanti āha
translated: Then he concludes with the two terms “with recluses and brahmans” and “with gods and men.”

original: Evaṃ pañcahipi padehi sadevakattādinā tena tena pakārena tedhātukameva pariyādinnanti.
analyzed: evam padehi sa devakattā ādinā tena tena pakārena tedhātukam eva
translated: So the three worlds are concluded with the three kinds of high rank beginning with “with the devas.”

original: Abhiññāti yakāralopenāyaṃ niddeso, abhijānitvāti ayamettha atthoti āha “abhiññāya
analyzed: abhiññā iti yakāra lopena ayam niddesaḥ abhijānitvā iti ayam ettha atthaḥ ti āha abhiññāya
translated: “Having directly known”: the demonstrative pronoun ayaṃ is omitted here. The meaning is “having directly known after comprehending.”

original: adhikena ñāṇena ñatvā”ti. Anumānādipaṭikkhepoti anumānaupamānaatthāpattiādipaṭikkhepo
analyzed: adhikena ñāṇena ñatvā iti anumāna ādi paṭikkhepaḥ iti anumāna aupamāna atthāpatti ādi paṭikkhepaḥ
translated: and he knows by means of his surpassing knowledge.” “By inference, etc., is rejected” means that inference, analogy, testimony, etc., are rejected.

original: ekappamāṇattā. Sabbattha appaṭihatañāṇacāratāya hi sabbapaccakkhā buddhā bhagavanto.
analyzed: eka ppamāṇa ttā sabbattha a paṭihata ñāṇa cāra tāya hi sabba paccakkhāḥ buddhāḥ bhagavanto
translated: because of the singleness of the measure. For the Enlightened Ones, the Blessed Ones, have direct knowledge of all things.

original: Anuttaraṃ vivekasukhanti phalasamāpattisukhaṃ. Tena vīthimissāpi kadāci bhagavato🔽dhammadesanā hotīti hitvāpīti pisaddaggahaṇaṃ. Bhagavā hi dhammaṃ desento yasmiṃ
analyzed: anuttaram viveka sukhanti phala samāpatti sukham tena vīthi missā api kadāci bhagavataḥ  dhamma desanā hoti iti hitvā api iti pisadda ggahaṇam bhagavā hi dhammam desentaḥ yasmin
translated: “The bliss of seclusion unsurpassed” is the bliss of fruition attainment. Sometimes the Blessed One’s teaching of the Dhamma occurs through that, even though he has left the jhāna.

original: khaṇe parisā sādhukāraṃ vā deti, yathāsutaṃ vā dhammaṃ paccavekkhati, taṃ khaṇaṃ
analyzed: khaṇe parisā sādhukāram vā deti yathāsutam vā dhammam paccavekkhati tam khaṇam
translated: Therefore the word “even” is included in the text. For when the Blessed One is teaching the Dhamma, if at any moment the assembly makes an approving remark or reviews the Dhamma as heard, then the Blessed One,

original: pubbabhāgena paricchinditvā phalasamāpattiṃ samāpajjati, yathāparicchedañca samāpattito
analyzed: pubba bhāgena paricchinditvā phala samāpattim samāpajjati yathā paricchedam ca samāpattitaḥ
translated: having discerned that moment by means of the prior sign, attains fruition attainment. And emerging from attainment at the end of the moment, he teaches the Dhamma beginning from the point at which he left off.

original: vuṭṭhāya ṭhitaṭṭhānato paṭṭhāya dhammaṃ deseti. Appaṃ vā bahuṃ vā desentoti ugghaṭitaññussa🔽vasena appaṃ vā, vipañcitaññussa neyyassa vā vasena bahuṃ vā desento. Ādikalyāṇādippakārameva
analyzed: vuṭṭhāya ṭhita ṭṭhānataḥ paṭṭhāya dhammaṃ deseti appam vā bahum vā desento ti ugghaṭita ññussa 🔽vasena appam vā neyyassa vā vasena bahum vā desentaḥ ādi kalyāṇa ādi ppakāram eva
translated: “Teaching little or much” means teaching little to one who has the run of the Dhamma or much to one who has not. Teaching the Dhamma that is good in the beginning, etc.,

original: desetīti ādimhipi kalyāṇaṃ bhaddakaṃ anavajjameva katvā deseti. Majjhepi pariyosānepi
analyzed: deseti iti ādimhi pi kalyāṇam bhaddakam anavajjam eva katvā deseti majjhe pi pariyosāne pi
translated: He teaches, etc. : he teaches, making it good, excellent, and blameless, at the beginning, in the middle, and at the end.

original: kalyāṇaṃ bhaddakaṃ anavajjameva katvā desetīti vuttaṃ hoti. Dhammassa hi kalyāṇatā
analyzed: kalyāṇam bhaddakam anavajjam eva katvā deseti iti vuttam hoti dhammassa hi kalyāṇa tā
translated: He teaches, making it good, excellent, and blameless, at the beginning, in the middle, and at the end, is what is meant. For the goodness of the Dhamma

original: niyyānikatāya niyyānikatā ca sabbaso anavajjabhāvena.🔽Samantabhaddakattāti sabbabhāgehi sundarattā. Dhammassāti pariyattidhammassa. Kiñcāpi
analyzed: niyyānika tāya niyyānika tā ca sabbaso anavajja bhāvena  samantabhaddaka ttā ati sabba bhāgehi sundara ttā dhammassa āti pariyatti dhammassa kiñcā api
translated: is due to its being a way out, and the way out is due entirely to its being blameless.

original: avayavavinimutto samudāyo nāma paramatthato koci natthi, yesu pana avayavesu samudāyarūpena🔽apekkhitesu gāthāti samaññā, taṃ tato bhinnaṃ viya katvā saṃsāmivohāraṃ āropetvā🔽dassento “paṭhamapādena ādikalyāṇā”tiādimāha. Ekānusandhikanti idaṃ nātibahuvibhāgaṃ
analyzed: avayava vinimutto samudāyaḥ nāma paramatthato koci natthi yesu pana avayavesu samudāya rūpena  apekkhitesu gāthā ati samaññā tam tatas bhinnam viya katvā saṃsāmi vohāram āropetvā  paṭhama pādena ādi kalyāṇa ati ādim āha eka anusandhikam ti idam na ati bahu vibhāgam
translated: It is all good: it is good in all respects. Of the Dhamma: of the Dhamma as text. Although as regards the ultimate sense there is no such thing as an aggregate dissociated from its components, still, when the components are looked on as a whole,🔽the name “verse” is given to them. And so, as if showing a collection of threads as cloth, he shows the Dhamma as a whole by superimposing the conventional expression on it, treating it as if it were something separate from the components, when he says, “It is good in the beginning with the phrase ‘In dependence upon contact’ ,” and so on.

original: yathānusandhinā ekānusandhikaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Itarassa pana teneva desetabbadhammavibhāgena
analyzed: yathā anusandhinā eka anusandhikam sandhāya vuttam itarassa pana tena iva desetabba dhamma vibhāgena
translated: It has a single purport: this is said with reference to the fact that it is not divided into too many sections. But the other has a single purport with a single cause, with reference to the fact that the Dhamma to be taught is divided into the same number of sections as the cause.

original: ādimajjhapariyosānabhāgā labbhantīti. Nidānenāti ānandattherena ṭhapitakāladesadesakaparisādiapadisanalakkhaṇena🔽nidānaganthena. Nigamenāti “idamavocā”tiādikena “iti yaṃ taṃ vuttaṃ, idametaṃ paṭicca
analyzed: ādi majjha pariyosāna bhāgāḥ labbhanti iti nidānena ati ānanda therena ṭhapita kāla desa desaka parisā ādi apadisana lakkhaṇena  nidāna ganthena nigamena ati idam avoca ati ādikena iti yam tam vuttam idam etam paṭicca
translated: and the beginning, middle, and end are found.🔽In the introduction: the introduction is the words of the text that show the place, the time, the teacher, the audience, etc.,

original: vutta”nti vā yathāvuttatthanigamanena. Saṅgītikārakehi ṭhapitānipi hi nidānanigamanāni
analyzed: vuttanti vā yathā vutta ttha nigamanena saṅgīti kārakehi ṭhapitāni api hi nidāna nigamanāni
translated: and the conclusion is the words that conclude the discourse, such as “This did the Blessed One say” and “Thus it was said” or “This was the occasion for saying this.”

original: dassetvā tīṇi piṭakāni satthu desanāya anuvidhānato tadantogadhāneva. Teneva dīghanikāyaṭṭhakathāyaṃ
analyzed: dassetvā tīṇi piṭakāni satthu desanāya anuvidhānato tena iva dīgha nikāya ṭṭhakathā ayam
translated: For the introduction and conclusion are also included in the three Piṭakas, since the compilers of the Piṭakas set them down after showing the three Piṭakas in accordance with the Teacher’s teaching.

original: “ekānusandhikassa suttassa nidānaṃ ādi, idamavocāti pariyosānaṃ, ubhinnamantarā majjha”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: eka anusandhikassa suttassa nidānam ādi idam avoca ati pariyosānam ubhinnam antarā majjhanti vuttaṃ
translated: That is why it is said in the Commentary on the Dīgha Nikāya: “The introduction is the beginning of a sutta with a single connection; the conclusion is the end with ‘Thus it was said’; the middle is what is in between the two” .🔽Having thus shown the goodness of the beginning, etc., of the Dhamma by way of the Sutta Piṭaka, he now said “The entire” in order to show it by taking the three Piṭakas together.

original: Evaṃ suttantapiṭakavasena dhammassa ādikalyāṇāditaṃ dassetvā idāni tīṇi piṭakāni ekajjhaṃ gahetvā taṃ dassetuṃ “sakalopī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha sāsanadhammoti –🔽“Sabbapāpassa akaraṇaṃ, kusalassa upasampadā;
analyzed: evam suttanta piṭaka vasena dhammassa ādi kalyāṇa āditam dassetvā idāni tīṇi piṭakāni ekajjham gahetvā tam dassetum sakala upi itiādi vuttam tattha sāsana dhammo ti 🔽sabba pāpassa akaraṇam kusalassa upasampadā
translated: Herein, the Dhamma of the Dispensation is that of the three Piṭakas.

original: Sacittapariyodapanaṃ, etaṃ buddhāna sāsana”nti. –🔽Evaṃ vuttassa satthusāsanassa pakāsako pariyattidhammo. Sīlamūlakattā sāsanassa “sīlena
analyzed: sa citta pariyodapanam etam buddhāna  evam vuttassa satthu sāsanassa pakāsakaḥ pariyatti dhammo sīla mūlakattā sāsanassa sīlena
translated: The cleansing of one’s own mind: this is the dispensation of the Buddhas.”🔽The scriptures are the light for the teaching thus proclaimed by the Master. Since virtue is the root of the dispensation, it is said to be “good in the beginning” as virtue.

original: ādikalyāṇo”ti vuttaṃ. Samathādīnaṃ sāsanasampattiyā vemajjhabhāvato āha “samathavipassanāmaggaphalehi
analyzed: ādi kalyāṇaḥ iti vuttam samatha ādīnam sāsana sampattiyāḥ vemajjha bhāvataḥ āha samatha vipassanā magga phalehi
translated: Since serenity, insight, the path, and the fruits are the middle portion of the excellence of the dispensation, he says that the dispensation is “good in the middle” as serenity, insight, the path, and the fruits.

original: majjhekalyāṇo”ti. Nibbānādhigamato uttari karaṇīyābhāvato vuttaṃ “nibbānena pariyosānakalyāṇo”ti.
analyzed: majjhe kalyāṇaḥ ti nibbāna adhigamataḥ uttari karaṇīya abhāvataḥ vuttam nibbānena pariyosāna kalyāṇaḥ ti
translated: Since there is nothing further to be done beyond the realization of Nibbāna, it is said to be “good in the end” as Nibbāna.

original: Sāsane sammāpaṭipatti nāma paññāya hoti, tassā ca sīlaṃ samādhi ca mūlanti āha “sīlasamādhīhi
analyzed: sāsane sammāpaṭipatti nāma paññāya hoti tassā ca sīlam samādhi ca mūlanti āha sīla samādhīhi
translated: Right practice in the dispensation is wisdom. And since virtue and concentration are its roots, he says that it is “good in the beginning” as virtue and concentration.

original: vā ādikalyāṇo”ti. Paññā pana anubodhapaavedhavasena duvidhāti tadubhayampi gaṇhanto
analyzed: vā ādikalyāṇo ti paññā pana anubodha paavedha vasena duvidhā ati tat ubhayam pi gaṇhanto
translated: But wisdom is twofold as understanding and penetration. Including both, he says that it is “good in the middle” as insight and the path.

original: “vipassanāmaggehi majjhekalyāṇo”ti āha. Tassā nipphattiphalakiccaṃ nibbānasacchikiriyā,
analyzed: vipassanā maggehi majjhe kalyāṇaḥ ti āha tassāḥ nipphatti phala kiccam nibbāna sacchikiriyā
translated: The fruit of its fruition is the realization of Nibbāna.

original: tato paraṃ kattabbaṃ natthīti dassento āha “phalanibbānehi pariyosānakalyāṇo”ti.
analyzed: tatas param kattabbam natthi iti dassentaḥ āha phala nibbānehi pariyosāna kalyāṇaḥ ti
translated: Showing that there is nothing further to be done beyond that, he says that it is “good in the end” as the fruit and Nibbāna.

original: Phalaggahaṇena vā saupādisesaṃ nibbānamāha, itarena itaraṃ tadubhayañca sāsanasampattiyā
analyzed: phala ggahaṇena vā saupādisesam nibbānam āha itarena itaram tat ubhayam ca sāsana sampattiyā

original: “Yasmiṃ, bhikkhave, samaye ariyasāvako ohitasoto dhammaṃ suṇāti, pañcassa nīvaraṇāni tasmiṃ samaye pahīnāni hontī”ti –

original: Ca ādi. Samathavipassanāsukhāvahanatoti samathasukhassa vipassanāsukhassa ca sampāpanato.🔽Vuttampi cetaṃ “so vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ

original: tādibhāvassa lokadhammehi anupalepassa āvahanato. Nāthappabhavattāti pabhavati etasmāti

analyzed: uddesa bhāvataḥ tikkha indriyaḥ hi saṅkhepataḥ paṭhamam ca vuttam attham paṭipajjati saṃkhittassa  vitthāra vacanam sakim vuttassa puna vacanam ca vivaraṇa vibhajanāni yathā kusalā

analyzed: samaye kāmāvacaram kusalam citta nti ādinā vitthārataḥ vivaraṇa vasena vibhajana vasena  ca puna vacanam majjhima indriya apekkham etam pada dvayam niddesa bhāvataḥ vivaṭassa vitthāratara abhidhānam

analyzed: vibhattassa ca pakārehi ñāpanam vineyyānam citta paritosanam uttānīkaraṇa paññāpanāni  yathā phassaḥ hoti iti ādinā atthassa katamaḥ tasmin samaye phassaḥ

analyzed: nāma vivaṭassa vitthāra abhidhānena vibhattassa ca upamā abhidhānena uttānim karoti iti

analyzed: vivaraṇena katamaḥ tasmin samaye phassaḥ hoti yaḥ tasmin samaye phasso  phusanā saṃphusanā ati ati vivaritvā kathanam vibhajanena vibhattassa seyyathā api
translated: When, after the very detailed explanation, “What is contact on that occasion? It is contact, contact by way of contact,🔽contacting,” the meaning is further explained, “Bhikkhus, I say that this nutriment contact should be seen as similar to a cow with a goad,”

original: bhikkhave, gāvī niccammā, evameva khvāyaṃ bhikkhave phassāhāro daṭṭhabboti vadāmī”ti
analyzed: bhikkhave gāvī niccammā evam eva khvā ayam bhikkhave phassa āhāraḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ iti vadāmi iti

analyzed: evamādi upamā kathanam ca uttānīkaraṇam nāma dhammam suṇantānam dhamma desanena vicittena

analyzed: paññatti nāma sotūnam citta tosanena citta nisānena ca paññāpanam paññatti iti katvā

original: sātthaṃ. Saṅkāsanapakāsanādayo hi atthākārattā “atthapadānī”ti vuccanti. Atthoyeva

analyzed: akkhara pada byañjana ākāra nirutti niddesa sampattiyā ti ettha saṭṭhi vassa sahassāni iti

original: pavattitadesanāvācāhi akkharaṇato avevacanato akathitattā akkharanti saññitā. Taṃ
analyzed: pavattita desanā vācāhi akkharaṇataḥ a vevacanataḥ a kathita ttā akkharanti saññi tā tam

analyzed: pārāyanika brāhmaṇānam manasā pucchita pañhānam vasena bhagavatā ratana ghare nisīditvā
translated: That should be taken by way of the questions asked by the brahmin Pārāyana with his mind, and by way of the Blessed One’s sitting in the Jetavana and pondering over the Mahāpakkha Suttas.

analyzed: sammasita paṭṭhāna mahā pakaraṇa vasena ca gahetabban ti vadanti vibhattiyantam atthassa
translated: The word is that which is to be inflected, which is the meaning of the word “attha.”

original: ñāpanato padaṃ. Pajjati attho etenāti hi padaṃ. Taṃ nāmapadaṃ ākhyātapadaṃ upasaggapadaṃ🔽nipātapadanti catubbidhaṃ. Tattha phasso vedanā cittanti evamādikaṃ dabbapadhānaṃ🔽nāmapadaṃ. Nāmapadehi dabbamāvibhūtarūpaṃ, kiriyā anāvibhūtarūpā. Phusati vedayati
analyzed: ñāpanataḥ padam pajjati atthaḥ etena ati hi padam tam nāma padam ākhyāta padam upasagga padam  nipāta padanti catubbidham tattha phassaḥ vedanā cittan ti evamādikam dabba padhānam  nāma padam nāma padehi dabbam āvibhūta rūpam kiriyā anāvibhūta rūpā phusati vedayati
translated: and a term is so called because of its being a footing for the communication of meaning. The meaning is “it is communicated by this” . The materiality that is disclosed by the name-terms is the function that is not disclosed. It touches, it feels, it cognizes,

original: vijānātīti evamādikaṃ kiriyāpadhānaṃ ākhyātapadaṃ. Ākhyātapadehi kiriyā āvibhūtarūpā,🔽dabbamanāvibhūtarūpaṃ. Yathā “cirappavāsi”nti ettha pa-saddo vasanakiriyāya viyogavisiṭṭhataṃ🔽dīpeti, evaṃ kiriyāvisesadīpanato kiriyāvisesāvabodhanimittaṃ. Pa-iti evamādikaṃ
analyzed: vijānāti iti evamādikam kiriyā apadhānam ākhyāta padam ākhyāta pade hi kiriyā āvibhūta rūpā  dabba manāvi bhūta rūpam yathā cirappavāsin ti ettha pasaddaḥ vasana kiriyāya  dīpeti evam kiriyā visesa dīpanataḥ kiriyā visesa avabodha nimittam paiti evamādikam
translated: and a term is so called because of its being a footing for the communication of meaning. For the meaning is communicated by it. That is of four kinds as a name-term, a verb-term, a prefix-term, and a particle-term. Herein, the term “contact,” the term “feeling,” the term “cognizing,” and so on, are a name-term. The materiality that is communicated by the name-terms is uncommunicated by the verb-terms, and the action is communicated by the verb-terms. The materiality is uncommunicated by the verb-terms. The term “touches,” the term “feels,” the term “perceives,” and so on, are verb-terms. The action that is communicated by the verb-terms is communicated by the name-terms,

original: upasaggapadaṃ. Kiriyāya dabbassa ca sarūpavisesappakāsanahetubhūtaṃ evanti evamādikaṃ🔽nipātapadaṃ. “Evaṃ manasi karotha, mā evaṃ manasākatthā”tiādīsu hi kiriyāvisesadīpanato
analyzed: upasagga padam kiriyāya dabbassa ca sarūpa visesa pakāsana hetu bhūtam evam ti evamādikam 🔽nipāta padam evam manasi karotha mā evam manasā akattha ati ādīsu hi kiriyā visesa dīpanataḥ
translated: and the materiality is uncommunicated by the name-terms. Just as the word “pa” in the word “cirappavāsi” signifies the state of being distinguished by separation from the action of dwelling, so too the prefix-term signifies the distinction of the action. It is the cause of the understanding of the distinction of the action. The word “pa” and so on are prefix-terms. The word “eva” and so on are particle-terms, which are the cause of the manifestation of the distinction of the materiality and the action. For in such passages as “Mind it thus, do not mind it thus” the particle-term signifies the distinction of the action.

original: kiriyāvisesassa jotako evaṃsaddo, “evaṃsīlā evaṃdhammā”tiādīsu dabbavisesassa. Saṅkhepato
analyzed: kiriyā visesassa jotakaḥ evaṃsaddaḥ evaṃsīlāḥ evaṃdhammāḥ ti ādīsu dabba visesassa saṅkhepato
translated: The word evaṃ is a marker of a particular action, as in “He is such a one of such virtue, such a one of such qualities” .🔽In brief,🔽it is a statement of meaning expressed by words.🔽The sentence is the expression of meaning expressed in brief.🔽“The four bases of success” is said in brief.

original: vuttaṃ padābhihitaṃ atthaṃ byañjetīti byañjanaṃ, vākyaṃ. “Cattāro iddhipādā”ti saṅkhepena
analyzed: vuttam pada abhihitam attham byañjeti iti byañjanam vākyam cattāraḥ iddhipādāḥ ti saṅkhepena
translated: The meaning expressed by that is made clear by the sentence:

original: kathitamatthaṃ “katame cattāro? Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu chandasamādhipadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ
analyzed: kathitam attham katame cattāraḥ idha bhikkhave bhikkhu chanda samādhi padhāna saṅkhāra samannāgatam
translated: “What are the four? Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu develops the basis for success that possesses both concentration due to desire to act and the will to act,

original: iddhipādaṃ bhāveti, vīriya, citta, vīmaṃsasamādhipadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgataṃ iddhipādaṃ
analyzed: iddhipādam bhāveti iddhipādam
translated: develops the basis for success that possesses both concentration due to energy and the will to act, develops the basis for success that possesses both concentration due to natural purity of consciousness and the will to act, develops the basis for success that possesses both concentration due to inquiry and the will to act” .

original: bhāvetī”tiādinā pākaṭaṃ karotīti vākyameva byañjanaṃ, taṃ pana atthato padasamudāyoti
analyzed: bhāva iti iti ādinā pākaṭam karoti iti vākyam eva byañjanam tam pana atthato
translated: The sentence is the expression of meaning expressed in brief. But it should be regarded as a collection of words in meaning.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Saākhyātaṃ sanipātaṃ sakārakaṃ savisesanaṃ vākyanti hi vadanti. Nanu
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam sa ākhyātam sa nipātam sa kārakam sa visesanam hi vadanti nanu
translated: For they say that a sentence is a statement, a collection, a doing, and a distinction.🔽But is not meaning also expressed by a word? So should not a word also be called an expression of meaning?

original: ca padenapi attho byañjīyatīti padampi byañjananti āpajjatīti? Taṃ na. Padamattasavanepi
analyzed: ca padena api atthaḥ byañjīyati iti padam pi āpajjati iti tam na pada matta savane pi
translated: No. For even when a word is heard by itself,

original: hi adhikārādivasena labbhamānehi padantarehi anusandhānaṃ katvāva atthasampaṭipatti
analyzed: hi adhikāra ādi vasena labbhamānehi pada antarehi anusandhānam katvā ava attha sampaṭipatti
translated: For the understanding of the meaning is effected only by connecting the words with other words that can be supplied by implication, such as the words “of” and “in” .

original: hotīti vākyameva atthaṃ byañjayatīti.
analyzed: hoti iti vākyam eva byañjayati iti
translated: So it is the sentence that conveys the meaning.

original: Pakārato vākyavibhāgo ākāro. “Tattha katamo chando? Yo chando chandikatā kattukamyatā”ti
analyzed: pakārataḥ vākya vibhāgaḥ ākāro tattha katamo chandaḥ yaḥ chando chandika tā kattu kamya tā ati
translated: Or else, the mode is the analysis of a sentence according to its parts of speech, as in the passage beginning, “Herein, what is will? It is will, willing, wish, wish- ing, desire, the state of desiring, the state of being desirous” .

original: evamādīsu kathitasseva vākyassa anekavidhena vibhāgakaraṇaṃ ākāro nāma. Ākārābhihitaṃ
analyzed: evamādīsu kathitassa iva vākyassa anekavidhena vibhāga karaṇam ākāraḥ nāma ākāra abhihitam
translated: The mode is the way in which a sentence is analysed by means of the various parts of speech.

original: nibbacanaṃ nirutti. “Phasso vedanā”ti evamādīsu ākārena kathitaṃ “phusatīti phasso,🔽vedayatīti vedanā”ti nīharitvā vitthāravacanaṃ nirutti nāma. “Nibbānaṃ maggati, nibbānatthikehi
analyzed: nibbacanam nirutti phassaḥ vedanā ti evamādīsu ākārena kathitam phusati iti phassaḥ  vedayati iti vedanā ati nīharitvā vitthāra vacanam nirutti nāma nibbānam maggati nibbāna atthikehi
translated: The expression is the etymology. In the passage beginning, “Contact, feeling” , the etymology is the explanation in detail of the words “contact” and “feeling” by deriving them etymologically as follows: “It contacts , thus it is contact ;🔽it feels , thus it is feeling” .

original: vā maggīyati, kilese vā mārento gacchatīti maggo”tiādinā nibbacanavitthāro niravasesadesanattā
analyzed: vā kilese vā mārentaḥ gacchati iti magga uti ādinā nibbacana vitthāraḥ niravasesa desanā ttā
translated: The definition is the explanation in detail of the derivation. In the passage beginning, “It goes to nibbāna , or it is gone to by those who seek nibbāna, or it goes by destroying defilements” , the definition is the explanation in detail of the derivation of the word “path” , which is given as “It goes , thus it is a path” .

original: niddeso. Atha vā vedayatīti vedanāti nibbacanaladdhapadesu sukhadukkhaadukkhamasukhāsu
analyzed: niddesaḥ atha vā vedayati iti vedanā ati nibbacana laddha padesu sukha dukkha adukkham asukhāsu
translated: Or alternatively, the definition is the explanation in detail of the words “feeling” and “perception” , which are given in the derivation as “It feels , thus it is feeling” and “It perceives , thus it is perception” , by means of the words “pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant” , “sensuous, spiritual, and spiritual-spiritual” , etc., which are supplied by implication.

original: sukhayatīti sukhā, dukkhayatīti dukkhā, neva dukkhayati na sukhayatīti adukkhamasukhāti
analyzed: sukhayati iti sukhā dukkhayati iti dukkhā na iva dukkhayati na sukhayati iti adukkham asukhā ati
translated: It gives pleasure, thus it is pleasant; it gives pain, thus it is painful; it gives neither pleasure nor pain, thus it is neither-painful-nor-pleasant.🔽The explanation is so called because the meaning is stated without remainder.

original: atthavitthāro niravasesena kathitattā niddeso nāma. Etesaṃ akkharādīnaṃ byañjanapadānaṃ
analyzed: attha vitthāraḥ niravasesena kathita ttā niddesaḥ nāma etesam akkhara ādīnam byañjana padānam
translated: The words beginning with “syllable” are

original: sampattiyā sampannatāya sabyañjanaṃ.
analyzed: sampattiyā sampanna tāyai sa byañjanam
translated: complete with the completeness of the syllables.

original: Evaṃ panassa atthapadasamāyogo byañjanapadasampatti ca veditabbā. Tattha bhagavā
analyzed: evam pana assa attha pada samāyogaḥ byañjana pada sampatti ca veditabbā tattha bhagavā
translated: The meaning and the words should be understood thus. Therein, the Blessed One

original: akkharehi saṅkāseti, padehi pakāseti, byañjanehi vivarati, ākārehi vibhajati, niruttīhi
analyzed: akkharehi saṅkāseti padehi pakāseti byañjanehi vivarati ākārehi vibhajati niruttīhi
translated: expounds with syllables, reveals with words, elucidates with phrases, classifies with clauses,

original: uttāniṃ karoti, niddesehi paññapeti. Tathā hi padāvayavaggahaṇamukhena padaggahaṇaṃ,🔽gahitena ca padena padatthāvabodho gahitapubbasaṅketassa hotīti bhagavā akkharehi
analyzed: uttānim karoti niddesehi paññapeti tathā hi pada avayava ggahaṇa mukhena pada ggahaṇam  gahitena ca padena padattha avabodhaḥ gahita pubba saṅketassa hoti iti bhagavā akkharehi
translated: elucidates with etymologies, and explains with explanations. For it is by way of the apprehension of the parts of a sentence that there is the apprehension of a sentence,🔽and when a sentence has been apprehended, the meaning of the sentence is understood by one who has previously learned the conventional usage, thus the Blessed One expounds with syllables.🔽But when the meaning is revealed briefly with syllables, it is only at the end of the words that the meaning of the sentence is understood by one who has previously learned the conventional usage, thus the Blessed One reveals with words.

original: saṅkāseti. Yasmā pana akkharehi saṃkhittena dīpiyamāno attho padapariyosāne vākyassa
analyzed: saṅkāse ti yasmā pana akkharehi saṃkhittena dīpiyamānaḥ attho pada pariyosāne vākyassa
translated: And when the meaning is revealed in detail with words, it is only at the end of the phrases that the meaning of the sentence is understood by one who has previously learned the conventional usage, thus the Blessed One elucidates with phrases.🔽And when the meaning is revealed in detail with phrases, it is only at the end of the clauses that the meaning of the sentence is understood by one who has previously learned the conventional usage, thus the Blessed One classifies with clauses.🔽And when the meaning is revealed in detail with clauses, it is only at the end of the etymologies that the meaning of the sentence is understood by one who has previously learned the conventional usage, thus the Blessed One elucidates with etymologies.🔽And when the meaning is revealed in detail with etymologies, it is only at the end of the explanations that the meaning of the sentence is understood by one who has previously learned the conventional usage, thus the Blessed One explains with explanations.

original: apariyositattā padena paṭhamaṃ pakāsito dīpito hoti, tasmā padehi pakāseti. Vākyapariyosāne🔽pana so attho vivarito vivaṭo kato hotīti byañjanehi vivarati. Yasmā ca pakārehi
analyzed: padena paṭhamam pakāsitaḥ dīpitaḥ hoti tasmā padehi pakāsa iti vākya pariyosāne  pana so atthaḥ vivaritaḥ vivaṭaḥ kataḥ hoti iti byañjanehi vivarati yasmā ca pakārehi
translated: But at the end of the sentence the meaning is opened up, disclosed, made plain, so he opens it out by means of the syllables.🔽And since the meaning is then said to be “analysed” when the sentence is analysed by means of the parts of speech, he analyses it by means of the parts of speech.

original: vākyabhede kate tadattho vibhatto nāma hoti, tasmā ākārehi vibhajati. Tathā vākyāvayavānaṃ🔽paccekaṃ nibbacanavibhāge kate so attho pākaṭo hotīti niruttīhi uttāniṃ karoti. Katanibbacanehi🔽pana vākyāvayavehi vitthāravasena niravasesato desitehi veneyyānaṃ cittaparitosanaṃ
analyzed: vākya bhede kate tad atthaḥ vibhattaḥ nāma hoti tasmai ākārehi vibhajati tathā vākya avayavānam  paccekam nibbacana vibhāge kate saḥ atthaḥ pākaṭaḥ hoti iti niruttīhi uttānim karoti kata nibbacanehi  pana vākya avayavehi vitthāra vasena niravasesataḥ desitehi veneyyānam citta paritosanam
translated: And since the meaning is then clear when the parts of speech are uttered separately and analysed, he makes it clear by means of the rules of pronunciation.🔽But when the parts of speech have been uttered separately and explained in detail without omission, the minds of the disciples are satisfied and their understanding is sharpened, so he makes it understood by means of the explanations.

original: buddhinisānañca kataṃ hotīti niddesehi paññapeti. Apica bhagavā akkharehi ugghaṭetvā🔽padehi vineti ugghaṭitaññuṃ, byañjanehi vipañcetvā ākārehi vineti vipañcitaññuṃ,
analyzed: buddhi nisānam ca katam hoti iti niddesehi paññapeti apica bhagavā akkharehi ugghaṭetvā  padehi vinā iti ugghaṭitaññum byañjanehi vipañcetvā ākārehi vinā iti vipañcitaññum
translated: Besides, the Blessed One rouses the disciple who is roused by means of the syllables and converts him by means of the words;🔽he analyses the disciple who is analysed by means of the syllables and converts him by means of the parts of speech;🔽he leads the disciple who is led by means of the rules of pronunciation and converts him by means of the explanations.

original: niruttīhi netvā niddesehi vineti neyyaṃ. Evañcāyaṃ dhammo ugghaṭiyamāno ugghaṭitaññuṃ
analyzed: niruttīhi netvā niddesehi vinā iti neyyam evam ca ayam dhammaḥ ugghaṭiyamānaḥ ugghaṭitaññum
translated: And when this Dhamma is being roused, it rouses the one who is roused by means of the syllables,

original: vineti, vipañciyamāno vipañcitaññuṃ, nīyamāno neyyaṃ. Tattha ugghaṭanā ādi, vipañcanā🔽majjhe, nayanaṃ ante. Evaṃ tīsu kālesu tidhā desito dosattayavidhamano guṇattayāvaho🔽tividhavineyyavinayanoti evampi tividhakalyāṇoyaṃ dhammo atthabyañjanapāripūriyā
analyzed: vineti vipañciyamānaḥ vipañcitaññum nīyamānaḥ neyyam tattha ugghaṭanā ādi vipañcanā  majjhe nayanam ante evam tīsu kālesu tidhā desitaḥ dosattaya vidhamanaḥ guṇattaya āvahaḥ  tividha vineyya vinayanā ti evam pi tividha kalyāṇaḥ yam dhammo attha byañjana pāripūriyā
translated: He guides, he causes to expand, he leads. Herein, the arousing is the beginning, the expanding is the middle, the leading is the end. So this Dhamma, taught in three parts in three periods, is a bearer of three kinds of virtue,

original: sāttho sabyañjanoti veditabbo. Vuttañhetaṃ nettipakaraṇe –
analyzed: sa atthaḥ sa byañjanaḥ ti veditabbaḥ vuttam ha etam netti pakaraṇe
translated: and it is also a bearer of three kinds of excellence, being a bearer of three kinds of disciples. It should be understood as having meaning and having phrasing because it is complete with meaning and phrasing. For this is said in the Netti Pakaraṇa:

original: “Tattha bhagavā akkharehi saṅkāseti, padehi pakāseti, byañjanehi vivarati, ākārehi🔽vibhajati, niruttīhi uttāniṃ karoti, niddesehi paññapeti. Tattha bhagavā akkharehi🔽ca padehi ca ugghaṭeti, byañjanehi ca ākārehi ca vipañceti, niruttīhi ca niddesehi
analyzed: tattha bhagavā akkharehi saṅkāseti padehi pakāseti byañjanehi vivarati ākārehi  vibhajati niruttīhi uttānim karoti niddesehi paññapeti tattha bhagavā akkharehi  ca padehi ca ugghaṭa iti byañjanehi ca ākārehi ca vipañca iti niruttīhi ca niddesehi
translated: “Herein, the Blessed One illuminates with syllables, he illuminates with words, he reveals with phrasing,

original: ca vitthāreti. Tattha ugghaṭanā ādi, vipañcanā majjhe, vitthāranā pariyosānaṃ. Soyaṃ
analyzed: ca vitthārā iti tattha ugghaṭanā ādi vipañcanā majjhe vitthāranā pariyosānam sā uyam
translated: he classifies with modes, he elucidates with etymologies, he makes plain with descriptions. Herein, the Blessed One arouses with syllables and words, he expands with phrasing and modes, he elucidates with etymologies and descriptions. Herein, the arousing is the beginning, the expanding is the middle, the elucidating is the end. This Dhamma,

original: dhammavinayo ugghaṭiyanto ugghaṭitaññuṃ puggalaṃ vineti, tena naṃ āhu ādikalyāṇoti.
analyzed: dhamma vinayaḥ ugghaṭiyantaḥ ugghaṭitaññum puggalam vineti tena nam āhu ādi kalyāṇaḥ ti
translated: The Dhamma and Discipline, when it is being opened up, trains the person who is quick to understand, and therefore it is called “good in the beginning.”

original: Vipañciyanto vipañcitaññuṃ puggalaṃ vineti, tena naṃ āhu majjhekalyāṇoti. Vitthāriyanto
analyzed: puggalam vinā iti tena nam āhu majjhekalyāṇaḥ iti
translated: When it is being analysed, it trains the person who is an analyser, and therefore it is called “good in the middle.”

original: neyyaṃ puggalaṃ vineti, tena naṃ āhu pariyosānakalyāṇotī”ti.🔽Atthagambhīratātiādīsu attho nāma tantiattho. Dhammo tanti. Paṭivedho tantiyā tantiatthassa
analyzed: na iyyam puggalam vinā iti tena nam āhu pariyosāna kalyāṇa ūti iti  attha gambhīra tā ti ādīsu atthaḥ nāma tanti atthaḥ dhammo tanti paṭivedhaḥ tantiyā tanti atthassa
translated: When it is being expounded, it trains the person who is led by argument, and therefore it is called “good in the end.”🔽Meaning, etc., are respectively the meaning of the text, the text, and the penetration of the meaning of the text.

original: ca yathābhūtāvabodho. Desanā nāma manasā vavatthāpitāya tantiyā desanā. Te panete
analyzed: ca yathā bhūta avabodhaḥ desanā nāma manasā tantiyā desanā te panete
translated: The teaching is the teaching of the text that has been defined by the mind.

original: atthādayo yasmā sasādīhi viya mahāsamuddo mandabuddhīhi dukkhogāhā alabbhaneyyapatiṭṭhā
analyzed: attha ādayaḥ yasmā sa sa ādīhi viya mahā samuddaḥ manda buddhīhi dukkha ugāhā a labbha neyya patiṭṭhā
translated: But these meaning, etc., are as hard to fathom for those of little understanding as the ocean is for the small fish, and they are as hard to grasp as the ocean is for the crab.

original: ca, tasmā gambhīrā. Atha vā attho nāma hetuphalaṃ. Dhammo hetu. Desanā paññatti,
analyzed: ca tasmai gambhīrā atha vā atthaḥ nāma hetu phalam dhammaḥ hetu desanā paññatti
translated: Or alternatively, the meaning is cause and fruit. The text is the cause. The teaching is the description,

original: yathādhammaṃ dhammābhilāpo. Anulomapaṭilomasaṅkhepavitthārādivasena vā kathanaṃ.
analyzed: yathādhammam dhamma abhilāpaḥ anuloma paṭiloma saṅkhepa vitthāra ādi vasena vā kathanam
translated: the expression of the text in accordance with the meaning. Or alternatively, the teaching is the explanation by means of the forward and reverse order, the brief and the detailed, and so on.

original: Paṭivedho abhisamayo, atthānurūpaṃ dhammesu, dhammānurūpaṃ atthesu, paññattipathānurūpaṃ🔽paññattīsu avabodho. Tesaṃ tesaṃ vā dhammānaṃ paṭivijjhitabbo lakkhaṇasaṅkhāto aviparītasabhāvo.🔽Tepi cete atthādayo yasmā anupacitakusalasambhārehi duppaññehi sasādīhi viya mahāsamuddo
analyzed: paṭivedhaḥ abhisamayaḥ attha anurūpam dhammesu dhamma anurūpam atthesu paññatti patha anurūpam  paññattīsu avabodho tesam tesam vā dhammānam paṭivijjhitabbaḥ lakkhaṇa saṅkhātaḥ aviparīta sabhāvo  te pi ca ite attha ādayaḥ yasmai anupacita kusala sambhārehi duppaññehi sa sa ādīhi viya mahā samuddaḥ
translated: Penetration is the penetration of the truths. The meaning is the meaning of the truths. The teaching is the teaching of the truths. The language is the language of the teaching of the truths. The phrasing is the phrasing of the language of the teaching of the truths. The explanation is the explanation of the phrasing of the language of the teaching of the truths. The penetration is the penetration of the characteristics of the individual truths.🔽Or else, the meaning, etc., are called “profound” because they are hard to grasp, like the great ocean, by those who are not skilled in accumulating the requisites of insight and who are slow-witted.🔽And because they are hard to cross without a guide, like the great ocean, by those who are not skilled in accumulating the requisites of insight and who are slow-witted.🔽And because they are hard to cross without a guide, like the great ocean, by those who are not skilled in accumulating the requisites of insight and who are slow-witted.🔽And because they are hard to cross without a guide, like the great ocean, by those who are not skilled in accumulating the requisites of insight and who are slow-witted.

original: dukkhogāhā alabbhaneyyapatiṭṭhā ca, tasmā gambhīrā. Tesu paṭivedhassapi atthasannissitattā🔽vuttaṃ “atthagambhīratāpaṭivedhagambhīratāhi sāttha”nti atthaguṇadīpanato. Tāsaṃ🔽dhammadesanānaṃ byañjanasannissitattā vuttaṃ “dhammagambhīratādesanāgambhīratāhi
analyzed: dukkha ugāhā a labbha neyya patiṭṭhā ca tasmā gambhīrā tesu paṭivedhassa api attha sannissita ttā  vuttam attha gambhīra tā paṭivedha gambhīra tāhi sā attham ti attha guṇa dīpanato tāsam  dhamma desanānam byañjana sannissita ttā vuttam dhamma gambhīra tā desanā gambhīra tāhi
translated: And because they are hard to cross without a guide, like the great ocean, by those who are not skilled in accumulating the requisites of insight and who are slow-witted.🔽And because they are hard to cross without a guide, like the great ocean, by those who are not skilled in accumulating the requisites of insight and who are slow-witted.🔽And because they are hard to cross without a guide, like the great ocean, by those who are not skilled in accumulating the requisites of insight and who are slow-witted.🔽And because they are hard to cross without a guide, like the great ocean, by those who are not skilled in accumulating the requisites of insight and who are slow-witted.

original: sabyañjana”nti tāsaṃ byañjanasampattidīpanato. Atthesu pabhedagataṃ ñāṇaṃ atthapaṭisambhidā,
analyzed: sa byañjanam ti tāsam byañjana sampatti dīpanataḥ atthesu pabheda gatam ñāṇam attha paṭisambhidā
translated: And because they are hard to cross without a guide, like the great ocean, by those who are not skilled in accumulating the requisites of insight and who are slow-witted.🔽And because they are hard to cross without a guide, like the great ocean, by those who are not skilled in accumulating the requisites of insight and who are slow-witted.🔽And because they are hard to cross without a guide, like the great ocean, by those who are not skilled in accumulating the requisites of insight and who are slow-witted.

original: atthadhammaniruttipaṭisambhidāsu pabhedagataṃ ñāṇaṃ paṭibhānapaṭisambhidāti imissāpi
analyzed: attha dhamma nirutti paṭisambhidāsu pabheda gatam ñāṇam paṭibhāna paṭisambhidā ti imissā api
translated: The knowledge that occurs in the analysis of the meaning, of the law, and of language is the discrimination of perspicuity.

original: paṭisambhidāya atthavisayattā āha “atthapaṭibhānapaṭisambhidāvisayato sāttha”nti
analyzed: paṭisambhidāya attha visaya ttā āha attha paṭibhāna paṭisambhidā visayato sā attham ti
translated: This discrimination also has the meaning as its domain. Therefore it is said: “It is meaningful because it has the meaning as its domain.”🔽When there is no excellence of meaning, there is no perspicuity because of the absence of the latter.

original: atthasampattiyā asati tadabhāvato. Dhammoti tanti. Niruttīti tantipadānaṃ niddhāretvā
analyzed: attha sampattiyāḥ asati tad abhāvataḥ tanti nirutti iti tanti padānam niddhāretvā
translated: The law is the teaching. Language is the expression of the words of the teaching.

original: vacanaṃ. Tattha pabhedagatāni ñāṇāni dhammaniruttipaṭisambhidāti āha “dhammaniruttipaṭisambhidāvisayato
analyzed: vacanam tattha pabheda gatāni ñāṇāni dhamma nirutti paṭisambhidā ti āha dhamma nirutti paṭisambhidā visayato
translated: The knowledge that occurs in the analysis of the law and of language is the discrimination of the law and of language. Therefore it is said: “It is well-phrased because it has the law and language as its domain.”

original: sabyañjana”nti asati byañjanasampattiyā tadabhāvato.
analyzed: asati
translated: When there is no excellence of phrasing, there is no perspicuity because of the absence of the latter.🔽It delights the minds of those who are critical. Here the word iti has the meaning of cause.

original: Parikkhakajanappasādakantīti ettha iti-saddo hetuattho. Yasmā parikkhakajanānaṃ kiṃkusalagavesīnaṃ
analyzed: parikkhaka jana ppasāda kanti iti ettha iti saddaḥ hetu atthaḥ yasmā parikkhaka janānam kiṃkusala gavesīnam
translated: Because it delights the minds of those who are critical, who are seekers after what is wholesome, therefore it is meaningful.

original: pasādāvahaṃ, tasmā sātthaṃ. Atthasampannanti phalena hetuno anumānaṃ nadīpūrena viya
analyzed: pasāda āvaham phalena hetunaḥ anumānam nadīpūrena
translated: The excellence of meaning is the inference of the cause by the effect, as the inference of the rainfall by the flood of water.

original: upari vuṭṭhipavattiyā. Sātthakatā panassa paṇḍitavedanīyatāya, sā paramagambhīrasaṇhasukhumabhāvato
analyzed: upari vuṭṭhi pavattiyā sātthaka tā pana assa paṇḍita vedanīya tāya sā parama gambhīra saṇha sukhuma bhāvato
translated: The excellence of phrasing is the delight of the wise because of its extreme profundity, subtlety, and delicacy.

original: veditabbā. Vuttañhetaṃ “gambhīro duddaso”tiādi. Lokiyajanappasādakanti sabyañjananti
analyzed: veditabbā vuttam ha etam gambhīraḥ duddasaḥ tiādi lokiya jana ppasādakanti sa byañjananti
translated: and it should be understood as said in the way beginning, “Deep, difficult to see … ”🔽It is “with phrasing” because it causes confidence in worldly people.

original: yasmā lokiyajanassa pasādāvahaṃ, tasmā sabyañjanaṃ. Lokiyajano hi byañjanasampattiyā
analyzed: yasmā lokiya janassa pasāda āvaham tasmā sa byañjanam lokiya janaḥ hi byañjana sampattiyā
translated: For it is by the excellence of the phrasing that worldly people are pleased.🔽Herein, the inference of the cause from the effect is intended.

original: tussati. Idhāpi phalena hetuno anumānaṃ. Sabyañjanatā panassa saddheyyatāya, sā ādikalyāṇādibhāvato
analyzed: tussati idha api phalena hetunaḥ anumānam sa byañjana tā pana assa saddheyya tāya sā ādi kalyāṇa ādi bhāvato
translated: But its excellence of phrasing should be understood as due to its excellence of meaning, which is due to its being good in the beginning, and so on.

original: veditabbā. Atha vā paṇḍitavedanīyato sātthanti paññāpadaṭṭhānatāya atthasampannataṃ🔽āha, tato parikkhakajanappasādakaṃ saddheyyato sabyañjananti saddhāpadaṭṭhānatāya
analyzed: veditabbāḥ atha vā paṇḍita vedanīyato sa atthanti paññā padaṭṭhāna tāya attha sampanna taṃ  āha tatas parikkhaka jana ppasādakam saddheyyataḥ sa byañjana nti saddhā padaṭṭhāna tāya
translated: Or alternatively, it is “meaningful” because it is to be felt by the wise, since it is the basis for the words of wisdom;🔽and it is “with phrasing” because it causes confidence in the average man, since it is the basis for the words of faith.🔽And it is “good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end” because it causes confidence in worldly people.

original: byañjanasampannataṃ, tato lokiyajanappasādatanti evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Gambhīrādhippāyato
analyzed: byañjana sampanna tam tatas lokiya jana ppasāda tam ti evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ gambhīra adhippāyato
translated: This is how the meaning should be regarded here.🔽It is “meaningful” because it has a profound purport, since its purport is hard to fathom;

original: sātthanti adhippāyato agādhāpāratāya atthasampannaṃ aññathā tadabhāvato. Uttānapadato
analyzed: sā atthanti adhippāyataḥ agādha apāratāya attha sampannam aññathā tad abhāvataḥ uttāna padato
translated: otherwise it would not be so. It is “with phrasing” because it has clear words, since its words are easy to understand;

original: sabyañjananti subodhasaddakatāya byañjanasampannaṃ paramagambhīrassapi atthassa vineyyānaṃ
analyzed: sa byañjanam ti su bodha saddaka tāya byañjana sampannam parama gambhīrassa api atthassa vineyyānam
translated: “With the phrasing” means that it is endowed with the phrasing, that is, with the words, which are easy to understand. Even though the meaning is extremely profound, it is easy to grasp for those to be trained.

original: suviññeyyabhāvāpādanato. Sabbopesa atthasampattiyā sātthaṃ, byañjanasampattiyā sabyañjananti🔽sabbapaṭhamaṃ vuttasseva atthadvayassa papañcoti daṭṭhabbo. Tathā ceva tattha tattha
analyzed: su viññeyya bhāva āpādanato sabba upesaḥ attha sampattiyā sa attham byañjana sampattiyā sa byañjanam ti  sabba paṭhamam vuttassa iva attha dvayassa papañco ti daṭṭhabbo tathā ca iva tattha tattha
translated: “With its meaning and with its phrasing” : with its meaning it is meaningful because it is endowed with the meaning of the whole of the noble truth of suffering, etc.,🔽and with its phrasing it is phrased because it is endowed with the phrasing of the noble truth of suffering, etc., which is well-phrased in the sense of being easy to understand, and because, though it is supremely profound, it makes the meaning easy to understand for those to be trained.🔽But all this is only a proliferation of the two meanings stated at the very beginning, namely, “meaningful” as endowment with meaning and “with its phrasing” as endowment with phrasing.🔽And this is how it should be regarded, for it is commended in this way in the various places where the word “meaningful” occurs.

original: saṃvaṇṇitaṃ. Tathā hettha vikappassa samuccayassa vā aggahaṇaṃ. Upanetabbassa abhāvatoti🔽pakkhipitabbassa vodānatthassa avuttassa abhāvato. Kevalasaddo sakalādhivacananti
analyzed: saṃvaṇṇitam tathā ha ittha vikappassa samuccayassa vā aggahaṇam upanetabbassa abhāvato ti  pakkhipitabbassa vodāna atthassa avuttassa abhāvataḥ kevala saddo sakala adhivacananti
translated: And it is not mentioned here in the way of a specification or a cumulative addition.🔽Because there is nothing to be added, that is, because there is no purity of meaning not already stated that needs to be added.🔽The word “only” is a term for the whole.🔽Therefore it is said, “in the sense of being complete in every aspect.” The meaning is that it is complete in all its aspects.

original: āha “sakalaparipuṇṇabhāvenā”ti, sabbabhāgehi paripuṇṇatāyāti attho. Apanetabbassāti saṃkilesadhammassa.🔽Brahmacariyaṃ pakāsetīti ettha pana ayaṃ brahmacariya-saddo dāne veyyāvacce pañcasikkhāpadasīle
analyzed: āha sakala paripuṇṇa bhāvena ati sabba bhāgehi paripuṇṇa tāya ati atthaḥ apanetabbassa nti saṃkilesa dhammassa 🔽brahmacariyam pakāseti iti ettha pana ayam brahmacariya saddaḥ dāne veyyāvacce pañca sikkhāpada sīle
translated: Because there is nothing to be subtracted, that is, because there is no defilement that needs to be subtracted.

original: appamaññāsu methunaviratiyaṃ sadārasantose vīriye uposathaṅgesu ariyamagge sāsaneti
analyzed: appamaññāsu methuna viratiyam sa dāra santose vīriye uposathaṅgesu ariya magge sāsane ti
translated: in the measureless states, in the abstinence from sexual intercourse, in the satisfaction of one’s wife, in energy, in the Uposatha factors, in the Noble Eightfold Path, in the Dispensation.

original: imesu atthesu dissati.🔽“Kiṃ te vataṃ kiṃ pana brahmacariyaṃ,
analyzed: imesu atthesu dissati  kim te vatam kim pana brahmacariyam
translated: It is found in these meanings.🔽“What is your gift, and what is your holy life,

original: Kissa suciṇṇassa ayaṃ vipāko;
analyzed: kissa su ciṇṇassa ayam vipākaḥ
translated: What is the result of your good conduct?

original: Iddhī jutī balavīriyūpapatti,
analyzed: iddhī jutī
translated: Your psychic power, your splendour, your strength, your energy,

original: Idañca te nāgamahāvimānaṃ.
analyzed: idam ca te nāga mahā vimānam
translated: And this your great mansion, O Nāga.

original: “Ahañca bhariyā ca manussaloke,
analyzed: ahañca bhariyā ca manussa loke
translated: “My wife and I in the human world,

original: Saddhā ubho dānapatī ahumhā;
analyzed: saddhā ubho dānapatī ahumhā
translated: We were both faithful and givers of gifts.

original: Opānabhūtaṃ me gharaṃ tadāsi,
analyzed: opāna bhūtam me gharam tadā asi
translated: My house was open to all,

original: Santappitā samaṇabrāhmaṇā ca.
analyzed: santappitā samaṇa brāhmaṇā ca
translated: And ascetics and brahmins were satisfied.

original: “Taṃ me vataṃ taṃ pana brahmacariyaṃ,
analyzed: tam me tam pana brahmacariyam
translated: “That is my gift, and that is my holy life,

original: Tassa suciṇṇassa ayaṃ vipāko;
analyzed: tassa su ciṇṇassa ayam vipākaḥ
translated: That is the result of my good conduct.

original: Iddhī jutī balavīriyūpapatti,
analyzed: iddhī jutī
translated: Your psychic power, your splendour, your strength, your energy,

original: Idañca me dhīra mahāvimāna”nti. –
analyzed: idam ca me dhīra
translated: And this my great mansion, O wise one.”

original: Imasmiñhi puṇṇakajātake dānaṃ “brahmacariya”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: imasmin hi puṇṇaka jātake dānam brahmacariyan ti vuttam
translated: In this Puṇṇaka Jātaka, giving is called “holy life.”

original: “Kena pāṇi kāmadado, kena pāṇi madhussavo;
analyzed: kena pāṇi kāmadadaḥ kena pāṇi madhussavaḥ
translated: “By what hand do you give gifts, by what hand do you give sweet drink?🔽By what holy life of yours

original: Kena te brahmacariyena, puññaṃ pāṇimhi ijjhati.
analyzed: kena te brahmacariyena puññam pāṇimhi ijjhati
translated: Does merit come to your hand?

original: “Tena pāṇi kāmadado, tena pāṇi madhussavo;
analyzed: tena pāṇi kāmadadaḥ tena pāṇi madhussavaḥ
translated: “By that hand do I give gifts, by that hand do I give sweet drink.

analyzed: tena me brahmacariyena puññam pāṇimhi ijjhati iti  imasmin aṅkura peta vatthumhi veyyāvaccam brahmacariyanti vuttam evam kho tam bhikkhave
translated: merit is produced in my hand.”🔽In this story of the Aṅkura ghost, the service is called “holy life.”🔽“Bhikkhus, that is how the holy life named Tittiriya came to be.”

original: tittiriyaṃ nāma brahmacariyaṃ ahosī”ti imasmiṃ tittirajātake pañcasikkhāpadasīlaṃ
analyzed: tittiriyam nāma brahmacariyam ahosi iti imasmin tittira jātake pañca sikkhāpada sīlam
translated: In this Tittiriya Birth Story, the virtue of the five precepts is called “holy life.”

original: “brahmacariya”nti vuttaṃ. “Taṃ kho pana me pañcasikha brahmacariyaṃ neva nibbidāya
analyzed: brahmacariyanti vuttam tam kho pana me pañcasikha brahmacariyam na iva nibbidāya
translated: “But, Pañcasikha, that holy life of mine did not lead to disenchantment,

original: na virāgāya na nirodhāya yāvadeva brahmalokūpapattiyā”ti imasmiṃ mahāgovindasutte
analyzed: na virāgāya na nirodhāya yāvat eva brahma loka upapattiyā ati imasmin mahāgovindasutte
translated: to dispassion, to cessation, to peace, to direct knowledge, to enlightenment, to Nibbana, but only to reappearance in the Brahma-world.”🔽In this Mahā-Govinda Discourse, the four divine abodes are called “holy life.”

original: catasso appamaññāyo “brahmacariya”nti vuttā. “Pare abrahmacārī bhavissanti, mayamettha
analyzed: catasso appamaññāyaḥ brahmacariyanti vuttā pare abrahmacārī bhavissanti mayam ettha
translated: “Others will be unchaste, but we are chaste here;🔽others will be unchaste, but we are not unchaste.”

original: brahmacārī bhavissāmā”ti imasmiṃ sallekhasutte methunavirati “brahmacariya”nti vuttā.
analyzed: brahmacārī bhavissāma ati imasmim sallekha sutte methuna virati brahmacariyanti vuttā
translated: In this Discourse on Striving, abstinence from sexual intercourse is called “holy life.”

original: “Mayañca bhariyā nātikkamāma,
analyzed: mayam ca bhariyāḥ na atikkamāma
translated: “We do not transgress our wives,

original: Amhe ca bhariyā nātikkamanti;
analyzed: amhe ca bhariyāḥ na atikkamanti
translated: Nor do our wives transgress us.

original: Aññatra tāhi brahmacariyaṃ carāma,
analyzed: aññatra tāhi brahmacariyam carāma
translated: Apart from them we lead the holy life,

original: Tasmā hi amhaṃ daharā na mīyare”ti. –
analyzed: tasmai hi amham daharā na
translated: Therefore our young ones do not die.”

original: Mahādhammapālajātake sadārasantoso “brahmacariya”nti vutto. “Abhijānāmi kho panāhaṃ,
analyzed: mahādhammapāla jātake sa dāra santosaḥ brahmacariyanti vutto abhijānāmi kho pana aham
translated: In the Mahādhammapāla Jātaka the satisfaction of the householder and his wife is called the “holy life.”

original: sāriputta, caturaṅgasamannāgataṃ brahmacariyaṃ caritā, tapassī sudaṃ homī”ti lomahaṃsanasutte
analyzed: sāriputta catur aṅga samannāgatam brahmacariyam caritā tapassī sudam homi iti lomahaṃsana sutte
translated: In the Lomahaṃsa Sutta the Buddha says: “Sāriputta, I remember practicing the holy life possessed of four factors, and I was an ascetic.”

original: vīriyaṃ “brahmacariya”nti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vīriyam brahmacariyan ti vuttam
translated: Here the ascetic practice is called the “holy life.”

original: “Hīnena brahmacariyena, khattiye upapajjati;
analyzed: hīnena brahmacariyena khattiye upapajjati
translated: “By the lower holy life one is reborn among the Khattiyas;🔽By the middle one among the gods;

original: Majjhimena ca devattaṃ, uttamena visujjhatī”ti. –
analyzed: majjhimena ca devattam uttamena visujjhati iti
translated: By the higher one is purified.”

original: Evaṃ nimijātake attadamanavasena kato aṭṭhaṅgiko uposatho “brahmacariya”nti vutto.🔽“Idaṃ kho pana me, pañcasikha, brahmacariyaṃ ekantanibbidāya virāgāya…pe… ayameva
analyzed: evam nimi jātake atta damana vasena kataḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ uposathaḥ brahmacariya nti vutto  idam kho pana me pañcasikha brahmacariyam ekanta nibbidāya virāgāya ape ayam eva
translated: In the Nimi Jātaka the eight-factored uposatha is called the “holy life” because it is the self-control practiced by the Buddha in a previous birth.

original: ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo”ti mahāgovindasuttasmiṃyeva ariyamaggo “brahmacariya”nti vutto.
analyzed: ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo ti mahāgovindasuttasmiṃ yeva ariya maggaḥ brahmacariyanti vutto
translated: In the Mahāgovinda Sutta the noble eightfold path is called the “holy life.”

original: “Tayidaṃ brahmacariyaṃ iddhañceva phītañca vitthārikaṃ bāhujaññaṃ puthubhūtaṃ yāvadeva
analyzed: tayā idam brahmacariyam iddham ca iva phītam ca vitthārikam bāhujaññam puthu bhūtam yāvat eva
translated: “This holy life is prosperous, flourishing, well-populated, widely-spread, and made known far and wide.”

original: manussehi suppakāsita”nti pāsādikasutte sikkhattayasaṅgahaṃ sakalasāsanaṃ “brahmacariya”nti
analyzed: manussehi su pakāsitanti pāsādika sutte sikkhattaya saṅgaham sakala sāsanam brahmacariyanti
translated: The three trainings are included in the whole dispensation, which is called “the life of purity” in the Pāsādikasutta: “The life of purity is well proclaimed by the Lord, open, clear, and bare for all to see.”

original: vuttaṃ. Imasmimpi ṭhāne idameva “brahmacariya”nti adhippetanti āha “sikkhattayapariggahitattā”tiādi.
analyzed: vuttam imasmim pi ṭhāne idam eva brahmacariyanti adhippetanti āha sikkhattaya pariggahita ttā atiādi
translated: And here too the life of purity is intended in the same sense. That is why he said “because it is included in the three trainings.”

original: Seṭṭhehīti buddhādīhi seṭṭhehi. Seṭṭhaṭṭhena brahmabhūtaṃ vā cariyaṃ brahmacariyaṃ.🔽Sanidānanti heṭṭhā vuttalakkhaṇena nidānena sanidānaṃ. Sauppattikanti saaṭṭhuppattikaṃ.
analyzed: seṭṭhehi iti buddha ādīhi seṭṭhehi seṭṭha ṭṭhena brahma bhūtam vā cariyam brahmacariyam  sa nidānam ti heṭṭhā vutta lakkhaṇena nidānena sa nidānam sauppattikam ti sa aṭṭhuppattikam
translated: “By the best”: by the best, namely, the Buddhas, etc. Or the life of purity is the life of one who is purified by the best, that is, by the supreme state of a brahma.🔽“With its cause” means with the cause stated as its characteristic in the way already stated . “With its provenance” means with its origination.🔽“In accordance with the disciples’ way of life, etc.”: in accordance with the disciples’ temperament, etc.

original: Veneyyānaṃ anurūpatoti veneyyānaṃ cariyādianurūpato. Atthassāti desiyamānassa sīlādiatthassa.
analyzed: veneyyānam anurūpato ti veneyyānam cariyā ādi anurūpataḥ atthassa ati desiyamānassa sīla ādi atthassa
translated: “The meaning”: the meaning of virtue, etc., that is being taught.

original: Hetudāharaṇayuttatoti “taṃ kissa hetu seyyathāpi, bhikkhave”ti ca ādinā tattha tattha
analyzed: hetu dāharaṇa yuttato ti tam kissa hetu seyyathā api bhikkhave iti ca ādinā tattha tattha
translated: “With reason and illustration”: with reasons and illustrations given here and there in the way beginning: “For what reason? It is, bhikkhus, as follows” .

original: hetupamaggahaṇena hetudāharaṇehi yuttato. Saddhāpaṭilābhenāti “te taṃ dhammaṃ sutvā
analyzed: hetu pamaggahaṇena hetu udāharaṇehi yuttataḥ saddhā paṭilābhena ati te tam dhammam sutvā
translated: “With the acquisition of faith”: having heard that Dhamma, they acquire faith thus: “This is the Dhamma and Discipline, the Master’s Dispensation,” and they go for refuge.

original: tathāgate saddhaṃ paṭilabhantī”tiādinā vuttasaddhāpaṭilābhena. Paṭipattiyāti sīlavisuddhiyādisammāpaṭipattiyā,
analyzed: tathāgate saddham paṭilabhanti iti ādinā vutta saddhā paṭilābhena paṭipattiyā ati sīla visuddhiyā ādi sammā paṭipattiyā
translated: By the practice: by the right practice of purification of virtue, and so on.🔽The meaning is: by the sign of the practice.🔽By the extent of the attainment: by the extent of the attainment of the discovery of the truths,🔽which is the state of being endowed with the discovery of the truths.

original: paṭipattinimittanti attho. Adhigamabyattitoti saccappaṭivedhena adhigamaveyyattiyasabbhāvato
analyzed: paṭipatti nimittanti atthaḥ adhigama byattitaḥ ti sacca ppaṭivedhena adhigama veyyattiya sabbhāvato
translated: By the extent of the tradition: by the extent of the tradition, which is the state of being endowed with the discovery of the tradition,
