original: tassā kathāya vacanacāturiyamāha. Atthaparisuddhatāyāti atthassa nirupakkilesataṃ.
analyzed: tassā kathāya vacana cāturiyam āha attha parisuddha tāya ati atthassa nirupakkilesa tam
translated: He said this in order to show the purity of the meaning.

original: Anekehi pariyāyehīti anekehi kāraṇehi.🔽Atidūraaccāsannapaṭikkhepena nātidūranāccāsannaṃ nāma gahitaṃ, taṃ pana avakaṃsato
analyzed: anekehi pariyāyehi iti anekehi kāraṇehi  atidūra acca āsanna paṭikkhepena na atidūra nācca āsannam nāma gahitam tam pana avakaṃsato
translated: By many a method: by many a reason.🔽Not too far and not too near: this is said by way of the rejection of too far and too near. But that should be understood by way of the distance between the two outstretched arms.

original: ubhinnaṃ pasāritahatthāsaṅghaṭṭanena daṭṭhabbaṃ. Gīvaṃ pasāretvāti gīvaṃ parivattanavasena
analyzed: ubhinnam pasārita hattha a saṅghaṭṭanena daṭṭhabbam gīvam pasāretvā iti gīvam parivattana vasena
translated: Having stretched out his neck: having stretched out his neck by turning it.

original: pasāretvā. Meti kattuatthe sāmivacananti āha “mayā suta”nti. Jātibrāhmaṇeti jātiyā
analyzed: pasāretvā mā iti kattuatthe sāmi vacananti āha mayā sutanti jāti brāhmaṇa iti jātiyā
translated: Me: the word me is a possessive. He said “I heard” .

original: brāhmaṇe, na bāhitapāpatāyāti vuttaṃ hoti. Khaṇḍiccādibhāvaṃ āpāditeti khaṇḍitadantapalitakesādibhāvaṃ
analyzed: brāhmaṇe na bāhita pāpa tāya iti vuttam hoti āpāditā iti khaṇḍita danta palita kesa ādi bhāvam
translated: Brahmin by birth: a Brahmin by birth, not by the casting out of defilements, is what is said.

original: sampāpite. Vuḍḍhimariyādappatteti vuḍḍhiparicchedaṃ sampatte, vuḍḍhipariyantappatteti
analyzed: sampāpite vuḍḍhi mariyādappattā iti vuḍḍhi paricchedam sampatte vuḍḍhi pariyantappattā iti
translated: Having reached the state of having broken teeth, grey hair, etc.: having reached the state of having broken teeth, grey hair, etc.🔽Having reached the limit of growth: having reached the limit of growth, having reached the end of growth, is what is said.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Jātimahallakatāyāti uppattiyā mahallakabhāvena. Mahattaṃ lāti gaṇhātīti
analyzed: vuttam hoti jāti mahallaka tāya ati uppattiyāḥ mahallaka bhāvena mahattam lāti gaṇhāti iti
translated: By the greatness of his birth: by the greatness of his origin.

original: mahallako, jātiyā mahallako, na vibhavādināti jātimahallako. Addhānanti dīghakālaṃ.
analyzed: mahallakaḥ jātiyā mahallakaḥ na vibhava ādinā ati jāti mahallakaḥ dīgha kālam
translated: “Elder” means elder by birth, not elder by wealth. “Long time” means a long period.

original: Kittako pana soti āha “dve tayo rājaparivaṭṭe”ti, dvinnaṃ tiṇṇaṃ rājūnaṃ rajjapasāsanapaṭipāṭiyoti
analyzed: kittako pana saḥ ti āha dve tayo rāja parivaṭṭe iti dvinnam tiṇṇam rajja pasāsana paṭipāṭiyā ti
translated: “How long?”—he says “two or three royal generations,” the meaning is “the succession of two or three kings’ reigns.”

original: attho. “Addhagate”ti vatvā kathaṃ vayogahaṇaṃ osānavayāpekkhanti āha “pacchimavayaṃ
analyzed: attho addha gatā iti vatvā katham vayaḥ gahaṇam osāna vayā apekkhanti āha pacchima vayam
translated: After saying “half-way,” why is the word “end” mentioned? He says “when the last stage of life has been reached.”

original: anuppatte”ti. Pacchimo tatiyabhāgoti sattasaṭṭhito paṭṭhāya pacchimavayo koṭṭhāso.
analyzed: an uppattā iti pacchimo tatiya bhāgo ti satta saṭṭhitaḥ paṭṭhāya pacchima vayaḥ koṭṭhāso
translated: The last third part is the last stage of life beginning from the age of seventy-six.

original: Dutiye atthavikappe jiṇṇeti nāyaṃ jiṇṇatā vayomattena, atha kho kulaparivaṭṭena purāṇatāyāti
analyzed: dutiye attha vikappe jiṇṇā iti na ayam jiṇṇa tā vayaḥ mattena atha kho kula parivaṭṭena purāṇa tāya ati
translated: In the second interpretation, “old” does not mean old by age, but rather old by the succession of generations.

original: āha “jiṇṇeti porāṇe”tiādi. Tena tesaṃ brāhmaṇānaṃ kulavasena uditoditabhāvamāha.🔽“Vayoanuppatte”ti iminā jātivuḍḍhiyā vakkhamānattā guṇavuḍḍhiyā tato sātisayattā
analyzed: āha jiṇṇa iti porāṇa itiādi tena tesam brāhmaṇānam kula vasena udita udita bhāvam āha  vayaḥ anuppattā iti iminā jāti vuḍḍhiyā vakkhamāna ttā guṇa vuḍḍhiyā tatas sā ati saya ttā
translated: Therefore he says “old” means “ancient,” etc. By this he shows the state of being well-known by the families of those brahmins.🔽By “when the last stage of life has been reached,” since the increase of age is being spoken of, the increase of qualities is even more than that.

original: ca “vuḍḍheti sīlācārādiguṇavuḍḍhiyutte”ti āha. Tathā jātimahallakatāyapi teneva vakkhamānattā
analyzed: ca vuḍḍhā iti sīla ācāra ādi guṇa vuḍḍhi yuttā iti āha tathā tena iva
translated: Therefore he says “old” means “endowed with the increase of qualities such as virtue and conduct.” Likewise, since the state of being elder by birth is also being spoken of by that very word,

original: mahallaketi padena vibhavamahattatā yojitā. Maggapaṭipanneti brāhmaṇānaṃ paṭipattividhiṃ🔽upagate taṃ avokkamma caraṇato. Antimavayanti pacchimavayaṃ.
analyzed: mahallaka iti padena vibhava mahatta tā yojitā magga paṭipannā iti brāhmaṇānam paṭipatti vidhim  upagate tam avokkamma caraṇataḥ antima vayanti pacchima vayam
translated: The word “old” is used to imply the greatness of his wealth. “Practicing the holy life”: he has undertaken the practice of the brahmans.🔽“Without looking back”: he does not look back at them. “The last stage”: the final stage.

original: Paccuṭṭhānaṃ nāma āsanā vuṭṭhānanti āha “nāsanā vuṭṭhahatī”ti, nisinnāsanato na vuṭṭhātīti🔽attho. Ettha ca jiṇṇe…pe… vayoanuppatteti upayogavacanaṃ āsanā vuṭṭhānakiriyāpekkhaṃ
analyzed: paccuṭṭhānam nāma āsanā vuṭṭhānanti āha na āsanā vuṭṭhahati iti nisinna āsanataḥ na vuṭṭhāti iti  atthaḥ ettha ca vayaḥ anuppattā iti upayoga vacanam āsanā vuṭṭhāna kiriyā apekkham
translated: “Rising up” means rising up from one’s seat. “Does not rise up from his seat” means he does not rise up from the seat he is sitting on.🔽Here the expression “when he sees an old person, etc.” is not used with reference to the action of rising up from one’s seat.

original: na hoti, tasmā jiṇṇe…pe… vayoanuppatte disvāti ajjhāhāraṃ katvā attho veditabbo.🔽Atha vā paccuggamanakiriyāpekkhaṃ upayogavacanaṃ, tasmā na paccuṭṭhetīti uṭṭhāya
analyzed: na hoti tasmā jiṇṇepe vayaḥ anuppatte disvā iti ajjhāhāram katvā atthaḥ veditabbo  atha vā paccuggamana kiriyā apekkham upayoga vacanam tasmā na paccuṭṭheti iti uṭṭhāya
translated: Therefore the meaning should be understood as follows: “having seen an old person, etc.,”🔽or the expression is used with reference to the action of going to meet the person. Therefore “does not rise up” means “having risen up, he does not go to meet the person.”

original: paccuggamanaṃ na karotīti attho veditabbo. Paccuggamanampi hi paccuṭṭhānanti vuccati.
analyzed: paccuggamanam na karoti iti atthaḥ veditabbaḥ paccuggamanam pi hi paccuṭṭhānam ti vuccati
translated: For going to meet is also called “rising up.”

original: Vuttañhetaṃ “ācariyaṃ pana dūratova disvā paccuṭṭhāya paccuggamanakaraṇaṃ paccuṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: vuttam ha etam ācariyam pana dūratas va disvā paccuṭṭhāya paccuggamana karaṇam paccuṭṭhānam
translated: For this is said: “But when he sees his teacher from afar, he rises up and goes to meet him. This is called rising up.

original: nāmā”ti. Nāsanā vuṭṭhātīti iminā pana paccuggamanābhāvassa upalakkhaṇamattaṃ dassitanti
analyzed: nāma ati na āsanā vuṭṭhāti iti iminā pana paccuggamana abhāvassa upalakkhaṇa mattam dassitan ti
translated: But by the words “he does not rise to meet him” the mere indication of the absence of going out to meet is shown.🔽So it should be understood.

original: daṭṭhabbaṃ. Vibhāvane nāma attheti pakativibhāvanasaṅkhāte atthe, na abhivādeti vāti
analyzed: daṭṭhabbam vibhāvane nāma atthe iti pakati vibhāvana saṅkhāte atthe na abhivāde iti vāti
translated: In the sense of “distinction” : in the sense of the distinction called “natural distinction” .

original: na abhivādetabbanti sallakkhetīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: na abhivādetabbanti sallakkheti iti vuttam hoti
translated: He does not pay homage : he does not consider that he should pay homage.

original: Taṃ aññāṇanti “ayaṃ mama abhivādanādīni kātuṃ araharūpo na hotī”ti ajānanavasena🔽pavattaṃ aññāṇaṃ. Olokentoti “dukkhaṃ kho agāravo viharati appatisso, kiṃ nu kho
analyzed: tam ayam mama abhivādana ādīni kātum araha rūpaḥ na hoti iti a jānana vasena  pavattam aññāṇam olokento ti dukkham kho agāravaḥ viharati appatissaḥ kim nu kho
translated: That ignorance : the ignorance that occurs through not knowing that “This one is not worthy of my homage, etc.”

original: ahaṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā sakkareyyaṃ, garuṃ kareyya”ntiādisuttavasena ñāṇacakkhunā
analyzed: aham samaṇam vā brāhmaṇam vā sakkareyyam garum kareyya nti ādi sutta vasena ñāṇa cakkhunā
translated: Looking around : looking around with the eye of knowledge in the way stated in the sutta: “It is painful, bhikkhus, to live without respect and without deference. What if I were to honour and respect some ascetic or brahmin? ”🔽Worthy of offerings : worthy of prostration.

original: olokento. Nipaccakārārahanti paṇipātārahaṃ. Sampatijātoti muhuttajāto, jātasamanantaramevāti
analyzed: olokentaḥ nipaccakāra arahanti paṇipāta arahan sampati jātaḥ ti muhutta jātaḥ jāta samanantaram eva ati
translated: Just born : born a moment ago; what is meant is: immediately after birth.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Uttarena mukhoti uttarābhimukho, uttaradisābhimukhoti vuttaṃ hoti. Sattapadavītihārena
analyzed: vuttam hoti uttarena mukho ti uttara abhimukho uttara disa abhimukho ti vuttam hoti satta padavī tihārena
translated: Facing north : facing northwards; what is meant is: facing the northern direction.

original: gantvā sakalaṃ dasasahassilokadhātuṃ olokesinti idaṃ “dhammatā esā, bhikkhave, sampatijāto
analyzed: gantvā sakalam dasa sahassi lokadhātum olokesin ti idam dhammatā esā bhikkhave sampatijātaḥ
translated: “It is the rule that the Bodhisatta,

original: bodhisatto samehi pādehi patiṭṭhahitvā uttarābhimukho sattapadavītihārena gacchati,
analyzed: bodhisattaḥ samehi pādehi patiṭṭhahitvā uttara abhimukhaḥ satta padavī tihārena gacchati
translated: as soon as he is born, stands firm on his feet, takes seven steps to the north,

original: setamhi chatte anudhāriyamāne sabbā disā viloketi, āsabhiñca vācaṃ bhāsatī”ti evaṃ
analyzed: setamhi chatte anudhāriyamāne sabbāḥ disāḥ viloketi āsabhiḥ ca vācam bhāsati iti evam
translated: and, while a white parasol is held over him, he looks in the four directions and utters his lion’s roar.”

original: pāḷiyaṃ sattapadavītihārūpariṭṭhitassa viya sabbadisānuvilokanassa kathitattā vuttaṃ,
analyzed: pāḷiyam vuttam
translated: This is said in the texts as if the looking in all directions were done only after the seven steps,🔽but it should not be taken like that, because the looking in all directions was done even before the seven steps.

original: na panetaṃ evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, sattapadavītihārato pageva disāvilokanassa katattā. Mahāsatto
analyzed: na pana itam evam daṭṭhabbam satta padavī tihārato pagā iva disā vilokanassa kata ttā mahāsatto
translated: The Great Being,

original: hi manussānaṃ hatthato muccitvā puratthimadisaṃ olokesi, anekāni cakkavāḷasahassāni🔽ekaṅgaṇāni ahesuṃ. Tattha devamanussā gandhamālādīhi pūjayamānā “mahāpurisa idha
analyzed: hi manussānam hatthataḥ muccitvā puratthima disam olokesi anekāni cakkavāḷa sahassāni  ekaṅgaṇāni ahesum tattha deva manussāḥ gandha mālā ādīhi pūjayamānāḥ mahā purise idha
translated: as soon as he was freed from the hands of the men, looked towards the east, and many thousands of world-spheres🔽became one vast expanse. There the gods and men worshipped him with perfumes, garlands, and so on, saying: “Great Man, there is no one equal to you, let alone anyone superior.”

original: tumhehi sadisopi natthi, kuto uttaritaro”ti āhaṃsu. Evaṃ catasso disā catasso anudisā
analyzed: tumhehi sadisaḥ api natthi kutas uttaritaro ti āhaṃsu evam catassaḥ disā catassaḥ anudisā
translated: In this way he looked in the four cardinal and four intermediate directions,

original: heṭṭhā uparīti dasapi disā anuviloketvā attano sadisaṃ adisvā “ayaṃ uttarā disā”ti🔽sattapadavītihārena agamāsīti veditabbo. Olokesinti mama puññānubhāvena lokavivaraṇapāṭihāriye
analyzed: heṭṭhā upari iti dasa api disā anuviloketvā attano sadisam a disvā ayam uttarā disā ati  agamāsi iti veditabbo olokesin ti mama puñña anubhāvena loka vivaraṇa pāṭihāriye
translated: Looking down and up: having looked down and up in the ten directions, not seeing anyone like himself, he thought: “This is the northern direction.”

original: jāte paññāyamānaṃ dasasahassilokadhātuṃ maṃsacakkhunāva olokesinti attho.🔽Mahāpurisoti jātigottakulappadesādivasena mahantapuriso. Aggoti guṇehi sabbapadhāno.
analyzed: jāte paññāyamānam dasa sahassi lokadhātum maṃsa cakkhunā āva olokesin ti attho  mahā puriso ti jāti gotta kula ppadesa ādi vasena mahanta purisaḥ aggo ti guṇehi sabba padhāno
translated: He went forward in a stride of seven steps. The meaning is: they looked with their physical eyes at the ten-thousand world-element, which was manifested when the marvel of the opening of the world took place through the power of my merit.🔽The Great Man: a great man by way of his clan, family, country, etc. The foremost: the foremost by way of his special qualities.

original: Jeṭṭhoti guṇavaseneva sabbesaṃ vuḍḍhatamo, guṇehi mahallakatamoti vuttaṃ hoti. Seṭṭhoti
analyzed: jeṭṭhaḥ ti guṇa vasena iva sabbesam vuḍḍhatamaḥ guṇehi mahallakatamaḥ ti vuttam hoti seṭṭhaḥ ti
translated: The chief: the most senior by way of his special qualities; the most venerable by way of his special qualities. The best:

original: guṇavaseneva sabbesaṃ pasatthatamo. Atthato pana pacchimāni dve purimasseva vevacanānīti🔽veditabbaṃ. Tayāti nissakke karaṇavacanaṃ. Uttaritaroti adhikataro. Patimānesīti
analyzed: guṇa vasena iva sabbesam pasatthatamaḥ atthataḥ pana pacchimāni dve purimassa iva vevacanāni iti  veditabbam tayā iti nissakke karaṇa vacanam uttaritaraḥ iti adhikataraḥ patim ānesi iti
translated: the most highly regarded by way of his special qualities. But in meaning the last two terms are mere synonyms for the first.

original: pūjesi. Āsabhinti uttamaṃ. Mayhaṃ abhivādanādiraho puggaloti mayhaṃ abhivādanādikiriyāya
analyzed: pūjesi uttamam mayham abhivādana ādi raho puggalo ti mayham abhivādana ādi kiriyāya
translated: The three: the instrumental case in the singular number. The highest: the most excellent. He worshipped: he paid homage. The most: the best. A person worthy of being worshipped by me: a person worthy of being paid homage by me.

original: araho anucchaviko puggalo. Niccasāpekkhatāya panettha samāso daṭṭhabbo. Tathāgatāti
analyzed: arahaḥ anucchavikaḥ puggalo nicca sāpekkha tāya pana ittha samāsaḥ daṭṭhabbo tathāgata ati
translated: and the person who is worthy and fit. But here the compound is to be regarded as a genitive dependent, as in “The Teacher’s doctrine” .🔽Thus-gone:🔽thus-gone from the Enlightened One, thus-gone to the Enlightened One, is what is meant. Such:

original: tathāgatato, tathāgatassa santikāti vuttaṃ hoti. Evarūpanti abhivādanādisabhāvaṃ.
analyzed: tathāgatataḥ tathāgatassa santikā iti vuttam hoti evarūpam ti abhivādana ādi sabhāvam
translated: of the nature of paying homage, etc.

original: Paripākasithilabandhananti paripākena sithilabandhanaṃ.🔽3. Taṃ vacananti “nāhaṃ taṃ brāhmaṇā”tiādivacanaṃ. “Nāhaṃ arasarūpo, mādisā vā arasarūpā”ti
analyzed: paripāka sithila bandhanam ti paripākena sithila bandhanam  tam na aham tam brāhmaṇa ati ādi vacanam na aham a rasa rūpaḥ mā adisā vai a rasa rūpā iti
translated: Whose bonds are slackened by ripening: whose bonds are slackened by ripening.🔽That speech: the speech beginning, “Brahmin, I am not one who is without heart” .

original: vutte brāhmaṇo thaddho bhaveyya. Tena vuttaṃ “cittamudubhāvajananattha”nti. Ayañhi
analyzed: vutte brāhmaṇaḥ thaddhaḥ bhaveyya tena vuttam citta mudu bhāva janana attham ti ayan hi
translated: If the brahmin were told, “I am not one without heart, nor are those like me,” he would become obstinate. That is why it is said “in order to soften his mind.”

original: pariyāyasaddo desanāvārakāraṇesu vattatīti ettha pariyāyeti desetabbamatthaṃ avagameti
analyzed: pariyāya saddaḥ desanā vāra kāraṇesu vattati iti ettha pariyāya iti desetabbam attham avagame iti
translated: For this word pariyāya is used in the sense of a reason for a method of teaching. Herein, it is the meaning to be taught that is “gone around” , thus it is a pariyāya ;

original: bodhetīti pariyāyo, desanā. Pariyāyati aparāparaṃ parivattetīti pariyāyo, vāro. Pariyāyati🔽attano phalaṃ pariggahetvā vattati, tassa vā kāraṇabhāvaṃ gacchatīti pariyāyo, kāraṇanti
analyzed: bodhā iti iti pariyāyaḥ desanā pariyāyati apara aparam parivattā iti iti pariyāyaḥ vāro pariyāyati 🔽attanaḥ phalam pariggahetvā vattati tassa vā kāraṇa bhāvam gacchati iti pariyāyaḥ kāraṇam ti
translated: it is a teaching. It is a turn , thus it is a pariyāya; it is a turn. It is a reason , thus it is a pariyāya; it is a reason.

original: evaṃ pariyāyasaddassa desanāvārakāraṇesu pavatti veditabbā. Aññāya saṇṭhaheyyāti
analyzed: evam pariyāya saddassa desanā vāra kāraṇesu pavatti veditabbā aññāya saṇṭhaheyya ati
translated: This is how the word “mode” should be understood to occur in the sense of a reason for teaching. He would settle down in the knowledge:

original: arahatte patiṭṭhaheyya. Katamo pana soti pariyāyāpekkho pulliṅganiddeso, katamo so
analyzed: arahatte patiṭṭhaheyya katamaḥ pana so ti pariyāya apekkho pulliṅga niddeso katamaḥ so
translated: he would be established in Arahantship. But what is that? What is the neuter noun “mode”?

original: pariyāyoti attho. Jātivasenāti khattiyādijātivasena. Upapattivasenāti devesu upapattivasena.🔽Seṭṭhasammatānampīti api-saddena pageva aseṭṭhasammatānanti dasseti. Abhinandantānanti🔽sappītikataṇhāvasena pamodamānānaṃ. Rajjantānanti balavarāgavasena rajjantānaṃ. Rūpādiparibhogena🔽uppannataṇhāyuttasomanassavedanā rūpato nibbattitvā hadayatappanato ambarasādayo
analyzed: pariyāyaḥ ti atthaḥ jāti vasena ati khattiya ādi jāti vasena upapatti vasena ati devesu upapatti vasena  seṭṭha sammatānam pi iti api saddena pagā iva aseṭṭha sammatānam ti dasseti abhinandantānam ti  sappītika taṇhā vasena pamodamānānam balava rāga vasena rajjantānam rūpa ādi paribhogena  uppanna taṇhā yutta somanassa vedanāḥ rūpataḥ nibbattitvā hadaya tappanataḥ ambarasa ādayaḥ
translated: What is the meaning of “mode”? As to kind: as to the kind called “noble warrior,” and so on. As to rebirth: as to rebirth among the gods.🔽As to those who are esteemed: the word “even” shows that it is so as to those who are not esteemed. As to those who are infatuated: as to those who are delighted by craving accompanied by happiness. As to those who are greedy: as to those who are greedy by reason of strong lust. The “flavour of form,” etc., are so called because the feelings of pleasure consisting in the happiness of the happiness and gladness that arise through the enjoyment of form, etc., are born of form, etc., and because they moisten the heart-basis, like the flavours of honey, molasses, etc.

original: viya “rūparasā”ti vuccanti. Āviñchantīti ākaḍḍhanti. Vatthārammaṇādisāmaggiyanti
analyzed: rūpa rasā ti vuccanti āviñchanti iti ākaḍḍhanti
translated: They “draw” : they attract. As to the concurrence of the conditions consisting in the object, etc.: as to the concurrence of the conditions consisting in the object, the sense-organ, light, attention, etc.

original: vatthuārammaṇādikāraṇasāmaggiyaṃ. Anukkhipantoti attukkaṃsanavasena kathite brāhmaṇassa
analyzed: vatthu ārammaṇa ādi kāraṇa sāmaggiyam an ukkhipanto ti atta ukkaṃsana vasena kathite brāhmaṇassa
translated: As to the one who extols: as to the brahmin who extols himself in the way beginning, “Brahmins are the highest caste” ,

original: asappāyabhāvato attānaṃ anukkhipanto anukkaṃsento.🔽Etasmiṃ panatthe karaṇe sāmivacananti “jahitā”ti etasmiṃ atthe. Tathāgatassāti karaṇe
analyzed: a sappāya bhāvataḥ attānam anukkhipantaḥ anukkaṃsentaḥ  etasmin pana atthe karaṇe sāmi vacananti jahitā ati etasmin atthe tathāgatassa ati karaṇe
translated: He does not extol himself and does not disparage others.🔽In this sense, the word “abandoned” is a locative case.🔽In the same way, the word “by the Tathāgata” is a locative case. The meaning is: abandoned by the Tathāgata.

original: sāmivacanaṃ, tathāgatena jahitāti attho. Mūlanti bhavamūlaṃ. “Tālavatthuvatthukatā”ti
analyzed: sāmi vacanam tathāgatena jahitā ati attho mūlanti bhava mūlam tāla vatthu vatthuka tā ati
translated: The word “root” means the root of existence.🔽In the passage “having the trunk of a palm-tree as their basis,”

original: vattabbe “oṭṭhamukho”tiādīsu viya majjhepadalopaṃ katvā akārañca dīghaṃ katvā “tālāvatthukatā”ti
analyzed: vattabbe oṭṭha mukhā ti ādīsu viya majjhe pada lopam katvā akāram ca dīgham katvā tālā vatthuka tā ti
translated: the middle part of the compound is elided, and the vowel a is lengthened, just as in the words “oṭṭhamukha” , etc.🔽The meaning is: “having the trunk of a palm-tree as their basis.”

original: vuttanti āha “tālavatthu viya nesaṃ vatthu katanti tālāvatthukatā”ti. Tattha tālassa🔽vatthu tālavatthu. Yathā ārāmassa vatthubhūtapubbo padeso ārāmassa abhāve “ārāmavatthū”ti
analyzed: vuttanti āha tāla vatthu viya nesam vatthu katanti tattha tālassa  vatthu tāla vatthu yathā ārāmassa vatthu bhūta pubbaḥ padesaḥ ārāmassa abhāve ārāma vatthu uti
translated: Herein, the trunk of a palm-tree is the trunk of a palm.🔽Just as a place that was formerly the site of a monastery is called “the site of the monastery” even after the monastery has been destroyed,

original: vuccati, evaṃ tālassa patiṭṭhitokāso samūlaṃ uddharite tāle padesamatte ṭhite tālassa
analyzed: vuccati evam tālassa patiṭṭhita ukāsaḥ sa mūlam uddharite tāle padesa matte ṭhite tālassa
translated: so too, the place where a palm-tree stood is called “the trunk of a palm-tree” even after the palm-tree has been uprooted and only the stump remains, because it was formerly the trunk of a palm-tree.

original: vatthubhūtapubbattā “tālavatthū”ti vuccati. Nesanti rūparasādīnaṃ. Kathaṃ pana tālavatthu
analyzed: vatthu bhūta pubbattā tāla vatthu iti vuccati na isanti rūpa rasa ādīnam katham pana tāla vatthu
translated: The word “their” refers to the things such as form, etc.

original: viya nesaṃ vatthu katanti āha “yathā hī”tiādi. Rūpādiparibhogena uppannataṇhāyuttasomanassavedanāsaṅkhātarūparasādīnaṃ
analyzed: viya nesam vatthu katanti āha yathā hi itiādi rūpa ādi paribhogena uppanna taṇhā yutta somanassa vedanā saṅkhāta rūpa rasa ādīnam
translated: He says “For just as … ” and so on. The craving that arises through the enjoyment of visible forms, etc., and the visible forms, tastes, etc., that are classed as pleasant feeling, pleasant mental reaction, and so on,🔽are called “made into the object” because they are the basis for the continuity of consciousness.

original: cittasantānassa adhiṭṭhānabhāvato vuttaṃ “tesaṃ pubbe uppannapubbabhāvena vatthumatte🔽cittasantāne kate”ti. Tattha pubbeti pure, sarāgakāleti vuttaṃ hoti. Tālāvatthukatāti
analyzed: citta santānassa adhiṭṭhāna bhāvataḥ vuttam tesam pubbe uppanna pubba bhāvena vatthumatte  citta santāne katā iti tattha pubba iti pure sa rāga kāle iti vuttam hoti tālā vatthuka tā ati
translated: Herein, “before” means previously, with lust.🔽They are called “made into the object of the palm-spirit”

original: vuccantīti tālavatthu viya attano vatthussa katattā rūparasādayo “tālāvatthukatā”ti
analyzed: vuccanti iti tāla vatthu viya attanaḥ vatthussa kata ttā rūpa rasa ādayaḥ tālāvatthuka tā ati
translated: because they have made their own object into the object of the palm-spirit, as it were.

original: vuccanti. Etena pahīnakilesānaṃ puna uppattiyā abhāvo dassito.
analyzed: vuccanti etena pahīna kilesānam puna uppattiyāḥ abhāvaḥ dassito
translated: By this he shows that there is no reappearance of the defilements in one who has abandoned them.🔽“Because of the non-arisenness of the state” means because of the non-arisenness of the nature.

original: Aviruḷhidhammattāti aviruḷhisabhāvatāya. Matthakacchinno tālo pattaphalādīnaṃ avatthubhūto🔽tālāvatthūti āha “matthakacchinnatālo viya katā”ti. Etena “tālāvatthu viya katāti
analyzed: a viruḷhi dhamma ttā ati a viruḷhi sabhāva tāya matthaka chinno tālo patta phala ādīnam a vatthu bhūto  tālāvatthu iti āha matthaka chinna tālaḥ viya katā ati etena tālāvatthu viya katā ati
translated: The palm-tree that has been cut down is no longer a basis for leaves, flowers, fruits, and so on.🔽He says “made like a palm-tree cut down at the crown” .

original: tālāvatthukatā”ti ayaṃ viggaho dassito. Ettha pana avatthubhūto tālo viya katāti
analyzed: tāla avatthukatā iti ayam viggahaḥ dassitaḥ ettha pana avatthu bhūtaḥ tālaḥ viya katā ati
translated: By this he shows the analysis “They are made into the object of the palm-spirit because they have made their own object into the object of the palm-spirit, as it were.”🔽Herein, “made like a palm-tree that has been cut down” means made like a palm-tree that is no longer a basis for leaves, flowers, fruits, and so on.

original: avatthutālākatāti vattabbe visesanassa padassa paranipātaṃ katvā “tālāvatthukatā”ti
analyzed: avatthu tālākatā ati vattabbe visesanassa padassa para nipātam katvā tālā avatthukatā ati
translated: “The state of having a base that is like a palm-tree stump” should be understood as a compound in which the word “state” is omitted and the word “base” is made the last member.

original: vuttanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Iminā panatthena idaṃ dasseti – rūparasādivacanena vipākadhammadhammā🔽hutvā pubbe uppannā kusalākusaladhammā gahitā, te uppannāpi matthakasadisānaṃ taṇhāvijjānaṃ
analyzed: vuttanti daṭṭhabbam iminā pana atthena idam dasseti rūpa rasa ādi vacanena vipāka dhamma dhammā  hutvā pubbe uppannā kusala akusala dhammā gahitā te uppannā api matthaka sadisānam taṇhā vijjānam
translated: By this meaning he shows that the words “form, feeling, etc.” include profitable and unprofitable states that have already arisen and have the nature of results,🔽which are like the top of the head of craving and ignorance.🔽They have become incapable of producing the resultant aggregates in the future, which are like palm-tree leaves,

original: maggasatthena chinnattā āyatiṃ tālapattasadise vipākakkhandhe nibbattetuṃ asamatthā🔽jātā, tasmā tālāvatthu viya katāti tālāvatthukatā rūparasādayoti. Imasmiñhi atthe
analyzed: magga satthena chinna ttā āyatim tāla patta sadise vipāka kkhandhe nibbattetum asamatthā  jātā tasmā tālāvatthu viya katā ati tālāvatthu katā rūpa rasa ādayaḥ imasmin hi atthe
translated: because they have been cut off by the sword of the path.🔽Therefore they are called “the state of having a base that is like a palm-tree stump,” since they are like a palm-tree stump.

original: “abhinandantāna”nti iminā padena kusalasomanassampi saṅgahitanti vadanti.
analyzed: iminā padena kusala somanassam pi saṅgahitanti vadanti
translated: For this is the meaning: “form, feeling, etc.” include profitable joy too, according to the words “rejoicing in them” .

original: Anabhāvaṃkatāti ettha anu-saddo pacchā-saddena samānatthoti āha “yathā nesaṃ pacchābhāvo
analyzed: anabhāvaṃkatā iti ettha anusaddo pacchā saddena samānattho ti āha yathā nesam pacchābhāvo
translated: “The state of having no future” : the prefix anu- has the same meaning as the prefix paṭi- . That is why he said “as if they had no future” .

original: na hotī”tiādi. Anuabhāvaṃ gatāti pacchā anuppattidhammatāvasena abhāvaṃ gatā vināsamupagatā,
analyzed: na hoti itiādi anu abhāvam gatā ati pacchā anuppatti dhamma tā vasena abhāvam gatā vināsam upagatā
translated: They have gone to non-existence, have reached destruction, in the sense of having no future arising.

original: pahīnāti attho. “Imā anacchariyā gāthāyo paṭibhaṃsū”ti ettha anacchariyasaddaṃ udāharaṇavasena
analyzed: pahīnā ati ettha anacchariya saddam udāharaṇa vasena
translated: the meaning is, “abandoned.”🔽In the passage, “These verses not marvelous,”🔽showing the word “not marvelous” by way of an example, he said, “As in the case of anuacchariya and anacchariya.”

original: dassento āha “yathā anuacchariyā anacchariyā”ti. Tattha anuacchariyāti savanakāle
analyzed: dassentaḥ āha yathā anuacchariyā anacchariyā ati tattha anuacchariyā ati savana kāle
translated: Herein, anuacchariya means that which causes wonder

original: uparūpari vimhayakarāti attho.
analyzed: upari upari attho
translated: more and more at the time of hearing.🔽And the meaning is, “That reason which you state is not a reason.”

original: Yañca kho tvaṃ vadesi, so pariyāyo na hotīti yaṃ vandanādisāmaggirasābhāvasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: yat ca kho tvam vadesi saḥ pariyāyaḥ na hoti iti yam
translated: The meaning is, “That reason which you state, namely, that the Blessed One is without the taste of the concordance of worship, etc.,🔽is not a reason, does not exist, is not found.”

original: kāraṇaṃ arasarūpatāya vadesi, taṃ kāraṇaṃ na hoti, na vijjatīti attho. Nanu ca brāhmaṇo
analyzed: kāraṇam a rasa rūpatāya vadesi tam kāraṇam na hoti na vijjati iti atthaḥ nanu ca brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: But did not the brahmin say, “Master Gotama is without the taste of the concordance of worship, etc.,”

original: yaṃ vandanādisāmaggirasābhāvasaṅkhātaṃ pariyāyaṃ sandhāya “arasarūpo bhavaṃ gotamo”ti🔽āha, so pariyāyo natthīti vutte vandanādīni bhagavā karotīti āpajjatīti imaṃ aniṭṭhappasaṅgaṃ
analyzed: yam vandanā ādi sāmaggi rasa abhāva saṅkhātam pariyāyam sandhāya a rasa rūpaḥ bhavam gotama uti  āha so pariyāyaḥ natthi iti vutte vandana ādīni bhagavā karoti iti āpajjati iti imam aniṭṭha ppasaṅgam
translated: referring to the reason consisting in the absence of the taste of the concordance of worship, etc.?🔽When it is said that that reason does not exist, does it not follow that the Blessed One performs worship, etc.?

original: dassento āha “kasmā pana bhagavā evamāhā”tiādi.
analyzed: dassentaḥ āha kasmai pana bhagavā evam āha atiādi
translated: Showing this undesirable conclusion, he said, “Why did the Blessed One say this?”🔽In all the instances

original: 4. Sabbapariyāyesūti sabbavāresu. Sandhāya bhāsitamattanti yaṃ sandhāya brāhmaṇo
analyzed: sabba pariyāyesu iti sabba vāresu sandhāya yam sandhāya brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: . Referring to something

original: “nibbhogo bhavaṃ gotamo”tiādimāha, bhagavā ca yaṃ sandhāya nibbhogatādiṃ attani anujānāti,
analyzed: nibbhogaḥ bhavam gotama uti ādim āha bhagavā ca yam sandhāya nibbhoga tā ādim anujānāti
translated: “You are free from passion, Master Gotama,”🔽and the Exalted One assents to the description of himself as free from passion, etc.,

original: taṃ sandhāya bhāsitamattaṃ. Chandarāgaparibhogoti chandarāgavasena paribhogo. Aparaṃ🔽pariyāyanti aññaṃ kāraṇaṃ.
analyzed: tam sandhāya bhāsita mattam chanda rāga paribhogaḥ iti chanda rāga vasena paribhogaḥ aparam  pariyāyanti aññam kāraṇam
translated: “You are free from passion, Master Gotama,” and so on. And the Blessed One’s reply is only a statement of fact, namely, what he himself admits. “By the enjoyment of desire and lust”: by the enjoyment of desire and lust. “Another way”: another reason.

original: 5. Kulasamudācārakammanti kulācārasaṅkhātaṃ kammaṃ, kulacārittanti vuttaṃ hoti. Akiriyanti🔽akaraṇabhāvaṃ. Duṭṭhu caritaṃ duccaritaṃ, kāyadvāre bāhullavuttito kāyato pavattaṃ
analyzed: kula samudācāra kammanti kula ācāra saṅkhātam kammam kula cārittanti vuttam hoti a kiriyanti  akaraṇa bhāvam duṭṭhu caritam duccaritam kāya dvāre bāhulla vuttitaḥ kāyataḥ pavattam
translated: “The practice of families”: the practice called “of families,” i.e., the conduct of families. “Non-doing”:🔽the state of non-doing. “Bad conduct”: conduct that is bad. “Bodily misconduct”: misconduct that occurs through the body, because it is frequently manifested through the body.

original: duccaritanti kāyaduccaritaṃ. Taṃ sarūpato dassento “tattha cā”tiādimāha. Pāṇātipātaadinnādānamicchācāracetanā
analyzed: duccaritanti kāya duccaritam tam sarūpataḥ dassentaḥ tattha ca ati ādim āha pāṇa atipāta a dinna ādānam icchā ācāra cetanā
translated: In order to show its nature, he said, “Herein, the intention to kill living beings, to take what is not given, and to engage in sexual misconduct should be understood as bodily misconduct.”

original: veditabbāti ettha pāṇoti paramatthato jīvitindriyaṃ, vohārato satto. Jīvitindriyañcettha
analyzed: veditabbā ti ettha pāṇo ti paramatthataḥ jīvitindriyam vohārato satto jīvitindriyam ca ittha
translated: Herein, “living beings” are, in the ultimate sense, the life faculty; in the conventional sense, a being. The life faculty should be understood

original: rūpārūpavasena veditabbaṃ. Rūpajīvitindriye hi vikopite itarampi taṃsambandhatāya
analyzed: rūpa arūpa vasena veditabbam rūpa jīvita indriye hi vikopite itaram pi tad sambandha tāya
translated: as material and immaterial. For when the material life faculty is disturbed, the immaterial one is also disturbed, because of its connection with the former.

original: vinassati. Sattoti ca khandhasantāno gahetabbo. Tattha hi sattapaññatti. Saraseneva🔽patanasabhāvassa antarā eva atīva pātanaṃ atipāto, saṇikaṃ patituṃ adatvā sīghaṃ🔽pātananti attho. Atikkamma vā satthādīhi abhibhavitvā pātanaṃ atipāto, pāṇassa atipāto
analyzed: vinassati satto ti ca khandha santānaḥ gahetabbo tattha hi satta paññatti sa rasena iva  patana sabhāvassa antarā eva atīva pātanam atipāto saṇikam patitum a datvā sīgham  pātanam ti atthaḥ atikkamma vā sattha ādīhi abhibhavitvā pātanam atipātaḥ pāṇassa atipātaḥ
translated: “Will be destroyed” : the continuity of aggregates should be taken as the being. For the designation of being is there.🔽“Falling down” : the state of falling down. “Falling down excessively” is excessive falling down, falling down very quickly, without falling down slowly. The meaning is: falling down quickly.

original: pāṇātipāto, pāṇavadho pāṇaghātoti vuttaṃ hoti. Atthato pana pāṇe pāṇasaññino parassa
analyzed: pāṇa atipātaḥ pāṇa vadhaḥ pāṇa ghāto ti vuttam hoti atthato pana pāṇe pāṇa saññinaḥ parassa
translated: Or else, “falling down excessively” is falling down after overcoming a sword, etc., and “excessive falling down of a living being” is “killing a living being.” “Killing a living being,” “slaying,” and “murder” are said.

original: jīvitindriyupacchedakapayogasamuṭṭhāpikā kāyavacīdvārānamaññatarappavattā vadhakacetanā.🔽Yāya hi cetanāya vattamānassa jīvitindriyassa nissayabhūtesu mahābhūtesu upakkamakaraṇahetukamahābhūtapaccayā
analyzed: jīvita indriya upacchedaka payoga samuṭṭhāpikā kāya vacī dvāra ānama aññatara ppavattā vadhaka cetanā  yāya hi cetanāya vattamānassa jīvitindriyassa nissaya bhūtesu mahābhūtesu upakkama karaṇa hetuka mahābhūta paccayā
translated: But in meaning it is the volition to kill that occurs in one of the two doors, the bodily or the verbal door, and that originates the action that cuts off another’s life faculty when there is a living being and the perception of a living being.

original: uppajjanakamahābhūtā nuppajjissanti, sā tādisappayogasamuṭṭhāpikā cetanā pāṇātipāto.
analyzed: uppajjanaka mahābhūtāḥ na uppajjissanti sā tādisa payoga samuṭṭhāpikā cetanā pāṇātipātaḥ
translated: For by whatever volition the great primaries that are the support of the life faculty occurring in a living being do not arise because of the harm done to them, the great primaries that would arise with the great primaries as condition, that volition is the killing of a living being, the volition that originates such an action.

original: Laddhupakkamāni hi bhūtāni itarabhūtāni viya na visadānīti samānajātiyānaṃ kāraṇāni na honti.🔽Etthāha – khaṇe khaṇe nirujjhanasabhāvesu saṅkhāresu ko hantā, ko vā haññati, yadi
analyzed: laddhu pakkamāni hi bhūtāni itara bhūtāni na visadāni iti samāna jāti yānam kāraṇāni na honti  ettha āha khaṇe khaṇe nirujjhana sabhāvesu saṅkhāresu kaḥ hantā kaḥ vā haññati yadi
translated: For the kinds of beings that are not to be killed do not become clear by the killing of other kinds of beings.

original: cittacetasikasantāno, so arūpatāya na chedanabhedanādivasena vikopanasamattho, napi🔽vikopanīyo. Atha rūpasantāno, so acetanatāya kaṭṭhakaliṅgarūpamoti na tattha chedanādinā
analyzed: citta cetasika santāno saḥ arūpa tāya na chedana bhedana ādi vasena vikopana samatthaḥ  vikopanīyaḥ atha rūpa santāno so acetana tāya na tattha chedana ādinā
translated: Here it may be asked: Who is the killer and who is the killed in the case of formations that are by nature to cease from one moment to the next? If it is a continuity of consciousnesses and its concomitants, that cannot be disturbed by cutting, breaking, etc., because it is immaterial,

original: pāṇātipāto labbhati yathā matasarīre. Payogopi pāṇātipātassa paharaṇappahārādi atītesu🔽vā saṅkhāresu bhaveyya anāgatesu vā paccuppannesu vā, tattha na tāva atītānāgatesu
analyzed: pāṇātipātaḥ labbhati yathā mata sarīre payogaḥ api pāṇātipātassa paharaṇa pahāra ādi atītesu  vā saṅkhāresu bhaveyya anāgatesu vā paccuppannesu vā tattha na tāva atīta anāgatesu
translated: nor can it be disturbed by anything else. If it is a continuity of materiality, that is inanimate, like wood and stone, so killing is not possible there, as in the case of one’s own body.🔽And the act of killing, as a means to killing, would be in past formations, or in future ones, or in present ones. Herein, it cannot be in past or future formations,

original: sambhavati tesaṃ abhāvato, paccuppannesu ca saṅkhārānaṃ khaṇikattā saraseneva nirujjhanasabhāvatāya
analyzed: sambhavati tesam abhāvato paccuppannesu ca saṅkhārānam khaṇika ttā sarasena iva nirujjhana sabhāva tāya
translated: because they do not exist. And it cannot be in present formations, because they cease immediately they are born.

original: vināsābhimukhesu nippayojano payogo siyā, vināsassa ca kāraṇarahitattā na paharaṇappahārādippayogahetukaṃ🔽maraṇaṃ, nirīhakatāya ca saṅkhārānaṃ kassa so payogo, khaṇikattā vadhādhippāyasamakālabhijjanato
analyzed: vināsa abhimukhesu nippayojanaḥ payogaḥ siyā vināsassa ca kāraṇa rahita ttā na paharaṇa ppahāra ādi ppayoga hetukam  maraṇam nirīhaka tāya ca saṅkhārānam kassa so payogaḥ khaṇika ttā vadha adhippāya sama kāla bhijjanato
translated: The application of the effort would be purposeless in the case of those facing destruction, and death is not caused by the application of the effort of striking, etc., because the cause of destruction is absent.🔽And since formations are inert, whose is that application of effort? And whose is the action, since the one who is to kill and the one who is killed are both born and perish at every moment?

original: kassa kiriyā, pariyosānakālānavaṭṭhānato kassa vā pāṇātipātakammabaddhoti?
analyzed: kassa kiriyā pariyosāna kāla an avaṭṭhānato kassa vā pāṇātipāta kamma baddho ti
translated: And whose is the bondage of the action of killing, since it does not endure at the time of the completion of the action?

original: Vuccate – yathāvuttavadhakacetanāsahito saṅkhārānaṃ puñjo sattasaṅkhāto hantā. Tena🔽pavattitavadhappayoganimittaṃ apagatusmāviññāṇajīvitindriyo matavohārappavattinibandhano
analyzed: vuccate yathā vutta vadhaka cetanā sahito saṅkhārānam puñjaḥ satta saṅkhāto hantā tena  pavattita vadha ppayoga nimittam mata vohāra ppavatti nibandhanaḥ
translated: It may be said in reply: the “killer” is the mass of formations called a living being, accompanied by the volition to kill as described.🔽The “killed” is the collection of material and immaterial dhammas that is fit to arise at the moment of the application of the effort to kill, which is the cause of the application of the effort to kill, and which is the condition for the occurrence of the expression “dead” when the life faculty, consciousness, and heat have departed.

original: yathāvuttavadhappayogakaraṇe uppajjanāraho rūpārūpadhammasamūho haññati, kevalo vā
analyzed: yathā vutta vadha ppayoga karaṇe uppajjana arahaḥ rūpa arūpa dhamma samūhaḥ haññati kevalaḥ vā
translated: Or it is the mere continuum of consciousness and consciousness-concomitants.

original: cittacetasikasantāno. Vadhappayogāvisayabhāvepi tassa pañcavokārabhave rūpasantānādhīnavuttitāya
analyzed: citta cetasika santānaḥ vadha payoga a visaya bhāve pi tassa pañcavokāra bhave rūpa santāna adhīna vutti tāya
translated: Even though it is not the object of the application of the effort to kill, still, in the case of one who is reborn in the five-constituent becoming, the occurrence of the material continuum is dependent on the mental continuum.

original: rūpasantāne parena payojitajīvitindriyupacchedakapayogavasena tannibbattivinibandhakavisadisarūpuppattiyā
analyzed: rūpa santāne parena payojita jīvitindriya upacchedaka payoga vasena tad nibbatti vinibandhaka visadisa rūpa uppattiyā
translated: The destruction of the continuity of the aggregates is called “death” because the continuity of the aggregates is destroyed by the cessation of the life faculty, which is brought about by the application of a knife or a stick by another person to the continuity of material form.

original: vihate vicchedo hotīti na pāṇātipātassa asambhavo, napi ahetuko pāṇātipāto, na ca🔽payogo nippayojano. Paccuppannesu saṅkhāresu katapayogavasena tadanantaraṃ uppajjanārahassa
analyzed: vihate vicchedaḥ hoti iti na pāṇātipātassa asambhavaḥ ahetuko pāṇātipātaḥ na ca  payogaḥ nippayojanaḥ paccuppannesu saṅkhāresu kata payoga vasena tad anantaram uppajjanā rahassa
translated: Therefore, killing is not impossible. Nor is killing without a cause,

original: saṅkhārakalāpassa tathā anuppattito khaṇikānaṃ saṅkhārānaṃ khaṇikamaraṇassa idha🔽maraṇabhāvena anadhippetattā santatimaraṇassa ca yathāvuttanayena sahetukabhāvato🔽na ahetukaṃ maraṇaṃ, na ca katturahito pāṇātipātapayogo nirīhakesupi saṅkhāresu sannihitatāmattena
analyzed: saṅkhāra kalāpassa tathā anuppattitaḥ khaṇikānam saṅkhārānam khaṇika maraṇassa idha  maraṇa bhāvena anadhippeta ttā santati maraṇassa ca yathā vutta nayena sa hetuka bhāvato  na ahetukam maraṇam na ca pāṇa atipāta payogaḥ nirīhakesu pi saṅkhāresu sannihita tā mattena
translated: nor is the application of the knife or the stick useless. The non-arising of the aggregate of aggregates that is due to arise next, by the application of the knife or the stick to the present aggregates,🔽is called “death” here. The momentariness of momentary aggregates is not intended by the term “death.”

original: upakārakesu attano attano anurūpaphaluppādaniyatesu kāraṇesu kattuvohārasiddhito
analyzed: upakārakesu attanaḥ attanaḥ anurūpa phala uppāda niyatesu kāraṇesu kattu vohāra siddhitaḥ
translated: Death is not without a cause, because death through a continuity is caused by the method stated. Nor is the application of killing without an agent, because the function of the cause is established in the aggregates, which are inactive but are present and are capable of producing their own appropriate effects.

original: yathā “padīpo pakāseti, nisākarova candimā”ti. Na ca kevalassa vadhādhippāyasahabhuno
analyzed: yathā padīpaḥ pakāseti na ca kevalassa vadha adhippāya sahabhuno
translated: As in the passage, “The lamp illuminates itself,” and “The moon shines by its own radiance.”

original: cittacetasikakalāpassa pāṇātipāto icchitabbo santānavasena avaṭṭhitasseva paṭijānanato.🔽Santānavasena vattamānānañca padīpādīnaṃ atthakiriyā dissatīti attheva pāṇātipātena
analyzed: citta cetasika kalāpassa pāṇātipātaḥ icchitabbaḥ santāna vasena avaṭṭhitassa iva paṭijānanato  santāna vasena vattamānānam ca padīpa ādīnam attha kiriyā dissati iti atthā iva pāṇa atipātena
translated: And it should not be held that the mere aggregate of consciousness and mental factors that is conascent with the intention to kill is the killing of a living being, because it is admitted that the intention to kill does not persist as a continuum.🔽And the action of lamps, etc., which occur as a continuum is seen to be effective. Therefore, killing a living being is bound up with kamma.

original: kammabaddho. Ayañca vicāro adinnādānādīsupi yathāsambhavaṃ vibhāvetabbo.
analyzed: kamma baddhaḥ ayam ca vicāraḥ adinnādāna ādīsu pi yathāsambhavam vibhāvetabbaḥ
translated: And this discussion should be extended to taking what is not given, etc., as appropriate.

original: So ca pāṇātipāto guṇavirahitesu tiracchānagatādīsu pāṇesu khuddake pāṇe appasāvajjo,
analyzed: so ca pāṇa atipātaḥ guṇa virahitesu tiracchāna gata ādīsu pāṇesu khuddake pāṇe appasāvajjo
translated: And this killing of a living being is less blameworthy when the living being is a small animal such as an insect, etc., which have no special qualities;

original: mahante mahāsāvajjo. Kasmā? Payogamahantatāya, payogasamattepi vatthumahantatāya.
analyzed: mahante kasmai payoga mahantatāya vatthu mahantatāya
translated: it is more blameworthy when the living being is a large animal. Why? Because of the greater magnitude of the effort. Even when the effort is equal, it is more blameworthy when the object is greater.

original: Guṇavantesu manussādīsu appaguṇe pāṇe appasāvajjo, mahāguṇe mahāsāvajjo. Sarīraguṇānaṃ
analyzed: guṇavantesu manussa ādīsu appaguṇe pāṇe appa sāvajjaḥ mahā guṇe mahā sāvajjaḥ sarīra guṇānaṃ
translated: It is less blameworthy when the living being has few special qualities, such as a human being, etc.; it is more blameworthy when the living being has great special qualities.

original: pana samabhāve satipi kilesānaṃ upakkamānañca mudutāya appasāvajjo, tibbatāya mahāsāvajjoti veditabbo.
analyzed: pana sama bhāve sati pi kilesānam upakkamānam ca mudu tāya appasāvajjo tibba tāya mahā sāvajjaḥ ti veditabbo
translated: Even when the special qualities of the body are equal, it should be understood that it is less blameworthy when the defilements and the approach are mild, and more blameworthy when they are strong.

original: Kāyavācāhi na dinnanti adinnaṃ, parasantakaṃ, tassa ādānaṃ adinnādānaṃ. Parassaharaṇaṃ🔽theyyaṃ, corikāti vuttaṃ hoti. Atthato pana parapariggahe parapariggahitasaññino
analyzed: na dinnanti adinnam para santakam tassa ādānam adinna ādānam parassa haraṇam  theyyam corikā iti vuttam hoti atthataḥ pana para pariggahe para pariggahita saññinaḥ
translated: Not given by way of body and speech: not given, not presented by another, taking it by theft is taking what is not given. Taking what is not given is theft.

original: tadādāyakaupakkamasamuṭṭhāpikā kāyavacīdvārānamaññataradvārappavattā theyyacetanā.
analyzed: tad ādāyaka aupakkama samuṭṭhāpikā kāya vacī dvāra ānama aññatara dvāra ppavattā theyya cetanā
translated: It is said. In fact, taking what is not given is the intention to steal, which arises from the act of taking what belongs to another, and which occurs by way of one of the doors of body or speech, in one who perceives what belongs to another as such.

original: Taṃ hīne parasantake appasāvajjaṃ, paṇīte mahāsāvajjaṃ. Kasmā? Vatthupaṇītatāya.🔽Vatthusamatte sati guṇādhikānaṃ santake vatthusmiṃ mahāsāvajjaṃ, taṃtaṃguṇādhikaṃ
analyzed: tam hīne para santake appa sāvajjam paṇīte mahā sāvajjam kasmā vatthu paṇīta tāya  vatthu samatte sati guṇa adhikānam santake vatthusmin mahā sāvajjam taṃ taṃ guṇa adhikam
translated: That is, taking what is not given is less blameworthy when it is of little value and belongs to another, and more blameworthy when it is of great value and belongs to another. Why is that? Because of the value of the object.

original: upādāya tato tato hīnaguṇassa santake vatthusmiṃ appasāvajjaṃ.
analyzed: upādāya tatas tatas hīna guṇassa santake vatthusmim appasāvajjam
translated: When the value of the object is the same, taking what belongs to one who has greater special qualities is more blameworthy, and taking what belongs to one who has fewer special qualities is less blameworthy.

original: Micchā caraṇaṃ micchācāro, methunasamācāresu ekantanindito lāmakācāro. So pana lakkhaṇato
analyzed: micchā caraṇam micchā ācāro methuna samācāresu ekanta ninditaḥ lāmaka ācāro so pana lakkhaṇato
translated: Sexual misconduct is the wrong practice, the contemptible practice, in regard to sexual intercourse. But in its individual essence,

original: asaddhammādhippāyena kāyadvārappavattā agamanīyaṭṭhānavītikkamacetanā. So panesa
analyzed: asat dhamma adhippāyena kāya dvāra ppavattā agamanīya ṭṭhāna vītikkama cetanā so pana isa
translated: it is the intention to transgress a place that should not be transgressed, which occurs by way of the body door, with the aim of an unallowable object.🔽This is how it should be understood.

original: micchācāro sīlādiguṇavirahite agamanīyaṭṭhāne appasāvajjo, sīlādiguṇasampanne mahāsāvajjo.
analyzed: micchā ācāro sīla ādi guṇa virahite agamanīya ṭṭhāne appasāvajjo sīla ādi guṇa sampanne mahāsāvajjo
translated: Wrong conduct is less blameworthy when the place is not one to be visited by those who have virtue, etc., and more blameworthy when the place is one to be visited by those who have virtue, etc.

original: Tassa cattāro sambhārā – agamanīyavatthu, tasmiṃ sevanacittaṃ, sevanapayogo, maggenamaggappaṭipattiadhivāsananti.
analyzed: tassa cattāro sambhārāḥ agamanīya vatthu tasmim sevana cittam sevana payogaḥ maggena magga paṭipatti adhivāsananti
translated: Its four constituents are: the place not to be visited, the mind of intercourse with that, the act of intercourse, and the consent to the path of intercourse.

original: Eko payogo sāhatthiko eva.
analyzed: ekaḥ payogaḥ sāhatthikaḥ eva
translated: There is only one act, and that is by body.

original: Vacīdvāre bāhullavuttito vācato pavattaṃ duccaritanti vacīduccaritaṃ. Taṃ sarūpato
analyzed: vacī dvāre bāhulla vuttitaḥ vācataḥ pavattam duccaritanti vacī duccaritam tam sarūpataḥ
translated: Verbal misconduct is misconduct occurring by way of speech, which is the more usual way.

original: dassento āha “musāvādapisuṇavācāpharusavācāsamphappalāpacetanā veditabbā”ti. Tattha🔽musāti abhūtaṃ atacchaṃ vatthu. Musā vadīyati vuccati etāyāti musāvādo, atathaṃ vatthuṃ
analyzed: dassentaḥ āha musā vāda pisuṇa vācā pharusa vācā samphappalāpa cetanā veditabbā ati tattha  abhūtam ataccham vatthu musā vadīyati vuccati musā vādaḥ atatham vatthum
translated: Showing its individual essence, he said, “The intention to tell lies, to use divisive speech, to use harsh speech, and to use idle chatter should be understood.” Herein,

original: tathato paraṃ viññāpetukāmassa tathāviññattisamuṭṭhāpikā cetanā. So yamatthaṃ bhañjati,
analyzed: tathatas param viññāpetu kāmassa tathā viññatti samuṭṭhāpikā cetanā saḥ yam attham bhañjati
translated: a lie is a non-existent, unreal thing. It is called a lie because one says “lie” when one says “lie.” It is the intention that originates in the desire to make another understand a non-existent thing as existent.

original: tassa appatāya appasāvajjo, mahantatāya mahāsāvajjo. Apica gahaṭṭhānaṃ attano santakaṃ
analyzed: tassa appa tāya appa sāvajjaḥ mahanta tāya mahā sāvajjaḥ apica gaha ṭṭhānam attano santakam
translated: It is less blameworthy when the matter is slight and more blameworthy when the matter is great. Furthermore, for householders it is less blameworthy

original: adātukāmatāya natthīti ādinayappavatto appasāvajjo, sakkhinā hutvā atthabhañjanatthaṃ🔽vutto mahāsāvajjo. Pabbajitānaṃ appakampi telaṃ vā sappiṃ vā labhitvā hasādhippāyena
analyzed: a dātu kāma tāya natthi iti ādi naya ppavatto appasāvajjo sakkhinā hutvā attha bhañjana ttham  vuttaḥ mahā sāvajjaḥ pabbajitānam appakampi telam vā sappim vā labhitvā hasa adhippāyena
translated: The kind of lying that occurs in the form of the statement “There is none” when one is unwilling to give something is less blameworthy;🔽the kind that occurs when one who is capable of giving lies for the purpose of wasting is more blameworthy.

original: “ajja gāme telaṃ nadī maññe sandatī”ti pūraṇakathānayena pavatto appasāvajjo, adiṭṭhaṃyeva
analyzed: ajja gāme telam nadī maññe sandati iti pūraṇa kathā nayena pavattaḥ appasāvajjaḥ a diṭṭham yā iva
translated: The kind of lying that occurs when one who has received a little oil or ghee from the bhikkhus laughs and says, “Today the oil in the village must be running, it seems, since they give so much,” and so speaks in praise of the gift, is less blameworthy;🔽but the kind that occurs when one says, “I have seen such and such a thing,” when one has not seen it, is more blameworthy.

original: pana diṭṭhantiādinā nayena vadantānaṃ mahāsāvajjo. Tassa cattāro sambhārā honti –
analyzed: pana diṭṭha nti ādinā nayena vadantānam mahā sāvajjo tassa cattāro sambhārāḥ honti
translated: And this has four constituents:

original: atathaṃ vatthu, visaṃvādanacittaṃ, tajjo vāyāmo, parassa tadatthaviññāpananti. Eko
analyzed: atatham vatthu visaṃvādana cittam tajjaḥ vāyāmaḥ parassa tad attha viññāpanan ti ekaḥ
translated: the object that is not as it is; the intention to deceive; the effort that is appropriate to that; the communication of that meaning to another.🔽There is only one means:

original: payogo sāhatthikova. So kāyena vā kāyapaṭibaddhena vā vācāya vā paravisaṃvādakakiriyākaraṇe
analyzed: payogaḥ sāhatthikaḥ uva saḥ kāyena vā kāya paṭibaddhena vā vācāya vā para visaṃvādaka kiriyā karaṇe
translated: by body, by what is connected to the body, or by speech.🔽And that should be understood as the act of making another understand.

original: daṭṭhabbo. Tāya ce kiriyāya paro tamatthaṃ jānāti, ayaṃ kiriyāsamuṭṭhāpikacetanākkhaṇeyeva
analyzed: daṭṭhabbaḥ tāya ce kiriyāya paraḥ tam attham jānāti ayam kiriyā samuṭṭhāpika cetanā kkhaṇeya iva
translated: And when the other understands that meaning, then at the very moment of the volition that instigates the act,🔽he is bound by the kamma of false speech.

original: musāvādakammunā bajjhati. Yasmā pana yathā kāyakāyapaṭibaddhavācāhi paraṃ visaṃvādeti,
analyzed: musāvāda kammunā bajjhati yasmai pana yathā param visaṃvāda iti
translated: But just as he deceives another by body, by what is connected to the body, and by speech,

original: tathā “idamassa bhaṇāhī”ti āṇāpentopi, paṇṇaṃ likhitvā purato nissajjantopi, “ayaṃ
analyzed: tathā idam assa bhaṇāhi iti āṇāpentaḥ api paṇṇam likhitvā puratas nissajjantaḥ api ayam
translated: Likewise, if he tells him, “Speak thus,” and if he writes a letter and places it in front of him,

original: attho evaṃ veditabbo”ti kuṭṭādīsu likhitvā ṭhapentopi, tasmā ettha āṇattikanissaggiyathāvarāpi
analyzed: atthaḥ evam veditabbaḥ ti kuṭṭa ādīsu likhitvā ṭhapentaḥ api tasmai ettha āṇattika nissaggi yathāvarā api
translated: and if he writes the meaning on a wall, etc., and places it there, saying, “This meaning should be understood thus,”

original: payogā yujjanti. Aṭṭhakathāsu pana anāgatattā vīmaṃsitvā gahetabbā.🔽Pisatīti pisuṇā, samagge satte avayavabhūte vagge bhinne karotīti attho. Niruttinayena🔽vā piyasuññakaraṇato pisuṇā. Yāya hi vācāya yassa taṃ vācaṃ bhāsati, tassa hadaye
analyzed: payogāḥ yujjanti aṭṭhakathāsu pana anāgata ttā vīmaṃsitvā gahetabbā  pisati iti pisuṇā samagge satte avayava bhūte vagge bhinne karoti iti atthaḥ nirutti nayena  vā piya suñña karaṇataḥ pisuṇā yāya hi vācāya yassa tam vācam bhāsati tassa hadaye
translated: then the intimation and the giving up of the effort are appropriate here. But since they are not mentioned in the commentaries, they should be included only after careful consideration.

original: attano piyabhāvaṃ, parassa ca piyasuññabhāvaṃ karoti, sā pisuṇavācā. Lakkhaṇato pana
analyzed: attanaḥ piya bhāvam parassa ca piya suñña bhāvam karoti sā pisuṇa vācā lakkhaṇato pana
translated: A slanderer is one who is pisuṇā, that is, one who is pisuṇā because of the manner of speaking, or because of the removal of the dear one . For by the speech by which one speaks that speech to another, one removes the dear one from the heart of the other and makes him dear to oneself. This is slander. But by definition,

original: saṃkiliṭṭhacittassa paresaṃ vā bhedāya attano piyakamyatāya vā kāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā
analyzed: saṃkiliṭṭha cittassa paresam vā bhedāya attanaḥ piya kamyatāya vā kāya vacī payoga samuṭṭhāpikā
translated: slander is the volition that originates in bodily and verbal effort in one whose mind is defiled, either in order to cause division among others or in order to make himself dear .

original: cetanā pisuṇavācā pisuṇaṃ vadati etāyāti katvā. Sā yassa bhedaṃ karoti, tassa appaguṇatāya
analyzed: cetanā pisuṇa vācā pisuṇam vadati etāya ati katvā sā yassa bhedam karoti tassa appaguṇa tāya
translated: It is called slander because one slanders by means of it. But it is the other’s lack of good qualities that is the reason for the division.

original: appasāvajjā, mahāguṇatāya mahāsāvajjā. Tassā cattāro sambhārā – bhinditabbo paro,🔽“iti ime nānā bhavissanti vinā bhavissantī”ti bhedapurekkhāratā vā “iti ahaṃ piyo
analyzed: appasāvajjā mahā guṇa tāya mahāsāvajjā tassā cattāro sambhārā bhinditabbo paraḥ  iti ime nānā bhavissanti vinā bhavissanti iti bheda purekkhāra tā vā iti aham piyaḥ
translated: and it is less blameworthy when the person is of little account, and more blameworthy when the person is of great account. It has four constituents: the other person to be split,

original: bhavissāmi vissāsiko”ti piyakamyatā vā, tajjo vāyāmo, tassa tadatthavijānananti.
analyzed: bhavissāmi vissāsikaḥ ti piya kamyatā vā tad jaḥ vā āyāmaḥ tassa tad attha vijānana ti
translated: the wish to split them by thinking, “So they will be divided and fall out,” or the wish to be dear and trusted by thinking, “So I shall be dear and trusted,” or the effort appropriate to that, or the knowledge of the purpose of that.

original: Pare pana abhinne kammapathabhedo natthi, bhinne eva hoti.🔽Pharusayatīti pharusā, vācā. Yāya hi vācāya attānampi parampi pharusaṃ sinehābhāvena
analyzed: pare pana abhinne kamma patha bhedaḥ natthi bhinne eva hoti  pharusayati iti pharusā vācā hi vācāya attānam pi param pi pharusam sineha abhāvena
translated: But when the other person is not split, there is no breach of the path of action; it is only when he is split that there is.🔽It is harsh because it harasses , thus it is harsh speech . For it is by means of this speech that one harasses oneself and others, making them lose their composure and become miserable.

original: lūkhaṃ karoti, sā pharusavācā. Atha vā sayampi pharusā domanassasamuṭṭhitattā sabhāvenapi🔽kakkasā neva kaṇṇasukhā na hadayasukhāti pharusavācā. Ettha pana paresaṃ mammacchedanavasena
analyzed: lūkham karoti sā pharusa vācā atha vā sayam pi pharusā domanassa samuṭṭhita ttā sabhāvena api  kakkasā nā iva kaṇṇa sukhā na hadaya sukhā ati pharusa vācā ettha pana paresam mamma chedana vasena
translated: Or alternatively, it is harsh because it is unpleasant , for it is unpleasant both to the ear and to the heart because it arises with displeasure.🔽Herein, it is called “harsh speech” because it occurs as the cutting off of others’ affection,

original: pavattiyā ekantaniṭṭhuratāya sabhāvena kāraṇavohārena ca vācāya pharusasaddappavatti
analyzed: pavattiyāḥ ekanta niṭṭhura tāya sabhāvena kāraṇa vohārena ca vācāya pharusa sadda ppavatti
translated: and because of its utter fierceness, the sound “pharusā” occurs as the name for the speech, as a designation for the cause by means of the inherent cause method.

original: daṭṭhabbā. Taṃ pharusaṃ vadati etāyāti pharusavācā, parassa mammacchedakakāyavacīpayogasamuṭṭhāpikā
analyzed: daṭṭhabbā tam pharusam vadati etāya ati pharusa vācā parassa mamma chedaka kāya vacī payoga samuṭṭhāpikā
translated: It should be understood as the opposite of the kind of speech described in the passage beginning, “When speech is spoken … that is beneficial, agreeable, and endearing” .

original: ekantapharusā cetanā. Tassā āvibhāvatthamidaṃ vatthu – eko kira dārako mātu vacanaṃ🔽anādiyitvā araññaṃ gacchati, taṃ mātā nivattetuṃ asakkontī “caṇḍā taṃ mahiṃsī anubandhatū”ti
analyzed: ekanta pharusā cetanā tassāḥ āvi bhāva attham idam vatthu ekaḥ kira dārakaḥ mātu vacanam  an ādiyitvā araññam gacchati tam mātā nivattetum a sakkontī caṇḍā tam mahiṃsī anubandhatu uti
translated: It is a form of intention that is exclusively harsh and is the instigator of a bodily or verbal action that causes another being to feel pain.🔽The following story illustrates its nature. A certain boy, it seems, went off to the forest without paying attention to his mother’s words.🔽Unable to dissuade him, she cursed him, saying, “May a fierce she-buffalo attack you!”

original: akkosi. Athassa tatheva araññe mahiṃsī uṭṭhāsi. Dārako “yaṃ mama mātā mukhena kathesi,
analyzed: akkosi athassa tathā iva araññe mahiṃsī uṭṭhāsi dārakaḥ yam mama mātā mukhena kathesi
translated: Then a she-buffalo did indeed appear in the forest. The boy thought, “Let what my mother said with her mouth not come to pass,

original: taṃ mā hotu. Yaṃ cittena cintesi, taṃ hotū”ti saccakiriyamakāsi. Mahiṃsī tattheva
analyzed: tam mā hotu yam cittena cintesi tam hotu uti mahiṃsī tattha iva
translated: but let what she thought with her mind come to pass.” He made an aspiration, and the she-buffalo stood there as if tied.

original: baddhā viya aṭṭhāsi. Evaṃ mammacchedakopi payogo cittasaṇhatāya pharusavācā na hoti.🔽Mātāpitaro hi kadāci puttake evampi vadanti “corā vo khaṇḍākhaṇḍikaṃ karontū”ti,
analyzed: baddhā viya aṭṭhāsi evam payogo citta saṇha tāya pharusa vācā na hoti  mātā pitaraḥ hi kadāci puttake evam pi vadanti corāḥ vaḥ khaṇḍākhaṇḍikam karontu uti
translated: So a bodily or verbal action that causes another to feel pain is not harsh speech if it is done with a mind that is in harmony with the path.🔽For parents sometimes say to their children, “May thieves cut you limb from limb,”

original: uppalapattampi ca nesaṃ upari patantaṃ na icchanti. Ācariyupajjhāyā ca kadāci nissitake
analyzed: uppala pattam pi ca nesam upari patantam na icchanti ācariya upajjhāyā ca kadāci nissitake
translated: but they do not want them to be struck even by a flower. And teachers and preceptors sometimes say to their pupils, “May dogs eat you,”

original: evaṃ vadanti “kiṃ ime ahirikā anottappino caranti, niddhamatha ne”ti. Atha ca nesaṃ
analyzed: evam vadanti kim ime ahirikāḥ anottappino caranti atha ca
translated: They say: “Do they go about shameless and audacious? Drive them out!” And yet they want to claim that they have the attainment of the scriptures and the attainment of the fruits.

original: āgamādhigamasampattiṃ icchanti, yathā cittasaṇhatāya pharusavācā na hoti, evaṃ vacanasaṇhatāya🔽apharusavācāpi na hoti. Na hi mārāpetukāmassa “imaṃ sukhaṃ sayāpethā”ti vacanaṃ apharusavācā
analyzed: āgama adhigama sampattim icchanti yathā citta saṇhatāya pharusa vācā na evam vacana saṇhatāya  a pharusa vācā api na hoti na hi māra apetu kāmassa imam sukham vacanam a pharusa vācā
translated: And just as there is no harsh speech when there is a softening of the mind, so there is no harsh speech when there is a softening of the words.🔽For when one who wants to have someone killed says: “Let him lie down at ease,” his words are not “not harsh speech.”

original: hoti, cittapharusatāya pana esā pharusavācāva. Sā yaṃ sandhāya pavattitā, tassa appaguṇatāya
analyzed: hoti citta pharusa tāya pana esā pharusa vācā ava sā yam sandhāya tassa appaguṇa tāya
translated: But they are harsh speech because of the harshness of the mind. And they are less blameworthy when they are uttered with reference to one who has few good qualities,🔽more blameworthy when with reference to one who has great qualities.

original: appasāvajjā, mahāguṇatāya mahāsāvajjā. Tassā tayo sambhārā – akkositabbo paro, kupitacittaṃ, akkosanāti.🔽Saṃ sukhaṃ hitañca phalati visarati vināsetīti samphaṃ, attano paresañca anupakārakaṃ
analyzed: appasāvajjā mahā guṇa tāya mahā sāvajjā tassā tayo sambhārā akkositabbo parassa kupita cittam  sam sukham hitam ca phalati visarati paresam ca anupakārakam
translated: It has three constituents: the other person is one who should be reviled, the mind is in a state of annoyance, and the reviling is done.🔽It is “idle chatter” because it chatters with what is futile, that is, what is not beneficial either to oneself or to others.

original: yaṃ kiñci, samphaṃ palapati etāyāti samphappalāpo, anatthaviññāpikakāyavacīpayogasamauṭṭhāpikā
analyzed: yam kiñci sampham palapati etāya ati sampha ppalāpaḥ anattha viññāpika kāya vacī payoga samauṭṭhāpikā
translated: It is a bodily or verbal instigation to the communication of what is not beneficial.

original: akusalacetanā. So āsevanamandatāya appasāvajjo, āsevanamahantatāya mahāsāvajjo. Tassa
analyzed: akusala cetanā saḥ āsevana manda tāya appa sāvajjaḥ āsevana mahanta tāya mahā sāvajjaḥ tassa
translated: Unprofitable intention. It is less blameworthy when the instigation is slight, more blameworthy when the instigation is great.

original: dve sambhārā – bhāratayuddhasītāharaṇādiniratthakakathāpurekkhāratā, tathārūpīkathākathanañca.
analyzed: dve sambhārāḥ bhārata yuddha sītā haraṇa ādi niratthaka kathā purekkhāra tā tathārūpī kathā kathanam ca
translated: Its two constituents are the pre-occupation with such unprofitable talk as the story of the Battle of the Bāhukās, the story of Sītā, and so on, and the telling of such stories.

original: Pare pana taṃ kathaṃ agaṇhante kammapathabhedo natthi, parena pana samphappalāpe gahiteyeva hoti.
analyzed: pare pana tam katham a gaṇhante kamma patha bhedaḥ natthi parena pana samphappalāpe hoti
translated: But if others do not listen to it, there is no breach of a training precept; it is only when others understand the talk that there is a breach.

original: Abhijjhābyāpādamicchādiṭṭhiyoti ettha parasampattiṃ abhimukhaṃ jhāyatīti abhijjhā,
analyzed: abhijjhā byāpāda micchā diṭṭhiyā ti ettha para sampattim abhimukham jhāyati iti abhijjhā
translated: Covetousness, ill will, and wrong view: here, it is because of the word abhi in the sense of “facing” that covetousness is explained as “the state of burning up by facing the property of others” .

original: parasampattīsu lobho. Sā pana “aho vata idaṃ mamassā”ti evaṃ parabhaṇḍābhijjhāyanalakkhaṇā.
analyzed: para sampattīsu lobho sā pana aho vata idam mama assa ati evam parabhaṇḍa abhijjhāyana lakkhaṇā
translated: It is greed for the property of others. But its characteristic is that of the burning up of the mind in the wishing: “Oh, that this should be mine!”

original: Adinnādānaṃ viya appasāvajjā mahāsāvajjā ca. Tassā dve sambhārā – parabhaṇḍaṃ, attano🔽pariṇāmanañca. Parabhaṇḍavatthuke hi lobhe uppannepi na tāva kammapathabhedo hoti,
analyzed: adinnādānam viya appasāvajjā mahāsāvajjā ca tassāḥ dve sambhārā  pariṇāmanam ca parabhaṇḍa vatthuke hi lobhe uppanne pi na tāva kamma patha bhedaḥ hoti
translated: It is less blameworthy and more blameworthy too, like taking what is not given. Its two constituents are the property of others and the wish to make it one’s own.

original: yāva “aho vata idaṃ mamassā”ti attano na pariṇāmeti.
analyzed: aho vata idam attanaḥ na
translated: For even when greed has arisen in regard to the property of others, there is no breach of a training precept so long as there is no wish to make it one’s own with the thought “Oh, that this should be mine!”

original: Hitasukhaṃ byāpādeti vināsetīti byāpādo, paṭigho. So paravināsāya manopadosalakkhaṇo.🔽So pharusavācā viya appasāvajjo mahāsāvajjo ca. Tassa dve sambhārā – parasatto, tassa
analyzed: hita sukham vināseti iti byāpādo paṭigho so para vināsāya manaḥ padosa lakkhaṇo  so pharusa vācā viya appa sāvajjaḥ mahā sāvajjaḥ ca tassa dve sambhārā para satto tassa
translated: Ill will is the state of mind that is the opposite of loving kindness, that is, the state of mind that is the enemy of loving kindness. It is the state of mind that is the opposite of the state of mind that wishes for beings’ welfare and happiness, that is, the state of mind that wishes to destroy and harm them. Its characteristic is the wish to destroy others.

original: ca vināsanacintā. Parasattavatthuke hi kodhe uppannepi na tāva kammapathabhedo hoti,
analyzed: ca vināsana cintā para satta vatthuke hi kodhe uppanne pi na tāva kamma patha bhedaḥ hoti
translated: It is less blameworthy and more blameworthy like harsh speech. Its two constituents are a living being and the thought of destroying him. For even when anger has arisen towards a living being, there is no breach of a training precept

original: yāva “aho vatāyaṃ ucchijjeyya vinasseyyā”ti tassa vināsanaṃ na cinteti.
analyzed: yāva aho vata ayam ucchijjeyya vinasseyya ati tassa vināsanam na cinteti
translated: until one thinks of destroying him, thinking, “Oh, if only he might be cut to pieces! If only he might be destroyed!”

original: Yathābhuccagahaṇābhāvena micchā passatīti micchādiṭṭhi. Sā “natthi dinna”ntiādinā🔽nayena viparītadassanalakkhaṇā. Samphappalāpo viya appasāvajjā mahāsāvajjā ca. Apica
analyzed: yathā abhucca gahaṇa abhāvena micchā passati iti micchādiṭṭhi sā natthi  nayena viparīta dassana lakkhaṇā samphappalāpaḥ viya appasāvajjā mahāsāvajjā ca apica
translated: He sees wrongly, that is, he perceives contrary to actual fact, thus he has wrong view. Its characteristic is the seeing of what is not so, in the way beginning, “There is nothing given” .🔽It is less blameworthy and more blameworthy like frivolous talk. Furthermore,

analyzed: aniyatāḥ appasāvajjāḥ niyatāḥ mahāsāvajjā tassa dve sambhārāḥ vatthunaḥ gahita ākāra viparīta tā 🔽yathā ca tam gaṇhāti tathābhāvena tassa upaṭṭhānam ti tattha natthika a hetuka a ariya diṭṭhīhi

Its two constituents are the perception of the object in a contrary way and the manifestation of the object in that contrary way. Herein, the views “There is no generosity” and “There is no offering of sacrifice” are wrong view.

original: eva kammapathabhedo hoti.
analyzed: eva kamma patha bhedaḥ hoti
translated: This is the analysis of the courses of kamma.

original: “Anekavihitānaṃ pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammāna”nti sāmaññavacanepi pārisesañāyato
analyzed: aneka vihitānam pāpakānam akusalānam dhammānam ti sāmañña vacane pi pārisesa ñāyataḥ
translated: “Many kinds of bad unwholesome states”: the word “many” is a collective expression. By the rule of ellipsis,🔽the unwholesome states not already mentioned should be included.

original: vuttāvasesā akusalā dhammā gahetabbāti āha “ṭhapetvā te dhamme”tiādi. Te yathāvuttakāyaduccaritādike
analyzed: vutta avasesāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ gahetabbā ti āha ṭhapetvā te dhamma itiādi te yathā vutta kāya duccarita ādike
translated: The meaning is: “except for those states already mentioned.”

original: akusaladhamme ṭhapetvāti attho. Anekavihitāti anekappakārā.
analyzed: akusala dhamme ṭhapetvā ti attho aneka vihitā ati aneka ppakārā
translated: “Many kinds” means of many kinds.

original: 6. Ayaṃ lokatantīti ayaṃ vuḍḍhānaṃ abhivādanādikiriyālakkhaṇā lokappaveṇī. Anāgāmibrahmānaṃ
analyzed: ayam loka tantī iti ayam vuḍḍhānam abhivādana ādi kiriyā lakkhaṇā loka ppaveṇī anāgāmi brahmānam
translated: This is the world’s thread: this is the world’s warp, characterized by the paying of respect to elders, etc.

original: alaṅkārādīsu anāgāmibhikkhūnañca cīvarādīsu nikantivasena rāguppatti hotīti anāgāmimaggena🔽pañcakāmaguṇikarāgasseva pahānaṃ veditabbanti āha “pañcakāmaguṇikarāgassā”ti. Rūpādīsu

original: pañcasu kāmaguṇesu vatthukāmakoṭṭhāsesu uppajjamāno rāgo “pañcakāmaguṇikarāgo”ti
analyzed: pañcasu kāmaguṇesu vatthu kāma koṭṭhāsesu uppajjamānaḥ rāgaḥ pañca kāmaguṇika rāgaḥ ti

original: veditabbo. Koṭṭhāsavacano hettha guṇasaddo “vayoguṇā anupubbaṃ jahantī”tiādīsu viya.

original: Dvīsu akusalacittesūti domanassasahagatesu dvīsu akusalacittesu. Mohassa sabbākusalasādhāraṇattā

analyzed: āha sabba akusala sambhavassa iti avasesānam ti sakkāya diṭṭhi ādīnam  jigucchati maññā iti aham abhijātaḥ rūpavā paññavā katham nāma aññesam abhivādana ādim

translated: That is why it is said, “with the attainment of unprofitable things.” The attainment is a synonym for the state of being associated with them.

original: samaṅgibhāvoti. Maṇḍanakajātiyoti maṇḍanasabhāvo, maṇḍanasīloti attho. Jegucchitanti jigucchanasīlataṃ.

translated: The state of being adorned: the state of being ornamented, the habit of ornamenting, is what is meant. Disgusting: the habit of being disgusted.

analyzed: loka jeṭṭhaka kamman ti loke jeṭṭhakānam kattabba kammam loke vā seṭṭha sammatam kammam
