analyzed: opamma sampaṭipādanam ti opamma atthassa upameyyena sammat eva paṭipādanam atthena ati
translated: “The establishment of the simile”: the establishment of the meaning of the simile by the simile itself. “In the meaning”:

original: upameyyatthena. Yathā kukkuṭiyā aṇḍesu tividhakiriyākaraṇaṃ kukkuṭacchāpakānaṃ aṇḍakosato
analyzed: upameyya tthena yathā kukkuṭiyāḥ aṇḍesu tividha kiriyā karaṇam
translated: in the meaning of the simile. As the hen’s three activities in regard to the eggs are the same as those of the chicks in regard to the egg-shells,

original: nikkhamanassa mūlakāraṇaṃ, evaṃ bodhisattabhūtassa bhagavato tividhānupassanākaraṇaṃ
analyzed: nikkhamanassa mūla kāraṇam evam bodhisatta bhūtassa bhagavataḥ tividha anupassanā karaṇam
translated: The reason for the bird’s coming out of the egg is the doing of the three contemplations by the Blessed One when he was a Bodhisatta.

original: avijjaṇḍakosato nikkhamanassa mūlakāraṇanti āha “yathā hi tassā kukkuṭiyā…pe… tividhānupassanākaraṇa”nti.🔽“Santāne”ti vuttattā aṇḍasadisatā santānassa bahi nikkhantakukkuṭacchāpakasadisatā🔽buddhaguṇānaṃ, buddhaguṇāti ca atthato buddhoyeva “tathāgatassa kho etaṃ, vāseṭṭha,
analyzed: nikkhamanassa mūla kāraṇanti āha yathā hi tassā kukkuṭiyāpe tividha anupassanā karaṇanti  santāne iti vutta ttā aṇḍa sadisa tā santānassa bahi nikkhanta kukkuṭa chāpaka sadisa tā  buddha guṇānam ca atthataḥ buddhaḥ yeva tathāgatassa kho etam vāseṭṭha
translated: That is the reason for his coming out of the egg of ignorance. “Just as, when that hen” is said, etc.,🔽Since “in the continuity” is said, the continuity is like the egg, and the qualities of a Buddha are like the chick that has come out of the egg.

original: adhivacanaṃ dhammakāyo itipī”ti vacanato. Avijjaṇḍakosassa tanubhāvoti balavavipassanāvasena
analyzed: adhivacanam dhamma kāyaḥ iti pi iti vacanataḥ avijjaṇḍa kosassa tanu bhāvaḥ ti balava vipassanā vasena
translated: And the qualities of a Buddha are the Buddha himself, according to the words “Vasettha, that is a designation for the Tathagata. The body of the Dhamma too is said” .🔽The attenuation of the egg of ignorance is the attenuation of the egg of ignorance by means of powerful insight.

original: avijjaṇḍakosassa tanubhāvo, paṭicchādanasāmaññena ca avijjāya aṇḍakosasadisatā. Mudubhūtassapi
analyzed: tanu bhāvo paṭicchādana sāmaññena ca avijjāya aṇḍa kosa sadisa tā mudu bhūtassa api
translated: And ignorance is like the egg-shell because of its concealing.

original: kharabhāvāpatti hotīti tannivattanatthaṃ “thaddhakharabhāvo”ti vuttaṃ. Tikkhakharavippasannasūrabhāvoti
analyzed: khara bhāva āpatti hoti iti tad nivattana attham thaddha khara bhāvaḥ iti vuttam tikkha khara vippasanna sūra bhāvaḥ ti
translated: The state of being hard and rough is said in order to prevent the notion that it is soft and tender.🔽The state of being sharp, rough, and pungent is said in order to prevent the notion that it is smooth.

original: ettha pariggayhamānesu saṅkhāresu vipassanāñāṇassa samādhindriyavasena sukhānuppaveso🔽tikkhatā, anupavisitvāpi satindriyavasena anatikkamanato akuṇṭhatā kharabhāvo. Tikkhopi
analyzed: ettha pariggayhamānesu saṅkhāresu vipassanā ñāṇassa samādhi indriya vasena sukha anuppavesaḥ  tikkha tā an upavisitvā api sat indriya vasena an atikkamanataḥ akuṇṭha tā khara bhāvaḥ tikkhaḥ api
translated: When formations are discerned in this way, the penetration of pleasure is by means of the jhāna factor of happiness in the knowledge of insight.🔽The state of keenness is the state of being sharp. For even though one is keen, if one is sluggish, one is not keen in the way intended here. But this is not so.

original: hi ekacco saro lakkhaṃ patvā kuṇṭho hoti, na tathā idaṃ. Satipi kharabhāve sukhumappavattivasena
analyzed: hi ekaccaḥ saraḥ lakkham patvā kuṇṭhaḥ hoti na tathā idam sati api khara bhāve sukhuma ppavatti vasena
translated: And although there is keenness,

original: kilesasamudācārasaṅkhobharahitatāya saddhindriyavasena pasannabhāvo, satipi ca pasannabhāve🔽antarā anosakkitvā kilesapaccatthikānaṃ suṭṭhu abhibhavanato vīriyindriyavasena sūrabhāvo
analyzed: kilesa samudācāra saṅkhobha rahita tāya saddhi indriya vasena ca pasanna bhāve  antarā an osakkitvā kilesa paccatthikānam suṭṭhu abhibhavanataḥ vīriya indriya vasena sūra bhāvaḥ
translated: the state of clarity is by means of the faith faculty. And although there is clarity,

original: veditabbo. Evamimehi pakārehi saṅkhārupekkhāñāṇameva gahitanti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Vipassanāñāṇassa
analyzed: veditabbaḥ evam imehi pakārehi saṅkhāra upekkhā ñāṇam eva gahitan ti daṭṭhabbam vipassanā ñāṇassa
translated: the state of strength is by means of the energy faculty. This should be understood as the way in which the knowledge of equanimity about formations is included in these aspects.

original: pariṇāmakāloti vipassanāya vuṭṭhānagāminibhāvappatti, tadā ca sā maggañāṇagabbhaṃ
analyzed: pariṇāma kālaḥ ti vipassanāya vuṭṭhāna gāmini bhāva ppatti tadā ca sā magga ñāṇa gabbham
translated: The time for the change of insight knowledge is the time for the attainment of the state of going out of insight. And then that knowledge is pregnant with path knowledge.

original: dhārentī viya hotīti āha “gabbhaggahaṇakālo”ti. Gabbhaṃ gaṇhāpetvāti saṅkhārupekkhāya
analyzed: dhārentī viya hoti iti āha gabbha ggahaṇa kālo ti gabbham gaṇhāpetvā iti saṅkhāra upekkhāya
translated: “The time of conception” is the time of the conception of the embryo.

original: anantaraṃ sikhāppattaanulomavipassanāvasena maggavijāyanatthaṃ gabbhaṃ gaṇhāpetvā.
analyzed: anantaram sikhāppatta anuloma vipassanā vasena magga vijāyana attham gabbham gaṇhāpetvā
translated: “Having conceived the embryo”: having conceived the embryo for the purpose of the realization of the path by means of the insight that has reached its peak by means of the equanimity about formations.🔽“By means of the realization in due course”: by means of the realization in the order of the first path.

original: Anupubbādhigatenāti paṭhamamaggapaṭipāṭiyā adhigatena. Abhiññāpakkheti lokiyābhiññāpakkhe.
analyzed: anupubba adhigatena ati paṭhama magga paṭipāṭiyā adhigatena abhiññā pakkhe ti lokiya abhiññā pakkhe
translated: “In the category of direct-knowledge”: in the category of mundane direct-knowledge.

original: Lokuttarābhiññā hi avijjaṇḍakosaṃ padālitā. Potthakesu pana katthaci “chaabhiññāpakkhe”ti🔽likhanti, so apāṭhoti veditabbo. Jeṭṭho seṭṭhoti vuddhatamattā jeṭṭho, sabbaguṇehi
analyzed: lokuttara abhiññā hi avijjaṇḍakosam padālitā potthakesu pana katthaci cha abhiññā pakkhā iti  likhanti so apāṭho ti veditabbaḥ jeṭṭhaḥ seṭṭho ti vuddhatama ttā jeṭṭhaḥ sabba guṇehi
translated: For the supramundane direct-knowledge has burst the egg of ignorance. But in some editions it is written “in the category of the six direct-knowledges.”

original: uttamattā pasatthatamoti seṭṭho.
analyzed: uttamattā pasatthatamaḥ ti seṭṭhaḥ
translated: This should be understood as a wrong reading. “The eldest, the best”: he is the eldest because of his seniority, and he is the best because of his pre-eminence in all good qualities.

original: Idāni “āraddhaṃ kho pana me brāhmaṇa vīriya”ntiādikāya desanāya anusandhiṃ dassento
analyzed: idāni āraddham kho pana me brāhmaṇa vīriyanti ādikāya desanāya anusandhim dassento
translated: Now, in order to show the connection with the teaching beginning with “My energy, brahmin, has been exerted” ,

original: āha “evaṃ bhagavā”tiādi. Tattha pubbabhāgato pabhutīti bhāvanāya pubbabhāgiyavīriyārambhādito
analyzed: āha evam bhagavā tiādi tattha pubbabhāgataḥ pabhuti iti bhāvanāya pubbabhāgiya vīriya ārambha āditaḥ
translated: he said “Thus the Blessed One” and so on. Herein, “from the beginning of the development” is from the beginning of the exertion of energy in the development of insight.

original: paṭṭhāya. Cittamevamuppannanti evaṃ upari vakkhamānaparivitakkavasena cittamuppannanti
analyzed: paṭṭhāya cittam evam uppannanti evam upari vakkhamāna parivitakka vasena cittam uppannanti
translated: “The thought arose in his mind” means the thought arose in his mind in the way described above, in the way that will be described below.

original: attho. “Cittameva uppanna”ntipi pāṭho, tattha cittameva uppannaṃ, na tāva bhagavati
analyzed: cittam eva uppannam tipi tattha cittam eva uppannam na tāva bhagavati
translated: The meaning is: “The thought arose in his mind.” “The thought arose in his mind alone” is another reading, which means: “The thought arose in his mind alone, but not yet confidence in the Exalted One.”

original: pasādoti attho. Muṭṭhassatināti vinaṭṭhassatinā, sativirahitenāti attho. Sāraddhakāyenāti
analyzed: pasādaḥ ti attho muṭṭha satinā ati vinaṭṭha satinā sati virahitena ati attho sāraddha kāyena ati
translated: “With his mindfulness lost” means with his mindfulness destroyed; the meaning is: “deprived of mindfulness.” “With his body agitated” means with his body agitated by pain.

original: sadarathakāyena. Bodhimaṇḍeti bodhisaṅkhātassa ñāṇassa maṇḍabhāvappatte ṭhāne. Bodhīti
analyzed: sada ratha kāyena bodhimaṇḍā iti bodhi saṅkhātassa ñāṇassa maṇḍa bhāva ppatte ṭhāne bodhi iti
translated: “The Bodhi tree” is the place that has become the basis for the knowledge called “bodhi.”

original: hi paññā vuccati, sā ettha maṇḍā pasannā jātāti so padeso “bodhimaṇḍo”ti paññāto.🔽Caturaṅgasamannāgatanti “kāmaṃ taco ca nhāru ca aṭṭhi ca avasissatu, sarīre upasussatu
analyzed: hi paññā vuccati sā ettha maṇḍā pasannā jātā ati so padesaḥ bodhimaṇḍo ti paññāto  catur aṅga samannāgatanti kāmam taco ca nhāru ca aṭṭhi ca avasissatu sarīre upasussatu
translated: For “bodhi” is said to be wisdom, and it is well known that the place where that wisdom arose is called “the Bodhi tree.”🔽“Endowed with four factors”: the energy described in the passage: “Let the skin, sinews, bones, and marrow of my body dry up,

original: maṃsalohita”nti evaṃ vuttacaturaṅgasamannāgataṃ vīriyaṃ. Tattha tacoti ekaṃ aṅgaṃ
analyzed: maṃsa lohitanti evam vutta caturaṅga samannāgatam vīriyam tattha taco ti ekam aṅgam
translated: let the blood and flesh waste away, but this my exertion shall not relax until I attain the supreme state.” Herein, skin is one factor,

original: nhāru ekaṃ aṅgaṃ aṭṭhi ekaṃ aṅgaṃ maṃsalohitaṃ ekaṃ aṅganti veditabbaṃ. Taco ekaṃ
analyzed: nhāru ekam aṅgam aṭṭhi ekam aṅgam maṃsa lohitam ekam aṅgam ti veditabbam tacaḥ ekam
translated: sinews are one factor, bones are one factor, and blood and flesh are one factor.

original: aṅganti ca tace nirapekkhabhāvo ekaṃ aṅganti gahetabbaṃ. Padhānaṃ anuyuñjantassa
analyzed: ca tace nirapekkha bhāvaḥ ekam aṅgam iti gahetabbam padhānam anuyuñjantassa
translated: and the state of being unconcerned with that is one factor of the energy.

original: hi tace palujjamānepi taṃnimittaṃ avosānāpajjanaṃ tassa vīriyassa ekaṃ aṅgaṃ ekaṃ
analyzed: hi tace palujjamāne pi tad nimittam avosāna āpajjanam tassa vīriyassa ekam aṅgam ekam
translated: For when one is engaged in exerting,

original: kāraṇaṃ. Evaṃ sesesupi attho veditabbo. Paggahitanti ārambhaṃ sithilaṃ akatvā daḷhaparakkamasaṅkhātussāhanabhāvena
analyzed: kāraṇam evam sesesu pi attho veditabbo paggahitanti ārambham sithilam a katvā daḷha parakkama saṅkhāta ussāhana bhāvena
translated: if that is slipping away, the non-abandoning of the sign is one factor, one cause, of that energy. The meaning should be understood in this way in the other instances too.🔽“Upholding” is the state of being undertaken by arousing, which is a strong advance without slackness.

original: gahitaṃ. Tenāha “asithilappavattitanti vuttaṃ hotī”ti.
analyzed: gahitam tena āha asithila pavattitan ti vuttam hoti iti
translated: Hence it is said, “It is said to be the occurrence without slackness” .

original: Asallīnanti asaṅkucitaṃ kosajjavasena saṅkocaṃ anāpannaṃ. Upaṭṭhitāti ogāhanasaṅkhātena
analyzed: asallīnam ti asaṅkucitam kosajja vasena saṅkocam an āpannam upaṭṭhitā ati ogāhana saṅkhātena
translated: “Uncowed” : not contracted by idleness, not become contracted in the sense of shrinking.🔽“Well-established” : having approached the object by the state of non-diffusion called “engaging” .

original: apilāpabhāvena ārammaṇaṃ upagantvā ṭhitā. Tenāha “ārammaṇābhimukhībhāvenā”ti. Sammosassa
analyzed: apilāpa bhāvena ārammaṇam upagantvā ṭhitā tena āha ārammaṇa abhimukhībhāvena ati sammosassa
translated: Hence it is said, “By the state of facing the object” .

original: viddhaṃsanavasena pavattiyā na sammuṭṭhāti asammuṭṭhā. Kiñcāpi cittapassaddhivaseneva
analyzed: viddhaṃsana vasena pavattiyā na sammuṭṭhā ati asammuṭṭhā kiñca api citta passaddhi vasena eva
translated: It is “unwavering” because of occurrence by the state of piercing the slackness.🔽Although the mind is only calmed by the state of mental tranquillity,

original: cittameva passaddhaṃ, kāyapassaddhivaseneva ca kāyo passaddho hoti, tathāpi yasmā
analyzed: cittam eva passaddham kāya passaddhi vasena iva ca kāyaḥ passaddhaḥ hoti tathā api yasmai
translated: and the body is only calmed by the state of bodily tranquillity,🔽nevertheless,

original: kāyapassaddhi uppajjamānā cittapassaddhiyā saheva uppajjati, na vinā, tasmā vuttaṃ
analyzed: kāya passaddhi uppajjamānā citta passaddhiyā saha iva uppajjati na vinā tasmā vuttam
translated: Tranquillity of body arises together with and not without tranquillity of cognizance. Hence it was said above

original: “kāyacittapassaddhivasenā”ti. Kāyapassaddhiyā ubhayesampi kāyānaṃ passambhanāvahattā
analyzed: kāya citta passaddhi vasena ati kāya passaddhiyāḥ ubhayesam pi kāyānam
translated: “by means of tranquillity of body and of cognizance.” Because of the quieting of both kinds of body,

original: vuttaṃ “rūpakāyopi passaddhoyeva hotī”ti. So ca khoti so ca kho kāyo. Vigatadarathoti
analyzed: vuttam rūpa kāyaḥ api passaddhaḥ yeva hoti iti so ca kho iti saḥ ca kho kāyo vigata daratho ti
translated: it is said that “the material body is quiet too.” And that body: that material body. Free from agitation:

original: vigatakilesadaratho. Nāmakāye hi vigatadarathe rūpakāyopi vūpasantadarathapariḷāho🔽hoti. Sammā āhitanti nānārammaṇesu vidhāvanasaṅkhātaṃ vikkhepaṃ vicchinditvā ekasmiṃyeva
analyzed: vigata kilesadarathaḥ nāma kāye hi vigata darathe rūpa kāyaḥ api  hoti sammā āhitanti nānā ārammaṇesu vidhāvana saṅkhātam vikkhepam vicchinditvā ekasmiṃ yeva
translated: free from the agitation of defilements. For when the mental body is free from agitation, the material body is free from the agitation of fever due to agitation.

original: ārammaṇe avikkhittabhāvāpādanena sammadeva āhitaṃ ṭhapitaṃ. Tenāha “suṭṭhu ṭhapita”ntiādi.
analyzed: ārammaṇe avikkhitta bhāva āpādanena sammad eva āhitam ṭhapitam tena āha suṭṭhu ṭhapita ntiādi
translated: Well directed: well directed, well placed, by the abandoning of distraction consisting in running out to the various objects of the senses and by the obtaining of un- distractedness in a single object. Hence it was said above “well placed” and so on.

original: Cittassa anekaggabhāvo vikkhepavasena cañcalatā, sā sati ekaggatāya na hotīti āha
analyzed: cittassa anekagga bhāvaḥ vikkhepa vasena cañcala tā sā sati ekagga tāya na hoti iti āha
translated: The unsteadiness of cognizance due to distraction is the non-single function of cognizance. That is not so when there is unification of cognizance. Hence it was said:

original: “ekaggaṃ acalaṃ nipphandana”nti. Ettāvatāti “āraddhaṃ kho panā”tiādinā vīriyasatipassaddhisamādhīnaṃ
analyzed: ekaggam acalam nipphandanam ti ettāvatā ati āraddham kho pana ati ādinā vīriya sati passaddhi samādhīnam
translated: “unification of cognizance, steadiness of cognizance, non-distraction of cognizance” . So far: with the words “And his energy is aroused” and so on.

original: kiccasiddhidassanena.
analyzed: kicca siddhi dassanena
translated: By showing the success of the function.

original: Nanu ca saddhāpaññānampi kiccasiddhi jhānassa pubbapaṭipadāya icchitabbāti? Saccaṃ🔽icchitabbā, sā pana nānantarikabhāvena avuttasiddhāti na gahitā. Asati hi saddhāya
analyzed: nanu ca saddhā paññānam pi kicca siddhi jhānassa pubbapaṭipadāya icchitabbā ti saccam  icchitabbā sā pana nānantarika bhāvena avutta siddhā ati na gahitā asati hi saddhāya
translated: But is not the success of the function of faith and understanding also required for the preliminary work of the jhāna?🔽It is required, but it is not mentioned separately because it is included in the words “with the abandoning of pleasure and pain” and “with the previous disappearance of happiness and unhappiness.”

original: vīriyārambhādīnaṃ asambhavoyeva, paññāpariggahe ca nesaṃ asati ñāyārambhādibhāvo🔽na siyā, tathā asallīnāsammosatādayo vīriyādīnanti asallīnatādiggahaṇenevettha paññākiccasiddhi🔽gahitāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Jhānabhāvanāyaṃ vā samādhikiccaṃ adhikaṃ icchitabbanti dassetuṃ
analyzed: vīriya ārambha ādīnam paññā pariggahe ca na isam asati ñāya ārambha ādi bhāvo  na siyā tathā asallīna asammosa tā ādayaḥ asallīna tā ādi gahaṇena iva ittha paññā kicca siddhi  gahitā ti daṭṭhabbam jhāna bhāvanāyam vā samādhi kiccam adhikam icchitabbanti dassetuṃ
translated: For if there were no faith, there would be no exertion of energy, and if there were no understanding, there would be no right instigation of the process of application, etc.,🔽and there would be no absence of idleness, confusion, etc., in energy, and so on. So the success of the function of understanding should be regarded as included by the words “without unhappiness” and so on.🔽Or alternatively, the words “without unhappiness” and so on should be regarded as said in order to show that the success of the function of concentration is required in excess in the development of jhāna.

original: samādhipariyosānāva jhānassa pubbapaṭipadā kathitāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: samādhi pariyosānā ava jhānassa pubba paṭipadā kathitā ti daṭṭhabbaṃ
translated: For the preliminary work of the jhāna is said to end with concentration.

original: Paṭhamajjhānakathā
translated: The first jhāna

original: Idāni “vivicceva kāmehī”tiādinayappavattāya pāḷiyā jhānavibhaṅge vuttampi atthaṃ
analyzed: idāni vivicca iva kāmehi iti ādi naya ppavattāya pāḷiyā jhāna vibhaṅge vuttam pi attham
translated: Now, as to the text beginning, “Quite secluded from sense desires, secluded from unprofitable things” , the meaning of the words should be understood as follows:

original: aṭṭhakathānayeneva saṃvaṇṇetukāmo vibhaṅgapāḷiyaṃ vuttanayena avacane kāraṇaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhakathā nayena iva saṃvaṇṇetu kāmaḥ vibhaṅga pāḷiyam vutta nayena avacane kāraṇam dassetuṃ
translated: He wishes to comment in the way of the commentary. In order to show the reason for the expression in the way stated in the Vibhaṅga text,

original: “kiñcāpi tattha katame kāmā”tiādimāha. Tattha patthanākārena pavatto dubbalo lobho
analyzed: kiñcā api tattha katame kāma ati ādim āha tattha patthanā ākārena pavattaḥ dubbalaḥ lobho
translated: he says, “And what are the sensual desires? ” Herein, weak greed that occurs in the mode of longing

original: chandanaṭṭhena chando, tato balavā rañjanaṭṭhena rāgo, tatopi balavataro bahalarāgo
analyzed: chandana ṭṭhena chando tatas balavā rañjana ṭṭhena rāgo tatas api balavataraḥ bahala rāgo
translated: is will. Stronger than that is lust, which delights. Stronger than that is strong lust,

original: chandarāgo. Nimittānubyañjanāni saṅkappeti etenāti saṅkappo, tathāpavatto lobho.🔽Tattha nimittasaṅkappanā nāma avayave samodhānetvā “itthī puriso”tiādinā ekajjhaṃ
analyzed: chanda rāgaḥ nimitta anubyañjanāni saṅkappeti etena ati saṅkappaḥ tathā pavattaḥ lobho  tattha nimitta saṅkappanā nāma avayave samodhānetvā itthī purisa iti ādinā ekajjham
translated: which is will and lust. He conceives signs and particulars by means of this, thus it is conceiving. It is greed that occurs thus.

original: katvā uparūpari kilesuppattiyā nimittassa kappanā. Anubyañjanasaṅkappanā pana “hatthā
analyzed: katvā upari upari kilesa uppattiyāḥ nimittassa kappanā anubyañjana saṅkappanā pana
translated: Herein, the conceiving of signs is the conceiving of a sign by the successive production of defilements after making into one by collecting together the parts thus, “This is a woman,” “This is a man,” etc.

original: sobhanā, pādā sobhanā”ti evaṃ anubyañjanavasena vibhajitvā kappanāti. Kilesānañhi
analyzed: evam anubyañjana vasena vibhajitvā
translated: The conceiving of particulars is the conceiving after dividing up by way of particulars thus, “The hands are beautiful,” “The feet are beautiful,” etc.

original: anu anu byañjanato paribyañjanato paribyattivasena uppattiyā paccayabhāvato anubyañjanaṃ
analyzed: anu anu byañjanataḥ paribyañjanataḥ paribyatti vasena uppattiyāḥ paccaya bhāvataḥ anubyañjanam
translated: For defilements arise in succession, by way of the successive particulars, by way of the successive changes, by way of the successive alterations, of the particulars.

original: hatthapādādiavayavā vuccanti. Tato balavā rañjanaṭṭhena rāgo, saṅkappavaseneva pavatto🔽tatopi balavataro saṅkapparāgo. Svāyaṃ pabhedo ekasseva lobhassa pavattiākāravasena
analyzed: hattha pāda ādi avayavāḥ vuccanti tatas balavā rañjana ṭṭhena rāgaḥ saṅkappa vasena iva pavatto  tatas api balavataraḥ saṅkappa rāgaḥ svāyam pabhedaḥ ekassa iva lobhassa pavatti ākāra vasena
translated: the parts of the hand, foot, etc., are called. From that, lust is the stronger in the sense of delighting. It occurs by way of thought.🔽From that, lust by thought is stronger. This classification should be understood as the mode of occurrence and

original: avatthābhedavasena ca veditabbo yathā “vaccho dammo balībaddo”ti. Kāmāti kilesakāmā,
analyzed: avatthā bheda vasena ca veditabbaḥ yathā vacchaḥ dammaḥ balībaddo iti kāmā ati kilesa kāmā
translated: the classification of the bases of the one greed, just as “calf,” “ox,” and “bull” are. Sensual desires are the sensual desires of defilement.

original: kāmentīti kāmā, kāmenti etehīti vā.
analyzed: kāmenti iti kāmā kāmenti vā
translated: They cause to desire, thus they are sensual desires, or they cause to desire by these, thus they are sensual desires.

original: Seyyathidanti imassa taṃ katamaṃ, taṃ kathanti vā attho. Viviccitvāti visuṃ hutvā.
analyzed: imassa tam katamam tam kathanti vā atthaḥ viviccitvā ati visum hutvā
translated: As to what this is, or what this is, is the meaning of “such as.” Having become separated: having become separate.

original: Tenāha “vinā hutvā apasakkitvā”ti, pajahanavasena apakkamitvāti attho. Vivicceva🔽kāmehīti ettha viviccāti iminā vivecanaṃ jhānakkhaṇe kāmānaṃ abhāvamattaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tena āha vinā hutvā apasakkitvā iti pajahana vasena apakkamitvā iti atthaḥ vivicca iva  kāmehi iti ettha vivicca ati iminā vivecanam jhāna kkhaṇe kāmānam abhāva mattam vuttam
translated: Therefore it is said: “having become separated, having become detached.” The meaning is: having become detached by way of abandoning.🔽Having become separated from sensual desires: here, by “having become separated” the mere absence of sensual desires at the moment of jhāna is stated.

original: Viviccevāti pana iminā ekaṃsato kāmānaṃ vivecetabbatādīpanena tappaṭipakkhatā jhānassa
analyzed: vivicca iva āti pana iminā ekaṃsataḥ kāmānam vivecetabba tā dīpanena tad paṭipakkha tā jhānassa
translated: But by “having become separated from,” the jhāna’s opposition to sensual desires is shown by the indication of the state of being separated from them entirely.

original: kāmavivekappahānassa ca jhānādhigamūpāyatā dassitā hotīti imamatthaṃ dassetuṃ “paṭhamajjhāna”ntiādiṃ
analyzed: kāma viveka ppahānassa ca jhāna adhigama upāya tā dassitā hoti iti imam attham dassetum paṭhama jhāna nti ādiṃ
translated: The meaning of this is stated in the words, “The first jhāna” .🔽The words, “How? ” are stated in order to make the meaning clear.

original: vatvā tamevatthaṃ pākaṭataraṃ kātuṃ “katha”ntiādi vuttaṃ. Andhakāre sati padīpo viyāti
analyzed: vatvā tam eva attham pākaṭataram kātum katham tiādi vuttam andhakāre sati padīpaḥ viyāti
translated: “As the light of a lamp overcomes the darkness” :

original: etena yathā padīpābhāvena rattiyaṃ andhakārābhibhavo, evaṃ jhānābhāvena cittasantatiyaṃ🔽kāmābhibhavoti dasseti.
analyzed: etena yathā padīpa abhāvena rattiyam andhakāra abhibhavaḥ evam jhāna abhāvena citta santatiyam  dassa iti
translated: this shows that just as the darkness in a place is overcome by the light of a lamp, so the sensual desires in the continuity of consciousness are overcome by the light of jhāna.

original: Etanti pubbapadeyeva avadhāraṇavacanaṃ, na kho pana evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ “kāmehi evā”ti
analyzed: etat ti avadhāraṇa vacanam na kho pana evam daṭṭhabbam kāmehi eva ati
translated: The word “eva” in the phrase “kāmehi eva” is a restrictive particle. But it should not be viewed as a restrictive particle, for the reason that it is not stated in the phrase “kāmehi eva” .

original: avadhāraṇassa akatattā. Tannissaraṇatoti nissaranti niggacchanti etena, ettha vāti🔽nissaraṇaṃ. Ke niggacchanti? Kāmā. Tesaṃ kāmānaṃ nissaraṇaṃ pahānaṃ tannissaraṇaṃ,
analyzed: avadhāraṇassa a kata ttā tad nissaraṇato ti nissaranti niggacchanti etena ettha vā ati  nissaraṇam ke niggacchanti kāmā tesam kāmānam nissaraṇam pahānam tat nissaraṇam
translated: “From the surmounting of sensual desires” : they go out from it, they depart from it, thus it is the “surmounting” .🔽What goes out from what? Sensual desires. The surmounting of those sensual desires is their abandoning, their giving up.

original: tato kāmanissaraṇatoti attho. Kathaṃ pana samāne vikkhambhane kāmānamevetaṃ nissaraṇaṃ,
analyzed: tatas kāma nissaraṇato ti atthaḥ katham pana samāne vikkhambhane kāmānam eva etam nissaraṇam
translated: The meaning is: from the surmounting of sensual desires. But how can this be the surmounting of sensual desires when the same sensual desires are present?

original: na byāpādādīnanti codanaṃ yuttito āgamato ca sādhetuṃ “kāmadhātū”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha🔽kāmadhātusamatikkamanatoti sakalassapi kāmabhavassa samatikkamapaṭipadābhāvato. Tena
analyzed: na codanam yuttitaḥ āgamataḥ ca sādhetum kāmadhātu utiādi vuttam tattha  kāmadhātu samatikkamanato ti sakalassa api kāma bhavassa samatikkama paṭipadā abhāvato tena
translated: “Not for ill will, etc.,” is said in order to establish by both reasoning and scripture the fact that this jhāna is not for the purpose of ill will, etc.,

original: imassa jhānassa kāmapariññābhāvamāha. Kāmarāgapaṭipakkhatoti “chando kāmo”tiādinā🔽vuttavibhāgassa kilesakāmassa paccatthikabhāvato. Tena yathā mettā byāpādassa, karuṇā
analyzed: imassa jhānassa kāma pariññā bhāvam āha kāma rāga paṭipakkhato ti chando kāma iti ādinā  vutta vibhāgassa kilesa kāmassa paccatthika bhāvato tena yathā mettā byāpādassa karuṇā
translated: Herein, “because it surmounts the sense sphere” means that it is the way to surmount the whole sense-sphere existence. Thus it shows that this jhāna is the direct opponent of sense-desire by its surmounting of the sense sphere.🔽“Because it is the direct opponent of sense desire” means that it is the direct opponent of the defilement called sense desire, which is analyzed as “sense desire is a term for will” , etc.

original: vihiṃsāya, evamidaṃ jhānaṃ kāmarāgassa ujuvipaccanīkabhūtanti dasseti. Vipākena cettha🔽kāmadhātusamatikkamo attano pavattikkhaṇe kāmarāgapaṭipakkhatā ca veditabbā. Evamattano
analyzed: vihiṃsāya evam idam jhānam kāma rāgassa uju vipaccanīka bhūtanti dasseti vipākena ca ittha  kāmadhātu samatikkamaḥ attanaḥ pavatti kkhaṇe kāma rāga paṭipakkha tā ca veditabbā evam attanaḥ
translated: Thus it shows that this jhāna is the direct opponent of sense desire, just as loving-kindness is the direct opponent of ill will, compassion is the direct opponent of cruelty, and gladness is the direct opponent of aversion.🔽And here the surmounting of the sense sphere and the direct opposition to sense desire should be understood as the result of this jhāna.

original: pavattiyā vipākappavattiyā ca kāmarāgato kāmadhātuto ca vinivattasabhāvattā idaṃ
analyzed: pavattiyā vipāka ppavattiyā ca kāma rāgataḥ kāmadhātutaḥ ca vinivatta sabhāva ttā idam
translated: Thus it is the sense desires themselves and the sense sphere that are turned away from and surmounted by this jhāna, both as its occurrence and as its result.

original: jhānaṃ visesato kāmānameva nissaraṇaṃ, svāyamattho pāṭhāgato evāti āha “yathāhā”tiādi.
analyzed: jhānam visesataḥ kāmānam eva nissaraṇam eva ati āha yathā āha atiādi
translated: So this jhāna is the specific outlet from sense desires, and this meaning is stated in the text too, which is why the Master said “As it is said” , etc.

original: Nekkhammanti paṭhamajjhānaṃ.🔽Kāmañcettha tamatthaṃ dīpetuṃ purimapadeyeva avadhāraṇaṃ gahitaṃ, uttarapadepi pana
analyzed: nekkhammanti paṭhamajjhānam  kāmam ca itthā tam attham dīpetum avadhāraṇam gahitam uttara pade pi pana
translated: “Seclusion” is the first jhāna.

original: taṃ gahetabbameva tathā atthasambhavatoti dassetuṃ “uttarapadepī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Itoti🔽kāmacchandato. Esa daṭṭhabboti esa niyamo daṭṭhabbo. Sādhāraṇavacanenāti sabbavivekasādhāraṇavacanena.🔽Tadaṅgavikkhambhanasamucchedapaṭippassaddhinissaraṇavivekā tadaṅgavivekādayo. Kāyacittaupadhivivekā🔽kāyavivekādayo. Tayo eva idha daṭṭhabbāti tayo eva idha jhānakathāyaṃ daṭṭhabbā samucchedavivekādīnaṃ🔽asambhavato. Niddeseti mahāniddese. Tattha hi “uddānato dve kāmā vatthukāmā kilesakāmā
analyzed: tam gahetabbam eva tathā attha sambhavato ti dassetum uttara pade pi itiādi vuttam itas ti  kāmacchandato esa daṭṭhabbo ti esa niyamaḥ daṭṭhabbo sādhāraṇa vacanena ati sabba viveka sādhāraṇa vacanena  tad aṅga vikkhambhana samuccheda paṭippassaddhi nissaraṇa vivekā tad aṅga viveka ādayaḥ kāya citta aupadhi vivekā  kāya viveka ādayo tayo eva idha daṭṭhabbā ati tayo eva idha jhāna kathā ayam daṭṭhabbā samuccheda viveka ādīnam  asambhavataḥ niddese ti mahāniddese tattha hi uddānataḥ dve kāmā vatthu kāmā kilesa kāmā
translated: Although the restriction is taken in the first phrase in order to illustrate that meaning,

original: cā”ti uddisitvā tattha “katame vatthukāmā manāpiyā rūpā…pe… manāpiyā phoṭṭhabbā”tiādinā
analyzed: ca ati uddisitvā tattha katame vatthu kāmāḥ manāpiyā rūpa āpe manāpiyā phoṭṭhabba ati ādinā
translated: nevertheless it should be taken in the second phrase too, since the meaning is present there. In order to show this it is said: “In the second phrase too” . “From here” : from sense desire. “This restriction should be seen” : this restriction should be seen. “By the words ‘in common’” : by the words “seclusion” in common with all the jhānas. “Seclusion by suppression of the hindrances” , etc., are the “seclusion by suppression of the hindrances” , etc. “Seclusion of body and of mind and of cognizance-and- cognizance-concomitants” are the “seclusion of body” , etc. “Only three should be seen here” : only three should be seen here in the exposition of the jhanas, since the “seclusion by suppression” , etc., are impossible. “In the description” : in the Great Description. For after the description in the Great Description with the words “In brief the kinds of pleasure are two, that of sense desires and that of renunciation” , there is this exposition: “What are the kinds of pleasure of sense desires? There are pleasing visible objects … pleasing tangible objects” .

original: vatthukāmā niddiṭṭhā. Te pana kāmīyantīti kāmāti veditabbā. Tatthevāti niddeseyeva.
analyzed: vatthu kāmā niddiṭṭhā te pana kāmīyanti iti kāmā ati veditabbā tattha iva ati niddeseya iva
translated: The kinds of sensual desires are shown. But they should be understood as “sensual desires” in the sense that those who are subject to lust desire them.🔽“In that same place” means in the place that is being defined.🔽“In the Vibhaṅga” means in the explanation of the jhānas.🔽“When that is so” means when there is inclusion of both kinds of sensual desires in this way.

original: Vibhaṅgeti jhānavibhaṅge. Evañhi satīti evaṃ ubhayesampi kāmānaṃ saṅgahe sati. Vatthukāmehipīti
analyzed: vibhaṅga iti jhāna vibhaṅge evam hi sati iti evam ubhayesam pi kāmānam saṅgahe sati vatthu kāmehi pi iti
translated: The meaning “apart from the kinds of sensual desires as objects” is also appropriate.

original: vatthukāmehi viviccevātipi attho yujjatīti evaṃ yujjamānatthantarasamuccayattho pi-saddo,
analyzed: vatthu kāmehi atthaḥ yujjati iti evam yujjamāna ttha antara samuccaya tthaḥ pi saddaḥ
translated: So the word “and” has the meaning of inclusion of a further meaning that is appropriate,🔽not the meaning of inclusion of the kinds of sensual desires as defilements.

original: na kilesakāmasamuccayattho. Kasmā? Imasmiṃ atthe kilesakāmehi vivekassa dutiyapadena
analyzed: na kilesa kāma samuccaya tthaḥ kasmai imasmin atthe kilesa kāmehi vivekassa dutiya padena
translated: And why? Because the second phrase, “apart from the kinds of sensual desires as defilements,”🔽is stated in this sense. “By that” means by the separation from the kinds of sensual desires as objects.

original: vuttattā. Tenāti vatthukāmavivekena. Kāyaviveko vutto hotīti puttadārādipariggahavivekadīpanato
analyzed: vutta ttā tena ati vatthu kāma vivekena kāya vivekaḥ vuttaḥ hoti iti putta dāra ādi pariggaha viveka dīpanato
translated: “Separation of the mind is stated” because it shows the separation from wife, children, and so on.

original: kāyaviveko vutto hoti.🔽Purimenāti kāyavivekena. Etthāti “vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehī”ti
analyzed: kāya viveko vutto hoti  purimena ati kāya vivekena ettha ati vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi iti
translated: “By the former” means by the separation of the mind.🔽“Here” means in the two phrases, “quite secluded from sensual desires, secluded from unprofitable things.”

original: etasmiṃ padadvaye. Ito vā niddhārite vivekadvaye, akusalasaddena yadi kilesakāmā,
analyzed: etasmin pada dvaye itas vā niddhārite viveka dvaye yadi kilesa kāmā
translated: Or else, after the two kinds of seclusion have been brought in, if the word “unprofitable” refers to the kinds of sensual desires as defilements,

Niddhāraṇe cetaṃ sāmivacanaṃ. Taṇhādisaṃkilesānaṃ vatthuno pahānaṃ saṃkilesavatthuppahānaṃ.🔽Lolabhāvo nāma tattha tattha rūpādīsu taṇhuppādo, tassa hetū vatthukāmā eva veditabbā.
analyzed: sabba akusalā api vā gahitā sabbathā kilesa kāmehi vivekaḥ vuttaḥ ti āha dutiyena kilesa kāmehi  viveka vacanato ti dutiyena ati ca citta vivekena ati attho etesan ti yathāvuttānam dvinnam  padānam niddhāraṇe sāmi vacanam taṇhā ādi saṃkilesānam vatthuno pahānam saṃkilesa vatthu pahānam  lola bhāvaḥ nāma tattha tattha rūpa ādīsu taṇhuppādo tassa hetū vatthu kāmā eva veditabbā
translated: Or else all unprofitable things are included, and the words “seclusion from sense desires” are said with reference to all the defilements as sense desires.🔽“By the second” means by the second, namely, by the seclusion of the mind.🔽“These” refers to the two terms stated thus.🔽This is a word for a master in the sense of “exclusion.” The abandoning of the basis for defilement is the abandoning of the basis for defilement.🔽The state of being greedy is the arising of craving here and there for visible forms, etc., and the sense desires as the basis for that should be understood as the cause.🔽

analyzed: bāla bhāvassa hetu pariccāgaḥ ti sambandhaḥ bāla bhāvaḥ nāma avijjā du cintita cintita ādi 🔽vā tassa a yoniso manasikāro sabbe pi vā akusalāḥ dhammāḥ hetū kāma guṇa adhigama hetu 🔽pāṇa atipāta ādi asuddha ppayogaḥ hoti iti tad bivekena payoga suddhi vibhāvitā taṇhā saṃkilesa sodhanena
translated: Or else all unprofitable things are included, and the word “separation” is said with reference to all kinds of lust for sense desires. So he said: “By the second, by the statement of separation from lust for sense desires.” “By the second” is the same as “by the separation of the mind.” “These” : of the two terms stated thus. This is a word for a master in the sense of “taking up.” “The abandoning of the basis of defilement” is the abandoning of the basis of the defilements beginning with craving. “The state of being greedy” is the arising of craving here and there for visible forms, etc., and the causes of that should be understood as the sense desires as object. The construction is: “the giving up of the cause of the state of being a fool.” “The state of being a fool” is ignorance or wrong thinking, etc., and the cause of that is unwise attention or all unprofitable things. The unprofitable action of killing living things, etc., has as its cause the obtaining of the sense desires. So by the separation of the mind from that, the purification of action is demonstrated. original: vivaṭṭūpanissayasaṃvaḍḍhanena ca ajjhāsayavisodhanaṃ āsayaposanaṃ. Āsayaposananti
analyzed: vivaṭṭu upanissaya saṃvaḍḍhanena ca ajjhāsaya visodhanam āsaya posanam āsaya posananti
translated: And the purification of the heart by the increase of the conditions for the turning round is the nourishing of the heart’s resolve. The nourishing of the heart’s resolve is

original: ca jhānabhāvanāya paccayabhūtā pubbayogādivasena siddhā ajjhāsayasampadā, sā pana
analyzed: ca jhāna bhāvanāya paccaya bhūtā pubba yoga ādi vasena siddhā ajjhāsaya sampadā sā pana
translated: the perfection of the heart’s resolve that is established by previous practice, etc., which is a condition for the development of jhana. But that is

original: taṇhupatāpavigamena hoti. Tena vuttaṃ “taṇhāsaṃkilesavisodhanenā”ti. Kāmesūti niddhāraṇe bhummaṃ.
analyzed: taṇhā upatāpa vigamena hoti tena vuttam taṇhā saṃkilesa visodhanena ati kāmesu iti niddhāraṇe bhummam
translated: with the removal of the burning of craving. Hence it was said above ‘by the purification of the defilement of craving’. In the phrase ‘in the case of sensual desires’ the word ‘case’ is a locative.

original: Anekabhedoti kāmāsavakāmarāgasaṃyojanādivasena rūpataṇhādivasena ca anekappabhedo.
analyzed: aneka bhedaḥ ti kāma āsava kāma rāga saṃyojana ādi vasena rūpa taṇhā ādi vasena ca aneka ppabhedaḥ
translated: It has many divisions: it has many divisions such as the taint of sensual desire, sensual desire as a fetter, etc., and craving for visible forms, etc.

original: Kāmacchandoyevāti kāmasabhāvoyeva chando, na kattukamyatāchando napi kusalacchandoti🔽adhippāyo. Akusalapariyāpannopīti “vivicca akusalehī”ti ettha vuttaakusalesu antogadhopi.
analyzed: chandaḥ na chandaḥ na  adhippāyaḥ akusala pariyāpannaḥ api iti vivicca akusalehi iti ettha vutta akusalesu antogadhaḥ api
translated: It is only will for sensual desires: the intention is that it is only will for what is of the nature of sensual desire, not will for what is desirable, nor will for what is profitable.🔽It is included among the unprofitable: it is included among the unprofitable mentioned in the passage ‘Apart from the unprofitable’ .

original: Jhānapaṭipakkhatoti jhānassa paṭipakkhabhāvato taṃhetu taṃnimittaṃ visuṃ vutto, akusalabhāvasāmaññena
analyzed: jhāna paṭipakkhato ti jhānassa paṭipakkha bhāvataḥ tad hetu tad nimittam visum vuttaḥ akusala bhāva sāmaññena
translated: It is a state opposed to jhana: it is mentioned separately because it is opposed to jhana, and it is not mentioned as a root of unprofit like the others, which are unprofitable by nature.

original: aggahetvā visuṃ sarūpena gahito. Yadi kilesakāmova purimapade vutto, taṃ kathaṃ bahuvacananti
analyzed: aggahetvā visum sarūpena gahitaḥ yadi purima pade vuttaḥ tam katham bahuvacanam ti
translated: and it is not taken separately in its own individual form. If the word “lust” in the first line refers only to defilement-lust, how is it used in the plural?

original: āha “anekabhedato”tiādi. Aññesampīti diṭṭhimānaahirikānottappādīnaṃ taṃsahitaphassādīnañca.🔽Uparijhānaṅgapaccanīkapaṭipakkhabhāvadassanatoti “savitakkaṃ savicāra”ntiādinā upari🔽vuccamānāni jhānaṅgāni uparijhānaṅgāni, tesaṃ attano paccanīkānaṃ paṭipakkhabhāvadassanato🔽tappaccanīkanīvaraṇavacanaṃ. “Uparijhānaṅgānaṃ paccanīkapaṭipakkhabhāvadassanato”tipi
analyzed: āha aneka bhedato tiādi aññesam pi iti diṭṭhi māna ahirika anottappa ādīnam tad sahita phassa ādīnam ca  upari jhāna aṅga paccanīka paṭipakkha bhāva dassanato ti sa vitakkam sa vicāra nti ādinā upari  vuccamānāni jhāna aṅgāni upari jhāna aṅgāni tesam attanaḥ paccanīkānam paṭipakkha bhāva dassanato  tad paccanīka nīvaraṇa vacanam upari jhāna aṅgānam paccanīka paṭipakkha bhāva dassanato ti pi
translated: He says “because of its many kinds” and so on. “Others too” are such things as views, conceit, shamelessness, fearlessness of wrongdoing, and contact associated with them.🔽“Because of showing the state of opposition to the factors of higher jhāna”: the factors of jhāna that are mentioned later in the text beginning with “accompanied by thought and accompanied by examination” are called “factors of higher jhāna.” The words “hindrances that are opposed to the factors of higher jhāna” show that they are opposed to those factors.

original: pāṭho. Tattha paccanīkapaṭipakkhabhāvadassanatoti upari vuccamānajhānaṅgānaṃ ujuvipaccanīkavasena
analyzed: pāṭhaḥ tattha paccanīka paṭipakkha bhāva dassanato ti upari vuccamāna jhāna aṅgānam uju vipaccanīka vasena
translated: There is also a reading “because of showing the state of opposition to the factors of higher jhāna.” Here “opposition” is the direct opposite.

original: paṭipakkhabhāvadassanatoti atthaṃ vadanti. Jhānaṅgapaccanīkānīti jhānaṅgānaṃ pavattinivāraṇato
analyzed: paṭipakkha bhāva dassanato ti attham vadanti jhāna aṅga paccanīkāni iti jhāna aṅgānam pavatti nivāraṇato
translated: The meaning is that they are shown to be the direct opposite of the factors of jhāna mentioned later. “The hindrances that are opposed to the factors of jhāna” means that they prevent the arising of the factors of jhāna.

original: jhānaṅgapaccanīkāni. Viddhaṃsakānīti vighātakāni. Samādhi kāmacchandassa paṭipakkhoti
analyzed: jhānaṅga paccanīkāni viddhaṃsakāni iti vighātakāni samādhi kāmacchandassa paṭipakkhaḥ ti
translated: The jhāna factors are the opposites of the hindrances. “They pierce them” : they destroy them. “Concentration is the opposite of sensual desire” :

original: rāgapaṇidhiyā ujuvipaccanīkabhāvato nānārammaṇehi palobhitassa paribbhamantassa cittassa🔽samādhānato kāmacchandassa samādhi paṭipakkho. Pīti byāpādassāti pāmojjena samānayogakkhemattā
analyzed: rāga paṇidhiyāḥ uju vipaccanīka bhāvataḥ nānā ārammaṇehi palobhitassa paribbhamantassa cittassa  samādhānato kāmacchandassa samādhi paṭipakkhaḥ pi iti byāpādassa ati pāmojjena samāna yogakkhema ttā
translated: because it is the direct opposite of the will to sensual lust, and because it concentrates the mind that is wandering about being tempted by various objects.🔽“Rapture is the opposite of ill will” : because it is the opposite of the state of mind that is ill-tempered and hostile.

original: byāpādassa pīti paṭipakkhā. Vitakko thinamiddhassāti yoniso saṅkappanavasena savipphārappavattito
analyzed: byāpādassa pi iti paṭipakkhā vitakko thinam iddhassa ati yoniso saṅkappana vasena sa vipphāra ppavattito
translated: “Applied thought is the opposite of stiffness and torpor” : because it occurs with the function of directing the mind onto the object and with the characteristic of investigation.

original: vitakko thinamiddhassa paṭipakkho. Sukhaṃ uddhaccakukkuccassāti sukhaṃ vūpasantasītalasabhāvattā🔽avūpasamānutāpasabhāvassa uddhaccakukkuccassa paṭipakkhaṃ. Vicāro vicikicchāyāti
analyzed: vitakko thinam iddhassa paṭipakkhaḥ sukham uddhacca kukkuccassa ati sukham vūpasanta sīta lasa bhāvattā  a vūpasama anutāpasa bhāvassa uddhacca kukkuccassa paṭipakkham vicāraḥ vicikicchāya ati
translated: “Happiness is the opposite of agitation and worry” : because it is the opposite of the state of mind that is not calm and collected.

original: vicāro ārammaṇe anumajjanavasena paññāpatirūpasabhāvattā vicikicchāya paṭipakkho.🔽Mahākaccānattherena desitā piṭakānaṃ saṃvaṇṇanā peṭakaṃ, tasmiṃ peṭake.
analyzed: vicāraḥ ārammaṇe anumajjana vasena vicikicchāya paṭipakkho 🔽mahākaccāna therena desitā piṭakānam saṃvaṇṇanā peṭakam tasmim peṭake
translated: “Sustained thought is the opposite of uncertainty” : because it is the opposite of the state of mind that is wavering and undecided.

original: Pañcakāmaguṇabhedavisayassāti rūpādipañcakāmaguṇavisesavisayassa. Āghātavatthubhedādivisayānanti
analyzed: pañca kāmaguṇa bheda visayassa ati rūpa ādi pañca kāmaguṇa visesa visayassa
translated: “With the five strands of sense pleasure as its object” means with the particular five strands of sense pleasure as its object. “With the object of the various grounds for annoyance” means:

original: byāpādavivekavacanena “anatthaṃ me acarī”tiādiāghātavatthubhedavisayassa dosassa,🔽mohādhikehi thinamiddhādīhi vivekavacanena paṭicchādanavasena dukkhādipubbantādibhedavisayassa
analyzed: byāpāda viveka vacanena anattham me acari iti ādi āghāta vatthu bheda visayassa dosassa  moha adhikehi thinam iddha ādīhi viveka vacanena paṭicchādana vasena dukkha ādi pubbanta ādi bheda visayassa
translated: with the object of the various grounds for annoyance such as “He has done me harm,” which is ill will,🔽and with the object of the various kinds of suffering, etc., which is delusion, by way of concealment,🔽the abandoning of the various kinds of ill will and delusion is stated by the words “the surmounting of ill will” and “the surmounting of the hindrances of stiffness and torpor, etc.”🔽This surmounting of ill will and delusion is stated without distinction, because it is the abandoning of all unwholesome states by the surmounting of sensual lust, etc.,

original: mohassa vikkhambhanaviveko vutto. Kāmarāgabyāpādatadekaṭṭhathinamiddhādivikkhambhakañcetaṃ
analyzed: mohassa vikkhambhana vivekaḥ vutto kāma rāga byāpāda tad eka ṭṭhathina middha ādi vikkhambhakam ca etat
translated: and because it is the abandoning of all unwholesome states by the surmounting of sensual lust, etc.,🔽and because it is the abandoning of all unwholesome states by the surmounting of sensual lust, etc.,

original: sabbākusalapaṭipakkhasabhāvattā sabbakusalānaṃ, tena sabhāvena sabbākusalappahāyakaṃ
analyzed: sabba akusala paṭipakkha sabhāva ttā sabba kusalānam tena sabhāvena sabba akusala ppahāyakam
translated: and because it is the abandoning of all unwholesome states by the surmounting of sensual lust, etc.,🔽and because it is the abandoning of all unwholesome states by the surmounting of sensual lust, etc.,🔽and because it is the abandoning of all unwholesome states by the surmounting of sensual lust, etc.,🔽and because it is the abandoning of all unwholesome states by the surmounting of sensual lust, etc.,

original: hontampi kāmarāgādivikkhambhanasabhāvameva hoti taṃsabhāvattāti avisesetvā nīvaraṇākusalamūlādīnaṃ🔽vikkhambhanaviveko vutto hotīti āha.
analyzed: hontam pi kāma rāga ādi vikkhambhana sabhāvam eva hoti tad sabhāva ttā ati a visesetvā nīvaraṇa akusala mūla ādīnam  vikkhambhana vivekaḥ vuttaḥ hoti iti āha
translated: and because it is the abandoning of all unwholesome states by the surmounting of sensual lust, etc.,🔽and because it is the abandoning of all unwholesome states by the surmounting of sensual lust, etc.,🔽and because it is the abandoning of all unwholesome states by the surmounting of sensual lust, etc.,🔽and because it is the abandoning of all unwholesome states by the surmounting of sensual lust, etc.,🔽and because it is the abandoning of all unwholesome states by the surmounting of sensual lust, etc.,🔽and because it is the abandoning of all unwholesome states by the surmounting of sensual lust, etc.,🔽and because it is the abandoning of all unwholesome states by the surmounting of sensual lust, etc.,🔽and because it is the abandoning of all unwholesome states by the surmounting of sensual lust, etc.,

original: Yathāpaccayaṃ pavattamānānaṃ sabhāvadhammānaṃ natthi kāci vasavattitāti vasavattibhāvanivāraṇatthaṃ
analyzed: yathāpaccayam pavattamānānam sabhāva dhammānam na atthi kāci vasa vatti tā ati vasa vatti bhāva nivāraṇa attham
translated: and because it is the abandoning of all unwholesome states by the surmounting of sensual lust, etc.,🔽and because it is the abandoning of all unwholesome states by the surmounting of sensual lust, etc

original: “vitakkanaṃ vitakko”ti vuttaṃ. Vitakkananti hi vitakkanakiriyā, sā ca vitakkassa
analyzed: vitakkanam vitakko ti vuttam vitakkanan ti hi vitakkana kiriyā sā ca vitakkassa
translated: “Thinking is thinking” is said. For thinking is the action of thinking, and that is the thinking’s

original: attano paccayehi pavattimattamevāti bhāvaniddeso vasavattibhāvanivāraṇāya hoti. Tayidaṃ
analyzed: attanaḥ paccayehi pavattimattam evā ti bhāva niddesaḥ vasa vatti bhāva nivāraṇāya
translated: “The act of thinking is thinking” is said. For thinking is the act of thinking, and that is merely the occurrence of thinking itself by means of its own conditions. So the description of development is given in order to preclude the idea that it is the development of mastery.

original: vitakkanaṃ “īdisamida”nti ārammaṇaparikappananti āha “ūhananti vuttaṃ hotī”ti. Yasmā
analyzed: vitakkanam īdisam idam ti ārammaṇa parikappananti āha ūhananti vuttam hoti iti yasmā
translated: This thinking is the apprehending of an object thus: “It is like this.” So he said “It is said to be the pondering” .

original: cittaṃ vitakkabalena ārammaṇaṃ abhiniruḷhaṃ viya hoti, tasmā so ārammaṇābhiniropanalakkhaṇo
analyzed: cittam vitakka balena ārammaṇam abhiniruḷham viya hoti tasmā saḥ ārammaṇa abhiniropana lakkhaṇo
translated: Since the mind is as if nailed to the object by the force of thinking, it is said to have the characteristic of nailing the mind to an object.

original: vutto. Yathā hi koci rājavallabhaṃ ñātiṃ vā mittaṃ vā nissāya rājagehaṃ ārohati anupavisati,
analyzed: vuttaḥ yathā hi koci rāja vallabham ñātim vā mittam vā nissāya rāja geham ārohati anupavisati
translated: For just as a man climbs up to a royal palace and enters it by depending on a royal favourite or a relation or a friend,🔽so the mind climbs up to the object and enters it by depending on thinking.

original: evaṃ vitakkaṃ nissāya cittaṃ ārammaṇaṃ ārohati. Yadi evaṃ kathaṃ avitakkaṃ cittaṃ🔽ārammaṇaṃ ārohatīti? Vitakkabaleneva. Yathā hi so puriso paricayena tena vināpi nirāsaṅko
analyzed: evam vitakkam nissāya cittam ārammaṇam ārohati yadi evam katham a vitakkam cittam  ārammaṇam ārohati iti vitakka balena iva yathā hi saḥ purisaḥ paricayena tena vinā api nirāsaṅkaḥ
translated: If that is so, how does a thought-free mind climb up to an object?🔽It is by the force of thinking. For just as the man, by his familiarity with it, enters the royal palace without hesitation even without the royal favourite,

original: rājagehaṃ pavisati, evaṃ paricayena vitakkena vināpi avitakkaṃ cittaṃ ārammaṇaṃ ārohati.
analyzed: rāja geham pavisati evam paricayena vitakkena vinā api avitakkam cittam ārammaṇam ārohati
translated: so the thought-free mind climbs up to the object by its familiarity with thinking.

original: Paricayenāti ca santāne pavattavitakkabhāvanāsaṅkhātena paricayena. Vitakkassa hi
analyzed: paricayena ati ca santāne pavatta vitakka bhāvanā saṅkhātena paricayena vitakkassa hi
translated: And by ‘habit’ is meant the repeated occurrence of applied thought in the life-continuum.

original: santāne abhiṇhaṃ pavattassa vasena cittassa ārammaṇābhiruhanaṃ ciraparicitaṃ, tena🔽taṃ kadāci vitakkena vināpi tattha pavattateva. Yathā taṃ ñāṇasahitaṃ hutvā sammasanavasena
analyzed: santāne abhiṇham pavattassa vasena cittassa ārammaṇa abhiruhanam cira paricitam tena  tam kadāci vitakkena vinā api tattha yathā tam ñāṇa sahitam hutvā sammasana vasena
translated: For the mind’s repeated occurrence in the life-continuum with the occurrence of applied thought is long habituated to the object,

original: ciraparicitaṃ kadāci ñāṇarahitampi sammasanavasena pavattati, yathā vā kilesasahitaṃ
analyzed: cira paricitam kadāci ñāṇa rahitam pi sammasana vasena pavattati yathā vā kilesa sahitam
translated: so that sometimes it occurs there even without applied thought. Just as, when it has occurred with knowledge, the adverting occurs later on without knowledge because of the long habit of doing so,

original: hutvā pavattaṃ sabbaso kilesarahitampi paricayena kilesavāsanāvasena pavattati, evaṃsampadamidaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: hutvā pavattam sabbaso kilesa rahitam pi paricayena kilesa vāsanā vasena pavattati evaṃsampadam idam daṭṭhabbam
translated: or just as, when it has occurred with defilement, the adverting occurs later on without defilement because of the long habit of doing so, so too this should be regarded.🔽‘The meaning of striking and striking around’: the striking is the striking at first or the striking face to face.

original: Āhananapariyāhananarasoti ādito, abhimukhaṃ vā hananaṃ āhananaṃ. Parito, parivattitvā
analyzed: āhanana pariyāhanana rasaḥ ti āditas abhimukham vā hananam āhananam paritas
translated: The striking around is the striking after turning away from that.

original: vā āhananaṃ pariyāhananaṃ. “Rūpaṃ rūpaṃ, pathavī pathavī”ti ākoṭentassa viya pavatti
analyzed: vā āhananam pariyāhananam rūpam rūpam pathavī pathavī iti ākoṭentassa viya pavatti
translated: It occurs as if one were striking at ‘materiality, materiality’ and ‘earth, earth.’

original: āhananaṃ pariyāhanananti ca veditabbaṃ. Yasmiñhi ārammaṇe cittaṃ abhiniropeti, taṃ
analyzed: āhananam pariyāhananam ti ca veditabbam yasmin hi ārammaṇe cittam abhiniropeti tam
translated: It should be understood as “striking” and “repeated striking.” For when consciousness strikes an object,

original: tassa gahaṇayogyaṃ karonto vitakko ākoṭento viya hoti. Yadi evaṃ nāgasenattherena
analyzed: tassa gahaṇa yogyam karontaḥ vitakkaḥ ākoṭentaḥ viya hoti yadi evam nāgasena ttherena
translated: volitional formations make it suitable for it to be seized. Volition is like the striking. If that is so, why did the Elder Nāgasena say:

original: “ākoṭanalakkhaṇo vitakko. Yathā, mahārāja, bherī ākoṭitā atha pacchā anuravati anusaddāyati,🔽evameva kho, mahārāja, yathā ākoṭanā, evaṃ vitakko daṭṭhabbo. Atha pacchā anuravanā
analyzed: ākoṭana lakkhaṇaḥ vitakkaḥ yathā mahā rāja bherī ākoṭitā atha pacchā anuravati anusaddāyati  evam eva kho mahā rāja yathā ākoṭanā evam vitakkaḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ atha pacchā anuravanā
translated: “The characteristic of applied thought is striking. Just as, sire, when a drum is struck, then afterwards it resounds and reverberates,

original: anusaddanā, evaṃ vicāro daṭṭhabbo”ti ākoṭanalakkhaṇatā vitakkassa kasmā vuttā? Nāyaṃ🔽virodho. Therena hi kiccasannissitaṃ katvā lakkhaṇaṃ vuttaṃ. Dhammānañhi sabhāvavinimuttā
analyzed: anusaddanā evam vicāraḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ ti ākoṭana lakkhaṇa tā vitakkassa kasmā vuttā na ayam  virodhaḥ therena hi kicca sannissitam katvā lakkhaṇam vuttam dhammānam hi sabhāva vinimuttā
translated: even so, sire, applied thought should be regarded as the striking, and sustained thought as the reverberation and the resounding afterwards.”

original: kāci kiriyā nāma natthi tathā gahetabbākāro ca. Bodhaneyyajanānurodhena pana paramatthato
analyzed: kāci kiriyā nāma natthi tathā gahetabba ākāraḥ ca bodhaneyya jana anurodhena pana paramatthato
translated: This is not a contradiction. For the elder stated the characteristic of applied thought in terms of its function. For there is no action of dhammas apart from their individual essences.

original: ekībhāvopi sabhāvadhammo pariyāyavacanehi viya samāropitarūpehi bahūhi pakārehi pakāsīyati.
analyzed: ekībhāvaḥ api sa bhāva dhammo pariyāya vacanehi viya samāropita rūpehi bahūhi pakārehi pakāsīyati
translated: And the mode of apprehension is the same. But in order to instruct those who are teachable, the single ultimate reality is revealed in many modes, as if it were a multiplicity, by means of synonyms, as if they were different aspects superimposed upon it.

original: Evañhi so suṭṭhu pakāsito hoti. Ānayanapaccupaṭṭhānoti ettha ānayanaṃ citte ārammaṇassa
analyzed: evam hi so suṭṭhu pakāsitaḥ hoti ānayana paccupaṭṭhāno ti ettha ānayanam citte ārammaṇassa
translated: for it is thus that it is well demonstrated. ‘The act of bringing’: here the bringing is the adverting of consciousness to the object.

original: upanayanaṃ, ākaḍḍhanaṃ vā.
analyzed: upanayanam ākaḍḍhanam vā
translated: For it is thus that it is well demonstrated. “The function of bringing about” is the bringing of the object into the mind’s presence, or the dragging of the mind into the object’s presence.

original: Anusañcaraṇaṃ anuparibbhamanaṃ. Svāyaṃ viseso santānamhi labbhamāno eva santāne pākaṭo🔽hotīti daṭṭhabbo. Sesesupi eseva nayo. Anumajjananti ārammaṇe cittassa anumasanaṃ,🔽parimajjananti attho. Tathā hi “vicāro parimajjanahattho viya sañcaraṇahattho viyā”ti
analyzed: anusañcaraṇam anuparibbhamanam su ayam viseso santānamhi labbhamānaḥ eva santāne pākaṭaḥ  hoti iti daṭṭhabbo sesesu pi esa eva nayaḥ anumajjananti ārammaṇe cittassa anumasanaṃ  parimajjananti attho tathā hi vicāraḥ parimajjana hatthaḥ viya sañcaraṇa hatthaḥ viya ati
translated: “The function of traversing” is the traversing, the moving to and fro. And this difference is evident only in a continuity, that is to say, in a series of states.🔽The same method of explanation applies to the rest. “The function of diving in” is the mind’s diving into the object, the meaning is, its plunging in. For it is said, “Applied thought is like a hand in that it plunges in , and sustained thought is like a hand in that it moves to and fro” .

original: ca vutto. Tatthāti ārammaṇe. Sahajātānaṃ anuyojanaṃ ārammaṇe anuvicaraṇasaṅkhātaanumajjanavaseneva
analyzed: ca vuttaḥ tattha ati ārammaṇe sahajātānam anuyojanam ārammaṇe anuvicaraṇa saṅkhāta anumajjana vasena iva
translated: “There” in the object. “The function of directing” should be understood as the directing of the associated states to the object by means of the diving in consisting in the traversing there.

original: veditabbaṃ. Anuppabandhanaṃ ārammaṇe cittassa avicchinnassa viya pavatti. Tathā hi
analyzed: veditabbam anuppabandhanam ārammaṇe cittassa avicchinnassa viya pavatti tathā hi
translated: “The function of binding” is the occurrence of the mind as if uninterruptedly bound to the object. For it is described as “the binding” .

original: so “anuppabandhanatā”ti niddiṭṭho. Teneva ca “ghaṇṭānuravo viya, paribbhamanaṃ viyā”ti
analyzed: so an uppabandhana tā ati niddiṭṭhaḥ tena iva ca ghaṇṭā anuravaḥ viya paribbhamanam viya ati
translated: And it is said, “Like the sound of a bell, like the moving to and fro” .

original: ca vutto. Katthacīti paṭhamajjhāne parittacittuppādesu ca. Oḷārikaṭṭhenāti vicārato🔽oḷārikaṭṭhena. Yathā ghaṇṭābhighātasaddo paṭhamābhinipāto hoti, evaṃ ārammaṇābhimukhaniropanaṭṭhena
analyzed: ca vuttaḥ katthaci iti paṭhama jhāne paritta cittuppādesu ca oḷārika ṭṭhena ati vicārataḥ  oḷārika ṭṭhena yathā ghaṇṭā abhighāta saddo paṭhama abhinipātaḥ hoti evam ārammaṇa abhimukha niropana ṭṭhena
translated: and so on. “In what way?” In the first jhāna and in the first two or three consciousnesses in the cognitive series that arise after it. “In the sense of grossness”: in the sense of grossness due to applied thought.🔽Just as the sound of a bell is the first to be heard when many sounds such as a drum, etc., are beaten together, so too applied thought is the first to be known in the sense of directing the mind on to the object.

original: vitakko cetaso paṭhamābhinipāto viya hotīti āha “ghaṇṭābhighātasaddo viyā”tiādi.
analyzed: vitakko cetaso paṭhama abhinipātaḥ viya hoti iti āha ghaṇṭā abhighāta saddo viya atiādi
translated: That is why it is said, “like the sound of a bell.”

original: Vipphāravāti ettha vipphāro nāma vitakkassa thinamiddhapaṭipakkho ārammaṇe anolīnatā🔽asaṅkoco, so pana abhiniropanabhāvena calanaṃ viya hotīti adhippāyenāha “paripphandanabhāvo
analyzed: vipphāravā ti ettha vipphāraḥ nāma vitakkassa thinam iddha paṭipakkho ārammaṇe anolīna tā  asaṅkocaḥ saḥ pana abhiniropana bhāvena calanam viya hoti iti adhippāyena āha paripphandana bhāvaḥ
translated: “In the sense of diffusing”: the diffusing is the opposite of stiffness and torpor. It is the non-sluggishness, the non-dullness, in the adverting of consciousness to the object.

original: cittassā”ti. Paribbhamanaṃ viyāti ettha parissayābhāvavīmaṃsanatthaṃ paribbhamananti
analyzed: cittassa ati paribbhamanam viyā ti ettha parissaya abhāva vīmaṃsana attham paribbhamanam ti
translated: But that is like shaking because of the shaking of the adverting. That is the intention in the words, “the shaking of consciousness.”🔽“Like the shaking of a bird’s wings”: here the shaking should be understood as the shaking of the wings of a great bird flying in the air that shakes them in order to test whether they are strong enough to support it.

original: karontassa majjhe sannirumbhitvā ṭhitakaṇṭako viya abhiniropano vitakko, bahi paribbhamanakaṇṭako🔽viya anumajjano vicāroti veditabbaṃ.

translated: and they are shown by being distributed according to individual essence.
