original: sītacchāyāya mandamande vāte paharante nipannova “aho sukhaṃ aho sukha”nti vadeyya,
analyzed: manda mande vāte paharante nipannā uva aho sukham aho sukham ti vadeyya
translated: and he would lie down in the cool shade, fanned by a gentle breeze, and he would say: “Ah, what happiness! Ah, what happiness!”

original: evaṃsampadamidaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Tassa hi purisassa jātassaravanasaṇḍasavanato paṭṭhāya🔽yāva udakadassanā haṭṭhapahaṭṭhakālo viya pubbabhāgārammaṇe haṭṭhapahaṭṭhākārā pīti,🔽nhāyitvā ca pivitvā ca sītacchāyāya mandamande vāte paharante “aho sukhaṃ aho sukha”nti
analyzed: evaṃsampadam idam daṭṭhabbam tassa hi purisassa paṭṭhāya  yāva udaka dassanā haṭṭha pahaṭṭha kālaḥ viya pubba bhāga ārammaṇe haṭṭha pahaṭṭha ākārā pi iti  nhāyitvā ca pivitvā ca sīta chāyāya manda mande vāte paharante aho sukham aho sukhanti
translated: This should be regarded as a simile. For the man’s state of being thrilled and elated begins with the hearing of the sound of the waterfall🔽and continues up to the seeing of the water. So too, the happiness called “happiness born of pleasure” is the state of being thrilled and elated due to the object of the first jhāna.

original: vadanto nipannakālo viya balappattaṃ ārammaṇarasānubhavanākārasaṇṭhitaṃ sukhaṃ.
analyzed: vadantaḥ nipanna kālaḥ viya bala ppattam ārammaṇa rasa anubhavana ākāra saṇṭhitam sukham
translated: And the happiness called “happiness born of concentration” is the state of being settled in the happiness of savouring the taste of the object that has reached absorption.

original: Tasmiṃ tasmiṃ samayeti iṭṭhārammaṇassa paṭilābhasamaye paṭiladdhassa rasānubhavanasamaye
analyzed: tasmin tasmin samaye iti iṭṭha ārammaṇassa paṭilābha samaye paṭiladdhassa rasa anubhavana samaye
translated: “In each case” means at the time of obtaining a desirable object, at the time of savouring the taste of what is obtained,

original: vanacchāyādīnaṃ savanadassanasamaye paribhogasamaye ca. Pākaṭabhāvatoti yathākkamaṃ
analyzed: vana chāyā ādīnam savana dassana samaye paribhoga samaye ca pākaṭa bhāvato ti yathākkamam
translated: at the time of hearing and seeing the shade of the trees, etc., and at the time of using them. “By reason of its being evident” means🔽by reason of the happiness and the bliss becoming evident respectively.

original: pītisukhānaṃ vibhūtabhāvato. Vivekajaṃ pītisukhanti ettha purimasmiṃ atthe vivekajanti
analyzed: vibhūta bhāvataḥ viveka jam ettha purimasmin atthe viveka janti
translated: “Born of seclusion”: here the meaning of “seclusion” is the jhāna itself,

original: jhānaṃ vuttaṃ. Pītisukhasaddato ca atthiatthavisesavato assa jhānassa, asmiṃ vā jhāneti
analyzed: jhānam vuttam pīti sukha saddato ca atthi attha visesavataḥ assa jhānassa asmim vā jhāne ti
translated: and the meaning of “born of seclusion” is either that the jhāna is secluded from the defilements and from the hindrances or that it has secluded it.

original: ettha akāro daṭṭhabbo yathā arisasoti. Dutiye pītisukhameva vivekajaṃ, vivekajaṃpītisukhanti
analyzed: ettha akāraḥ daṭṭhabbaḥ yathā ari sasā iti dutiye pīti sukham eva viveka jam viveka jam pīti sukham ti
translated: Here the letter a is to be seen as in the word “arisa” .🔽In the second jhāna the bliss and happiness are born of seclusion, and seclusion is the meaning of the word “born of seclusion” .

original: ca aññapadatthasamāso paccattaniddesassa ca alopo kato, lope vā sati “vivekajapītisukha”nti
analyzed: ca añña padattha samāsaḥ paccatta niddesassa ca a lopaḥ kataḥ lope vā sati viveka ja pīti sukhanti
translated: Or the compound may be resolved as “the bliss and happiness born of seclusion are the second” .

original: pāṭhoti ayaṃ viseso.🔽Gaṇanānupubbato paṭhamanti iminā desanākkamaṃ ulliṅgeti. “Gaṇanānupubbatā paṭhama”ntipi
analyzed: ayam visesaḥ  gaṇanā anupubbataḥ iminā desanā kkamam ulliṅgeti gaṇanā anupubbatā
translated: This is the difference here.🔽By “first” in the sense of first in numerical series he shows the order of teaching.

original: pāṭho, tatthāpi gaṇanānupubbatāyāti attho, gaṇanānupubbatāmattaṃ vā paṭhamanti idaṃ
analyzed: tattha api gaṇanā anupubba tāya ati atthaḥ gaṇanā anupubba tā mattam vā paṭhamam ti idam
translated: Or the reading may be “paṭhamaṃ gaṇanānupubbatā” , in which case the meaning is “first in the order of counting” , or “first in the sense of first in the order of counting” is what is said.

original: vacananti attho. Paṭhamaṃ samāpajjatīti paṭhamanti idaṃ pana na ekantalakkhaṇaṃ.🔽Ciṇṇavasībhāvo hi aṭṭhasamāpattilābhī ādito paṭṭhāya matthakaṃ pāpentopi samāpajjituṃ🔽sakkoti, matthakato paṭṭhāya ādiṃ pāpentopi samāpajjituṃ sakkoti, antarantarā okkamantopi
analyzed: vacanam ti attho paṭhamam samāpajjati iti paṭhamam ti idam pana na ekanta lakkhaṇam 🔽ciṇṇavasībhāvaḥ hi aṭṭha samāpatti lābhī āditaḥ paṭṭhāya matthakam pāpentaḥ api samāpajjitum 🔽sakkoti matthakato paṭṭhāya ādim pāpentaḥ api samāpajjitum sakkoti antar antarā okkamantaḥ api
translated: But the meaning of “he enters upon it first” is not a specific characteristic.

original: sakkoti. Evaṃ pubbuppattiyaṭṭhena pana paṭhamaṃ uppannantipi paṭhamaṃ. Teneva visuddhimagge
analyzed: sakkoti evam pubbuppattiyaṭṭhena pana paṭhamam uppannanti pi paṭhamam tena iva visuddhi magge
translated: He is able to. And it is in this way that it is the first in the sense of what comes first. That is why it is said in the Visuddhimagga:

original: “gaṇanānupubbatā paṭhamaṃ, paṭhamaṃ uppannantipi paṭhama”nti ettakameva vuttaṃ. Paccanīkadhamme
analyzed: gaṇanā anupubba tā paṭhamam paṭhamam uppannam ti pi paṭhamam ti ettakam eva vuttam paccanīka dhamme
translated: “It is the first because of the order of enumeration, and it is the first because it arises first” .

original: jhāpetīti nīvaraṇādipaccanīkadhamme dahati, vikkhambhanavasena pajahatīti attho.
analyzed: jhāpeti iti nīvaraṇa ādi paccanīka dhamme dahati vikkhambhana vasena pajahati iti attho
translated: It burns up the states that are adverse to it: the meaning is that it abandons them by suppression.

original: Gocaranti kasiṇādiālambanaṃ. Tanti taṃ gocaraṃ. Upanijjhāyatīti passati. Saha upacārenāti
analyzed: gocaranti kasiṇa ādi ālambanam tanti tam gocaram upanijjhāyati iti passati saha upacārena ati
translated: The domain: the object consisting of the kasiṇa, and so on. That: that domain. He looks on: he sees. Together with access:

original: saddhiṃ upacārajjhānena. Kasiṇārammaṇūpanijjhāyanatoti pathavīkasiṇādino attano ārammaṇassa🔽rūpaṃ viya cakkhunā upanijjhāyanato. Lakkhaṇūpanijjhāyanatoti yathāsambhavaṃ aniccādilakkhaṇattayassa
analyzed: saddhim upacāra jhānena kasiṇa ārammaṇa upanijjhāyanataḥ ti pathavī kasiṇa ādinaḥ attanaḥ ārammaṇassa  rūpam viya cakkhunā upanijjhāyanataḥ lakkhaṇa upanijjhāyanataḥ ti yathāsambhavam anicca ādi lakkhaṇa ttayassa
translated: together with the jhāna that is access to it. Because he looks on at the object of the kasiṇa: because he looks on at his own object, the earth kasiṇa, and so on,

original: nibbānadhātuyā tathalakkhaṇassa ca upanijjhāyanato. Tenevāha “ettha hī”tiādi. Niccādivipallāsappahānena
analyzed: nibbāna dhātuyāḥ tatha lakkhaṇassa ca upanijjhāyanato tena iva āha ettha hi itiādi nicca ādi vipallāsa ppahānena
translated: as though with the eye at visible form. Because he looks on at the characteristics: because he looks on at the three characteristics, namely, impermanence, and so on, and the characteristic of that in nibbāna, as they occur. That is why he says “Herein, firstly,” and so on.🔽By abandoning the perversions of permanence, and so on:

original: maggo asammohato aniccādilakkhaṇāni upanijjhāyatīti lakkhaṇūpanijjhānanti āha “vipassanāya🔽upanijjhāyanakicca”ntiādi. Tathalakkhaṇanti avināsadhammassa nibbānassa anaññathābhāvato
analyzed: maggaḥ asammohataḥ anicca ādi lakkhaṇāni upanijjhāyati iti lakkhaṇa upanijjhānan ti āha vipassanāya  upanijjhāyana kicca ntiādi tatha lakkhaṇa ti avināsa dhammassa nibbānassa anaññathābhāvato
translated: The path is called “contemplation of the characteristics” because it contemplates the characteristics of impermanence, etc., by way of non-delusion.🔽The meaning is that it performs the function of contemplation in insight.🔽The meaning of “contemplation of the suchness of the characteristics” is this: since Nibbāna, which is the characteristic of the unformed, is not subject to destruction, it is suchness.

original: aviparītasabhāvo tathalakkhaṇaṃ, maggassapi vā nibbānārammaṇato tathalakkhaṇūpanijjhānatā yojetabbā.
analyzed: aviparīta sabhāvaḥ tatha lakkhaṇam maggassa api vā nibbāna ārammaṇato tatha lakkhaṇa upanijjhāna tā yojetabbā
translated: The meaning of “contemplation of the suchness of the path” is this: since the path has Nibbāna as its object, it is suchness.

original: Visadisodāharaṇaṃ tāva dassento āha “yathā sadhano”tiādi. Añño apadesāraho hotīti
analyzed: visadisa udāharaṇam tāva dassentaḥ āha yathā sa dhana utiādi aññaḥ apadesa arahaḥ hoti iti
translated: In order to show a dissimilar example, he says, “Just as one who has wealth,” etc.

original: dhanato parijanato ca añño dhanavā parijanavā ca puriso saha dhanena vattati parijanena
analyzed: dhanataḥ parijanataḥ ca aññaḥ dhanavā parijanavā ca puriso saha dhanena vattati parijanena
translated: One who has wealth and retinue is one who has wealth and a retinue. He is worthy of mention because of his wealth and retinue.

original: cāti sadhano saparijanoti apadesaṃ arahatīti apadesāraho hoti, apadisitabbo hotīti
analyzed: ca ati sa dhanaḥ sa parijanaḥ iti apadesam arahati iti apadesa arahaḥ hoti apadisitabbaḥ hoti iti
translated: He is called “worthy of mention” because he is to be mentioned.🔽The meaning is that he is to be spoken of.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Senaṅgesu eva senāsammutīti rathādisenaṅgavinimuttāya senāya abhāvepi
analyzed: vuttam hoti senaṅgesu eva senā sammuti iti ratha ādi senaṅga vinimuttāya senāya abhāve pi
translated: Although there is no army apart from the army’s requisites such as chariots, etc.,

original: rathehi pattīhi ca saha vattanato sarathā sapatti senāti rathādisenaṅgesuyeva senāvohāroti
analyzed: rathehi pattīhi ca saha vattanato sa rathā sa patti senā ati senā vohāraḥ iti
translated: Because it occurs together with chariots and foot-soldiers, the army is called “with chariots and foot-soldiers” . The meaning is that the term “army” is a collective term for the component parts of an army, such as chariots, etc.

original: attho. Kasmā panettha jhānapāṭhe aggahitā cittekaggatā gahitāti anuyogaṃ sandhāyāha
analyzed: atthaḥ kasmā pana ittha jhāna pāṭhe aggahitā citta ekagga tā gahitā iti anuyogam sandhāya āha
translated: But why is unification of mind, which is included in the jhāna, not mentioned in the description of the first jhāna?🔽“Because it is not stated” , etc.

original: “avuttattā”tiādi. Evaṃ vuttāyevāti evaṃ sarūpato vibhaṅge vuttāyeva. Sacittekaggatanti🔽idha avuttepīti “sacittekaggata”nti evaṃ sarūpato imasmiṃ jhānapāṭhe avuttepīti attho,
analyzed: a vutta ttā ati ādi evam vuttāya iva ati evam sarūpataḥ vibhaṅge vuttāya iva sa citta ekagga tat ti  idha a vutte api iti evam sarūpataḥ imasmin jhāna pāṭhe a vutte api iti attho
translated: It is mentioned only in the description of the second jhāna, etc.,🔽and it is mentioned in the Vibhaṅga only in the way beginning, “Herein, what is unification of mind? It is this: confidence” .🔽But it is included in the jhāna by its general characteristic, though not mentioned by its particular name.

original: sāmaññato pana jhānaggahaṇena gahitā eva. Tenevāha “yena hī”tiādi. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti
analyzed: sāmaññato pana jhāna ggahaṇena gahitāḥ eva tena iva āha yena hi itiādi idam vuttam hoti
translated: That is why he said, “For the purpose of which” , etc. This is the meaning:

original: – yena vitakkādīhi saha vattabbaṃ, taṃ dhammaṃ dīpetuṃ tassa pakāsanādhippāyena “savitakkaṃ
analyzed: yena vitakka ādīhi saha vattabbam tam dhammam dīpetum tassa pakāsana adhippāyena sa vitakkam
translated: the purpose for the sake of which the exposition was undertaken by the words “accompanied by thought and examination” , etc., was to show that state accompanied by those things beginning with thought.

original: savicāra”ntiādinā uddeso kato, so eva adhippāyo tena bhagavatā vibhaṅge “cittassekaggatā”ti
analyzed: uddeso kato so eva adhippāyo tena bhagavatā vibhaṅge cittassa ekagga tā ti
translated: That purpose is fulfilled by the mere mentioning of the jhāna itself by the words “the second jhāna” , etc., so there is no need to mention unification of mind as well.

original: niddisantena pakāsito, tasmā sā jhānapāṭhe aggahitāti na cintetabbanti.
analyzed: niddisantena pakāsitaḥ tasmā sā jhāna pāṭhe aggahitā iti na cintetabbanti
translated: That is why it is not mentioned in the description of the first jhāna.

original: Upasampajjāti ettha upa-saṃsaddā “upalabbhatī”tiādīsu viya niratthakāti dassetuṃ
analyzed: upasampajja ati ettha upasaṃsaddā upalabbhati iti ādīsu viya niratthakā ati dassetum
translated: ‘He attains’: here the prefix upa in the word upasampajja is meaningless, like the upa in such words as upalabbhati, upacita, and upasampajja.🔽In order to show that it is meaningless, he said ‘having gone up to’ and so on.

original: “upagantvā”tiādiṃ vatvā puna tesaṃ sātthakabhāvaṃ dassetuṃ “upasampādayitvā”tiādi
analyzed: upagantvā atiādim vatvā puna tesam sātthaka bhāvam dassetuṃ upasampādayitvā atiādi
translated: Then in order to show that it has a meaning he said ‘having attained’ and so on.🔽So here the meaning of upasampajja is ‘having gone up to’ or ‘having accomplished.’

original: vuttaṃ, tasmā upasampajjāti ettha patvā sādhetvāti vā attho. Iriyanti kiriyaṃ. Vuttintiādīni
analyzed: vuttam tasmai upasampajja āti ettha patvā sādhetvā ati vā attho iriyanti kiriyam vutti nti ādīni
translated: ‘Posture’: action. ‘Livelihood’ and the rest

original: tasseva vevacanāni. Ekaṃ iriyāpathabādhanaṃ iriyāpathantarehi rakkhaṇaṃ pālanaṃ.
analyzed: tassa iva vevacanāni ekam iriyāpatha bādhanam iriyāpatha antarehi rakkhaṇam pālanam
translated: are synonyms for it. ‘One posture’ is the guarding and protecting of one posture by means of another when one is hindered by the first.

original: Sabbabuddhānaṃ āciṇṇattā ānāpānassatikammaṭṭhānameva vuttaṃ. Tañhi sabbabuddhānaṃ āciṇṇanti vadanti.
analyzed: sabba buddhānam āciṇṇa ttā āna apāna ssati kammaṭṭhānam eva vuttam tat hi sabba buddhānam āciṇṇam ti vadanti
translated: It is said that only mindfulness of breathing is the subject of meditation practised by all Buddhas, for they say that it is the subject of meditation practised by all Buddhas.

original: Paṭhamajjhānakathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: paṭhama jhāna kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the first jhāna is ended.

original: Dutiyajjhānakathā🔽Vūpasamāti vūpasamahetu. Vūpasamoti cettha pahānaṃ adhippetaṃ, tañca vitakkavicārānaṃ
analyzed: dutiya jhāna kathā  vūpasamā ati vūpasama hetu vūpasamaḥ ti ca ittha pahānam adhippetam tat ca
translated: The explanation of the second jhāna

original: atikkamo atthato dutiyajjhānakkhaṇe anuppādoti āha “samatikkamā”tiādi. Katamesaṃ
analyzed: atikkamaḥ atthataḥ dutiya jhāna kkhaṇe anuppādaḥ ti āha samatikkama atiādi katamesam
translated: ‘Fading away’: the cause of fading away. ‘Fading away’ here is intended as abandoning. And that is the surmounting of applied and sustained thought in the sense of their non- occurrence at the moment of the second jhāna. So he said ‘with the surmounting’ and so on. Of what?

original: panettha vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamo adhippeto, kiṃ paṭhamajjhānikānaṃ, udāhu dutiyajjhānikānanti,
analyzed: pana ittha vitakka vicārānam vūpasamaḥ adhippeto kim paṭhama jhānikānam udāhu dutiya jhānikānam ti
translated: But here the intention is to point to the stilling of applied and sustained thought, and it is asked whether it is the stilling of those of the first jhāna or of those of the second jhāna.

original: kiñcettha – yadi paṭhamajjhānikānaṃ, natthi tesaṃ vūpasamo. Na hi kadāci paṭhamajjhānaṃ🔽vitakkavicārarahitaṃ atthi. Atha dutiyajjhānikānaṃ, evampi nattheva vūpasamo sabbena
analyzed: kiñca ittha yadi paṭhamajjhānikānam na atthi tesam vūpasamaḥ na hi kadāci paṭhamajjhānam  vitakka vicāra rahitam atthi atha dutiya jhānikānam evam pi nattha iva vūpasamaḥ sabbena
translated: And here, if it is the stilling of those of the first jhāna, there is none, since the first jhāna🔽is never without applied and sustained thought. But if it is the stilling of those of the second jhāna, there is none either, since they are absent there

original: sabbaṃ tesaṃ tattha abhāvatoti imaṃ anuyogaṃ sandhāyāha “tattha kiñcāpī”tiādi. Yasmā
analyzed: sabbam tesam tattha abhāvato ti imam anuyogam sandhāya āha tattha kiñcā api itiādi yasmā
translated: altogether. This is the intention here. And it is in order to show this that he said, “Here, although … stilling of applied and sustained thought is not stated separately as a factor of the second jhāna” .

original: diṭṭhādīnavassa taṃtaṃjhānakkhaṇe anuppattidhammatāpādanaṃ vūpasamanaṃ adhippetaṃ,
analyzed: diṭṭha ādīnavassa taṃ taṃ jhāna kkhaṇe anuppatti dhamma tā āpādanam vūpasamanam adhippetam
translated: For what is intended is the stilling of the occurrence of the danger in each case, which has arisen in the first jhāna, etc.,

original: vitakkādayo eva ca jhānaṅgabhūtā tathā karīyanti, na taṃsampayuttā phassādayo, tasmā🔽vitakkādīnaṃyeva vūpasamādhivacanaṃ jhāne āgataṃ. Yasmā pana vitakkādīnaṃ viya taṃsampayuttadhammānampi
analyzed: vitakka ādayaḥ eva ca tathā na phassa ādayaḥ 🔽vitakka ādīnam yeva jhāne āgatam pana vitakka ādīnam viya
translated: and it is only the applied thought, etc., that are so classed as factors of the first jhāna, etc., and not the contact, etc., associated with them.🔽That is why the words “stilling of applied and sustained thought” are said of the applied and sustained thought only in the first and second jhānas respectively. But just as the words “stilling of applied and sustained thought” are said of the applied and sustained thought in the second jhāna, so too the words “signless” should be said of the sign of that jhāna, that is, of the applied thought, etc., in the second jhāna. And the words “void” should be said of the voidness of that jhāna, that is, of the voidness consisting in the absence of applied thought, etc., in the second jhāna. And the words “desireless” should be said of the desirelessness of that jhāna, that is, of the desirelessness consisting in the absence of desire for applied thought, etc., in the second jhāna. And the words “desireless” should be said of the desirelessness of that jhāna, that is, of the desirelessness consisting in the absence of desire for applied thought, etc., in the second jhāna. And the words “desireless” should be said of the desirelessness of that jhāna, that is, of the desirelessness consisting in the absence of desire for applied thought, etc., in the second jhāna. And the words “desire

original: “etena etaṃ oḷārika”nti ādīnavadassanaṃ sutte āgataṃ, tasmā avisesena vitakkādīnaṃ
analyzed: etena etam oḷārikam ti ādīnava dassanam sutte āgatam tasmai avisesena vitakka ādīnam
translated: “By this it is gross” and so on is said in the texts to show the seeing of the danger in it. Therefore, when it is necessary to say of the stilling, etc., of applied thoughts, etc., and of what is associated with them,

original: taṃsahagatānañca vūpasamādike vattabbe vitakkādīnaṃyeva vūpasamo vuccamāno adhikavacanaṃ
analyzed: tad sahagatānam ca vūpasama ādike vattabbe vitakka ādīnam yeva vūpasamaḥ vuccamānaḥ adhika vacanam
translated: without distinction, it is the stilling of applied thoughts, etc., that is mentioned. This is a more specific expression

original: aññamatthaṃ bodhetīti katvā kañci visesaṃ dīpetīti dassento “oḷārikassa panā”tiādimāha.🔽Ayañhettha adhippāyo – yehi vitakkavicārehi paṭhamajjhānassa oḷārikatā, tesaṃ samatikkamā
analyzed: aññam attham bodheti iti katvā kañci visesam dīpeti iti dassentaḥ oḷārikassa pana atiādim āha  ayam ha ittha adhippāyaḥ yehi vitakka vicārehi paṭhamajjhānassa oḷārika tā tesam samatikkamā
translated: and so it indicates some distinction, showing that it “informs of a different meaning.”

original: dutiyajjhānassa samadhigamo, na sabhāvato anoḷārikānaṃ phassādīnaṃ samatikkamāti🔽ayamattho “vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā”ti etena dīpito, tasmā “kiṃ paṭhamajjhānikānaṃ
analyzed: dutiya jhānassa samadhigamaḥ na sabhāvataḥ anoḷārikānam phassa ādīnam samatikkamāti  ayam atthaḥ vitakka vicārānam etena dīpitaḥ tasmā kim paṭhama jhānikānam
translated: The intention here is this. It is by the applied thoughts and the sustained thoughts that the first jhāna is gross. So it is the surmounting of these that is meant by the attainment of the second jhāna, not the surmounting of the other factors such as contact, etc., that are not gross by nature.🔽So the meaning intended by the words “with the stilling of applied and sustained thought” is this: “It is by the surmounting of the applied thought and the sustained thought that are gross that the second jhāna is entered upon and dwelt in.”

original: vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamo idhādhippeto, udāhu dutiyajjhānikāna”nti edisī codanā anokāsāva.
analyzed: vitakka vicārānam vūpasamaḥ idha adhippetaḥ udāhu dutiya jhānikānam ti edisī codanā
translated: Therefore the question “Is it the stilling of the applied and sustained thought of the first jhāna that is intended here, or that of the second jhāna?” is out of place.

original: “Pītiyā ca virāgā”tiādīsupi eseva nayo. Tasmā vitakkavicārapītisukhasamatikkamavacanāni
analyzed: ca virāga ati ādīsu pi esa iva tasmā vitakka vicāra pīti sukha sama ti kama vacanāni
translated: The same method of explanation applies also in the case of the words “with the fading away of happiness” and so on. So the words “with the surmounting of applied and sustained thought”

original: oḷārikoḷārikaṅgasamatikkamā dutiyādiadhigamadīpakānīti tesaṃ ekadesabhūtaṃ vitakkavicārasamatikkamavacanaṃ
analyzed: oḷārika uḷārika aṅga samatikkamāḥ dutiya ādi adhigama dīpakāni iti tesam eka desa bhūtam vitakka vicāra samatikkama vacanam
translated: The words “and the surmounting of applied and sustained thought” indicate the second jhāna, etc., as well as the first.

original: avayavena samudāyopalakkhaṇanayena taṃ dīpakaṃ vuttaṃ. Visuṃ visuṃ ṭhitepi hi vitakkavicārasamatikkamavacanādike🔽paheyyaṅganiddesatāsāmaññena cittena samūhato gahite vitakkavicāravūpasamavacanassa
analyzed: avayavena samudāya upalakkhaṇa nayena tam dīpakam vuttam visum visum ṭhite api hi vitakka vicāra sama tikkama vacana ādike  cittena samūhataḥ gahite vitakka vicāra vūpasama vacanassa
translated: So they are said to indicate them by a part. For although the words “with the surmounting of applied and sustained thought” and so on are actually stated separately,🔽nevertheless, when the mind is taken as the subject of the act of surmounting, then the words “with the stilling of applied and sustained thought”

original: tadekadesatā hotīti. Atha vā vitakkavicāravūpasamavacaneneva taṃsamatikkamā dutiyādiadhigamadīpakena🔽pītivirāgādivacanānaṃ pītiādisamatikkamā tatiyādiadhigamadīpakatā dīpitā hotīti tassa
analyzed: tad eka desa tā hoti iti atha vā vitakka vicāra vūpasama vacanena iva dutiya ādi adhigama dīpakena  pīti virāga ādi vacanānam pīti ādi samatikkamā tatiya ādi adhigama dīpaka tā dīpitā hoti iti tassa
translated: indicate the surmounting of applied and sustained thought by a part of it. Or alternatively, the words “with the surmounting of applied and sustained thought” indicate the second jhāna, etc., as well as the first,🔽by indicating the surmounting of applied and sustained thought. And that is said to indicate them by a part.

original: taṃdīpakatā vuttā. Evañhi avayavena samudāyopalakkhaṇaṃ vinā vitakkavicāravūpasamavacanena
analyzed: tad dīpaka tā vuttā evam hi avayavena samudāya upalakkhaṇam vinā vitakka vicāra vūpasama vacanena
translated: So the words “with the fading away of happiness” and so on are said to indicate them by a part. For in this way, without the indication of the whole aggregate, the words “with the fading away of happiness”

original: pītivirāgādivacanānaṃ savisaye samānabyāpāratā dassitā hoti.
analyzed: pīti virāga ādi vacanānam sa visaye samāna byāpāra tā dassitā hoti
translated: show that they have the same function in their respective fields.

original: Ajjhattanti niyakajjhattaṃ adhippetaṃ, na ajjhattajjhattādīti dassento āha “ajjhattanti🔽niyakajjhattaṃ adhippeta”nti. Tattha kāraṇamāha “vibhaṅge panā”tiādi. Pana-saddopi
analyzed: ajjhattam ti niyaka ajjhattam adhippetam na ajjhatta ajjhatta ādi iti dassentaḥ āha ajjhattam ti  niyaka jjhattam adhippetanti tattha kāraṇam āha vibhaṅge pana atiādi pana saddaḥ api
translated: “Internally” is intended as one’s own internal . Showing that it is not the internal of the internal, etc., he says, “Internally means one’s own internal . ” Here he gives the reason, “But in the Vibhaṅga” , etc. The word “but” is used to reject the opinion of the Abhidhamma teachers.

original: apisaddattho, vibhaṅgepīti attho. Ayameva vā pāṭho.
analyzed: api sadda atthaḥ vibhaṅge pi iti atthaḥ ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ
translated: “Internally” is intended as one’s own internal . Showing that it is not the internal-external, etc., he says, “Internally is intended as one’s own internal.” Here he gives the reason, “But in the Vibhaṅga,” etc. The word pana is also equivalent to api; the meaning is, “in the Vibhaṅga also.” Or this is the reading.

original: Nīlavaṇṇayogato nīlavatthaṃ viyāti nīlayogato vatthaṃ nīlaṃ viyāti adhippāyo. Imasmiñca🔽atthavikappeti “ceto sampasādayatī”ti etasmiṃ pakkhe. Cetasoti ca upayogatthe sāmivacanaṃ.
analyzed: nīla vaṇṇa yogataḥ nīla vattham viyāti nīla yogataḥ vattham nīlam viyāti adhippāyaḥ imasmin ca  attha vikappeti cetaḥ sampasādayati iti etasmin pakkhe cetasā iti ca upayoga atthe sāmi vacanam
translated: The intention is this: “Just as a cloth is called ‘blue’ because of its connection with blue, so too the jhāna is called ‘with internal confidence’ because of its connection with confidence.”🔽And in this context, in the Vibhaṅga passage, “confidence is confidence, faith, trust, full confidence, a characteristic of confidence, a state of confidence, resoluteness in the Buddha, resoluteness in the Dhamma, resoluteness in the Saṅgha,” the word “confidence” is a word for a state.

original: Purimasminti “sampasādanayogato jhānampi sampasādana”nti vuttapakkhe. Cetasoti sambandhe🔽sāmivacanaṃ. “Yāva na pare ekagate karomī”tiādīsu seṭṭhavacanopi ekasaddo loke dissatīti
analyzed: purimasmin ti sampasādana yogataḥ jhānam pi sampasādananti vutta pakkhe cetasaḥ iti sambandhe  sāmi vacanam yāva na pare eka gate karomi iti ādīsu seṭṭha vacanaḥ api eka saddo loke dissati iti
translated: In the first passage, “because of the connection with confidence, jhāna is confidence,” the word “confidence” is a word for resoluteness.🔽In the world the word “one” is also seen used in the sense of best, as in such passages as “I will not let others make you one” .

original: āha “seṭṭhopi hi loke ekoti vuccatī”ti. “Ekākīhi khuddakehi jita”ntiādīsu asahāyatthopi
analyzed: āha seṭṭhaḥ api hi loke ekaḥ ti vuccati iti ekākīhi khuddakehi jita nti ādīsu asahāya tthaḥ api
translated: In the passage, “One who is alone, who is secluded,” etc., the word “one” is also seen used in the sense of companionless.

original: ekasaddo diṭṭhoti āha “eko asahāyo hutvā”ti. Saddhādayopi kāmaṃ sampayuttadhammānaṃ
analyzed: eka saddaḥ diṭṭhaḥ ti āha ekaḥ asahāyaḥ hutvā iti saddhā ādayaḥ api kāmam sampayutta dhammānam
translated: “Alone” is seen as a single term, thus he said “alone, without a second.”🔽Faith, etc., are certainly conditions for associated states

original: sādhāraṇato ca asādhāraṇato ca paccayā hontiyeva, samādhi pana jhānakkhaṇe sampayuttadhammānaṃ
analyzed: sādhāraṇato ca asādhāraṇato ca paccayā honti yeva samādhi pana jhāna kkhaṇe sampayutta dhammānam
translated: both as common and uncommon conditions, but concentration is a condition for associated states

original: avikkhepalakkhaṇe indaṭṭhakaraṇena sātisayaṃ paccayo hotīti dassento “sampayuttadhamme…pe… adhivacana”nti āha.
analyzed: avikkhepa lakkhaṇe sa atisayam paccayaḥ hoti iti dassento sampayutta dhamma īpe adhivacanam ti āha
translated: at the jhāna-moment by acting as their predominance in the sense of non-distraction. Showing this, he said “It is a condition by predominance for associated states, etc.”

original: “Sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāva”nti visesanadvayaṃ jhānassa atisayavacanicchāvasena
analyzed: sampasādanam cetasaḥ eka udi bhāvanti visesana dvayam jhānassa atisaya vacanicchā vasena
translated: The two distinctions “tranquillity of mental body” and “unification of mind” are stated🔽by way of the wish to describe the jhāna’s excellence.

original: gahitaṃ. Svāyamatisayo yathā imasmiṃ jhāne labbhati, na tathā paṭhamajjhāneti imaṃ
analyzed: gahitam svāyam atisayaḥ yathā imasmin jhāne labbhati na tathā paṭhamajjhāna iti imam
translated: This excellence is not found in the same degree in the first jhāna, thus🔽to point out this distinction it is said “But is not the first jhāna also a unification of mind?”

original: visesaṃ dassetuṃ “nanu cā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Ārammaṇe āhananapariyāhananavasena anumajjanaanuyujjanavasena
analyzed: visesam dassetum nanu ca atiādi vuttam ārammaṇe āhanana pariyāhanana vasena anumajjana anuyujjana vasena
translated: The states occurring by striking and by striking and by pressing and by pressing and by guiding and by guiding the object

original: ca pavattamānā dhammā satipi nīvaraṇappahānena kilesakālussiyāpagame sampayuttānaṃ
analyzed: ca pavattamānāḥ dhammāḥ sati pi nīvaraṇa pahānena kilesa kālussiya apagame sampayuttānam
translated: are, even though the disappearance of the defilement of agitation has taken place with the abandoning of the hindrances, still not free from the coarseness of the associated states.

original: kiñci khobhaṃ karontā viya tehi ca te na sannisinnā hontīti vuttaṃ “vitakkavicārakkhobhena…pe…
analyzed: kiñci khobham karontāḥ viya tehi ca te na sannisinnāḥ honti iti vuttam
translated: That is why it is said: ‘Because of the disturbance of applied and sustained thought, etc.,

original: na suppasanna”nti. Tattha khuddikā ūmiyo vīciyo, mahatiyo taraṅgā. Samādhipi na suṭṭhu
analyzed: na su pasannanti tattha khuddikāḥ ūmiyaḥ vīciyaḥ mahatiyaḥ taraṅgāḥ na suṭṭhu
translated: the concentration is not very evident, like waves in a shallow ford.’🔽And although the faculties are balanced and the energy is balanced,

original: pākaṭoti satipi indriyasamatte vīriyasamatāya ca teneva khotena sampasādābhāvena
analyzed: satipi indriya samatte vīriya samatāya ca tena iva khotena sampasāda abhāvena
translated: nevertheless, owing to the absence of that kind of confidence,🔽the concentration is not very evident, like a fish in deep water.

original: ca bahale viya jale maccho samādhipi na suṭṭhu pākaṭo. Vitakkavicārapalibodhābhāvenāti
analyzed: ca bahale jale na suṭṭhu pākaṭaḥ vitakka vicāra palibodha abhāvena ati
translated: Because of the absence of disturbance by applied and sustained thought: here the disturbance already mentioned is the disturbance.

original: ettha yathāvuttakhobho eva palibodho. Evaṃ vuttenāti yassā saddhāya vasena sampasādanaṃ,
analyzed: ettha yathā vutta khobhaḥ eva palibodhaḥ evam vuttena ati yassā saddhāya vasena sampasādanam
translated: Thus it is said: ‘The confidence by means of which there is confidence is confidence.

original: yassā ca cittekaggatāya vasena ekodibhāvanti ca jhānaṃ vuttaṃ, tāsaṃ eva “saddahanā”tiādinā
analyzed: yassā ca citta ekagga tāya vasena eka udi bhāvanti ca jhānam vuttam tāsam eva saddahana ati ādinā
translated: The unification by means of which there is unification is unification.’

original: pavattiākāravisesavibhāvanavasena vuttena tena vibhaṅgapāṭhena. Ayaṃ atthavaṇṇanāti
analyzed: pavatti ākāra visesa vibhāvana vasena vuttena tena vibhaṅga pāṭhena ayam attha vaṇṇanā ti
translated: This is the commentary on the meaning of the words.

original: “sampasādanayogato, sampasādanato vā sampasādanaṃ. Ekodiṃ bhāvetīti ekodibhāvanti
analyzed: sampasādana yogataḥ sampasādanataḥ vā sampasādanam eka ūdim bhāva iti iti eka ūdi bhāvanti
translated: ‘Because of the state of confidence’ means either because of the state of confidence or because of the confidence. ‘He develops unification’ means he develops unification.

original: jhānaṃ vutta”nti evaṃ pavattā ayaṃ atthavaṇṇanā. Aññadatthu saṃsandati ceva sameti
analyzed: jhānam vuttan ti evam pavattā ayam attha vaṇṇanā aññadatthu saṃsandati ca iva sameti
translated: This is the commentary on the meaning of the words of the stanza.

original: ca, evaṃ veditabbāti kathaṃ panāyaṃ atthavaṇṇanā tena vibhaṅgapāṭhena saddhiṃ saṃsandati
analyzed: ca evam veditabbā ti katham pana ayam attha vaṇṇanā tena vibhaṅga pāṭhena saddhim saṃsandati
translated: As to how the commentary on the meaning is to be construed with the text of the Vibhaṅga, it is as follows.

original: sameti, nanu jhānavibhaṅge “sampasādana”nti padaṃ uddharitvā “yā saddhā saddahanā”tiādinā🔽saddhāyeva vuttā, “cetaso ekodibhāva”nti ca padaṃ uddharitvā “yā cittassa ṭhiti saṇṭhiti
analyzed: samā iti nanu jhāna vibhaṅge sampasādana iti padam uddharitvā yā saddhā saddahana ati ādinā  saddhāya iva vuttā cetasaḥ ekodi bhāvanti ca padam uddharitvā yā cittassa saṇṭhiti
translated: In the Vibhaṅga, after extracting the words “confidence-trust” , only faith is stated thus: “What is confidence-trust? It is this: faith, confidence, trust, full confidence” .🔽And after extracting the words “one-pointedness of mind” , only concentration is demonstrated thus: “What is unification of mind? It is this: steadiness of mind, steadiness of awareness, a state of being unmoved, a state of being unperturbed” .

original: avaṭṭhitī”tiādinā samādhisseva niddeso kato, aṭṭhakathāyaṃ pana “sampasādanaṃ ekodibhāva”nti🔽jhānameva vuttanti aṭṭhakathāya vibhaṅgapāṭhena saddhiṃ virodho āpajjatīti? Nāpajjati
analyzed: avaṭṭhiti iti ādinā samādhissa iva niddeso kato aṭṭhakathā ayam pana sampasādanam ekodibhāvanti  jhānam eva vuttanti aṭṭhakathāya vibhaṅga pāṭhena saddhim virodhaḥ āpajjati iti na āpajjati
translated: But in the commentary only jhāna is stated thus: “Confidence-trust, one-pointedness of mind” . So there is a contradiction between the commentary and the text of the Vibhaṅga.🔽There is no contradiction,🔽because the demonstration in the Vibhaṅga was made with this very intention. For in the Vibhaṅga, after extracting the words “confidence-trust” , only faith is stated thus: “What is confidence-trust? It is this: faith, confidence, trust, full confidence” .

original: vibhaṅgepi imināva adhippāyena niddesassa katattā. Tathā hi yena sampasādanena yogā
analyzed: vibhaṅge pi iminā āva adhippāyena niddesassa kata ttā tathā hi yena sampasādanena yogā
translated: And after extracting the words “one-pointedness of mind” , only concentration is demonstrated thus: “What is unification of mind? It is this: steadiness of mind, steadiness of awareness, a state of being unmoved, a state of being unperturbed” .

original: jhānaṃ “sampasādana”nti vuccati, tasmiṃ “yā saddhā saddahanā”tiādinā dassite sampasādanaṃ
analyzed: jhānam sampasādananti vuccati tasmin yā saddhā saddahana ati ādinā dassite sampasādanam
translated: The jhāna is called “confidence” . The confidence shown in the passage beginning, “The faith, the believing, the confidence” is confidence in the jhāna.🔽The word “jhāna” is supplied as the referent of the word “that” in the phrase “that confidence in the jhāna” .🔽The word “unification” is supplied as the referent of the word “that” in the phrase “that unification in the jhāna” .

original: jhānanti samānādhikaraṇaniddeseneva taṃyogā jhāne taṃsaddappavatti dassitā hoti.🔽“Ekodibhāva”nti ca padaṃ uddharitvā ekodimhi dassite ekodibhāvaṃ jhānanti samānādhikaraṇaniddeseneva
analyzed: jhānanti samāna adhikaraṇa niddesena iva tad yogā jhāne tad sadda pavatti dassitā hoti  ekodi bhāvanti ca padam uddharitvā ekodimhi dassite ekodi bhāvam jhānanti samāna adhikaraṇa niddesena iva
translated: The word “jhāna” is supplied as the referent of the word “that” in the phrase “that unification in the jhāna” .🔽The word “jhāna” is supplied as the referent of the word “that” in the phrase “that unification in the jhāna” .

original: jhānassa ekodivaḍḍhanatā vuttāva hotīti iminā adhippāyena byañjanavicāraṃ akatvā🔽dhammamattameva niddiṭṭhanti avirodho yutto.
analyzed: jhānassa eka udi vaḍḍhana tā vuttā ava hoti iti iminā adhippāyena byañjana vicāram a katvā  dhamma mattam eva niddiṭṭhanti avirodhaḥ yuttaḥ
translated: The word “jhāna” is supplied as the referent of the word “that” in the phrase “that unification in the jhāna” .🔽The word “jhāna” is supplied as the referent of the word “that” in the phrase “that unification in the jhāna” .🔽The word “jhāna” is supplied as the referent of the word “that” in the phrase “that unification in the jhāna” .🔽The word “jhāna” is supplied as the referent of the word “that” in the phrase “that unification in the jhāna” .🔽The word “jhāna” is supplied as the referent of the word “that” in the phrase “that unification in the jhāna” .🔽The word “jhāna” is supplied as the referent of the word “that” in the phrase “that unification in the jhāna” .

original: Yaṃ pana vuttaṃ ṭīkākārehi ācariyadhammapālattherādīhi “yadi ekodīti samādhissa gahaṇaṃ🔽adhippetaṃ, tadā ‘ekodibhāva’nti padaṃ uddharitvā samādhissa niddeso na kattabbo
analyzed: yam pana vuttam ṭīkākārehi ācariya dhammapāla tthera ādīhi yadi ekodī iti samādhissa gahaṇam  adhippetam tadā ekodibhāvanti padam uddharitvā samādhissa niddesaḥ na kattabbo
translated: The word “jhāna” is supplied as the referent of the word “that” in the phrase “that unification in the jhāna” .🔽The word “jhāna” is supplied as the referent of the word “that” in the phrase “that unification in the jhāna” .🔽The word “jhāna” is supplied as the referent of the word “that” in the phrase “that unification in the jhāna” .

original: siyā. Tasmā ekodibhāvasaddo eva samādhimhi pavatto sampasādanasaddo viya jhāne pavattatīti
analyzed: siyā tasmai eka udi bhāva saddo eva samādhimhi pavatto sampasādana saddaḥ viya jhāne pavattati iti
translated: The word “jhāna” is supplied as the referent of the word “that” in the phrase “that unification in the jhāna” .🔽The word “jhāna” is supplied as the referent of the word “that” in the phrase “that unification in the j

original: yutta”nti, taṃ aṭṭhakathāya virujjhati. Tasmā so aṭṭhakathānirapekkho visuṃyeveko
analyzed: yuttam ti tam aṭṭhakathāya virujjhati tasmā saḥ aṭṭhakathā nirapekkhaḥ visum yeva ekaḥ
translated: and that is contrary to the commentary. So it should be taken as a separate interpretation independent of the commentary.

original: atthavikappoti gahetabbaṃ. Ayañhi nesaṃ adhippāyo – vitakkavicārehi anajjhāruḷhattā
analyzed: attha vikappaḥ ti gahetabbam ayam hi nesam adhippāyaḥ vitakka vicārehi an ajjhāruḷha ttā
translated: This is their intention: because it is not overmastered by applied and sustained thought,

original: ekaṃ udetīti ekodīti tathāvidhasamādhiyuttaṃ jhānacittameva gahetvā ekodissa bhāvo🔽ekodibhāvoti samādhissa gahaṇaṃ sakkā vattunti. Yo panāyaṃ tesamabhiniveso “ekodīti🔽samādhissa gahaṇe sati ‘ekodibhāva’nti padaṃ uddharitvā samādhissa niddeso na kattabbo🔽siyā”ti, so anekantikattā ayutto. Aññatthapi hi byañjanavicāraṃ akatvā atthamattasseva
analyzed: ekam udeti iti ekodī iti tathāvidha samādhi yuttam jhāna cittam eva gahetvā ekodissa bhāvo  ekodi bhāvaḥ ti samādhissa gahaṇam sakkā vattunti yaḥ pana ayam ekodī iti  samādhissa gahaṇe sati eka udi bhāvanti padam uddharitvā samādhissa niddesaḥ na kattabbo  siyā iti saḥ anekantika ttā ayuttaḥ aññattha api hi byañjana vicāram a katvā attha mattassa iva
translated: it is said to be “one-pointed” . And it is possible to say that the state of being “one-pointed” is the possession of concentration, taking the consciousness associated with that kind of concentration as “one-pointed” in the sense of being unified.

original: bāhullena vibhaṅge niddeso dissati.
analyzed: bāhullena vibhaṅge niddesaḥ dissati
translated: But the insistence of those who say that, when concentration is taken as “one-pointed,” the expression “state of being one-pointed” should not be taken as a description of concentration by extracting the word “state” from the compound, is unreasonable, because it is inconclusive. For in the Vibhaṅga the description is given without any consideration of the verbal form, and only by the abundance of the meaning.

original: Santāti samaṃ nirodhaṃ gatā. Samitāti bhāvanāya samaṃ gamitā nirodhitā. Vūpasantāti
analyzed: santā ati samam nirodham gatā samitā ati bhāvanāya samam gamitā nirodhitā vūpasantā ati
translated: “They are ‘still’ because they have reached complete cessation. They are ‘calm’ because they have gone to calm by means of development. They are ‘at peace’ because they have gone to peace by means of development. They are ‘luminous’ because they have gone to luminosity by means of development. translated: and so are quite stilled. They have gone to destruction: they have gone to the state of having been destroyed. translated: Understanding of equanimity about formations consisting in the contemplation of the fading away of happiness arises for the purpose of attaining the third jhāna.

original: pītiṃ paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhārupekkhāsu ñāṇaṃ, catutthajjhānapaṭilābhatthāya
analyzed: pītim paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhāra upekkhāsu ñāṇam catuttha jhāna paṭilābha tthāya
translated: Understanding of equanimity about formations consisting in the contemplation of equanimity arises for the purpose of attaining the fourth jhāna.

original: sukhadukkhe paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhārupekkhāsu ñāṇaṃ, ākāsānañcāyatanasamāpattipaṭilābhatthāya
analyzed: sukha dukkhe paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhāra upekkhāsu ñāṇam ākāsa anañca āyatana samāpatti paṭilābha tthāya
translated: Understanding of equanimity about formations consisting in the contemplation of the abandoning of pleasure and pain arises for the purpose of attaining the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.

original: rūpasaññaṃ paṭighasaññaṃ nānattasaññaṃ paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhārupekkhāsu
analyzed: rūpa saññam paṭigha saññam nānatta saññam paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhāra upekkhāsu
translated: Understanding of equanimity about formations consisting in the contemplation of the perception of materiality, the perception of resistance, and the perception of variety as being formations arises for the purpose of attaining the base consisting of boundless space.

original: ñāṇaṃ, viññāṇañcāyatanasamāpattipaṭilābhatthāya ākāsānañcāyatanasaññaṃ paṭisaṅkhā🔽santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhārupekkhāsu ñāṇaṃ, ākiñcaññāyatanasamāpattipaṭilābhatthāya
analyzed: ñāṇam viññāṇañca āyatana samāpatti paṭilābha atthāya ākāsa ānañca āyatana saññam paṭisaṅkhā  santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhāra upekkhāsu ñāṇam ākiñcañña āyatana samāpatti paṭilābha tthāya
translated: Understanding of the perception of the base of infinite space as a state of composure to be attained by venturing out through the perception of the base of infinite consciousness is the knowledge of equanimity about formations.🔽Understanding of the perception of the base of infinite consciousness as a state of composure to be attained by venturing out through the base of infinite space is the knowledge of equanimity about formations.

original: viññāṇañcāyatanasaññaṃ paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhārupekkhāsu ñāṇaṃ, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpattipaṭilābhatthāya🔽ākiñcaññāyatanasaññaṃ paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhārupekkhāsu ñāṇaṃ, imā aṭṭha
analyzed: viññāṇañca āyatana saññam paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhāra upekkhāsu ñāṇam nevasaññānāsaññāyatana samāpatti paṭilābha tthāya  ākiñcaññāyatana saññam paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhāra upekkhāsu ñāṇam imāḥ aṭṭha
translated: Understanding of the perception of the base of nothingness as a state of composure to be attained by venturing out through the base of infinite consciousness is the knowledge of equanimity about formations.

original: saṅkhārupekkhā samathavasena uppajjanti.
analyzed: saṅkhāra upekkhā samatha vasena uppajjanti
translated: These are the eight kinds of equanimity about formations that arise by way of serenity.

original: “Katamā dasa saṅkhārupekkhā vipassanāvasena uppajjanti? Sotāpattimaggapaṭilābhatthāya🔽uppādaṃ pavattaṃ nimittaṃ āyūhanaṃ paṭisandhiṃ gatiṃ nibbattiṃ upapattiṃ jātiṃ jaraṃ
analyzed: katamāḥ dasa saṅkhārupekkhāḥ vipassanā vasena uppajjanti sotāpatti magga paṭilābha tthāya  uppādam pavattam nimittam āyūhanam paṭisandhim gatim nibbattim upapattim jātim jaram
translated: “What are the ten kinds of equanimity about formations that arise by way of insight?🔽Understanding of arising, occurrence, signs, fabrication, and determination as a state of composure to be attained by venturing out through birth, aging, and death is the knowledge of equanimity about formations.

original: byādhiṃ maraṇaṃ sokaṃ paridevaṃ upāyāsaṃ paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhārupekkhāsu
analyzed: byādhim maraṇam sokam paridevam upāyāsam paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhāra upekkhāsu
translated: Understanding of birth, aging, and death as a state of composure to be attained by venturing out through sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and despair is the knowledge of equanimity about formations.

original: ñāṇaṃ, sotāpattiphalasamāpattatthāya uppādaṃ pavattaṃ nimittaṃ āyūhanaṃ paṭisandhiṃ🔽paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhārupekkhāsu ñāṇaṃ, sakadāgāmimaggapaalābhatthāya…pe…🔽sakadāgāmiphalasamāpattatthāya…pe… anāgāmimaggapaṭilābhatthāya…pe… anāgāmiphalasamāpattatthāya…pe…🔽arahattamaggapaṭilābhatthāya uppādaṃ pavattaṃ nimittaṃ āyūhanaṃ paṭisandhiṃ gatiṃ🔽nibbattiṃ upapattiṃ jātiṃ jaraṃ byādhiṃ maraṇaṃ sokaṃ paridevaṃ upāyāsaṃ paṭisaṅkhā
analyzed: ñāṇam sa utāpatti phala samāpatta tthāya uppādam pavattam nimittam āyūhanam paṭisandhim  paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhāra upekkhāsu ñāṇam  sakadāgāmi phala samāpatta tthāyape anāgāmi magga paṭilābha tthāyape anāgāmi phala samāpatta tthāyape  arahatta magga paṭilābha atthāya uppādam pavattam nimittam āyūhanam paṭisandhim gatim  nibbattim upapattim jātim jaram byādhim maraṇam sokam paridevam upāyāsam paṭisaṅkhā

original: santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhārupekkhāsu ñāṇaṃ, imā dasa saṅkhārupekkhā vipassanāvasena uppajjantī”ti –
analyzed: santiṭṭhanā paññā saṅkhāra upekkhāsu ñāṇam imā dasa saṅkhāra upekkhāḥ vipassanā vasena uppajjanti iti
translated: Understanding of persistence is knowledge of equanimity about formations. These ten kinds of equanimity about formations arise in the course of insight” .

original: Evamāgatā nīvaraṇādipaṭisaṅkhāsantiṭṭhanākārabhūtā upekkhā, ayaṃ saṅkhārupekkhā nāma.
analyzed: evam āgatā nīvaraṇa ādi paṭisaṅkhā santiṭṭhana ākāra bhūtā upekkhā ayam saṅkhārupekkhā nāma
translated: The equanimity that occurs in this way, which is a kind of persistence in the form of reflection upon the hindrances, etc., is called equanimity about formations.

original: Tattha nīvaraṇe paṭisaṅkhāti pañca nīvaraṇāni pahātabbabhāvena paṭisaṅkhāya, pariggahetvāti🔽attho. Santiṭṭhanāti nīvaraṇānaṃ pahānābhimukhībhūtattā tesaṃ pahānepi abyāpārabhāvūpagamanena🔽majjhattatāya santiṭṭhanā. Saṅkhārupekkhāsūti nīvaraṇappahāne byāpārākaraṇena nīvaraṇasaṅkhātānaṃ
analyzed: tattha nīvaraṇe paṭisaṅkhāti pañca nīvaraṇāni pahātabba bhāvena paṭisaṅkhāya pariggahetvā ati  nīvaraṇānam pahāna abhimukhībhūta ttā tesam pahāne pi a byāpāra bhāva upagamanena  majjhatta tāya santiṭṭhanā saṅkhāra upekkhāsu iti nīvaraṇa ppahāne byāpāra akaraṇena nīvaraṇa saṅkhātānam
translated: Herein, he reflects upon the hindrances as things to be abandoned. The meaning is that he regards them.🔽He persists in equanimity: he persists in equanimity by way of the middle, that is, by not taking sides with the abandoning of the hindrances, since he is now facing in the direction of their abandoning.

original: saṅkhārānaṃ upekkhanāsūti attho. Esa nayo vitakkavicārādīsu uppādādīsu ca. Tattha
analyzed: saṅkhārānam upekkhanāsu iti atthaḥ esa nayaḥ vitakka vicāra ādīsu uppāda ādīsu ca tattha
translated: He is equanimous about formations called hindrances: the meaning is that he is equanimous about formations called hindrances by not taking sides with them. The same method applies in the case of applied thought, etc., and in the case of arising, etc. Herein,🔽arising is the occurrence of the aggregates here through kamma as their condition.

original: uppādanti purimakammapaccayā khandhānaṃ idha uppattimāha. Pavattanti tathāuppannassa
analyzed: uppādanti purima kamma paccayā khandhānam idha uppattim āha pavattanti tathāuppannassa
translated: Occurrence is the occurrence of what has arisen.

original: pavattiṃ. Nimittanti sabbampi tebhūmakaṃ saṅkhāragataṃ nimittabhāvena upaṭṭhānato.🔽Āyūhananti āyatiṃ paṭisandhihetubhūtaṃ kammaṃ. Paṭisandhinti āyatiṃ upapattiṃ. Gatinti
analyzed: pavattim nimittanti sabbam pi tebhūmakam saṅkhāra gatam nimitta bhāvena upaṭṭhānato  āyūhananti āyatim paṭisandhi hetu bhūtam kammam paṭisandhim ti āyatim upapattim gatim
translated: Occurrence. Sign means all that is included in the three planes as a sign in the sense of appearing as a sign.🔽Accumulation means kamma that is a cause for rebirth-linking in the future. Rebirth-linking means future rebirth.

original: yāya gatiyā sā paṭisandhi hoti. Nibbattinti khandhānaṃ nibbattanaṃ. Upapattinti vipākappavattiṃ.
analyzed: yāya gatiyā sā paṭisandhi hoti nibbattim ti khandhānam nibbattanam upapattim ti vipāka ppavattim
translated: Destination means the destiny by means of which there is that rebirth-linking. Appearance means the appearance of the aggregates. Re-arising means the occurrence of the result.

original: Jātinti jarādīnaṃ paccayabhūtaṃ bhavapaccayā jātiṃ. Jarāmaraṇādayo pākaṭā eva.
analyzed: jātim ti jarā ādīnam paccaya bhūtam bhava paccayāḥ jātim jarā maraṇa ādayaḥ pākaṭāḥ eva
translated: Birth means birth that is conditioned by becoming and is a condition for ageing, etc. Ageing, death, etc., are obvious.

original: Ettha ca uppādādayo pañceva saṅkhārupekkhāñāṇassa visayavasena vuttā, sesā tesaṃ
analyzed: ettha ca uppāda ādayo pañca iva saṅkhāra upekkhā ñāṇassa visaya vasena vuttā sesā tesam
translated: And here the five, namely, arising, etc., are stated as the province of the knowledge of equanimity about formations, while the others

original: vevacanavasena. Nibbatti jātīti idañhi dvayaṃ uppādassa ceva paṭisandhiyā ca vevacanaṃ.
analyzed: vevacana vasena nibbatti jāti iti idam hi dvayam uppādassa ca iva paṭisandhiyā ca vevacanam
translated: are synonyms for them. For appearance and birth are synonyms for arising and rebirth-linking.

original: Gati upapatti cāti idaṃ dvayaṃ pavattassa, jarādayo nimittassāti veditabbaṃ. Nanu
analyzed: gati upapatti ca ati idam dvayam pavattassa jarā ādayaḥ nimittassa ati veditabbam nanu
translated: And destination and reappearance are synonyms for occurrence. Ageing, etc., should be understood as synonyms for sign.

original: cettha catūsu maggavāresu “uppāda”ntiādīni pañca mūlapadāni, “gatī”tiādīni dasa vevacanapadānīti
analyzed: ca ittha catūsu magga vāresu uppāda nti ādīni pañca mūla padāni gati iti ādīni dasa vevacana padāni iti
translated: But here, it may be asked, are not the five root terms “arising,” etc., in the four sections on the path, and the ten terms beginning with “destination” synonyms?

original: pannarasa padāni vuttāni, chasu pana phalasamāpattivāresu pañca mūlapadāneva vuttāni,
analyzed: pannarasa padāni vuttāni chasu pana phala samāpatti vāresu pañca mūla padānā iva vuttāni
translated: The fifteen terms are stated in the section on the path, but only the five basic terms are stated in the six sections on fruition attainment.

original: taṃ kasmāti ce? Saṅkhārupekkhāya tikkhabhāve sati kilesappahānasamatthassa maggassa
analyzed: tam kasmā iti ce saṅkhāra upekkhāya tikkha bhāve sati kilesa ppahāna samatthassa maggassa
translated: Why is that? Because when equanimity about formations is keen, the path is able to abandon defilements.

original: sabbhāvato tassā tikkhabhāvadassanatthaṃ vevacanapadehi saha daḷhaṃ katvā mūlapadāni
analyzed: sabbhāvataḥ tassā tikkha bhāva dassana attham vevacana padehi saha daḷham katvā mūla padāni
translated: In order to show that it is keen in every way, the basic terms are stated with synonyms in order to strengthen them.

original: vuttāni, phalassa nirussāhabhāvena santasabhāvattā maggāyattattā ca mandabhūtāpi
analyzed: vuttāni phalassa nirussāha bhāvena santa sabhāva ttā magga āyatta ttā ca manda bhūtā api
translated: Although equanimity about formations is weak because of the absence of urgency in fruition and because of its peaceful nature and its dependence on the path,

original: saṅkhārupekkhā phalassa paccayo hotīti dassanatthaṃ mūlapadāneva vuttānīti veditabbāni.
analyzed: saṅkhārupekkhā phalassa paccayaḥ hoti iti dassana ttham mūla padāni eva vuttāni iti veditabbāni
translated: it should be understood that the basic terms are stated in order to show that it is a condition for fruition.

original: Tattha “sotāpattimaggapaṭilābhatthāyā”tiādīsu catūsu maggavāresu suññatānimittappaṇihitamaggānaṃ
analyzed: tattha sotāpatti magga paṭilābha atthāya ati ādīsu catūsu magga vāresu suññatā nimitta paṇihita maggānam
translated: Herein, in the four sections on the path, any one of the paths of voidness, of desirelessness, and of the signless is stated in the passage beginning, “For the attainment of the path of stream-entry” .

original: aññataro vutto. “Sotāpattiphalasamāpattatthāyā”tiādīsu catūsu phalavāresu pana appaṇihitaphalasamāpatti
analyzed: aññataro vutto sotāpatti phala samāpatta tthāya atiādīsu catūsu phala vāresu pana appaṇihita phala samāpatti
translated: But in the four sections on fruition, only the fruition attainment of the desireless is stated in the passage beginning, “For the attainment of the fruition of stream-entry” .

original: veditabbā. Kasmā? Suññatavihārasamāpattatthāya animittavihārasamāpattatthāyāti itarāsaṃ
analyzed: veditabbā kasmā suññata vihāra samāpatta tthāya animitta vihāra samāpatta tthāya ati itarāsam
translated: Why? For the attainment of the void abiding, for the attainment of the signless abiding.🔽

original: dvinnaṃ phalasamāpattīnaṃ visuṃ vuttattā. Aniccānupassanāvuṭṭhānavasena hi animittamaggo,🔽tatheva phalasamāpattikāle animittaphalasamāpatti, dukkhānupassanāvuṭṭhānavasena
analyzed: tathā iva phala samāpatti kāle animitta phala samāpatti dukkha anupassanā vuṭṭhāna vasena
translated: Why? Because the other two attainments of fruition are mentioned separately. For the path of the signless is the emergence from the contemplation of impermanence,

original: appaṇihitamaggaphalasamāpattiyo, anattānupassanāvuṭṭhānavasaena suññatamaggaphalasamāpattiyo
analyzed: appaṇihita magga phala samāpattiyaḥ anatta anupassanā vuṭṭhāna vasaena suññata magga phala samāpattiyaḥ
translated: and the attainment of the fruition of the signless is the attainment of fruition at the time of that path. The attainment of the path and fruition of the desireless is the emergence from the contemplation of pain. The attainment of the path and fruition of the void is the emergence from the contemplation of not-self.

original: suttantanayena veditabbā. Evañca katvā suññatādivimokkhavasena magguppattihetubhūtā
analyzed: suttanta nayena veditabbā evam ca katvā suññatā ādi vimokkha vasena magga uppatti hetu bhūtā
translated: This is how it should be understood by the method of the sutta.🔽And when it is put this way, it is the four kinds of understanding consisting in insight classed as the void, etc., that are the cause for the arising of the path.

original: catasso, tathā appaṇihitaphalasamāpattiyā catasso, suññatavihāraanimittavihāravasena🔽dveti dasa saṅkhārupekkhāvipassanāpaññā vuttā, samathasaṅkhārupekkhā pana appanāvīthiyā
analyzed: catasso tathā appaṇihita phala samāpattiyā catasso suññata vihāra animitta vihāra vasena  dve ti dasa saṅkhāra upekkhā vipassanā paññā vuttā samatha saṅkhāra upekkhā pana appanā vīthiyā
translated: And likewise the four kinds of attainment of fruition of the desireless, and the two kinds classed as void and signless,

original: āsannapubbabhāge balappattaṃ bhāvanāmayañāṇaṃ.
analyzed: āsanna pubbabhāge bala ppattam bhāvanā maya ñāṇam
translated: making ten kinds of understanding consisting in insight classed as equanimity about formations. But equanimity about serenity is understanding consisting in knowledge of the meditative development consisting in the proximate cause of the path of stream-entry, which has reached the state of predominance in the period immediately before the path.

original: Yā pana “yasmiṃ samaye kāmāvacaraṃ kusalaṃ cittaṃ uppannaṃ hoti upekkhāsahagata”nti evamāgatā adukkhamasukhasaññitā upekkhā, ayaṃ vedanupekkhā nāma.
analyzed: yā pana yasmin samaye kāmāvacaram kusalam cittam uppannam hoti upekkhā sahagatam ti evam āgatā adukkham asukha saññitā upekkhā ayam vedanupekkhā nāma
translated: The equanimity called “feeling equanimity” is that which is called “equanimity as neither- painful-nor-pleasant feeling” in the passage, “On an occasion, bhikkhus, when a profitable mind-element has arisen that is accompanied by equanimity” ,

original: Yā “yadatthi yaṃ bhūtaṃ, taṃ pajahati, upekkhaṃ paṭilabhatī”ti evamāgatā vicinane majjhattabhūtā upekkhā, ayaṃ vipassanupekkhā nāma.
analyzed: yā yat atthi yam bhūtam tam pajahati upekkham paṭilabhati iti evam āgatā vicinane majjhatta bhūtā upekkhā ayam vipassanupekkhā nāma
translated: The equanimity called “equanimity about seeing” is that which is called “equanimity” in the passage, “Whatever exists, bhikkhus, is subject to decay; having arisen, it is subject to extinction” , and it is the equanimity that is neutrality in seeing.

original: Tattha yadatthi yaṃ bhūtanti khandhapañcakaṃ, taṃ muñcitukamyatāñāṇena pajahati.🔽Upekkhaṃ paṭilabhatīti diṭṭhasovattikattayassa sappassa lakkhaṇavicinane viya diṭṭhalakkhaṇattayassa
analyzed: tattha yat atthi yam khandha pañcakam tam muñcitu kamya tā ñāṇena pajahati  upekkham paṭilabhati iti diṭṭha sovattika ttayassa sappassa lakkhaṇa vicinane viya diṭṭha lakkhaṇa ttayassa
translated: Herein, “Whatever exists, bhikkhus, is subject to decay” is the five aggregates as objects of clinging. “Having arisen, it is subject to extinction”: he abandons them by means of the knowledge that is desirous for deliverance.🔽“He obtains equanimity”: the meaning is that he obtains equanimity about seeing in the investigation of the three kinds of seeing, as in the case of the three kinds of bile in the description of the jaundice-born type of eye disease .🔽The equanimity called “equanimity about what is not seen” is that which is called “equanimity” in the passage, “When a bhikkhu is ardent, … he achieves equanimity” .

original: khandhapañcakassa saṅkhāralakkhaṇavicinane upekkhaṃ paṭilabhatīti attho.
analyzed: khandha pañcakassa saṅkhāra lakkhaṇa vicinane upekkham paṭilabhati iti attho
translated: The equanimity called “equanimity about what is seen” is that which is called “equanimity” in the passage, “When a bhikkhu is ardent, … he achieves equanimity” .🔽The equanimity called “equanimity about what is not seen” is that which is called “equanimity” in the passage, “When a bhikkhu is ardent, … he achieves equanimity” .🔽The equanimity called “equanimity about what is seen” is that which is called “equanimity” in the passage, “When a bhikkhu is ardent, … he achieves equanimity” .🔽The equanimity called “equanimity about what is not seen” is that which is called “equanimity” in the passage, “When a bhikkhu is ardent, … he achieves equanimity” .

original: Yā pana chandādīsu yevāpanakesu āgatā sahajātānaṃ samappavattihetubhūtā upekkhā, ayaṃ tatramajjhattupekkhā nāma.
analyzed: yā pana chanda ādīsu yevāpanakesu āgatā sahajātānam sama ppavatti hetu bhūtā upekkhā ayam tatram ajjhattupekkhā nāma
translated: The equanimity called “equanimity about what is seen” is that which is called “equanimity” in the passage, “When a bhikkhu is ardent, … he achieves equanimity” .🔽The equanimity called “equanimity about what is not seen” is that which is called “equanimity” in the passage, “When a bhikkhu is ardent, … he achieves equ

original: Yā “upekkhako ca viharatī”ti evamāgatā aggasukhepi tasmiṃ apakkhapātajananī upekkhā, ayaṃ jhānupekkhā nāma.
analyzed: yā upekkhakaḥ ca viharati iti evam āgatā agga sukhe pi tasmim a pakkhapāta jananī upekkhā ayam jhānupekkhā nāma
translated: The equanimity that comes in the clause “he dwells in equanimity” is equanimity as a divine abiding.🔽The equanimity that comes in the clause “purification by equanimity, by unification of cognizance” is equanimity as a jhana factor.🔽The equanimity that comes in the clause “purification by overcoming doubt by direct knowledge of the line of practice” is equanimity as a path factor.

original: Yā pana “upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhāna”nti evamāgatā sabbapaccanīkaparisuddhā paccanīkavūpasamanepi abyāpārabhūtā upekkhā, ayaṃ pārisuddhupekkhā nāma.🔽Tattha chaḷaṅgupekkhā ca brahmavihārupekkhā ca bojjhaṅgupekkhā ca tatramajjhattupekkhā
analyzed: yā pana upekkhā sati pārisuddhim catuttham jhānanti evam āgatā sabba paccanīka parisuddhā paccanīka vūpasamane pi a byāpāra bhūtā upekkhā ayam pārisuddhupekkhā nāma  tattha chaḷaṅgu pekkhā ca brahmavihāru pekkhā ca bojjhaṅgu pekkhā ca tatra ajjhattu pekkhā
translated: The equanimity that comes in the clause “purification by knowledge and vision of what is the path and what is not the path” is equanimity as knowledge of the way.🔽The equanimity that comes in the clause “purification by knowledge and vision of the way” is equanimity as knowledge of what is the path.

original: ca jhānupekkhā ca pārisuddhupekkhā ca atthato ekā tatramajjhattupekkhāva hoti. Tena🔽tena avatthābhedena panassā ayaṃ bhedo ekassapi sato sattassa kumārayuvatherasenāpatirājādivasena
analyzed: ca jhānupekkhā ca pārisuddhupekkhā ca atthataḥ ekā hoti tena  tena avatthā bhedena panassāḥ ayam bhedaḥ ekassa api sato sattassa kumāra yuvathera senāpati rāja ādi vasena
translated: The equanimity that comes in the clause “purification by knowledge and vision” is equanimity as knowledge of what is the higher and lower.🔽The equanimity that comes in the clause “purification by knowledge and vision” is equanimity as knowledge of the growth and decline .🔽The equanimity that comes in the clause “purification by knowledge and vision” is equanimity as knowledge of one who is developing .

original: bhedo viya. Tasmā tāsu yattha chaḷaṅgupekkhā, na tattha bojjhaṅgupekkhādayo. Yattha
analyzed: bhedaḥ tāsu yattha chaḷaṅgu pekkhāḥ na tattha bojjhaṅgu pekkhā ādayaḥ yattha
translated: The equanimity that comes in the clause “purification by knowledge and vision” is equanimity as knowledge of one who is not developing .🔽The equanimity that comes in the clause “purification by knowledge and vision” is equanimity as knowledge of the adept.🔽The equanimity that comes in the clause “purification by knowledge and vision” is equanimity as knowledge of the non-adept.🔽The equanimity that comes in the clause “purification by knowledge and vision” is equanimity as knowledge of the ordinary man.🔽The equanimity that comes in the clause “purification by knowledge and vision” is equanimity as knowledge of the noble person.🔽The equanimity that comes in the clause “purification by knowledge and vision” is equanimity as knowledge of the disciple of average ability.🔽The equanimity that comes in the clause “purification by knowledge and vision” is equanimity as knowledge of the disciple of keen ability.🔽The equanimity that comes in the clause “purification by knowledge and vision” is equanimity as knowledge of the Paccekabuddha.🔽The equanimity that comes in the clause “purification by knowledge and vision” is equanimity as knowledge of the Perfect Buddha.🔽The equanimity that comes in the clause “purification by knowledge and vision” is equ

original: vā pana bojjhaṅgupekkhā, na tattha chaḷaṅgupekkhādayo hontīti veditabbā. Yathā cetāsaṃ
analyzed: vā pana bojjhaṅgu pekkhā na tattha chaḷaṅgu pekkhā ādayaḥ honti iti veditabbā yathā cetāsam
translated: But the equanimity of the enlightenment factors is not the equanimity of the six senses, etc., it should be understood.

original: atthato ekībhāvo, evaṃ saṅkhārupekkhāvipassanupekkhānampi. Paññā eva hi sā kiccavasena🔽dvidhā bhinnā. Yathā hi purisassa sāyaṃ gehaṃ paviṭṭhaṃ sappaṃ ajapadadaṇḍaṃ gahetvā
analyzed: atthataḥ ekībhāvaḥ evam saṅkhāra upekkhā vipassanā upekkhānam pi paññā eva hi sā kicca vasena  dvidhā bhinnā yathā hi purisassa sāyam geham paviṭṭham sappam aja pada daṇḍam gahetvā
translated: And just as there is this single meaning in the case of equanimity about formations and equanimity of insight, so too there is a single meaning in the case of equanimity about formations and equanimity as a divine abiding.🔽For equanimity about formations is insight, and equanimity as a divine abiding is concentration.

original: pariyesamānassa taṃ thusakoṭṭhake nipannaṃ disvā “sappo nu kho, no”ti avalokentassa
analyzed: pariyesamānassa tam thusa koṭṭhake nipannam disvā sappaḥ nu kho no ti avalokentassa
translated: Just as when a man has gone into his house in the evening and is looking for a snake that has bitten him, and he sees it lying in the grain store and he looks on at it without fear, thinking “Is it poisonous or not?”

original: sovattikattayaṃ disvā nibbematikassa “sappo, na sappo”ti vicinane majjhattatā hoti,
analyzed: sovattika ttayam disvā nibbematikassa sappaḥ na sappo ti vicinane majjhatta tā hoti
translated: and when he sees the three marks of the kusa grass he is sure that it is poisonous, and he has no more doubt as to whether it is or not,

original: evameva yā āraddhavipassakassa vipassanāñāṇena lakkhaṇattaye diṭṭhe saṅkhārānaṃ aniccabhāvādivicinane🔽majjhattatā uppajjati, ayaṃ vipassanupekkhā. Yathā pana tassa purisassa ajapadena
analyzed: evam eva yā āraddha vipassakassa vipassanā ñāṇena lakkhaṇa ttaye diṭṭhe saṅkhārānam anicca bhāva ādi vicinane 🔽majjhatta tā uppajjati ayam vipassanā upekkhā yathā pana tassa purisassa aja padena
translated: so too, when a man has begun insight, and he sees the three characteristics with insight knowledge, and he looks on at formations to see whether they are impermanent, or the reverse,🔽and he has no more doubt as to whether they are impermanent or not,

original: daṇḍena gāḷhaṃ sappaṃ gahetvā “kintāhaṃ imaṃ sappaṃ aviheṭhento attānañca iminā aḍaṃsāpento🔽muñceyya”nti muñcanākārameva pariyesato gahaṇe majjhattatā hoti, evameva yā lakkhaṇattayassa
analyzed: daṇḍena gāḷham sappam gahetvā kintā aham imam sappam a viheṭhentaḥ attānam ca iminā  muñceyyanti muñcana ākāram eva pariyesataḥ gahaṇe majjhatta tā hoti evam eva yā lakkhaṇa ttayassa
translated: When a man catches a fierce snake with a stick, he is seeking a way to let it go without hurting it or being bitten by it himself.

original: diṭṭhattā āditte viya tayo bhave passato saṅkhāraggahaṇe majjhattatā, ayaṃ saṅkhārupekkhā.🔽Iti vipassanupekkhāya siddhāya saṅkhārupekkhāpi siddhāva hoti. Iminā panesā vicinanagahaṇesu
analyzed: diṭṭha ttā āditte viya tayaḥ bhave passato saṅkhāra ggahaṇe majjhatta tā ayam saṅkhāra upekkhā  iti vipassanā upekkhāya siddhāya saṅkhāra upekkhā api siddhā ava hoti iminā pana isā vicinana gahaṇesu
translated: So too, when the three characteristics are seen, equanimity about formations in the catching of formations is like the neutrality in the catching of the snake.🔽So when insight equanimity is established, equanimity about formations is established too. But this is twofold as the function of neutrality in discerning and in catching.

original: majjhattasaṅkhātena kiccena dvidhā bhinnā. Vīriyupekkhā pana vedanupekkhā ca aññamaññañca🔽avasesāhi ca atthato bhinnā evāti.🔽Imāsaṃ pana dasannampi upekkhānaṃ bhūmipuggalādivasena vibhāgo tattha tattha vuttanayeneva
analyzed: majjhatta saṅkhātena kiccena dvidhā bhinnā vīriyupekkhā pana vedanupekkhā ca aññamaññam ca  avasesā hi ca atthataḥ bhinnā evā ti  imāsam pana dasannam pi upekkhānam bhūmi puggala ādi vasena vibhāgaḥ tattha tattha vutta nayena iva
translated: Equanimity about energy and equanimity about feeling are different from each other and from the rest.🔽But the exposition of these ten equanimities according to plane, person, consciousness, object, etc., should be understood in the way given in the Description of the Meditations.

original: veditabboti dassento āha “evamayaṃ dasavidhāpī”tiādi. Tattha bhūmipuggalacittārammaṇatoti
analyzed: veditabbaḥ iti dassentaḥ āha evam ayam dasavidhā api itiādi tattha bhūmi puggala citta ārammaṇato ti
translated: So he said, “This tenfold equanimity” and so on. Herein: “According to plane, person, consciousness, object, etc.” means according to the exposition of the equanimities according to plane, person, consciousness, object, etc.

original: “chaḷaṅgupekkhā kāmāvacarā, brahmavihārupekkhā rūpāvacarā”ti evamādinā bhūmito. “Chaḷaṅgupekkhā
analyzed: chaṭṭha aṅga pekkhā kāmāvacarā brahmavihāru pekkhā rūpāvacarā ati evamādinā bhūmitaḥ chaṭṭha aṅga pekkhā
translated: “The equanimity about the six sense doors is of the sense sphere, that of the divine abidings is of the fine-material sphere” , and so on according to plane.

original: khīṇāsavasseva, brahmavihārupekkhā tiṇṇampi puthujjanasekkhāsekkhāna”nti evamādinā
analyzed: khīṇāsavassa iva brahmavihāra pekkhā tiṇṇam pi puthujjana sekkhā sekkhānam ti evamādinā
translated: “The equanimity about the six sense doors is only in one whose cankers are destroyed, that of the divine abidings is in all three kinds of persons, that is to say, in the ordinary man, in the trainer, and in the one beyond training” , and so on according to person.

original: puggalato. “Chaḷaṅgupekkhā somanassupekkhāsahagatacittasampayuttā”tiādinā cittato.
analyzed: puggalataḥ chaḷaṅgu pekkhā somanassu pekkhā sahagata citta sampayuttā ati ādinā cittataḥ
translated: “The equanimity about the six sense doors is associated with consciousness accompanied by joy and associated with equanimity” , and so on according to association.

original: “Chaḷaṅgupekkhā chaḷārammaṇā, brahmavihārupekkhā dhammārammaṇā”tiādinā ārammaṇato.
analyzed: chaṭṭha aṅga upekkhā chaṭṭha ārammaṇā brahmavihāra upekkhā dhamma ārammaṇā ati ādinā ārammaṇato
translated: “The equanimity about the six sense doors has six objects, that of the divine abidings has the ideas of the divine abidings as object” , and so on according to object.

original: Khandhasaṅgahaekakkhaṇakusalattikasaṅkhepavasenāti “vedanupekkhā vedanākkhandhena
analyzed: khandha saṅgaha eka khaṇa kusala ttika saṅkhepa vasena ati vedan upekkhā vedanā kkhandhena
translated: As to grouping under the aggregates, as to a single moment, as to the three kinds of skill, as to the brief and detailed version, “The equanimity about feeling is included in the feeling aggregate,🔽the other two in the formations aggregate” , is according to grouping under the aggregates.

original: saṅgahitā, itarā nava saṅkhārakkhandhenā”ti khandhasaṅgahavasena. Chaḷaṅgupekkhā🔽brahmavihārabojjhaṅgajhānapārisuddhitatramajjhattupekkhā ca atthato ekā, tasmā ekakkhaṇe
analyzed: saṅgahitāḥ itarāḥ nava saṅkhāra kkhandhena ati khandha saṅgaha vasena chaṭṭha aṅga upekkhā  ca atthataḥ ekā tasmai eka khaṇe
translated: The equanimity about the six sense doors,🔽the divine-abidings equanimity, the enlightenment factor equanimity, the jhāna equanimity, and the middle equanimity are one in meaning, so that when one of them is present the others are too.🔽So also the equanimity about formations and the equanimity of insight should be understood.

original: tāsu ekāya sati na itarā, tathā saṅkhārupekkhāvipassanupekkhāpi veditabbā, vedanāvīriyupekkhānaṃ
analyzed: tāsu ekāya sati na itarā tathā saṅkhāra upekkhā vipassanā upekkhā api veditabbā vedanā vīriya upekkhānaṃ
translated: And the equanimity of feeling and the equanimity of energy

original: ekakkhaṇe siyā uppattīti evaṃ ekakkhaṇavasena. Chaḷaṅgupekkhā abyākatā, brahmavihārupekkhā
analyzed: eka khaṇe siyā uppatti iti evam eka khaṇa vasena chaḍaṅga upekkhā abyākatā brahmavihāra upekkhā
translated: In a single moment: in this way, by way of a single moment. The equanimity of the six sense doors is indeterminate. The equanimity of the divine abidings is

original: kusalābyākatā, tathā sesā, vedanupekkhā pana siyā akusalāpīti evaṃ kusalattikavasena.
analyzed: kusala abyākatā tathā sesā vedanupekkhā pana siyā akusalā api iti evam kusala ttika vasena
translated: wholesome and indeterminate. So too, the rest. But the equanimity of feeling may be unwholesome as well. In this way, by way of the three classes of wholesomeness.

original: Dasapetā saṅkhepato cattārova dhammā vīriyavedanātatramajjhattatāñāṇavasenāti evaṃ saṅkhepavasena.
analyzed: dasa petā saṅkhepato cattāro va dhammā vīriya vedanā tatram ajjhatta tā ñāṇa vasena ati evam saṅkhepa vasena
translated: The ten kinds of equanimity are, in brief, four dhammas: energy, feeling, the middle, and knowledge. In this way, by way of briefness.

original: Idāni idhādhippetāya jhānupekkhāya lakkhaṇādiṃ niddhāretvā dassento āha “lakkhaṇādito
analyzed: idāni idha adhippetāya jhānupekkhāya lakkhaṇa ādim niddhāretvā dassentaḥ āha lakkhaṇa āditaḥ
translated: Now, pointing out the characteristic, etc., of the equanimity of jhāna, which is intended here, he said, “The characteristic, etc.,

original: panā”tiādi. Tattha anābhogarasāti paṇītasukhepi tasmiṃ avanatipaṭipakkhakiccāti attho.
analyzed: pana atiādi tattha anābhoga rasā ati paṇīta sukhe pi tasmin avanati paṭipakkha kiccā ati attho
translated: is non-restraint in taste.” The meaning is that it is the opposite of the function of bending towards, in that even in that refined pleasure.

original: Abyāpārapaccupaṭṭhānāti satipi sukhapāramippattiyaṃ tasmiṃ sukhe abyāvaṭā hutvā paccupatiṭṭhati,
analyzed: a byāpāra paccupaṭṭhānā ti sati pi sukha pārami pattiyam tasmim sukhe a byāvaṭāḥ hutvā paccupatiṭṭhati
translated: The manifestation is non-affliction: even though the fulfilment of pleasure has been reached, it stands manifesting non-affliction in that pleasure,

original: sampayuttānaṃ vā tattha abyāpāraṃ paccupaṭṭhapetīti attho. Sampayuttadhammānaṃ khobhaṃ
analyzed: sampayuttānam vā tattha a byāpāram paccupaṭṭhapeti iti attho sampayutta dhammānam khobham
translated: or it causes the non-affliction of the associated states to be manifested there. The meaning is that it causes the associated states to be🔽equanimous.

original: uppilavañca āvahantehi vitakkādīhi abhibhūtattā aparibyattaṃ tattha tatramajjhattatāya
analyzed: āvahantehi vitakka ādīhi a paribyattam tattha tatram ajjhatta tāya
translated: and it is not adaptable because it is overcome by the thoughts of conceit, etc., and is not equanimous in regard to them.

original: kiccaṃ, tadabhāvato idha paribyattanti āha “aparibyattakiccato”ti. Tenevāha “aparibyattaṃ hī”tiādi.🔽Idāni sato ca sampajānoti ettha “vuccatī”ti ajjhāharitabbaṃ. Saratīti iminā “sato”ti
analyzed: kiccam tad abhāvataḥ idha paribyattanti āha a paribyatta kiccato ti tena iva āha a paribyattam hi itiādi  idāni sataḥ ca sampajānoti ettha vuccati iti ajjhāharitabbam sarati iti iminā sataḥ ti
translated: But here it is adaptable because it has that quality. That is why he said “because it is not adaptable” and so on.

original: padassa kattusādhanatamāha. Sampajānātīti sammadeva pajānāti. Puggalenāti puggalādhiṭṭhānena.
analyzed: padassa kattu sādhanatam āha sampajānāti iti sammat eva pajānāti puggalena ati puggala adhiṭṭhānena
translated: Now as to “mindful and fully aware”: the word “said” should be supplied. By “mindful” he shows the agency of the word “mindful” in the sense of one who remembers. By “fully aware” he shows the sense of one who is fully aware of. “In regard to a person”: in regard to a person as object.🔽The characteristic of mindfulness is the remembering, the bearing in mind, the keeping in evidence, the making a focus of attention.🔽The function is the non-forgetting of that. The manifestation is the state of one whose nature it is to prevent the loss of the object by not letting it go.🔽The proximate cause of mindfulness is the sign of the object.

original: Saraṇaṃ cintanaṃ upaṭṭhānaṃ lakkhaṇametissāti saraṇalakkhaṇā. Sammussanapaṭipakkho
analyzed: saraṇam cintanam upaṭṭhānam lakkhaṇam etissa ati saraṇa lakkhaṇā sammussana paṭipakkho
translated: The characteristic of full awareness is the full understanding of the object.

original: asammussanaṃ kiccaṃ etissāti asammussanarasā. Kilesehi ārakkhā hutvā paccupatiṭṭhati,🔽tato vā ārakkhaṃ paccupaṭṭhapetīti ārakkhapaccupaṭṭhānā. Asammuyhanaṃ sammadeva pajānanaṃ,
analyzed: a sammussanam kiccam etissa ati a sammussana rasā kilesehi ārakkhā hutvā paccupatiṭṭhati 🔽tatas vā ārakkham paccupaṭṭhapeti iti ārakkha paccupaṭṭhānā a sammuyhanam sammat eva pajānanam
translated: The function is the non-confusion of that. The manifestation is the state of one whose nature it is to prevent confusion of the object.

original: sammohapaṭipakkho vā asammoho lakkhaṇametassāti asammohalakkhaṇaṃ. Tīraṇaṃ kiccassa🔽pāragamanaṃ. Pavicayo vīmaṃsā. Kāmaṃ upacārajjhānādiṃ upādāya paṭhamadutiyajjhānānipi
analyzed: sammoha paṭipakkhaḥ vā asammohaḥ lakkhaṇam etassa ati asammoha lakkhaṇam tīraṇam kiccassa  pāra gamanam vīmaṃsā kāmam upacāra jhāna ādim upādāya paṭhama dutiya jhānāni pi
translated: Or else non-delusion is a distinguishing mark in that it is the opposite of delusion. Its function is to make a decision about an object.🔽Its manifestation is the crossing of a river. Its proximate cause is investigation.

original: sukhumāneva, imaṃ pana uparimajjhānaṃ upādāya “oḷārikattā pana tesaṃ jhānāna”nti
analyzed: sukhumān eva imam pana uparima jhānam upādāya oḷārika ttā pana tesam
translated: The first and second jhānas are subtle too, to be sure, in comparison with the jhāna of the sensuous sphere, and so on. But it is said of them: “But because of the grossness of those jhānas” .🔽And that grossness should be understood as grossness of mental process owing to the presence of applied thought, etc.,

original: vuttaṃ, sā ca oḷārikatā vitakkādithūlaṅgatāya veditabbā. Keci “bahucetasikatāyā”ti
