translated: for grief does not occur without hate. And it should not be supposed that there is a contradiction here with the text of the Schedule.

original: Yasmā tattha parihīnajjhānaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā pavattamānaṃ domanassaṃ dassitaṃ, aparihīnajjhānaṃ
analyzed: yasmā tattha parihīna jhānam ārammaṇam katvā pavattamānam domanassam dassitam a parihīna jhānam
translated: For what is shown there is grief occurring with the jhāna’s object as its object in one who has fallen away from the jhāna,

original: ārammaṇaṃ katvā uppajjamānassa domanassassa asambhavato jhānalābhīnaṃ sabbaso domanassaṃ
analyzed: ārammaṇam katvā uppajjamānassa domanassassa asambhavataḥ jhāna lābhīnam sabbaso domanassam
translated: and because it is impossible for grief to arise in one who has attained jhāna by making that grief’s object.

original: nuppajjatīti ca na sakkā vattuṃ aṭṭhasamāpattilābhino api tassa uppannattā, na heva
analyzed: nuppajjati iti ca na sakkā vattum aṭṭha samāpatti lābhinaḥ api tassa uppanna ttā na ha eva
translated: And it cannot be said that grief does not arise in one who has attained jhāna at all, because it does arise in one who has attained the eight attainments.

original: kho so parihīnajjhāno ahosī”ti, taṃ ayuttaṃ anīvaraṇasabhāvassa domanassassa abhāvato.
analyzed: kho so parihīna jhānaḥ ahosi iti tat ayuttam anīvaraṇa sabhāvassa domanassassa abhāvato
translated: But it is not right to say that he is one who has lapsed from jhāna.

original: Yadi siyā, rūpārūpāvacarasattānampi uppajjeyya, na ca uppajjati. Tathā hi āruppe
analyzed: yadi siyā rūpa arūpa avacara sattānam pi uppajjeyya na ca uppajjati tathā hi āruppe
translated: If it were, it would arise in beings in the fine-material and immaterial realms too, but it does not.

original: kāmacchandanīvaraṇaṃ paṭicca thinamiddhanīvaraṇaṃ uddhaccanīvaraṇaṃ avijjānīvaraṇantiādīsu🔽byāpādakukkuccanīvaraṇāni anuddhaṭāni, na cettha anīvaraṇatāpariyāyo kāmacchandādīnampi
analyzed: kāmacchanda nīvaraṇam paṭicca thinamiddha nīvaraṇam uddhacca nīvaraṇam avijjā nīvaraṇa nti ādīsu  byāpāda kukkucca nīvaraṇāni anuddhaṭāni na ca itthā anīvaraṇa tā pariyāyaḥ kāmacchanda ādīnam pi
translated: For in the passage, “With the sense-desire element as condition there is the hindrance of lust, with the ill-will element as condition there is the hindrance of ill-will, with the stiffness-and-torpor element as condition there is the hindrance of stiffness-and-torpor, with the agitation-and-worry element as condition there is the hindrance of agitation-and-worry, with the uncertainty element as condition there is the hindrance of uncertainty” ,🔽the hindrances of ill-will and worry are not mentioned.🔽And it is not because they are not hindrances that they are not mentioned,🔽because the hindrance of lust, etc., are mentioned even though they are not hindrances here.

original: anīvaraṇānaṃyeva nīvaraṇasadisatāya nīvaraṇapariyāyassa vuttattā. Yaṃ pana vuttaṃ
analyzed: anīvaraṇānaṃ yeva nīvaraṇa sadisa tāya nīvaraṇa pariyāyassa vutta ttā yat pana vuttam
translated: But it was said that it is impossible for grief to arise in one who has attained jhāna by making that grief’s object.

original: “aṭṭhasamāpattilābhino api tassa uppannattā”ti, tampi akāraṇaṃ uppajjamānena ca domanassena
analyzed: aṭṭha samāpatti lābhinaḥ api tassa uppanna ttā ati tat pi akāraṇam uppajjamānena ca domanassena
translated: And it is not a reason to say that it arises in one who has attained the eight attainments.

original: jhānato parihāyanato. Lahukena pana paccayena parihīnaṃ tādisā naṃ appakasireneva
analyzed: jhānataḥ parihāyanataḥ lahukena pana paccayena parihīnam tādisā nam appa kasirena iva
translated: and from the jhāna, too, through falling away from it. But when it has fallen away through a light condition, it should be regarded as being restored by the mere renewal of the application of the will.

original: paṭipākatikaṃ karontīti daṭṭhabbaṃ. “Tatthassa siyā uppattī”ti idaṃ pana parikappanavacanaṃ
analyzed: paṭipākatikam karonti iti daṭṭhabbam tattha siyā uppatti iti idam pana parikappana vacanam
translated: “There it may arise in him”: this is said for the purpose of showing that the words “he does not advert to the sign” are said of the time of access.

original: upacārakkhaṇe domanassassa appahīnabhāvadassanatthaṃ. Tathā hi vuttaṃ “na tveva antoappanāya”nti.
analyzed: upacāra kkhaṇe domanassassa appahīna bhāva dassana attham tathā hi vuttam na tu eva antoappanāyanti
translated: For it is said: “But not by the mere act of adverting” .

original: Yadi pana tadā domanassaṃ uppajjeyya, paṭhamajjhānampissa parihīnamevāti daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: yadi pana tadā domanassam uppajjeyya paṭhamajjhānam pissa parihīnam eva ati daṭṭhabbaṃ
translated: But if it were to arise then, it should be regarded as having fallen away from the first jhāna too.

original: Pahīnampi somanassindriyaṃ pīti viya na dūreti katvā “āsannattā”ti vuttaṃ. Nānāvajjanūpacāre
analyzed: pahīnam pi somanassindriyam viya na dūra iti katvā āsanna ttā iti vuttam nānā vajjana upacāre
translated: And although the joy faculty has been abandoned, it is said that “it is near” because it is not far away, like the happiness .

original: pahīnampi pahānaṅgaṃ paṭipakkhena avihatattā antarantarā uppajjeyya vāti imamatthaṃ
analyzed: pahīnam pi pahāna aṅgam paṭipakkhena avihata ttā antarantarā uppajjeyya vā ti imamattham
translated: And although the factor of abandoning has been abandoned, it should arise again from time to time because it has not been suppressed by its opposite in the case of one who has not reached the stage of conformity.

original: dassento “appanāppattāyā”tiādimāha. Tādisāya āsevanāya icchitabbattā yathā maggavīthito
analyzed: dassentaḥ appanā appattāya ati ādim āha tādisāya āsevanāya icchitabba ttā yathā magga vīthitaḥ
translated: Showing the meaning of this, he said: “When he has reached the attainment” , etc.

original: pubbe dve tayo javanavārā sadisānupassanāva pavattanti, evamidhāpi appanāvārato pubbe
analyzed: pubbe dve tayo javana vārā sadisa anupassanā va pavattanti evam idha api appanā vārato pubbe
translated: Two or three impulsions occurring similarly to the life-continuum before absorption is reached are called “access.”🔽

original: dve tayo javanavārā upekkhāsahagatāva pavattantīti vadanti.
analyzed: dve tayaḥ javana vārāḥ upekkhā sahagatāḥ ava pavattanti iti vadanti
translated: The two or three impulsions that precede absorption are of the same kind as the contemplation. So too here, they say, the two or three impulsions that precede absorption are of the same kind as equanimity.

original: Samāharīti samānesi, saṅgahetvā abhāsīti attho. Sukhumāti sukhadukkhāni viya anoḷārikattā
analyzed: samāhari iti samānesi saṅgahetvā abhāsi iti attho sukhumā ti sukha dukkhāni viya anoḷārika ttā
translated: He brought together: he brought into being, he spoke, is the meaning. Subtle: subtle because of non-grossness, like pleasure and pain,

original: avibhūtatāya sukhumā, tato eva anuminitabbasabhāvattā dubbiññeyyā. Duṭṭhassāti duṭṭhapayogassa,
analyzed: avibhūta tāya sukhumā tatas eva anuminitabba sabhāva ttā dubbiññeyyā duṭṭhassa ati duṭṭha payogassa
translated: because of non-manifestness. Because of that it is hard to recognize, since its nature can only be inferred. For the wicked: for one of wicked practice.

original: duddamassāti attho. Sakkā hoti esā gāhayitunti aññāpohananayena sakkā gāhayitunti
analyzed: duddamassa ati attho sakkā hoti esā gāhayitunti aññā apohana nayena sakkā gāhayitunti
translated: Hard to see: hard to subdue, is the meaning. It is possible to take it: the intention is that it is possible to take it by the method of exclusion.

original: adhippāyo. Adukkhamasukhāya cetovimuttiyāti idameva catutthaṃ jhānaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.🔽Paccayadassanatthanti adhigamassa upāyabhūtapaccayadassanatthaṃ. Tenāha “dukkhappahānādayo
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ adukkham asukhāya cetaḥ vimuttiyā ti idam eva catuttham jhānam daṭṭhabbaṃ  paccaya dassana ttham ti adhigamassa upāya bhūta paccaya dassana ttham tena āha dukkha ppahāna ādayaḥ
translated: And the liberation of the heart that is neither-unhappy-nor-happy: this should be regarded as the fourth jhāna.

original: hi tassā paccayā”ti. Dukkhappahānādayoti ca sopacārā paṭhamajjhānādayovettha adhippetā.
analyzed: hi tassā paccayā ti dukkha ppahāna ādayaḥ ti ca sa upacārā adhippetā
translated: For the purpose of showing the conditions: for the purpose of showing the conditions that are the means to the attainment. Hence he said: “For its conditions are the abandoning of pleasure, and so on” . And here the first jhāna, and so on, with their adjuncts are intended by “the abandoning of pleasure, and so on.”

original: Pahīnāti vuttāti “pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā”ti vuttattā. Etāti🔽sukhādayo vedanā. Sukhaṃ somanassassa paccayoti vasanagandhālepanapupphābharaṇasamālepanādinibbattaṃ🔽kāyikasukhaṃ somanassassa paccayo. “Sukhāya kho, āvuso visākha vedanāya, rāgānusayo
analyzed: pahīnā ati vuttā ti pañcannam orambhāgiyānam saṃyojanānam parikkhayā ati vutta ttā etā ati  sukha ādayaḥ vedanā sukham somanassassa paccayo ti vasana gandha ālepana puppha ābharaṇa samālepana ādi nibbattam  kāyika sukham somanassassa paccayaḥ sukhāya kho āvuso visākha vedanāya rāga anusayaḥ
translated: “Abandoned” is said because of the words “with the destruction of the five lower fetters” . “These”

original: anusetī”ti vacanato āha “somanassaṃ rāgassa paccayo”ti. “Dukkhāya kho, āvuso visākha,🔽vedanāya paṭighānusayo anusetī”ti vacanato vuttaṃ “domanassaṃ dosassa paccayo”ti.
analyzed: anuseti iti vacanataḥ āha somanassam rāgassa paccayaḥ ti dukkhāya kho āvuso visākha  vedanāya paṭigha anusayaḥ anuseti iti vacanataḥ vuttam domanassam dosassa paccayo ti
translated: are the feelings of pleasure, etc. “Pleasure is a condition for joy” : bodily pleasure that arises from the use of robes, alms food, etc., is a condition for joy. Because of the words “Friend Visākha, in pleasant feeling craving is present” , he says “joy is a condition for craving.” Because of the words “Friend Visākha, in painful feeling the underlying tendency to irritation is present” , he says “grief is a condition for hatred.”

original: Sukhādighātenāti sukhādīnaṃ pahānena.🔽Adukkhamasukhanti ettha na dukkhanti adukkhaṃ, dukkhavidūraṃ. Yasmā tattha dukkhaṃ
analyzed: sukha ādi ghātena ati pahānena  adukkham asukhanti ettha na dukkhanti adukkham dukkha vidūram yasmā tattha dukkham
translated: “By the abandoning of pleasure, etc.”: by the abandoning of pleasure, etc.

original: natthi, tasmā vuttaṃ “dukkhābhāvenā”ti. Asukhanti etthāpi eseva nayo. Etenāti dukkhasukhapaṭikkhepavacanena.
analyzed: natthi tasmā vuttam dukkha abhāvena ati asukhanti ettha api esa iva nayaḥ etena ati dukkha sukha paṭikkhepa vacanena
translated: “Neither-painful-nor-pleasant”: “not painful” means “free from pain,” “far removed from pain.” Because there is no pain there, it is said “by the absence of pain.” “Not pleasant” means “free from pleasure,” “far removed from pleasure.” Because there is no pleasure there, it is said “by the absence of pleasure.” “By these words” : by the words that deny pain and pleasure.

original: Paṭipakkhabhūtanti idaṃ idha tatiyavedanāya dukkhādīnaṃ samatikkamavasena pattabbattā
analyzed: paṭipakkha bhūtanti idam idha tatiya vedanāya dukkha ādīnam samatikkama vasena pattabba ttā
translated: This is said because the third feeling is to be reached here by surmounting pleasure and pain,

original: vuttaṃ, na kusalākusalānaṃ viya ujuvipaccanīkatāya. Iṭṭhāniṭṭhaviparītānubhavanalakkhaṇāti
analyzed: vuttam na kusala akusalānam viya uju vipaccanīka tāya iṭṭha aniṭṭha viparīta anubhavana lakkhaṇā ti
translated: not because it is the direct opposite of the profitable and the unprofitable. The characteristic of its is that of experiencing the opposite of the desirable and the undesirable.

original: iṭṭhāniṭṭhaviparītassa majjhattārammaṇassa, iṭṭhāniṭṭhaviparītaṃ vā majjhattākārena
analyzed: iṭṭha aniṭṭha viparītassa majjhatta ārammaṇassa iṭṭha aniṭṭha viparītam vā majjhatta ākārena
translated: The meaning is that it experiences the opposite of the desirable and the undesirable in the aspect of neutrality, or it experiences the desirable and the undesirable in the aspect of neutrality.

original: anubhavanalakkhaṇā. Tato eva majjhattarasā. Avibhūtapaccupaṭṭhānāti sukhadukkhāni
analyzed: anubhavana lakkhaṇā tatas eva majjhatta rasā avibhūta paccupaṭṭhānā ati sukha dukkhāni
translated: And because of that it has the taste of neutrality. Its manifestation is unadulterated: it is not adulterated in aspect, like pleasure and pain,

original: viya na vibhūtākārā piṭṭhipāsāṇe migagatamaggo viya tehi anumātabbāvibhūtākāropaṭṭhānā.
analyzed: viya na vibhūta ākārā piṭṭhi pāsāṇe miga gata maggaḥ viya tehi anumātabba a vibhūta ākāra upaṭṭhānā
translated: but its manifestation is to be inferred by them, like the path traversed by a deer in a mountain cleft.🔽The approach to the fourth jhāna is called “the cessation of pleasure” here. It is the basis for that,

original: Sukhanirodho nāma idha catutthajjhānūpacāro, so padaṭṭhānaṃ etissāti sukhanirodhapadaṭṭhānā.🔽Upekkhāsatipārisuddhinti purimapade uttarapadalopenetaṃ samāsapadanti āha “upekkhāya
analyzed: sukha nirodho nāma idha catuttha jhāna upacāro so padaṭṭhānam etissa ati sukha nirodha padaṭṭhānā  upekkhā sati pārisuddhin ti purima pade uttara pada lopena itam samāsa padam ti āha upekkhāya
translated: thus it is “having the cessation of pleasure as its basis.”🔽The compound upekkhāsatipārisuddhi is a dvanda compound, he says, with the elision of a pada, thus “purification of mindfulness due to equanimity”

original: janitasatipārisuddhi”nti. Sabbapaccanīkadhammaparisuddhāya paccanīkasamanepi abyāvaṭāya
analyzed: janita sati pārisuddhinti sabba paccanīka dhamma parisuddhāya paccanīka samane pi a byāvaṭāya
translated: is what is meant. It is because it is purified from all opposing states and is not sluggish in opposing those states,

original: pārisuddhupekkhāya vattamānāya catutthajjhāne sati sampahaṃsanapaññā viya suparisuddhā
analyzed: pārisuddha upekkhāya vattamānāya catuttha jhāne sati sampahaṃsana paññā viya su parisuddhā
translated: When equanimity as purification is occurring, mindfulness is purified and clear, like the fanning of a fire in the fourth jhāna.

original: suvisadā ca hotīti āha “satiyā pārisuddhi, sā upekkhāya katā na aññenā”ti. Yadi tatramajjhattatā
analyzed: su visadā ca hoti iti āha satiyā pārisuddhi sā upekkhāya katā na aññena ati yadi tatram ajjhatta tā
translated: That is why it is said: “Purity of mindfulness is equanimity, and that is accomplished by equanimity, not by anything else.”

original: idha “upekkhā”ti adhippetā, kathaṃ satiyeva pārisuddhāti vuttāti āha “na kevala”ntiādi.
analyzed: idha upekkhā ati adhippetā katham satiyā iva pārisuddhā ati vuttā iti āha na kevala ntiādi
translated: If the neutrality of mind is intended here by “equanimity,” how is it said to be “purity of mindfulness”? That is why he said: “Not only …

original: Satisīsenāti satiṃ uttamaṅgaṃ katvā, padhānaṃ katvāti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: sati sīsena ati satim uttamaṅgam katvā padhānam katvā iti vuttam hoti
translated: By the head of mindfulness”: by making mindfulness the head, the chief, the leader, is what is meant.

original: Evamapi kasmā idheva sati “upekkhāsatipārisuddhī”ti vuttāti anuyogaṃ sandhāya “tattha🔽kiñcāpī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha heṭṭhā tīsu jhānesu vijjamānāyapi tatramajjhattatāya
analyzed: evam api kasmai idha iva sati upekkhā sati pārisuddhī iti vuttā ati anuyogam sandhāya tattha  kiñcā api itiādi vuttam tattha heṭṭhā tīsu jhānesu tatram ajjhatta tāya
translated: But why is it said here only of mindfulness that it is “purity of equanimity and mindfulness”? Anticipating this question, he said: “Here …

original: paccanīkābhibhavanato sahāyapaccayavekallato ca apārisuddhi, tathā taṃsampayuttānaṃ
analyzed: paccanīka abhibhavanato sahāya paccaya vekallato ca tathā tad sampayuttānam
translated: Although neutrality of mind exists in the three lower jhānas, it is not purified there because it is overcome by opposition and because it lacks the requisite conditions of a companion, etc.,🔽and because the associated states are not purified. But here it is purified because of the absence of those. This is the meaning. In order to illustrate this he gave the simile of the moon’s disk,

original: tadabhāvato idha pārisuddhīti imamatthaṃ upamāvasena dassetuṃ “yathā panā”tiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tad abhāvataḥ idha pārisuddhī iti imam attham upamā vasena dassetum yathā pana atiādi vuttam
translated: “Just as …

original: Sūriyappabhābhibhavāti sūriyappabhāya abhibhuyyamānattā. Atikkhatāya candalekhā viya
analyzed: sūriyappabhā abhibhavā ati sūriyappabhāya atikkhatāya candalekhā viya
translated: Overpowered by the sun’s rays: because it is overpowered by the sun’s rays.🔽Like the line of the dawn:🔽the line of the dawn shines in the night only, and it is similar to the night in being of the same nature as the night.

original: rattipi sommasabhāvā sabhāgāya rattiyameva ca candalekhā samujjalatīti sā tassā saṅgayhatīti
analyzed: rattipi somma sabhāvā sabhāgāya rattiyam eva ca canda lekhā samujjalati iti sā tassā saṅgayhati iti
translated: So it is associated with the night.

original: dassento “sommabhāvena ca attano upakārakattena vā sabhāgāya rattiyā”ti āha. Sesamettha uttānatthameva.
analyzed: dassentaḥ somma bhāvena ca attanaḥ upakāraka ttena vā sabhāgāya rattiyā iti āha sesam ettha uttānattham eva
translated: Showing this, he said “to the night which is similar to it in being of the same nature as itself or in being helpful to it.” The rest is clear.

original: Catutthajjhānakathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: catuttha jhāna kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the fourth meditation is ended.

original: Pubbenivāsakathā
analyzed: pubbenivāsa kathā
translated: The explanation of recollection of past lives

original: 12. Rūpavirāgabhāvanāvasena pavattaṃ catubbidhampi arūpajjhānaṃ catutthajjhānasaṅgahamevāti
analyzed: rūpa virāga bhāvanā vasena pavattam catubbidham pi arūpa jhānam catuttha jhāna saṅgaham eva ati
translated: . The fourfold immaterial jhāna, which occurs by means of the development of the surmounting of perception of matter, is included in the fourth meditation,

original: āha “cattāri jhānānī”ti. Yuttaṃ tāva cittekaggatā bhavokkamanatthatā viya vipassanāpādakatāpi🔽catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ sādhāraṇāti tesaṃ vasena “cattāri jhānānī”ti vacanaṃ, abhiññāpādakatā
analyzed: āha cattāri jhānāni iti yuttam tāva citta ekagga tā bhava ukkamana attha tā viya vipassanā pādaka tā api  catunnam jhānānam sādhāraṇā ati tesam vasena cattāri jhānāni iti vacanam abhiññā pādaka tā
translated: so he said “four meditations.” It is appropriate that the state of being a condition for direct-knowledge, like the state of being a condition for emergence from jhāna,

original: pana nirodhapādakatā ca catutthasseva jhānassa āveṇikā, sā kathaṃ catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ
analyzed: pana nirodha pādaka tā ca catutthassa iva jhānassa āveṇikā sā katham catunnam jhānānam
translated: should be common to the four meditations, so the statement “four meditations” is made on the grounds of that. But the state of being a condition for the kinds of direct-knowledge and the state of being a condition for the attainment of cessation are unique to the fourth meditation only. How then can the statement “four meditations” be made on the grounds of that?

original: sādhāraṇā vuttāti? Paramparādhiṭṭhānabhāvato. Padaṭṭhānapadaṭṭhānampi hi padaṭṭhānantveva🔽vuccati, kāraṇakāraṇampi kāraṇanti yathā “tiṇehi bhattaṃ siddha”nti. Evañca katvā🔽payojananiddese aṭṭhasamāpattiggahaṇaṃ samatthitaṃ hoti. Cittekaggatatthānīti ittasamādhatthāni,🔽diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāratthānīti attho. Cittekaggatāsīsena hi diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāro
analyzed: sādhāraṇā vuttā ati paramparā adhiṭṭhāna bhāvato padaṭṭhāna padaṭṭhānam pi hi padaṭṭhānam tu eva  vuccati kāraṇa kāraṇam pi kāraṇanti yathā tiṇehi bhattam evam ca katvā  payojana niddese aṭṭha samāpatti ggahaṇam samatthitam hoti citta ekagga tatthāni iti  diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihāra atthāni iti attho citta ekagga tā sīsena hi diṭṭhadhamma sukha vihāraḥ
translated: Are they common? They are so called because they are the basis of the series. For what is a basis of a basis is called simply a basis,🔽just as what is a cause of a cause is called simply a cause. “Rice cooked with grass” is said. And so,🔽in the description of the purpose, the inclusion of the eight attainments is appropriate. They are for the purpose of unification of cognizance: for the purpose of unification of concentration.🔽They are for the purpose of abiding in comfort in this very life: this is the meaning. For abiding in comfort in this very life is by means of unification of cognizance.

original: vutto, sukkhavipassakakhīṇāsavavasena cetaṃ vuttaṃ. Tenāha “ekaggacittā sukhaṃ divasaṃ🔽viharissāmā”ti. Bhavokkamanatthānīti bhavesu nibbattiatthāni. Sattāhaṃ nirodhasamāpattiyā🔽samāpajjanato āha “sattāhaṃ acittakā hutvā”ti. Kasmā pana sattāhameva nirodhaṃ samāpajjantīti?
analyzed: vuttaḥ sukkha vipassaka khīṇāsava vasena ca itam vuttam tena āha ekagga cittā sukham divasam 🔽viharissāma ati bhava ukkamana atthāni iti bhavesu nibbatti atthāni satta aham nirodha samāpattiyā 🔽samāpajjanataḥ āha satta aham acittakāḥ hutvā ati kasmā pana satta aham eva nirodham samāpajjanti iti
translated: Are they common? They are so in the sense of being the basis of the other. For what is a basis of a basis is called simply a basis, just as what is a cause of a cause is called simply a cause, as in the passage, “Rice is the cause of a cause” . And in that case the inclusion of the eight attainments in the description of the purpose is appropriate. They are for the purpose of unification of cognizance: for the purpose of concentration of cognizance. The meaning is that they are for the purpose of abiding in bliss here and now. For abiding in bliss here and now is stated with reference to unification of cognizance. And this is said with reference to the dry-insight worker and the cankerless saint. That is why it is said, “We shall abide in bliss here and now, with unified cognizance” . They are for the purpose of transcending being: for the purpose of rebirth in becoming. He says, “We shall be without cognizance for seven days,” because he attains cessation for seven days.

original: Tathākālaparicchedakaraṇato, tañca yebhuyyena āhārūpajīvīnaṃ sattānaṃ upādinnakappavattassa
analyzed: tathā kāla pariccheda karaṇataḥ tat ca yebhuyyena āhāra upajīvīnam sattānam upādinna kappa vattassa
translated: And it is the maker of the delimitation of time, and that is mostly in the case of beings who live by physical nutriment and who have what is clung to as their occurrence.

original: ekadivasaṃ bhuttāhārassa sattāhameva yāpanato.🔽Kā panāyaṃ nirodhasamāpatti nāma, ke taṃ samāpajjanti, ke na samāpajjanti, kattha
analyzed: eka divasam bhutta āhārassa satta aham eva yāpanataḥ  kā pana ayam nirodha samāpatti nāma ke tam samāpajjanti ke na samāpajjanti kattha
translated: And it is so called too because it defines the time, for it is by this that the life-span of beings who subsist on material food is maintained for seven days at most after the last meal.

original: samāpajjanti, kasmā samāpajjanti, kathañcassā samāpajjanaṃ hotīti? Vuccate – tattha
analyzed: samāpajjanti kasmā samāpajjanti katham ca assā samāpajjanam hoti iti vuccate tattha
translated: But what is this attainment of cessation? Who attains it? Who does not? Where do they attain it? Why do they attain it? And how does the attainment come about in this case?🔽Here is the answer:

original: kā panāyaṃ nirodhasamāpatti nāmāti yā anupubbanirodhavasena cittacetasikānaṃ dhammānaṃ🔽appavatti. Ke taṃ samāpajjanti, ke na samāpajjantīti sabbepi puthujjanasotāpannasakadāgāmino
analyzed: kā pana ayam nirodha samāpatti nāma ati yā anupubba nirodha vasena citta cetasikānam dhammānam  appavatti ke tam samāpajjanti ke na samāpajjanti iti sabbe pi puthujjana sa utāpanna sakadāgāmino
translated: What is this attainment of cessation? It is the non- occurrence of consciousness and its concomitants by suppression.

original: sukkhavipassakā ca anāgāmiarahanto na samāpajjanti, aṭṭhasamāpattilābhino pana anāgāmino
analyzed: sukkha vipassakā ca anāgāmi arahantaḥ na samāpajjanti aṭṭha samāpatti lābhinaḥ pana anāgāmino
translated: Who attains it? Who does not? Ordinary men, stream- enterers, once-returners, and non-returners who are bare- insight workers do not attain it. But non-returners who have attained the eight attainments and arahats who have attained the eight attainments attain it.

original: khīṇāsavā ca samāpajjanti. Kattha samāpajjantīti pañcavokārabhave. Kasmā? Anupubbasamāpattisabbhāvato.
analyzed: khīṇa āsavā ca samāpajjanti kattha samāpajjanti iti pañcavokāra bhave kasmai anupubba samāpatti sabbhāvato
translated: Where do they attain it? In the five-constituent kind of becoming. Why? Because it is a successive attainment.

original: Catuvokārabhave pana paṭhamajjhānādīnaṃ uppattiyeva natthi, tasmā na sakkā tattha🔽samāpajjituṃ. Kasmā samāpajjantīti saṅkhārānaṃ pavattibhede ukkaṇṭhitvā “diṭṭhadhamme
analyzed: catuvokāra bhave pana paṭhamajjhāna ādīnam uppattiyā iva natthi tasmā na sakkā tattha  samāpajjitum kasmā samāpajjanti iti saṅkhārānam pavatti bhede ukkaṇṭhitvā diṭṭhadhamme
translated: But there is no arising of the first jhāna, etc., in the fourfold existence, so it cannot be entered there.

original: acittakā hutvā nirodhaṃ nibbānaṃ patvā sukhaṃ viharissāmā”ti. Kathañcassā samāpajjanaṃ
analyzed: acittakāḥ hutvā nirodham nibbānam patvā sukham viharissāma ati katham ca assā samāpajjanam
translated: Why do they enter it? Because of dissatisfaction with the occurrence of formations, thinking, “Having become mindless in this very life, we shall dwell in bliss on entering the cessation that is Nibbāna.”

original: hotīti samathavipassanāvasena ussakkitvā katapubbakiccassa nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ🔽nirodhayato evamassā samāpajjanaṃ hoti. Yo hi samathavaseneva ussakkati, so nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpattiṃ
analyzed: hoti iti samatha vipassanā vasena ussakkitvā kata pubba kiccassa nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam  nirodhayataḥ evam assā samāpajjanam hoti yaḥ hi samatha vasena iva ussakkati saḥ nevasaññānāsaññāyatana samāpattim
translated: How does the entering of it come about? It comes about for one who has made the preliminary work effective by striving with serenity and insight and who then brings about the cessation of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception.

original: patvā tiṭṭhati. Yopi vipassanāvaseneva ussakkati, so phalasamāpattiṃ patvā tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: patvā tiṭṭhati yaḥ api vipassanā vasena iva ussakkati so phala samāpattim patvā tiṭṭhati
translated: For one who strives with serenity alone reaches the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception and stops there. And one who strives with insight alone reaches the fruition attainment and stops there.

original: Yo pana ubhayavaseneva ussakkitvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ nirodheti, so taṃ samāpajjatīti ayamettha saṅkhepo.
analyzed: yaḥ pana ubhaya vasena iva ussakkitvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam nirodheti saḥ tam samāpajjati iti ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ
translated: But one who strives with both reaches the cessation of perception and feeling and enters it. This is the brief treatment of it.

original: Ayaṃ pana vitthāro – idha bhikkhu nirodhaṃ samāpajjitukāmo paṭhamajjhānaṃ samāpajjitvā
analyzed: ayam pana vitthāraḥ idha bhikkhu nirodham samāpajjitu kāmo paṭhama jhānam samāpajjitvā
translated: This is the detailed explanation: Here a bhikkhu who wants to attain cessation attains the first jhāna.

original: vuṭṭhāya tattha saṅkhāre aniccato dukkhato anattato vipassati. Vipassanā ca panesā
analyzed: vuṭṭhāya tattha saṅkhāre aniccataḥ dukkhataḥ anattataḥ vipassati vipassanā ca pana isā
translated: On emerging he comprehends as impermanent, painful, and not-self the formations in that jhāna.

original: tividhā saṅkhārapariggaṇhanakavipassanā phalasamāpattivipassanā nirodhasamāpattivipassanāti.
analyzed: tividhā saṅkhāra pariggaṇhanaka vipassanā phala samāpatti vipassanā nirodha samāpatti vipassanā ati
translated: This insight is of three kinds: insight that discerns formations, insight that attains fruition attainment, and insight that attains cessation attainment.

original: Tattha saṅkhārapariggaṇhanakavipassanā mandā vā tikkhā vā maggassa padaṭṭhānaṃ hotiyeva.
analyzed: tattha saṅkhāra pariggaṇhanaka vipassanā mandā vā tikkhā vā maggassa padaṭṭhānam
translated: Herein, insight that discerns formations, whether sluggish or keen, is the proximate cause for the path.

original: Phalasamāpattivipassanā tikkhāva vaṭṭati maggabhāvanāsadisā. Nirodhasamāpattivipassanā
analyzed: phala samāpatti vipassanā vaṭṭati magga bhāvanā sadisā nirodha samāpatti vipassanā
translated: Insight that attains fruition attainment must be keen and is similar to development of the path.🔽But insight that attains cessation attainment must be neither sluggish nor keen.

original: pana nātimandanātitikkhā vaṭṭati, tasmā esa nātimandāya nātitikkhāya vipassanāya
analyzed: pana na atimanda na atitikkhā vaṭṭati tasmai esa na atimandāya na atitikkhāya vipassanāya
translated: So he comprehends those formations with insight that is neither sluggish nor keen.

original: te saṅkhāre vipassati. Tato dutiyajjhānaṃ…pe… tato viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samāpajjitvā🔽vuṭṭhāya tattha saṅkhāre tatheva vipassati. Atha ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya
analyzed: te saṅkhāre vipassati tatas dutiya jhānaṃ pe tatas viññāṇaṃ ca āyatanam samāpajjitvā 🔽vuṭṭhāya tattha saṅkhāre tathā iva vipassati atha ākiñcaññāyatanam samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya
translated: Then he attains the second jhāna … the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception.🔽On emerging he comprehends as impermanent, painful, and not-self the formations in that attainment.

original: catubbidhaṃ pubbakiccaṃ karoti nānābaddhaavikopanaṃ saṅghapatimānanaṃ satthupakkosanaṃ
analyzed: catubbidham pubba kiccam karoti nānā baddha a vikopanam saṅgha pati mānanam satthu pakkosanam
translated: He performs the four preliminary duties, namely, the duty of not disturbing those who are not related to him, the duty of pleasing the Community, the duty of informing the Teacher,

original: addhānaparicchedanti.🔽Tattha nānābaddhaavikopananti yaṃ iminā bhikkhunā saddhiṃ ekābaddhaṃ na hoti, nānābaddhaṃ
analyzed: addhāna paricchedanti  tattha nānābaddha avikopanam ti yam iminā bhikkhunā saddhim ekābaddham na hoti nānābaddham
translated: and the duty of defining the period.

original: hutvā ṭhitaṃ pattacīvaraṃ vā mañcapīṭhaṃ vā nivāsagehaṃ vā aññaṃ vā pana yaṃ kiñci🔽parikkhārajātaṃ, taṃ yathā na vikuppati, aggiudakavātacoraundūrādīnaṃ vasena na vinassati,🔽evaṃ adhiṭṭhātabbaṃ. Tatridaṃ adhiṭṭhānavidhānaṃ “idañcidañca imasmiṃ sattāhabbhantare
analyzed: hutvā ṭhitam patta cīvaram vā mañca pīṭham vā nivāsa geham vā aññam vā pana yam kiñci  parikkhāra jātam tam yathā na vikuppati aggi udaka vāta cora aundūra ādīnam vasena na vinassati  evam adhiṭṭhātabbam tatra idam adhiṭṭhāna vidhānam idam ca idam ca imasmin
translated: Herein, the duty of not disturbing those who are not related to him is this. If he has no one related to him to whom he can entrust his bowl and robe, or his bed and chair, or his dwelling, or any other requisite,🔽then he should resolve thus, ‘Let none of these things be lost through fire, water, kings, thieves, or misers ,

original: mā agginā jhāyatu, mā udakena vuyhatu, mā vātena viddhaṃsatu, mā corehi harīyatu,
analyzed: mā agginā jhāyatu mā udakena vuyhatu mā vātena mā corehi harīyatu
translated: and let none of them be damaged by white-ant hills, etc.,’ and he should define the period thus, ‘Let them not be lost or damaged during this period of seven days.’

original: mā undūrādīhi khajjatū”ti. Evaṃ adhiṭṭhite taṃ sattāhaṃ tassa na koci parissayo hoti,
analyzed: mā undūra ādīhi khajjatu iti evam adhiṭṭhite tam sattāham tassa na koci parissayaḥ hoti
translated: And if he so resolves, none of them is lost or damaged during that period.

original: anadhiṭṭhahato pana aggiādīhi nassati, idaṃ nānābaddhaavikopanaṃ nāma. Yaṃ pana ekābaddhaṃ
analyzed: an adhiṭṭhahataḥ pana aggi ādīhi nassati idam nānābaddhaavikopanam nāma yam pana eka ābaddham
translated: But if it is not determined, it is lost through fire, etc.,🔽and this is called “non-determination of what is not shared.” But what is shared,

original: hoti nivāsanapārupanaṃ vā nisinnāsanaṃ vā, tattha visuṃ adhiṭṭhānakiccaṃ natthi,
analyzed: hoti nivāsana pārupanam vā nisinnāsanam vā tattha visum adhiṭṭhāna kiccam natthi
translated: such as the robe and bowl, or the seat on which he is sitting, is not determined separately;

original: samāpattiyeva naṃ rakkhati.
analyzed: samāpattiyā iva nam rakkhati
translated: only the attainment protects it.

original: Saṅghapatimānananti bhikkhusaṅghassa patimānanaṃ udikkhanaṃ, yāva so bhikkhu āgacchati,
analyzed: saṅgha patimānanam ti bhikkhu saṅghassa patimānanam udikkhanam yāva saḥ bhikkhu āgacchati
translated: “The Sangha’s approval”: the Sangha’s approval of a monk, that is, the announcement of his name, so that until that monk returns

original: tāva saṅghakammassa akaraṇanti attho. Ettha ca patimānanaṃ etassa na pubbakiccaṃ,🔽patimānanāvajjanaṃ pana pubbakiccaṃ. Tasmā evaṃ āvajjitabbaṃ “sace mayi sattāhaṃ
analyzed: tāva saṅgha kammassa akaraṇanti atthaḥ ettha ca pati mānanam etassa na pubba kiccam  pati mānana āvajjanam pana pubba kiccam tasmai evam āvajjitabbam sace mayi sattāham
translated: the Sangha may not do any legal act. And here the approval is not the preliminary work;

original: nirodhaṃ samāpajjitvā nisinne saṅgho apalokanakammādīsu kiñcideva kammaṃ kattukāmo
analyzed: nirodham samāpajjitvā nisinne saṅghaḥ apalokana kamma ādīsu kiñcid eva kammam kattu kāmo
translated: but the act of giving approval is the preliminary work. So he should advert in this way: “If the Sangha should want to do a legal act, such as a reconciling, while I am sitting in attainment of cessation for seven days,

original: hoti, yāva maṃ koci bhikkhu āgantvā na pakkosati, tāvadeva vuṭṭhahissāmī”ti. Evaṃ
analyzed: hoti yāva mama koci bhikkhu āgantvā na pakkosati tāvat eva vuṭṭhahissāmi iti evam
translated: and if no one monk comes to inform me, I shall emerge then and there.”

original: katvā samāpanno hi tasmiṃ samaye vuṭṭhahatiyeva. Yo pana evaṃ na karoti, saṅgho ce
analyzed: katvā samāpannaḥ hi tasmin samaye vuṭṭhahatiyā iva yaḥ pana evam na karoti saṅghaḥ ce
translated: For if he does it this way, he emerges at that moment. But if he does not do it this way, if the Sangha does a legal act,

original: sannipatitvā taṃ apassanto “asuko bhikkhu kuhi”nti pucchitvā “nirodhaṃ samāpanno”ti🔽vutte kañci bhikkhuṃ peseti “taṃ pakkosāhī”ti, athassa tena bhikkhunā savanūpacāre
analyzed: sannipatitvā tam a passantaḥ asukaḥ bhikkhu kuhinti pucchitvā nirodham samāpanno ti  vutte kañci bhikkhum peseti tam pakkosāhi iti athassa tena bhikkhunā savana upacāre
translated: When they have assembled and do not see him, they ask, “Where is the bhikkhu so-and-so?” When they hear that he has attained cessation,

original: ṭhatvā “saṅgho taṃ āvuso patimānetī”ti vuttamatteyeva vuṭṭhānaṃ hoti. Evaṃ garukā
analyzed: ṭhatvā saṅghaḥ tam āvuso patimāneti iti vutta matteyā iva vuṭṭhānam hoti evam garukā
translated: they send a bhikkhu to him with the order, “Go and fetch him.” Then as soon as the bhikkhu stands within hearing and says, “Friend, the Community summons you,” he emerges. So great

original: hi saṅghassa āṇā nāma, tasmā taṃ āvajjitvā yathā paṭhamameva vuṭṭhāti, evaṃ samāpajjitabbaṃ.
analyzed: hi saṅghassa āṇā nāma tasmā tam āvajjitvā yathā paṭhamam eva vuṭṭhāti evam samāpajjitabbam
translated: is the Community’s order. That is why he should attain it by adverting thus, so that he emerges first of all.

original: Satthupakkosananti idhāpi satthupakkosanāvajjanameva imassa pubbakiccaṃ, tasmā tampi evaṃ āvajjitabbaṃ. Sesaṃ purimanayeneva veditabbaṃ.🔽Addhānaparicchedoti jīvitaddhānassa paricchedo. Iminā bhikkhunā addhānaparicchedesu
analyzed: satthu pakkosananti idha api satthu pakkosana āvajjanam eva imassa pubba kiccam tasmā tam pi evam āvajjitabbam sesam purima nayena iva veditabbam  addhāna paricchedo ti jīvita ddhānassa paricchedaḥ iminā bhikkhunā addhāna paricchedesu
translated: The summons of the Master: here too the prior condition is the adverting to the summons of the Master. So that should be adverted to in the same way. The rest should be understood in the way already described.

original: kusalena bhavitabbaṃ, “attano āyusaṅkhārā sattāhaṃ pavattissanti na pavattissantī”ti
analyzed: kusalena bhavitabbam attanaḥ āyu saṅkhārā sattāham pavattissanti na pavattissanti iti
translated: The delimitation of the life span: the delimitation of the life-process. This bhikkhu should be skilled in the delimitation of the life span. He should know how to delimit the life span thus: “The life- formations will continue for seven days” or “They will continue for six days” … etc.

original: āvajjitvāva samāpajjitabbaṃ. Sace hi sattāhabbhantare nirujjhanake āyusaṅkhāre anāvajjitvāva
analyzed: āvajjitvā ava samāpajjitabbam sace hi satta ahabbhantare nirujjhanake āyu saṅkhāre an āvajjitvā ava
translated: and he should only attain it after adverting to it. For if he were to attain it without adverting to the life-continuum that is due to cease within seven days,

original: samāpajjati, tassa nirodhasamāpatti maraṇaṃ paṭibāhituṃ na sakkoti, antonirodhe maraṇassa🔽natthitāya antarāva samāpattito vuṭṭhāti, tasmā etaṃ āvajjitvāva samāpajjitabbaṃ.
analyzed: samāpajjati tassa nirodha samāpatti maraṇam paṭibāhitum na sakkoti antar nirodhe maraṇassa  na atthitāya antarā ava samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhāti tasmai etam āvajjitvā ava samāpajjitabbam
translated: He should attain it only after adverting. For if he attains it without adverting to the life-continuum that is due to cease in seven days, then he is unable to prevent the attainment of cessation from becoming death, and so he emerges from the attainment of cessation in mid-course,🔽because there is no death in the state of cessation. That is why it is said that he should attain it only after adverting.

original: Avasesañhi anāvajjitumpi vaṭṭati, idaṃ pana āvajjitabbamevāti vuttaṃ. So evaṃ ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ
analyzed: avasesam hi an āvajjitum pi vaṭṭati idam pana āvajjitabbam eva ati vuttam saḥ evam ākiñcaññāyatanam
translated: For the rest it is allowable not to advert, but this must be adverted to.

original: samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya idaṃ pubbakiccaṃ katvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samāpajjati,🔽athekaṃ vā dve vā cittavāre atikkamitvā acittako hoti, nirodhaṃ phusati. Kasmā panassa
analyzed: samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya idam pubba kiccam katvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam samāpajjati  atha ekam vā dve vā cittavāre atikkamitvā acittakaḥ hoti nirodham phusati kasmā panassa
translated: So, after attaining the base consisting of nothingness and emerging from it, he performs this preliminary task and then attains the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception.🔽After traversing one or two consciousnesses, he becomes without consciousness and contacts cessation.

original: dvinnaṃ cittānaṃ upari cittāni na pavattantīti? Nirodhassa payogattā. Idañhi imassa
analyzed: dvinnam cittānam upari cittāni na pavattanti iti nirodhassa payoga ttā idam hi imassa
translated: But why do consciousnesses not go on occurring after the two? Because the attainment of cessation is a preparation for that.

original: bhikkhuno dve samathavipassanādhamme yuganaddhe katvā aṭṭhasamāpattiārohanaṃ anupubbanirodhassa
analyzed: bhikkhunaḥ dve samatha vipassanā dhamme yuga naddhe katvā aṭṭha samāpatti ārohanam anupubba nirodhassa
translated: The bhikkhu’s practice of the eight attainments by yoking the two dhammas of serenity and insight together is the practice of the attainment of cessation.

original: payogo, na nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasamāpattiyāti nirodhassa payogattā dvinnaṃ cittānaṃ🔽upari cittāni na pavattantīti.
analyzed: payogaḥ na nevasaññānāsaññāyatana samāpattiyā ati nirodhassa payoga ttā dvinnam cittānam  upari cittāni na pavattanti iti
translated: Because it is the practice of cessation, no consciousnesses occur above the two consciousnesses.

original: Yasmā bodhisattena bodhimaṇḍupasaṅkamanato pubbepi carimabhave catutthajjhānaṃ nibbattitapubbaṃ,🔽tadā pana taṃ nibbattitamattameva ahosi, na vipassanādipādakaṃ. Tasmā “bodhirukkhamūle
analyzed: yasmai bodhisattena bodhimaṇḍa upasaṅkamanataḥ pubbe api carima bhave catuttha jjhānam nibbattita pubbam  tadā pana tat nibbattita mattam eva ahosi na vipassanā ādi pādakam tasmā bodhi rukkha mūle
translated: Because the Bodhisatta had already produced the fourth jhāna in his last birth before he went to the Bodhi-tree,🔽it was only produced by him then, but it was not the basis for insight, etc.; that is why it is said with the distinction that “it was produced at the foot of the Bodhi tree.”

original: nibbattita”nti tato visesetvā vuttaṃ. Vipassanāpādakanti vipassanārambhe vipassanāya🔽pādakaṃ. Abhiññāpādakanti etthāpi eseva nayo. Buddhānañhi paṭhamārambhe eva pādakajjhānena
analyzed: nibbattitanti tatas visesetvā vuttam vipassanā pādakanti vipassanā ārambhe vipassanāya  pādakam abhiññā pādakan ti ettha api esā iva nayaḥ buddhānam hi paṭhama ārambhe eva pādaka jjhānena
translated: The basis for insight: the basis for the beginning of insight.🔽The basis for direct-knowledge: the same explanation applies here.

original: payojanaṃ ahosi, na tato paraṃ uparimaggādhigamaphalasamāpattiabhiññāvaḷañjanādiatthaṃ.
analyzed: payojanam na tatas param upari magga adhigama phala samāpatti abhiññā vaḷañjana ādi attham
translated: For the Buddhas have no need of the basic jhāna only at the beginning, but they also attain the higher paths, and they perfect the fruition attainment and the kinds of direct-knowledge, and so on.

original: Abhisambodhisamadhigamato paṭṭhāya hi sabbaṃ ñāṇasamādhikiccaṃ ākaṅkhāmattapaṭibaddhamevāti.
analyzed: abhisambodhi samadhigamataḥ paṭṭhāya hi sabbam ñāṇa samādhi kiccam ākaṅkhā matta paṭibaddham eva ati
translated: For from the time of his enlightenment all the work of knowledge and concentration is bound up with his will.

original: Sabbakiccasādhakanti anupubbavihārādisabbakiccasādhakaṃ. Sabbalokiyalokuttaraguṇadāyakanti
analyzed: sabba kicca sādhakam ti anupubba vihāra ādi sabba kicca sādhakam sabba lokiya lokuttara guṇa dāyakam
translated: It fulfils all duties: it fulfils all duties such as the successive dwellings.

original: ettha vipassanābhiññāpādakattā eva catutthassa jhānassa bhagavato sabbalokiyalokuttaraguṇadāyakatā
analyzed: ettha vipassanā abhiññā pādaka ttā eva catutthassa jhānassa bhagavato sabba lokiya lokuttara guṇa dāyaka tā
translated: It gives all mundane and supramundane special qualities: here the Blessed One’s giving of all mundane and supramundane special qualities should be understood as due to the fourth jhāna itself, which is the forerunner of insight and of the direct-knowledge of supernormal power,

original: veditabbā. Sabbaññutaññāṇapadaṭṭhānañhi maggañāṇaṃ taṃpadaṭṭhānañca sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ
analyzed: veditabbā sabbaññu taññāṇa padaṭṭhānañ hi magga ñāṇam tad padaṭṭhānañca sabbaññu taññāṇam
translated: for knowledge of the path has the knowledge of omniscience as its proximate cause, and the knowledge of omniscience has that knowledge of the path as its proximate cause.

original: abhisambodhi, tadadhigamasamakālameva ca bhagavato sabbe buddhaguṇā hatthagatā ahesuṃ,
analyzed: abhisambodhi tad adhigama sama kālam eva ca bhagavataḥ sabbe buddha guṇāḥ hattha gatāḥ ahesuṃ
translated: And at the moment of his enlightenment the Blessed One acquired all the special qualities of a Buddha at the same time as he acquired omniscience,

original: catutthajjhānasannissayo ca maggādhigamoti.🔽“Catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihāsi”nti vatvā “so”ti vuttattā āha “so aha”nti. Evaṃ
analyzed: catuttha jhāna sannissayo ca magga adhigamaḥ ti  catuttham jhānam upasampajja vihāsin ti vatvā saḥ ti vutta ttā āha saḥ aham iti evam
translated: and the acquisition of the path has the fourth jhāna as its proximate cause.🔽Having entered upon the fourth jhāna, he abided in it: having entered upon the fourth jhāna in the way already described, he abided in it, he persisted in it, he maintained himself in it, he controlled himself in it.🔽Having thus entered upon and abided in the fourth jhāna, he had full awareness of his emergence from it, and so too of his entry into it, and he did so in such wise that there was no inconstancy in his emergence or in his entry.

original: samāhiteti ettha evaṃ-saddo heṭṭhā jhānattayādhigamapaṭipāṭisiddhassa catutthajjhānasamādhānassa
analyzed: samāhita iti ettha evaṃsaddaḥ heṭṭhā jhāna ttayā adhigama paṭipāṭi siddhassa catuttha jhāna samādhānassa
translated: “In such a way”: the word “such” refers back to the attainment of the three jhānas before the fourth jhāna.

original: nidassanatthoti āha “evanti catutthajjhānakkamanidassanameta”nti. Catutthajjhānassa
analyzed: nidassana atthaḥ ti āha evam ti catuttha jhāna kkama nidassanam etat ti catuttha jhānassa
translated: “Indication” is said in the words “This is the indication of the way to the fourth jhāna” .

original: tassa ca adhigamamaggassa nidassanaṃ, yena samādhānānukkamena catutthajjhānasamādhi🔽laddho, tadubhayanidassananti attho. Tenāha “iminā…pe… vuttaṃ hotī”ti. Tattha iminā
analyzed: tassa ca adhigama maggassa nidassanam yena samādhāna anukkamena catuttha jhāna samādhi  laddhaḥ tad ubhaya nidassananti attho tena āha vuttam hoti iti tattha iminā
translated: The indication of the fourth jhāna and of the path of its attainment is what is meant. The meaning is that the indication of both is by the order of the concentration.

original: kamenāti iminā paṭhamajjhānādhigamādinā kamena. Yadipi “eva”nti idaṃ āgamanasamādhinā
analyzed: kamena ati iminā paṭhamajjhāna adhigama ādinā kamena idam āgamana samādhinā
translated: That is why he said “by this order” . Herein, by this order is by the order of the attainment of the first jhāna, and so on.

original: saddhiṃ catutthajjhānasamādhānaṃ dīpeti, satipārisuddhisamādhi eva pana iddhiyā adhiṭṭhānabhāvato
analyzed: saddhim catuttha jhāna samādhānam dīpeti sati pārisuddhi samādhi eva pana iddhiyāḥ adhiṭṭhāna bhāvato
translated: Although this “thus” indicates the concentration of the fourth jhāna together with the attainment, nevertheless it is the concentration of purity of mindfulness that is the principal thing here because it is the basis for the resolve for direct-knowledge.

original: padhānanti āha “catutthajjhānasamādhinā samāhite”ti. Sabbapaccanīkadhammupakkilesaparisuddhāya
analyzed: padhānam ti āha catuttha jhāna samādhinā samāhitā iti sabba paccanīka dhamma upakkilesa parisuddhāya
translated: That is why he said “when he has concentrated by means of the concentration of the fourth jhāna” .

original: paccanīkasamanepi abyāvaṭāya pārisuddhupekkhāya vattamānāya catutthajjhānaṃ taṃsampayuttā
analyzed: paccanīka samane pi abyāvaṭāya pārisuddha upekkhāya vattamānāya catuttha jjhānam tad sampayuttā
translated: The fourth jhāna occurs with the purification of mindfulness that is purified of hindrances and of the defilements too, and it occurs with equanimity due to purification, which is unmoved by the defilements.

original: ca dhammā suparisuddhā suvisadā ca honti, satisīsena pana tattha desanā katāti āha
analyzed: ca dhammā su parisuddhā su visadā ca honti sati sīsena pana tattha desanā katā ati āha
translated: and the ideas are quite purified and quite clear. But the teaching is given there by means of mindfulness with its outlet, which is why he said

original: “upekkhāsatipārisuddhibhāvena parisuddhe”ti, upekkhāya janitasatipārisuddhisambhavenāti
analyzed: upekkhā sati pārisuddhi bhāvena parisuddhā iti upekkhāya janita sati pārisuddhi sambhavena ati
translated: “purified by means of purification of mindfulness due to equanimity” . The meaning is that it is owing to the presence of the purification of mindfulness generated by equanimity.

original: attho. Parisuddhiyā eva paccayavisesena pavattiviseso pariyodātatā sudhantasuvaṇṇassa
analyzed: atthaḥ parisuddhiyāḥ eva paccaya visesena pavatti visesaḥ pariyodāta tā su dhanta suvaṇṇassa
translated: And the difference in the occurrence due to the difference in the condition for the purification is the state of being quite purified, like the state of being bright in gold that is well-refined.

original: nighaṃsanena pabhassaratā viyāti āha “parisuddhattāyeva pariyodāte, pabhassareti vuttaṃ hotī”ti.
analyzed: nighaṃsanena pabhassara tā viya iti āha parisuddha ttāya iva pariyodāte pabhassarā iti vuttam hoti iti
translated: That is why he said “It is said to be quite purified, quite purified, quite bright, quite bright, because of the purification itself” .🔽By the suppression of the conditions for pleasure, etc.,

original: Sukhādīnaṃ paccayānaṃ ghātenāti sukhasomanassānaṃ dukkhadomanassānañca yathākkamaṃ
analyzed: sukha ādīnam paccayānam ghātena ati sukha somanassānam dukkha domanassānam ca yathākkamam
translated: the suppression of the conditions for pleasure and joy and for pain and grief respectively,

original: rāgadosapaccayānaṃ vikkhambhanena. “Sukhaṃ somanassassa paccayo, somanassaṃ rāgassa,
analyzed: rāga dosa paccayānam vikkhambhanena sukham somanassassa paccayaḥ somanassam rāgassa
translated: which are stated thus: “Pleasure is a condition for joy, joy for greed,

original: dukkhaṃ domanassassa paccayo, domanassaṃ dosassā”ti vuttaṃ. Yathā rāgādayo cetaso
analyzed: dukkham domanassassa paccayaḥ domanassam dosassa ati vuttam yathā rāga ādayo cetasaḥ
translated: pain for grief, grief for hate” . Just as greed, etc., are called “defilements” because of their dirty state as stains on the mind,

original: malāsucibhāvena “aṅgaṇānī”ti vuccanti, evaṃ upagantvā kilesanaṭṭhena upakkilesāti
analyzed: mala asuci bhāvena aṅgaṇāni iti vuccanti evam upagantvā kilesana ṭṭhena upakkilesā ti
translated: so they are called “adulterants” in the sense of defiling.

original: āha “anaṅgaṇattā eva ca vigatupakkilese”ti. Tenāha “aṅgaṇena hi cittaṃ upakkilissatī”ti,
analyzed: āha an aṅgaṇa ttā eva ca vigata upakkilesa iti tena āha aṅgaṇena hi cittam upakkilissati iti
translated: He says, “And because it is without a flaw, it is without defilement.” Hence he said, “For the mind is defiled by a flaw” .

original: vibādhīyati upatāpīyatīti attho. Subhāvitattāti paguṇabhāvāpādanena suṭṭhu bhāvitattā.
analyzed: vibādhīyati upatāpīyati iti attho su bhāvita ttā ati paguṇa bhāva āpādanena suṭṭhu bhāvita ttā
translated: The meaning is that it is obstructed, afflicted. Well developed: well developed by making it familiar.🔽Hence he said, “When mastery has been reached” .

original: Tenāha “vasībhāvappatte”ti, āvajjanādinā pañcadhā cuddasavidhena vā paridamanena
analyzed: tena āha vasībhāva pattā iti āvajjana ādinā pañcadhā vā paridamanena
translated: The meaning is that it has come to be able to be directed to mastery by means of the fivefold or fourteenfold directing of the mind.🔽For a mind that is being directed to mastery is called “pliant.”

original: vasaṃ vattituṃ upagateti attho. Vase vattamānañhi cittaṃ mudūti vuccatīti vase vattamānaṃ🔽cittaṃ paguṇabhāvāpattiyā suparimadditaṃ viya cammaṃ suparikammakatā viya ca lākhā
analyzed: vasam vattitum upagatā iti atthaḥ vase vattamānam hi cittam mudu iti vuccati iti vase vattamānam  cittam paguṇa bhāva āpattiyā su parimadditam viya cammam su parikammakatā viya ca lākhā
translated: When it is being directed to mastery, it is called “pliant” because it has reached familiarity, like a hide that is being worked and becomes pliable by being soaked in water, or like lac that becomes pliable when it is heated.🔽It is “capable of being exerted” in the various kinds of supernormal knowledge such as the wonder-working powers, etc.

original: mudūti vuccati. Kammakkhameti vikubbanādiiddhikammakkhame. Tadubhayanti mudutākammaniyadvayaṃ.🔽Nāhantiādīsu na-kāro paṭisedhattho. Ahanti satthā attānaṃ niddisati. Bhikkhaveti
analyzed: mudu uti vuccati kamma kkhamā iti vikubbana ādi iddhi kamma kkhame tat ubhayanti mudu tā kamma niya dvayam  na aham iti ādīsu nakāraḥ paṭisedha atthaḥ aham iti satthā attānam niddisati bhikkhave iti
translated: The two are the two kinds of action consisting of pliancy and capability.

original: bhikkhū ālapati. Aññanti idāni vuccamānacittato aññaṃ. Ekadhammampīti ekampi sabhāvadhammaṃ.
analyzed: bhikkhū ālapati aññam ti idāni vuccamāna cittataḥ aññam eka dhammam pi iti ekam pi sabhāva dhammam
translated: In the passage beginning, “It is not, bhikkhus” , the negative particle is a particle of denial. The word “it” the Master uses to refer to himself. The word “bhikkhus” he uses to address the bhikkhus. The word “another” he uses to refer to a mind other than the one being spoken of. The words “even one idea” he uses to refer to even one idea that is a state of being.

original: Na samanupassāmīti sambandho. Ayañhettha attho – ahaṃ, bhikkhave, sabbaññutaññāṇena🔽olokentopi aññaṃ ekadhammampi na samanupassāmi, yaṃ vasībhāvāpādanena bhāvitaṃ tathā🔽punappunaṃ karaṇena bahulīkataṃ evaṃ savisesamudubhāvappattiyā mudu kammakkhamatāya🔽kammaniyañca hoti yathā idaṃ cittanti. Idaṃ cittanti ca attano tesañca paccakkhatāya evamāha.
analyzed: na samanupassāmi iti sambandhaḥ ayam ha ittha atthaḥ aham bhikkhave sabbaññuta ññāṇena  olokentaḥ api aññam eka dhammam pi na samanupassāmi yam vasībhāva āpādanena bhāvitam tathā  punappunam karaṇena bahulīkatam evam sa visesa mudu bhāva ppattiyā mudu kamma kkhama tāya  kammaniyam ca hoti yathā idam cittam ti idam cittam ti ca attanaḥ tesam ca paccakkha tāya evam āha
translated: I do not see any other single thing, bhikkhus, that is so developed and much practiced as the mind.🔽For when the mind is developed and much practiced, it becomes workable, wieldy, and brilliant, and it attains to the righting of the higher wisdom.

original: Yathā yathāvuttā parisuddhatādayo na vigacchanti, evaṃ subhāvitaṃ cittaṃ tattha avaṭṭhitaṃ🔽idha “ṭhitaṃ āneñjappatta”nti ca vuttanti āha “etesu parisuddhabhāvādīsu ṭhitattā🔽ṭhite, ṭhitattāyeva āneñjappatte”ti. Yathā mudukammaññatā vasībhāvappattiyā lakkhīyati,🔽evaṃ vasībhāvappattipi mudukammaññatāhi lakkhīyatīti “mudukammaññabhāvena vā attano
analyzed: yathā yathā vuttā parisuddha tā ādayaḥ na vigacchanti evam su bhāvitam cittam tattha avaṭṭhitam 🔽idha ṭhitam āneñjappattanti ca vuttan ti āha etesu parisuddha bhāva ādīsu ṭhita ttā 🔽ṭhite ṭhita ttāya iva āneñja ppattā iti yathā mudu kammañña tā vasībhāva ppattiyā lakkhīyati 🔽evam mudu kammañña tāhi mudu kammañña bhāvena vā attanaḥ
translated: I do not see any other single thing, bhikkhus, that is so well developed, well undertaken, well pursued, well habituated, well consolidated by repetition, well remembered, well reflected original: vase ṭhitattā ṭhite”ti vuttaṃ. Yathā hi kāraṇena phalaṃ niddhārīyati, evaṃ phalenapi🔽kāraṇaṃ niddhārīyatīti niccalabhāvena avaṭṭhānaṃ āneñjappattiyā ca sampayuttadhammesu
analyzed: vase ṭhita ttā ṭhitā iti vuttam yathā hi kāraṇena phalam evam phalena api  kāraṇam niddhārīyati iti niccala bhāvena avaṭṭhānam āneñja ppattiyā ca sampayutta dhammesu
translated: “It is ‘unwavering’ because it is established in the bowl.” Just as the fruit is defined by the cause, so too the cause is defined by the fruit.

original: thirabhāvena paṭipakkhehi akammaniyatāya ca sambhavataṃ saddhādibalānaṃ ānubhāvena🔽hotīti āha “saddhādīhi pariggahitattā āneñjappatte”ti.
analyzed: thira bhāvena paṭipakkhehi akamma niyatāya ca sambhavatam saddhā ādi balānam ānubhāvena  hoti iti āha saddhā ādīhi pariggahita ttā āneñja ppattā iti
translated: The cause is defined by the fruit in the sense of the attainment of the imperturbable, which is unshakable, and in the sense of the attainment of the strength of faith, etc., which is unshakable in the sense of firmness, unshakable in the sense of non-reactivity to counter-corruptions, and unshakable in the sense of possibility.🔽Therefore it is said: “It is ‘unwavering’ because it is attained by the imperturbable and because it is accompanied by the strength of faith, etc.”

original: Idāni saṅkhepato vuttamevatthaṃ vivarituṃ “saddhāpariggahitaṃ hī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha🔽saddhāpariggahitanti evaṃ subhāvitaṃ vasībhāvappattaṃ cittaṃ ekaṃsena abhiññāsacchikaraṇīyānaṃ
analyzed: idāni saṅkhepataḥ vuttam eva attham vivaritum saddhā pariggahitam hi itiādi vuttam tattha  saddhā pariggahitam ti evam su bhāvitam vasībhāva ppattam cittam ekaṃsena abhiññā sacchikaraṇīyānam
translated: Now, in order to explain the meaning stated in brief, it is said: “Faith-inspired” and so on. Therein,

original: dhammānaṃ abhiññāsacchikiriyāya saṃvattatīti evaṃ pavattāya saddhāya pariggahitaṃ
analyzed: dhammānam abhiññā sacchikiriyāya saṃvattati iti evam pavattāya saddhāya pariggahitam
translated: “faith-inspired” means that the mind, thus well-developed and attained to mastery, is inspired by faith that occurs thus: “This mind of mine will certainly lead to the direct-knowledge and realization of those things that are to be realized by direct-knowledge.”

original: yathāvuttasaddhābalena upatthambhitaṃ. Assaddhiyenāti tappaṭipakkhena assaddhiyena
analyzed: yathā vutta saddhā balena upatthambhitam assaddhiyena ati tad paṭipakkhena assaddhiyena
translated: It is inspired by faith in the sense that it is supported by the strength of faith as stated above. “Uninspired by faith” means that it is uninspired by faith that is the opposite of faith.

original: hetunā. Na iñjatīti na calati na kampati, aññadatthu uparivisesāvahabhāveneva tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: hetunā na iñjati iti na calati na kampati añña datthu upari visesa āvaha bhāvena iva tiṭṭhati
translated: It does not waver, does not move, does not tremble, but stands firm as if fixed on a pivot.

original: Vīriyapariggahitantiādīsupi imināva nayena attho veditabbo. Ayaṃ pana viseso – vīriyapariggahitanti🔽vasībhāvāpādanaparidamanasādhanena vīriyena upatthambhitaṃ. Satipariggahitanti yathāvutte🔽bhāvanābahulīkāre asammosādikāya kusalānañca dhammānaṃ gatiyo samanvesamānāya satiyā
analyzed: vīriya pariggahita nti ādīsu pi iminā ava nayena atthaḥ veditabbaḥ ayam pana visesaḥ vīriya pariggahitanti  vasībhāva āpādana paridamana sādhanena vīriyena upatthambhitam sati pariggahitam ti yathā vutte  bhāvanā bahulīkāre asammosa ādikāya kusalānam ca dhammānam samanvesamānāya satiyā
translated: In the case of the words “supported by energy” and so on, the meaning should be understood in the same way. But there is this difference. “Supported by energy” means🔽supported by energy that has reached mastery by the act of exerting. “Supported by mindfulness” means supported by mindfulness that has reached mastery by the act of establishing, and that is not forgetful of the way stated above,

original: upatthambhitaṃ. Samādhipariggahitanti tattheva avikkhepasādhanena samādhānena upatthambhitaṃ.🔽Paññāpariggahitanti tassā eva bhāvanāya upakārānupakāradhammānaṃ pajānanalakkhaṇāya
analyzed: upatthambhitam samādhi pariggahitan ti tattha eva avikkhepa sādhanena samādhānena upatthambhitam  paññā pariggahitam ti tassāḥ eva bhāvanāya upakāra anupakāra dhammānam pajānana lakkhaṇāya
translated: and is seeking the way of profitable states. “Supported by concentration” means supported by concentration that has reached mastery by the act of concentrating on that same object without wavering.🔽“Supported by understanding” means supported by understanding that has reached mastery by the act of discerning the profitable states that are helpful to that same development and the unprofitable states that are obstructive to it, and that has the characteristic of knowing.

original: paññāya upatthambhitaṃ. Obhāsagatanti ñāṇobhāsasahagataṃ. Obhāsabhūtena hi yathāvuttasamādhānasaṃvaddhitena
analyzed: paññāya upatthambhitam obhāsa gatanti ñāṇa ubhāsa sahagatam obhāsa bhūtena hi yathā vutta samādhāna saṃvaddhitena
translated: “Possessed of light” means accompanied by the light of knowledge. For it is possessed of the light of the kind of concentration stated above.

original: ñāṇena saṃkilesapakkhaṃ yāthāvato passanto tato utrāsanto ottappanto taṃ abhibhavati,
analyzed: ñāṇena saṃkilesa pakkham yāthāvato passantaḥ tatas utrāsantaḥ ottappantaḥ tam abhibhavati
translated: and by means of knowledge he sees the defilement class as it actually is, and then, being afraid and ashamed of it, he overcomes it,

original: na tena abhibhuyyati. Tenāha “kilesandhakārena na iñjatī”ti. Etena ñāṇapariggahitaṃ
analyzed: na tena abhibhuyyati tena āha kilesa andhakārena na iñjati iti etena ñāṇa pariggahitam
translated: and it does not overcome him. Hence it is said that he is “not sluggish in the darkness of defilement.” By this he shows the strength of shame and moral dread, which is supported by knowledge.

original: hirottappabalaṃ dasseti. Aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgatanti catutthajjhānasamādhinā samāhitatā
analyzed: hirottappa balam dasseti aṭṭhaṅga samannāgatam ti catuttha jhāna samādhinā samāhita tā
translated: Possessing eight factors: it possesses the eight factors of concentration consisting in:

original: parisuddhatā pariyodātatā anaṅgaṇatā vigatupakkilesatā mudubhāvo kammaniyatā āneñjappattiyā
analyzed: parisuddha tā pariyodāta tā anaṅgaṇa tā vigata upakkilesa tā mudu bhāvaḥ kamma niya tā āneñja ppattiyā
translated: purity, purification, clearing, freedom from the hindrances, malleability, workability, steadiness, and imperturbability.

original: ṭhitatāti imehi aṭṭhahi aṅgehi samannāgataṃ. Atha vā samāhitassa cittassa imāni aṅgānīti🔽“samāhite”ti imaṃ aṅgabhāvena aggahetvā ṭhitiāneñjappattiyo visuṃ gahetvā yathāvuttehi
analyzed: ṭhita tā ati imehi aṭṭhahi aṅgehi samannāgatam atha vā samāhitassa cittassa imāni aṅgāni iti  samāhitā iti imam aṅga bhāvena aggahetvā ṭhiti āneñja ppattiyaḥ visum gahetvā yathā vuttehi
translated: Or alternatively, these are factors of concentration in one whose mind is concentrated.

original: aṭṭhahi aṅgehi samannāgatanti attho daṭṭhabbo. Abhinīhārakkhamanti iddhividhādiatthaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhahi aṅgehi samannāgatanti atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo abhinīhāra kkhamanti iddhividha ādi attham
translated: Without taking “concentration” as a factor, steadiness and imperturbability are taken separately, so the meaning should be regarded as follows: it possesses the eight factors stated thus.🔽Capable of exerting the mind: capable of exerting the mind for the purpose of the kinds of supernormal power, etc.,

original: abhinīhārakkhamaṃ tadabhimukhakaraṇayoggaṃ. Tenāha “abhiññāsacchikaraṇīyānaṃ dhammānaṃ
analyzed: abhinīhāra khamam tad abhimukha karaṇa yoggam tena āha abhiññā sacchikaraṇīyānam dhammānam
translated: capable of directing it towards that. Hence it is said: “Capable of exerting the mind, capable of directing it” .

original: abhiññāsacchikiriyāyā”ti.🔽Kāmaṃ nīvaraṇāni vikkhambhetvā eva paṭhamajjhānasamadhigamo, vitakkādivūpasamā eva🔽ca dutiyajjhānādisamadhigamo, tathāpi na tathā te tehi dūrībhūtā, apetā vā yathā🔽catutthajjhānato, tasmā cetaso malīnabhāvasaṅkhobhauppilābhāvakarehi nīvaraṇādīhi
analyzed: abhiññā sacchikiriyāya ati  kāmam nīvaraṇāni vikkhambhetvā eva paṭhama jhāna samadhigamaḥ vitakka ādi vūpasamāḥ eva  ca tathā api na tathā te tehi dūrībhūtāḥ apetāḥ vā yathā  catuttha jhānataḥ tasmā cetasaḥ malīna bhāva saṅkhobha auppila abhāva karehi nīvaraṇa ādīhi
translated: and the realization of them by direct-knowledge.”

original: suṭṭhu vimuttiyā tassa parisuddhipariyodātatā ca vuttāti āha “nīvaraṇa…pe… pariyodāte”ti.🔽Jhānapaṭilābhapaccanīkānanti ettha ācariyadhammapālattherena “jhānapaṭilābhapaccayāna”nti
analyzed: suṭṭhu vimuttiyā tassa parisuddhi pariyodāta tā ca vuttā iti āha nīvaraṇa pe pariyodātā iti  jhāna paṭilābha paccanīkānam ti ettha ācariya dhammapāla ttherena jhāna paṭilābha paccayānam ti
translated: Though the attainment of the first jhāna is indeed by suppression of the hindrances and the attainment of the second jhāna, etc., is by the subsiding of applied thought, etc., still they are not so far removed from it and so far eliminated as they are in the fourth jhāna. That is why it is said that it is purified by the complete surmounting of the kinds of identification already mentioned, that is to say, by the complete surmounting of the kinds of identification consisting in the hindrances, etc., which cause disturbance of the mind’s steadiness and clarity.

original: pāṭhaṃ gahetvā “jhānapaṭilābhapaccanīkāna”nti ayaṃ pāṭho paṭikkhitto. Vuttañhi tena –
analyzed: pāṭham gahetvā jhāna paṭilābha paccanīkānam ti ayam pāṭhaḥ paṭikkhittaḥ vuttam hi tena
translated: As to the words “the attainment of jhāna and its opposite,” the reading “the attainment of jhāna and its conditions” is rejected by the Elder Dhammapāla, who says that the reading is “the attainment of jhāna and its opposite.” For this is said by him:

original: “Jhānapaṭilābhapaccayānanti jhānapaṭilābhahetukānaṃ jhānapaṭilābhaṃ nissāya uppajjanakānaṃ.
analyzed: jhāna paṭilābha paccayānam ti jhāna paṭilābha hetukānam jhāna paṭilābham nissāya uppajjanakānam
translated: “The attainment of jhāna and its conditions: the attainment of jhāna and what arises contingent upon the attainment of jhāna having that as its means.

original: Pāpakānanti lāmakānaṃ. Icchāvacarānanti icchāya avacarānaṃ icchāvasena otiṇṇānaṃ
analyzed: pāpakānanti icchāya avacarānanti icchāya avacarānanti icchā vasena otiṇṇānanti
translated: ‘Bad’ means low-class. ‘Within the scope of desire’ means within the scope of desire, fallen into the scope of desire,

original: ‘aho vata mameva satthā paṭipucchitvā bhikkhūnaṃ dhammaṃ deseyyā’tiādinayappavattānaṃ
analyzed: aho vata mama eva satthā paṭipucchitvā bhikkhūnam dhammaṃ deseyya āti ādi naya ppavattānam
translated: ‘Oh that the Master might question me and teach the Dhamma to the bhikkhus’ and so on,

original: mānamāyāsāṭheyyādīnaṃ. Abhijjhādīnanti ādi-saddenapi tesaṃyeva saṅgaho. Abhijjhā
analyzed: māna māyā sāṭheyya ādīnam abhijjhā ādīnam ti ādi saddena api tesam yeva saṅgahaḥ abhijjhā
translated: pride, deceit, fraud, and so on. ‘Covetousness, etc.’: the word ‘etc.’ includes those same states.

original: cettha paṭhamajjhānena avikkhambhaneyyā mānādayo ca tadekaṭṭhā daṭṭhabbā jhānapaṭilābhapaccayānanti
analyzed: ca ittha paṭhama jhānena avikkhambhaneyyāḥ māna ādayo ca tad ekaṭṭhāḥ daṭṭhabbāḥ jhāna paṭilābha paccayānam
translated: Herein, the pride, etc., that are not suppressed by the first jhāna should be understood as being of the same plane as that jhāna. For it is said:🔽‘The jhāna is not reached because of the presence of the hindrances, which are the opposite of the jhāna factors’ .

original: anuvattamānattā. Vikkhambhaneyyā pana nīvaraṇaggahaṇena gahitā. Kathaṃ pana paṭhamajjhānena
analyzed: anuvatta māna ttā vikkhambhaneyyā pana nīvaraṇa ggahaṇena gahitā katham pana paṭhama jhānena
translated: But those that are suppressed are included by the word ‘hindrances.’ But how is it that those not suppressed by the first jhāna are abandoned here?

original: avikkhambhaneyyā idha vigacchantīti? ‘Sabbe kusalā dhammā sabbākusalānaṃ paṭipakkhā’ti🔽sallekhapaṭipattivasena evaṃ vuttaṃ jhānassa aparāmaṭṭhabhāvadassanato. Ye panettha
analyzed: a vikkhambhaneyyāḥ idha vigacchanti iti sabbe kusalāḥ dhammā sabba akusalānam paṭipakkhā ati  sallekha paṭipatti vasena evam vuttam jhānassa aparāmaṭṭha bhāva dassanataḥ ye pana ittha
translated: ‘All profitable states are the opposites of all unprofitable states’ .🔽This is said according to the method of ‘reversal’ . But it is said in order to show that the jhāna is not reached because of the presence of the hindrances, which are the opposite of the jhāna factors.

original: ‘icchāvacarānaṃ abhijjhādīna’nti imehi padehi kopaappaccayakāmarāgabyāpādādayo gahitāti
analyzed: abhijjhā ādīnam ti imehi padehi kopa appaccaya kāma rāga byāpāda ādayaḥ gahitā ati
translated: But as to the words ‘within the scope of desire, covetousness, etc.,’

original: adhippāyena ‘jhānapaṭilābhapaccayāna’nti pāṭhaṃ paṭikkhipitvā ‘jhānapaṭilābhapaccanīkāna’nti🔽pāṭhoti vadanti, taṃ tesaṃ matimattaṃ tathā pāṭhasseva abhāvato, jhānapaṭilābhapaccanīkā🔽ca nīvaraṇā ceva tadekaṭṭhā ca, tesaṃ dūrībhāvaṃ vatvā puna tesaṃyeva abhāvavigamacodanāya
analyzed: adhippāyena jhāna paṭilābha paccayānam ti pāṭham paṭikkhipitvā jhāna paṭilābha paccanīkānam ti  pāṭho ti vadanti tam tesam matimattam tathā pāṭhassa iva abhāvataḥ jhāna paṭilābha paccanīkā  ca nīvaraṇā ca iva tad ekaṭṭhā ca tesam dūrībhāvam vatvā puna tesam yeva abhāva vigama codanāya
translated: The reading “conditions for the obtaining of jhāna” is rejected by them with the comment that the intended meaning is “opposites of the obtaining of jhāna.”🔽But that is mere opinion on their part, since there is no such reading. And the hindrances are both opposites of the obtaining of jhāna and also included in it.🔽So it is not proper to mention their absence after stating their removal.

original: ayujjamānattā. Nanu ca anaṅgaṇasuttavatthasuttesu ayamattho labbhati oḷārikānaṃyeva🔽pāpadhammānaṃ tattha adhippetattāti. Saccametaṃ, idha pana adhigatacatutthajjhānassa
analyzed: nanu ca anaṅgaṇa sutta vattha suttesu ayam atthaḥ labbhati  pāpa dhammānam tattha adhippeta ttā ti saccam etam idha pana adhigata catuttha jhānassa
translated: But is not this meaning found in the Anaṅgaṇa Sutta and the Vattha Sutta?🔽—It is, but here the fine defilements are intended, since the sutta is stated in terms of one who has attained the fourth jhāna.

original: vasena vuttattā sukhumāyeva te gahitā, aṅgaṇupakkilesatāsāmaññena panettha suttānaṃ
analyzed: vasena vutta ttā sukhumāya iva te gahitāḥ
translated: And the suttas are cited here as being similar to the hindrances in being defilements of the jhāna factors.

original: apadisanaṃ. Tathā hi ‘suttānusārenā’ti vuttaṃ, na pana suttavasenā”ti.
analyzed: apadisanam tathā hi sutta anusārena iti vuttam na pana sutta vasena ati
translated: For it is said “in accordance with the suttas” , not “in accordance with the jhāna.”

original: Avassañcetamevaṃ sampaṭicchitabbaṃ adhigatajjhānānampi kesañci icchāvacarānaṃ pavattisabbhāvatoti.
analyzed: avassan ca itam evam sampaṭicchitabbam adhigata jhānānam pi kesañci icchāvacarānam pavatti sabbhāvato ti
translated: But it must be admitted that some who have attained jhāna are still subject to the occurrence of the hindrances.

original: Teneva ācariyadhammapālattherena “jhānapaṭilābhapaccayāna”nti pāṭhaṃ gahetvā “jhānapaṭilābhapaccanīkāna”nti
analyzed: tena iva ācariya dhammapāla ttherena jhāna paṭilābha paccayānam ti pāṭham gahetvā jhāna paṭilābha paccanīkānam ti
translated: And so the reading “conditions for the obtaining of jhāna” was taken by the teacher Dhammapāla and rejected the reading “conditions opposed to the obtaining of jhāna” .

original: ayaṃ pāṭho paṭikkhitto. Mahāgaṇṭhipade visuddhimaggassa sīhaḷagaṇṭhipadepi ca “jhānapaṭilābhapaccayāna”nti
analyzed: ayam pāṭhaḥ paṭikkhittaḥ mahāgaṇṭhi pade visuddhi maggassa sīhaḷagaṇṭhi pade pi ca jhāna paṭilābha paccayānam
translated: And in the Mahā-gaṇṭhi-pāda and in the Sihala-gaṇṭhi-pāda of the Visuddhimagga the meaning of the reading “conditions for the obtaining of jhāna” is stated.

original: imasseva pāṭhassa attho vutto, tasmā ayameva pāṭho gahetabbo, atthopi cettha yathāvuttanayeneva🔽veditabbo. Tena “icchāvacarānanti icchāya avacarānaṃ icchāvasena otiṇṇānaṃ pavattānaṃ
analyzed: imassa iva pāṭhassa atthaḥ vuttaḥ tasmai ayam eva pāṭhaḥ gahetabbaḥ atthaḥ api ca ittha yathā vutta nayena iva  veditabbaḥ tena icchā avacarānam ti icchāya avacarānam icchā vasena otiṇṇānam pavattānam
translated: So this reading should be accepted. And the meaning should be understood in the way already stated.

original: nānappakārānaṃ kopaappaccayānanti attho”ti ayampi pāṭho ayuttoyevāti gahetabbaṃ,
analyzed: nānā ppakārānam kopa appaccayānam ti atthaḥ iti ayam pi pāṭhaḥ ayuttaḥ yeva ati gahetabbam
translated: So too the reading “conditions for the occurrence of the various kinds of agitation due to craving” is unfitting, and so it should be rejected.

original: tatoyeva ca visuddhimagge ayaṃ pāṭho sabbena sabbaṃ na dassitoti.
analyzed: ca visuddhi magge ayam pāṭhaḥ sabbena sabbam na dassitaḥ iti
translated: And in the Visuddhimagga this reading is not given in full.

original: Iddhipādakabhāvūpagamanenāti iddhiyā pādakabhāvassa padaṭṭhānabhāvassa upagamanena.
analyzed: iddhi pādaka bhāva upagamanena ati iddhiyā pādaka bhāvassa padaṭṭhāna bhāvassa upagamanena
translated: By their becoming bases for success: by their becoming bases, by their becoming foundations, for success.

original: Bhāvanāpāripūriyāti ito paraṃ kattabbassa abhāvavasena abhinīhārakkhamabhāvanāya🔽paripuṇṇattā. Paṇītabhāvūpagamanenāti tato eva padhānabhāvaṃ nītatāya uttamaṭṭhena
analyzed: bhāvanā pāripūriyā ti itas param kattabbassa abhāva vasena abhinīhāra kkhama bhāvanāya  paripuṇṇa ttā paṇīta bhāva upagamanena ati tatas eva padhāna bhāvam nīta tāyai uttama ṭṭhena
translated: “Fulfilment of development”: because there is nothing more to be done after this, the development of the aspiration is fulfilled.

original: atittikaraṭṭhena ca paṇītabhāvassa upagamanena. Ubhayañcetaṃ bhāvanāya ṭhitiyā kāraṇavacanaṃ,
analyzed: a tittika raṭṭhena ca paṇīta bhāvassa upagamanena ubhayam ca etat bhāvanāya ṭhitiyā kāraṇa vacanam
translated: “By attaining the state of excellence”: by attaining the state of excellence in the sense of the highest and the most, because of having reached the state of predominance by reason of that very fulfilment of development.🔽Both of these are statements of the reason for the stability of development.

original: paripuṇṇāya bhāvanāya paṇītabhāvappattiyā ṭhiteti. Āneñjappatteti idaṃ ṭhitiyā visesanaṃ.
analyzed: paripuṇṇāya bhāvanāya paṇīta bhāva ppattiyā ṭhitā iti āneñja ppattā iti idam ṭhitiyāḥ visesanam
translated: “She stands firm” means that she stands firm by reason of the attainment of the state of excellence through the fulfilment of development.🔽“When she has attained imperturbability” is a qualification of “standing firm.”

original: Tenāha “yathā āneñjappattaṃ hoti, evaṃ ṭhite”ti. Imasmiṃ pakkhe “ṭhite āneñjappatte”ti
analyzed: tena āha yathā āneñjappattam hoti evam ṭhita iti imasmin pakkhe ṭhite āneñjappattā iti
translated: Therefore it is said: “She stands firm in such a way that she has attained imperturbability.”

original: ubhayamekaṃ aṅgaṃ, “samāhite”ti pana idampi ekamaṅgaṃ. Tenevassa paṭhamavikappato
analyzed: ubhayam ekam aṅgam samāhita iti pana idam pi ekam aṅgam tena iva assa paṭhama vikappataḥ
translated: In this case, “standing firm” and “having attained imperturbability” are one factor, and “being concentrated” is another factor.

original: visesaṃ sandhāyāha “evampi aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgata”nti.
analyzed: visesam sandhāya āha evam pi aṭṭhaṅga samannāgatan ti
translated: Therefore, referring to the difference from the first section, it is said: “So too, when one possesses the eight factors.”

original: Pubbenivāsaṃ anussarati, tassa vā anussaraṇaṃ pubbenivāsānussati taṃnissayādipaccayabhūtaṃ
analyzed: pubbenivāsam anussarati tassa vā anussaraṇam pubbenivāsa anussati tad nissaya ādi paccaya bhūtam
translated: The recollection of one’s former habitations or the recollection of his former habitations is pubbenivāsānussati. It is the condition of the support, etc.

original: paṭicca uppajjanato. Pubbenivāsānussatimhi yaṃ ñāṇaṃ tadatthāyāti saṅkhepena vuttamatthaṃ
analyzed: paṭicca uppajjanataḥ pubbenivāsa anussatimhi yam ñāṇam tad atthāya iti saṅkhepena vuttam attham
translated: because they arise in dependence on that. The knowledge in the recollection of past lives is the knowledge of that meaning.

original: vivaranto pubbenivāsaṃ tāva dassetvā tattha satiñāṇāni dassetuṃ “pubbenivāso”tiādimāha.🔽Tattha “pubbe”ti idaṃ padaṃ “ekampi jāti”ntiādivacanato atītabhavavisayaṃ idhādhippetanti
analyzed: vivarantaḥ pubbenivāsam tāva dassetvā tattha sati ñāṇāni dassetum pubbenivāsa uti ādim āha  tattha pubba iti idam padam ekam pi jāti nti ādi vacanataḥ atīta bhava visayam idha adhippetanti
translated: Having shown the past lives, he says “the knowledge of past lives” in order to show the mindfulness and knowledge there.

original: āha “atītajātīsū”ti. Nivāsasaddo kammasādhano, khandhavinimutto ca nivasitadhammo
analyzed: āha atīta jātīsu iti nivāsa saddo kamma sādhano khandha vinimuttaḥ ca nivasita dhammo
translated: Herein, the word “before” is intended to refer to past lives, because of the words “one birth, two births, three births, four births, five births, ten births, twenty births, thirty births, forty births, fifty births, a hundred births, a thousand births, a hundred thousand births, many eons of world contraction, many eons of world expansion, many eons of world contraction and expansion.”

original: natthīti āha “nivutthakkhandhā”ti. Nivutthatā cettha santāne pavattatā, tathābhūtā🔽ca te anu anu bhūtā jātā pavattā, tattha uppajjitvā vigatā ca hontīti āha “nivutthāti
analyzed: na atthi iti āha nivuttha khandhā ti nivuttha tā ca ittha santāne pavattatā tathābhūtā  ca te anu anu bhūtā jātā pavattā tattha uppajjitvā vigatā ca honti iti āha nivutthā iti
translated: The word “lived” is a synonym for kamma, and the state of living is free from the aggregates.

original: ajjhāvutthā anubhūtā attano santāne uppajjitvā niruddhā”ti. Evaṃ sasantatipariyāpannadhammavasena
analyzed: ajjhāvutthā anubhūtā attano santāne uppajjitvā niruddhā ati evam sa santati pariyāpanna dhamma vasena
translated: Therefore he says “the aggregates that have lived.” Herein, the state of living is the state of occurring in the continuum. And those that have that state are lived, born, occurred, arisen, and ceased there, having arisen in one’s own continuum. Therefore he says “lived means lived through, experienced, arisen and ceased in one’s own continuum.” Thus he shows the meaning of the word “lived” in terms of states included in one’s own continuum.

original: nivāsasaddassa atthaṃ vatvā idāni avisesena vattuṃ “nivutthadhammā vā nivutthā”ti
analyzed: nivāsa saddassa attham vatvā idāni avisesena vattum nivuttha dhammā vā nivutthā ti
translated: Now, in order to show it without distinction, he says “lived states or lived through.”

original: vatvā taṃ vivarituṃ “gocaranivāsenā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Gocarabhūtāpi hi gocarāsevanāya
analyzed: vatvā tam vivaritum gocara nivāsena ati ādi vuttam gocara bhūtā api hi gocara asevanāya
