original: āsevitā ārammaṇakaraṇavasena anubhūtā nivutthā nāma honti. Te pana duvidhā saparaviññāṇagocaratāyāti
analyzed: āsevitāḥ ārammaṇa karaṇa vasena anubhūtāḥ nivutthāḥ nāma honti te pana duvidhā sa para viññāṇa gocara tāya ati
translated: Having said this, he then said “By resort and by dwelling” in order to explain it. For although they are the resort, they are called “resorted to” when they are resorted to by the resort-maker, that is, when they are experienced by him as objects. These are twofold as the resort of one’s own consciousness and the resort of the consciousness of others.

original: ubhayepi te dassetuṃ “attano”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha “attano viññāṇena viññātā”ti vatvā🔽“paricchinnā”ti vacanaṃ ye te gocaranivāsena nivutthadhammā, na te kevalaṃ viññāṇena
analyzed: ubhaye api te dassetum attanaḥ tiādi vuttam tattha attanaḥ viññāṇena viññātā iti vatvā  paricchinnā ati vacanam ye te gocara nivāsena nivuttha dhammāḥ na te kevalam viññāṇena
translated: In order to show both of these he said “one’s own” and so on. Herein, having said “cognized by one’s own consciousness,” he said “defined”

original: viññātamattā, atha kho yathā pubbe nāmagottavaṇṇaliṅgāhārādīhi visesehi paricchedakārikāya
analyzed: viññāta mattā atha kho yathā pubbe nāma gotta vaṇṇa liṅga āhāra ādīhi visesehi pariccheda kārikāya
translated: in order to show that the things that are resorted to by resort and by dwelling are not only cognized by consciousness, but that they are also apprehended by the understanding that defines by means of the distinctions of name, race, colour, sex, food, and so on, as they were previously apprehended.

original: paññāya paricchijja gahitā, tathevetaṃ ñāṇaṃ paricchijja gaṇhātīti imassa atthassa🔽dīpanatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Paraviññāṇaviññātāpi vā nivutthāti sambandho. Na kevalaṃ attanova
analyzed: paññāya paricchijja gahitā tathā iva etam ñāṇam paricchijja gaṇhāti iti imassa atthassa  dīpana ttham vuttam para viññāṇa viññātā api vā nivutthā iti sambandho na kevalam attanā eva
translated: The words “defined by one’s own consciousness” are said for the purpose of showing this meaning.

original: viññāṇena, atha kho paresaṃ viññāṇena viññātāpīti attho. Idhāpi “paricchinnā”ti padaṃ
analyzed: viññāṇena atha kho paresam viññāṇena viññātā api iti atthaḥ idha api paricchinnā ati padam
translated: Or alternatively, the construction can be made thus: “They are also resorted to by being cognized by the consciousness of others.” The meaning is that they are not only cognized by one’s own consciousness, but also by the consciousness of others. Here too the words “defined by one’s own consciousness” are said

original: ānetvā sambandhitabbaṃ, paresampi vā viññāṇena viññātā paricchinnāti. Tassa ca gahaṇe
analyzed: ānetvā sambandhitabbam paresam pi vā viññāṇena viññātā paricchinnāti tassa ca gahaṇe
translated: and it must be brought to mind and defined by him, or else it must be defined by others and made known to him. The purpose of his taking it thus

original: payojanaṃ vuttanayeneva vattabbaṃ.
analyzed: payojanam vutta nayena iva vattabbam
translated: must be stated in the way already given.

original: Te ca kho yasmā atītāsu eva jātīsu aññehi viññātā paricchinnā, te ca parinibbutāpi🔽honti, yehi te viññātā, tesaṃ tadā vattamānasantānānusārena tesampi atīte pavatti
analyzed: te ca kho yasmai atītāsu eva jātīsu aññehi viññātā paricchinnā te ca parinibbutā api  honti yehi te viññātā tesam tadā vattamāna santāna anusārena tesam pi atīte pavatti
translated: But since it was defined by others in previous births, and since those who defined it have now attained Nibbāna,🔽it is the continuity of their present life that defines it by the force of the continuity of their past life.

original: viññāyatīti sikhāppattaṃ pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇassa visayabhūtaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ dassetuṃ🔽“chinnavaṭumakānussaraṇādīsū”ti vuttaṃ. Chinnavaṭumakā sammāsambuddhā, tesaṃ anussaraṇaṃ
analyzed: viññāyati iti sikhāppattam pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇassa visaya bhūtam pubbenivāsam dassetuṃ  chinna vaṭumaka anussaraṇa ādīsu iti vuttam chinna vaṭumakā sammāsambuddhā tesam anussaraṇam
translated: In order to show the past life that is the province of the knowledge of the recollection of past lives, which has reached its culmination,🔽it is said, “By the recollection of those who have cut off the cycle, etc.” The “recollection of those who have cut off the cycle” is the recollection of the fully enlightened Buddhas who have cut off the cycle.

original: chinnavaṭumakānussaraṇaṃ. “Ādisaddena paccekabuddhabuddhasāvakānussaraṇāni gayhantī”ti
analyzed: chinna vaṭumaka anussaraṇam ādi saddena paccekabuddha buddhasāvaka anussaraṇāni gayhanti iti
translated: Some say that the word “etc.” includes the recollection of paccekabuddhas and disciples.

original: keci vadanti. Chinnavaṭumakā pana sabbeva anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbutā
analyzed: keci vadanti chinna vaṭumakā pana sabbā iva anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbutā
translated: But all of them have attained Nibbāna in the Nibbāna-element without residue of clinging.

original: chinnasaṃsāramaggattā, tesaṃ anussaraṇaṃ nāma tesaṃ paṭipattiyā anussaraṇaṃ. Sā pana
analyzed: chinna saṃsāra magga ttā tesam anussaraṇam nāma tesam paṭipattiyāḥ anussaraṇam sā pana
translated: Because the Thread of the cycle of rebirths is cut, their remembering is called “ remembering of the cut-off cycle of rebirths “.🔽And that remembering is, in brief, characterized by the apprehending of the six bases.

original: paṭipatti saṅkhepato chaḷārammaṇaggahaṇalakkhaṇāti tāni idha paraviññāṇaviññātaggahaṇena🔽gahitāni. Tasmā purimāsu jātīsu attano viññāṇena aviññātānaṃ parinibbutānaṃ sabbesampi
analyzed: paṭipatti saṅkhepato chaṭ ārammaṇa ggahaṇa lakkhaṇā ti tāni idha para viññāṇa viññāta ggahaṇena  gahitāni tasmā purimāsu jātīsu attanaḥ viññāṇena aviññātānam parinibbutānam sabbesam pi
translated: So they are apprehended here by the apprehending of the cognizance of others.

original: buddhapaccekabuddhasāvakānaṃ anussaraṇaṃ chinnavaṭumakānussaraṇanti veditabbaṃ. Ādi-saddena🔽panettha purimāsu jātīsu attano viññāṇena aviññātānaṃ aparinibbutānampi vattamānakkhandhapaṭipāṭiyā
analyzed: buddha paccekabuddha sāvakānam anussaraṇam chinna vaṭumaka anussaraṇam ti veditabbam ādi saddena  pana ittha purimāsu jātīsu attanaḥ viññāṇena aviññātānam aparinibbutānam pi vattamāna kkhandha paṭipāṭiyā
translated: Therefore remembering of all Buddhas, Paccekabuddhas, and ordinary disciples who have attained extinction and who were not apprehended by one’s own cognizance in previous births should be understood as “ remembering of the cut-off cycle of rebirths “.🔽But by the word “ etc.”🔽herein remembering of those who have not attained extinction and who were not apprehended by one’s own cognizance in previous births is included, and that is remembered by the method of the lion’s leap without the occurrence of the present aggregates in the same order.

original: agantvā sīhokkantikavasena anussaraṇaṃ gahitaṃ, ime pana yathāvuttachinnavaṭumakānussaraṇādayo
analyzed: a gantvā sīha ukkantika vasena anussaraṇam gahitam ime pana yathāvutta chinna vaṭumaka anussaraṇa ādayaḥ
translated: But these kinds of remembering of the cut-off cycle of rebirths, etc., as stated,

analyzed: bhāvesum phala nibbānāni evam veneyye vinesun ti ettha sabbathā aññesam
translated: and they realized the fruits and Nibbāna. Thus they train their disciples in every way.

original: ñāṇassa gati atthīti. Ye pana purimāsu jātīsu attanova viññāṇena viññātā, te parinibbutepi

translated: “He directs his mind to the knowledge of the recollection of past lives”: he sends his mind forth to the recollection of past lives, he makes his mind inclined to, prone to, intent upon the recollection of past lives.🔽In the text, “he directs” is said to be “he sends forth” because of the usage of the highest person.

original: Āraddhappakāradassanattheti anussarituṃ āraddhassa pubbenivāsassa pabhedadassanatthe.🔽Ekampi jātinti ekampi bhavaṃ. So hi ekakammanibbatto ādānanikkhepaparicchinno antogadhadhammappabhedo
analyzed: āraddha ppakāra dassana tthe ti anussaritum āraddhassa pubbenivāsassa pabheda dassana tthe  ekam pi jātim ti ekam api bhavam saḥ hi eka kamma nibbattaḥ ādāna nikkhepa paricchinnaḥ antogadha dhamma ppabhedaḥ

original: khandhappabandho idha “jātī”ti adhippeto jāyatīti jātīti katvā. Tenāha “ekampi…pe…
analyzed: khandha ppabandhaḥ idha jātī iti adhippetaḥ jāyati iti jātī iti katvā tena āha ekampipe
translated: The continuity of aggregates is what is intended here. Hence he said: “One becoming … one continuity of aggregates” .🔽As it decays: as it wastes away, as it perishes.

analyzed: khandha santānanti parihāyamānaḥ ti khīyamānaḥ vinassamānaḥ kappo ti asaṅkhyeyya kappo
translated: An aeon: an asaṅkhyeya aeon.

analyzed: saḥ pana atthataḥ kālaḥ tadā pavattamāna saṅkhāra vasena assa veditabbā vaḍḍhamānaḥ

original: ekasmiṃ cakkavāḷe ṭhatvā sabbasattānaṃ atthāya paritte kate āṇākkhette sabbasattānaṃ
analyzed: ekasmin cakkavāḷe ṭhatvā sabba sattānam atthāya paritte kate āṇā khette sabba sattānam
translated: having recited the safeguard for the purpose of all beings in one world-sphere,

original: abhisambhuṇātveva parittānubhāvo tattha devatāhi parittānaṃ sampaṭicchitabbatoti
analyzed: abhisambhuṇātu eva paritta anubhāvaḥ tattha devatāhi parittānam sampaṭicchitabbato ti
translated: the influence of the safeguard is effective for all beings in that world-sphere, since the deities there accept the safeguard.🔽“The field of influence extends” is said.

original: vuttaṃ “ānubhāvo pavattatī”ti. Yaṃ yāvatā vā pana ākaṅkheyyāti vuttanti yaṃ visayakkhettaṃ
analyzed: vuttam ānubhāvaḥ pavattati iti yam yāvatā vā pana ākaṅkheyya ati vuttam ti yam visaya khettam
translated: As to “as far as he wishes”: the field of objects is that, referring to which,

original: sandhāya ekasmiṃyeva khaṇe sarena abhiviññāpanaṃ attano rūpadassanañca paṭijānantena
analyzed: sandhāya ekasmiṃ yeva khaṇe sarena abhiviññāpanam attanaḥ rūpa dassanañca paṭijānantena
translated: in a single moment, one who admits to the proclamation of knowledge and the seeing of his own form,

original: bhagavatā “yāvatā vā pana ākaṅkheyyā”ti vuttaṃ. Yatthāti yasmiṃ padese anantāparimāṇe
analyzed: bhagavatā yāvatā vā pana ākaṅkheyya ati vuttam yattha iti yasmin padese ananta aparimāṇe
translated: The Blessed One said, “Or whatever he wishes,”

original: visayakkhette. Yaṃ yaṃ ākaṅkhati, taṃ taṃ anussaratīti ākaṅkhamattapaṭibaddhavuttitāya
analyzed: visaya khette yam yam ākaṅkhati tam tam anussarati iti ākaṅkha matta paṭibaddha vutti tāya
translated: “In whatever place” means in whatever region, in whatever field of objects that is infinite and measureless.🔽“Whatever he wishes to recollect, that he recollects” means that since the Buddha’s knowledge occurs in accordance with his wish,

original: buddhañāṇassa yaṃ yaṃ anussarituṃ icchati, taṃ taṃ anussarati. Ekaṃ āṇākkhettaṃ vinassatīti
analyzed: buddha ñāṇassa yam yam anussaritum icchati tam tam anussarati ekam āṇā khettam vinassati iti
translated: whatever he wishes to recollect, that he recollects. “One field of his knowledge is destroyed”

original: iminā tiriyato saṃvaṭṭamānaparicchedo vutto. Saṇṭhahantanti vivaṭṭamānaṃ jāyamānaṃ.🔽Tassa vināso ca saṇṭhahanañca visuddhimagge vuttanti amhehipi heṭṭhā “lokavidū”ti
analyzed: iminā tiriyataḥ saṃvaṭṭamāna paricchedaḥ vuttaḥ saṇṭhahantanti vivaṭṭamānam jāyamānam  tassa vināso ca saṇṭhahanam ca visuddhi magge vuttanti amhehi pi heṭṭhā loka vidū ti
translated: means that the extent of the destruction is limited to the edge of the world. “It contracts” means that it is being destroyed and is being born again.🔽The destruction and contraction of the world are explained in the Visuddhimagga,

original: imassa atthasaṃvaṇṇanādhikāre pasaṅgato vuttattā idha na vuccati.
analyzed: imassa attha saṃvaṇṇanā adhikāre pasaṅgataḥ vutta ttā idha na vuccati
translated: and since they are also explained by us in the commentary on the words “world-knower” in the Niddesa, they are not explained here.

original: Evaṃ pasaṅgena saṃvaṭṭādike pakāsetvā idāni yathādhigataṃ tesaṃ anussaraṇākāraṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: evam pasaṅgena saṃvaṭṭa ādike pakāsetvā idāni yathā adhigatam tesam anussaraṇa ākāram dassetuṃ
translated: Having thus explained the world’s contraction and so on by way of the Buddha’s knowledge, the author now shows the mode of recollecting these things as he has understood them,

original: “ye panete saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭā vuttā”tiādimāha. Tattha etesūti niddhāraṇe bhummaṃ saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappasamudāyato
analyzed: ye pana ete saṃvaṭṭa vivaṭṭāḥ vuttā iti ādim āha tattha etesu iti niddhāraṇe bhummam saṃvaṭṭa vivaṭṭa kappa samudāyato
translated: saying, “But it was said that the world contracts and expands,” and so on. Herein, “in these” is a locative particle. The world’s contraction and expansion are stated🔽in the passage on the aeon of world-dissolution.

original: anekesaṃ saṃvaṭṭakappādīnaṃ niddhāriyamānattā. Amumhi saṃvaṭṭakappeti ettha vā-saddo
analyzed: anekesam saṃvaṭṭa kappa ādīnam niddhāriyamāna ttā amumhi saṃvaṭṭa kappe ti ettha vā saddaḥ
translated: because many aeons of world-expansion and so on are included. In the phrase “in this world-system’s aeon of world-expansion” the word “this”🔽should be regarded as indicating a particular aeon. And by that word, which

original: luttaniddiṭṭho daṭṭhabbo. Tena ca aniyamatthena itarāsaṃ asaṅkhyeyyānampi saṅgaho
analyzed: daṭṭhabbo tena ca aniyama tthena itarāsam saṅgahaḥ
translated: has the sense of “a certain,” the other innumerable aeons are included as well.

original: siddhoti. Atha vā amumhi saṃvaṭṭakappeti idaṃ saṃvaṭṭakappassa ādito pāḷiyaṃ gahitattā
analyzed: siddhaḥ ti atha vā amumhi saṃvaṭṭa kappe ti idam saṃvaṭṭa kappassa āditas pāḷiyam gahita ttā
translated: Or alternatively, the phrase “in this world-system’s aeon of world-expansion”🔽is said because the aeon of world-expansion is mentioned in the texts. For

original: vuttaṃ. Tatthāpi hi imassa katipayakālaṃ bhavādīsu saṃsaraṇaṃ upalabbhatīti. Saṃvaṭṭakappe
analyzed: vuttam tattha api hi imassa katipaya kālam bhava ādīsu saṃsaraṇam upalabbhati iti saṃvaṭṭa kappe
translated: even there it is possible to find the occurrence of this being in the various🔽states of existence for a few times. Or else this should be regarded as showing

original: vā vattamāne yesu bhavādīsu imassa upapatti ahosi, taṃdassanametaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Bhave
analyzed: vā vattamāne yesu bhava ādīsu imassa upapatti ahosi tad dassanam etam daṭṭhabbam bhave
translated: the states of existence, etc., in which this being was reborn while the aeon🔽of world-expansion was in progress. In the phrase “in the various states of🔽existence” , etc., the various states of existence are the sensual-sphere and🔽other kinds of existence; the various kinds of generation are the egg-born and🔽other kinds of generation; the various kinds of destiny are the divine and other

original: vātiādīsu kāmādibhave vā aṇḍajādiyoniyā vā devādigatiyā vā nānattakāyanānattasaññīādiviññāṇaṭṭhitiyā
analyzed: vāti ādīsu kāma ādi bhave vā aṇḍaja ādi yoniyā vā deva ādi gatiyā vā nānatta kāya nānatta saññī ādi viññāṇa ṭṭhitiyā
translated: destinies; the various kinds of station of consciousness are the station of consciousness characterized by diversity of body and diversity of perception,🔽and so on; the various kinds of abode of beings are the abode of beings consisting of the four great kings, and so on; the various kinds of aggregates of🔽beings are the aggregates of beings consisting of the khattiyas, and so on.

original: vā sattāvāse vā khattiyādisattanikāye vā. Yasmā idaṃ bhagavato vasena pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇaṃ
analyzed: vā satta āvāse vā khattiya ādi satta nikāye vā yasmai idam bhagavataḥ vasena pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇam
translated: Because this knowledge of recollecting past lives belongs to the Exalted🔽One,

original: āgataṃ, tasmā tasseva nāmādivasena atthaṃ yojetvā dassento āha “evaṃnāmoti vessantaro
analyzed: āgatam tasmā tassa iva nāma ādi vasena attham yojetvā dassentaḥ āha evaṃnāmā iti vessantaro
translated: and so he has come, and he is called by that name.🔽The food of rice and meat curry is mentioned with reference to the time when he was a householder.

original: vā jotipālo vā”tiādi. Sālimaṃsodanāhāro vāti gihikālaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Pavattaphalabhojano
analyzed: vā jotipālaḥ vā ati ādi sāli maṃsa udana āhāraḥ vā ati gihi kālam sandhāya vuttam pavatta phala bhojanaḥ
translated: The food of fallen fruits is mentioned with reference to the time when he was an ascetic.🔽The food of fallen fruits is the food of fruits that have fallen of themselves.

original: vāti tāpasādikālaṃ sandhāya. Pavattaphalabhojanoti sayampatitaphalāhāro. Sāmisanirāmisādippabhedānanti🔽ettha sāmisā gehassitasomanassādayo, nirāmisā nekkhammassitasomanassādayo. Ādi-saddena
analyzed: vāti tāpasa ādi kālam sandhāya sayam patita phala āhāraḥ  ettha sāmisāḥ gehassita somanassa ādayaḥ nirāmisāḥ nekkhamma ssita somanassa ādayaḥ ādi saddena
translated: The kinds of happiness classed as with and without lust, etc.,🔽Herein, those classed as with lust are the happiness of householders, such as that of the gods of the sense-sphere, and so on.

original: vivekajasamādhijasukhādīnaṃ saṅgaho.
analyzed: viveka ja samādhi ja sukha ādīnam saṅgaho
translated: Those classed as without lust are the happiness of those gone forth, such as that of the gods of the Brahmā-world, and so on.🔽The word “etc.” includes the kinds classed as born of seclusion, born of concentration, and so on.

original: Heṭṭhā sāmaññato vuttamevatthaṃ vibhajitvā dassetukāmo “atha vā”tiādimāha. Tattha
analyzed: heṭṭhā sāmaññataḥ vuttam eva attham vibhajitvā dassetu kāmaḥ atha vā ti ādim āha tattha
translated: He now said “Or alternatively” in order to show the meaning already stated in general above in detail.🔽Herein, he lived there means he lived there in that place.

original: amutrāsinti sāmaññaniddesoyaṃ, byāpanicchālopo vā, amutra amutra āsinti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: amutra āsinti sāmañña niddesaḥ yam vā amutra amutra āsinti vuttam hoti
translated: The word “there” is a demonstrative pronoun, or it is a locative indeclinable.🔽The word “there” is used in the sense of “there in that place.”

original: Anupubbena ārohantassa yāvadicchakaṃ anussaraṇanti ettha ārohantassāti paṭilomato
analyzed: anupubbena ārohantassa yāvadicchakam anussaraṇanti ettha ārohantassa ati paṭilomataḥ
translated: As to the words “he recollected as far as he wanted in forward order and in reverse order and in both ways,” “in forward order” is in the order of arising.

original: ñāṇena pubbenivāsaṃ ārohantassa. Paṭinivattantassāti pubbenivāsaṃ anussaraṇavasena
analyzed: ñāṇena pubbenivāsam ārohantassa paṭinivattantassa ati pubbenivāsam anussaraṇa vasena
translated: When he ascends to the knowledge of past lives.

original: yāvadicchakaṃ gantvā paccāgacchantassa. Paccavekkhaṇanti anussaritānussaritassa paccavekkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: yāvadicchakam gantvā paccāgacchantassa paccavekkhaṇanti anussarita anussaritassa paccavekkhaṇaṃ
translated: When he turns back: when he has gone as far as he wants to go by recollecting his past lives, he comes back. When he reviews: he reviews what he has already recollected.

original: Tasmāti vuttassevatthassa kāraṇabhāvena paccāmasanaṃ, paṭinivattantassa paccavekkhaṇabhāvatoti
analyzed: tasmā ati vuttassa iva atthassa kāraṇa bhāvena paccāmasanam paṭinivattantassa paccavekkhaṇa bhāvato ti
translated: Because: because of the reason for what has been said. He comes back: because he reviews when he turns back.

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Idhūpapattiyāti idha carimabhave upapattiyā. Anantaranti atītānantaramāha.
analyzed: vuttam hoti idha upapattiyā ti idha carima bhave upapattiyā anantaram iti atīta anantaram āha
translated: Here in this rebirth: here in this final existence. Immediately: he means immediately after the past.

original: Amutrāti amukasmiṃ bhaveti attho. Udapādinti uppajjiṃ. Tāhi devatāhīti tusitadevatāhi.
analyzed: amutra ati amukasmin bhave iti atthaḥ udapādinti uppajjim tāhi devatāhi iti tusita devatāhi
translated: There: the meaning is in that existence. I appeared: I was reborn. By those deities: by the Tusita deities.

original: Ekagottoti tusitagottena ekagotto. Mahābodhisattānaṃ santānassa pariyosānāvatthāyaṃ
analyzed: eka gotto ti tusita gottena eka gottaḥ mahā bodhisattānam santānassa
translated: Of the same clan: of the same clan as the Tusita clan. The rebirth in the world of the gods of a great Bodhisatta’s continuum at the end of the aeon

original: devalokūpapattijanakaṃ nāma akusalena kammunā anupaddutameva hotīti adhippāyena “dukkhaṃ
analyzed: deva loka upapatti janakam nāma akusalena kammunā anupaddutam eva hoti iti adhippāyena dukkham
translated: is not obstructed by any unwholesome action that causes rebirth in the world of the gods. With this intention he said: “Painful

original: pana saṅkhāradukkhamattamevā”ti vuttaṃ. Mahāpuññānampi pana devaputtānaṃ pubbanimittuppattikālādīsu
analyzed: pana saṅkhāra dukkha mattam evā ti vuttam mahā puññānam pi pana deva puttānam pubba nimitta uppatti kāla ādīsu
translated: But even for gods of great merit there is a concurrence of undesirable objects at the time of the appearance of the prenascent signs of death, etc.,

original: aniṭṭhārammaṇasamāyogo hotiyevāti “kadāci dukkhadukkhassapi sambhavo natthī”ti na
analyzed: aniṭṭha ārammaṇa samāyogaḥ kadāci dukkha dukkhassa api sambhavaḥ natthi iti na
translated: and so it cannot be said that “there is never any occurrence of the suffering of suffering.”

original: sakkā vattuṃ, dhammānaṃ uppādanirodhasaṅkhāradukkhanti veditabbaṃ. Sattapaññāsa…pe…
analyzed: sakkā vattum dhammānam uppāda nirodha saṅkhāra dukkham ti veditabbam satta paññāsape
translated: The arising and ceasing of formations should be understood as the suffering of formations.

original: pariyantoti idaṃ manussavassagaṇanāvasena vuttaṃ. Tattha devānaṃ vassagaṇanāya pana catusahassameva.
analyzed: pariyantaḥ ti idam manussa vassa gaṇanā vasena vuttam tattha devānam vassa gaṇanāya pana catu sahassam eva
translated: Fifty-seven … end: this is said according to human reckoning. But according to the gods’ reckoning it is only four thousand years.

original: Itīti vuttatthanidassanametaṃ, tañca kho yathārahato, na yathānupubbatoti dassento
analyzed: iti iti vutta attha nidassanam etam tat ca kho yathārahataḥ na yathā anupubbato ti dassentaḥ
translated: This is a mere indication of the meaning of the words “thus” . He shows that it is according to what is appropriate, not according to sequence, when he says

original: “nāmagottavasenā”tiādimāha. Uddisīyatīti disvāva aviññeyyattā “ayaṃ ko nāmo”ti pucchite🔽“tisso gotamo”ti nāmagottena uddisīyati. Vaṇṇādīhīti vaṇṇāhāravedayitāyuparicchedehi.
analyzed: nāma gotta vasena ati ādim āha uddisīyati iti ayam kaḥ nāma uti pucchite 🔽tissaḥ gotamaḥ ti nāma gottena uddisīyati vaṇṇa ādīhi iti vaṇṇa āhāra vedayita āyu paricchedehi
translated: “by name and race” . He is pointed out by name and race when he is asked, “Who is he?”🔽after he has been seen but cannot be recognized, and he is pointed out by his colour, shape, size, possessions, and so on.

original: Sāmotīti ettha iti-saddo ādiattho, pakārattho vā. Tena evamādievaṃpakāranānattatoti
analyzed: sāmaḥ ti iti ettha iti saddo ādi atthaḥ pakāra atthaḥ vā tena evamādi evaṃpakāra nānatta to ti
translated: Herein, the word “etc.” has the meaning of “beginning with” or the meaning of “such as”. So the meaning is: “because of the variety of such and such kinds of defilements”.🔽

original: dassitaṃ hoti. Nāmagottaṃ uddesoti uddisīyati satto etenāti uddeso nāmagottaṃ. Itare🔽ākārāti ākarīyati disvāva satto viññāyati etehīti itare vaṇṇādayo ākārā. “No ca kho
analyzed: dassitam hoti nāma gottam uddeso ti uddisīyati sattaḥ etena ati uddesaḥ nāma gottam itare  ākārāti ākarīyati disvā ava sattaḥ viññāyati etehi iti itare vaṇṇa ādayo ākārā no ca kho
translated: Herein, the word “etc.” has the meaning of “such as” or “for example.” So the meaning of “due to the diversity of name-and-surname, etc.,” is shown. “Name-and-surname” is the designation by which a being is designated. The other

original: avisesenā”ti saṅkhepato vuttamevatthaṃ vitthārena dassento āha “titthiyā hī”tiādi.
analyzed: avisesena āti saṅkhepataḥ vuttam eva attham vitthārena dassentaḥ āha titthiyāḥ hi itiādi
translated: are the “characteristics,” for by them a being is recognized when seen. “But not without distinction” : the meaning of this, stated briefly, is shown in detail by the words “for the sectarians,” etc.

original: Tattha titthiyāti aññatitthiyā. Te pana kammavādino kiriyavādino tāpasādayo. Yasmā
analyzed: tattha titthiyā ti aññatitthiyā te pana kamma vādinaḥ kiriya vādinaḥ tāpasa ādayaḥ yasmā
translated: Herein, “sectarians” are the adherents of other sects. They are the ascetics, etc., who are proponents of kamma and proponents of action.

original: titthiyānaṃ brahmajālādīsu cattālīsāya eva saṃvaṭṭavivaṭṭānaṃ anussaraṇaṃ āgataṃ,
analyzed: titthiyānam brahmajāla ādīsu cattālīsāyaḥ eva saṃvaṭṭa vivaṭṭānam anussaraṇam āgatam
translated: Since the sectarians are able to recollect only forty eons,

original: tasmā “na tato para”nti vatvā tattha kāraṇaṃ vadanto “dubbalapaññattā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: tasmā na tatas paranti vatvā tattha kāraṇam vadantaḥ dubbala paññattā ti ādim āha
translated: the text says “not beyond that.” And in order to explain the reason for this, it says “because of their weak knowledge.”

original: Tena vipassanābhiyogo pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇassa visesakāraṇanti dasseti. Tatoyeva
analyzed: tena vipassanā abhiyogaḥ pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇassa visesa kāraṇan ti dasseti
translated: This shows that the practice of insight is the special cause for the knowledge of the recollection of past lives.

original: ca balavapaññattā ṭhapetvā aggasāvakamahāsāvake itare pakatisāvakā kappasatampi kappasahassampi🔽anussarantiyevāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Teneva vuttaṃ visuddhimagge “pakatisāvakā kappasatampi
analyzed: ca balava paññattā ṭhapetvā aggasāvaka mahāsāvake itare pakatisāvakā kappa satam pi kappa sahassam pi  anussarantiyā iva āti daṭṭhabbam tena iva vuttam visuddhi magge pakati sāvakā kappa satam pi
translated: and because of the strength of their resolution, other ordinary disciples, except for the chief disciples and the great disciples, can recollect a thousand aeons or a hundred thousand aeons,🔽but not more than that. Therefore it should be understood that they can recollect a thousand aeons or a hundred thousand aeons.

original: kappasahassampi anussarantiyeva balavapaññattā”ti. Ettako hi tesaṃ abhinīhāroti kappānaṃ🔽satasahassampi tadadhikaṃ ekaṃ dve ca asaṅkhyeyyānīti kālavasena evaṃparimāṇo yathākkamaṃ
analyzed: kappa sahassam pi anussarantiyā iva balava paññattā ati ettakaḥ hi tesam abhinīhāraḥ ti kappānam  sata sahassam pi tad adhikam ekam dve ca asaṅkhyeyyāni iti kāla vasena evaṃparimāṇaḥ yathākkamam
translated: For that is the extent of their resolution.🔽The extent of the time of the great disciples, chief disciples, and paccekabuddhas is respectively a hundred thousand aeons, two incalculables and a hundred thousand aeons, and four incalculables and a hundred thousand aeons.

original: tesaṃ mahāsāvakaaggasāvakapaccekabuddhānaṃ puññañāṇābhinīhāro, sāvakapaccekabodhipāramitā
analyzed: tesam mahāsāvaka aggasāvaka paccekabuddhānam puñña ñāṇa abhinīhāraḥ sāvaka paccekabodhi pāramitā
translated: The perfection of the knowledge and resolution of the disciples and paccekabuddhas is thus established in terms of time.

original: siddhā. Yadi bodhisambhārasambharaṇakālaparicchinno tesaṃ tesaṃ ariyānaṃ abhiññāñāṇavibhavo,
analyzed: siddhāḥ yadi bodhi sambhāra sambharaṇa kāla paricchinno tesam tesam ariyānam abhiññā ñāṇa vibhavo
translated: If the knowledge and insight of the noble ones is limited to the time of accumulating the requisites for enlightenment,

original: evaṃ sante buddhānampissa paricchedatā āpannāti āha “buddhānaṃ pana paricchedo natthī”ti.
analyzed: evam sante buddhānam pi ssa pariccheda tā āpannā ti āha buddhānam pana paricchedaḥ natthi iti
translated: then the knowledge of the Buddhas must also be limited. Therefore it is said that the knowledge of the Buddhas is not limited.

original: “Yāvatakaṃ ñeyyaṃ, tāvatakaṃ ñāṇa”nti vacanato sabbaññutaññāṇassa viya buddhānaṃ
analyzed: yāvatakam ñeyyam tāvatakam ñāṇanti vacanato sabbaññu taññāṇassa viya buddhānam
translated: “As far as there is the knowable, so far there is knowledge” .

original: abhiññāñāṇānampi savisaye paricchedo nāma natthīti tattha yaṃ yaṃ ñātuṃ icchanti,
analyzed: abhiññā ñāṇānam pi sa visaye paricchedaḥ nāma natthi iti tattha yam yam ñātum icchanti
translated: Therefore, just as there is no limitation of the Buddha’s knowledge of omniscience, so too there is no limitation of the Buddha’s knowledge of direct-knowledge with regard to its domain.

original: taṃ taṃ jānanti eva. Atha vā satipi kālaparicchede kāraṇūpāyakosallapariggahādinā
analyzed: tam tam jānanti eva atha vā sati pi kāla paricchede kāraṇa upāya kosalla pariggaha ādinā
translated: Therefore, whatever they wish to know, they know.

original: sātisayattā mahābodhisambhārānaṃ paññāpāramitāya pavattiānubhāvassa paricchedo nāma
analyzed: sā ati saya ttā mahā bodhisambhārānam paññāpāramitāya pavatti ānubhāvassa paricchedaḥ nāma
translated: Or, although there is a limitation of time, there is no limitation of the power of the occurrence of the perfection of wisdom, which is endowed with the skill in means of the requisites of great enlightenment, etc.🔽How much less is there a limitation of the knowledge of direct-knowledge that arises from that!

original: natthi, kuto taṃnibbattānaṃ abhiññāñāṇānanti āha “buddhānaṃ pana paricchedo natthī”ti.
analyzed: natthi kutas tad nibbattānam abhiññā ñāṇānam ti āha buddhānam pana paricchedaḥ natthi iti
translated: Therefore it is said: “But there is no limitation for Buddhas.”🔽In the past there was no limitation of time such as “after so many incalculable periods of time” .

original: Atīte “ettakānaṃ kappānaṃ asaṅkhyeyyānī”ti evaṃ kālaparicchedo natthi anāgate anāgataṃsañāṇassa
analyzed: atīte ettakānam kappānam asaṅkhyeyyāni iti evam kāla paricchedaḥ na atthi anāgate anāgataṃsañāṇassa
translated: In the future there is no limitation of time such as “after so many years, etc.”,🔽like the knowledge of the future of the knowledge of the past of the five.

original: viya. Tenāha “yāva icchanti tāva sarantī”ti.
analyzed: tena āha yāvaḥ icchanti tāva saranti iti
translated: Therefore it is said: “They remember as far back as they wish.”

original: Evaṃ pañcannaṃ janānaṃ pubbenivāsānussaraṇaṃ kālavibhāgato dassetvā idāni ārammaṇaggahaṇavasenassa
analyzed: evam pañcannam janānam pubbenivāsa anussaraṇam kāla vibhāgataḥ dassetvā idāni ārammaṇa ggahaṇa vasena assa
translated: Having thus shown the recollection of past lives of the five kinds of persons by way of the division of time, he now shows it by way of the apprehension of the object.

original: pavattivisesaṃ dassento “titthiyā cā”tiādimāha. Khandhapaṭipāṭimeva sarantīti ettha
analyzed: pavatti visesam dassentaḥ titthiyā ca ati ādim āha khandha paṭipāṭim eva saranti iti ettha
translated: The phrase “remembering the order of the aggregates” means

original: khandhapaṭipāṭi khandhānaṃ anukkamo, sā ca kho cutito paṭṭhāya uppaṭipāṭivasena.🔽Keci panettha “iriyāpathapaṭipāṭi khandhapaṭipāṭī”ti vadanti. Vuttamevatthaṃ byatirekato🔽vibhāvento āha “paṭipāṭiṃ muñcitvā”tiādi. Tattha cutipaṭisandhivasenāti attano parassa
analyzed: khandha paṭipāṭi khandhānaṃ anukkamaḥ sā ca kho cutitaḥ paṭṭhāya uppaṭipāṭi vasena  keci pana ittha iriyāpatha paṭipāṭi khandha paṭipāṭi iti vadanti vuttam eva attham byatirekato  vibhāventaḥ āha paṭipāṭim muñcitvā atiādi tattha cuti paṭisandhi vasena āti attanaḥ parassa
translated: remembering the order of the aggregates in the order of arising, beginning with death.🔽But some say that the order of the aggregates is the order of the postures.

original: vā tasmiṃ tasmiṃ attabhāve cutiṃ disvā antarā kiñci anāmasitvā paṭisandhiyā eva gahaṇavasena.
analyzed: vā tasmin tasmin atta bhāve cutim disvā antarā kiñci an āmasitvā paṭisandhiyā eva gahaṇa vasena
translated: He distinguishes the meaning stated by the words “the order of the aggregates” by the words “excluding the order” , etc. Herein, by the words “by way of death and rebirth” is meant that they remember only the rebirth-linking, without mentioning anything else, after seeing the death in this or that existence of themselves or of others.

original: Yathā pana andhā yaṭṭhiṃ amuñcitvā gacchanti, evaṃ te khandhapaṭipāṭiṃ amuñcitvāva
analyzed: yathā pana andhāḥ yaṭṭhim a muñcitvā gacchanti evam te khandha paṭipāṭim a muñcitvā ava
translated: But just as the blind go on holding to a stick, so they remember only the order of the aggregates without reaching the desired place.

original: sarantīti āha “tesañhi andhānaṃ viya icchitappadesokkamanaṃ natthī”ti. Sāvakāti pakatisāvakāpi
analyzed: saranti iti āha tesam hi andhānam viya icchita padesa ukkamanam natthi iti sāvakā ati pakati sāvakā api
translated: Therefore it is said: “There is no going to the desired place for them, as for the blind.”🔽The word “disciple” refers to ordinary disciples, great disciples, and chief disciples.

original: mahāsāvakāpi aggasāvakāpi sāmaññato vuttā. Pakatisāvakāpi hi khandhapaṭipāṭiyāpi
analyzed: mahāsāvakā api aggasāvakā api sāmaññato vuttā pakati sāvakā api hi khandha paṭipāṭiyā api
translated: For ordinary disciples, too, remember the order of the aggregates.

original: anussaranti, cutipaṭisandhivasenapi saṅkamanti balavapaññattā, tathā asītimahāsāvakā.
analyzed: anussaranti cuti paṭisandhi vasena api saṅkamanti balava paññattā tathā asīti mahāsāvakā
translated: They remember and they pass on by way of death and rebirth too, because of the strength of their designation. So too the eighty great disciples.

original: Dvinnaṃ pana aggasāvakānaṃ khandhapaṭipāṭikiccaṃ natthi. Ekassa attabhāvassa cutiṃ
analyzed: dvinnam pana aggasāvakānam khandha paṭipāṭi kiccam natthi ekassa atta bhāvassa cutim
translated: But the two chief disciples have no succession of aggregates. Having seen the death of one individual

original: disvā paṭisandhiṃ passanti, puna aparassa cutiṃ disvā paṭisandhinti evaṃ cutipaṭisandhivasenapi🔽saṅkamantā gacchanti. Yathā nāma saradasamaye ṭhitamajjhanhikavelāyaṃ caturatanike
analyzed: disvā paṭisandhim passanti puna aparassa cutim disvā paṭisandhin ti evam cuti paṭisandhi vasena api  saṅkamantāḥ gacchanti yathā nāma sarada samaye ṭhita majjhanhika velāyam catur atanike
translated: they see the rebirth, and again having seen the death of another they see the rebirth. Thus they pass on🔽by way of death and rebirth too. Just as in the case of a man with good eyesight in a house with four windows

original: gehe cakkhumato purisassa rūpagataṃ supākaṭameva hotīti lokasiddhametaṃ. Siyā pana
analyzed: gehe cakkhumataḥ purisassa rūpa gatam su pākaṭam eva hoti iti loka siddham etam siyā pana
translated: looking at a form in the middle of the room, it is well known in the world that it is quite clear to him. But it may be

original: tassa sukhumataratirokuṭṭādibhedassa rūpagatassa agocaratā, na tveva buddhānaṃ ñātuṃ🔽icchitassa ñeyyassa agocaratā, atha kho taṃ ñāṇālokena obhāsitaṃ hatthatale āmalakaṃ
analyzed: tassa sukhuma tara tirokuṭṭa ādi bhedassa rūpa gatassa agocara tā na tu eva buddhānam ñātum  icchitassa ñeyyassa a gocara tā atha kho tam ñāṇa ālokena obhāsitam hattha tale āmalakam
translated: that the form is too subtle to be seen by him, and it is not that the Buddhas have no access to the knowable they wish to know,

original: viya supākaṭaṃ suvibhūtameva hoti, tathā ñeyyāvaraṇassa suppahīnattāti āha “buddhā panā”tiādi.
analyzed: viya su pākaṭam su vibhūtam eva hoti tathā ñeyya āvaraṇassa su pahīna ttā ti āha buddhāḥ pana atiādi
translated: but rather that it is quite clear and quite evident to them, like a fruit in the palm of the hand, because the obscuration to the knowable has been well abandoned, being lit up by the light of their knowledge. So he said “But Buddhas” and so on.

original: Tattha sīhokkantavasenāti sīhagatipatanavasena. Yaṃ yaṃ ṭhānaṃ ākaṅkhantīti yasmiṃ
analyzed: tattha sīha ukkanta vasena ati sīha gati patana vasena yam yam ṭhānam ākaṅkhanti iti yasmin
translated: Herein, by the lion’s stride: by the lion’s way of going. Whatever place they want to know:

original: kappe yasmiṃ bhave yaṃ yaṃ ṭhānaṃ jānituṃ icchanti. Taṃ sabbaṃ sarantiyevāti ñātuṃ
analyzed: kappe yasmin bhave yam yam ṭhānam jānitum icchanti tam sabbam sarantiyā iva ati ñātum
translated: whatever place they want to know in a certain aeon, in a certain becoming,

original: icchitaṃ taṃ sabbaṃ sarantiyeva, na na saranti. Buddhānañhi neva khandhapaṭipāṭikiccaṃ,
analyzed: icchitam tam sabbam sarantiyā iva na na saranti buddhānam hi na iva khandha paṭipāṭi kiccam
translated: they know all that: they know all that they want to know, they do not fail to know it. For Buddhas have no need to review the aggregates,

original: na ca cutipaṭisandhivasena saṅkamanakiccaṃ atthi. Tesañhi anekāsu kappakoṭīsu heṭṭhā🔽vā upari vā yaṃ yaṃ ṭhānaṃ icchanti, taṃ taṃ pākaṭameva hoti. Tasmā yathā peyyālapāḷiṃ
analyzed: na ca cuti paṭisandhi vasena saṅkamana kiccam atthi tesam hi anekāsu kappa koṭīsu heṭṭhā  vā upari vā yam yam ṭhānam icchanti tam tam pākaṭam eva tasmai yathā
translated: nor do they have any need to pass on from death to rebirth. For whatever place they want, whether in many millions of aeons below or above,

original: paṭhantā “paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ…pe… pañcamaṃ jhāna”ntiādipariyosānameva gaṇhantā saṅkhipitvā🔽sajjhāyanti, na anupadaṃ, evaṃ anekāpi kappakoṭiyo peyyālapāḷiṃ viya saṅkhipitvā
analyzed: paṭhantā paṭhamam jhānaṃpe pañcamam gaṇhantā saṅkhipitvā  na anupadam evam anekāḥ api kappa koṭiyaḥ peyyāla pāḷim viya saṅkhipitvā
translated: that becomes evident to them. So just as those who learn the recitation text take only the end thus, “The first jhāna … the fifth jhāna” , and they rehearse it in brief,

original: yaṃ yaṃ icchanti, tattha tattheva ñāṇena okkamantā sīhokkantavasena gacchanti. Evaṃ
analyzed: yam yam icchanti tattha tattha iva ñāṇena okkamantā sīha ukkanta vasena gacchanti evam
translated: not in detail, so too, Buddhas go by the lion’s stride, entering upon knowledge here and there, in whatever place they want, in brief, as it were,🔽like the recitation text, not in detail, though it may be of many millions of aeons.

original: gacchantānañca tesaṃ ñāṇaṃ yathā nāma katavālavedhiparicayassa sarabhaṅgasadisassa🔽dhanuggahassa khitto saro antarantarā rukkhalatādīsu asajjamāno lakkheyeva patati
analyzed: gacchantānam ca tesam ñāṇam yathā nāma kata vālavedhi paricayassa sarabhaṅga sadisassa  dhanuggahassa khittaḥ saraḥ antar antarā rukkha latā ādīsu a sajjamānaḥ patati
translated: And their knowledge as they go is like that of a skilled archer who has tested his bow.🔽An arrow shot by him does not touch the tree-trunks, creepers, etc., in between but hits the mark.

original: na sajjati na virajjhati, evaṃ antarantarāsu jātīsu na sajjati na virajjhati, asajjamānaṃ
analyzed: na sajjati na virajjhati evam antarantarāsu jātīsu na sajjati na virajjhati a sajjamānam
translated: It does not touch or cling to anything in between.

original: avirajjhamānaṃ icchiticchitaṭṭhānaṃyeva gaṇhāti.
analyzed: a virajjhamānam gaṇhāti
translated: It goes only to the place it is aimed at.

original: Atītabhave khandhā tappaṭibaddhanāmagottāni ca sabbaṃ pubbenivāsantveva saṅgahitānīti
analyzed: atīta bhave khandhāḥ tad paṭibaddha nāma gottāni ca sabbam pubbenivāsa ntu eva saṅgahitāni iti
translated: The aggregates in the past existence and the name and race bound up with them are all included in the knowledge of past lives.

original: āha “kiṃ viditaṃ karoti? Pubbenivāsa”nti. Moho paṭicchādakaṭṭhena tamo viya tamoti🔽āha “sveva moho”tiādi. Obhāsakaraṇaṭṭhenāti kātabbato karaṇaṃ, obhāsova karaṇaṃ obhāsakaraṇaṃ,
analyzed: āha kim viditam karoti moho paṭicchādaka ṭṭhena tamaḥ viya tamo ti  āha su eva moha utiādi obhāsa karaṇa ṭṭhena ati kātabbato karaṇam obhāsaḥ uva karaṇam obhāsa karaṇam
translated: So it is said: “What is known? Past lives.” Delusion is like darkness in the sense of concealing.🔽So it is said: “That same delusion” and so on.

original: attano paccayehi obhāsabhāvena nibbattetabbaṭṭhenāti attho. Sesaṃ pasaṃsāvacananti
analyzed: attanaḥ paccayehi obhāsa bhāvena nibbattetabba ṭṭhena ati attho sesam pasaṃsā vacanan ti
translated: The meaning is that it is to be produced by its conditions in the nature of illumination.

original: paṭipakkhavidhamanapavattivisesānaṃ bodhanato vuttaṃ. Avijjā vihatāti etena vijānanaṭṭhena🔽vijjāti ayampi attho dīpitoti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Kasmā? Yasmā vijjā uppannāti etena vijjāpaṭipakkhā
analyzed: paṭipakkha vidhamana pavatti visesānam bodhanataḥ vuttam avijjā vihatā ti etena vijānana ṭṭhena  vijjā ti ayam pi atthaḥ dīpito ti daṭṭhabbam kasmā yasmā vijjā uppannā ti etena vijjā paṭipakkhā
translated: and because it shows the special quality of the removal of the opposite qualities. By the words “ignorance is abolished” it shows the meaning of “knowledge” in the sense of knowing.

original: avijjā, paṭipakkhatā cassā pahātabbabhāvena vijjāya ca pahāyakabhāvenāti dasseti.🔽Esa nayo itarasmimpi padadvayeti iminā tamo vihato vinaṭṭho. Kasmā? Yasmā āloko uppannoti
analyzed: avijjā paṭipakkha tā ca assā pahātabba bhāvena vijjāya ca pahāyaka bhāvena ati dasseti  itarasmim pi pada dvaya iti iminā tamaḥ vihataḥ vinaṭṭhaḥ kasmai yasmai āloko uppanno ti
translated: Why? Because it is said “knowledge arises.” By this it shows that ignorance is the opposite of knowledge and that it is to be abandoned by knowledge and that knowledge is what abandons it.🔽The same method applies to the other two terms. By the words “darkness is abolished, destroyed” it shows the meaning of “light” in the sense of illuminating.🔽Why? Because it is said “light arises.”

original: imamatthaṃ atidisati. Kilesānaṃ ātāpanaparitāpanaṭṭhena vīriyaṃ ātāpoti āha “vīriyātāpena
analyzed: imam attham atidisati kilesānam ātāpana paritāpana ṭṭhena vīriyam ātāpo ti āha vīriya ātāpena
translated: It is energy that burns up defilements by the act of burning and scorching them. Hence it is said: “By the burning of energy, by burning.”

original: ātāpino”ti, vīriyavatoti attho. Pesitacittassāti yathādhippetatthasiddhiṃ pativissaṭṭhacittassa.
analyzed: ātāpinaḥ ti vīriyavato ti attho pesita cittassa ti yathā adhippeta ttha siddhim pativissaṭṭha cittassa
translated: The meaning is: in one who is energetic. “In one whose mind is rightly directed” means in one whose mind is rightly concentrated on the accomplishment of the purpose intended.

original: Yathā appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharatoti aññassapi kassaci mādisassāti
analyzed: yathā appamattassa ātāpinaḥ pahitattassa viharato ti aññassa api kassaci mādisassa ati
translated: “In one who abides diligent, ardent, and self-controlled” means in one who is not negligent, who is energetic, and who has established restraint. “In one who abides thus” means in one who abides in any one of the jhanas.

original: adhippāyo. Padhānānuyogassāti sammappadhānamanuyuttassa. Sesamettha uttānattā vuttanayattā ca suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ padhāna anuyogassa ti sammappadhānam anuyuttassa sesam ettha uttāna ttā vutta naya ttā ca su viññeyyam eva
translated: “The purport”: the purport of the jhāna. “Who is devoted to the practice of the right endeavours”: who is devoted to the practice of the four right endeavours. The rest is clear.

original: Pubbenivāsakathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: pubbenivāsa kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the knowledge of recollection of past lives is finished.

original: Dibbacakkhuñāṇakathā
analyzed: dibba cakkhu ñāṇa kathā
translated: Knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings

original: 13. Cutiyāti cavane. Upapāteti upapajjane. Samīpatthe cetaṃ bhummavacanaṃ, cutikkhaṇasāmantā
analyzed: cutiyā ati cavane upapāte iti upapajjane samīpa atthe ca itam bhumma vacanam cuti kkhaṇa sāmantā
translated: “Passing away”: in dying. “Reappearance”: in rebirth. This is a locative of sphere, meaning “in the passing away and reappearance of beings.”

original: upapattikkhaṇasāmantā cāti vuttaṃ hoti. Tathā hi vakkhati “ye pana āsannacutikā”tiādi.
analyzed: upapatti khaṇa sāmantā ca ati vuttam hoti tathā hi vakkhati ye pana āsanna cutikā tiādi
translated: For it is said: “Those who are about to die” , etc.

original: Yena ñāṇenāti yena dibbacakkhuñāṇena. Dibbacakkhuñāṇeneva hi sattānaṃ cuti ca upapatti🔽ca ñāyati. Parikammaṃ vattabbaṃ siyāti “dibbacakkhuñāṇaṃ uppādetukāmena ādikammikena
analyzed: yena ñāṇena ati yena dibba cakkhu ñāṇena dibba cakkhu ñāṇena iva hi sattānam cuti ca upapatti  ca parikammam vattabbam siyāti dibba cakkhu ñāṇam uppādetu kāmena ādikammikena
translated: “By means of which knowledge”: by means of the knowledge of the divine eye. For it is only by means of the knowledge of the divine eye that the passing away and reappearance of beings is known.

original: kulaputtena kasiṇārammaṇaṃ abhiññāpādakajjhānaṃ sabbākārena abhinīhārakkhamaṃ katvā
analyzed: kula puttena kasiṇa ārammaṇam abhiññā pādaka jjhānam sabba ākārena abhinīhāra khamam katvā
translated: “The preliminary work should be done”: a clansman beginner who wants to arouse the knowledge of the divine eye should make the jhāna, which has the kasiṇa as its object, that is a basis for direct-knowledge, capable of effecting his aim by repeated practice.

original: tejokasiṇaṃ odātakasiṇaṃ ālokakasiṇanti imesu tīsu kasiṇesu aññataraṃ āsannaṃ kātabbaṃ,
analyzed: tejokasiṇam odātakasiṇam ālokakasiṇanti imesu tīsu kasiṇesu aññataram āsannam kātabbam
translated: Then he should make one of the three kasiṇas—the fire kasiṇa, the white kasiṇa, or the light kasiṇa—present before him.

original: upacārajjhānagocaraṃ katvā vaḍḍhetvā ṭhapetabba”ntiādinā dibbacakkhuñāṇassa parikammaṃ vattabbaṃ bhaveyya.
analyzed: upacāra jhāna gocaram katvā vaḍḍhetvā ṭhapetabba nti ādinā dibba cakkhu ñāṇassa parikammam vattabbam bhaveyya
translated: and it would be necessary to say that the preliminary work for the knowledge of the divine eye should be stated thus: ‘Having made the object the fine-material sphere, he should extend it and establish it.’

original: So ahanti so katacittābhinīhāro ahaṃ. Dibbasadisattāti divi bhavanti dibbaṃ, devānaṃ🔽pasādacakkhu, tena dibbena cakkhunā sadisattāti attho. Dibbasadisattāti ca hīnūpamādassanaṃ
analyzed: saḥ aham iti saḥ kata citta abhinīhāraḥ aham dibba sadisa ttā ati divi bhavanti dibbam devānam  pasāda cakkhu tena dibbena cakkhunā sadisa ttā ati atthaḥ dibba sadisa ttā ati ca hīna upama a dassanam
translated: ‘I’: the one who has made the resolution of the mind. ‘Like the divine’: the divine is that of the gods, the eye of the gods; the meaning is that it is like that divine eye. And ‘like the divine’ is a deprecation of the inferior.

original: devatānaṃ dibbacakkhutopi imassa mahānubhāvattā. Idāni taṃ dibbasadisattaṃ vibhāvetuṃ🔽“devatānañhī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tattha sucaritakammanibbattanti saddhābahulatāvisuddhadiṭṭhitāānisaṃsadassāvitādisampattiyā🔽suṭṭhu caritattā sucaritena devūpapattijanakena puññakammena nibbattaṃ. Pittasemharuhirādīhīti
analyzed: devatānam dibba cakkhutaḥ pi imassa mahā anubhāva ttā idāni tam dibba sadisa ttam vibhāvetum  devatānam hi itiādi vuttam tattha su carita kamma nibbattanti  suṭṭhu carita ttā su caritena deva upapatti janakena puñña kammena nibbattam pitta semha ruhira ādīhi iti
translated: For the divine eye of the gods is also like this because of its great effectiveness. Now, in order to demonstrate that likeness to the divine,

original: ādi-saddena vātarogādīnaṃ saṅgaho. Apalibuddhanti anupaddutaṃ. Pittādīhi anupaddutattā
analyzed: ādi saddena vāta roga ādīnam saṅgahaḥ apalibuddhanti anupaddutam pitta ādīhi anupadduta ttā
