original: kammassa ca uḷāratāya upakkilesavimutti veditabbā. Upakkilesadosarahitañhi kammaṃ
analyzed: kammassa ca uḷāra tāya upakkilesa vimutti veditabbā upakkilesa dosa rahitam hi kammam
translated: and by the greatness of the kamma, the deliverance is called “unadulterated.” For kamma that is free from the stain of defilements

original: tiṇādidosarahitaṃ viya sassaṃ uḷāraphalaṃ anupakkiliṭṭhaṃ hoti. Kāraṇūpacārena cassa
analyzed: tiṇa ādi dosa rahitam viya sassam uḷāra phalam anupakkiliṭṭham hoti kāraṇa upacārena ca ssa
translated: is like a crop free from the stain of weeds and bears its fruit unadulterated. And its fruit is described in the way it is because of the cause,

original: phalaṃ tathā voharīyati yathā “sukkaṃ sukkavipāka”nti. Dūrepīti pi-saddena sukhumassapi
analyzed: phalam tathā voharīyati yathā sukkam sukka vipākam ti dūre pi iti pi saddena sukhumassa api
translated: just as “white” is described as the colour of a white cloth because of the colour. The word “also” in the text includes the apprehending of even a subtle object.

original: ārammaṇassa sampaṭicchanasamatthataṃ saṅgaṇhāti. Pasādacakkhūti catunnaṃ mahābhūtānaṃ🔽pasādalakkhaṇaṃ cakkhu. Vīriyabhāvanābalanibbattanti vīriyārambhavaseneva ijjhanato
analyzed: ārammaṇassa sampaṭicchana samattha tam saṅgaṇhāti pasāda cakkhu iti catunnam mahābhūtānam  pasāda lakkhaṇam cakkhu vīriya bhāvanā bala nibbattanti vīriya ārambha vasena iva
translated: The eye of confidence: the eye has the characteristic of confidence in the four great primaries.

original: sabbāpi kusalabhāvanā vīriyabhāvanā, padhānasaṅkhārasamannāgatā vā iddhipādabhāvanā
analyzed: sabbā api kusala bhāvanā vīriya bhāvanā padhāna saṅkhāra samannāgatā vā iddhipāda bhāvanā
translated: Produced by the power of the development of energy: all profitable development is development of energy, or the development of the road to power consisting in the volition of renunciation is particularly development of energy.

original: visesato vīriyabhāvanā, tassā ānubhāvena nibbattaṃ vīriyabhāvanābalanibbattaṃ. Ñāṇamayaṃ
analyzed: visesataḥ vīriya bhāvanā tassāḥ ānubhāvena nibbattam vīriya bhāvanā bala nibbattam ñāṇa mayam
translated: Produced by the power of the development of energy is produced by the influence of that.🔽The eye of knowledge is the eye of wisdom.

original: cakkhu ñāṇacakkhu. Tādisamevāti upakkilesavimuttatāya dūrepi sukhumassapi ārammaṇassa
analyzed: cakkhu ñāṇa cakkhu tādisam eva ati upakkilesa vimutta tāya dūre pi sukhumassa api ārammaṇassa
translated: Such as that: unadulterated, able to see even a subtle object at a distance,

original: sampaṭicchanasamatthatāya ca taṃsadisameva.🔽Dibbavihāravasena paṭiladdhattāti dibbavihārasaṅkhātānaṃ catunnaṃ jhānānaṃ vasena
analyzed: sampaṭicchana samattha tāya ca taṃsadisam eva  dibba vihāra vasena dibba vihāra saṅkhātānam catunnam jhānānam vasena
translated: and it is like that in being able to consent to the divine abidings.🔽It is “obtained by means of the divine abidings” because it is obtained by means of the four jhānas called “divine abidings.” This is the reason why it is divine.

original: paṭiladdhattā. Iminā kāraṇavasenassa dibbabhāvamāha. Dibbavihārasannissitattāti aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgamena🔽ukkaṃsagataṃ pādakajjhānasaṅkhātaṃ dibbavihāraṃ sannissāya pavattattā, dibbavihārapariyāpannaṃ🔽vā attanā sampayuttaṃ rūpāvacaracatutthajjhānaṃ nissāya paccayabhūtaṃ sannissitattāti🔽evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Ālokapariggahena mahājutikattāpi dibbanti kasiṇālokānuggahena
analyzed: paṭiladdha ttā iminā kāraṇa vasena assa dibba bhāvam āha dibba vihāra sannissita ttā ti aṭṭhaṅga samannāgamena  ukkaṃsa gatam pādakajjhāna saṅkhātam dibba vihāram sannissāya pavatta ttā dibba vihāra pariyāpannam  vā attanā sampayuttam rūpāvacara catuttha jhānam nissāya paccaya bhūtam sannissita ttā ti  evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo āloka pariggahena mahā jutika ttā api dibbanti kasiṇa āloka anuggahena
translated: “It is supported by the divine abidings”: it occurs supported by the divine abidings consisting of the basic jhānas that have reached excellence with the eight factors.🔽Or the meaning can be regarded as follows: it is supported by the fourth fine-material-sphere jhāna associated with it, which is a condition for it by acting as its support, and which is included in the divine abidings.🔽“It is divine because of the pervasion by light”: it is divine because of the pervasion by the light of knowledge, since it is obtained by means of the kasiṇa light.

original: pattabbattā sayaṃ ñāṇālokapharaṇabhāvena ca mahājutikabhāvatopi dibbanti attho. Mahājutikampi
analyzed: pattabba ttā sayam ñāṇa āloka pharaṇa bhāvena ca mahājutika bhāvataḥ pi dibbanti atthaḥ mahājutikam pi
translated: The meaning is that it is divine because of the great radiance.

original: hi dibbanti vuccati “dibbamidaṃ byamha”ntiādīsu. Mahāgatikattāti mahanīyagamanattā,
analyzed: hi dibbanti vuccati dibbam idam byamhanti ādīsu mahāgatika ttā ati mahanīya gamana ttā
translated: For what is of great radiance is called “divine” in such passages as “Divine is this radiance, lord, and more divine” .🔽“It is divine because of the great range”: because of the great extent of its range,

original: vimhayanīyappavattikattāti attho. Vimhayanīyā hissa pavatti tirokuṭṭādigatarūpadassanato.
analyzed: vimhayanīya ppavattika ttā ti atthaḥ vimhayanīyā hissa pavatti tirokuṭṭa ādi gata rūpa dassanato
translated: the meaning is that it is a mode of occurrence that is to be wondered at. For its occurrence is to be wondered at because of the seeing of visible objects beyond walls, etc.🔽“The ‘all’ is said with reference to the fivefold meaning stated above” .

original: Taṃ sabbanti “heṭṭhā vuttaṃ atthapañcakamapekkhitvā vutta”nti vadanti. Keci pana
analyzed: tat sabbam ti heṭṭhā vuttam attha pañcakam apekkhitvā vuttanti vadanti keci pana
translated: But some say that🔽since those who are experts in sound want the sound of the devas, it is said with reference to just these two, namely,

original: “jutigatiatthesupi saddavidū divusaddaṃ icchantīti mahājutikattā mahāgatikattāti
analyzed: juti gati atthesu pi sadda vidū divu saddam icchanti iti mahājutikattā mahāgatikattā ati
translated: because of its great radiance and because of its great range.

original: idameva dvayaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ, tasmā ‘saddasatthānusārena veditabba’nti idaṃ dibbati
analyzed: idam eva dvayam sandhāya vuttam tasmā sadda sattha anusārena veditabbanti idam
translated: Therefore this is said: ‘It should be understood according to the method of the sound’ .

original: jotayatīti dibbaṃ, dibbati gacchati asajjamānaṃ pavattatīti dibbanti imamatthaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: jotayati iti dibbam dibbati gacchati a sajjamānam pavattati iti dibbam ti imam attham dassetuṃ
translated: It is divine because it shines , and it is divine because it goes , because it occurs without touching. In order to illustrate this meaning it is said:

original: vutta”nti vadanti. Ācariyadhammapālatthero pana –
analyzed: vuttanti vadanti ācariya dhammapāla theraḥ pana
translated: But the teacher Dhammapāla says as follows:

original: “Dibbacakkhulābhāya yogino parikammakaraṇaṃ tappaṭipakkhābhibhavassa atthato tassa
analyzed: dibba cakkhu lābhāya yoginaḥ parikamma karaṇam tad paṭipakkha abhibhavassa atthataḥ tassa
translated: “The yogi’s performance of the preliminary work for the attainment of the divine eye is in fact a desire for victory over its opposite,

original: vijayicchā nāma hoti, dibbacakkhulābhī ca iddhimā devatānaṃ vacanagahaṇakkhamanadhammadānavasena
analyzed: vijayicchā nāma hoti dibba cakkhu lābhī ca iddhimā devatānam vacana gahaṇa kkhamana dhamma dāna vasena
translated: and one who has attained the divine eye is fit to receive the words of the devas and to give them the gift of the True Idea.

original: mahāmoggallānattherādayo viya dānaggahaṇalakkhaṇe vohāre ca pavatteyyāti evaṃ vihāravijayicchāvohārajutigatisaṅkhātānaṃ
analyzed: mahāmoggallāna tthera ādayaḥ viya dāna ggahaṇa lakkhaṇe vohāre ca evam
translated: like the Elder Moggallāna the Great and others, in the act of receiving gifts and in the act of speaking. So it is because of these four things, namely,

original: atthānaṃ vasena imassa abhiññāñāṇassa dibbacakkhubhāvasiddhito saddavidū ca tesu
analyzed: atthānam vasena imassa abhiññā ñāṇassa dibba cakkhu bhāva siddhitaḥ sadda vidū ca tesu
translated: abiding, victory, desire, and speaking, that this knowledge of the kind called the divine eye is established. And those who are skilled in the use of words

original: eva atthesu divusaddaṃ icchantīti ‘taṃ sabbaṃ saddasatthānusārena veditabba’nti vutta”nti –
analyzed: eva atthesu divu saddam icchanti iti tat sabbam sadda sattha anusārena veditabban ti vuttam ti
translated: desire the word dibba for these four things. So all this should be understood according to the method of the word dibba in the texts.

original: Āha.
analyzed: āha
translated: He said:

original: Dassanaṭṭhenāti rūpadassanabhāvena. Cakkhunā hi sattā rūpaṃ passanti. Yathā maṃsacakkhu
analyzed: dassana ṭṭhena ati rūpa dassana bhāvena cakkhunā hi sattāḥ rūpam passanti yathā maṃsa cakkhu
translated: As seeing: as the state of seeing visible objects. For it is by means of the eye that living beings see visible objects. As the eye

original: viññāṇādhiṭṭhitaṃ samavisamaṃ ācikkhantaṃ viya pavattati, na tathā idaṃ. Idaṃ pana🔽sayameva tato sātisayaṃ cakkhukiccakārīti āha “cakkhukiccakaraṇena cakkhumivātipi
analyzed: viññāṇa adhiṭṭhitam sama visamam ācikkhantam viya pavattati na tathā idam idam pana  sayam eva tatas sa atisayam cakkhu kicca kārī iti āha cakkhu kicca karaṇena
translated: does, so this does not occur as if it were announcing what is equal and unequal by being occupied with consciousness. But this🔽does its own function of seeing in a way that surpasses the eye. That is why he said, “It is called the divine eye because it does the eye’s function.”

original: cakkhū”ti. Diṭṭhivisuddhihetuttāti saṅkhepato vuttamatthaṃ vivarituṃ “yo hī”tiādi
analyzed: cakkhu iti diṭṭhi visuddhi hetu ttā ti saṅkhepataḥ vuttam attham vivaritum yaḥ hi itiādi
translated: As the cause of purification of view: in order to explain the meaning stated briefly he said, “For one who has the divine eye,” etc.

original: vuttaṃ. Ucchedadiṭṭhiṃ gaṇhātīti parato uppattiyā adassanato “etthe vāyaṃ satto ucchinno,
analyzed: vuttam uccheda diṭṭhim gaṇhāti iti paratas uppattiyāḥ adassanataḥ vā ayam satto ucchinno
translated: Because he does not see arising from another, he thinks: “Here this being is annihilated.🔽So it is with the others too.” Thus he takes up the annihilation view.

original: evamitarepī”ti ucchedadiṭṭhiṃ gaṇhāti. Navasattapātubhāvadiṭṭhiṃ gaṇhātīti jhānalābhī
analyzed: evam itare pi iti uccheda diṭṭhim gaṇhāti nava satta pātubhāva diṭṭhim gaṇhāti iti jhāna lābhī
translated: He takes up the view that nine kinds of beings become manifest.

original: adhiccasamuppanniko viya gaṇhāti. Yathā hi so asaññasattā cavitvā idhūpapanno pabbajito
analyzed: adhiccasamuppannikaḥ viya gaṇhāti yathā hi so asaññasattā cavitvā idhūpapannaḥ pabbajito
translated: He takes it up as though he were a chance-born being. For just as the chance-born being, having died in the non-percipient realm and been reborn here,

original: samāno abhiññālābhī hutvā pubbenivāsaṃ anussaranto idhūpapattimeva disvā tato paraṃ
analyzed: samānaḥ abhiññā lābhī hutvā pubbenivāsam anussarantaḥ idhu upapattim eva disvā tatas param
translated: having gone forth and obtained the jhānas, having attained the direct knowledges, recollects his previous existence here only,🔽and being unable to recollect his arising in the non-percipient realm after that, thinks: “I was not; now I am.

original: asaññabhave uppattiṃ anussaritumasakkonto “ahaṃ adhiccasamuppanno pubbe nāhosiṃ,🔽somhi etarahi ahutvā sattatāya pariṇato, sesāpi sattā tādisāyevā”ti abhinavasattapātubhāvadiṭṭhiṃ
analyzed: asañña bhave uppattim anussaritum a sakkontaḥ aham adhicca samuppannaḥ pubbe na ahosiṃ  etarahi a hutvā sattatāya pariṇataḥ sesā api sattā tādisāya iva ati abhinava satta pātubhāva diṭṭhim
translated: I have become from what was not. I have arisen without a cause,” and he takes up the view that a new being becomes manifest,

original: gaṇhāti, evamayampi upapātamattameva disvā cutiṃ apassanto navasattapātubhāvadiṭṭhiṃ gaṇhāti.
analyzed: gaṇhāti evam ayam pi upapāta mattam eva disvā cutim a passantaḥ nava satta pātubhāva diṭṭhim gaṇhāti
translated: so too this meditator, seeing only the descent into the womb and not the death there, takes up the view that a new being becomes manifest.

original: Idāni aññathāpi visuddhikāraṇaṃ dassento āha “ekādasaupakkilesavirahato vā”tiādi.
analyzed: idāni aññathā api visuddhi kāraṇam dassentaḥ āha ekādasa upakkilesa virahataḥ vā ati ādi
translated: Now, showing a cause for purification in another way, he said, “Or else, because of the absence of the eleven corruptions,” and so on.

original: Yathāhāti upakkilesasutte āgatapāḷiṃ nidasseti. Tattha hi anuruddho nandiyo kimiloti
analyzed: yathā āha iti upakkilesa sutte āgata pāḷim nidasseti tattha hi anuruddhaḥ nandiyaḥ kimilo ti
translated: “As follows”: he illustrates the passage in the Upakkilesa Sutta. For there, after addressing the three clansmen Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila,

original: ime tayo kulaputte āmantetvā dhammaṃ dassentena “anuruddhā tumhe kiṃ imehi na āluḷissanti,
analyzed: ime tayo kula putte āmantetvā dhammaṃ dassentena anuruddhā tumhe kim imehi naḥ āluḷissanti
translated: the Exalted One, teaching the Dhamma, said: “Anuruddha, why are you not repelled by these?

original: ahampi imehi upādāya ekādasahi upakkilesehi āluḷitapubbo”ti dassetuṃ –🔽“Ahampi sudaṃ anuruddhā pubbeva sambodhā anabhisambuddho bodhisattova samāno obhāsañceva
analyzed: aham pi imehi upādāya ekādasahi upakkilesehi āluḷita pubbaḥ ti dassetum  aham pi sudam anuruddhā pubbā iva sambodhā an abhisambuddhaḥ bodhisatto iva samānaḥ obhāsañca iva
translated: Even I, before my enlightenment, while I was still only an unenlightened Bodhisatta, was repelled by these eleven corruptions.”

original: sañjānāmi dassanañca rūpānaṃ, so kho pana me obhāso na cirasseva antaradhāyati dassanañca🔽rūpānaṃ. Tassa mayhaṃ anuruddhā etadahosi ‘ko nu kho hetu, ko paccayo, yena me obhāso
analyzed: sañjānāmi dassanam ca rūpānam saḥ kho pana me obhāsaḥ na cirassa iva antaradhāyati dassanam ca  rūpānam tassa mayham anuruddhāḥ etat ahosi kaḥ nu kho hetu kaḥ paccayaḥ yena me obhāsaḥ
translated: “Anuruddha, I too, before my enlightenment, while I was still only an unenlightened Bodhisatta, perceived light and saw forms. But that light and that vision of forms disappeared too soon.🔽Anuruddha, I thought: ‘What is the cause and condition why the light and the vision of forms disappeared? ‘

original: antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpāna’nti. Tassa mayhaṃ anuruddhā etadahosi ‘vicikicchā
analyzed: antaradhāyati dassanam ca tassa mayham anuruddhā vicikicchā
translated: Anuruddha, I thought: ‘Doubt and confusion were in me.

original: kho me udapādi, vicikicchādhikaraṇañca me samādhi cavi, samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati
analyzed: kho me udapādi vicikicchā adhikaraṇam ca me samādhi samādhimhi cute obhāsaḥ antaradhāyati
translated: and because of that doubt, my concentration fell apart. When my concentration fell apart, my light disappeared.

original: dassanañca rūpānaṃ, sohaṃ tathā karissāmi, yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissatī’ti.
analyzed: dassanam ca rūpānam saḥ uham tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati iti
translated: and I saw forms. I thought, ‘I’ll do whatever it takes to prevent doubt from arising in me again.’

original: “So kho ahaṃ anuruddhā appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto obhāsañceva sañjānāmi
analyzed: saḥ kho aham anuruddhā appamattaḥ ātāpī pahitattaḥ viharantaḥ obhāsam ca iva sañjānāmi
translated: “So, Anuruddha, I stayed determined, ardent, and resolute. I was mindful of the light

original: dassanañca rūpānaṃ, so kho pana me obhāso na cirasseva antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṃ.
analyzed: dassanam ca rūpānam saḥ kho pana me obhāsaḥ na cirassa iva antaradhāyati dassanam ca rūpānam
translated: and I saw forms. But that light disappeared after a short while.

original: Tassa mayhaṃ anuruddhā etadahosi ‘ko nu kho hetu, ko paccayo, yena me obhāso antaradhāyati
analyzed: tassa mayham anuruddhā etat ahosi kaḥ nu kho hetu kaḥ paccayaḥ yena me obhāsaḥ antaradhāyati
translated: I thought, ‘What is the cause, what is the reason, why my light disappeared

original: dassanañca rūpāna’nti. Tassa mayhaṃ anuruddhā etadahosi ‘amanasikāro kho me udapādi,
analyzed: dassanam ca rūpānanti tassa mayham anuruddhā etat ahosi amanasikāraḥ kho me udapādi
translated: and I no longer saw forms?’ I thought, ‘Inattention arose in me,

original: amanasikārādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi, samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati
analyzed: a manasikāra adhikaraṇam ca pana me samādhi samādhimhi cute obhāsaḥ antaradhāyati
translated: and because of that inattention, my concentration fell apart. When my concentration fell apart, my light disappeared.

original: dassanañca rūpānaṃ, sohaṃ tathā karissāmi, yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati
analyzed: dassanam ca rūpānam saḥ uham tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati
translated: and I no longer saw forms. I thought, ‘I’ll do whatever it takes to prevent doubt from arising in me again.’

original: na amanasikāro”’ti –
analyzed: na a manasikāroti
translated: ‘Non-attention’ is the non-attention to the sign of the object.”

original: Ādinā desanaṃ ārabhitvā idaṃ vuttaṃ “so kho ahaṃ anuruddhā vicikicchā cittassa upakkilesoti iti viditvā”tiādi.🔽Tattha vicikicchāti mahāsattassa ālokaṃ vaḍḍhetvā dibbacakkhunā nānāvidhāni rūpāni🔽passantassa “idaṃ nu kho ki”nti uppannā vicikicchā. Manasikāravasena pana me rūpāni🔽upaṭṭhahiṃsu, rūpāni passato vicikicchā uppajjati, tasmā idāni kiñci na manasi karissāmīti🔽tuṇhī bhavati, taṃ tuṇhībhāvappattiṃ sandhāyāha “amanasikāro”ti. Thinamiddhanti kiñci
analyzed: ādinā desanam ārabhitvā idam vuttam saḥ kho aham anuruddhā vicikicchā cittassa upakkileso ti iti viditvā atiādi  tattha vicikicchāti mahāsattassa ālokam vaḍḍhetvā dibba cakkhunā nānāvidhāni rūpāni  passantassa idam nu kho kinti uppannā vicikicchā manasikāra vasena pana me rūpāni  upaṭṭhahiṃsu rūpāni passataḥ vicikicchā uppajjati tasmai idāni kiñci na manasi karissāmi iti  tuṇhī bhavati tam tuṇhībhāva ppattim sandhāya āha amanasikāro ti kiñci
translated: This is said with reference to the teaching beginning with the words: “Then, Anuruddha, I considered thus: ‘Doubt is an imperfection of the mind.’ ”

original: amanasikarontassa uppannaṃ thinamiddhaṃ. Tathābhūtassa hi savipphārikamanasikārassa🔽abhāvato thinamiddhaṃ uppajjati. Chambhitattanti thinamiddhaṃ vinodetvā yathāraddhamanasikāravasena
analyzed: a manasikarontassa uppannam thinam iddham tathābhūtassa hi sa vipphārika manasikārassa 🔽abhāvataḥ thinam iddham uppajjati thinam iddham vinodetvā yathā āraddha manasikāra vasena
translated: Herein, doubt is the doubt that arises in the Great Being when he is developing the divine eye and sees various forms, wondering, “What is this?” Attention is the attention to forms that arises in him when he sees forms, and doubt arises in him. Therefore he thinks, “I shall pay no attention to anything,” and he becomes silent. The attainment of this silence is what is meant by “non-attention.” Lethargy-and-drowsiness is lethargy-and-drowsiness that arises in him when he pays no attention to anything. For when he has no attention that is directed outward, lethargy-and-drowsiness arises in him. Agitation-and-worry is agitation-and-worry that arises in him when he dispels lethargy-and-drowsiness and attends to the object as it was defined.

original: himavantābhimukhaṃ ālokaṃ vaḍḍhetvā dānavarakkhasaajagarādayo passantassa uppannaṃ
analyzed: himavanta abhimukham ālokam vaḍḍhetvā dānava rakkhasa ajagara ādayo passantassa uppannam
translated: He sees the light extending to the Himalayas and is frightened.

original: chambhitattaṃ. Uppilanti “mayā diṭṭhabhayaṃ pakatiyā cakkhuviññāṇena olokiyamānaṃ
analyzed: chambhi tattam uppilanti mayā diṭṭha bhayam pakatiyā cakkhu viññāṇena olokiyamānam
translated: He thinks: “The danger I saw was looked at with the eye-consciousness in its normal state.

original: na passati, adiṭṭhe parikappitasadise kiṃnāma bhaya”nti bhayassa vinodanavasena cintentassa
analyzed: na passati adiṭṭhe parikappita sadise kiṃnāma bhayanti bhayassa vinodana vasena cintentassa
translated: I do not see it now that I have looked at it with the supernormal power of the eye. What is this danger that I have imagined about what I have not seen?”

original: attano paccavekkhaṇākosallaṃ nissāya uppannaṃ uppilāvitattaṃ. Duṭṭhullanti kāyālasiyaṃ.
analyzed: attanaḥ paccavekkhaṇa ākosallam nissāya uppannam uppilā vitattam duṭṭhullanti kāya alasiyam
translated: He becomes excited through his own reflection, through his skill in dispelling fear.

original: “Mayā thinamiddhaṃ chambhitattānaṃ vūpasamanatthaṃ gāḷhaṃ vīriyaṃ paggahitaṃ, tena
analyzed: mayā thinam iddham chambhita ttānam vūpasamanattham gāḷham vīriyam paggahitam tena
translated: “I have aroused strong energy in order to dispel drowsiness and sleepiness and fear.

original: me uppilasaṅkhātā cittasamādhidūsitā gehassitā balavapīti uppannā”ti vīriyaṃ sithilaṃ
analyzed: me uppila saṅkhātā citta samādhi dūsitā gehassitā uppannā ati vīriyam sithilam
translated: As a result, I have become excited, and my concentration of mind has been disturbed. I have become over-energetic.”

original: karontassa hi kāyaduṭṭhullaṃ kāyadaratho kāyālasiyaṃ udapādi.
analyzed: karontassa hi kāya duṭṭhullam kāya daratho kāya alasiyam udapādi
translated: He slackens his energy.

original: Accāraddhavīriyanti “mama vīriyaṃ sithilaṃ karoto duṭṭhullaṃ uppanna”nti puna vīriyaṃ
analyzed: accā āraddha vīriyanti mama vīriyam sithilam karotaḥ duṭṭhullam uppannanti puna vīriyaṃ
translated: “I have become over-energetic,” he again arouses energy.

original: paggaṇhato uppannaṃ accāraddhavīriyaṃ. Atilīnavīriyanti “mama vīriyaṃ paggaṇhato🔽evaṃ jāta”nti puna vīriyaṃ sithilayato uppannaṃ atilīnavīriyaṃ. Abhijappāti devalokābhimukhaṃ
analyzed: paggaṇhataḥ uppannam acca āraddha vīriyam ati līna vīriyanti mama vīriyam paggaṇhataḥ  evam puna vīriyam sithilayataḥ uppannam ati līna vīriyam deva loka abhimukham
translated: Exertion that is over-exerted is that arisen in one who exerts himself thus: “My exertion is born in this way.”🔽Exertion that is under-exerted is that arisen in one who, having exerted himself, slackens his exertion again, thinking, “My exertion is born in this way.”

original: ālokaṃ vaḍḍhetvā devasaṅghaṃ passato uppannā taṇhā. “Evaṃ me hotū”ti hi abhinivisanavasena
analyzed: ālokam vaḍḍhetvā deva saṅgham passataḥ uppannā taṇhā evam me hotu iti hi abhinivisana vasena
translated: Longing is craving arisen in one who extends his consciousness, turning it towards the world of the gods, and sees a company of gods.

original: jappatīti abhijappā, taṇhā. Nānattasaññāti “mayhaṃ ekajātikaṃ rūpaṃ manasikarontassa🔽abhijappā uppannā, nānāvidhaṃ rūpaṃ manasikāraṃ karissāmī”ti kālena devalokābhimukhaṃ🔽kālena manussalokābhimukhaṃ vaḍḍhetvā nānāvidhāni rūpāni manasikaroto uppannā nānattasaññā,🔽nānatte nānāsabhāve saññāti nānattasaññā. Atinijjhāyitattanti “mayhaṃ nānāvidhāni
analyzed: jappati iti abhijappā taṇhā nānatta saññā ati mayham eka jātikam rūpam manasikarontassa  abhijappāḥ uppannāḥ nānāvidham rūpam manasikāram karissāmi iti kālena deva loka abhimukham  kālena manussa loka abhimukham vaḍḍhetvā nānāvidhāni rūpāni manasikarotaḥ uppannā nānatta saññā  nānatte nānā sabhāve saññā ati nānatta saññā mayham nānāvidhāni
translated: For he longs, that is, resolves, thus: “May I be like that.”🔽Perception of variety is that arisen in one who extends his consciousness, turning it towards the world of the gods at one time and towards the world of men at another, and perceives various kinds of visible objects, thinking: “Perception of variety is perception of the manifold, of the various, of the several kinds.”

original: rūpāni manasikarontassa nānattasaññā udapādi, iṭṭhaṃ vā aniṭṭhaṃ vā ekajātikameva
analyzed: rūpāni manasikarontassa nānatta saññā udapādi iṭṭham vā aniṭṭham vā eka jātikam eva
translated: Over-focusing is that arisen in one who, perceiving the various kinds of visible objects, thinks: “Perception of variety has arisen in me; I shall focus my mind on a single kind of visible object, either what is wished for or what is not wished for.”

original: rūpaṃ manasi karissāmī”ti tathā manasikaroto uppannaṃ rūpānaṃ atinijjhāyitattaṃ,
analyzed: rūpam manasi karissāmi iti tathā manasikarotaḥ uppannam rūpānam ati nijjhāyi tattam
translated: “I shall attend to visible forms” and so on, the over-looking of visible forms that arises in him is

original: ativiya uttari katvā nijjhānaṃ pekkhanaṃ atinijjhāyitattaṃ. Obhāsanti parikammasamuṭṭhitaṃ🔽obhāsaṃ. Na ca rūpāni passāmīti parikammobhāsamanasikārappasutatāya dibbacakkhunā🔽rūpāni na passāmi. Rūpāni hi kho passāmīti tena parikammobhāsena pharitvā ṭhitaṭṭhāne
analyzed: ativiya uttari katvā nijjhānam pekkhanam ati nijjhāyi tattam obhāsanti parikamma samuṭṭhitam  obhāsam na ca rūpāni passāmi iti parikamma ubhāsa manasikāra ppasuta tāya dibba cakkhunā  rūpāni na passāmi rūpāni hi kho passāmi iti tena parikamma ubhāsena pharitvā ṭhita ṭṭhāne
translated: the over-looking of visible forms by looking at them with excessive attention. The light is the light arisen from the preliminary-work-concentration.🔽I do not see visible forms is that he does not see visible forms with the divine eye because of his being intent on the over-looking of visible forms by the light of the preliminary-work-concentration.

original: dibbacakkhuno visayabhūtāni rūpagatāni passāmi.
analyzed: dibba cakkhuno visaya bhūtāni rūpa gatāni passāmi
translated: I see visible forms is that he sees visible forms that are objects of the divine eye in the place where they are established by the light of the preliminary-work-concentration.

original: Evamādīti ādi-saddena –
analyzed: evamādi iti ādi saddena
translated: “And so on” is said with reference to the following:

original: “Kevalampi rattiṃ kevalampi divaṃ kevalampi rattindivaṃ tassa mayhaṃ anuruddhā etadahosi
analyzed: kevalam pi rattim kevalam pi divam kevalam pi rattiṃdivam tassa mayham anuruddhā etat ahosi
translated: “Throughout the whole night, throughout the whole day, throughout the whole twenty-four hours, this occurred to me:

original: ‘ko nu kho hetu, ko paccayo, yvāhaṃ obhāsañhi kho sañjānāmi, na ca rūpāni passāmi,
analyzed: kaḥ nu kho hetu kaḥ paccayaḥ yvā aham obhāsan hi kho sañjānāmi na ca rūpāni passāmi
translated: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason, why I perceive light but do not see visible forms,

original: rūpāni kho passāmi, na ca obhāsaṃ sañjānāmi kevalampi rattiṃ kevalampi divaṃ kevalampi
analyzed: rūpāni kho passāmi na ca obhāsam sañjānāmi kevalam pi rattim kevalam pi divam kevalam pi
translated: why I see visible forms but do not perceive light throughout the whole night, throughout the whole day, throughout the whole

original: rattindiva’nti. Tassa mayhaṃ anuruddhā etadahosi ‘yasmiñhi kho ahaṃ samaye rūpanimittaṃ
analyzed: tassa mayham anuruddhāḥ yasmin hi kho aham samaye rūpa nimittam
translated: ‘day and night.’ Then this occurred to me: ‘On the occasion when I, not giving attention to the sign of visible forms,

original: amanasikaritvā obhāsanimittaṃ manasi karomi. Obhāsañhi kho tasmiṃ samaye sañjānāmi,
analyzed: a manasikaritvā obhāsa nimittam manasi karomi obhāsan hi khalu tasmin samaye sañjānāmi
translated: give attention to the sign of light, on that occasion I am aware of light,

original: na ca rūpāni passāmi. Yasmiṃ panāhaṃ samaye obhāsanimittaṃ amanasikaritvā rūpanimittaṃ
analyzed: na ca rūpāni passāmi yasmin pana aham samaye obhāsa nimittam a manasikaritvā rūpa nimittam
translated: but I do not see visible forms. On the occasion when I, not giving attention to the sign of light,

original: manasi karomi. Rūpāni hi kho tasmiṃ samaye passāmi, na ca obhāsaṃ sañjānāmi kevalampi
analyzed: manasi karomi rūpāni hi kho tasmin samaye passāmi na ca obhāsam sañjānāmi kevalam pi
translated: give attention to the sign of visible forms, on that occasion I see visible forms, but I am not aware of light.

original: rattiṃ kevalampi divaṃ kevalampi rattindiva”nti –
analyzed: rattim kevalam pi divam kevalam pi
translated: Only night, only day, only night and day.’

original: Evamādipāḷiṃ saṅgaṇhāti.🔽Manussānaṃ idanti mānusakaṃ, manussānaṃ gocarabhūtaṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ. Tadaññassa pana🔽dibbatirokuṭṭasukhumādibhedassa rūpassa dassanato atikkantamānusakaṃ. Evarūpaṃ tañca
analyzed: evamādi pāḷim saṅgaṇhāti  manussānam idam ti mānusakam manussānam gocara bhūtam rūpa ārammaṇam tad aññassa pana  dibba tirokuṭṭa sukhuma ādi bhedassa rūpassa dassanataḥ atikkanta mānusakam evarūpam tat ca
translated: He includes the text beginning with this.🔽‘Human’: that which is human is human-related; the visible-form object that is the domain of human beings. But because of the seeing of visible form of the kinds beginning with ‘divine’, ‘of the Brahmās’, ‘subtle’, ‘of the past’, ‘of the future’, it is ‘beyond the human’. Such as this is called ‘beyond the human range’.

original: manussūpacāraṃ atikkantaṃ nāma hotīti āha “manussūpacāraṃ atikkamitvā rūpadassanenā”ti.
analyzed: manussu upacāram atikkantam nāma hoti iti āha manussu upacāram atikkamitvā rūpa dassanena ati
translated: ‘Having surpassed the human range’: by the seeing of visible forms.

original: Tattha manussūpacāranti manussehi upacaritabbaṭṭhānaṃ, pakatiyā cakkhudvārena gahetabbaṃ
analyzed: tattha manussa upacāram ti manussehi upacaritabba ṭṭhānam pakatiyā cakkhu dvārena gahetabbam
translated: Herein, the meaning is that the place frequented by human beings is the objective field to be taken in by the eye faculty by its own nature.

original: visayanti adhippāyo. Evaṃ visayamukhena dassetvā idāni visayimukhena dassetuṃ “mānusakaṃ
analyzed: visayanti adhippāyaḥ evam visaya mukhena dassetvā idāni visayi mukhena dassetum mānusakam
translated: Having thus shown the objective field, he now said “divine” in order to show the objective field by way of the divine eye.

original: vā”tiādi vuttaṃ. Tatthāpi maṃsacakkhātikkamo tassa kiccātikkameneva daṭṭhabbo. Dibbena
analyzed: vā ti ādi vuttam tattha api maṃsa cakkha atikkamo tassa kicca atikkamena iva daṭṭhabbaḥ dibbena
translated: Herein, the transcendence of the fleshly eye should be seen as the transcendence of its function.

original: cakkhunāti dibbacakkhuñāṇenapi daṭṭhuṃ na sakkā khaṇassa atiittaratāya atisukhumatāya
analyzed: cakkhunā ati dibba cakkhu ñāṇena api daṭṭhum na sakkā khaṇassa ati ittara tāya ati sukhuma tāya
translated: “By the divine eye”: it is not possible to see by the divine eye knowledge, because of the extreme swiftness and extreme subtlety of the moment of death of some beings.

original: kesañci rūpassa, apica dibbacakkhussa paccuppannaṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ, tañca purejātapaccayabhūtaṃ,
analyzed: rūpassa api ca dibba cakkhussa paccuppannam rūpa ārammaṇam tat ca purejāta paccaya bhūtam
translated: Moreover, the object of the divine eye is present form, and that is a prenascent condition,

original: na ca āvajjanaparikammehi vinā mahaggatassa pavatti atthi, nāpi uppajjamānameva rūpaṃ
analyzed: na ca āvajjana parikammehi vinā mahaggatassa pavatti atthi na api uppajjamānam eva rūpam
translated: and there is no occurrence of the exalted state without the preliminary work of adverting,

original: ārammaṇapaccayo bhavituṃ sakkoti, bhijjamānaṃ vā, tasmā cutūpapātakkhaṇe rūpaṃ dibbacakkhunā
analyzed: ārammaṇa paccayaḥ bhavitum sakkoti bhijjamānam vā tasmā cutūpapāta khaṇe rūpam dibba cakkhunā
translated: nor can the form that is arising be a condition by way of object, nor that which is dissolving. Therefore the form at the moment of death and rebirth

original: daṭṭhuṃ na sakkāti suvuttametaṃ.
analyzed: daṭṭhum na sakkā ati su vuttam etam
translated: cannot be seen by the divine eye. Thus this is well said.

original: Yadi dibbacakkhuñāṇaṃ rūpārammaṇameva, atha kasmā “satte passāmī”ti vuttanti? Yebhuyyena🔽sattasantānagatarūpadassanato evaṃ vuttaṃ. Sattagahaṇassa vā kāraṇabhāvato vohāravasena
analyzed: yadi dibba cakkhu ñāṇam rūpa ārammaṇam eva atha kasmā satte passāmi iti vuttan ti yebhuyyena  satta santāna gata rūpa dassanataḥ evam vuttam satta gahaṇassa vā kāraṇa bhāvataḥ vohāra vasena
translated: If the knowledge of the divine eye has only visible form as its object, then why is it said, “I see beings”?🔽Because it sees visible forms that are included in the life-continuum of beings, it is said so. Or, because the visible forms are the cause of the designation of beings, it is said so in terms of conventional usage.

original: vuttantipi vadanti. Te cavamānāti adhippetāti sambandho. Evarūpeti na cutūpapātakkhaṇasamaṅginoti
analyzed: vuttam ti pi vadanti te cavamānā ati adhippetā ati sambandhaḥ evarūpā iti na cutūpapāta khaṇa samaṅginaḥ ti
translated: The meaning of the sentence is this: “I see beings passing away and being reborn.” The intended meaning of the phrase “such beings” is not those who are endowed with the state of death and rebirth.

original: adhippāyo. Mohūpanissayaṃ nāma kammaṃ nihīnaṃ nihīnaphalaṃ hotīti āha “mohanissandayuttattā”ti.🔽Mohūpanissayatā ca kusalakammassa pubbabhāge mohappavattibahulatāya veditabbā. Tāya
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ moha upanissayam nāma kammam nihīnam nihīna phalam hoti iti āha moha nissanda yutta ttā ti  moha upanissaya tā ca kusala kammassa pubba bhāge moha ppavatti bahula tāya veditabbā tāya
translated: It is said that kamma that is a condition for delusion has a low fruit. Therefore, it is said, “because of being associated with the result of delusion.”🔽The state of being a condition for delusion should be understood as the abundance of the occurrence of delusion in the prior stage of wholesome kamma.

original: pana mohappavattiyā saṃkiliṭṭhaṃ kusalakammaṃ nihīnameva jātiādiṃ nipphādetīti nihīnajātiādayo
analyzed: pana moha ppavattiyā saṃkiliṭṭham kusala kammam nihīnam eva jāti ādim nipphādeti iti nihīna jāti ādayaḥ
translated: Because of that occurrence of delusion, wholesome kamma that is defiled produces only a low rebirth, etc. Therefore, low rebirth, etc.,

original: mohassa nissandaphalānīti āha “hīnānaṃ jātikulabhogādīna”ntiādi. Hīḷiteti garahite.
analyzed: nissanda phalāni iti āha hīnānam jāti kula bhoga ādīnam tiādi gara hite
translated: are the result of the outcome of delusion. Therefore, it is said, “of low birth, low family, low wealth, etc.” Low means despised.

original: Ohīḷiteti visesato garahite. Uññāteti lāmakabhāvena ñāte. Avaññāteti visesato lāmakabhāvena🔽vidite. Amohanissandayuttattāti ettha amoho sampayuttavasena pubbabhāgavasena ca
analyzed: ohīḷitā iti visesataḥ gara hite uññātā iti lāmaka bhāvena ñāte avaññātā iti visesataḥ lāmaka bhāvena  vidite amoha nissanda yutta ttā ti ettha amohaḥ sampayutta vasena pubbabhāga vasena ca
translated: ‘Disparaged’ means especially despised. ‘Despised’ means known as contemptible. ‘Discredited’ means especially known as contemptible.

original: pavatto kathito, tena ca tihetukapaṭisandhike dasseti. Tabbiparīteti tassa hīḷitādibhāvassa
analyzed: pavattaḥ kathitaḥ tena ca ti hetuka paṭisandhike dasseti tad viparītā iti tassa hi iḷita ādi bhāvassa
translated: ‘Associated with the outcome of non-delusion’: here, non-delusion is stated as occurring by association and by being a prerequisite for the kamma, and by that he shows that it is associated with rebirth-linking of triple-rooted kamma. ‘The opposite of that’: the opposite of the states of being disparaged, etc.,

original: viparīte, ahīḷite anohīḷite anuññāte anavaññāte cittīkateti attho.
analyzed: viparīte a hīḷite anohīḷite anuññāte anavaññāte cittīkatā iti attho
translated: the meaning is, not disparaged, not despised, not despised, not discredited, esteemed.

original: Suvaṇṇeti sundaravaṇṇe. Dubbaṇṇeti asundaravaṇṇe. Sā panāyaṃ suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇatā yathākkamaṃ🔽kammassa adosadosūpanissayatāya hotīti āha “adosanissandayuttattā”tiādi. Adosūpanissayatā
analyzed: suvaṇṇā iti sundara vaṇṇe dubbaṇṇā iti asundara vaṇṇe sā pana ayam suvaṇṇa dubbaṇṇa tā yathākkamam  kammassa a dosa dosū panissaya tāya hoti iti āha a dosa nissanda yutta ttā atiādi a dosū panissaya tā
translated: ‘Beautiful’: of good appearance. ‘Ugly’: of bad appearance. But this beauty and ugliness are due respectively to the outcome of non-hate and to the outcome of hate in kamma,

original: ca kammassa mettādīhi paribhāvitasantānappavattiyā veditabbā. Abhirūpe virūpeti idaṃ
analyzed: ca kammassa metta ādīhi paribhāvita santāna pavattiyā veditabbā abhirūpe virūpe iti idam
translated: so he said ‘Associated with the outcome of non-hate,’ etc. And the outcome of non-hate should be understood as a prerequisite for kamma that occurs with a continuity imbued with loving-kindness, and so on. ‘Handsome’ and ‘ugly’ are said

original: saṇṭhānavasena vuttaṃ. Saṇṭhānavacanopi hi vaṇṇasaddo hoti “mahantaṃ hatthivaṇṇaṃ
analyzed: saṇṭhāna vasena vuttam saṇṭhāna vacanaḥ api hi vaṇṇa saddaḥ hoti mahantam hatthi vaṇṇam
translated: by way of shape. For the word ‘appearance’ is also used for shape: ‘a great appearance in the elephant troops’ ,

original: abhinimminitvā”tiādīsu viya. Paṭhamaṃ vutto pana attho vaṇṇavaseneva vutto. Sundaraṃ
analyzed: abhinimminitvā ati ādīsu viya paṭhamam vuttaḥ pana atthaḥ vaṇṇa vasena iva vuttaḥ sundaram
translated: and so on. But the meaning given first is the one in terms of colour.

original: gatiṃ gatā sugatāti āha “sugatigate”ti, sugatiṃ upapanneti attho. Alobhajjhāsayā🔽sattā vadaññū vigatamaccherā alobhūpanissayena kammunā sugatā samiddhā hontīti āha
analyzed: gatim gatā sugatā iti āha sugati gatā iti sugatim upapannā iti atthaḥ alobha jhāsayā  sattāḥ vadaññū vigata maccherāḥ a lobha upanissayena kammunā sugatāḥ samiddhāḥ honti iti āha
translated: They have gone to a good destination are called “gone to a good destination” . The meaning is that they have reappeared in a good destination.

original: “alobhanissandayuttattā vā aḍḍhe mahaddhane”ti. Dukkhaṃ gatiṃ gatā duggatāti āha🔽“duggatigate”ti. Lobhajjhāsayā sattā luddhā maccharino lobhūpanissayena kammunā duggatā
analyzed: alobha nissanda yutta ttā vai aḍḍhe mahat dhanā iti dukkham gatim gatā duggatā ati āha  duggati gatā iti lobha jjhāsayā sattāḥ luddhāḥ maccharinaḥ lobha upanissayena kammunā duggatā
translated: Beings who are disposed to non-greed are generous and free from avarice. By means of the kamma consisting in the support of non-greed they are well-off and prosperous. That is why he said “or in the rich, the very wealthy, because of the outcome of non-greed.”🔽They have gone to a bad destination are called “gone to a bad destination” .

original: durūpā hontīti āha “lobhanissandayuttattā vā dalidde appannapāne”ti. Upacitanti phalāvahabhāvena
analyzed: durūpāḥ honti iti āha lobha nissanda yutta ttā vā dalidde appanna pāne ti upacitanti phala āvaha bhāvena
translated: Beings who are disposed to greed are greedy and avaricious. By means of the kamma consisting in the support of greed they are ugly. That is why he said “or in the poor, the destitute, the needy, because of the outcome of greed.”

original: kataṃ. Yathā katañhi kammaṃ phaladānasamatthaṃ hoti, tathā kataṃ upacitaṃ. Cavamānetiādīhi
analyzed: katam yathā katam hi kammam phala dāna samattham hoti tathā katam upacitam cavamāna itiādīhi
translated: Accumulated is that done in such a way that it is capable of giving an effect. For kamma done in the way beginning “As it is done so it is stored” is accumulated.🔽By “are dying” and so on he shows the meaning of the word “dying” .

original: dibbacakkhukiccaṃ vuttanti visayamukhena visayibyāpāramāha. Purimehīti “dibbena cakkhunā”tiādīni🔽padāni sandhāya vuttaṃ. Ādīhīti ettha ca-saddo luttaniddiṭṭho, tasmā “dibbena…pe…
analyzed: dibba cakkhu kiccam vuttanti visaya mukhena visayi byāpāram āha purimehi iti dibbena cakkhunā atiādīni  padāni sandhāya vuttam ādīhi iti ettha ca saddaḥ lutta niddiṭṭhaḥ tasmā
translated: The function of the divine eye is stated by way of the object, and so he says “the range of the divine eye.”🔽The words “the divine eye” and so on are referred to by the words “the former.”🔽The word “and so on” is a demonstrative pronoun, and so he says “the divine eye” and so on.

original: passāmī”ti imehi “cavamāne”tiādīhi ca dibbacakkhukiccaṃ vuttanti attho. Iminā pana
analyzed: passāmi iti imehi cavamāna iti ādīhi ca dibba cakkhu kiccam vuttanti atthaḥ iminā pana
translated: The function of the divine eye is stated by way of the object, that is, by way of the objective field. The former, etc.: this is said referring to the words “With the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human,” etc. The latter, etc.: the word “and” in the latter, etc., is a demonstrative pronoun. Therefore the meaning is: the function of the divine eye is stated by the words “With the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, I see beings passing away and arising” and by the words “I understand that beings pass away according to their actions.”

original: padenāti “yathākammūpage satte pajānāmī”ti iminā vākyena. Pajjati ñāyati attho imināti hi padaṃ vākyaṃ.🔽Mahantaṃ dukkhamanubhavamāneti ettha dibbacakkhuñāṇena rūpaṃ disvā tesaṃ dukkhānubhavanaṃ
analyzed: padena ati yathā kammūpage satte pajānāmi iti iminā vākyena pajjati ñāyati atthaḥ iminā ati hi padam vākyam  mahantam dukkham anubhavamānā iti ettha dibba cakkhu ñāṇena rūpam disvā tesam dukkha anubhavanaṃ
translated: By this expression, etc.: by this sentence, “I understand that beings pass away according to their actions.” For the word “expression” means a sentence.

original: kāmāvacaracitteneva jānātīti veditabbaṃ. Soti nerayikasatte paccakkhato disvā ṭhito
analyzed: kāmāvacara cittena iva jānāti iti veditabbam saḥ ti nerayika satte paccakkhatas disvā ṭhitaḥ
translated: Experiencing great suffering: it should be understood that having seen the visible form by means of the knowledge of the divine eye, he knows their experience of suffering by means of the mind of the sense sphere. He: the one who has attained the knowledge of the divine eye, who is standing there having seen the beings in hell directly.

original: dibbacakkhuñāṇalābhī. Evaṃ manasi karotīti tesaṃ nerayikānaṃ nirayasaṃvattanikassa
analyzed: dibba cakkhu ñāṇa lābhī evam manasi karoti iti tesam nerayikānam niraya saṃvattanikassa
translated: Thus he directs his mind: he directs his mind thus to the hell-beings’ kamma that leads to hell.

original: kammassa ñātukāmatāvasena pādakajjhānaṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya parikammavasena manasi🔽karoti. Kiṃ nu khotiādi manasikāravidhidassanaṃ. Evaṃ pana parikammaṃ katvā pādakajjhānaṃ🔽samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhitassa taṃ kammaṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā āvajjanaṃ uppajjati, tasmiṃ niruddhe🔽cattāri pañca vā javanāni javanti. Yesaṃ purimāni tīṇi cattāri vā parikammaupacārānulomagotrabhunāmakāni🔽kāmāvacarāni, catutthaṃ pañcamaṃ vā appanācittaṃ rūpāvacaraṃ catutthajjhānikaṃ, tattha
analyzed: kammassa ñātu kāma tā vasena pādaka jhānam samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya parikamma vasena manasi  karoti kim nu kha itiādi manasikāra vidhi dassanam evam pana parikammam katvā pādakajjhānam  samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhitassa tam kammaṃ ārammaṇam katvā āvajjanam uppajjati tasmin niruddhe  cattāri pañca vā javanāni javanti yesam purimāni tīṇi cattāri vā  kāmāvacarāni catuttham pañcamam vā appanā cittam rūpāvacaram catuttha jhānikam tattha
translated: He attains jhāna by means of desire to know the kamma as object. When he has emerged he does the preliminary work by giving attention as “What now? What now?” This is the way he gives attention to the preliminary work. But when he has done the preliminary work in this way and has emerged from the jhāna, the adverting that has the kamma as object occurs to him. When that has ceased,🔽impulsion impels on that object four or five times. Of these, the first three or four are called preliminary-work impulsion, access impulsion, conformity impulsion, and change-of-lineage impulsion.🔽They are of the sense sphere. The fourth or the fifth is absorption impulsion. It is of the fine-material sphere and belongs to the fourth jhāna.

original: yaṃ tena appanācittena saddhiṃ uppannaṃ ñāṇaṃ, taṃ yathākammūpagañāṇanti veditabbaṃ.🔽“Visuṃ parikammaṃ natthī”ti idaṃ pana dibbacakkhuñāṇena vinā yathākammūpagañāṇassa
analyzed: yam tena appanā cittena saddhim uppannam ñāṇam tam yathā kammūpaga ñāṇam ti veditabbam 🔽visum parikammam natthi iti idam pana dibba cakkhu ñāṇena vinā yathākammūpaga ñāṇassa
translated: He attains jhāna as basis for direct-knowledge by surmounting the perception of the world’s permanence, and he emerges from it. Then he does the preliminary work by surmounting the perception of the world’s permanence and by perceiving it as impermanent, and so on. The words “What is this? ” and so on are the directions for doing the preliminary work. But after doing the preliminary work in this way, when he has emerged from the fourth jhāna, which is the basis for direct-knowledge, and has given attention to the kamma and its result as impermanent, etc., then the adverting that has that kamma and its result as object occurs next to the emergence from the fourth jhāna. After that, four or five impulsions impel with that kamma and its result as object. Of these, the first three or four are called preliminary- work, access, conformity, and change-of-lineage, respectively. They are of the sense sphere, and they have the characteristic of impulsion. But the fourth or the fifth is the absorption consciousness belonging to the fourth jhāna and is of the fine-material sphere. Herein, the knowledge that arises together with that absorption consciousness should be understood as knowledge of faring on according to one’s deeds. “There is no preliminary work apart from that” means that there is no preliminary work for this knowledge of faring on according to one’s deeds apart from the preliminary work for the divine eye.

original: visuṃ parikammaṃ natthīti adhippāyena vuttaṃ. Evañcetaṃ icchitabbaṃ, aññathā yathākammūpagañāṇassa
analyzed: visum parikammam natthi iti adhippāyena vuttam evam ca itam icchitabbam aññathā yathā kamma upaga ñāṇassa
translated: The intention is that there is no separate preliminary work. If this is admitted, then the knowledge of faring according to deeds

original: mahaggatabhāvo eva na siyā. Devānaṃ dassanepi eseva nayo. Nerayikadevaggahaṇañcettha
analyzed: mahaggata bhāvaḥ eva na siyā devānam dassane pi esa iva nayaḥ nerayika deva ggahaṇam ca ittha
translated: would not even be great. The same method applies to the seeing of gods. But the mention of the gods and the denizens of hell here

original: nidassanamattaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ. Ākaṅkhamāno hi dibbacakkhulābhī aññagatikesupi evaṃ paṭipajjatiyeva.
analyzed: nidassana mattam daṭṭhabbam ākaṅkhamānaḥ hi dibba cakkhu lābhī aññagatikesu pi evam paṭipajjatiyā iva
translated: should be regarded as an illustration only. For one who has obtained the divine eye and who wishes to do so can proceed in this way even with other kinds of destiny.

original: Tathā hi vakkhati “apāyaggahaṇena tiracchānayoniṃ dīpetī”tiādi, “sugatiggahaṇena
analyzed: tathā hi vakkhati apāya ggahaṇena tiracchānayonim dīpeti itiādi sugati ggahaṇena
translated: For it is said, “By the mention of the states of loss he illustrates the animal generation” , and “By the mention of the happy destinies he includes the human destiny” .

original: manussagatipi saṅgayhatī”ti ca. Taṃ nirayasaṃvattaniyakammaṃ ārammaṇametassāti taṃkammārammaṇaṃ.
analyzed: ca tam niraya saṃvattaniya kammam ārammaṇam etassa ati tam kamma ārammaṇam
translated: That kamma that is the cause of hell is its object, thus it is “having that kamma as its object” .

original: Phārusakavanādīsūti ādi-saddena cittalatāvanādīnaṃ saṅgaho.
analyzed: phārusaka vana ādīsu iti ādi saddena citta latā vana ādīnam saṅgahaḥ
translated: “In the Phārusaka, Vanasava, and so on” . The word “and so on” includes the Cittalatā, Vanasava, and so on.

analyzed: yathā ca imassa ati yathā ca imassa yathā kammūpaga ñāṇassa visum parikammam na atthi evam
translated: As in the case of this knowledge of faring according to deeds,

Tatrāyamadhippāyo – yathā dibbacakkhulābhī nirayādiabhimukhaṃ ālokaṃ🔽vaḍḍhetvā nerayikādike satte disvā tehi pubbe āyūhitaṃ nirayasaṃvattaniyādikaṃ kammaṃ🔽tādisena samādānena tajjena ca manasikārena parikkhate citte yāthāvato jānāti, evaṃ
analyzed: anāgataṃsañāṇassa api iti visum parikamma abhāvañca nidasseti tattha kāraṇam āha dibba cakkhu pādakān eva  hi imāni iti tatra ayam adhippāyaḥ yathā dibba cakkhu lābhī niraya ādi abhimukham ālokam  vaḍḍhetvā nerayika ādike satte disvā tehi pubbe āyūhitam niraya saṃvattaniya ādikam kammaṃ  tādisena samādānena tajjena ca manasikārena parikkhate citte yāthāvataḥ jānāti evam
translated: and also of knowledge of the future, and he shows that there is no preliminary work in each case. Herein, he gives the reason thus: “for these are the bases for the divine eye” . Herein, the meaning is this: Just as one who has obtained the divine eye extends light in the direction of the hells, and seeing the beings in the hells, he knows in accordance with reality the kamma that those beings have previously stored up that ripens in the hells, by means of the attention and the thought-conception that are appropriate to that, so too, one who has obtained knowledge of the future extends light in the direction of the future, and seeing the beings in the future, he knows in accordance with reality the kamma that those beings have previously stored up that will ripen in the future, by means of the attention and the thought-conception that are appropriate to that.

original: yassa yassa sattassa samanantaraṃ anāgataṃ attabhāvaṃ ñātukāmo, taṃ taṃ odissa ālokaṃ🔽vaḍḍhetvā tena tena atīte etarahi vā āyūhitaṃ tassa nibbattakaṃ kammaṃ yathākammūpagañāṇena🔽disvā tena tena nibbattetabbaṃ anāgataṃ attabhāvaṃ ñātukāmo tādisena samādānena tajjena
analyzed: yassa yassa sattassa samanantaram anāgatam atta bhāvam ñātu kāmo tam tam odissaḥ ālokam 🔽vaḍḍhetvā tena tena atīte etarahi vā āyūhitam tassa nibbattakam kammam yathā kammūpaga ñāṇena 🔽disvā tena tena nibbattetabbam anāgatam atta bhāvam ñātu kāmo tādisena samādānena tajjena
translated: and also of the knowledge of the future, by showing that there is no preliminary work. Herein, he gives the reason thus: ‘for these are the requisites for the divine eye only’. Herein, the intention is this: Just as one who has obtained the divine eye extends light in the direction of the hells, and seeing beings in the hells, etc., knows by means of the attention and the thought-process that have that as their object, in accordance with the way in which the kamma that has produced the hell-state, etc., was performed, so too, when he wants to know the next existence of any being, he extends light in the direction of that being, and seeing by means of the knowledge of the way of the kamma that has produced that being’s present existence, the kamma that will produce his next existence, he wants to know the next existence that will come into being. He does so by means of the attention and the thought-process that have that as their object.

original: ca manasikārena parikkhate citte yāthāvato jānāti. Esa nayo tato paresupi attabhāvesu.
analyzed: ca manasikārena parikkhate citte yāthāvataḥ jānāti esa nayo tatas paresu pi atta bhāvesu
translated: and he knows them as they are by means of attention. The same method applies to the other kinds of being.

original: Etaṃ anāgataṃsañāṇaṃ nāma. Yasmā etaṃ dvayaṃ dibbacakkhuñāṇe sati eva sijjhati, nāsati.
analyzed: etam anāgataṃsañāṇam nāma yasmai etam dvayam dibba cakkhu ñāṇe sati eva sijjhati na asati
translated: This is called knowledge of the future. Since this pair comes about only when the divine eye is present, not when it is absent,

original: Tena vuttaṃ “imāni dibbacakkhunā saheva ijjhantī”ti.🔽Kāyena duccaritaṃ, kāyato vā uppannaṃ duccaritanti kāyena duṭṭhu caritaṃ, kāyato🔽vā uppannaṃ kilesapūtikattā duṭṭhu caritaṃ kāyaduccaritanti evaṃ yathākkamaṃ yojetabbaṃ.
analyzed: tena vuttam imāni dibba cakkhunā saha iva ijjhanti iti  kāyena duccaritam kāyataḥ vā uppannam duccaritanti kāyena duṭṭhu caritam kāyataḥ  vā uppannam kilesa pūtikattā duṭṭhu caritam kāya duccaritan ti evam yathākkamam yojetabbam
translated: it is said, “They succeed only with the divine eye.”🔽Misconduct by body: either misconduct that occurs by means of the body or misconduct that occurs as defilement in the body.🔽Misconduct by body: either misconduct that occurs by means of the body or misconduct that occurs as defilement in the body.

original: Kāyoti cettha copanakāyo adhippeto. Kāyaviññattivasena pavattaṃ akusalaṃ kāyakammaṃ
analyzed: kāyaḥ ti ca ittha copana kāyaḥ adhippetaḥ kāya viññatti vasena pavattam akusalam kāya kammam
translated: Herein, the “body” is the physical body. Unwholesome bodily action that occurs by way of bodily intimation🔽is misconduct by body.

original: kāyaduccaritaṃ. Yasmiṃ santāne kammaṃ katupacitaṃ, asati āhārupacchede vipākārahasabhāvassa
analyzed: kāya duccaritam yasmin santāne kammam kata upacitam asati āhāra upacchede
translated: Since the kamma that is done and stored up in a given continuity does not relinquish its nature of being a potential for resultant states even when there is no opportunity for its fruition,

original: avigacchanato so tena sahitoyevāti vattabboti āha “samannāgatāti samaṅgībhūtā”ti.
analyzed: a vigacchanataḥ saḥ tena sahitaḥ yā iva ati vattabbaḥ iti āha samannāgatā ati samaṅgībhūtā iti
translated: it should be said that the continuity is endowed with it.

original: Anatthakāmā hutvāti etena mātāpitaro viya puttānaṃ, ācariyupajjhāyā viya ca nissitakānaṃ🔽atthakāmā hutvā garahakā upavādakā na hontīti dasseti. Guṇaparidhaṃsanenāti vijjamānānaṃ
analyzed: anattha kāmāḥ hutvā ti etena mātā pitaraḥ viya puttānam ācariya upajjhāyāḥ viya ca nissitakānam  attha kāmāḥ hutvā garahakāḥ upavādakāḥ na honti iti dasseti guṇa paridhaṃsanena ati vijjamānānam
translated: By “being well-wishers” he shows that they are not fault-finders or slanderers like parents who are not well-wishers to their children or teachers and preceptors who are not well-wishers to their pupils.🔽By “by disparaging their special qualities” he shows that they are not fault-finders or slanderers like those who disparage, i.e., destroy, the special qualities of others that exist.

original: guṇānaṃ viddhaṃsanena, vināsanenāti attho. Nanu ca antimavatthunāpi upavādo guṇaparidhaṃsanamevāti?
analyzed: guṇānam viddhaṃsanena vināsanena ati atthaḥ nanu ca antima vatthunā api upavādaḥ guṇa paridhaṃsanam eva ati

analyzed: saccam etam pana ittha jhāna ādi visesāḥ uttari manussa dhammāḥ adhippetā ti sīla paridhaṃsanam
translated: That is true, but here the special qualities referred to are the supramundane states of jhāna, etc., while the special qualities of virtue are taken separately.🔽Hence it is said: “They say: ‘They have no higher state than this.’“

original: visuṃ gahitaṃ. Tenāha “natthi imesaṃ samaṇadhammo”tiādi. Samaṇadhammoti ca sīlasaṃyamaṃ🔽sandhāya vadati. Jānaṃ vāti yaṃ upavadati, tassa ariyabhāvaṃ jānanto vā. Ajānaṃ vāti
analyzed: visum gahitam tena āha natthi imesam samaṇa dhammo tiādi samaṇa dhammo ti ca sīla saṃyamam  sandhāya vadati jānam vāti yam upavadati tassa ariya bhāvam jānantaḥ vai a jānam vāti
translated: By “higher state” he means the virtue and restraint of the noble ones.🔽By “knowing or not knowing” he shows that they are not fault-finders or slanderers like those who disparage the noble ones knowing or not knowing their noble qualities.

original: ajānanto vā. Jānanājānanañcettha appamāṇaṃ, ariyabhāvo eva pamāṇaṃ. Tenāha “ubhayathāpi
analyzed: a jānantaḥ vā jānana a jānanam ca ittha appamāṇam ariya bhāvaḥ eva pamāṇam tena āha ubhayathā api
translated: Here the noble qualities are immeasurable, but the noble ones are the measure. Hence it is said: “In both cases they are not fault-finders or slanderers.”

original: ariyūpavādova hotī”ti. “Ariyoti pana ajānato aduṭṭhacittasseva tattha ariyaguṇabhāvaṃ🔽pavedentassa guṇaparidhaṃsanaṃ na hotīti tassa ariyūpavādo natthī”ti vadanti. Bhāriyaṃ
analyzed: ariya upavādaḥ uva hoti iti ariyaḥ ti pana a jānataḥ aduṭṭha cittassa iva tattha ariya guṇa bhāvaṃ  guṇa paridhaṃsanam na hoti iti tassa ariya upavādaḥ na atthi iti vadanti bhāriyam
translated: “But if he does not know that he is an ariyan, and he does not have a mind of hate, then by his proclaiming the ariyan qualities there is no defamation of an ariyan.”🔽“There is no defamation of an ariyan for one who says this: ‘There is no defamation of an ariyan for one who does not know that he is an ariyan, and who does not have a mind of hate.’ ”🔽

But it is curable by confession,

Mahallakoti samaṇānaṃ🔽sāruppamasāruppaṃ, lokasamudācāramattaṃ vā na jānātīti adhippāyena vuttattā guṇaparidhaṃsanena
analyzed: na ānantariyam atekiccham  tassa ca āvi bhāva attham ti bhāriyā ādi sabhāvassa pakāsana attham tam jigucchi iti tam theram  tam vā kiriyam jigucchi khudā abhibhūtaḥ  sāruppam asāruppam loka samudācāra mattam vā na jānāti iti adhippāyena vutta ttā guṇa paridhaṃsanena
translated: unlike the immediate offenses, which are incurable.

analyzed: garahati iti veditabbam amhākam lajjitabbakam akāsi iti samaṇena nāma evam katam ti
translated: “And the ground for its disclosure” is for the purpose of disclosing its heavy nature, etc. “He who is disgusted” is disgusted with that elder or with that action. “He who is overcome by excessive hunger” is one who is overcome by excessive hunger. “He who is ignorant of what is proper” is ignorant of what is proper and improper, or he is ignorant of what is proper and improper in the world, according to the intention expressed.
