analyzed: vutte mayam sīsam ukkhipitum na sakkoma iti adhippāyaḥ jānantaḥ eva theraḥ atthi te  āvuso imasmin sāsane patiṭṭhāti pucchi itaraḥ api sacca abhisamayaḥ sāsane patiṭṭhāti  āha sotāpannaḥ ahanti theraḥ tam karuṇāyamānaḥ khīṇa āsavaḥ tayā upavaditaḥ iti attānam  āvi akāsi tena assa tam pākatikam ahosi iti tena assa tam kammam magga āvaraṇam na ahosi iti
translated: “We are unable to raise our heads when this is said.” The Elder, knowing this, asked: “Is there any footing for you in this Dispensation?” The other said: “I have attained the fruit of Stream-Entry.” The Elder, taking pity on him, revealed himself, saying: “I have been accused by you as being one whose cankers are destroyed.” Thereby that deed of his became ripe for him.🔽

original: adhippāyo. Pubbeva pana sotāpannattā apāyagāmīnaṃ suppahīnabhāvato saggāvaraṇamassa🔽kātumasamatthameva taṃ kammaṃ. Attanā vuḍḍhataro hotīti ettha “ukkuṭikaṃ nisīditvā🔽khamāpetabbo”ti visuddhimagge vuttaṃ. Sotāpannasakadāgāmino dosenapi nakkhamanti,
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ pubbā iva pana sotāpanna ttā apāya gāmīnam su pahīna bhāvato sagga āvaraṇam assa  kātum asamattham eva tam kammam attanā vuḍḍhataraḥ hoti iti ettha ukkuṭikam nisīditvā  khamāpetabbaḥ ti visuddhi magge vuttam sotāpanna sakadāgāminaḥ dosena api na khamanti
translated: The meaning is: we are unable to raise our heads. The Elder asked him, “Do you have a footing in this Dispensation?” The other said, “I have stream-entry,” meaning: I have attained the noble path. The Elder took pity on him and revealed himself, saying, “I have been accused by you as having destroyed the taints.” The meaning is: he made it clear to him that he was an arahat. Thereby that deed of his became ineffective. The meaning is: it did not become an obstruction to the path. But because he was already a stream-enterer, that deed was incapable of obstructing his rebirth in the happy destinies, since he had already abandoned rebirth in the unhappy destinies. “One who is older than oneself”: in the Visuddhimagga it is said that one should sit cross-legged and ask forgiveness. But even if one is a stream-enterer or once-returner, one should not forgive one who is a non-returner or an arahat,

original: sesaariyā vā tassa atthakāmā hutvā āyatiṃ saṃvaraṇatthāya na khamāpeyyunti āha “sace
analyzed: sesa ariyāḥ vā tassa attha kāmāḥ hutvā āyatim saṃvaraṇa atthāya na khamāpeyyunti āha sace
translated: or if one is a non-returner, one should not forgive an arahat. Or if one is a non-returner or an arahat, one should not forgive one who is one’s well-wisher and who wishes to restrain one in the future. Therefore it is said: “If one is a stream-enterer or once-returner, one should not forgive a non-returner or an arahat. If one is a non-returner or an arahat, one should not forgive one who is one’s well-wisher and who wishes to restrain one in the future.”

original: so nakkhamatī”ti. Attanā vuḍḍhataro hoti, ṭhitakenevāti etthāpi “ukkuṭikaṃ nisīditvā”ti
analyzed: so na khamati iti attanā vuḍḍhataraḥ hoti ṭhitakena iva ati ettha api ukkuṭikam nisīditvā ati
translated: In the passage beginning, “If he is standing,” the words “sitting crosslegged” are to be understood.

original: visuddhimagge vuttaṃ. Evañhi tattha vuttaṃ –
analyzed: visuddhi magge vuttam evam hi tattha vuttam
translated: For this is said in the Visuddhimagga:

original: “Sace disāpakkanto hoti, sayaṃ vā gantvā saddhivihārike vā pesetvā khamāpetabbo.
analyzed: sace disā pakkantaḥ hoti sayam vā gantvā saddhivihārike vā pesetvā khamāpetabbaḥ
translated: “If the other is absent, he should ask forgiveness either by going to him or by sending a message.🔽If he is unable to go or to send a message,

original: Sace nāpi gantuṃ, na pesetuṃ sakkā hoti, ye tasmiṃ vihāre bhikkhū vasanti, tesaṃ🔽santikaṃ gantvā sace navakatarā honti, ukkuṭikaṃ nisīditvā, sace vuḍḍhatarā, vuḍḍhesu
analyzed: sace na api gantum na pesetum sakkā hoti ye tasmin vihāre bhikkhū vasanti tesam  santikam gantvā sace navakatarāḥ honti ukkuṭikam nisīditvā sace vuḍḍhatarāḥ vuḍḍhesu
translated: he should go into the presence of the bhikkhus living in that monastery and,🔽if they are junior to him, he should sit down on his heels and say, ‘Venerable sirs, I have spoken to the venerable so-and-so like this and like this.

original: vuttanayeneva paṭipajjitvā ‘ahaṃ, bhante, asukaṃ nāma āyasmantaṃ idañcidañca avacaṃ,
analyzed: vutta nayena iva paṭipajjitvā aham bhante asukam nāma āyasmantam idañca idañca avacam
translated: Please tell him to forgive me.’ If they are senior to him, he should adopt the proper attitude towards them in accordance with their seniority and then say, ‘Venerable sirs, I have spoken to the venerable so-and-so like this and like this.

original: khamatu me so āyasmā’ti vatvā khamāpetabbaṃ. Sammukhā akhamantepi etadeva kātabba”nti.
analyzed: khamatu me saḥ āyasmā ati vatvā khamāpetabbam sammukhāḥ a khamante pi etat eva kātabbanti
translated: Please forgive me.’ If they do not forgive him even though he has asked forgiveness in this way, he should do this work of asking forgiveness even towards them.

original: Idaṃ pana parampi tattha vuttaṃ –
analyzed: idam pana param pi tattha vuttam
translated: ” And this is said in the same place:

original: “Sace ekacārikabhikkhu hoti, nevassa vasanaṭṭhānaṃ, na gataṭṭhānaṃ paññāyati, ekassa
analyzed: sace ekacārika bhikkhu hoti na iva assa vasana ṭṭhānam na gata ṭṭhānam paññāyati ekassa
translated: “If he is a bhikkhu who wanders without a fixed abode, and if his dwelling place is not known or the direction in which he has gone is not known, he should do the following.

original: paṇḍitassa bhikkhuno santikaṃ gantvā ‘ahaṃ, bhante, asukaṃ nāma āyasmantaṃ idañcidañca
analyzed: paṇḍitassa bhikkhuno santikam gantvā aham bhante asukam nāma āyasmantam idañc idam ca
translated: He should go to a wise bhikkhu and say, “Venerable sir, I said such and such to the venerable one so and so.

original: avacaṃ, taṃ me anussarato anussarato vippaṭisāro hoti, kiṃ karomī’ti vattabbaṃ. So
analyzed: avacam tam me anussarataḥ anussarataḥ vippaṭisāraḥ hoti kim karomi iti vattabbam so
translated: Remembering it, I am remorseful. What should I do?”

original: vakkhati ‘tumhe mā cintayittha, thero tumhākaṃ khamati, cittaṃ vūpasamethā’ti. Tenapi
analyzed: vakkhati tumhe mā cintayittha thero tumhākam khamati cittam vūpasametha ati tena api
translated: The other should say, “Do not be concerned, friend. The elder forgives you. Let your mind be happy.”

original: ariyassa gatadisābhimukhena añjaliṃ paggahetvā ‘khamatū’ti vattabba”nti.
analyzed: ariyassa gata disa abhimukhena añjalim paggahetvā khamatu uti vattabbanti
translated: And the other should face the direction in which the noble one is and, raising his joined palms in salutation, say, “Forgive me.”

original: Parinibbutamañcaṭṭhānanti pūjākaraṇaṭṭhānaṃ sandhāyāha. Pākatikameva hotīti evaṃ
analyzed: parinibbuta mañca ṭṭhānam ti pūjā karaṇa ṭṭhānam sandhāya āha pākatikam eva hoti iti evam
translated: The place of final nibbana: the place where the worship is performed. It is as it was before: some say that the intention is this:

original: kate attano cittaṃ pasīdatīti taṃ kammaṃ saggāvaraṇaṃ maggāvaraṇañca na hotīti adhippāyoti
analyzed: kate attano cittam pasīdati iti tam kammam sagga āvaraṇam magga āvaraṇam ca na hoti iti adhippāyo ti
translated: if he does this, his own mind becomes clear, and that action does not obstruct heaven or the path.

original: keci vadanti. Cariyāpiṭake mātaṅgacaritasaṃvaṇṇanāyaṃ –
analyzed: keci vadanti cariyāpiṭake mātaṅga carita saṃvaṇṇanā ayam
translated: In the commentary to the story of Matanga in the Cariyapitaka it is said:

original: “Pāramitāparibhāvanasamiddhāhi nānāsamāpattivihāraparipūritāhi sīladiṭṭhisampadāhi
analyzed: pāramitā paribhāvana samiddhāhi nānā samāpatti vihāra paripūritāhi sīla diṭṭhi sampadāhi
translated: “By the success of the fulfilment of the perfections, by the fulfilment of the various kinds of attainment, by the perfection of virtue and view,

original: susaṅkhatasantāne mahākaruṇādhivāse mahāsatte ariyūpavādakammaabhisapasaṅkhātaṃ pharusavacanaṃ
analyzed: su saṅkhata santāne mahā karuṇā adhivāse mahāsatte pharusa vacanam
translated: In the case of the Great Being, who was of well-ordered consciousness, who was the abode of great compassion, and who was a Great Man, the harsh speech consisting in the slander was

original: saṃyuttaṃ mahāsattassa khettavisesabhāvato tassa ca ajjhāsayapharusatāya diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ
analyzed: saṃyuttam mahāsattassa khetta visesa bhāvataḥ tassa ca ajjhāsaya pharusa tāya diṭṭha dhamma vedanīyam
translated: appropriate because of the difference in the field and because of the harshness of his intention. It was to be experienced in this very life.

original: hutvā sace so mahāsattaṃ na khamāpeti, sattame divase vipaccanasabhāvaṃ jātaṃ. Khamāpite
analyzed: hutvā sace saḥ mahāsattam na khamāpeti sattame divase vipad canasa bhāvam jātam khamāpite
translated: After burning him, if that Great Being did not forgive, it would have become of a nature to ripen on the seventh day. But when the Great Being forgave,

original: pana mahāsatte payogasampattiyā vipākassa paṭibāhitattā avipākadhammataṃ āpajji ahosikammabhāvato.
analyzed: pana mahāsatte payoga sampattiyāḥ vipākassa paṭibāhita ttā avipāka dhamma tam āpajji ahosi kamma bhāvato
translated: the deed became of a nature not to ripen because the success of the means prevented the result. It became a deed that had been done but was not stored up.

original: Ayañhi ariyūpavādapāpassa diṭṭhadhammavedanīyassa ca dhammatā”ti –🔽Ācariyadhammapālattherena vuttattā evaṃ khamāpite taṃ kammaṃ payogasampattiyā vipākassa
analyzed: ayam hi ariya upavāda pāpassa diṭṭhadhamma vedanīyassa ca dhamma tā ti  ācariya dhammapāla therena vutta ttā evam khamāpite tam kammam payoga sampattiyāḥ vipākassa
translated: For this is the nature of the evil of slander of Noble Ones and of a state that is to be experienced in this very life.”🔽Because this is said by the teacher Dhammapāla, when the Great Being forgave in this way, that deed became of a nature not to ripen because the success of the means prevented the result. It became a deed that had been done but was not stored up.

original: paṭibāhitattā ahosikammabhāvena avipākadhammataṃ āpannanti neva saggāvaraṇaṃ na mokkhāvaraṇañca
analyzed: paṭibāhita ttā ahosikamma bhāvena avipāka dhamma tam āpannanti na iva sagga āvaraṇam na mokkha āvaraṇam ca
translated: It is neither an obstruction to heaven nor an obstruction to deliverance.

original: hotīti evamettha attho gahetabbo.
analyzed: hoti iti evam ettha atthaḥ gahetabbo
translated: This is how the meaning should be understood here.

original: Viparītaṃ dassanametesanti viparītadassanā. Samādātabbaṭṭhena samādānāni, kammāni
analyzed: viparītam dassanam etesan ti viparīta dassanā samādātabba ṭṭhena samādānāni kammāni
translated: They have wrong view: thus they are “those with wrong view.”🔽They are undertakings in the sense of being what should be undertaken.

original: samādānāni yesaṃ te kammasamādānā, micchādiṭṭhivasena kammasamādānā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā,🔽hetuatthaṃ vā antogadhaṃ katvā micchādiṭṭhivasena pare kammesu samādāpakā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā.
analyzed: samādānāni yesam te kamma samādānāḥ micchādiṭṭhi vasena kamma samādānāḥ micchādiṭṭhi kamma samādānā  hetu attham vā antogadham katvā micchādiṭṭhi vasena pare kammesu samādāpakāḥ micchādiṭṭhi kamma samādānā
translated: They are undertakings of kamma by way of wrong view.🔽Or they are those who, by way of wrong view, instigate others to kamma.🔽He shows the meaning of this by “By way of wrong view” and so on.

original: Tayimaṃ atthaṃ dassento “micchādiṭṭhivasenā”tiādimāha. Ye ca…pe… samādapenti, tepi
analyzed: tayimam attham dassentaḥ micchādiṭṭhi vasena atiādim āha ye cape samādapenti te pi
translated: Those who instigate others to kamma by way of wrong view are also “those with wrong view.”

original: micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānāti yojetabbaṃ. Sīlasampannotiādi paripakkindriyassa maggasamaṅgino
analyzed: micchādiṭṭhi kamma samādānā ti yojetabbam sīla sampannaḥ tiādi paripakka indriyassa magga samaṅgino
translated: “Endowed with virtue” and so on is said with reference to one who has developed his faculties and possesses the path.

original: vasena vuttaṃ, aggamaggaṭṭhe pana vattabbameva natthi. Atha vā aggamaggapariyāpannā
analyzed: vasena vuttam aggamagga aṭṭhe pana vattabbam eva natthi atha vā aggamagga pariyāpannā
translated: But there is nothing to be said with reference to one who possesses the supreme path.

original: eva sīlādayo veditabbā. Aggamaggaṭṭhassa hi diṭṭheva dhamme ekaṃsikā aññārādhanā,
analyzed: eva sīla ādayaḥ veditabbāḥ aggamagga ṭṭhassa hi diṭṭhe iva dhamme ekaṃsikā aññā ārādhanā
translated: Or virtue and so on should be understood as included in the supreme path.🔽For one who possesses the supreme path has no need to seek another refuge in this very life.

original: itaresaṃ anekaṃsikā. Aññanti arahattaṃ. Evaṃsampadamidanti ettha sampajjanaṃ sampadā,🔽nipphatti, evaṃ avirajjhanakanipphattikanti attho, yathā taṃ avassambhāvī, evamidampīti🔽vuttaṃ hoti. Yathā hi maggānantaraṃ avirajjhitvāva phalaṃ nibbattaṃ, evametaṃ imassapi🔽puggalassa cutianantaraṃ avirajjhitvāva niraye paṭisandhi hotīti dasseti. Sakalasmiñhi🔽buddhavacane na imāya upamāya gāḷhataraṃ katvā vuttaupamā atthi. Taṃ vācaṃ appahāyātiādīsu
analyzed: itaresam anekaṃsikāḥ arahattam evaṃsampadam idam ti ettha sampajjanam sampadā  nipphatti evam a virajjhanaka nipphattikanti atthaḥ yathā tam evam idam pi iti  vuttam hoti yathā hi magga anantaram a virajjhitvā ava phalam nibbattam evam etam imassa api  puggalassa cuti anantaram a virajjhitvā va niraye paṭisandhi hoti iti dasseti sakalasmin hi  buddha vacane na imāya upamāya gāḷhataram katvā vutta aupamā atthi tam vācam appahāya ati ādīsu
translated: and the rest are inconclusive. ‘Another’: Arahantship. ‘In this way’: the meaning is that the fruition is the outcome of non-falling-away in this way.🔽‘As it were’: what is meant is that it is as though it were.🔽For just as the fruition is produced without falling away from the path, so too this rebirth-linking in hell is produced without falling away from that fruition.🔽For in the whole of the Buddha’s word there is no simile that can make this state more plain than this one.🔽In the passage beginning, ‘Not abandoning that speech’ ,🔽

original: ariyūpavādaṃ sandhāya “puna evarūpiṃ vācaṃ na vakkhāmī”ti vadanto vācaṃ pajahati🔽nāma, “puna evarūpaṃ cittaṃ na uppādessāmī”ti cintento cittaṃ pajahati nāma, “puna🔽evarūpiṃ diṭṭhiṃ na gaṇhissāmī”ti pajahanto diṭṭhiṃ pajahati nāma. Tathā akaronto
analyzed: ariyūpa vādam sandhāya punar evarūpim vācam na vakkhāmi iti vadantaḥ vācam pajahati 🔽nāma punar evarūpam cittam na uppādessāmi iti cintentaḥ cittam pajahati nāma punar 🔽evarūpim diṭṭhim na gaṇhissāmi iti pajahantaḥ diṭṭhim pajahati nāma tathā a karontaḥ
translated: The rest are inconclusive. ‘Another’: Arahantship. ‘In this way’: the meaning is that it is the non-abandoning of the kind of rebirth-linking that has that as its fruit. ‘As it were’: what is meant is that ‘this is just as if’. For just as the fruit is produced without the non-abandoning of the path that has that as its fruit, so too this rebirth-linking in hell is produced without the non-abandoning of the kind of rebirth-linking that has that as its fruit. For in the whole of the Buddha’s word there is no simile that illustrates this more closely than this one. As regards the words ‘without abandoning that speech’ and so on, it is said: ‘I shall not speak that kind of speech again’—he abandons speech by saying this. ‘I shall not arouse that kind of thought again’—he abandons thought by saying this. ‘I shall not hold that kind of view again’—he abandons view by saying this. And by not doing it again he abandons it.

original: neva pajahati na paṭinissajjati. Yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ nirayeti yathā nirayapālehi
analyzed: na iva pajahati na paṭinissajjati yathābhatam nikkhittaḥ evam nirayeti yathā niraya pālehi
translated: He neither abandons nor relinquishes it. He is cast into hell as he stands, as though he were thrown into hell by the warders of hell.

original: āharitvā niraye ṭhapito, evaṃ niraye ṭhapitoyeva, nāssa nirayūpapattiyā koci vibandho.
analyzed: āharitvā niraye ṭhapitaḥ evam niraye na assa niraya upapattiyā koci vibandho
translated: He is placed in hell as he stands, and there is no obstacle to his rebirth in hell.

original: Tatrāyaṃ yutti – nirayūpago ariyūpavādī tadādāyakassa avijahanato seyyathāpi micchādiṭṭhīti.
analyzed: tatra ayam yutti nirayūpagaḥ ariyūpavādī tad ādāyakassa a vijahanataḥ sā iyyathā api micchādiṭṭhī iti
translated: Here is the argument: The one who misrepresents the noble ones is reborn in hell because he does not relinquish the one who misrepresents the noble ones, just like one of wrong view.

original: Ettha ca “taṃ vācaṃ appahāyā”ti evamādivacanena tadādāyakassa appahāneneva ariyūpavādo
analyzed: ettha ca tam vācam appahāya ati evamādi vacanena tad ādāyakassa appahānena iva ariya upavādaḥ
translated: And here the words “without abandoning that speech” show that misrepresenting the noble ones is an obstacle and a harm only through not abandoning the one who misrepresents the noble ones.

original: antarāyiko anatthāvahova, pahānena pana accayaṃ desetvā khamāpanena na antarāyiko🔽anatthāvaho yathā taṃ vuṭṭhitā desitā ca āpattīti dasseti. Micchādiṭṭhivasena akattabbaṃ🔽nāma pāpaṃ natthi, yato saṃsārakhāṇubhāvopi nāma hotīti āha “micchādiṭṭhiparamāni,
analyzed: antarāyikaḥ anattha āvahaḥ uva pahānena pana accayam desetvā khamāpanena na antarāyikaḥ  anattha āvahaḥ yathā tam vuṭṭhitā desitā ca āpatti iti dasseti micchādiṭṭhi vasena a kattabbam  nāma pāpam natthi yatas saṃsāra khāṇu bhāvaḥ pi nāma hoti iti āha micchādiṭṭhi paramāni
translated: But when it is abandoned, it is not an obstacle and a harm, as shown by the example of the offence that is confessed and thereby cleared.

original: bhikkhave, vajjānī”ti.
analyzed: bhikkhave vajjāni iti
translated: There is no evil that should not be done through wrong view, since even the state of being a hell-dweller is a result of it. Thus it is said: “The worst offenders, bhikkhus, are those who hold wrong view” .

original: “Ucchinnabhavanettiko, bhikkhave, tathāgatassa kāyo tiṭṭhati, ayañceva kāyo bahiddhā
analyzed: ucchinna bhavanettikaḥ bhikkhave tathāgatassa kāyaḥ tiṭṭhati ayam ca iva kāyaḥ bahiddhā
translated: “The body of the Tathāgata, monks, remains with the life-faculty suspended, and this body and the mind-and-matter outside” . Here the word “body” refers to the five aggregates.

original: ca nāmarūpa”nti ca evamādīsu viya idha kāya-saddo khandhapañcakavisayoti āha “kāyassa🔽bhedāti upādinnakkhandhapariccāgā”ti. Avītarāgassa maraṇato paraṃ nāma bhavantarūpādānamevāti
analyzed: ca nāma rūpam ti ca evamādīsu viya idha kāya saddo khandha pañcaka visayaḥ ti āha kāyassa  bhedā ati upādinna kkhandha pariccāgā ati avīta rāgassa maraṇataḥ param nāma bhavantaru upādānam eva ati
translated: “The breakup of the body” means the relinquishing of the appropriated aggregates.🔽After death, for one who is not free from passion, there is the appropriation of aggregates in another existence.

original: āha “paraṃ maraṇāti tadanantaraṃ abhinibbattakkhandhaggahaṇe”ti. Yena tiṭṭhati, tassa
analyzed: āha param maraṇā ti tad anantaram abhinibbatta khandha ggahaṇā iti yena tiṭṭhati tassa
translated: “After death” means the appropriation of the aggregates that are reborn immediately after that.🔽The body breaks up by the cutting off of that by which it stands.

original: upacchedeneva kāyo bhijjatīti āha “kāyassa bhedāti jīvitindriyassa upacchedā”ti.
analyzed: upacchedena iva kāyaḥ bhijjati iti āha kāyassa jīvitindriyassa
translated: “The breakup of the body” means the cutting off of the life faculty.🔽“Ay” is derived from “sukha” in the sense of “going to” .

original: Eti imasmā sukhanti ayo, puññanti āha “puññasammatā ayā”ti. Āyanti etasmā sukhānīti
analyzed: eti imasma āha puñña sammatāḥ āha etasma sukhāni iti
translated: “Ay” is derived from “sukha” in the sense of “coming from” .🔽It is the means of achieving happiness, such as meritorious deeds, etc.

original: āyo, puññakammādīnaṃ sukhasādhanaṃ. Tenāha “sukhānaṃ vā āyassa abhāvā”ti. Vivasāti
analyzed: āyaḥ puñña kamma ādīnam sukha sādhanam tena āha vivasāti
translated: “The absence of ay” means the absence of the means of achieving happiness.

original: kammassa vase vattanato attano vase vattituṃ na sakkontīti vigato vaso etesanti vivasā,
analyzed: kammassa vase vattanataḥ attanaḥ vase vattitum na sakkonti iti vigataḥ vaso etesanti vivasā
translated: “Vivas” is derived from “vas” in the sense of “going away” .

original: avasavattinoti attho. Iyati assādīyatīti ayo, assādoti āha “assādasaññito ayo”ti.
analyzed: avasavattino ti attho iyati assādīyati iti ayaḥ assādaḥ iti āha assāda saññitaḥ ayaḥ ti
translated: the meaning is, it is known as an enjoyment.🔽The “kings of the nāgas” and so on: the word “and so on” includes the supaṇṇas, etc.

original: Nāgarājādīnanti ādi-saddena supaṇṇādīnaṃ saṅgaho. Asurasadisanti petāsurasadisaṃ.
analyzed: nāga rāja ādīnam ti ādi saddena supaṇṇa ādīnam saṅgahaḥ asura sadisam ti peta asura sadisam
translated: The asuras are like the petas:🔽that asura body is like the peta body.🔽In all the enjoyments: in all the enjoyments of the kinds of success.

original: So hīti so asurakāyo. Sabbasamussayehīti sabbehi sampattisamussayehi, sabbasampattirāsitoti🔽vuttaṃ hoti. Vuttavipariyāyenāti “suṭṭhu caritaṃ, sobhanaṃ vā caritaṃ anavajjattāti
analyzed: saḥ hi iti saḥ asura kāyaḥ sabba samussayehi iti sabbehi sampatti samussayehi sabba sampattiḥ āsitaḥ ti  vuttam hoti vutta vipariyāyena ati suṭṭhu caritam sobhanam vā caritam anavajja ttā ti
translated: The meaning is, in all the storehouses of success.🔽The opposite of what was said: the opposite of the meaning of the words “bodily good conduct” and so on, which were said in the way beginning: “Well conducted, good conduct, blameless,

original: sucarita”ntiādinā kāyaduccaritenātiādīnaṃ padānaṃ vuttassa atthassa vipariyāyena.
analyzed: su carita nti ādinā kāya duccaritena ati ādīnam padānam vuttassa atthassa vipariyāyena
translated: blameless conduct, that is to say, bodily good conduct” .

original: “Ito bho sugatiṃ gacchā”ti vacanato manussagatipi sugatiyevāti āha “sugatiggahaṇena
analyzed: itas bho sugatim gacchāti vacanataḥ manussa gati pi sugatiyā iva āti āha sugati ggahaṇena
translated: Because of the words “Go from here, good sir, to a good destination,” the human destination is also a good destination.

original: manussagatipi saṅgayhatī”ti. Sesamettha vuttanayattā uttānatthato ca suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: saṅgayhati iti sesam ettha vutta naya ttā uttāna tthato ca su viññeyyam eva
translated: The rest is clear in meaning and easy to understand since its meaning is already stated in the way already given.

original: Dibbacakkhuñāṇakathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: dibba cakkhu ñāṇa kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the knowledge of the divine eye is ended.

original: Āsavakkhayañāṇakathā
analyzed: āsava khaya ñāṇa kathā
translated: Knowledge of the destruction of the taints

original: 14. Vipassanāpādakanti vipassanāya padaṭṭhānabhūtaṃ. Vipassanā ca tividhā vipassakapuggalabhedena.
analyzed: vipassanā pādakanti vipassanāya padaṭṭhāna bhūtam vipassanā ca tividhā vipassaka puggala bhedena
translated: The “preliminary work for insight” is the foundation for insight. And insight is threefold according to the difference of the persons who have insight.

original: Mahābodhisattānañhi paccekabodhisattānañca cintāmayañāṇasaṃvaddhitattā sayambhūñāṇabhūtā,🔽itaresaṃ sutamayañāṇasaṃvaddhitattā paropadesasambhūtā. Sā “ṭhapetvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ
analyzed: mahā bodhisattānam hi pacceka bodhisattānam ca cintā maya ñāṇa saṃvaddhi tattā sayambhū ñāṇa bhūtā  itaresam suta maya ñāṇa saṃvaddhi tattā para upadesa sambhūtā sā ṭhapetvā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam
translated: For the great Bodhisattas and the Paccekabodhisattas, it is self-become knowledge, since it is developed by knowledge consisting in what is thought out.🔽For the rest, it is knowledge consisting in what is learnt, since it is developed by knowledge consisting in what is learnt. It is stated in the Visuddhimagga in many ways as follows: “Having emerged from any one of the immaterial jhānas, which are other than the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception, he defines mentality and materiality by discerning the four elements in the way beginning ‘The head hairs, body hairs, teeth, nails, etc., are the earth element, the water element’ .

original: avasesarūpārūpajjhānānaṃ aññatarato vuṭṭhāyā”tiādinā anekadhā arūpamukhavasena catudhātuvavatthāne
analyzed: avasesa rūpa arūpa jhānānaṃ aññataratas vuṭṭhāya ati ādinā anekadhā arūpa mukha vasena catu dhātu vavatthāne
translated: This is the method of development in the case of those who have insight by means of the immaterial as the door.🔽But in the case of the great Bodhisattas, it is stated in the Visuddhimagga in many ways as follows: ‘The method of development in the case of those who have insight by means of the material as the door is as follows. Having emerged from any one of the jhānas, he defines mentality and materiality by discerning the four elements in the way beginning “The head hairs, body hairs, teeth, nails, etc., are the earth element, the water element” .

original: vuttānaṃ tesaṃ tesaṃ dhātupariggahamukhānaṃ aññataramukhavasena anekadhāva visuddhimagge🔽nānānayato vibhāvitā. Mahābodhisattānaṃ pana catuvīsatikoṭisatasahassamukhena pabhedagamanato
analyzed: vuttānam tesam tesam dhātu pariggaha mukhānam aññatara mukha vasena anekadhā va visuddhi magge  nānā nayataḥ vibhāvitā mahā bodhisattānam pana catuvīsati koṭi sata sahassa mukhena pabheda gamanato
translated: This is the method of development in the case of those who have insight by means of the material as the door.🔽But in the case of the great Bodhisattas, it is stated in the Visuddhimagga in many ways as follows: ‘The method of development in the case of those who have insight by means of the material as the door is as follows. Having emerged from any one of the jhānas, he defines mentality and materiality by discerning the four elements in the way beginning “The head hairs, body hairs, teeth, nails, etc., are the earth element, the water element” .🔽This is the method of development in the case of those who have insight by means of the material as the door.

original: nānānayaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇasannissayassa ariyamaggañāṇassa adhiṭṭhānabhūtaṃ pubbabhāgañāṇagabbhaṃ
analyzed: nānānayam sabbaññuta ññāṇa sannissayassa ariya magga ñāṇassa adhiṭṭhāna bhūtam pubbabhāga ñāṇa gabbham
translated: But in the case of the great Bodhisattas, it is stated in the Visuddhimagga in many ways as follows: ‘The method of development in the case of those who have insight by means of the material as the door is as follows. Having emerged

original: gaṇhāpentaṃ paripākaṃ gacchantaṃ paramagambhīraṃ saṇhasukhumataraṃ anaññasādhāraṇaṃ
analyzed: gaṇhāpentam paripākam gacchantam parama gambhīram saṇha sukhumataram an añña sādhāraṇam
translated: It is the knowledge of insight, which is being taken up, which is reaching maturity, which is extremely profound, which is very delicate and subtle, which is not shared by others,

original: vipassanāñāṇaṃ hoti. Yaṃ aṭṭhakathāsu mahāvajiraññāṇanti vuccati. Yassa ca pavattivibhāgena
analyzed: vipassanā ñāṇam hoti yam aṭṭhakathāsu mahāvajiraññāṇanti vuccati yassa ca pavatti vibhāgena
translated: which is called the “Great Diamond Wheel” in the Commentaries. And it is by the analysis of the occurrence of this knowledge

original: catuvīsatikoṭisatasahassapabhedassa pādakabhāvena samāpajjiyamānā catuvīsatikoṭisatasahassasaṅkhyā
analyzed: catuvīsati koṭi sata sahassa pabhedassa pādaka bhāvena samāpajjiyamānā catuvīsati koṭi sata sahassa saṅkhyā
translated: that the twenty-four hundred thousand kinds of concentration are reached as the footing for the twenty-four hundred thousand kinds of concentration

original: devasikaṃ satthu vaḷañjanakasamāpattiyo vuccanti, svāyaṃ buddhānaṃ vipassanācāro
analyzed: devasikam satthu vaḷañjanaka samāpattiyaḥ vuccanti svāyam buddhānam vipassanā ācāro
translated: that are called the “daily concentrations of the Elder Vaḍḍha.” This is the Blessed One’s practice of insight,

original: paramatthamañjusāyaṃ visuddhimaggavaṇṇanāyaṃ uddesato dassito, atthikehi tato gahetabbo.
analyzed: paramattha mañjusāyam visuddhi magga vaṇṇanāyam uddesataḥ dassitaḥ atthikehi tatas gahetabbo
translated: which is shown here in the commentary on the Path of Purification in the ultimate sense in the form of a summary. Those who want to know it should learn it from there.

original: Āsavānaṃ khepanato samucchindanato āsavakkhayo ariyamaggo, ukkaṭṭhaniddesavasena
analyzed: āsavānam khepanataḥ samucchindanataḥ āsava kkhayaḥ ariya maggaḥ ukkaṭṭha niddesa vasena
translated: The destruction of the cankers is the noble path, because it is the abandoning, the uprooting, of the cankers. The expression “the path of arahatship” is used here in the sense of the highest.

original: arahattamaggaggahaṇaṃ. Āsavānaṃ khaye ñāṇaṃ āsavakkhayañāṇanti dassento “tatra cetaṃ
analyzed: arahatta magga ggahaṇam āsavānam khaye ñāṇam āsava kkhaya ñāṇam ti dassento tatra ca itaṃ
translated: The knowledge of the destruction of the cankers is called the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers. Showing this, the commentator says, “Herein, this is the knowledge,”

original: ñāṇa”nti vatvā khayeti ca ādhāre bhummaṃ, na visayeti dassento “tappariyāpannattā”ti
analyzed: vatvā khaya iti ca ādhāre bhummam na visaya iti dassento tad pariyāpanna ttā ti
translated: and he shows that the word “destruction” is in the locative case, not in the objective case, by saying, “because it is included in that.”

original: āha. Idaṃ dukkhanti dukkhassa ariyasaccassa tadā paccakkhato gahitabhāvadassanaṃ.
analyzed: āha idam dukkhan ti dukkhassa ariya saccassa tadā paccakkhataḥ gahita bhāva dassanam
translated: He said: “This is the noble truth of suffering” is the seeing of the fact of the suffering of the noble truth of suffering as it really is.

original: Ettakaṃ dukkhanti tassa paricchijja gahitabhāvadassanaṃ. Na ito bhiyyoti anavasesetvā
analyzed: ettakam dukkhan ti tassa paricchijja gahita bhāva dassanam na itas bhiyyas ti anavasesetvā
translated: “This is the extent of suffering” is the seeing of the fact of the delimitation of that suffering. “No more than this” is the seeing of the fact of the non-excess of suffering.

original: gahitabhāvadassanaṃ. Tenāha “sabbampi dukkhasacca”ntiādi. Sarasalakkhaṇapaṭivedhenāti
analyzed: gahita bhāva dassanam tena āha sabbam pi dukkha sacca nti ādi sa rasa lakkhaṇa paṭivedhena ati
translated: Therefore it is said: “All the truth of suffering” and so on. By penetration of the general characteristic:

original: sabhāvasaṅkhātassa lakkhaṇassa asammohato paṭivijjhanena. Asammohapaṭivedhoti ca
analyzed: sabhāva saṅkhātassa lakkhaṇassa asammohataḥ paṭivijjhanena asammoha paṭivedho ti ca
translated: by non-delusion regarding the characteristic called the individual essence. Penetration of non-delusion is

original: yathā tasmiṃ ñāṇe pavatte pacchā dukkhassa sarūpādiparicchede sammoho na hoti, tathā
analyzed: yathā tasmim ñāṇe pavatte pacchā dukkhassa sarūpa ādi paricchede sammohaḥ na hoti tathā
translated: the occurrence of the knowledge of the characteristic of suffering in such a way that afterwards there is no delusion regarding the individual essence of suffering and so on, when it occurs.🔽Therefore it is said: “He fully understood as it really is” . By producing:

original: pavatti. Tenāha “yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsi”nti. Nibbattikanti nipphādentaṃ. Yaṃ ṭhānaṃ
analyzed: tena āha yathābhūtam abbhaññāsin ti nibbattikam ti nipphādentam yam ṭhānam
translated: by making manifest. Having reached the place:

original: patvāti yaṃ nibbānaṃ maggassa ārammaṇapaccayaṭṭhena kāraṇabhūtaṃ āgamma. Tadubhayavato
analyzed: patvā ti yam nibbānam maggassa ārammaṇa paccaya ṭṭhena kāraṇa bhūtam āgamma tad ubhayavataḥ
translated: having reached the Nibbāna which is the cause of the path by way of being its object condition.

original: hi puggalassa patti tadubhayassa pattīti vuttaṃ. Patvāti vā pāpuṇanahetu. Appavattinti
analyzed: hi puggalassa tad ubhayassa patti iti vuttam patvā ati vā pāpuṇana hetu appavattin ti
translated: For it is said of a person who possesses both that he has reached the attainment of both. Or “having reached” is the cause of the attainment. By non-occurrence:

original: appavattinimittaṃ. Te vā na pavattanti etthāti appavatti, nibbānaṃ. Tassāti dukkhanirodhassa.
analyzed: appavatti nimittam te vā na pavattanti ettha ati appavatti nibbānam tassa ti dukkha nirodhassa
translated: The sign of non-occurrence. Or else, it is non-occurrence because they do not occur there. Nibbāna is that. His, of the cessation of suffering.

original: Sampāpakanti sacchikiriyāvasena sammadeva pāpakaṃ.
analyzed: sampāpakam ti sacchikiriyā vasena sammat eva pāpakam
translated: Fully understood: fully penetrated by realization.

original: Kilesavasenāti āsavasaṅkhātakilesavasena. Yasmā āsavānaṃ dukkhasaccapariyāyo, tappariyāpannattā,
analyzed: kilesa vasena ati āsava saṅkhāta kilesa vasena yasmai āsavānam dukkha sacca pariyāyo tad pariyāpanna ttā
translated: By means of defilements: by means of defilements called taints. Because the truth of suffering is the domain of the taints, and because the other truths are included in it,

original: sesasaccānañca taṃsamudayādipariyāyo atthi, tasmā vuttaṃ “pariyāyato”ti. Dassento
analyzed: tad samudaya ādi pariyāyaḥ atthi tasmā vuttam pariyāyato ti dassento
translated: and because they have the characteristic of its origin, etc., it is said “indirectly.” Showing

original: saccānīti yojanā. Āsavānaṃyeva cettha gahaṇaṃ “āsavānaṃ khayañāṇāyā”ti āraddhattā.🔽Tathā hi āsavavimuttisīseneva sabbasaṃkilesavimutti vuttā. Idaṃ dukkhanti yathābhūtaṃ
analyzed: saccāni iti yojanā āsavānaṃ yeva ca ittha gahaṇam āsavānam khaya ñāṇāya ati āraddha ttā  tathā hi āsava vimutti sīsena iva sabba saṃkilesa vimutti vuttā idam dukkhanti yathābhūtam
translated: the truths. But here only the taints are included, because the passage begins, “for the knowledge of the destruction of the taints.”

original: abbhaññāsintiādinā missakamaggo idha kathitoti “saha vipassanāya koṭippattaṃ maggaṃ
analyzed: abbhaññāsin ti ādinā missaka maggaḥ idha kathito ti saha vipassanāya koṭi pattam maggaṃ
translated: For thus the deliverance from all defilements is stated by means of the head of deliverance from the taints. The mixed path is stated here by the passage beginning, “He fully understood as it really is: ‘This is suffering’ ”

original: kathetī”ti vuttaṃ. Ettha ca saccappaṭivedhassa tadā atītakālikattā “yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsi”nti
analyzed: kathā iti iti vuttam ettha ca sacca ppaṭivedhassa tadā atīta kālika ttā yathābhūtam abbhaññāsin ti
translated: and so on. Therefore it is said, “He teaches the path that has reached the summit together with insight.” And here, since the penetration of the truths belongs to the past time, it is said, “He fully understood as it really is”🔽.

original: vatvāpi abhisamayakāle tassa paccuppannataṃ upādāya “evaṃ jānato evaṃ passato”ti
analyzed: vatvā api abhisamaya kāle tassa paccuppanna tam upādāya evam jānataḥ evam passato ti
translated: And although he said this, still the demonstrative pronoun “this” is used in the phrase “having thus known, having thus seen”

original: vattamānakālena niddeso kato. So ca kāmaṃ maggakkhaṇato paraṃ yāvajjatanā atītakāliko
analyzed: vattamāna kālena niddeso kato so ca kāmam magga khaṇato param yāvajjatanā atīta kāliko
translated: in the sense of the present because of the fact that the path is present at the time of penetration. And although the path is past after the moment of its arising,

original: eva, sabbapaṭhamaṃ panassa atītakālikattaṃ phalakkhaṇeneva veditabbanti āha “vimuccitthāti
analyzed: eva sabba paṭhamam panassa atīta kālika ttam phala kkhaṇena iva veditabbanti āha vimuccittha iti
translated: nevertheless its pastness should be understood only through the fruit, which is why it is said: “By the words ‘was liberated’

original: iminā phalakkhaṇaṃ dassetī”ti. Jānato passatoti vā hetuniddesoyaṃ. Jānanahetu dassanahetu
analyzed: iminā phala kkhaṇam dasseti iti jānataḥ passataḥ ti vā hetu niddesaḥ yam jānana hetu dassana hetu
translated: he shows the moment of the fruit.” Or else the words “having thus known, having thus seen” are a reason clause. The construction is:

original: kāmāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccitthāti yojanā. Bhavāsavaggahaṇeneva cettha bhavarāgassa
analyzed: kāma āsavā api cittam vimuccittha ati yojanā bhava āsava ggahaṇena iva ca ittha bhava rāgassa
translated: “The mind was liberated from the taint of sensual desire, from the taint of being,🔽from the taint of ignorance, because of knowing, because of seeing.” And by the mention of the taint of being,

original: viya bhavadiṭṭhiyāpi samavarodhoti diṭṭhāsavassapi saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo.🔽Yasmā pahīnakilesapaccavekkhaṇena vijjamānassapi kammassa āyatiṃ appaṭisandhikabhāvato
analyzed: viya bhava diṭṭhiyā api samavarodhaḥ ti diṭṭha āsavassa api saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo  yasmā pahīna kilesa paccavekkhaṇena vijjamānassa api kammassa āyatim appaṭisandhika bhāvato
translated: the inclusion of the taint of views should be understood, just as the inclusion of lust for being is.🔽“Having thus known, having thus seen, he knew: ‘Destroyed is birth, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more for this state of being.’“

original: “khīṇā jātī”ti jānāti, yasmā ca maggapaccavekkhaṇādīhi vusitaṃ brahmacariyantiādiṃ
analyzed: khīṇā jātī iti jānāti yasmai ca magga paccavekkhaṇa ādīhi vusitam brahmacariya ntiādiṃ
translated: “Having thus known, having thus seen, he knew: ‘Destroyed is birth, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more for this state of being.’“

original: pajānāti, tasmā vuttaṃ “khīṇā jātīti ādīhi tassa bhūmi”nti. Tattha tassāti paccavekkhaṇañāṇassa.
analyzed: pajānāti tasmā vuttam khīṇā jātī iti ādīhi tassa bhūmin ti tattha tassa āti paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇassa
translated: Herein, his is the plane of the reviewing knowledge.🔽Plane is the occurrence-base.

original: Bhūminti pavattiṭṭhānaṃ. Yenādhippāyena “katamā panā”tiādinā codanā katā, taṃ pakāsetvā
analyzed: bhūmin ti pavatti ṭṭhānam yena adhippāyena katamā pana ati ādinā codanā katā tam pakāsetvā
translated: The intention with which the question was asked is shown by the words “What is the plane of the reviewing knowledge?”🔽and the answer is given by the words “It is not that his birth is destroyed.”

original: parihāraṃ vattukāmo āha “na tāvassā”tiādi. Na tāvassa atītā jāti khīṇāti maggabhāvanāya
analyzed: parihāram vattu kāmaḥ āha na tāvassa atiādi na atītā magga bhāvanāya
translated: The meaning is that it is not destroyed by the development of the path.🔽The reason is given: “because it is already destroyed.”

original: na khīṇāti adhippāyo. Tattha kāraṇamāha “pubbeva khīṇattā”ti. Na anāgatā assa jāti🔽khīṇāti yojanā. Na anāgatāti ca anāgatattasāmaññaṃ gahetvā lesena vadati. Tenāha
analyzed: na khīṇā ti adhippāyaḥ tattha kāraṇam āha pubbā iva khīṇa ttā ti na anāgatā assa jāti  khīṇā ati yojanā na anāgatā ati ca anāgata tta sāmaññam gahetvā lesena vadati tena āha
translated: The construction is: “It is not that his future birth is destroyed.”🔽And he speaks of the future by the word “future” in order to include the future in the general sense.

original: “anāgate vāyāmābhāvato”ti. Vijjamāneyeva hi payogo sambhavati, nāvijjamāneti adhippāyo.
analyzed: anāgate vāyāma abhāvato ti vijjamānā iya iva hi payogo sambhavati na a vijjamānā iti adhippāyo
translated: That is why he says “because there is no effort in the future.” For it is only when something exists that it is possible to make an effort about it, not when it does not exist, is the meaning.

original: Anāgataviseso panettha adhippeto, tassa ca khepane vāyāmopi labbhateva. Tenāha “yā
analyzed: anāgata visesaḥ pana ittha adhippeto tassa ca khepane vāyāmaḥ pi labbhatā iva tena āha yā
translated: But what is intended here is a distinction in the future, and in the rejection of that, effort is also included. That is why he says “because there is no effort in the future.”

original: pana maggassā”tiādi. “Yā panā”ti hi ādinā maggabhāvanāya anāgatajātiyā eva hetuvināsanadvārena
analyzed: pana maggassa atiādi yā pana ati hi ādinā magga bhāvanāya anāgata jātiyāḥ eva hetu vināsana dvārena
translated: For the words “But if” , etc., show the exhaustion of birth by the destruction of its cause through the future birth being made to cease by the path’s being developed.

original: khīṇabhāvo pakāsīyati. Ekacatupañcavokārabhavesūti bhavattayaggahaṇaṃ vuttanayena
analyzed: khīṇa bhāvaḥ eka catu pañca vokāra bhavesu iti bhava taya gahaṇam vutta nayena
translated: The words “in one kind of becoming, in four kinds, in five kinds” include the three kinds of becoming,🔽and they show the exhaustion of birth without remainder in the way already stated.

original: anavasesato jātiyā khīṇabhāvadassanatthaṃ. Tanti yathāvuttajātiṃ. Soti bhagavā.
analyzed: anavasesataḥ jātiyā khīṇa bhāva dassana attham tat ti yathā vutta jātim saḥ ti bhagavā
translated: The word “that” refers to the birth stated thus. The word “he” refers to the Blessed One.

original: Brahmacariyavāso nāma idha maggabrahmacariyassa nibbattanamevāti āha “niṭṭhita”nti.
analyzed: brahmacariya vāsaḥ nāma idha magga brahmacariyassa nibbattanam eva ati āha niṭṭhitam ti
translated: The word “lived” means that the life of the spiritual practice was completed.

original: Sammādiṭṭhiyā catūsu saccesu pariññādikiccasādhanavasena pavattamānāya sammāsaṅkappādīnampi
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhiyā catūsu saccesu pariññā ādi kicca sādhana vasena pavattamānāya sammāsaṅkappa ādīnam pi
translated: When right view occurs in the four truths by accomplishing the functions of full-understanding, etc., then right thought, etc.,

original: dukkhasacce pariññābhisamayānuguṇā pavatti, itarasaccesu ca nesaṃ pahānābhisamayādivasena
analyzed: dukkha sacce pariññā abhisamaya anuguṇā pavatti itara saccesu ca na isam pahāna abhisamaya ādi vasena
translated: also occur in conformity with the clear vision of the truth of suffering, and so on, and in the other truths they occur by way of the clear vision of abandoning, etc.,

original: pavatti pākaṭā eva. Tena vuttaṃ “catūhi maggehi pariññāpahānasacchikiriyābhāvanābhisamayavasenā”ti.
analyzed: pavatti pākaṭā eva tena vuttam catūhi maggehi pariññā apahāna sacchikiriyā bhāvanā abhisamaya vasena ati
translated: and so on. That is why it is said, “By means of the four paths there is clear vision of full-understanding, abandoning, realizing, and developing.”

original: Nāparaṃ itthattāyāti ime pakārā itthaṃ, tabbhāvo itthattaṃ, tadatthanti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: na aparam itthattāya ati ime pakārāḥ ittham tad bhāvaḥ itthattam tad attham ti vuttam hoti
translated: ‘There is no more of this mundane state’: this kind of state is ‘thus’ , and that is what is meant by ‘this mundane state.’

original: Te pana pakārā ariyamaggabyāpārabhūtā pariññādayo idhādhippetāti āha “evaṃsoḷasakiccabhāvāyā”ti.
analyzed: te pana pakārāḥ ariya magga byāpāra bhūtā pariññā ādayaḥ idha adhippetā ti āha evam soḷasa kicca bhāvāya ati
translated: But the kinds of state intended here are the kinds of state consisting in the sixteen kinds of function, namely, full-understanding, etc., which are the domain of the noble path. That is why it is said ‘for the sake of the sixteen kinds of function.’

original: Te hi maggaṃ paccavekkhato maggānubhāvena pākaṭā hutvā upaṭṭhahanti, pariññādīsu🔽ca pahānameva padhānaṃ, tadatthattāya itaresanti āha “kilesakkhayāya vā”ti. Pahīnakilesapaccavekkhaṇavasena🔽vā etaṃ vuttaṃ. “Nāparaṃ itthattāyāti abbhaññāsi”nti etthāyamaparo nayo – itthattāyāti🔽nissakke sampadānavacanaṃ. Tenāyamattho – itthattāya itthambhāvato imasmā evaṃpakārā
analyzed: te hi maggam paccavekkhataḥ magga anubhāvena pākaṭāḥ hutvā upaṭṭhahanti pariññā ādīsu  ca pahānam eva padhānam tad attha ttāya itaresan ti āha kilesa kkhayāya vā ati pahīna kilesa paccavekkhaṇa vasena  vā etam vuttam na aparam itthattāya ati ettha ayam aparaḥ nayaḥ itthattāya ati  nissakke sampadāna vacanam tena ayam atthaḥ itthattāya itthambhāvataḥ imasmai evaṃpakārā
translated: For these become evident and manifest to one reviewing the path through the power of the path.🔽And in the case of full-understanding, etc., abandoning is the exertion, and the others are for the sake of that. That is why it is said ‘for the exhaustion of taints.’ Or this is said with reference to reviewing the abandoning of taints.

original: idāni vattamānakkhandhasantānā aparaṃ anāgatakkhandhasantānaṃ mayhaṃ natthi, ime
analyzed: idāni vattamāna kkhandha santānāḥ aparam anāgata kkhandha santānam mayham natthi ime
translated: ‘He directly knew: There is no more of this mundane state’: there is this other way of explaining this. ‘Of this mundane state’ is a locative of cause. The meaning is this: ‘For this reason, for this cause, for this reason of this kind, for this cause of this kind, namely, for the reason of the present continuity of aggregates, there is no more future continuity of aggregates for me.’

original: pana carimattabhāvasaṅkhātā pañcakkhandhā pariññātā appatiṭṭhā tiṭṭhanti chinnamūlakā
analyzed: pana carimatta bhāva saṅkhātā pañca kkhandhā pariññātā appatiṭṭhā tiṭṭhanti chinna mūlakā
translated: but the five aggregates, which are called the last, stand without being able to stand, being cut off at the root, being like hacked bamboos, being unable to attain growth, increase, and expansion.

original: rukkhā viya. Apariññātamūlakā hi patiṭṭhā. Yathāha “kabaḷīkāre ce, bhikkhave, āhāre🔽atthi rāgo atthi nandī atthi taṇhā, patiṭṭhitaṃ tattha viññāṇaṃ viruḷha”ntiādi. Te
analyzed: rukkhāḥ viya a pariññāta mūlakāḥ hi patiṭṭhāḥ yathā āha kabaḷīkāre ce bhikkhave āhāre  atthi rāgaḥ atthi nandī atthi taṇhā patiṭṭhitam tattha viññāṇam viruḷhanti ādi te
translated: But the five aggregates, called the last state of being, are known, and they stand without a footing, like trees with their roots cut. For a footing has no root in what is fully known. As it is said: “If, bhikkhus, there is lust, delight, craving, in the case of solid food, consciousness takes a footing there, grows, and increases” ,

original: pana pañcakkhandhā carimakaviññāṇanirodhena anupādāno viya jātavedo nibbāyissantīti abbhaññāsinti.
analyzed: pana pañca kkhandhā carimaka viññāṇa nirodhena anupādānaḥ viya jātavedo nibbāyissanti iti abbhaññāsinti
translated: and so on. But with the cessation of the last consciousness, those five aggregates will be extinguished like a fire when the firewood is consumed.

original: Paccavekkhaṇañāṇapariggahitanti na paṭhamadutiyañāṇadvayādhigamaṃ viya kevalanti
analyzed: paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇa pariggahitanti na paṭhama dutiya ñāṇa dvaya adhigamam viya kevalanti
translated: “Comprehending”: the intention is that it is not like the attainment of the first and second knowledges.

original: adhippāyo. Dassentoti nigamanavasena dassento. Sarūpato hi pubbe dassitamevāti. Sesamettha
analyzed: adhippāyaḥ dassento ti nigamana vasena dassento sarūpataḥ hi pubbe dassitam evā ti sesam ettha
translated: “Showing”: showing by way of the conclusion. For it was shown in its individual essence earlier.🔽The rest here is quite clear,

original: vuttanayattā suviññeyyameva.
analyzed: vutta naya ttā su viññeyyam eva
translated: since the method of explanation has already been given.

original: Tikkhattuṃ jātoti iminā pana idaṃ dasseti “ahaṃ, brāhmaṇa, paṭhamavijjāya jātoyeva
analyzed: tikkhattum jātaḥ iti iminā pana idam dasseti aham brāhmaṇa paṭhama vijjāya
translated: “Three times born”: by this he shows that he was born even with the first knowledge,

original: purejātassa sahajātassa vā abhāvato sabbesaṃ vuḍḍho mahallako, kimaṅgaṃ pana tīhi
analyzed: purejātassa sahajātassa vā abhāvato sabbesam vuḍḍhaḥ mahallakaḥ kim aṅgam pana tīhi
translated: Because there is no prior-arisen or simultaneous one, all are senior, elderly, and old, so how much more so the one born three times with the three knowledges?

original: vijjāhi tikkhattuṃ jātoti. Pubbenivāsañāṇena atītaṃsañāṇanti atītārammaṇasabhāgatāya
analyzed: vijjāhi tikkhattum jātaḥ ti pubbenivāsa ñāṇena atīta aṃsa ñāṇam ti atīta ārammaṇa sabhā gatāya
translated: With the knowledge of past lives, the knowledge of the past: because of the similarity of the object of past lives,

original: tabbhāvībhāvato ca pubbenivāsañāṇena atītaṃsañāṇaṃ pakāsetvāti yojetabbaṃ. Tattha🔽atītaṃsañāṇanti atītakkhandhāyatanadhātusaṅkhāte atītakoṭṭhāse appaṭihatañāṇaṃ. Dibbacakkhuñāṇassa
analyzed: tad bhāvībhāvato ca pubbenivāsa ñāṇena atīta aṃsa ñāṇam pakāsetvā iti yojetabbam tattha  atīta aṃsa ñāṇam ti atīta kkhandha āyatana dhātu saṅkhāte atīta koṭṭhāse appaṭihata ñāṇam dibba cakkhu ñāṇassa
translated: and because of the state of being its outcome, the knowledge of the past should be construed as revealed by the knowledge of past lives. Herein,🔽knowledge of the past is knowledge unobstructed as to the past portion consisting of past aggregates, bases, and elements.

original: paccuppannārammaṇattā yathākammūpagañāṇassa anāgataṃsañāṇassa ca dibbacakkhuvaseneva
analyzed: paccuppanna ārammaṇa ttā yathā kammūpaga ñāṇassa anāgataṃsa ñāṇassa ca dibba cakkhu vasena iva
translated: Because the knowledge of the divine eye has a present object, and because the knowledge of faring according to deeds and the knowledge of the future come about only by means of the divine eye,

original: ijjhanato dibbacakkhuno paribhaṇḍañāṇattā dibbacakkhumhiyeva ca ṭhitassa cetopariyañāṇasiddhito
analyzed: ijjhanataḥ dibba cakkhuno paribhaṇḍa ñāṇa ttā dibba cakkhumhiyā iva ca ṭhitassa cetas pariya ñāṇa siddhito
translated: the knowledge of the divine eye is the proximate cause for the knowledge of the future. And because the knowledge of the future is established for one who is established in the divine eye alone,

original: vuttaṃ “dibbacakkhunā paccuppannānāgataṃsañāṇa”nti. Tattha dibbacakkhunāti saparibhaṇḍena
analyzed: vuttam dibba cakkhunā paccuppanna anāgata sañāṇam ti tattha dibba cakkhunā ti sa paribhaṇḍena
translated: it is said that “the knowledge of the future is by means of the divine eye.” Herein,

original: dibbacakkhuñāṇena. Paccuppannaṃso ca anāgataṃso ca paccuppannānāgataṃsaṃ, tattha
analyzed: dibba cakkhu ñāṇena paccuppanna ṃsaḥ ca anāgata ṃsaḥ ca paccuppanna anāgata ṃsam tattha
translated: by means of the divine eye is by means of the knowledge of the divine eye together with its proximate cause. The present portion and the future portion are the present and the future. Herein,

original: ñāṇaṃ paccuppannānāgataṃsañāṇaṃ. Āsavakkhayañāṇādhigameneva sabbaññutaññāṇassa viya
analyzed: ñāṇam paccuppanna anāgata sa ñāṇam āsava kkhaya ñāṇa adhigamena iva sabbaññuta ññāṇassa viya
translated: With the attainment of the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers, the knowledge of omniscience,

original: sesāsādhāraṇañāṇadasabalañāṇaāveṇikabuddhadhammādīnampi anaññasādhāraṇānaṃ buddhaguṇānaṃ🔽ijjhanato vuttaṃ “āsavakkhayena sakalalokiyalokuttaraguṇa”nti. Tenāha “sabbepi sabbaññuguṇe pakāsetvā”ti.
analyzed: sesa a sādhāraṇa ñāṇa dasa bala ñāṇa āveṇika buddha dhamma ādīnam pi anañña sādhāraṇānam buddha guṇānam  ijjhanataḥ vuttam āsava kkhayena sakala lokiya lokuttara guṇan ti tena āha sabbe api sabbaññu guṇe pakāsetvā iti
translated: and the other special knowledges, the ten powers, the eighteen exclusive qualities of a Buddha, etc., are manifested.🔽Therefore it is said: “Having manifested all the qualities of omniscience.”

original: Āsavakkhayañāṇakathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: āsava khaya ñāṇa kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers is concluded.

original: Desanānumodanakathā
analyzed: desanā anumodana kathā
translated: The explanation of the expression of appreciation

original: 15. Pītivipphāraparipuṇṇagattacittoti pītipharaṇena paripuṇṇakāyacitto. Aññāṇanti
analyzed: pīti vipphāra paripuṇṇa gatta citto ti pīti pharaṇena paripuṇṇa kāya cittaḥ aññāṇam ti
translated: Pītivipphāraparipuṇṇagattacitto: his body and mind are filled with the expansion of rapture. Aññāṇanti

original: aññāṇassāti attho. Dhīsaddassa yogato hi sāmiatthe etaṃ upayogavacanaṃ. Abhikkantāti
analyzed: aññāṇassa ati atthaḥ dhī saddassa yogataḥ hi sāmi atthe etam upayoga vacanam abhikkanta ati
translated: means “of ignorance.” For the word dhī is used here in the sense of a master, in the sense of one who is employed. Abhikkantāti

original: ettha atikkantā, vigatāti atthoti āha “khaye dissatī”ti. Teneva hi “nikkhanto paṭhamo
analyzed: ettha atikkantā vigatā ati atthaḥ ti āha khaye dissati iti tena iva hi nikkhantaḥ paṭhamaḥ
translated: means “gone beyond,” “departed.” Therefore it is said: “The first watch is over.” Abhikkantataro cāti

original: yāmo”ti vuttaṃ. Abhikkantataro cāti ativiya kantataro manoramo, tādiso ca sundaro
analyzed: yāmaḥ ti vuttam abhikkantataro ca ati ati viya kantataro manoramo tādiso ca sundaro
translated: means “more gone beyond,” more delightful, more beautiful.

original: bhaddako nāma hotīti āha “sundare dissatī”ti. Koti devanāgayakkhagandhabbādīsu ko
analyzed: bhaddakaḥ nāma hoti iti āha sundare dissati iti ko ti deva nāga yakkha gandhabba ādīsu ko
translated: “He is called ‘blessed’ ” : he said “he is seen in a beautiful way” . Who ? Among gods, nāgas, yakkhas, gandhabbas, etc., who is he ?

original: katamo. Meti mama. Pādānīti pāde. Iddhiyāti imāya evarūpāya deviddhiyā. Yasasāti
analyzed: katamaḥ mā iti mama pādāni iti pāde iddhiyā ati imāya evarūpāya deviddhiyā yasasā ati
translated: Me : of me . Pādānī : at the feet . Iddhiyāti : by this kind of divine power . Yasas :

original: iminā edisena parivārena paricchedena. Jalanti vijjotamāno. Abhikkantenāti ativiya
analyzed: iminā edisena parivārena paricchedena jalanti vijjotamānaḥ abhikkantena ati ativiya
translated: by this kind of retinue, this kind of delimitation . Jalanti : they shine, they are radiant . Abhikkantenāti : by what is exceedingly

original: kantena kamanīyena abhirūpena. Vaṇṇenāti chavivaṇṇena sarīravaṇṇanibhāya. Sabbā obhāsayaṃ
analyzed: kantena kamanīyena abhirūpena vaṇṇena ati chavi vaṇṇena sarīra vaṇṇa nibhāya sabbāḥ obhāsayam
translated: pleasing, by what is lovely, by what is beautiful . Vaṇṇenāti : by the colour of the six colours, by the radiance of the bodily colour . Sabbā obhāsayaṃ

original: disāti dasapi disā pabhāsento cando viya sūriyo viya ca ekobhāsaṃ ekālokaṃ karontoti
analyzed: disā candaḥ viya sūriyaḥ viya ca ekobhāsam ekālokam karonto iti
translated: disāti : illuminating all the ten directions, making one light, one illumination, like the moon and like the sun .

original: gāthāya attho. Abhirūpeti uḷārarūpe sampannarūpe.🔽Abhikkantaṃ bho gotama, abhikkantaṃ bho gotamāti vacanadvayassa “sādhu sādhu bho
analyzed: gāthāya atthaḥ abhirūpā iti uḷāra rūpe sampanna rūpe  abhikkantam bho gotama abhikkantam bho gotama ati vacana dvayassa sādhu sādhu bho
translated: This is the meaning of the stanza. Abhirūpeti : in a very beautiful form, in a perfect form .🔽“Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent, Master Gotama!” : having shown the meaning of the two statements by way of the addition “Good, Master Gotama!

original: gotamā”ti āmeḍitavasena atthaṃ dassetvā tassa visayaṃ niddhārento āha “bhaye kodhe”tiādi.
analyzed: gotama ti āmeḍita vasena attham dassetvā tassa visayam niddhārentaḥ āha bhaye kodha itiādi
translated: Good, Master Gotama!” , he elucidated their province by saying “In fear, in anger” , etc.

original: Tattha “coro coro, sappo sappo”tiādīsu bhaye āmeḍitaṃ. “Vijjha vijjha, pahara paharā”tiādīsu
analyzed: tattha coro coro sappo sappo iti ādīsu bhaye āmeḍitam vijjha vijjha pahara pahara ati ādīsu
translated: Herein, in such passages as “A thief, a thief! A snake, a snake!” there is urgency in fear.🔽In such passages as “Strike, strike!” there is urgency in anger.

original: kodhe. “Sādhu sādhū”tiādīsu pasaṃsāyaṃ. “Gaccha gaccha, lunāhi lunāhī”tiādīsu turite.🔽“Āgaccha āgacchā”tiādīsu kotūhale. “Buddho buddhoti cintento”tiādīsu acchare. “Abhikkamathāyasmanto,
analyzed: kodhe sādhu sādhu itiādīsu gaccha gaccha lunāhi lunāhi itiādīsu turite  āgaccha āgaccha atiādīsu kotūhale buddhaḥ buddhaḥ iti cintentaḥ iti ādīsu acchare
translated: In such passages as “Good, good!” there is urgency in praise. In such passages as “Go, go! Cut, cut!” there is urgency in haste.

original: abhikkamathāyasmanto”tiādīsu hāse. “Kahaṃ ekaputtaka, kahaṃ ekaputtakā”tiādīsu soke.🔽“Aho sukhaṃ, aho sukha”ntiādīsu pasāde. Ca-saddo avuttasamuccayattho. Tena garahaasammānādīnaṃ
analyzed: abhikkamatha ayasmantaḥ iti ādīsu hāse kaham eka puttaka kaham eka puttaka ati ādīsu soke  aho sukham aho sukham ti ādīsu pasāde ca saddo avutta samuccaya tthaḥ tena gara ha asammāna ādīnam
translated: In such passages as “Come, come!” there is urgency in eagerness. In such passages as “Thinking ‘Buddha, Buddha!’” there is urgency in amazement. In such passages as “Come forth, venerable sirs, come forth, venerable sirs!” there is urgency in laughter. In such passages as “Where is my only son? Where is my only son?” there is urgency in grief.🔽In such passages as “Oh, what bliss! Oh, what bliss!” there is urgency in confidence. The word “ca” has the meaning of “and” and “also.” Therefore censure, contempt, etc., should be seen as included by it.

original: saṅgaho daṭṭhabbo. Tattha “pāpo pāpo”tiādīsu garahāyaṃ. “Abhirūpaka abhirūpakā”tiādīsu
analyzed: saṅgahaḥ daṭṭhabbo tattha pāpaḥ pāpa iti ādīsu garahā ayam abhirūpaka abhirūpaka ati ādīsu
translated: Herein, in such passages as “A sinner, a sinner!” there is urgency in censure. In such passages as “Handsome, handsome!”

original: asammāne daṭṭhabbaṃ.
analyzed: a sammāne daṭṭhabbam
translated: it should be seen as urgency in contempt.

original: Nayidaṃ āmeḍitavasena dvikkhattuṃ vuttaṃ, atha kho atthadvayavasenāti dassento “atha
analyzed: na yidam āma eḍita vasena dvi kkhattum vuttam atha kho attha dvaya vasena ati dassento atha
translated: It is not said twice in this way by way of urgency, but rather by way of a twofold meaning. Showing this, he says “then,

original: vā”tiādimāha. Abhikkantanti vacanaṃ apekkhitvā napuṃsakaliṅgavasena vuttaṃ. Taṃ pana
analyzed: vā ti ādim āha abhikkantam iti vacanam apekkhitvā napuṃsaka liṅga vasena vuttam tam pana
translated: and so on. The word abhikkanta is in the neuter gender, in view of the word vacanam.

original: bhagavato vacanaṃ dhammassa desanāti katvā vuttaṃ “yadidaṃ bhoto gotamassa dhammadesanā”ti.
analyzed: bhagavataḥ vacanam dhammassa desanā ati katvā vuttam yat idam bhoto gotamassa dhamma desanā ati
translated: But it is said: “The teaching of the Dhamma by Master Gotama,” in view of the fact that the Blessed One’s word is the teaching of the Dhamma.

original: Atthamattadassanaṃ vā etaṃ, tasmā atthavasena liṅgavibhattivipariṇāmo veditabbo.🔽Dutiyapadepi eseva nayo. Dosanāsanatoti rāgādikilesaviddhaṃsanato. Guṇādhigamanatoti
analyzed: attham atta dassanam vai etam tasmai attha vasena liṅga vibhatti vipariṇāmaḥ veditabbo  dutiya pade pi esa iva nayaḥ rāga ādi kilesa vid haṃsanataḥ guṇa adhigamanataḥ iti
translated: Or it is said in this way in order to show the mere meaning, and therefore the change of gender and case should be understood according to the meaning.🔽The same method applies to the second phrase.

original: sīlādiguṇānaṃ sampāpanato. Ye guṇe desanā adhigameti, tesu padhānabhūtā guṇā dassetabbāti
analyzed: sīla ādi guṇānam sampāpanataḥ ye guṇe desanā adhigameti tesu padhāna bhūtāḥ guṇāḥ dassetabbā ati
translated: The word dosanāsanato is derived from the verbal root nas, to destroy, and means “by the destruction of lust, etc.” The word guṇādhigamanato is derived from the verbal root gam, to go, and means “by the attainment of the special qualities of virtue, etc.” The special qualities of virtue, etc., are shown as the chief among the special qualities that the teaching of the Dhamma causes to be attained.

original: te padhānabhūte guṇe tāva dassetuṃ “saddhājananato paññājananato”ti vuttaṃ. Saddhāpamukhā
analyzed: te padhāna bhūte guṇe tāva dassetum saddhā jananataḥ paññā jananataḥ ti vuttam saddhā pamukhā
translated: In order to show the special qualities that are chief among them, the text says: “because it causes faith to arise, because it causes understanding to arise.”🔽For the mundane special qualities are headed by faith, and the supramundane special qualities are headed by understanding.

original: hi lokiyā guṇā, paññāpamukhā lokuttarā. Sātthatotiādīsu sīlādiatthasampattiyā sātthato,
analyzed: hi lokiyā guṇā paññā apamukhā lokuttarā sātthato tiādīsu sīla ādi attha sampattiyā sātthato
translated: The word sātthato is derived from the verbal root as, to be, and means “having the meaning of virtue, etc.”

original: sabhāvaniruttisampattiyā sabyañjanato. Suviññeyyasaddappayogatāya uttānapadato, saṇhasukhumabhāvena
analyzed: sabhāva nirutti sampattiyā sa byañjanataḥ su viññeyya sadda payogatāya uttāna padataḥ saṇha sukhuma bhāvena
translated: and by the perfection of its inherent nature, by its having the letters. It is in plain text by the use of easy-to-understand words.

original: duviññeyyatthatāya gambhīratthato. Siniddhamudumadhurasaddappayogatāya kaṇṇasukhato,
analyzed: du viññeyya attha tāya gambhīra atthataḥ siniddha mudu madhura sadda ppayoga tāya kaṇṇa sukhataḥ
translated: It is of profound meaning by the difficulty of understanding it in its twofold sense of letter and meaning.🔽It is pleasant to the ear by the use of words that are smooth, soft, and sweet.

original: vipulavisuddhapemanīyatthatāya hadayaṅgamato. Mānātimānavidhamanena anattukkaṃsanato,
analyzed: vipula visuddha pemanīya ttha tāya hadayaṅgamataḥ māna ati māna vidhamanena anattukkaṃsanataḥ
translated: It is heart-winning by its being extensive, pure, and lovable. It is not self- praising by the removal of conceit and pride.

original: thambhasārambhanimmaddanena aparavambhanato. Hitādhippāyappavattiyā paresaṃ rāgapariḷāhādivūpasamanena
analyzed: thambha sārambha nimmaddanena apara vambhanataḥ hita adhippāya ppavattiyā paresam rāga pariḷāha ādi vūpasamanena
translated: It is not contemptuous of others by the removal of stiffness and arrogance. It is cool with loving-kindness by the removal of lust, hate, etc., in others through the practice of the thought of good will.

original: karuṇāsītalato, kilesandhakāravidhamanena paññāvadātato. Karavīkarutamañjutāya āpātharamaṇīyato,
analyzed: karuṇā sītalataḥ kilesa andhakāra vidhamanena paññā avadātataḥ karavīka ruta mañju tāya āpātha ramaṇīyato
translated: It is bright with understanding by the removal of the darkness of defilement. It is lovely to hear by the loveliness of its sound like the cuckoo’s call.

original: pubbāparāviruddhasuvisuddhatthatāya vimaddakkhamato. Āpātharamaṇīyatāya eva suyyamānasukhato,🔽vimaddakkhamatāya hitajjhāsayappavattitāya ca vīmaṃsiyamānahitatoti evamattho veditabbo.
analyzed: pubba apara aviruddha su visuddha attha tāya vimadda khamataḥ āpātha ramaṇīya tāya eva suyyamāna sukhataḥ 🔽vimadda khama tāya hita ajjhāsaya ppavatti tāya ca vīmaṃsiyamāna hitato ti evamatthaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: It is pleasant to reflect upon by its being pure and free from internal contradiction. It is good for one’s heart by its being suitable for reflection and by its being the practice of a benevolent disposition.

translated: The duties of one who has gone for refuge are the duties that should be done by one who has gone for refuge. The word iti in the words saraṇam-gacchāmi is a demonstrative particle.

original: āha “saraṇanti gacchāmī”ti. Ettha hi nāyaṃ gamisaddo nīsaddādayo viya dvikammako,
analyzed: āha saraṇanti gacchāmi iti ettha hi na ayam gami saddaḥ nī sadda ādayaḥ viya dvi kammako
translated: Therefore it is said: ‘saraṇam-gacchāmī’ . For here this word gacchāmi is not a verb of two-fold function like the word nīsaddādayo .

original: tasmā yathā ajaṃ gāmaṃ netīti vuccati, evaṃ “gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmī”ti vattuṃ na🔽sakkā, “saraṇanti gacchāmī”ti pana vattabbaṃ, tasmā ettha iti-saddo luttaniddiṭṭhoti🔽veditabbaṃ. analyzed: tasmai yathā ajam gāmam neti iti vuccati evam gotamam saraṇam gacchāmi iti vattum na  sakkā saraṇanti gacchāmi iti pana vattabbam tasmai ettha iti saddaḥ lutta niddiṭṭhaḥ ti  veditabbam saraṇam ti paṭisaraṇam tena āha parāyaṇam ti parāyaṇa bhāvaḥ ca anattha nisedhanena  attha sampaṭipādanena ca hoti iti āha aghassa tātā hitassa ca vidhātā ati aghassa ati
translated: Therefore, just as it is said that one leads a goat to the village, so it is not possible to say “I go for refuge to Gotama,”🔽but it is necessary to say “I go for refuge to the Buddha,” therefore here the word iti should be understood as a demonstrative pronoun.🔽The word saraṇa means a refuge. Therefore it is said “parāyaṇa.” And the state of being a refuge is due to the prevention of harm🔽and the provision of benefit. Therefore it is said “the provider of safety and the bestower of welfare.” Aghassa means🔽

original: dukkhatoti vadanti, pāpatoti pana attho yutto, nissakke cetaṃ sāmivacanaṃ. Saraṇanti🔽gamanañcettha tadadhippāyena bhajanaṃ tathā jānanaṃ vāti dassento “iti iminā adhippāyenā”tiādimāha.
analyzed: dukkhato ti vadanti pāpato ti pana atthaḥ yuttaḥ nissakke ca itam sāmi vacanam saraṇan ti  gamanam ca ittha tad adhippāyena bhajanam tathā jānanam vā ati dassentaḥ iti iminā adhippāyena ati ādim āha
translated: Therefore, just as it is said that one leads a goat to the village, so it is not possible to say “I go for refuge to Gotama.” But it is possible to say “I go for refuge.” Therefore, here the word iti should be understood as a particle. The meaning of saraṇa is a refuge. Therefore it is said “parāyaṇa.” And the state of being a refuge is due to the prevention of harm and the provision of benefit. Therefore it is said “the protector from evil and the provider of welfare.” The word aghassa is an accusative of the word aghā. But the meaning of pāpa is appropriate. This is a possessive form. The meaning of saraṇa is going. Here, by the intention of that, it is the understanding of it as such. Showing this, he said “by this intention.”

original: Tattha gacchāmītiādīsu purimassa purimassa pacchimaṃ pacchimaṃ atthavacanaṃ. Bhajanaṃ
analyzed: tattha gacchāmi iti ādīsu purimassa purimassa pacchimam pacchimam attha vacanam bhajanam
translated: Herein, in the words gacchāmi, etc., the meaning of each subsequent word is the meaning of the preceding word.

original: vā saraṇādhippāyena upasaṅkamanaṃ, sevanā santikāvacaratā, payirupāsanaṃ vattappaṭivattakaraṇena
analyzed: vā saraṇa adhippāyena upasaṅkamanam sevanā santika avacara tā payirupāsanam vatta paṭivatta karaṇena
translated: The meaning of the words “I go for refuge” is the going for refuge by the mere act of approaching the Buddha with the desire to go for refuge. “Serving” is the state of being a follower by frequenting him. “Honouring” is the state of being a follower by rendering service.🔽“Attending” is the state of being a follower by attending on him. Thus all these terms indicate the state of being a follower by not going to anyone else for refuge.

original: upaṭṭhānanti evaṃ sabbathāpi anaññasaraṇataṃyeva dīpeti. Gacchāmīti padassa kathaṃ
analyzed: upaṭṭhānam ti evam sabbathā api anañña saraṇataṃyā iva dīpeti gacchāmi iti padassa katham
translated: How can the meaning of the words “I go for refuge” be taken to be “I awaken to”?

original: bujjhāmīti ayamattho labbhatīti āha “yesaṃ hī”tiādi.
analyzed: bujjhāmi iti ayam atthaḥ labbhati iti āha yesam hi itiādi
translated: The meaning of the words “I go for refuge” can be taken to be “I awaken to” in the way stated in the following sutta: “Bhikkhus, when a bhikkhu is an arahant, one whose taints are destroyed, who has lived the holy life, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, reached his own goal, utterly destroyed the fetters of existence, and is completely liberated through final knowledge, he is called one who has awakened to the incomparable safe haven, who has awakened to the unsurpassed safe haven” .

original: Adhigatamagge sacchikatanirodheti padadvayenapi phalaṭṭhā eva dassitā, na maggaṭṭhāti
analyzed: adhigata magge sacchikata nirodhā iti pada dvayena api phala ṭṭhā eva dassitā na magga ṭṭhā ti
translated: The two terms “the path that has been penetrated” and “the cessation that has been realized” also indicate only the fruit-attainer, not the path-attainer.🔽To show this he says, “and in those who are practising in accordance with the teaching.”

original: te dassento “yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipajjamāne cā”ti āha. Nanu ca kalyāṇaputhujjanopi🔽yathānusiṭṭhaṃ paṭipajjatīti vuccatīti? Kiñcāpi vuccati, nippariyāyena pana maggaṭṭhā🔽eva tathā vattabbā, na itare niyāmokkamanābhāvato. Tathā hi te eva “apāyesu apatamāne
analyzed: te dassentaḥ yathānusiṭṭham paṭipajjamāne ca ati āha nanu ca kalyāṇa puthujjanaḥ api  yathānusiṭṭham paṭipajjati iti vuccati iti kiñcā api vuccati nippariyāyena pana magga ṭṭhā  eva tathā vattabbāḥ na itare niyāma ukkamana abhāvataḥ tathā hi te eva apāyesu a patamāne
translated: But isn’t it said that the good worldling too practises in accordance with the teaching?🔽Although it is said, it is only the path-attainer who should be called a “practiser” in the strict sense of the word, not the others, because they do not enter upon the fixed course .🔽For they are called “those who do not fall into states of woe” .

original: dhāretī”ti vuttā. Sammattaniyāmokkamanena hi apāyavinimuttasambhavo. Akkhāyatīti
analyzed: dhāreti iti vuttā sammatta niyāma ukkamanena hi apāya vinimutta sambhavaḥ akkhāyati iti
translated: And it is only by entering upon the fixed course that one becomes capable of being free from states of woe. “Is proclaimed” .

analyzed: ettha iti saddaḥ ādi atthaḥ pakāra atthaḥ vā tena yāvatā bhikkhave dhammā saṅkhatā
translated: Thus it includes the sutta passage: “Bhikkhus, in so far as there are dhammas, whether formed or unformed,

original: vā asaṅkhatā vā, virāgo tesaṃ aggamakkhāyatī”ti suttapadaṃ saṅgaṇhāti, “vitthāro”ti🔽vā iminā. Ettha ca ariyamaggo niyyānikatāya, nibbānaṃ tassa tadatthasiddhihetutāyāti
analyzed: vā asaṅkhatā vā virāgo tesam aggam akkhāyati iti sutta padam saṅgaṇhāti vitthāro ti  vā iminā ettha ca ariya maggo niyyānika tāya nibbānam tassa tad attha siddhi hetu tāya ati
translated: the fading away of lust is declared to be their chief” , or it includes the word “elaboration” .🔽And here the noble path is called “Dhamma” in the true sense of the word because it leads out , and Nibbāna because it is the cause for the establishment of the path’s purpose.

original: ubhayameva nippariyāyena dhammoti vutto. Nibbānañhi ārammaṇapaccayabhūtaṃ labhitvā
analyzed: ubhayam eva nippariyāyena dhammaḥ ti vuttaḥ nibbānam hi ārammaṇa paccaya bhūtam labhitvā
translated: For it is by obtaining Nibbāna as object condition that the noble path establishes its purpose.

original: ariyamaggassa tadatthasiddhi, tathāpi ariyaphalānaṃ “yasmā tāya saddhāya avūpasantāyā”tiādivacanato🔽maggena samucchinnānaṃ kilesānaṃ paṭippassaddhippahānakiccatāya niyyānānuguṇatāya
analyzed: ariya maggassa tathā api yasmā tāya saddhāya a vūpasantāya ati ādi vacanataḥ  maggena samucchinnānam kilesānam paṭippassaddhi ppahāna kicca tāya niyyāna anuguṇa tāya
translated: And although it is so, still the fruit of stream-entry is called “Dhamma” in the true sense of the word because it is the cause for the attainment of the Dhamma that leads out, since it is said: “Because that faith is not yet settled” ,

original: niyyānapariyosānatāya ca. Pariyattidhammassa pana niyyānadhammasamadhigamahetutāyāti
analyzed: niyyāna pariyosāna tāya ca pariyatti dhammassa pana niyyāna dhamma samadhigama hetu tāya ati
translated: and because it is the cause for the attainment of the Dhamma that leads out, since it is the cause for the attainment of the path, which is the cause for the abandonment by substitution of opposites of the defilements cut off by the path, and since it is the cause for the attainment of the Dhamma that leads out, since it is the culmination of the leading out.🔽But the Dhamma of the scriptures is called “Dhamma” in the figurative sense because it is the cause for the attainment of the Dhamma that leads out.

original: iminā pariyāyena vuttanayena dhammabhāvo labbhati eva, svāyamattho pāṭhāruḷho evāti
analyzed: iminā pariyāyena vutta nayena dhamma bhāvaḥ labbhati eva pāṭha āruḷhaḥ evā ati
translated: So the state of being Dhamma is obtained in this way, in the way stated, and this meaning is evident in the texts.

original: dassento “na kevala”ntiādimāha.🔽Rāgavirāgoti maggo kathitoti kāmarāgo bhavarāgoti evamādibhedo sabbopi rāgo virajjati🔽pahīyati etenāti rāgavirāgoti maggo kathito. Anejamasokanti phalanti ejāsaṅkhātāya
analyzed: na kevala nti ādim āha  rāga virāgaḥ ti maggo kathito ti kāma rāgaḥ bhava rāgaḥ iti evamādi bhedaḥ sabbaḥ api rāgaḥ virajjati  pahīyati etena ati rāga virāgaḥ ti maggo kathito phalanti ejā saṅkhātāya
translated: “Not only” he says, in order to show that.🔽“The path is said to be the fading away of lust”: all lust is said to be of the kinds of lust for sense desires and lust for becoming, etc.;🔽it fades away, is abandoned, by means of this, thus it is the fading away of lust.

original: taṇhāya antonijjhānalakkhaṇassa sokassa ca taduppattiyaṃ sabbaso parikkhīṇattā anejamasokanti
analyzed: taṇhāya antar nijjhāna lakkhaṇassa sokassa ca tad uppattiyam sabbaso parikkhīṇa ttā
translated: “The fruit is said to be the absence of grief and the absence of fear”: because craving, which is called “grief,” has the characteristic of burning inside, and because there is complete exhaustion of the arising of grief,🔽the fruit is said to be the absence of grief.

original: phalaṃ kathitaṃ. Appaṭikūlanti avirodhadīpanato kenaci aviruddhaṃ, iṭṭhaṃ paṇītanti

original: vā attho. Paguṇarūpena pavattitattā, pakaṭṭhaguṇavibhāvanato vā paguṇaṃ. Yathāha
analyzed: vā paguṇa rūpena pavatti tattā pakaṭṭha guṇa vibhāvanataḥ vā paguṇam yathā āha
translated: It is “excellent” because it occurs in the form of what is excellent, or because it manifests excellent qualities, as it is said:

original: “vihiṃsasaññī paguṇaṃ nabhāsiṃ, dhammaṃ paṇītaṃ manujesu brahme”ti. Sabbadhammakkhandhā
analyzed: vihiṃsa saññī paguṇam nabha asim dhammam paṇītam manujesu brahmā iti sabba dhamma kkhandhāḥ
translated: “I did not speak of the excellent Dhamma among men, O Brahmā, perceiving it as harmful” .🔽“The aggregates of all dhammas are said” is the construction.
