analyzed: kathitā ati yojanā diṭṭhi sīla saṅghātena ati yā ayam diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa
translated: “By the yoke of view and virtue”: the view that is noble, leading out , leading out to the complete destruction of suffering,

original: sammā dukkhakkhayāya, tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhisāmaññagato viharatī”ti evaṃ vuttāya🔽diṭṭhiyā “yāni tāni sīlāni akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni asabalāni akammāsāni bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni🔽aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhisaṃvattanikāni, tathārūpehi sīlehi sīlasāmaññagato viharatī”ti
analyzed: sammā dukkha kkhayāya tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhi sāmañña gataḥ viharati iti evam vuttāya  diṭṭhiyā yāni tāni sīlāni akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni a sabalāni a kammāsāni bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni  aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhi saṃvattanikāni tathārūpehi sīlehi sīla sāmañña gataḥ viharati iti
translated: “He lives with a view that accords with that view, a view that is in conformity with it, a view that is in accordance with it, a view that is in agreement with it, a view that is in harmony with it, a view that is in conformity with rightness, a view that is in conformity with the way things are, a view that is in conformity with knowledge, a view that is in conformity with the way things are and with knowledge, a view that leads to the complete destruction of suffering.”🔽“He lives with virtue that accords with that view, virtue that is in conformity with it, virtue that is in accordance with it, virtue that is in agreement with it, virtue that is in harmony with it, virtue that is in conformity with rightness, virtue that is in conformity with the way things are, virtue that is in conformity with knowledge, virtue that is in conformity with the way things are and with knowledge, virtue that leads to the complete destruction of suffering.”🔽The meaning is that he lives with virtue that accords with the view stated in this way and with the virtue stated in the way beginning, “These rules of training are not broken by anyone, not violated by anyone, not despised by anyone, not trampled upon by anyone, but observed, undertaken and lived by him.”

original: evaṃ vuttānaṃ sīlānañca saṃhatabhāvena, diṭṭhisīlasāmaññenāti attho. Saṃhatoti ghaṭito,
analyzed: evam vuttānam sīlānam ca saṃhata bhāvena diṭṭhi sīla sāmaññena ati atthaḥ saṃhataḥ ti ghaṭito
translated: “United” means combined.

original: sametoti attho. Ariyapuggalā hi yattha katthaci dūre ṭhitāpi attano guṇasāmaggiyā🔽saṃhatā eva. Aṭṭha ca puggalā dhammadasā teti purisayugaḷavasena cattāropi puggalavasena
analyzed: sametā iti atthaḥ ariya puggalāḥ hi yattha katthaci dūre ṭhitā api attanaḥ guṇa sāmaggiyā  saṃhatāḥ eva aṭṭha ca puggalāḥ dhamma dasā te ti purisa yugaḷa vasena cattāro api puggala vasena
translated: The meaning is that they are mixed together. For the noble persons, wherever they may be, even though they are far away, are united by the unity of their special qualities.🔽And the eight persons who see the Dhamma, the four pairs, are “seers of the Dhamma” because they have seen the noble Dhamma with the eye of understanding.

original: aṭṭheva ariyadhammassa paccakkhadassāvitāya dhammadasā. Tīṇi vatthūni saraṇanti gamanena
analyzed: aṭṭha iva ariya dhammassa paccakkha dassāvitāya dhamma dasā tīṇi vatthūni gamanena
translated: “They have gone for refuge in the three objects” means that they have gone for refuge by means of the going for refuge.

original: tikkhattuṃ gamanena ca tīṇi saraṇagamanāni. Paṭivedesīti attano hadayaṅgataṃ vācāya pavedesi.
analyzed: tikkhattum gamanena ca tīṇi saraṇa gamanāni paṭivedesi iti attanaḥ hadayaṅgatam vācāya pavedesi
translated: and by the going for refuge three times, the three goings for refuge. He announced: he made known what was in his heart by speech.

original: Pasannākārakathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: pasanna ākāra kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Discussion of the Marks of Confidence is ended

original: Saraṇagamanakathā
analyzed: saraṇa gamana kathā
translated: The Discussion of Going for Refuge

original: Saraṇagamanassa visayappabhedaphalasaṃkilesabhedānaṃ viya kattu ca vibhāvanā tattha
analyzed: saraṇa gamanassa visaya ppabheda phala saṃkilesa bhedānam viya kattu ca vibhāvanā tattha
translated: As in the case of the classification of the object, the fruit, and the defilement of the going for refuge, so too the exposition of the doing should be known here for the sake of skill in the goings for refuge.

original: kosallāya hotīti “saraṇagamanesu kosallatthaṃ saraṇaṃ…pe… veditabbo”ti vuttaṃ tena
analyzed: kosallāya hoti iti saraṇa gamanesu kosalla attham saraṇaṃpe veditabbaḥ iti vuttam tena
translated: This is why it was said above: “The going for refuge should be understood as the going for refuge in the Three Jewels … for the sake of skill in the goings for refuge” .

original: vinā saraṇagamanasseva asambhavato. Tattha saraṇanti padatthato tāva hiṃsatīti saraṇaṃ.
analyzed: vinā saraṇa gamanassa iva asambhavataḥ tattha saraṇam ti padatthato tāva hiṃsati iti saraṇam
translated: For without that the going for refuge itself is impossible. Herein, as to the meaning of the word saraṇa : it shelters , thus it is a refuge ;

original: Hiṃsatthassa hi sarasaddassa vasenetaṃ padaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, tasmā saraṇagatānaṃ teneva
analyzed: hiṃsa atthassa hi sara saddassa vasena itam padam daṭṭhabbam tasmā saraṇa gatānam tena iva
translated: for this word should be regarded as derived from the verbal root śri with the preposition upa ;

original: saraṇagamanena vaṭṭabhayaṃ cittutrāsaṃ kāyikaṃ dukkhaṃ duggatipariyāpannaṃ sabbampi
analyzed: saraṇa gamanena vaṭṭa bhayam cittu trāsam kāyikam dukkham duggati pariyāpannam sabbam pi
translated: so it kills , destroys, all fear of the round of rebirths, all mental worry, all bodily suffering, and all suffering classed as “ bad destination ” .

original: dukkhaṃ hanati, vināsetīti attho. Ratanattayassevetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Atha vā hite pavattanena
analyzed: dukkham hanati vināseti iti atthaḥ adhivacanam atha vā hite pavattanena
translated: This is the meaning. It is a name for the Triple Gem. Or alternatively, it is a name for the three gems of virtue, concentration, and understanding, which are the refuge of those who go for refuge, since they are the way to the blissful states.

original: “sampannasīlā, bhikkhave, viharathā”tiādinā atthe niyojanena ahitā ca nivattanena
analyzed: sampanna sīlāḥ bhikkhave viharatha atiādinā atthe niyojanena ahitā ca nivattanena
translated: “Live with perfect virtue” , etc., by directing to the goal, and by turning away from what is harmful,

original: “pāṇātipātassa kho pana pāpako vipāko, pāpakaṃ abhisamparāya”ntiādinā ādīnavadassanādimukhena🔽anatthato nivattanena sattānaṃ bhayaṃ hiṃsati, hitāhitesu appavattipavattihetukaṃ
analyzed: pāṇātipātassa kho pana pāpakaḥ vipākaḥ pāpakam abhisamparāyanti ādinā ādīnava dassana ādi mukhena  anatthataḥ nivattanena sattānam bhayam hiṃsati hita ahitesu appavatti pavatti hetukam
translated: “The result of killing living beings is evil, the outcome is evil” , etc., by showing the danger, and so on,

original: byasanaṃ apavattikaraṇena vināseti buddho. Bhavakantārauttaraṇena maggasaṅkhāto dhammo🔽sattānaṃ bhayaṃ hiṃsati, itaro assāsadānena. Appakānampi dānavasena pūjāvasena ca
analyzed: byasanam apavatti karaṇena buddhaḥ bhava kantāra auttaraṇena magga saṅkhātaḥ dhammaḥ  sattānam bhayam hiṃsati itaraḥ appakānam pi dāna vasena pūjā vasena ca
translated: and by turning away from what is harmful, the Enlightened One destroys the fear of beings, which is the cause of their not avoiding what is harmful and of their pursuing what is harmful. And the Dhamma, which is called the path, destroys the fear of beings by causing them to avoid the wilderness of existence.🔽The other , the Community, destroys the fear of beings by causing them to avoid the fear of want, which is the cause of their not avoiding and pursuing, and by causing them to avoid the fear of despair, which is the cause of their not avoiding and pursuing.

original: upanītānaṃ sakkārānaṃ vipulaphalapaṭilābhakaraṇena sattānaṃ bhayaṃ hiṃsati saṅgho🔽anuttaradakkhiṇeyyabhāvato, tasmā imināpi vibhajitvā vuttapariyāyena ratanattayaṃ
analyzed: upanītānam vipula phala paṭilābha karaṇena sattānam bhayam hiṃsati saṅghaḥ 🔽an uttara dakkhiṇeyya bhāvataḥ tasmai iminā api vibhajitvā vutta pariyāyena
translated: And the Community destroys the fear of beings by causing them to obtain a great fruit from the little they give, by causing them to avoid the fear of want, which is the cause of their not avoiding and pursuing, and by causing them to avoid the fear of despair, which is the cause of their not avoiding and pursuing.🔽The Community destroys the fear of beings by causing them to avoid the fear of want, which is the cause of their not avoiding and pursuing, and by causing them to avoid the fear of despair, which is the cause of their not avoiding and pursuing, and by causing them to avoid the fear of death, which is the cause of their not avoiding and pursuing.🔽The Community destroys the fear of beings by causing them to avoid the fear of want, which is the cause of their not avoiding and pursuing, and by causing them to avoid the fear of despair, which is the cause of their not avoiding and pursuing, and by causing them to avoid the fear of death, which is the cause of their not avoiding and pursuing, and by causing them to avoid the fear of the loss of the true faith, which is the cause of their not avoiding and pursuing.

original: saraṇaṃ. “Sammāsambuddho bhagavā, svākkhāto dhammo, suppaṭipanno saṅgho”ti evaṃ pavattaratanattayapasaādataggarukatāhi
analyzed: saraṇam sammāsambuddhaḥ bhagavā su ākkhātaḥ dhammo su paṭipanno saṅghaḥ ti evam pavatta ratana ttaya pasaāda taggaruka tāhi
translated: and the Sangha. The going for refuge is the arising of consciousness in the mode of taking the Triple Gem as one’s supreme resort, which occurs through the act of generating the thought: “The Blessed One is the Fully Enlightened One, the Dhamma is well-expounded, the Sangha is practising the good way.”

original: vidhutadiṭṭhivicikicchāsammohaassaddhiyāditāya vihatakileso tadeva ratanattayaṃ saraṇaṃ🔽parāyaṇaṃ gati tāṇaṃ leṇanti evaṃ pavattiyā tapparāyaṇatākārappavatto cittuppādo🔽saraṇagamanaṃ saraṇanti gacchati etenāti katvā. Tena yathāvuttacittuppādena samannāgato
analyzed: vidhuta diṭṭhi vicikicchā sammoha assaddhi yā āditāya vihata kilesaḥ tat eva saraṇam  parāyaṇam tāṇam evam pavattiyā tad parāyaṇa tā ākāra ppavatto cittuppādo  saraṇa gamanam saraṇanti gacchati etena ati katvā tena yathā vutta cittuppādena samannāgataḥ
translated: The person who goes for refuge is one who has dispelled the defilements of wrong view, doubt, confusion, lack of faith, etc., and who has taken the Triple Gem as his supreme resort.

original: satto saraṇanti gacchati, vuttappakārena cittuppādena “etāni me tīṇi ratanāni saraṇaṃ,
analyzed: satto saraṇanti gacchati vutta ppakārena cittuppādena etāni me tīṇi ratanāni saraṇam
translated: The going for refuge is the arising of consciousness in the mode of taking the Triple Gem as one’s supreme resort, which occurs through the act of generating the thought: “I take the Triple Gem as my refuge, as my supreme resort, my protection, my shelter, my final ally.”🔽The person who possesses the consciousness that arises in the mode of taking the Triple Gem as one’s supreme resort is one who goes for refuge.

original: etāni parāyaṇa”nti evaṃ upeti bhajati sevati payirupāsati, evaṃ vā jānāti, bujjhatīti
analyzed: etāni evam upeti bhajati sevati payirupāsati evam vā jānāti bujjhati iti
translated: He goes for refuge by means of the consciousness that arises in the mode of taking the Triple Gem as one’s supreme resort, by means of which he approaches, resorts to, serves, venerates, and knows, or understands, the Triple Gem in the way described.

original: attho. Evaṃ tāva saraṇaṃ, saraṇagamanaṃ, yo ca saraṇaṃ gacchati, idaṃ tayaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: evam tāva saraṇam saraṇa gamanam yaḥ ca saraṇam gacchati idam tayam veditabbam
translated: This, firstly, is how the refuge, the going for refuge, and the person who goes for refuge should be understood.

analyzed: saraṇa gamana ppabhede pana duvidham saraṇa gamanam lokuttaram lokiyam ca tattha lokuttaram
translated: In the classification of going for refuge, however, there are two kinds of going for refuge, namely, supramundane and mundane. Herein, the supramundane

analyzed: diṭṭha saccānam magga kkhaṇe saraṇa gamana upakkilesa samucchedanena ārammaṇataḥ nibbāna ārammaṇam

analyzed: hutvā kiccataḥ sakale api rata nattaye ijjhati atthataḥ catu sacca adhigamaḥ eva hi lokuttara saraṇa gamanam
translated: As to function, it succeeds in the whole Triple Gem. For the attainment of the four noble truths is itself the supramundane going for refuge.

original: Tattha hi nibbānadhammo sacchikiriyābhisamayavasena, maggadhammo bhāvanābhisamayavasena🔽paṭivijjhiyamānoyeva saraṇagamanatthaṃ sādheti, buddhaguṇā pana sāvakagocarabhūtā
analyzed: tattha hi nibbāna dhammo sacchikiriyā abhisamaya vasena magga dhammo bhāvanā abhisamaya vasena  paṭivijjhiyamānā yā iva saraṇa gamana attham sādheti buddha guṇā pana sāvaka gocara bhūtā
translated: Herein, the state of Nibbāna succeeds as the going for refuge by penetrating it by way of the realization of the fruit of stream-entry, etc., and the state of the path succeeds by penetrating it by way of the realization of development.

original: pariññābhisamayavasena, tathā ariyasaṅghaguṇā. Tena vuttaṃ “kiccato sakalepi ratanattaye
analyzed: pariññā abhisamaya vasena tathā ariya saṅgha guṇā tena vuttam kiccato sakale api rata nattaye
translated: But the special qualities of the Buddha, which are the province of disciples, succeed as the going for refuge by penetrating them by way of the realization of full understanding. Likewise the special qualities of the ariyan community. That is why it is said that as to function it succeeds in the whole Triple Gem.

original: ijjhatī”ti. Ijjhantañca saheva ijjhati, na lokiyaṃ viya paṭipāṭiyā asammohapaṭivedhena
analyzed: ijjhati iti ijjhantam ca saha iva ijjhati na lokiyam asammoha paṭivedhena
translated: And it succeeds simultaneously, not successively like the mundane going for refuge, by way of the penetration of non-delusion.

analyzed: paṭividdha ttā ye pana vadanti na saraṇa gamanam nibbāna ārammaṇam hutvā pavattati
translated: But those who say that the going for refuge does not occur with Nibbāna as its object,🔽but that it is only attained when the path is attained, like the mundane knowledge of the three kinds of supernormal power, etc.,

analyzed: maggassa adhigata ttā pana adhigatam eva hoti ekaccānam tevijja ādīnam lokiya vijja ādayaḥ  viyāti tesam lokiyam eva saraṇa gamanam siyā na lokuttaram tat ca ayuttam duvidhassa api
translated: of some who have attained the path, have a mundane going for refuge only, not a supramundane one.🔽And that is illogical, because both kinds are required.🔽But the mundane going for refuge succeeds by way of the object, with the special qualities of the Buddha, etc., as its object, in the case of ordinary people by suppressing the defilements that are impediments to the going for refuge.🔽In the case of the noble person it succeeds by way of the object, with the special qualities of the Buddha, etc., as its object, by suppressing the defilements that are impediments to the going for refuge.

analyzed: icchitabba ttā lokiyam pana saraṇa gamanam puthujjanānam saraṇa gamana upakkilesa vikkhambhanena  ārammaṇataḥ buddha ādi guṇa ārammaṇam hutvā ijjhati tam atthataḥ buddha ādīsu vatthūsu sammāsambuddhaḥ
translated: In the case of the noble person it succeeds by way of the object, with the special qualities of the Buddha, etc., as its object, by suppressing the defilements that are impediments to the going for refuge.🔽In the case of the noble person it succeeds by way of the object, with the special qualities of the Buddha, etc., as its object, by suppressing the defilements that are impediments to the going for refuge.🔽In the case of the noble person it succeeds by way of the object, with the special qualities of the Buddha, etc., as its object, by suppressing the defilements that are impediments to the going for refuge.🔽In the case of the noble person it succeeds by way of the object, with the special qualities of the Buddha, etc., as its object, by suppressing the defilements that are impediments to the going for refuge.🔽In the case of the noble person it succeeds by way of the object, with the special qualities of the Buddha, etc., as its object, by suppressing the defilements that are impediments to the going for refuge.🔽In the case of the noble person it succeeds by way of the object, with the special qualities of the Buddha, etc., as its object, by suppressing the defilements that are impediments to the going for refuge.

original: bhagavā”tiādinā saddhāpaṭilābho yathāvuttasaddhāpubbaṅgamā ca sammādiṭṭhi, dasasu
analyzed: bhagavā ati ādinā saddhā paṭilābhaḥ yathā vutta saddhā pubbaṅgamā ca sammādiṭṭhi dasasu
translated: In the case of the noble person it succeeds by way of the object, with the special qualities of the Buddha, etc., as its object, by suppressing the defilements that are impediments to the going for refuge.

analyzed: puñña kiriya vatthūsu diṭṭhi ju kammanti vuccati ettha ca saddhā paṭilābhaḥ ti iminā 🔽mātā ādīhi ussāhita dāraka ādīnam viya ñāṇa vippayutta saraṇa gamanam dassitan ti veditabbam
translated: In the case of the noble person it succeeds by way of the object, with the special qualities of

original: “Sammādiṭṭhī”ti iminā pana ñāṇasampayuttaṃ saraṇagamanaṃ dassitaṃ buddhasubuddhataṃ
analyzed: sammādiṭṭhi iti iminā pana ñāṇa sampayuttam saraṇa gamanam dassitam buddha su buddha tam
translated: “Right view” shows the going for refuge associated with knowledge, because it sees the Buddha as a well-gone,

original: dhammasudhammataṃ saṅghasuppaṭipattiñca lokiyāvabodhavaseneva sammā ñāyena dassanato.
analyzed: dhamma su dhamma tam saṅgha suppaṭipattiñca lokiya avabodha vasena iva sammā ñāyena dassanato
translated: the Dhamma as a well-taught, and the Saṅgha as a well-practicing, by means of right knowledge in the sense of mundane understanding.

original: Tayidaṃ lokiyasaraṇagamanaṃ catudhā pavattati attasanniyyātanena tapparāyaṇatāya🔽sissabhāvūpagamanena paṇipātenāti. Tattha attasanniyyātanaṃ nāma “ajja ādiṃ katvā🔽ahaṃ attānaṃ buddhassa niyyātemi, dhammassa, saṅghassā”ti evaṃ buddhādīnaṃyeva saṃsāradukkhanittharaṇatthaṃ🔽attano attabhāvassa pariccajanaṃ. Tapparāyaṇatā nāma “ajja ādiṃ katvā ahaṃ buddhaparāyaṇo
analyzed: tayā idam lokiya saraṇa gamanam catudhā pavattati atta sanniyyātanena tad parāyaṇa tāya  sissa bhāva upagamanena paṇipātena ati tattha attasanniyyātanam nāma ajja ādim katvā  aham attānam buddhassa niyyātemi dhammassa saṅghassa ati evam buddha ādīnam yeva saṃsāra dukkha nittharaṇa ttham  attanaḥ atta bhāvassa pariccajanam tad parāyaṇa tā nāma ajja ādim katvā aham buddha parāyaṇaḥ
translated: This mundane going for refuge occurs in four ways: by surrendering oneself, by taking the Triple Gem as one’s refuge,🔽by becoming a disciple, and by paying homage. original: dhammaparāyaṇo saṅghaparāyaṇoti maṃ dhārethā”ti evaṃ tapparāyaṇabhāvo. Sissabhāvūpagamanaṃ
analyzed: dhamma parāyaṇo saṅgha parāyaṇaḥ iti mam dhāretha ati evam tad parāyaṇa bhāvaḥ sissa bhāva upagamanam
translated: Becoming a disciple is the state of becoming a disciple of the Buddha, Dhamma, and Saṅgha, saying: “From today onward, regard me as a disciple of the Buddha, Dhamma, and Saṅgha.”🔽Paying homage is the state of paying homage to the Triple Gem, saying: “From today onward, I pay homage to the Buddha, Dhamma, and Saṅgha.”

original: nāma “ajja ādiṃ katvā ‘ahaṃ buddhassa antevāsiko, dhammassa, saṅghassā’ti maṃ dhārethā”ti
analyzed: nāma ajja ādim katvā aham buddhassa antevāsikaḥ dhammassa saṅghassa ati mama dhāretha ati
translated: “From today let the venerable ones remember me as a lay follower who has gone to him for refuge for life.”🔽This is the way of going for refuge by undertaking the state of a disciple.

original: evaṃ sissabhāvūpagamo. Paṇipāto nāma “ajja ādiṃ katvā ‘ahaṃ abhivādanaṃ paccuṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: evam sissa bhāva upagamaḥ paṇipātaḥ nāma ajja ādim katvā aham abhivādanam paccuṭṭhānam
translated: The act of bowing down is the act of bowing down to the Buddha, Dhamma, and Sangha, saying:

original: añjalikammaṃ sāmīcikammaṃ buddhādīnaṃyeva tiṇṇaṃ vatthūnaṃ karomī’ti maṃ dhārethā”ti

original: caturāsītiyā kaññāsahassānaṃ caturāsītiyā pallaṅkasahassānaṃ caturāsītiyā vatthakoṭisahassānaṃ🔽aparimāṇassa ca khajjabhojjādibhedassa āhārassa pariccajanavasena sattamāsādhikāni
analyzed: caturāsītiyā kaññā sahassānam caturāsītiyā pallaṅka sahassānam caturāsītiyā vattha koṭi sahassānam  aparimāṇassa ca khajja bhojja ādi bhedassa āhārassa pariccajana vasena satta māsa adhikāni
translated: He gives away and gives up the four great continents and the seven treasures, the four kinds of gifts, the four kinds of bases of giving, and the four kinds of gifts given by the four kinds of bases of giving.🔽He gives away and gives up the four great continents and the seven treasures, the four kinds of gifts, the four kinds of bases of giving, and the four kinds of gifts given by the four kinds of bases of giving.🔽He gives away and gives up the four great continents and the seven treasures, the four kinds of gifts, the four kinds of bases of giving, the four kinds of gifts given by the four kinds of bases of giving, and the four kinds of gifts given by the four kinds of bases of giving.

original: satta saṃvaccharāni nirantaraṃ pavattavelāmamahādānato ekassa sotāpannassa dinnaṃ
analyzed: satta saṃvaccharāni nirantaram ekassa sotāpannassa dinnam
translated: He gives away and gives up the four great continents and the seven treasures, the four kinds of gifts, the four kinds of bases of giving, the four kinds of gifts given by the four kinds of bases of giving, and the four kinds of gifts given by the four kinds of bases of giving

original: mahapphalataraṃ, tato sataṃ sotāpannānaṃ dinnadānato ekassa sakadāgāmino, tato ekassa🔽anāgāmino, tato ekassa arahato, tato ekassa paccekasambuddhassa, tato sammāsambuddhassa,🔽tato buddhappamukhassa saṅghassa dinnadānaṃ mahapphalataraṃ, tato cātuddisaṃ saṅghaṃ
analyzed: mahapphalataram tatas satam sotāpannānam dinna dānataḥ ekassa sakadāgāmino tatas ekassa  anāgāminaḥ tatas ekassa arahataḥ tatas ekassa paccekasambuddhassa tatas sammāsambuddhassa  tatas buddha ppamukhassa saṅghassa dinna dānam mahapphalataram tatas cātuddisam saṅgham
translated: is of even greater fruit than that, than the gift given to a hundred Stream-Enterers, than the gift given to one Once-Returner, than the gift given to one Non-Returner, than the gift given to one Worthy One, than the gift given to one Independent Sambuddha, than the gift given to a Perfect Sambuddha,🔽than the gift given to the Community with the Buddha at its head, than the gift given to the Community of the four quarters,

original: uddissa vihārakaraṇaṃ, tato saraṇagamanaṃ mahapphalatara”nti pakāsitaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ –
analyzed: uddissa vihāra karaṇam tatas saraṇa gamanam mahapphalataranti pakāsitam vuttam ha etam
translated: and so on up to: “More fruitful than a gift to a hundred Stream-Enterers is a gift to a Once-Returner. More fruitful than a gift to a hundred Once-Returners is a gift to a Non-Returner. More fruitful than a gift to a hundred Non-Returners is a gift to an Arahant. More fruitful than a gift to a hundred Arahants is a gift to a Private Buddha. More fruitful than a gift to a hundred Private Buddhas is a gift to a Fully Enlightened Buddha. More fruitful than a gift to a hundred Fully Enlightened Buddhas is a gift to the Community headed by the Buddha. More fruitful than building a dwelling dedicated to the Community of the four quarters is the going for refuge.” This is stated. For this is said:

original: “Yaṃ, gahapati, velāmo brāhmaṇo dānaṃ adāsi mahādānaṃ, yo cekaṃ diṭṭhisampannaṃ bhojeyya, idaṃ tato mahapphalatara”nti –
analyzed: yam gahapati velāmaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ dānam adāsi mahā dānam yaḥ ca ekam diṭṭhi sampannam bhojeyya idam tatas mahapphalataranti
translated: “Householder, more fruitful than the great gift given by Velama the brahmin is a meal given to a single person accomplished in view” .

original: Ādi. Evaṃ saraṇagamanaphalaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ādi evam saraṇa gamana phalam veditabbam
translated: Thus the fruit of going for refuge should be understood.

original: Saraṇagamanaphalakathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: saraṇa gamana phala kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the fruit of going for refuge is ended.

original: Saraṇagamanasaṃkilesabhedakathā
analyzed: saraṇa gamana saṃkilesa bheda kathā
translated: 1.1. The explanation of the defilement and breach of going for refuge

original: Tattha ca lokiyasaraṇagamanaṃ tīsu vatthūsu aññāṇasaṃsayamicchāñāṇādīhi saṃkilissati,
analyzed: tattha ca lokiya saraṇa gamanam tīsu vatthūsu aññāṇa saṃsayam icchā ñāṇa ādīhi saṃkilissati
translated: Herein, mundane going for refuge is defiled by ignorance, doubt, wrong knowledge, etc., about the three objects of refuge,

original: na mahājutikaṃ, na ujjalaṃ aparisuddhaṃ apariyodātaṃ hoti, na mahāvipphāraṃ anuḷāraṃ.🔽Ettha ca aññāṇaṃ nāma vatthuttayassa guṇānaṃ ajānanaṃ tattha sammoho. “Buddho nu🔽kho, na nu kho”tiādinā vicikicchā saṃsayo. Micchāñāṇaṃ nāma tassa guṇānaṃ aguṇabhāvaparikappanena
analyzed: na mahā jutikam na ujjalam a parisuddham a pariyodātam hoti na mahā vipphāram anuḷāram  ettha ca aññāṇam nāma vatthuttayassa guṇānaṃ a jānanam tattha sammohaḥ buddhaḥ nu  kho na nu kho ti ādinā vicikicchā saṃsayaḥ micchāñāṇam nāma tassa guṇānaṃ aguṇa bhāva parikappanena
translated: It is not very brilliant, not very clear, not very pure, not very bright, not very extensive.

original: viparītaggāhoti veditabbaṃ. Lokuttarassa pana saraṇagamanassa natthi saṃkileso. Lokiyassa🔽ca saraṇagamanassa duvidho bhedo sāvajjo anavajjo ca. Tattha sāvajjo aññasatthārādīsu🔽attaniyyātanādīhi hoti, so aniṭṭhaphalo. Anavajjo pana kālakiriyāya hoti. Lokiyañhi
analyzed: viparīta ggāhaḥ ti veditabbam lokuttarassa pana saraṇa gamanassa natthi saṃkilesaḥ lokiyassa  ca saraṇa gamanassa duvidhaḥ bhedaḥ sāvajjaḥ anavajjaḥ ca tattha sāvajjaḥ añña satthārā ādīsu  atta niyyātana ādīhi hoti so aniṭṭha phalaḥ anavajjaḥ pana kāla kiriyāya hoti lokiyam hi
translated: Herein, not knowing is the delusion about the three objects, namely, the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha. “Is he a Buddha or is he not?” is doubt and uncertainty. Wrong knowing should be understood as the misapprehension of the opposite, by misapprehending the qualities as non-qualities. But the supramundane going for refuge has no defilements.

original: saraṇagamanaṃ sikkhāpadasamādānaṃ viya aggahitakālaparicchedakaṃ jīvitapariyantameva
analyzed: saraṇa gamanam sikkhāpada samādānam viya agga hita kāla paricchedakam jīvita pariyantam eva
translated: And the mundane going for refuge has two kinds of breaks: blameworthy and blameless. Herein, the blameworthy is by surrendering oneself to other teachers, etc.; it has an undesirable result. But the blameless is by death. For the mundane going for refuge, like the undertaking of the training precepts, has no time limit set for it; it lasts only as long as life does.

original: hoti, tasmā tassa khandhabhedena bhedo, so avipākattā aphalo. Lokuttarassa pana nevatthi
analyzed: hoti tasmā tassa khandha bhedena bhedaḥ so a vipāka ttā aphalaḥ lokuttarassa pana na iva atthi
translated: Therefore it is broken by the dissolution of the aggregates, but it has no result because it is not ripening. But the supramundane going for refuge has no break.

original: bhedo. Bhavantarepi hi ariyasāvako aññaṃ satthāraṃ na uddisatīti. Evaṃ saraṇagamanassa
analyzed: bhedaḥ bhavantare pi hi ariya sāvako aññam satthāram na uddisati iti evam saraṇa gamanassa
translated: for even a noble disciple in the interval does not acknowledge another teacher.🔽

original: saṃkileso ca bhedo ca veditabbo.
analyzed: saṃkilesaḥ ca bhedaḥ ca veditabbo
translated: and the breach. For even when he is still a worldling, a noble disciple does not take another teacher. This is how the defilement and the breach should be understood.

original: Kasmā panettha vodānaṃ na gahitaṃ, nanu vodānavibhāvanāpi tattha kosallāya hotīti?🔽Saccametaṃ, taṃ pana saṃkilesaggahaṇena atthato dīpitaṃ hotīti na gahitaṃ. Yāni hi🔽tesaṃ saṃkilesakāraṇāni aññāṇādīni, tesaṃ sabbena sabbaṃ anuppādanena uppannānañca
analyzed: kasmā pana ittha vodānam na gahitam nanu vodāna vibhāvanā api tattha kosallāya hoti iti  saccam etam tam pana saṃkilesa ggahaṇena atthataḥ dīpitam hoti iti na gahitam yāni hi  tesam saṃkilesa kāraṇāni aññāṇa ādīni tesam sabbena sabbam anuppādanena uppannānam ca
translated: Why is the cleansing not stated here? Is not the development of the cleansing also a means of skill?

original: pahānena vodānaṃ hotīti. Evamettha “saraṇaṃ saraṇagamana”ntiādīnaṃ papañco veditabbo.🔽Imassa pana yathāvuttapapañcassa idha avacane kāraṇaṃ dassento āha “so pana idha
analyzed: pahānena vodānam hoti iti evam ettha saraṇam saraṇa gamana nti ādīnam papañcaḥ veditabbo  imassa pana yathāvutta papañcassa idha avacane kāraṇam dassentaḥ āha saḥ pana idha
translated: That is so, but it is implied by the stating of the defilement, for the cleansing is effected by the complete abandonment of the defilements, such as ignorance, etc., and by the abandoning of those that have arisen. This is how the elaboration should be understood here.

original: vuccamāno”tiādi. Tattha saraṇavaṇṇanatoti sāmaññaphalasutte vuttasaraṇavaṇṇanato.
analyzed: vuccamānaḥ tiādi tattha saraṇa vaṇṇanato ti sāmaññaphala sutte vutta saraṇa vaṇṇanato
translated: Showing the reason for the statement of the above-mentioned elaboration here, he said, “But when it is stated here” and so on. Herein, because of the praise of the refuges means because of the praise of the refuges stated in the Sāmaññaphala Sutta .

original: Saraṇagamanasaṃkilesabhedakathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: saraṇa gamana saṃkilesa bheda kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the defilement and the breach of going for refuge is ended.

original: Upāsakattapaṭivedanākathā
analyzed: upāsaka atta paṭivedanā kathā
translated: The explanation of the announcement of the state of an upāsaka

original: Evaṃ dhāretūti evaṃ jānātūti attho. Ettha ko upāsakoti sarūpapucchā, tasmā kiṃlakkhaṇo🔽upāsakoti vuttaṃ hoti. Kasmāti hetupucchā. Tena kena pavattinimittena upāsakasaddo
analyzed: evam dhāretu uti evam jānātu uti attho ettha ko upāsakaḥ iti sarūpa pucchā tasmā kiṃlakkhaṇo  upāsakaḥ iti vuttam hoti kasmā ati hetu pucchā tena kena pavatti nimittena upāsaka saddaḥ
translated: “Let him bear it in mind” means “let him know it” . Herein, “who is a lay follower?” is a question about the individual essence. Therefore it is said, “What is the characteristic of a lay follower?”

original: tasmiṃ puggale niruḷhoti dasseti. Tenāha “kasmā upāsakoti vuccatī”ti. Saddassa hi🔽abhidheyyapavattinimittaṃ tadatthassa tabbhāvakāraṇaṃ. Kimassa sīlanti kīdisaṃ assa
analyzed: tasmin puggale niruḷhaḥ iti dasseti tena āha kasmai upāsakaḥ iti vuccati iti saddassa hi  abhidheyya pavatti nimittam tad atthassa tad bhāva kāraṇam kim assa sīlanti kīdisam assa
translated: “Why?” is a question about the cause. It shows the reason for the term “lay follower” to be applied to that person. Hence he said, “Why is he called a lay follower?”🔽For the reason for the occurrence of a term is the cause for the meaning of that term.

original: upāsakassa sīlaṃ, kittakena sīlenāyaṃ sīlasampanno nāma hotīti attho. Ko ājīvoti
analyzed: upāsakassa sīlam kittakena sīlena ayam sīla sampannaḥ nāma hoti iti ko ājīvo ti
translated: “What is his virtue?” means “What kind is his virtue? How much virtue does one have to have to be called ‘endowed with virtue’?”🔽“What is his livelihood?”

original: ko assa sammāājīvo. So pana micchājīvassa parivajjanena hotīti sopi vibhajīyati.
analyzed: kaḥ assa sammāājīvo saḥ pana micchājīvassa parivajjanena hoti iti saḥ api
translated: But that is only possible by avoiding wrong livelihood, so that is also analyzed.

original: Kā vipattīti kassa sīlassa ājīvassa vā vipatti. Anantarassa hi vidhi vā paṭisedho
analyzed: kā vipatti iti kassa sīlassa ājīvassa vā vipatti anantarassa hi vidhi vā paṭisedho
translated: “What is his failure?” is failure in what kind of virtue or livelihood? For there is either a method or a prohibition for what immediately follows.

original: vā. Sampattīti etthāpi eseva nayo.
analyzed: vā sampatti iti ettha api esā iva nayaḥ
translated: “What is his success?” is to be construed in the same way.🔽How is this to be understood as miscellaneous?

original: Idaṃ pakiṇṇakaṃ veditabbanti kathaṃ veditabbaṃ? Vuccate – ko upāsakoti khattiyādīsu
analyzed: idam pakiṇṇakam veditabbanti katham veditabbam vuccate  kaḥ upāsakaḥ iti khattiya ādīsu
translated: It is said: “Who is a lay follower?” is asked about the khattiya, etc.,

original: yo koci tisaraṇaṃ gato gahaṭṭho. Saraṇagamanameva hettha kāraṇaṃ, na jātiādiviseso.
analyzed: yaḥ koci ti saraṇam gataḥ gahaṭṭho saraṇa gamanam eva ha ittha kāraṇam na jāti ādi viseso
translated: Whoever has gone for refuge to the three is a lay follower. The going for refuge is the reason here, not a distinction of birth, etc.

original: Vuttañhetaṃ “yato kho, mahānāma, buddhaṃ saraṇaṃ gato hoti, dhammaṃ, saṅghaṃ saraṇaṃ
analyzed: vuttam ha etam yatas kho mahānāma buddham saraṇam gataḥ hoti dhammam saṅgham saraṇam
translated: For this is said: “When, Mahānāma, someone has gone for refuge to the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha,

original: gato hoti. Ettāvatā kho, mahānāma, upāsako hotī”ti.🔽Kasmā upāsakoti ratanattayaupāsanato. Teneva saraṇagamanena tattha ca sakkaccakiriyāya
analyzed: gataḥ hoti ettāvatā kho mahānāmaḥ upāsakaḥ hoti iti  kasmai upāsakaḥ iti tena iva saraṇa gamanena tattha ca sakkacca kiriyāya
translated: it is in this way that one becomes a lay follower” .🔽Why is he called a lay follower? Because he reveres the Triple Gem. By that going for refuge and by the performance of duties therein with devotion,

original: ādaragāravabahumānādiyogena payirupāsanatoti vuttaṃ hoti. So hi buddhaṃ upāsatīti
analyzed: ādara gārava bahu māna ādi yogena vuttam hoti saḥ hi buddham upāsati iti
translated: with the combination of respect, esteem, and reverence, etc., he reveres, thus he is a lay follower .

original: upāsako. Dhammaṃ, saṅghaṃ upāsatīti upāsako.🔽Kimassa sīlanti pañca veramaṇiyo. Veramaṇiyoti cettha veraṃ vuccati pāṇātipātādīsu
analyzed: upāsakaḥ dhammam saṅgham upāsati iti upāsakaḥ  kim assa sīlanti pañca veramaṇiyaḥ veramaṇiyaḥ ti ca ittha veram vuccati pāṇa atipāta ādīsu
translated: He reveres the Buddha, thus he is a lay follower. He reveres the Dhamma, he reveres the Saṅgha, thus he is a lay follower.

original: dussīlyaṃ, tassa mananato hananato vināsanato veramaṇiyo pañca viratiyo viratippadhānattā
analyzed: dussīlyam tassa mananataḥ hananataḥ vināsanataḥ veramaṇiyaḥ pañca viratiyaḥ virati ppadhāna ttā
translated: What is his virtue? The five abstinences. Herein, evil is called “abstinence” because it is abstained from, because it is shunned, because it is destroyed. The five kinds of non-abandonment are the virtue of that abstinence because of the pre-eminence of non-abandonment.

original: tassa sīlassa. Vuttañhetaṃ “yato kho, mahānāma, upāsako pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti,
analyzed: tassa sīlassa vuttam ha etam yatas kho mahānāmaḥ upāsakaḥ pāṇa atipātā paṭivirataḥ hoti
translated: For this is said: “When, Mahānāma, a lay follower abstains from the destruction of life …

original: adinnādānā, kāmesumicchācārā, musāvādā, surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭivirato hoti.
analyzed: a dinna ādānā kāmesumicchā ācārā musāvādā surā meraya majja pamāda ṭṭhānā paṭivirataḥ hoti
translated: he abstains from taking what is not given, from unchastity, from false speech, and from liquor, wine, and intoxicants, the basis for heedlessness.

original: Ettāvatā kho, mahānāma, upāsako sīlavā hotī”ti.
analyzed: ettāvatā kho mahānāmaḥ upāsakaḥ sīlavā hoti iti
translated: It is in this way, Mahānāma, that a lay follower is virtuous.”

original: Ko ājīvoti pañca micchāvaṇijjā pahāya dhammena samena jīvitakappanaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ
analyzed: kaḥ ājīvaḥ ti pañca micchā vaṇijjāḥ pahāya dhammena samena jīvita kappanam vuttam ha etam
translated: “What is right livelihood?”—Abandoning the five kinds of wrong livelihood, he makes his living by means that are in accordance with the Dhamma.🔽For it is said:

original: – “pañcimā, bhikkhave, vaṇijjā upāsakena akaraṇīyā. Katamā pañca? Satthavaṇijjā sattavaṇijjā
analyzed: pañcimā bhikkhave vaṇijjā upāsakena a karaṇīyā katamā pañca sattha vaṇijjā satta vaṇijjā
translated: “Bhikkhus, there are these five kinds of wrong livelihood by which a clansman makes his living. What five?🔽Trading in weapons, trading in living beings, trading in meat, trading in intoxicants, and trading in poisons.

original: maṃsavaṇijjā majjavaṇijjā visavaṇijjā. Imā kho, bhikkhave, pañca vaṇijjā upāsakena akaraṇīyā”ti.🔽Ettha ca satthavaṇijjāti āvudhabhaṇḍaṃ katvā vā kāretvā vā yathākataṃ vā paṭilabhitvā🔽tassa vikkayo. Sattavaṇijjāti manussavikkayo. Maṃsavaṇijjāti sūnakārādayo viya migasūkarādike
analyzed: maṃsa vaṇijjāḥ majja vaṇijjāḥ visa vaṇijjāḥ imāḥ kho bhikkhave pañca vaṇijjāḥ upāsakena a karaṇīyāḥ ati  ettha ca sattha vaṇij jāti āvudha bhaṇḍam katvā vā kāretvā vā yathākatam vā paṭilabhitvā  tassa vikkayaḥ satta vaṇijjā āti manussa vikkayaḥ maṃsa vaṇijjā āti sūnakāra ādayaḥ miga sūkara ādike
translated: These are the five kinds of wrong livelihood by which a clansman makes his living.🔽Herein, trading in weapons is either making weapons oneself or causing them to be made and then selling them, or dealing in weapons made by others.🔽Trading in living beings is buying and selling living beings after catching them oneself or causing them to be caught, or inducing others to catch them.

original: posetvā maṃsaṃ sampādetvā vikkayo. Majjavaṇijjāti yaṃ kiñci majjaṃ yojetvā tassa
analyzed: posetvā maṃsam sampādetvā vikkayaḥ majjavaṇijjāti yam kiñci majjam yojetvā tassa
translated: Trading in meat is either rearing cattle oneself or causing them to be reared, or inducing others to rear them, and then slaughtering them oneself or causing them to be slaughtered or inducing others to slaughter them, and then selling the meat; or dealing in meat after buying it.🔽Trading in intoxicants is either distilling arrack oneself or causing it to be distilled, or inducing others to distil it, and then selling it; or dealing in intoxicants after buying them.

original: vikkayo. Visavaṇijjāti visaṃ yojetvā saṅgahetvā vā tassa vikkayo. Tattha satthavaṇijjā
analyzed: vikkayaḥ visavaṇijjā ti visam yojetvā saṅgahetvā vā tassa vikkayaḥ tattha satthavaṇijjā
translated: Dealing in poison. Dealing in intoxicants: dealing in intoxicants by mixing them with other things or by storing them after having mixed them. Herein, dealing in weapons

original: paroparodhanimittatāya akaraṇīyā vuttā, sattavaṇijjā abhujissabhāvakaraṇato, maṃsavisavaṇijjā
analyzed: para uparodha nimitta tāya akaraṇīyā vuttā satta vaṇijjā abhujissa bhāva karaṇataḥ maṃsa visa vaṇijjā
translated: is said not to be done because it is a cause for harming others, dealing in living beings because it makes one a slave-owner, dealing in flesh

original: vadhahetuto, majjavaṇijjā pamādaṭṭhānatoti veditabbā.🔽Kā vipattīti yā tasseva sīlassa ca ājīvassa ca vipatti bhedo kopo pakopo ca, ayamassa
analyzed: vadha hetutaḥ majja vaṇijjā pamāda ṭṭhānato ti veditabbā  kā vipatti iti yā tassa iva sīlassa ca ājīvassa ca vipatti bhedaḥ kopaḥ pakopaḥ ca ayam assa
translated: because it is a cause for killing, and dealing in intoxicants because it is a cause for negligence.

original: vipatti. Apica yāya esa caṇḍālo ceva hoti malañca paṭikuṭṭho ca, sāpissa vipattīti
analyzed: vipatti apica yāya esa caṇḍālo ca iva hoti malaṃ ca paṭikuṭṭhaḥ ca sā apissa vipatti iti
translated: What is the failure? The failure, the breach, the transgression, the falling away, the deviation, the departure, the loss, the non-existence, the non- manifestation, the non-attainment, the non-realization of that virtue and that livelihood is the failure here. Moreover, the failure should be understood as that by which he becomes an outcast among the outcasts, a stain among the stains, a blot among the blots.

original: veditabbā. Te ca atthato assaddhiyādayo pañca dhammā honti. Yathāha –
analyzed: veditabbā te ca atthataḥ assaddhi ādayaḥ pañca dhammāḥ honti yathā āha
translated: And these are, in fact, the five states beginning with lack of faith, according as it is said:

original: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato upāsako upāsakacaṇḍālo ca hoti upāsakamalañca
analyzed: pañcahi bhikkhave dhammehi samannāgataḥ upāsakaḥ upāsaka caṇḍālo ca hoti upāsaka malam ca
translated: “Bhikkhus, a lay follower possessing five qualities is an outcast among lay followers, a stain of lay followers, a blot on lay followers.

original: upāsakapaṭikuṭṭho ca. Katamehi pañcahi? Assaddho hoti, dussīlo hoti, kotūhalamaṅgaliko
analyzed: upāsaka paṭikuṭṭho ca katamehi pañcahi assaddhaḥ hoti dussīlaḥ hoti kotūhala maṅgalikaḥ
translated: Possessing what five qualities? He is without faith, without moral shame, without moral dread, stingy, of deluded wisdom.

original: hoti, maṅgalaṃ pacceti, no kammaṃ, ito ca bahiddhā dakkhiṇeyyaṃ pariyesati, tattha🔽ca pubbakāraṃ karotī”ti.
analyzed: hoti maṅgalam pacceti no kammam itas ca bahiddhā dakkhiṇeyyam pariyesati tattha  ca pubba kāram karoti iti
translated: He is a low-down lay follower, he seeks for a field of merit outside, and he does it first.

original: Ettha ca upāsakapaṭikuṭṭhoti upāsakanihīno. Buddhādīsu kammakammaphalesu ca saddhāvipariyāyo
analyzed: ettha ca upāsaka paṭikuṭṭhaḥ ti upāsaka nihīnaḥ buddha ādīsu kamma kamma phalesu ca saddhā vipariyāyaḥ
translated: And here the words “a low-down lay follower” mean a lay follower who is low down. Lack of faith is the opposite of faith in the Buddha, Dhamma, and Sangha and in action and ripening of action.

original: assaddhiyaṃ micchādhimokkho, yathāvuttena assaddhiyena samannāgato assaddho. Yathāvuttasīlavipattiājīvavipattivasena🔽dussīlo. “Iminā diṭṭhādinā idaṃ nāma maṅgalaṃ hotī”ti evaṃ bālajanaparikappitakotūhalasaṅkhātena
analyzed: assaddhiyam micchā adhimokkhaḥ yathāvuttena assaddhiyena samannāgataḥ assaddhaḥ yathāvutta sīla vipatti ājīva vipatti vasena  dussīlaḥ iminā diṭṭha ādinā idam nāma maṅgalam hoti iti evam bāla jana parikappita kotūhala saṅkhātena
translated: He is faithless because he possesses the faithlessness described in the way already stated. He is immoral because of the failure in virtue and the failure in livelihood described in the way already stated.

original: diṭṭhasutamutamaṅgalena samannāgato kotūhalamaṅgaliko. Maṅgalaṃ paccetīti diṭṭhamaṅgalādibhedaṃ🔽maṅgalameva pattiyāyati. No kammanti kammassakataṃ no pattiyāyati. Itobahiddhāti
analyzed: diṭṭha suta muta maṅgalena samannāgataḥ kotūhala maṅgalikaḥ maṅgalam pacceti iti diṭṭha maṅgala ādi bhedam  maṅgalam eva pattiyāyati no kammanti kammassakatam no pattiyāyati itobahiddhā ati
translated: He is one who makes a lucky throw his lucky throw because he possesses the lucky throw consisting of what is seen, heard, or sensed, which is a mere lucky throw imagined by foolish people thus: “This or that is a lucky thing because of this or that reason.”

original: ito sabbaññubuddhasāsanato bahiddhā bāhirakasamaye. Dakkhiṇeyyaṃ pariyesatīti duppaṭipannaṃ
analyzed: itas sabbaññu buddha sāsanataḥ bahiddhā bāhiraka samaye dakkhiṇeyyam pariyesati iti duppaṭipannam
translated: He makes a lucky throw his lucky throw: he makes a lucky throw the means of his salvation. He does not make action his lucky throw: he does not make action the means of his salvation. Outside here: outside this dispensation of the Buddha who possesses omniscience.🔽He seeks for a field of merit: he seeks for one who is well behaved.

original: dakkhiṇārahasaññī gavesati. Pubbakāraṃ karotīti dānamānanādikaṃ kusalakiriyaṃ paṭhamataraṃ
analyzed: dakkhiṇā raha saññī gavesati pubba kāram karoti iti dāna mānana ādikam kusala kiriyam paṭhamataram
translated: He seeks out those worthy of offerings. He does the preliminary service. He does the preliminary service of giving, honouring, etc., of wholesome action.

original: karoti. Ettha ca dakkhiṇeyyapaayesanapubbakāre ekaṃ katvā pañca dhammā veditabbā.
analyzed: karoti ettha ca dakkhiṇeyya paayesana pubbakāre ekam katvā pañca dhammā veditabbā
translated: And here the seeking out of those worthy of offerings and the doing of preliminary service should be understood as one thing, making five things in all.

original: Kā sampattīti sāva tassa sīlasampadā ca ājīvasampadā ca sampatti, ye cassa ratanabhāvādikarā saddhādayo pañca dhammā. Yathāha –
analyzed: kā sampatti iti sāva tassa sīla sampadā ca ājīva sampadā ca sampatti ye ca ssa ratana bhāva ādi karā saddhā ādayaḥ pañca dhammā yathā āha
translated: What are the gains? The gains are the fulfilment of virtue and the fulfilment of livelihood in the case of the disciple, and the five things beginning with faith that are the cause of his being a jewel, according as it is said:

original: “Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato upāsako upāsakaratanañca hoti upāsakapadumañca🔽upāsakapuṇḍarīko ca. Katamehi pañcahi? Saddho hoti, sīlavā hoti, na kotūhalamaṅgaliko
analyzed: pañcahi bhikkhave dhammehi samannāgataḥ upāsakaḥ upāsaka ratanam ca hoti upāsaka padumam ca  upāsaka puṇḍarīkaḥ ca katamehi pañcahi saddhaḥ hoti sīlavā hoti na kotūhala maṅgalikaḥ
translated: “Bhikkhus, a lay follower endowed with five qualities is a lay follower who is a jewel, a pearl, a gem, an ornament, a treasure.

original: hoti, kammaṃ pacceti, no maṅgalaṃ, na ito bahiddhā dakkhiṇeyyaṃ pariyesati, idha
analyzed: hoti kammam pacceti naḥ maṅgalam naḥ itas bahiddhā dakkhiṇeyyam pariyesati idha
translated: With what five? He has faith; he is virtuous; he is not a ritualist in respect of austerities; he is one who looks upon the action of giving as fruitful; he does not seek outside the true Dhamma for one more worthy of offerings than his own teacher.

original: ca pubbakāraṃ karotī”ti.
analyzed: ca pubba kāram karoti iti
translated: He does the preliminary service here” .

original: Ettha ca catunnampi parisānaṃ ratijananaṭṭhena upāsakova ratanaṃ upāsakaratanaṃ,
analyzed: ettha ca catunnam pi parisānam rati janana ṭṭhena upāsaka uva ratanam upāsaka ratanam
translated: And here, a lay follower is a jewel for lay followers because he causes delight in the four assemblies.

original: guṇasobhākittisaddasugandhatāhi upāsakova padumaṃ upāsakapadumaṃ, tathā upāsakapuṇḍarīko🔽ca veditabbo. Sesamettha vipattiyaṃ vuttavipariyāyena viññeyyaṃ. Evamidaṃ “ko upāsako”tiādikaṃ
analyzed: guṇa sobhā kitti sadda sugandha tāhi upāsaka uva padumam upāsaka padumam tathā upāsaka puṇḍarīkaḥ  ca veditabbo sesam ettha vipattiyam vutta vipariyāyena viññeyyam evam idam kaḥ upāsaka iti ādikam
translated: The lotus of the lay-follower is the lay-follower’s lotus. The white-water-lily of the lay-follower is the lay-follower’s white-water-lily. The rest here should be understood in the opposite sense to the failure stated.

original: pakiṇṇakaṃ vitthārato veditabbaṃ. Imassa pana pakiṇṇakassa idha vitthāretvā avacane
analyzed: pakiṇṇakam vitthārataḥ veditabbam imassa pana pakiṇṇakassa idha vitthāretvā avacane
translated: The lotus of the male lay follower is the male lay follower’s lotus. The white water lily of the male lay follower is the male lay follower’s white water lily. The rest should be understood in the opposite sense to the failure stated. This is how the miscellaneous section beginning “Who is a male lay follower?” should be understood in detail.

original: kāraṇaṃ dassento āha “taṃ atibhāriyakaraṇato”tiādi.🔽Ādimhīti ādiatthe. Koṭiyanti pariyantakoṭiyaṃ. Vihāraggenāti ovarakakoṭṭhāsena, “imasmiṃ
analyzed: kāraṇam dassentaḥ āha tam ati bhāriya karaṇatā itiādi  ādimhi iti ādi atthe pariyanta koṭiyam vihāra aggena ati ovaraka koṭṭhāsena imasmin
translated: The reason for not expounding this miscellaneous section here in detail is stated in the words “because it would make the book too large.”

original: gabbhe vasantānaṃ idaṃ panasaphalaṃ pāpuṇātī”tiādinā taṃtaṃvasanaṭṭhānakoṭṭhāsenāti🔽attho. Ajjatanti ajja icceva attho. Pāṇehi upetanti iminā tassa saraṇagamanassa āpāṇakoṭikataṃ
analyzed: gabbhe vasantānam idam panasa phalam pāpuṇāti itiādinā taṃ taṃ vasana ṭṭhāna koṭṭhāsena ati  attho ajjatanti ajja icca iva attho pāṇehi upetanti iminā tassa saraṇa gamanassa āpāṇa koṭi katam
translated: At the beginning: in the sense of “at the beginning.” At the end: at the end of the limit. In the cell: in the cell of the room. “Those who live in this cell will get this fruit” and so on. The meaning is: in the cell of the place of residence.

original: dassento “yāva me jīvitaṃ pavattatī”tiādīni vatvā puna jīvitenapahaṃ vatthuttayaṃ
analyzed: dassentaḥ yāva me jīvitam pavattati itiādīni vatvā puna
translated: Today: the meaning is: today itself. With life: showing that the going for refuge has the life as its limit, he says “as long as I live” and so on. Then he says “I go for refuge to the Buddha” and so on.

original: paṭipūjento saraṇagamanañca rakkhāmīti uppannaṃ tassa brāhmaṇassa adhippāyaṃ vibhāvento
analyzed: paṭipūjento saraṇa gamanañca rakkhāmi iti uppannam tassa brāhmaṇassa adhippāyam vibhāvento
translated: “I too” he said, explaining the intention that had arisen in the mind of that brāhmaṇa.

original: “ahañhī”tiādimāha. Pāṇehi upetanti hi yāva me pāṇā dharanti, tāva saraṇaṃ upetaṃ,
analyzed: ahañhi iti ādim āha pāṇehi hi yāva me pāṇāḥ dharanti tāva saraṇam upetam
translated: “I am gone for refuge” means: as long as my life lasts, I am gone for refuge,

original: upento na vācāmattena na ekavāraṃ cittuppādanamattena, atha kho pāṇānaṃ pariccajanavasena
analyzed: upentaḥ na vācā mattena na eka vāram citta uppādana mattena atha kho pāṇānam pariccajana vasena
translated: not merely by speech, not merely by the arising of the thought once, but rather by the relinquishing of life,

original: yāvajīvaṃ upetanti evamettha attho veditabbo.
analyzed: yāvajīvam upetan ti evam ettha atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: I am gone for refuge as long as life lasts. This is the meaning to be understood here.

original: Adhivāsetūti sādiyatu, taṃ pana sādiyanaṃ manasā sampaṭiggaho hotīti āha “sampaṭicchatū”ti.🔽Kāyaṅganti kāyameva aṅganti vadanti, kāyassa vā aṅgaṃ sīsādi kāyaṅgaṃ, sīsādi sarīrāvayavanti🔽vuttaṃ hoti. Vācaṅganti “hotu sādhū”ti evamādivācāya aṅgaṃ avayavaṃ. Vācaṅgassa copanaṃ
analyzed: adhivāsetu uti sādiyatu tam pana sādiyanam manasā sampaṭiggahaḥ hoti iti āha sampaṭicchatu uti  kāyaṅganti kāyam eva aṅganti vadanti kāyassa vā aṅgam sīsa ādi kāyaṅgam sīsa ādi sarīra avayavanti  vuttam hoti vācaṅganti hotu sādhu iti evamādi vācāya aṅgam avayavam vācaṅgassa copanam
translated: “May you accept” means: may you agree to it. But that agreement is the mental reception of it. Therefore he said: “May you consent.”

original: vācāya pavattanamevāti veditabbaṃ. Abbhantareyevāti attano cittasantāneyeva. Khantiṃ

original: cāretvāti khantiṃ pavattetvā, ruciṃ uppādetvāti vuttaṃ hoti. “Khantiṃ dhāretvā”tipi
analyzed: cāretvā iti khantim pavattetvā rucim uppādetvā iti vuttam hoti khantim dhāretvā atipi
translated: Having made him go forth: having caused him to enter into patience, having aroused his approval, is what is meant. There is also the reading “having borne patience,”

original: pāṭho, uppannaṃ ruciṃ abbhantareyeva dhāretvā vacībhedena apakāsetvāti vuttaṃ hoti.🔽Kathaṃ pana verañjo brāhmaṇo bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ aññāsi. Na hi tena sakkā bhagavato
analyzed: pāṭhaḥ uppannam rucim dhāretvā vacībhedena apakāsetvā iti vuttam hoti  katham pana verañjaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ bhagavataḥ adhivāsanam aññāsi na hi tena sakkā bhagavato
translated: which means: having borne the approval that has arisen within himself, having made it manifest by means of speech.🔽But how did the brahmin of Verañjā know that the Exalted One had consented? For he could not have known it by directly perceiving the occurrence of a thought in the Exalted One’s mind.

original: cittappavatti paccakkhato viññātuṃ, tasmā “bhagavato adhivāsanaṃ viditvā”ti kasmā
analyzed: citta ppavatti paccakkhataḥ viññātum tasmā bhagavataḥ adhivāsanam viditvā iti kasmā
translated: Therefore, why is it said that he “having known the Exalted One’s consent”?

original: vuttanti ce? Kiñcāpi tena na sakkā cittappavatti paccakkhato viññātuṃ, tathāpi ākārasallakkhaṇakusalatāya
analyzed: vuttam ti ce kiñcā api tena na sakkā citta ppavatti paccakkhataḥ viññātum tathā api ākāra sat lakkhaṇa kusala tāya
translated: Although he could not have known it by directly perceiving the occurrence of a thought in the Exalted One’s mind, still he knew it by inference through the method of positive and negative concomitance, showing that he was skilled in discerning the signs of thought.

original: anvayabyatirekavasena anumānato aññāsīti dassento āha “sace me samaṇo gotamo”tiādi.
analyzed: anvaya byatireka vasena anumānataḥ aññāsi iti dassentaḥ āha sace me samaṇaḥ gotama utiādi
translated: He said: “If the recluse Gotama” and so on.

original: Ākārasallakkhaṇakusalatāyāti cittappavattiākāravijānane chekatāya, adhippāyavijānane
analyzed: ākāra sallakkhaṇa kusala tāya ati citta ppavatti ākāra vijānane cheka tāya adhippāya vijānane
translated: Skilled in discerning the signs of thought: skilled in knowing the occurrence of a thought, skilled in discerning the intention,

original: kusalatāyāti vuttaṃ hoti. Dasanakhasamodhānasamujjalanti dvīsu hatthesu dasannaṃ
analyzed: kusala tāya iti vuttam hoti dasa nakha samodhāna samujjalanti dvīsu hatthesu
translated: is what is meant. The ten nails shining forth in the two hands: the ten nails of the two hands shining forth,

original: nakhānaṃ samodhānena ekībhāvena samujjalantaṃ. Añjalinti hatthapuṭaṃ. Paṭimukhoyevāti
analyzed: nakhānam samodhānena ekībhāvena samujjalantam añjalinti hattha puṭam
translated: and the fingers were extended in a straight line. The hollow of the hands: the hollow of the palms. Face to face:

original: abhimukhoyeva, na bhagavato piṭṭhiṃ dassetvāti attho. Vanditvāti pañcapatiṭṭhitena vanditvā.
analyzed: abhimukhaḥ yā iva na bhagavataḥ piṭṭhim dassetvā ati atthaḥ vanditvā iti pañca patiṭṭhitena vanditvā
translated: in front, not showing the back to the Blessed One, is the meaning. Having paid homage: having paid homage with the fivefold prostration.

original: Upāsakattapaṭivedanākathā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: upāsaka tta paṭivedanā kathā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Discussion of the Announcing of the Going Forth is finished.

original: Dubbhikkhakathā
analyzed: dubbhikkha kathā
translated: The Discussion of the Famine

original: 16. Susassakālepīti sampannasassakālepi. Atisamagghepīti atisayena appagghepi, yadā
analyzed: su sassa kāle iti sampanna sassa kāle atisamagghe iti atisayena appagghe pi yadā
translated: Even in a good harvest: even in a time of good harvest. Even in a time of plenty: even in a time of extreme plenty, when

original: kiñcideva datvā bahuṃ pubbaṇṇāparaṇṇaṃ gaṇhanti, tādise kālepīti attho. Sāliādi dhaññaṃ🔽pubbaṇṇaṃ, muggamāsādi aparaṇṇaṃ. Dvidhā pavattaṃ īhitaṃ etthāti dvīhitikāti majjhapadalopībāhiratthasamāsoyamīti
analyzed: kiñcid eva da tvā bahum pubbaṇṇa aparaṇṇam gaṇhanti tādise kāle pi iti sāli ādi dhaññam  pubbaṇṇam muggam āsa ādi aparaṇṇam dvidhā pavattam īhitam ettha ati dvīhitikā ati majjha pada lopī bāhirattha samāsaḥ yamī iti
translated: having given a little they take away much rice and curry, is the meaning. Rice, etc.,🔽is the first harvest; beans, etc., is the second harvest. It is called “a time of plenty” because it is sought after by the two harvests.

original: dassento āha “dvidhā pavattaīhitikā”ti. Īhanaṃ īhitanti īhitasaddoyaṃ bhāvasādhanoti
analyzed: dassentaḥ āha dvidhā pavatta īhitikā ati īhanam īhitam ti īhita saddaḥ yam bhāva sādhanaḥ ti
translated: Pointing out that this is a compound in which the middle term is elided and the last term is in the locative case, he said, “A time of plenty is a time of the two harvests.” The word īhita is derived from the verb īh, to seek.

original: āha “īhitaṃ nāma iriyā”ti. Tattha iriyāti kiriyā. Kassa panesā kiriyāti āha “cittairiyā”ti,
analyzed: āha īhitam nāma iriyā ti tattha iriyā ati kiriyā kassa pana esā kiriyā ti āha citta eriyā ti
translated: Therefore he said, “The seeking is the activity.” Here activity is the function. But whose function? The function of the mind, he said.

original: cittakiriyā cittappayogoti attho. Tenevāha “cittaīhā”ti. Kathaṃ panettha īhitassa
analyzed: citta kiriyā citta ppayogo ti attho tena iva āha citta īhā iti katham pana ittha īhitassa
translated: The meaning is: mental activity, mental exertion. Hence he said: “mental effort”.

original: dvidhā pavattīti āha “lacchāma nu kho”tiādi. Tattha lacchāma nu khoti idaṃ duggatānaṃ
analyzed: dvidhā pavatti iti āha lacchāma nu kho tiādi tattha lacchāma nu kho ti idam duggatānam
translated: But how does it occur in two ways here? He said: “Will we get … ?” etc. Herein, “Will we get” is said with reference to the unfortunate states of existence.

original: vasena vuttaṃ. Jīvituṃ vā sakkhissāma nu kho, noti idaṃ pana issarānaṃ vasena vuttanti
analyzed: vasena vuttam jīvitum vā sakkhissāma nu kho no ti idam pana issarānam vasena vuttanti
translated: “Or will we be able to live” is said with reference to the fortunate states of existence.

original: veditabbaṃ. Bhikkhamānāti yācamānā. “Duhitikā”tipi pāṭho. Tatthāpi vuttanayenevattho🔽veditabbo. Dvi-saddassa hi du-saddādesenāyaṃ niddeso hoti. Dukkhaṃ vā īhitaṃ ettha🔽na sakkā koci payogo sukhena kātunti duhitikā, dukkarajīvitappayogāti attho.
analyzed: veditabbam bhikkhamānā iti yācamānā duhitikā iti pi pāṭhaḥ tattha api vutta nayena iva atthaḥ  veditabbaḥ dvi saddassa hi du sadda ādesena ayam niddesaḥ hoti dukkham vā īhitam ettha  na sakkā koci payogaḥ sukhena kātunti duhitikā dukkara jīvita payogā ti attho
translated: “Begging for alms” means: asking for alms. The reading “duhitikā” is also correct. Herein, the meaning should be understood in the same way as stated above.🔽For this is the definition of the word “duhitikā” by the method of derivation from the word “dukkha” .🔽“Or, because of the word ‘du’ , the vowel ‘u’ of the word ‘dukkha’ is changed to ‘a’ , and the definition is: ‘duhitikā’ is by the method of derivation from the word ‘dvīhi’ .

original: Du-sadde vā ukārassa vakāraṃ katvā dvīhitikāti ayaṃ niddesoti āha “atha vā”tiādi.
analyzed: du sadde vā ukārassa vakāram katvā dvīhitikā ati ayam niddesaḥ iti āha atha vā atiādi
translated: “Or, alternatively” , etc.

original: Byādhi rogoti etāni “āturatā”ti imassa vevacanāni. Tena setaṭṭikā nāma ekā rogajātīti
analyzed: etāni ātura tā ati imassa vevacanāni tena setaṭṭikā nāma ekā roga jātī iti
translated: “Sickness” and “disease” are synonyms for “illness” . Therefore, “setaṭṭhikā” is a kind of disease.

original: dasseti. So pana rogo pāṇakadosena sambhavati. Eko kira pāṇako nāḷamajjhagataṃ gaṇṭhiṃ
analyzed: dasseti saḥ pana rogaḥ pāṇaka dosena sambhavati ekaḥ kira pāṇakaḥ nāḷa majjha gatam gaṇṭhim
translated: and that disease arises from the fault of the grain. It is said that a certain grain has a husk that splits open in the middle,

original: vijjhati, yena viddhattā nikkhantampi sālisīsaṃ khīraṃ gahetuṃ na sakkoti. Tenāha
analyzed: vijjhati yena viddhattā nikkhantam pi sāli sīsam khīram gahetum na sakkoti tena āha
translated: by which splitting the grain of rice, though it has come out, is unable to take up water. Hence it is said

original: “pacchinnakhīra”ntiādi.
translated: “rice that has no water.”

original: Vuttasassanti vapitasassaṃ. Tatthāti verañjāyaṃ. Salākāmattaṃ vuttaṃ etthāti salākāvuttā,
analyzed: vutta sassanti vapita sassam tattha ati verañjāyam salākā mattam vuttam ettha ati salākā vuttā
translated: “Sown crop”: crop that has been sown. “There”: in Verañjā. “The announcement of the bamboo staff” is what is said there.

original: purimapade uttarapadalopenāyaṃ niddeso. Tenāha “salākā eva sampajjatī”ti. Yaṃ tattha
analyzed: purima pade uttara pada lopena ayam niddeso tena āha salākā eva sampajjati iti yam tattha
translated: The demonstrative pronoun “that” in the first part of the compound is omitted in the second part. Hence it is said, “the announcement of the bamboo staff itself.” What is said there

original: vuttaṃ vāpitaṃ, taṃ salākāmattameva ahosi, phalaṃ na jāyatīti attho. Sampajjatīti
analyzed: vuttam vāpitam tam salākā mattam eva ahosi phalam na jāyati iti attho sampajjati iti
translated: is that the crop that was sown became only the announcement of the bamboo staff; it did not bear fruit, is the meaning. And by the word “itself”

original: ca iminā “salākāvuttā”ti etthāyaṃ vuttasaddo nipphattiatthoti dasseti. Salākāyāti
analyzed: ca iminā salākā vuttā ti ettha ayam vutta saddaḥ nipphatti attho ti dasseti salākāya āti
translated: in “the announcement of the bamboo staff itself,” it shows that the word “that” has the meaning of result. “The bamboo staff”

original: veḷuvilīvatālapaṇṇādīhi katasalākāya. Dhaññavikkayakānaṃ santikanti dhaññaṃ vikkiṇantīti
analyzed: veḷu vilīva tāla paṇṇa ādīhi kata salākāya dhañña vikkayakānam santikanti dhaññam vikkiṇanti iti
translated: is a bamboo staff made of leaves of the veḷu, vīraṇa, tāla, and other trees. “To the sellers of grain”: those who sell grain.

original: dhaññavikkayakā, tesaṃ samīpanti attho. Kayakesūti dhaññagaṇhanakesu. Kiṇitvāti gahetvā.
analyzed: dhañña vikkayakā tesam samīpanti attho kayakesu iti dhañña gaṇhanakesu kiṇitvā iti gahetvā
translated: The meaning is: near those who sell grain. In the grain-dealers’ means in those who gather grain. Having bought means having taken.

original: Dhaññakaraṇaṭṭhāneti koṭṭhāgārassa samīpaṭṭhāne, dhaññaminanaṭṭhāneti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: dhañña karaṇa ṭṭhāne ti koṭṭhāgārassa samīpa ṭṭhāne dhañña minana ṭṭhāne iti vuttam hoti
translated: In the grain-dealers’ place means in the vicinity of the granary, what is meant is: in the place where the grain is measured.

original: Vaṇṇajjhakkhanti kahāpaṇaparikkhakaṃ. Nasukarā uñchena paggahena yāpetunti paggayhatīti
analyzed: kahāpaṇa parikkhakam nasukarāḥ uñchena paggahena yāpetunti paggayhati iti
translated: A coloured cloak means a cloak with a border. They cannot live by gleaning and picking up what is dropped means

original: paggaho, patto. Tena paggahena pattenāti attho, pattaṃ gahetvā bhikkhācariyāya yāpetuṃ🔽na sakkāti vuttaṃ hoti. Tenevāha “paggahena yo uñcho”tiādi. Nasukarāti sukarabhāvo
analyzed: paggahaḥ pattaḥ tena paggahena pattena ati atthaḥ pattam gahetvā bhikkhā cariyāya yāpetum  na sakkā iti vuttam hoti tena iva āha paggahena yaḥ uñchaḥ iti ādi nasukarā iti sukara bhāvaḥ
translated: gleaning is picking up ,🔽what is meant is: they cannot live by going on alms round with a bowl,🔽therefore he said: “By gleaning and picking up what is dropped” and so on. They cannot live means they are not able to live.

original: ettha natthīti nasukarā. Piṇḍāya caritvāti piṇḍāya caraṇahetu. Hetuatthepi hi tvāsaddameke icchanti.
analyzed: ettha natthi iti nasukarā piṇḍāya caritvā ati piṇḍāya caraṇa hetu hetu atthe pi hi tvāsaddam eke icchanti
translated: They have come on alms round means because of going on alms round.🔽Some people want to take tvā as having the meaning of cause.

original: Uttarāpathato āgatā, uttarāpatho vā nivāso etesanti uttarāpathakāti vattabbe niruttinayena
analyzed: uttarāpathataḥ āgatāḥ uttarāpathaḥ vā nivāsaḥ etesan ti uttarāpathakā ati vattabbe nirutti nayena
translated: They have come from the northern region, or their dwelling place is the northern region, therefore they should be called northerners, but because of the method of expression

original: “uttarāhakā”ti vuttaṃ. Tenāha “uttarāpathavāsikā”tiādi. “Uttarāpathakā”icceva vā
analyzed: uttarāhakā iti vuttam tena āha uttarāpatha vāsika atiādi vā
translated: “Uttarāhakas” is said. Hence he said “inhabitants of the northern countries” and so on. Or the reading “Uttarāpaṭhakā” should be understood.

original: pāḷipāṭho veditabbo. Keci pana “uttaraṃ visiṭṭhaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ āharantīti uttarāhakā,
analyzed: pāḷi pāṭhaḥ veditabbaḥ keci pana uttaram visiṭṭham bhaṇḍam āharanti iti uttarāhakāḥ
translated: But some explain the meaning in a different way: “They bring in goods from the northern countries, thus they are Uttarāhakas;

original: uttaraṃ vā adhikaṃ agghaṃ nentīti uttarāhakā”tiādinā aññena pakārena atthaṃ vaṇṇayanti.🔽Assānaṃ uṭṭhānaṭṭhāneti assānaṃ ākaraṭṭhāne. Verañjanti verañjāyaṃ. Bhummatthe hetaṃ
analyzed: uttaram vā adhikam aggham nenti iti uttarāhaka ati ādinā aññena pakārena attham vaṇṇayanti  assānam uṭṭhāna ṭṭhāne iti assānam ākara ṭṭhāne verañjanti verañjāyam bhummatthe
translated: or they send up the price of goods to the northern countries, thus they are Uttarāhakas.”🔽“The place where the horses were tethered”: the place where the horses were kept. “In Verañjā”: this is a locative of place.

original: upayogavacanaṃ. Mandiranti assasālaṃ. Assamaṇḍalikāyoti paññāyiṃsūti parimaṇḍalākārena
analyzed: upayoga vacanam mandiram ti assa sālam assa maṇḍalikāyaḥ ti paññāyiṃsu iti parimaṇḍala ākārena
translated: The word “place” is used in the sense of location. “The horse-grove”: the grove of horses. “They were known as the horse-walkers”: because they were made in the form of a circle,

original: katattā assamaṇḍalikāyoti pākaṭā ahesuṃ. Evaṃ katānañca assasālānaṃ bahuttā bahuvacananiddeso
analyzed: kata ttāḥ assa maṇḍalikāyaḥ ti pākaṭāḥ ahesuṃ evam katānam ca assa sālānam bahu ttā bahuvacana niddeso
translated: they were well known as the horse-walkers. And because there were many such horse-groves, the plural

original: kato. Dasannaṃ dasannaṃ assānaṃ vasanokāso ekekā assamaṇḍalikātipi vadanti. Addhānakkhamā
analyzed: kataḥ dasannam dasannam assānam vasanokāsaḥ ekekāḥ vadanti addhānakkhamā
translated: form “assamaṇḍalikāyo” is used. They say that each horse-grove was the dwelling place of ten horses.

original: na hontīti dīghakālaṃ pavattetuṃ khamā na honti, na cirakālappavattinoti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: na honti iti dīgha kālam pavattetum khamāḥ na honti na cira kāla ppavattinaḥ iti vuttam hoti
translated: “They were not enduring”: they were not enduring in the sense of lasting for a long time; they were not lasting for a long time, is what is meant.

original: Gaṅgāya dakkhiṇā disā appatirūpadeso, uttarā disā patirūpadesoti adhippāyenāha “na🔽hi te”tiādi. Gaṅgāya dakkhiṇatīrajātā dakkhiṇāpathamanussā. “Amhākaṃ buddho”ti evaṃ
analyzed: gaṅgāya dakkhiṇā disā appatirūpadesaḥ uttarā disā patirūpadesaḥ ti adhippāyena āha na  hi ta itiādi gaṅgāya dakkhiṇa tīra jātāḥ dakkhiṇāpatha manussāḥ amhākam buddhaḥ ti evam
translated: The meaning intended is that the southern side of the Ganges is an unsuitable region, the northern side a suitable region.🔽The people of the southern region are born on the southern side of the Ganges.🔽They are called “mine-Buddhas” because they think “Our Buddha.”

original: buddhaṃ mamāyantīti buddhamāmakā. Evaṃ sesesupi. Paṭiyādetunti sampādetuṃ. Niccabhattasaṅkhepenāti
analyzed: buddham mamāyanti iti buddha māmakāḥ evam sesesu pi paṭiyādetum ti sampādetum nicca bhatta saṅkhepena ati
translated: The same method applies to the rest.🔽To prepare: to make.🔽By way of a regular meal:

original: niccabhattākārena. Pubbaṇhasamayanti idaṃ bhummatthe upayogavacananti āha “pubbaṇhasamayeti🔽attho”ti. Accantasaṃyoge vā idaṃ upayogavacananti dassetuṃ yathā accantasaṃyogattho
analyzed: nicca bhatta ākārena pubbaṇha samayanti idam bhumma tthe upayoga vacananti āha pubbaṇha samaya iti  atthaḥ iti acc anta saṃyoge vā idam upayoga vacanan ti dassetum yathā
translated: The meaning is “in the morning.”🔽Or this expression of use is to show that it has the meaning of complete connection.🔽To show the meaning as it occurs, he says, “Or in the morning.”

original: sambhavati, tathā atthaṃ dassento āha “pubbaṇhe vā samaya”ntiādi. Evanti evaṃ pacchā🔽vuttanayena atthe vuccamāne. Nanu ca vihāre nisīdantāpi antaravāsakaṃ nivāsetvāva
analyzed: sambhavati tathā attham dassentaḥ āha pubbaṇhe vā evam ti evam pacchā 🔽vutta nayena atthe vuccamāne nanu ca vihāre nisīdantā api antaravāsakam
translated: Thus: in this way, when the meaning is being spoken of in the way stated later.🔽But don’t they also sit in the monastery after putting on the sarong?

original: nisīdanti, tasmā “nivāsetvā”ti idaṃ kasmā vuttanti āha “vihāranivāsanaparivattanavasenā”tiādi.🔽Vihāranivāsanaparivattanañca vihāre nisinnakāle nivatthampi puna gāmappavesanasamaye
analyzed: nisīdanti tasmai nivāsetvā iti idam kasmai vuttanti āha vihāra nivāsana parivattana vasena atiādi  vihāra nivāsana parivattanam ca vihāre nisinna kāle puna gāma ppavesana samaye
translated: Why is it said “having dressed”? He says “by way of the change of dwelling and dress” and so on.

original: cāletvā ito cito ca saṇṭhapetvā sakkaccaṃ nivāsanamevāti veditabbaṃ. Tenevāha “na
analyzed: cāletvā itas citas ca saṇṭhapetvā sakkaccam nivāsanam eva ati veditabbam tena iva āha na
translated: And the change of dwelling and dress should be understood as the dressing again after sitting in the dwelling, and the shaking out and re-arranging here and there of the dress when entering the village again.

original: hi te tato pubbe anivatthā ahesu”nti. Pattacīvaramādāyāti pattañca cīvarañca gahetvā.
analyzed: hi te tatas pubbe anivatthāḥ ahesunti patta cīvaram ādāya ati pattañca cīvarañca gahetvā
translated: Therefore he says, “for they were not undressed before that” . Taking bowl and robe: taking the bowl and the robe.

original: Gahaṇañcettha na kevalaṃ hattheneva, atha kho yena kenaci ākārena dhāraṇamevāti dassento
analyzed: gahaṇam ca ittha na kevalam hatthena iva atha kho yena kenacid ākārena dhāraṇam eva ati dassento
translated: Here the taking is not only by the hand, but it shows that it is the mere carrying by some means or other.

original: yathāsambhavamatthayojanaṃ karoti “pattaṃ hatthehī”tiādinā.
analyzed: yathāsambhavam attha yojanam karoti pattam hatthehi itiādinā
translated: Therefore he gives the explanation according to the circumstances, beginning with “the bowl in the hand” .

original: Gatagataṭṭhāneti assamaṇḍalikāsu sampattasampattaṭṭhāne. Udukkhale koṭṭetvā koṭṭetvā
analyzed: gata gata ṭṭhāne iti assa maṇḍalikāsu sampatta sampatta ṭṭhāne udukkhale koṭṭetvā koṭṭetvā
translated: In the places they had reached: in the places they had arrived at in the hermitages. Having pounded it in the mortar and pounded it,

original: paribhuñjantīti ettha kasmā pana te bhikkhū sayameva evaṃ katvā paribhuñjanti, kimevaṃ
analyzed: paribhuñjanti iti ettha kasmai pana te bhikkhū sayam eva evam katvā paribhuñjanti kim evam
translated: they ate it. Why did those bhikkhus eat it after doing it themselves in this way? What did they do?

original: laddhaṃ kappiyakārakehi yāguṃ vā bhattaṃ vā pacāpetvā sayaṃ vā pacitvā paribhuñjituṃ
analyzed: laddham kappiya kārakehi yāgum vā bhattam vā pacāpetvā sayam vā pacitvā paribhuñjitum
translated: and he says that it is not allowable to cook the rice gruel or rice obtained from those who do the work of preparation and then to eat it oneself.

original: na vaṭṭatīti āha “therānaṃ koci kappiyakārako natthī”tiādi. Kappiyākappiyabhāvaṃ🔽anapekkhitvā bhikkhūnaṃ evaṃ kātuṃ sāruppaṃ na hotīti vatvā puna akappiyabhāvampi
analyzed: na vaṭṭati iti āha therānam koci kappiya kārakaḥ natthi itiādi kappiya akappiya bhāvam  an apekkhitvā bhikkhūnam evam kātum sāruppam na hoti iti vatvā puna a kappiya bhāvam pi
translated: “There is no one to do the work of preparation for the elder bhikkhus.”🔽He says that it is not proper for bhikkhus to do this without regard to what is allowable and what is not.🔽Then, showing also the unallowable nature of it, he says, “It is not allowable.”

original: dassento āha “na ca vaṭṭatī”ti. Bhājanādipariharaṇavasena bahubhaṇḍikatāya abhāvato
analyzed: dassentaḥ āha na ca vaṭṭati iti bhājana ādi pariharaṇa vasena bahu bhaṇḍika tāya abhāvato
translated: Because they have no many requisites such as bowls, etc., to look after,

original: vuttaṃ “sallahukavuttitā”ti. Sakaṃ sakaṃ paṭivīsanti attano attano koṭṭhāsaṃ. Appossukkāti🔽samaṇadhammato aññattha nirussāhā. Tadupiyanti tadanurūpaṃ. Pisatīti cuṇṇeti. Puññañāṇavisesehi
analyzed: vuttam sat lahuka vutti tā ti sakam sakam paṭivīsanti attanaḥ attanaḥ koṭṭhāsam appossukkā ati  samaṇa dhammataḥ aññattha nirussāhā tat upiyanti tad anurūpam pisati iti cuṇṇā iti puññañāṇa visesehi
translated: he says, “They are of simple livelihood.” “Their own share” means their own portion.🔽“Not occupied” means not occupied with anything else than the ascetic’s duties.🔽“In accordance with that” means in accordance with that .🔽“They grind” means they pound.

original: kattabbakammassa manāpatā hotīti āha “puññavatā”tiādi. Nanti naṃ patthapulakaṃ. “Na
analyzed: kattabba kammassa manāpa tā hoti iti āha puññavatā atiādi nanti naṃ pattha pulakam na
translated: “They are pleasing to the mind in the matter of the duties to be done by means of the special qualities of merit and knowledge” .🔽“The one who is so” means the one who is so, i.e., the bhikkhu who is a forest-dweller.

original: tato paṭṭhāyā”ti vacanato tato pubbe bhagavato piṇḍāya caraṇampi dassitanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: tatas paṭṭhāya ati vacanato tatas pubbe bhagavataḥ piṇḍāya caraṇam pi dassitanti veditabbam
translated: “From then on” means from then on. It should be understood that the Blessed One’s alms round is shown by the words “From then on.”

original: Laddhāti labhitvā. “Laddho”ti vā pāṭho, upaṭṭhākaṭṭhānaṃ neva laddhoti attho. Kadā
analyzed: laddhā iti labhitvā laddhaḥ iti vā pāṭhaḥ upaṭṭhāka ṭṭhānam na iva laddhaḥ iti attho kadā
translated: Having received: having obtained. Or the reading is “received” , the meaning being that he did not receive the position of attendant.

original: pana thero upaṭṭhākaṭṭhānaṃ laddhoti? Vuccate – ekadā kira bhagavā nāgasamālattherena🔽saddhiṃ addhānamaggappaṭipanno dvedhāpathaṃ patto. Thero maggā ukkamma “bhagavā ahaṃ
analyzed: pana thero upaṭṭhāka ṭṭhānam laddhaḥ ti vuccate ekadā kira bhagavā nāgasamāla therena  saddhim addhāna magga ppaṭipannaḥ dvedhāpatham pattaḥ theraḥ maggāḥ ukkamma bhagavā aham
translated: But when did the Elder receive the position of attendant? It is said: once the Blessed One was travelling along the highway with the Elder Nāgasamāla.🔽When they came to a fork in the road, the Elder stepped off the path and said, “I will go by this road, Blessed One.”

original: iminā maggena gacchāmī”ti āha. Atha naṃ bhagavā “ehi bhikkhu, iminā gacchāmā”ti āha.
analyzed: iminā maggena gacchāmi iti āha atha nam bhagavā ehi bhikkhu iminā gacchāma ati āha
translated: The Blessed One said, “Come, bhikkhu, let us go by this road.”

original: So “handa bhagavā tumhākaṃ pattacīvaraṃ gaṇhatha, ahaṃ iminā gacchāmī”ti vatvā pattacīvaraṃ
analyzed: saḥ handa bhagavā tumhākam patta cīvaram gaṇhatha aham iminā gacchāmi iti vatvā patta cīvaram
translated: The Elder said, “Very well, Blessed One, you take your bowl and robe, I will go by this road.” And he began to put the bowl and robe on the ground.

original: chamāyaṃ ṭhapetuṃ āraddho. Atha bhagavā “āhara bhikkhū”ti vatvā pattacīvaraṃ gahetvā
analyzed: chamāyam ṭhapetum āraddhaḥ atha bhagavā āhara bhikkhū iti vatvā patta cīvaram gahetvā
translated: Then the Blessed One said, “Bring them, bhikkhu,” and taking the bowl and robe, he went on.

original: gato. Tassapi bhikkhuno itarena maggena gacchato corā pattacīvarañceva hariṃsu, sīsañca
analyzed: gataḥ tassa api bhikkhuno itarena maggena gacchataḥ corā patta cīvaram ca iva hariṃsu sīsam ca
translated: As the other bhikkhu went by the other road, thieves stripped him of his bowl and robe and broke his head open.

original: bhindiṃsu. So “bhagavā dāni me paṭisaraṇaṃ, na añño”ti cintetvā lohitena gaḷantena
analyzed: bhindiṃsu saḥ bhagavā dāni me paṭisaraṇam na cintetvā lohitena gaḷantena
translated: He thought, “Now the Blessed One is my refuge, not anyone else.” With his throat parched with blood,

original: bhagavato santikaṃ āgami. “Kimidaṃ bhikkhū”ti ca vutte taṃ pavattiṃ ārocesi. Atha
analyzed: bhagavatoḥ santikam āgami kim idam bhikkhu iti ca vutte tam pavattim ārocesi atha
translated: and came to the Blessed One. “What is this, monks?” he said. When they told him what had happened,

original: naṃ bhagavā “mā cintayi bhikkhu, etaṃ kāraṇaṃyeva te nivārayimhā”ti vatvā samassāsesi.
analyzed: nam bhagavā mā cintayi bhikkhu etam kāraṇaṃ yā iva te nivārayimha ati vatvā samassāsesi
translated: he said: “Do not worry, monk. It was for this very reason that I prevented you.”

original: Ekadā pana bhagavā meghiyattherena saddhiṃ pācīnavaṃsamigadāye jantugāmaṃ agamāsi.
analyzed: ekadā pana bhagavā meghiya ttherena saddhim jantu gāmam agamāsi
translated: And on another occasion the Blessed One went with the Elder Meghiya to Jantugāma in the eastern hills.

original: Tatrāpi meghiyo jantugāme piṇḍāya caritvā nadītīre pāsādikaṃ ambavanaṃ disvā “bhagavā
analyzed: tatra api meghiyaḥ jantugāme piṇḍāya caritvā nadī tīre pāsādikam ambavanam disvā bhagavā
translated: There Meghiya went for alms in Jantugāma, and when he had finished his alms round he saw a delightful mango grove by the river. He thought, “If the Blessed One would allow me, I would do the ascetic’s duties in this mango grove.”

original: tumhākaṃ pattacīvaraṃ gaṇhatha, ahaṃ etasmiṃ ambavane samaṇadhammaṃ karomī”ti vatvā
analyzed: tumhākam patta cīvaram gaṇhatha aham etasmin ambavane samaṇa dhammam karomi iti vatvā
translated: So he said to the Blessed One, “Venerable sir, let me take your bowl and robe. I will do the ascetic’s duties in this mango grove.”

original: bhagavatā tikkhattuṃ nivāriyamānopi gantvā akusalavitakkehi anvāsatto paccāgantvā
analyzed: bhagavatā tikkhattum nivāriyamānaḥ api gantvā akusala vitakkehi anvāsattaḥ paccāgantvā
translated: Although the Blessed One prevented him three times, Meghiya went and was overcome by unwholesome thoughts. He returned and told the Blessed One what had happened.

original: taṃ pavattiṃ ārocesi. Tampi bhagavā “idameva te kāraṇaṃ sallakkhayitvā nivārayimhā”ti
analyzed: tam pavattim ārocesi tam pi bhagavā idam eva te kāraṇam sallakkhayitvā nivārayimha ati
translated: The Blessed One said, “It was for this very reason that I prevented you,”

original: vatvā anupubbena sāvatthiṃ agamāsi. Tattha gandhakuṭipariveṇe paññattavarabuddhāsane
analyzed: vatvā anupubbena sāvatthim agamāsi tattha gandhakuṭi pariveṇe paññatta vara buddha āsane
translated: and he eventually went to Sāvatthī. There he sat down on the excellent seat prepared for him in the Fragrant Cottage in the cloister of the Resting Place for the Elders.

original: nisinno bhikkhusaṅghaparivuto bhikkhū āmantesi – “bhikkhave, idānimhi mahallako,
analyzed: nisinnaḥ bhikkhu saṅgha parivutaḥ bhikkhū āmantesi bhikkhave idānimhi mahallakaḥ
translated: and he sat down surrounded by the Community of monks. He addressed the monks: “Monks, now I am old,

original: ekacce bhikkhū ‘iminā maggena gacchāmā’ti vutte aññena gacchanti, ekacce mayhaṃ pattacīvaraṃ🔽bhūmiyaṃ nikkhipanti, mayhaṃ nibaddhupaṭṭhākaṃ bhikkhuṃ jānāthā”ti. Bhikkhūnaṃ dhammasaṃvego
analyzed: ekacce bhikkhū iminā maggena gacchāma ati vutte aññena gacchanti ekacce mayham patta cīvaram  bhūmiyam nikkhipanti mayham nibaddha upaṭṭhākam bhikkhum jānātha ati bhikkhūnam dhamma saṃvegaḥ

analyzed: patthayamānaḥ sata sahassa kappa adhikam asaṅkhyeyyam pāramiyaḥ pūresim nanu mādisaḥ mahā pañño

analyzed: na me tayā upaṭṭhāka kiccam atthi iti paṭikkhipi etena iva upāyena mahāmoggallānam ādim
